Response Message: Subject: Patient Presentation - Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: This is a case presentation of Mr. John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian man who has presented with symptoms suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism.   History of Present Illness: Mr. Doe reported sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain this morning that worsens upon deep inhalation. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  coughing  sweating  and bluish coloration of the skin and lips. He also mentioned having been experiencing periods of lightheadedness and palpitations for the past week.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are well-controlled with medication. He is a current smoker with a 30-pack year history. He also had an open reduction and internal fixation for a right hip fracture six weeks ago after a fall at his construction job. Postoperatively  he had a significant period of immobility due to pain and was partially non-compliant with physiotherapy. He denied history of any similar episodes in the past. He has no known drug allergies.  Current Medications: 1. Lisinopril 20 mg once daily for hypertension 2. Atorvastatin 40 mg at bedtime for hyperlipidemia   Family History: Mr. Doe's father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 75. His mother has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus but no history of blood clots or genetic diseases.  These symptoms combined with his recent major surgery and extended immobilization  his smoking history  and positive family history of cardiovascular disease place Mr. Doe at a high risk of having an Acute Pulmonary Embolism. Immediate steps will be taken to confirm diagnosis and start appropriate management.

Title: Presentation of Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 65-year-old Female Patient  I. Demographic Information  Patient Name: Ms. Susan Thompson Age: 65 Sex: Female DOB: February 2  1956 Race: Caucasian Marital Status: Widow Occupation: Retired Teacher  II. Chief Complaint  The patient presents to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that has been worsening over the past several hours. She describes the pain as a ""sharp  stabbing"" pain that increases with deep inhalation.  III. Relevant Medical History   Ms. Thompson has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which is controlled with daily use of Lisinopril. In addition  she has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago  for which she was treated with warfarin for 6 months. She has been off anticoagulant therapy since then. She is also a former smoker with a 20 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking after her DVT diagnosis.  IV. Recent Activity and Lifestyle  Ms. Thompson is recently post-operative from a total hip replacement surgery two weeks ago. She has been immobile at home during her recovery  doing minimal physical activity. She lives alone and is relatively sedentary even before her hip surgery. With the death of her husband 6 months ago  she reports periods of stress and anxiety.  V. Likely Diagnosis   The combination of her recent surgery  previous DVT  history of smoking  limited mobility  and her current symptoms (chest pain and acute onset of shortness of breath) points to a strong possibility of an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). Further diagnostic tests such as D-dimer  CT Pulmonary Angiogram  or V/Q scan should be pursued to confirm the diagnosis.  VI. Risk Factors  Risk factors in this patient include older age  personal history of DVT  recent orthopedic surgery  prolonged immobility  and history of smoking. While hypertension is not a direct risk factor for PE  it does contribute to overall cardiovascular risk.  VII. Conclusion  Management strategy will depend on confirmation of diagnosis and assessment of the severity of her disease. In the meantime  anticoagulant therapy should be initiated to prevent further clot formation and propagation. Patient education on lifestyle modifications  physical activities suitable for her condition  and the importance of medication adherence will further contribute to her long-term management.

Patient Presentation:  I am discussing Mr. James Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male who presents to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath  increased heart rate  sweating  and pain in the chest area  notably worse when taking deep breaths. Symptoms began approximately 6 hours ago and have progressively worsened.   He lives in Washington  D.C.  with his wife  and before retirement  he worked for a construction company. Mr. Johnson is a former smoker  with a 20-pack year history. He quit smoking ten years ago.  Our patient has a significant medical history of hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and type-2 diabetes  for which he takes Metformin  Lipitor  Metoprolol  and Aspirin daily. He had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left lower extremity about five years ago  which was successfully treated with anticoagulation therapy  but unfortunately didn't comply with the recommended lifestyle changes.  Family history includes his father  who died of myocardial infarction at an early age  and his mother  who is alive and well.  He denies any recent long-distance travel  trauma  surgeries  or significant change in activity level. His pain scores 7 on a 10-point scale. His body mass index (BMI) is 31  indicating obesity  which may have contributed to the thrombus formation.   On physical examination  he appears anxious. Vital signs measurements are as follows: Blood pressure is 155/95 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 26 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 89% on room air. Auscultation reveals tachycardia and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. Lower limb examination reveals no signs of deep vein thrombosis.  Given his previous history of DVT  current presentation  and risk factors  there is a high suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism. We will admit Mr. Johnson to the ICU for further evaluation and treatment as necessary.

Patient Presentation  Good day  everyone. I would like to introduce a patient with acute pulmonary embolism admitted to our department recently. The patient is a 63-year old Caucasian male named Mr. John Bryce. His BMI is 27  putting him slightly in the overweight range.   Mr. Bryce presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset dyspnea  chest pain  and feelings of anxiety. The symptoms began two days ago  mildly and intermittently but progressively worsened which made him visit the hospital.   His past medical history is significant with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well-controlled on medication for the last 15 years. He had a deep vein thrombosis following cardiothoracic surgery for a coronary artery bypass graft in 2011. He is a former smoker  quitting in 2007 after a span of 20 years smoking history. Mr. Bryce lives alone and is retired  and his alcohol consumption is within the recommended limits. He has no known drug allergies.  On examination  Mr. Bryce was found to be tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His resting oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. He appeared anxious but was oriented to time  place  and person.  The diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was confirmed via helical computed tomography (CT) angiography which revealed a clot in the right pulmonary artery. Blood work showed an elevated D-dimer level of 1500 ng/mL (Normal value: ≤ 500 ng/mL) and a mildly elevated troponin level.  Overall  this patient  Mr. Bryce  being at a heightened risk due to past medical history of DVT and recent surgery  presented with classically acute onset of dyspnea and chest pain leading us to suspect acute pulmonary embolism. After a series of diagnostic tests  our suspicions were confirmed.  Later today  the medical team will discuss with Mr. Bryce the treatment options  including anticoagulant therapy and potentially thrombolytic therapy.  I will keep you all updated on his progress and the final treatment decision. Thank you.

Title: Case Presentation of Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Introduction: Patient Info: Mr. James Stevens  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented today with complaints consistent with acute pulmonary embolism.  Demographic Info: The patient lives in Seattle with his wife. He is a retired construction worker and has a 40-pack/year history of smoking  which he quit 5 years ago. He does not engage in any regular physical activity  follows a high-fat diet and consumes moderate amounts of alcohol. He has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Stevens has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been fairly well-managed with medication (Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively). He was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago after surgery for a broken femur which he sustained from a fall. He was maintained on Warfarin for DVT but stopped the medication a year ago of his own accord.  Presenting Symptoms: For the past 24 hours  Mr. Stevens has been experiencing increasingly severe shortness of breath  chest pain aggravated by deep inspiration and cough productive of pink-tinged frothy sputum. He also reported episodes of light-headedness  but no loss of consciousness.   In Delving further into his history  he mentioned a recent long drive (8 hours each way) to visit his daughter over the Thanksgiving holiday which could have contributed to prolonged immobility.   Based on his past medical history  current symptoms  and risk factors  an acute pulmonary embolism is highly suspected. The patient has been admitted for urgent further investigation and treatment.   It is crucial to educate the patient about the importance of medication adherence and lifestyle modifications to manage his multiple chronic conditions  and the potential consequences of untreated or sub-optimally treated DVT leading to life-threatening conditions like pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian female presenting with symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism. She complains of sudden onset of shortness of breath  harsh coughing and chest pain which seems to worsen with deep breathing. She also states that she experienced an episode of lightheadedness and palpitations earlier in the day.  Demographic Information:  The patient is a retired schoolteacher; she lives alone in an apartment in uptown with her pet dog. She is a non-smoker  rarely drinks alcohol and she maintains an active lifestyle which includes daily walks  and weekly yoga classes. She has a BMI of 24.3 which is within the healthy range.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension for which she has been on medication (metoprolol) for the past 8 years. She was hospitalized 2 months ago for a hip replacement surgery following a fall in her home. She also has a history of recurrent deep-vein thrombosis  and has been on long-term anticoagulation therapy (warfarin) for the same. Her family history reveals a maternal aunt had a PE in her latter years.

Patient Presentation:  We are discussing Mr. John Doe  a 69-year-old Caucasian male who has presented with symptoms indicative of an acute pulmonary embolism. Mr. Doe currently resides in Austin  Texas with his wife of 40 years. He is a retired police officer and non-smoker. His alcohol intake is minimal and he has no known drug allergies. Mr. Doe does not have a personal or family history of clotting disorders. He is fairly active and tries to maintain a healthy weight and lifestyle.   Regarding his past medical history  he was previously diagnosed with Stage II hypertension and he maintains it with prescription medication  Lisinopril. Also  he underwent a hip replacement surgery due to osteoarthritis two weeks ago. In addition to the hypertension and osteoarthritis  Mr. Doe has a controlled case of type II diabetes  which he manages with the help of metformin.   Today  Mr. Doe has presented in the emergency department with sharp  stabbing chest pain that started out of nowhere when he was gardening at home. He rated it as a severe 10/10 and described the pain as ""worse when taking a deep breath."" He reports additional symptoms of lightheadedness  rapid heart rate  uneasy feeling  and shortness of breath. Considering his recent surgery and his presenting complaints  we have a high clinical suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism. Further investigations including D-Dimer Test  imaging studies like CT Pulmonary Angiogram  and possibly an echocardiogram will be carried out to confirm the diagnosis and severity.  In conclusion  considering Mr. Doe's age  recent surgery  and signs and symptoms  pulmonary embolism may be the likely diagnosis. Immediate diagnostic tests will be ordered and he will be prepared for the necessary emergency treatment. As part of our differential diagnosis  we will also consider other conditions such as acute myocardial infarction and pneumothorax. A thorough examination and prompt treatment is crucial to improve the patient’s outcome.

Title: Case Presentation on Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: Patient's Name: John Doe Age: 55 years Gender: Male Occupation: Bank accountant Race: Caucasian Relative: Wife   Presenting Complaint: Mr. John Doe presented with acute shortness of breath  sharp chest pain exacerbated on inspiration  and palpitations. These symptoms started suddenly two hours prior to admission. John also reported feeling faint and dizzy with episodes of profuse sweating.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago. He also suffers from hypertension and hyperlipidemia managed by medications at regular intervals. The patient was a smoker for 25 years but quit five years ago. His father had a history of DVT and pulmonary embolism (PE).  Physical Examination: General examination revealed a breathless patient with a respiratory rate of 30 breaths/minute. His oxygen saturation was at 90% on room air. He had a pulse of 110 beats per minute and his blood pressure was 155/90 mmHg.   Investigations: A chest X-ray did not reveal any acute abnormality. However  due to clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism and risk factors  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was ordered.   In terms of blood investigations  a complete blood count  serum electrolytes  liver  and renal function tests were all within normal limits. D-dimer was elevated  further increasing the suspicion of PE.   Conclusion:  Based on the patient's history of DVT  current symptoms  and preliminary test results  this clinical scenario is highly suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism. The results of the CTPA would provide definitive diagnosis. Meanwhile  anticoagulation therapy was initiated to prevent further clot propagation. Should the diagnosis of PE be confirmed  further investigations would be required to identify the source of emboli  and long term anticoagulation therapy will continue to prevent recurrent PE instances.   Next Steps:  Mr. Doe has been admitted for close monitoring and appropriate Stabilisation of his acute condition. Confirmation of PE and further treatment plans will be executed promptly once we have the CTPA and other remaining investigations.

Patient Presentation:  Introduction: Today  I would like to discuss the case of Mr. John Wilson  a 75-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with symptoms indicative of acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Background Information: Mr. Wilson is a retired industrial worker  originally from Detroit  Michigan  is a non-smoker  and consumes alcohol occasionally. His BMI is 25.7  suggesting he is slightly overweight.  Past Medical History: In terms of past medical history  Mr. Wilson is a well-controlled hypertensive and has type II diabetes  for which he takes Metformin consistently. He was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) about three years ago  which was treated successfully with warfarin. He also has a significant history of hyperlipidemia. His family history reveals that both his parents died of cardiac diseases.  Presenting Complaints and Findings: Mr. Wilson presented to the ED with sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain that worsened upon deep inhalation  and mild cough with scanty hemoptysis for the past few hours. On examination  he had tachycardia and tachypnea. Auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds on the right side. Oxygen saturation was slightly low.   Blood Investigation: Lab investigations showed a slightly increase in his D-dimer levels  and his blood sugar and blood pressure were moderately elevated at the time of the assessment. An ECG showed signs of right ventricular strain with sinus tachycardia.  Conclusion: Considering Mr. Wilson's signs  symptoms  and past medical history of DVT  a likely diagnosis is acute pulmonary embolism. Further investigation with a CT pulmonary angiogram would be valuable for confirmation. Immediate administration of heparin should be considered for anticoagulation  and subsequent transition to long-term oral anticoagulation would be suggested  given his high risk due to his age  hypertension  diabetes  and history of DVT.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting with the sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and palpitations. His name is Mr. John Jones  and he lives with his wife in downtown San Diego  California. Mr. Jones is a retired engineer and an ex-smoker  having quit smoking five years ago after a 40-year smoking history.  Past Medical History:  In terms of his past medical history  Mr. Jones was diagnosed with type-2 diabetes twenty years ago  which he manages with metformin and lifestyle adjustments. He also suffered a myocardial infarction seven years ago  and is on aspirin and statins since then.   He underwent a hip replacement surgery three weeks ago and has been relatively immobile during his post-operation recovery. Given his recent surgery and low activity levels  he stands at a significant risk of developing a venous thromboembolic event. There is also a family history of Pulmonary embolism  suggesting a possible genetic predisposition.  Current presentation:  Today  his wife brought him into the Emergency Department worried about his sudden difficulty in breathing and feeling faint. On arrival  he displayed classic signs of a pulmonary embolism  such as tachypnea  slight hypoxia  and a rapid heart rate. His blood tests indicated a slightly elevated D-dimer  triggering concern for a thromboembolic event.  Conclusion:  In conclusion  given Mr. Jones's current symptoms of shortness of breath  chest pain and tachycardia  along with his risk factors including his recent immobilization due to hip surgery  a long history of smoking and diabetes  pulmonary embolism should be highly suspected. His elevated D-dimer also supports this suspicion.   Further appropriate diagnostic imaging such as a CT pulmonary angiography should be pursued promptly. If this diagnosis is confirmed  initiation of anticoagulation therapy would be the immediate next step to prevent further clot propagation and secondary complications.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Case Presentation: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Slide 2: Patient Information  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John  a retired mechanical engineer. He's a former smoker with 30 pack-years of smoking history. He quit five years ago.   John lives with his wife and enjoys playing golf and gardening.   Slide 3: Presenting Complaint & History of Present Illness  John presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and coughing that started around 6 hours ago.   The chest pain was sharp  located in the mid-chest and intensified with deep breathing. He also reported easy fatigability and mild lightheadedness.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  John has a history of uncontrolled hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes  and obesity. He underwent hip replacement surgery two weeks ago.   He does not have any known allergies. Current medications include Metformin  Losartan  and post-surgical prophylactic low molecular weight heparin which he stopped taking after one week.  Slide 5: Clinical Assessment  On examination  John was tachycardic  tachypneic  and hypoxic. Saturation on room air was 88%  improved to 95% with supplemental oxygen.   His blood pressure was elevated. The remainder of the examination was unremarkable.   Slide 6: Preliminary Diagnosis  Considering John's presenting symptoms and recent surgery (a known risk factor)  the primary concern is acute pulmonary embolism.  Slide 7: Investigations  We plan to confirm our suspicion with a D-Dimer test  followed by CT Pulmonary Angiography if D-Dimers are elevated.   Also  complete blood count  chest X-Ray  EKG and blood cultures will be done to rule out other potential causes of his symptoms.  Slide 8: Conclusion   John's case illustrates the importance of considering Pulmonary Embolism in patients who present with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea  particularly those with significant risk factors like recent surgery. Timely detection  diagnosis  and management can be life-saving in such situations.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: Mrs. Samantha Johnson  a 65-year-old African-American woman  comes from a middle-class family background. She's a retired school teacher and has two children who live close by. She is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. She is slightly overweight with a BMI of 28. This case presentation pertains to her most recent visit in the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: Mrs. Johnson presented to the emergency department with the chief complaints of acute shortness of breath and faintness which started two hours prior to her hospital arrival. She also reported sharp  intense chest pain that worsened with deep breaths.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Johnson's medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with medication for the last 10 years. She underwent left hip replacement surgery 6 weeks ago and has been relatively immobile since then. Her mother and older sister both had deep vein thrombosis.  Current Medications: The patient’s current medication regimen includes Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Physical Examination: On examination  her vital signs were: Blood Pressure - 145/95 mmHg  Heart Rate - 110 bpm  Respiratory Rate - 24 breaths per minute  Oxygen Saturation - 91% on room air. On auscultation  slight wheezing was noted. The left leg was mildly swollen and red. The remainder of her physical examination was within normal limits.   Working Diagnosis & Discussion: Given her risk factors  including significant immobility related to recent orthopedic surgery  family history of thrombotic disease  and clinical presentation of acute onset dyspnea  chest pain  and unilateral leg swelling  she is suspected to have a pulmonary embolism. Diagnostic workup will include a D-dimer test  CT pulmonary angiography  and a Doppler ultrasound of the left leg. As this condition is potentially life-threatening  immediate diagnostic and treatment measures are crucial in this case.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism Case Presentation   Identifying Details:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J. He's a retired engineer with a smoking history of 20 pack-years but quit 15 years back. He is currently residing in a suburb with his wife  is a father to three kids  and leads a rather sedentary lifestyle.  Chief Complaint: Mr. J was brought into the emergency department after experiencing acute shortness of breath that has exacerbated over the past couple of days. He also reports moderate to severe chest pain that's more pronounced when he tries to take a deep breath.  Past Medical History: He has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  with the latest episode occurring three years ago. He follows a medication regime  including an anti-coagulant  Warfarin  for his DVT. He also has a past medical history of hypertension (controlled with Lisinopril)  and he suffers from controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (on Metformin). He has no known allergies.  Family History: His mother had died from a stroke at the age of 73  and his father passed away from myocardial infarction when he was 67. He has two siblings; one brother diagnosed with DVT and one sister with no significant health issues.  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. J appeared in respiratory distress. His pulse was 110 bpm  blood pressure 145/95 mmHg  respiratory rate 28 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 89% on room air. Auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds in the left lower lobe. The rest of the examination was within normal limits.  Plan:  Given his symptoms  past medical history  and physical examination findings  an acute pulmonary embolism was suspected. He was started on high-flow oxygen and heparin therapy. The decision was made to perform imaging tests  including a chest X-ray  computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)  and Doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremities.  This brief presentation has outlined the clinical suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism in Mr. J  a 62-year-old male with a history of DVT  hypertension  and diabetes mellitus. Immediate therapeutic measures have been initiated and diagnostic tests have been ordered to confirm the diagnosis  evaluate the extent  and guide subsequent therapy.

Presentation Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Male   Introduction:  Presenting today is Mr. John Doe  a 57-year-old Caucasian male who was admitted to the hospital emergency department approximately two hours ago. Mr. Doe was brought in due to a sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp chest pain radiating to his left shoulder  light-headedness  and coughing up blood-tinged sputum.   Demographics:  Mr. Doe is a married gentleman with two adult children. He lives in suburban Atlanta  Georgia  and works as an accountant. He has never smoked  drinks socially  and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his occupation.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago  which is managed with a daily dose of Losartan 50 mg. His mother had a stroke at the age of 65. His family history also includes a brother who has deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  suggesting a possible genetic predisposition to clotting disorders.   Recent Medical Events:   Two weeks ago  Mr. Doe underwent an arthroscopic knee surgery for a torn meniscus. Post-surgery  he was prescribed analgesics and was less mobile due to discomfort  which could have contributed to his current condition.  Clinical Assessment:  On examination  Mr. Doe is anxiously positioned in a sitting position  as it's most comfortable for his breathing. His heart rate is tachycardic at 110 bpm  respirations are fast at 24 breaths per minute; blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg; oxygen saturation levels are low at 92% on room air  indicating hypoxemia. On auscultation  breath sounds are decreased in the left lower zone  and his left leg is swollen and tender on palpation.  Impression and Diagnosis:  Given his presenting symptoms  recent surgery  and family history of DVT  an acute pulmonary embolism (PE) is suspected.   Plan:  An urgent D-dimer test  chest CT angiography  and Doppler ultrasound of his left leg will be performed to confirm the diagnosis. If the results are positive for PE  he will be initiated on anticoagulant therapy and possibly thrombolytic therapy if the situation worsens  considering the risk and benefits.  In conclusion  Mr. Doe’s case highlights the importance of considering pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with shortness of breath and chest pain  especially when they have risk factors such as recent immobilization and family history of DVT.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-aged Male  Patient Profile: The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male  married  employed as an international sales representative  with a 27 pack-year smoking history. He drinks alcohol socially (2-3 drinks per week) and denies any illicit drug use. His BMI falls into the overweight category (BMI=28).  Medical History: The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past 7 years and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 3 years ago. His father had a heart attack at age 55  and his mother has a history of recurrent deep vein thrombosis. His medication regimen includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and a daily low-dose aspirin regimen.  Current Situation: The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain  shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and palpitations that started a few hours ago while he was sitting on a long trans-Atlantic flight. He rates his pain as a 7 on a scale of 1-10 and describes it as a sharp  stabbing pain that worsens with deep breaths.  On physical examination: He was anxious and mildly diaphoretic  with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  heart rate 98 bpm  blood pressure 146/92  oxygen saturation 91% on room air and temperature 37.1 degrees Celsius. On auscultation  his breath sounds were slightly diminished in the lower lobes bilaterally  without wheezing  crackles or rubs. His heart sounds were normal rhythm without murmurs. Lower extremity exam did not reveal any obvious signs of deep vein thrombosis such as edema  pain on palpation  or discoloration.  This clinical scenario  coupled with his risk factors (long-duration sedentary travel  smoking history  family history of venous thromboembolism  and personal history of hypertension and diabetes) suggests a high likelihood of an acute pulmonary embolism. Immediate further evaluation with D-dimer  Troponin test and radiographic imaging are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and guide immediate management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the Emergency Department with a two-day history of sudden onset chest pain and slight shortness of breath. Mr. Smith is a pack-a-day smoker and leads a fairly sedentary lifestyle. His BMI is 29  indicating that he is overweight. He works a desk job and reports long periods of sitting. He also reports recent long-haul travel- a 6-hour plane ride for work a week prior to this acute presentation.  Past Medical History  Mr. Smith underwent a total knee replacement two years ago  but reports no other past surgeries. He has a medical history of well-controlled hypertension and was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes five years ago. He does not have any known respiratory diseases  no known clotting disorders  and no family history of thromboembolic events. The patient's medication regimen includes daily Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for anti-hypertension  and Simvastatin for hypercholesterolemia.  Current Presentation   The patient reports that the chest pain is sharp and increases with deep breaths. The pain is localized on the left side of the mid-chest area. He rates his perceived exertion as 5 out of 10 at rest but can increase up to 7 out of 10 during exertion. He reports a low-grade fever but denies any other symptoms such as coughing  blood in sputum  wheezing or swelling in leg veins. On examination  his respiratory rate was slightly increased to 22 breaths per minute  blood pressure was 136/90 mm Hg  and O2 saturation was 93% on room air.  All these clinical signs and symptoms  along with his recent travel history  sedentary lifestyle  and being overweight  raise suspicion for an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). We have requested a D-dimer test  and are considering a CT pulmonary angiogram to confirm the diagnosis if required. Appropriate action and treatment will be undertaken based on the further diagnostic findings.

Patient Presentation  Patient's Title: Mrs.   Demographic Information:   Full Name: Mrs. Jane Smith  Age: 65 years  Gender: Female  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Teacher  Marital Status: Widowed  Religion: Catholic  Language: English   Presenting Issue: Presenting with sudden shortness of breath  chest pain which has worsened on deep breathing  and a fever of 38 degrees Celsius.   Smoking History: Mrs. Smith is a non-smoker.  Alcohol Intake: She drinks alcohol occasionally.  Drug History: No history of illicit drug use.  Family History: Her mother died at 75 due to congestive heart failure.   Past Medical History:   Mrs. Smith has been medically managed for Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years. She was diagnosed with hypertension 7 years ago  which is well-controlled with medication. She also has hyperlipidemia  for which she takes a statin. She underwent a cholecystectomy 5 years ago. Mrs. Smith also suffered from a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after a long-haul flight 3-years ago and has been on Rivaroxaban ever since.   Current Medication:   1. Metformin for diabetes 2. Lisinopril for hypertension  3. Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  4. Rivaroxaban for DVT history  Allergies: She is allergic to penicillin  which causes a rash.  Social History: Mrs. Smith enjoys spending time with her two grown-up children and four grandchildren. She enjoys gardening and going for walks in her local park.  Based on the above-highlighted history and sudden onset of symptoms  the patient might be experiencing an acute pulmonary embolism  which is very likely due to her past DVT history. Immediate diagnostic testing and potential medical intervention are crucial.   This overall suspecting diagnosis could potentially be based on well-known risk factors such as age  history of DVT  and the presence of chronic diseases like diabetes  hypertension. Furthermore  the symptoms which Jane Smith is presenting with are typical indications of a possible acute pulmonary embolism. The worsening chest pain during deep breathing  sudden onset shortness of breath  and low-grade fever are all worrisome red flags for this condition.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 68-year-old Male Patient  Introduction:  I present Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who arrives in the emergency department with symptoms suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient is a retired teacher  lives with his wife  and they have two adult children. He has an average build for his age and height  is a non-smoker  and only consumes alcohol occasionally.   Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus which has been well controlled on metformin. He was also diagnosed with hypertension around seven years ago and has been managed on losartan. He underwent a knee replacement procedure approximately three months ago. There is no known drug allergy. He has no previous history of clotting disorders. He does not have any reported family history of thromboembolic disease or known genetic clotting disorders.  Current Presentation: Mr. Doe reports the sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain that began approximately six hours ago and has progressively worsened. He also complains of shortness of breath  which is more noticeable upon exertion. He denies any cough  fever  or contact with sick persons. He mentions that over the past week  he has noticed sharp  intermittent left calf pain. According to the patient  his leg pain and breathlessness have made it increasingly difficult to participate in his usual daily walks.  Examination: On examination  Mr. Doe is in obvious distress. He is afebrile with tachycardia (heart rate of 110 beats per minute) and slightly tachypneic. His blood pressure is stable. Examination of the chest reveals decreased breath sounds on the right lung field. His left calf appears mildly swollen and warm to touch compared to the right.  Probable Diagnosis:  Given the patient’s recent history of surgery  his symptoms  the physical findings  and his cardiovascular risk factors  a working diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is considered.  Further Investigations: Further investigations have been planned to confirm the diagnosis  which include D-dimer assay  computer tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)  and a Doppler ultrasound of his left leg to look for deep vein thrombosis.  It is an urgent case  which needs immediate attention and management to prevent catastrophic outcomes. The patient has been immediately started on an anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin per hospital protocol  pending investigation results.   In conclusion  recognition of high risk patients and timely diagnosis will improve the prognosis for Mr. Doe and others with suspected acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Details: Mrs. Mabel Richardson  67-year-old Caucasian female.  Chief Complaint: Difficulty in breathing  chest pain.  Presenting Issue: The patient presents with acute onset dyspnea  stabbing type chest pain  and had a syncopal episode earlier today  symptoms began at rest.  Medical History: She was diagnosed with deep venous thrombosis (DVT) 5 years back in the left lower limb post knee replacement surgery. She has been receiving oral anticoagulants intermittently. In addition to DVT  the patient has a history of hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  for which she is on Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively.  Family History: Her father had a history of recurrent DVT and pulmonary embolism. Her mother died of a stroke.  Lifestyle habits: Non-smoker  moderate alcohol intake  sedentary lifestyle.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient appears distressed  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  SpO2 is 89% on room air  Blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  Pulse rate-110 bpm  Temperature-98.6°F. Chest examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side with mild pleural rub.   Provisional Diagnosis: These findings suggest an acute pulmonary embolism.  Next Steps: Immediate therapeutic anticoagulation initiation  D-dimer test  troponin I levels  arterial blood gas analysis  CT pulmonary angiography are planned to confirm the diagnosis. Patient may require telemetry and supplemental oxygen.   Plan for acute PE management  including systemic thrombolysis or surgical embolectomy  after evaluating patient's risk profile  will be discussed. Long term anticoagulation with regular follow-ups for surveillance are to be planned  given her history of DVT and recurrent non-adherence to medications.  Informed patient about the critical nature of her condition and the need for urgent hospital admission.

Slide 1: Introduction -------------------------- Patient Presentation: Mrs. Emily Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the emergency department with acute onset of shortness of breath  tachypnea (rapid breathing)  and chest pain.  Slide 2: Demographics ---------------------------- Address: 123 Main Street  Evergreen County  Texas.   Occupation: Retired school teacher  Slide 3: Relevant Past Medical History ------------------------------------------ - Hypertension managed with Ramipril - Non-insulin dependent Diabetes Mellitus - Previous Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) 3 years ago - No known drug allergies - Previous smoker – 20 cigarettes/day for 35 years  quit 5 years ago  Slide 4: Current Presentation  ----------------------------- Symptoms initiated suddenly about 12 hours prior to presentation. Symptoms include: - Difficulty in breathing  especially during physical exertion - Sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep breathing - Episodes of coughing  sometimes with blood (hemoptysis) - Swelling and tenderness in right calf  Slide 5: Clinical Examination --------------------------------- On physical examination  vital signs were noted as: - Tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute - Blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  - Oxygen saturation: 90% on room air - Body temperature: 98.2°F  Slide 6: Laboratory Results/Imaging -------------------------------------- Preliminary investigations such as D-dimer test came back positive  indicating a possible blood clot. A CT Pulmonary Angiogram was conducted and it confirmed the presence of a blood clot in the pulmonary artery.   Slide 7: Diagnosis ----------------- Based on the clinical presentation  past medical history  and investigative results  Mrs. Smith has been diagnosed with Acute Pulmonary Embolism.   Slide 8: Management Plan --------------------------- Following the diagnosis  she has been started on parenteral anticoagulation therapy (Low Molecular Weight Heparin) and will be transitioned to oral anticoagulant therapy. She will also be evaluated for possible thrombolytic therapy depending upon her severity and risk factors. Respiratory support will be provided as needed.  Slide 9: Follow Up and Education -------------------------------------- Patient education will include understanding the significance of her condition  importance of medication compliance and monitoring for signs of worsening symptoms. Regular follow-ups will be essential to monitor her condition and adjust treatment as required. She will also be encouraged to maintain a healthy lifestyle.

Subject: Patient Presentation - Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Name: Mr. Matthew Reynolds Age: 52  Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Driver  Presenting Problem: Mr. Reynolds has recently been referred to our department from his primary healthcare provider presenting symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism. He has been experiencing difficulty breathing  chest pain  and occasional coughing  with the signs of lightheadedness and faintness.   Past Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history relevant to his current illness. He was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago  a condition which predisposes to the development of PE. Mr. Reynolds also has a history of smoking  and although a former smoker  he smoked two packs of cigarettes a day for approximately 20 years. Besides  he has a family history of heart diseases. He has been under medication for hypertension for the past ten years.   Risk Factors: It is observed that Mr. Reynolds is overweight with a BMI of 30. Being a long-distance driver  he stays in a seated position for long periods - a sedentary lifestyle is a known risk factor for clot formation. His age also inclines him towards an increased risk for PE  as older adults are more susceptible.   Clinical Note:  Further investigations are scheduled for tomorrow  which includes a chest CT scan and D-dimer blood test to confirm the diagnosis. Meanwhile  he has been prescribed anticoagulants and advised to remain active to enhance blood circulations. The patient's immediate and extended family have been advised on the situation and necessary precautions for PE.   In conclusion  Mr. Reynolds represents a typical case of an acute pulmonary embolism with observable risk factors including age  past medical history  and lifestyle. However  further investigations are necessary to firmly establish the diagnosis and guide the development of a management plan.  It is planned to discuss the prognosis  lifestyle modifications  and the necessity of regular follow-ups during his next appointment.

Title: Case Presentation: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Profile: The patient is Mrs. Rhoda Jenkins  a 66-year-old African-American female. She lives with her retired husband in a small town in Oregon. Her BMI (Body Mass Index) is 28  thus marking her in the 'overweight' category. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol only in moderation during social events. Occasionally  she also endures bouts of anxiety.  Presenting Illness: Mrs. Jenkins presented to the ER with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  palpitations  and light-headedness following an 8-hour car journey.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Jenkins has a history of hypertension  which is controlled with Lisinopril. She is also a borderline type 2 diabetic  currently managed with diet and healthy lifestyle modifications. Her surgical history includes a total knee replacement six months ago  which was followed by a 2-month period of prolonged immobility. Notably  she has a family history of thromboembolic disorders; her mother suffered from deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Her regular medications include Lisinopril and a daily Aspirin regimen  started after a careful calculation of coronary disease risk 3 years ago. She is also on a statin for her moderately high cholesterol levels.  Mental Health:  Mrs. Jenkins occasionally encounters anxiety episodes for which she undergoes cognitive behavioral therapy but is not any psychiatric medication.  Allergies: She has a reported allergy to Penicillin which causes a non-anaphylactic rash.  Examination and Investigation: She appeared anxious and breathless on arrival. Her vital signs were as follows: BP- 145/90mmHg  HR- 118/min  SpO2- 91% on room air  RR- 22/min  Temp- 37.6℃. The rest of her physical examination was unremarkable. Lab tests showed elevated D-dimer levels. An urgent CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the presence of a bilateral pulmonary embolism.  This presentation is epidemiologically consistent with Pulmonary Embolism (PE)  and the recent immobility following knee surgery confirmed the likelihood of the diagnosis. Hence  the patient will be managed and monitored as per the standard treatment protocol.

Slide 1: Patient Presentation - Name: Mr. Johnson - Age: 72 years old  - Sex: Male  - Race: Caucasian  Slide 2: Chief Complaint - Mr. Johnson presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain that started three hours ago at home.  Slide 3: Associated Symptoms - Patient also reports feeling light-headed  with an intermittent cough occasionally bringing up blood-streaked phlegm.  Slide 4: Personal Medical History - Mr. Johnson has a history of well-controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus and was a smoker for 40 years (quit 10 years ago).   Slide 5: Recent Events  - Mr. Johnson had a total knee replacement surgery two weeks prior and had been mostly bed-ridden since the surgery.   Slide 6: Family Medical History - His elder brother died of myocardial infarction at a relatively young age (50 years old) and his mother suffers from deep venous thrombosis.  Slide 7: Social History - He lives alone  upstate  and is retired. He does not consume alcohol or use illicit substances.   Slide 8: Current Medications - He’s currently on metformin for diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and had been receiving subcutaneous heparin for thromboprophylaxis postoperatively.  Slide 9: Physical Examination - On examination  the patient looks anxious with some signs of respiratory distress. Vitals reveal a high heart rate at 115 beats per minute and oxygen saturation reading of 88%.  Slide 10: Impression & Plan  - Given his sudden onset dyspnea  chest pain  hypoxia and recent surgery  the clinical suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism is very high. Further diagnostic testing will be conducted immediately including a D-dimer test  CT pulmonary angiography  and possibly a VQ scan to confirm the diagnosis and guide further treatment.

Patient Presentation  Today  our patient is a 64-year-old Caucasian female named Mrs. Wilson  who presents with complaints of acute onset shortness of breath and a sharp  stabbing chest pain radiating to the back. The patient reports that the symptoms began earlier this afternoon while she was gardening  and has been progressively worsening.  Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  well-controlled with amlodipine 5mg once daily and atorvastatin 20mg once daily  respectively. She had an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) ten years ago and completed the standard course of anticoagulation with warfarin. She also has a positive family history of pulmonary embolism in her father. She is a former smoker  quit smoking 15 years ago  has a history of occasional alcohol usage  and denies any recreational drug use.   Mrs. Wilson has no known drug allergies and is currently not on any supplemental medications. She recently took a long haul flight  spending the past month abroad with her family. Although limited mobility during this travel time might have predisposed her to thromboembolism  it is still a differential to be considered.  The combination of her medical history  current symptomatology  and recent travel strongly suggests a possible case of acute pulmonary embolism. However  we will need further assessments and diagnostic tests (including D-Dimer  CT pulmonary angiogram  etc.) to rule out other differential diagnoses and confirm this suspicion.   The subsequent plan of care will involve addressing her acute symptoms  initiating appropriate therapeutic interventions  assessing her risk factors  strategies for future DVT/PE prevention  and a thorough follow-up plan.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 63-year-old Female  Introduction: I present a case of a 63-year-old African American female patient who has been diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.  Demographics: The patient is a retired high school teacher  she has lived the majority of her life in New York City. She's a widow and resides with her two middle-aged children. She has a previous history of drinking and smoking but reports to have discontinued consumption and smoking for the past 15 years. She has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History: Her past medical history is significant for systemic hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are medically managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. Five years ago  she was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus which is controlled with Metformin. She has had no previous surgeries but states that four months prior  she sustained a leg fracture due to a fall in her home  for which she had been immobilized and bed-ridden for a couple of weeks.  Presenting Symptoms: She has reported acute onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  light-headedness  and palpitations  which have been progressing over the past few hours. According to her  the chest discomfort is sharp  located in the middle of her chest and becomes worse upon deep breaths.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  she was tachycardic with a heart rate of 118 beats per minute  her blood pressure was 145/85mmHg  respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute and her oxygen saturation was 89% at room air  which improved to 95% with 3 liters of oxygen via a nasal cannula.  Inference: The combination of the patient's history of recent immobilization due to her leg fracture  her current symptoms  and her physical examination findings lead us to the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment: The patient has been started on a heparin drip and we are considering further diagnostic testing to confirm the diagnosis. Further management will be guided by her response to the initial treatment  diagnostic findings  overall health status  and her decision-making capacity.    Conclusion: This case exemplifies a classical presentation of acute pulmonary embolism occurring in an already medically compromised individual due to prolonged immobility. As part of the care plan  the addition of a consult with the physical therapy team for early mobilization and prophylactic anticoagulation should be contemplated.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism: A Patient Presentation  Demographics  Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 55 years  Sex: Male  Occupation: Office worker Ethnicity: Caucasian Current Address: Boston  Massachusetts  Clinical History:   The patient presented into the emergency department (ED)  complaining of a sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain that developed over a couple of hours while at work. The pain alleviated slightly when he was at rest. The patient also noted a sense of anxiety and a feeling of faintness  but no syncope. His current vital signs upon arrival were: BP 140/90 mmHg  HR 110 bpm  RR 22 breaths/min and SpO2 90% room air. No recent travel  surgeries  hospitalizations or infectious symptoms were reported.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago after a 20-year pack history. He has a history of chronic hypertension (managed with Lisinopril) and hyperlipidemia (controlled with Atorvastatin). There is no personal or familial history of deep vein thrombosis or blood clotting disorder  nor are there any previous episodes of pulmonary embolism.   Family History:  The patient's father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and his mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at 53. His elder brother is hypertensive.   Social History:  He uses alcohol socially  denying any illicit drug use. He lives with his wife and two children  and is moderately active. His job involves sitting for long hours. The patient keeps up with routine physical check-ups and screening procedures  including annual wellness visits and has had twice-yearly lipid profiles for the past 5 years.  Review of System:  All other systems were reviewed and considered negative  apart from his reported respiratory and cardiovascular symptoms.   Based on this patient presentation  an acute pulmonary embolism is suspected  and further diagnostic tests including D-dimer test  CT pulmonary angiogram and EKG will be recommended. Subsequently  the medical team will initiate supportive measures – oxygen therapy and potentially anticoagulation treatment – based on the diagnostic findings.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents himself to the emergency room with a chief complaint of acute shortness of breath that began abruptly two hours ago. He also describes a sensation of chest pain radiating to his left shoulder and associated with severe weakness  dizziness and a sudden bout of coughing  with traces of blood found in his sputum.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has been diagnosed with hypertension for which he has been taking medication for the past 15 years. Also  he has a history of hypercholesterolemia. He quit smoking tobacco two years ago  after a total of 30 years of smoking. No known drug allergies have been reported. He had surgery for a right hip replacement 6 weeks ago for which he was immobilized for several weeks.   Family History:  Mr. Doe's father had a history of myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his mother was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis in her late 60s. His maternal aunt died from an unconfirmed cause  but the family suspects it was a stroke.   Social History:  Mr. Doe is a retired bank manager and lives with his wife. He quit smoking 2 years ago but has a history of heavy alcohol use  although he has been sober for 10 years. He does not perform any regular or strenuous exercise. He is not on any special diet and has a preference for high-fat foods.  Review of Systems:  Mr. Doe reports a significant decrease in exercise tolerance in recent months and an associated weight gain of 10 pounds. He has denied fever  chills  night sweats  headaches  vision change  or recent travel. He reports no changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Given the presenting symptoms  clinical history  recent surgery  and immobilization  there seems to be a high index of suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism  and immediate diagnostic workup  including D-dimer testing and imaging studies  is recommended.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and a rapid pulse. The patient reported that the symptoms started abruptly a few hours before his ER arrival.  Past medical history reveals that Mr. Doe is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history who quit 10 years ago. He has been diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and suffers occasional flare-ups but is otherwise well-managed on inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators. He also has stage 2 hypertension controlled with lisinopril. His only other significant history is of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in his left leg five years earlier  managed with a 6-month course of anticoagulation.   Mr. Doe also reported recent surgery for total hip replacement four weeks ago  spending most of his time in physical rehabilitation and been sedentary for extended periods.   There is no reported history of chest trauma  asthma  lung cancer  tuberculosis  or previous pneumothoraces. He has no known allergies.   Family history reveals both parents had cardiovascular diseases. His father had an MI at age 56  and his mother suffered from chronic heart failure.  Conclusion:  In light of the patient's history  especially the recent orthopedic surgery  previous history of DVT  COPD  sudden onset of symptoms  it is highly suggestive that Mr. Doe is suffering from an acute episode of pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic evaluation and interventions are urgently needed for this potentially life threatening condition.   (Note: This generated presentation is only hypothetical and should not be used as a diagnostic tool or medical advice. Always consult with a healthcare professional for medical advice.)

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones  a 67-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency department with signs and symptoms suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). He has a past medical history of obesity  type II diabetes mellitus  and hypertension  and has been a 30 pack-year smoker. His medications include oral metformin for diabetes  lisinopril and atenolol for hypertension. Also  he had a total knee replacement surgery six weeks ago.   Over the past several days  the patient started experiencing sudden onset chest pain that radiates to his left shoulder  along with shortness of breath and hemoptysis. Mr. Jones also describes experiencing a rapid heart rate and feeling dizzy recently.  His family history is notable for a sister who was diagnosed with PE years ago  and both his father and older brother died from some form of cardiovascular disease.   This presentation of acute chest pain  dyspnea  and hemoptysis  combined with the risk factors of obesity  smoking  recent surgery  and family history of PE  raises significant concerns about the possibility of an acute pulmonary embolism  warranting immediate investigation and treatment.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Post-operative Patient   Introduction Patient Details: Ms. Rebecca Adams  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of breathlessness and chest pain. The breathlessness started abruptly while she was resting at home and has been progressively worsening since then.  Past Medical History: Ms. Adams is a known case of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both of which have been reasonably well controlled with medications. She underwent a total right hip replacement procedure approximately three weeks ago  for which her recovery was uneventful until now. Ms. Adams had also been admitted to hospital 5 years ago for an ischemic stroke but reports a full recovery with no residual deficits.  Presenting Symptoms: Ms. Adams describes the chest pain as sudden in onset  moderately severe  and pleuritic in nature. She denies any history of cardiac disease but has acute dyspnea  cyanosis  and tachycardia. Upon physical examination  the patient was distressed and diaphoretic  with an arterial oxygen saturation of 89% on room air.   Possible Diagnosis: Given her recent orthopedic surgery  her symptoms and physical signs point towards an acute episode of pulmonary embolism  a known post-operative complication. To confirm this  an urgent chest CT angiogram and D-dimer testing have been ordered  as characterized by minimally invasive and widely available diagnostic tools for PE.   Conclusion: Ms. Rebecca Adams might have experienced an acute pulmonary embolism  which is a potentially life-threatening condition if not recognized and treated promptly. She will require immediate anticoagulant treatment once the diagnosis is confirmed  and further recommendations for chronic anticoagulation therapy shall be based on her risk assessment to prevent future thromboembolic episodes. We also need to consider that this might not be a straightforward cardiac event given her past medical history  but a multi-organ condition that will require complex management.

Patient Introduction:  We are presenting the case of Mrs. Joan Simpson  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  who is a non-smoker and lives independently at home. She has been diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism. She is an active individual  frequently participating in low-impact exercises like walking and swimming.  Demographics:  Mrs. Simpson is a retired nurse. She lives with her husband and has a history of occasional alcohol consumption. She is the mother of two children and has four grandkids.   Medical History:  There is a significant past medical history to note. Mrs. Simpson has been managing her hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 10 years  regulated by medication. She also has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a previous hip replacement surgery around 5 years ago.  Current Presentation:  She was presented to the emergency department after developing a sudden onset of breathlessness  cough  and sharp  stabbing chest pain over the last 12 hours. The chest pain was intensified upon deep inspiration. She also reported a feeling of apprehensiveness. On examination  she was found to be tachypnoeic and tachycardic. Syncope and hemoptysis were not noted.  Investigations:  Her vitals were checked  and an electrocardiogram  chest-X-ray  complete blood count  arterial blood gas (ABG)  D-dimer  troponin levels  and CT pulmonary angiogram were recommended based on her symptoms for confirming the diagnosis and ruling out other conditions.  Conclusion:  In conclusion  Mrs. Simpson  due to her medical history and the current presentation  is an ideal example of acute pulmonary embolism. Immediate management by the multidisciplinary team is required to prevent adverse outcomes. The response will be monitored  and adjustments will be made accordingly to her therapeutic regimen.

Introduction:   Our patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presented with symptoms suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Demographic information:  The patient resides in a suburban neighborhood in New York and is a retired engineer. He lives with his wife  and occasionally  with visiting grandchildren. The patient is a former smoker with a 30-year pack history  having quit 15 years ago. He does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs. He maintains a balanced diet  but his physical activity is limited due to arthritis.   Presenting Symptoms:  He arrived in the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and chest discomfort. The patient rates his pain as 7 on a scale of 10  which he describes as sharp and radiating to the back. He also reports lightheadedness and faster-than-normal heartbeat. He has no history of such symptoms.   Past Medical History:  The patient has past medical history of autoimmune rheumatoid arthritis and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) secondary to his prior tobacco use. The rheumatoid arthritis was diagnosed approximately 10 years ago and is well controlled with methotrexate. As for COPD  it has been managed using bronchodilators and inhaled corticosteroids successfully.   In addition  he has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) around 5 years ago. The DVT was treated with warfarin for 6 months  and no subsequent recurrent DVT events were noted in his medical records.  Family History:  His father passed on due to a heart attack in his 70s  and his mother has Alzheimer's disease. There's a notable absence of any known familial coagulopathies.  Medication:  His regular medications include methotrexate for the rheumatoid arthritis  and combination bronchodilator/inhaled corticosteroid for his COPD.  Allergic Status:  The patient has no known allergies to medications.  Conclusion:  Given his signs  symptoms  and past medical history  an acute pulmonary embolism was suspected upon admission. Urgent investigations  including an ECG  D-dimer  and chest CT-angiogram  were performed to confirm the diagnosis. Further medical therapeutic management was done according to the current PE guidelines. He is also referred to a Hematologist for appropriate secondary prevention given his past history of DVT.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism Case Presentation  Patient Information:  • Name: Mr. John Smith  • Gender: Male • Age: 62 years • Race: Caucasian • Occupation: Retired Teacher • Marital Status: Married  Presenting Symptomology:   Mr. Smith presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain that intensifies with deep breaths  and a sense of impending doom. He has a cough and is also mildly tachypneic at 24 breaths per minute. The patient's pulse rate has increased to 110 beats per minute.  Clinical History:  • Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 2 years ago for which he had been on periodic anticoagulant therapy. • He has a 10-year history of Type 2 Diabetes mellitus. • Hypertension diagnosed 7 years ago. • He experienced a mild stroke 5 years ago. • He is a former smoker  quit 12 years ago. • Family history of cardiovascular disease.  Medication:  Currently  Mr. Smith is on oral metformin 500 mg twice daily  losartan 50 mg once daily  and aspirin 81 mg once in a day.   Investigation and Results:   Considering the patient's past medical history and current symptoms  a high-resolution CT chest was done immediately following triage and lab investigations were ordered which revealed the presence of a clot in the right pulmonary artery indicating a pulmonary embolism.   Hospital Course:   Given the patient’s history and presenting symptoms  he was diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism. He was admitted to the intensive care unit and anticoagulation therapy was promptly initiated with the administration of heparin  followed by oral anticoagulants for long-term management.  Mr. Smith's condition improved over the course of a week. He has been advised to continue oral anticoagulant therapy and regular check-ups will be needed to monitor his condition.

Patient Presentation:  I would like to present an evaluation of a 65-year-old female  Mrs. Jane McDowell  who arrived at our emergency department today complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp and stabbing chest pain prone to worsening with deep breaths  and light-headedness. Mrs. McDowell has also reported experiencing a cough producing blood-streaked sputum  noticeable heart palpitations  and excessive sweating in the last two hours.  Mrs. McDowell is a Caucasian woman. She is a non-smoker  maintains a sedentary lifestyle  consumes alcohol in moderation  and has no known drug allergies. She has a BMI of 25.8 kg/m2.   For past medical history  Mrs. McDowell has been treated for hypertension for the past ten years by her primary care physician and has been on Lisinopril. She has had no known history of any pulmonary diseases in the past. She has not undergone any recent surgical intervention but reports a significant period of bed rest following a knee injury and resulting immobility three weeks earlier. Her mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis  but no other familial history of thromboembolic disease is known.   That covers the initial demographic and past medical and familial history. Currently  based on her persisting symptoms and risk factors  namely her sedentary lifestyle  recent immobilization  and family history of thrombosis  we are suspecting a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. However  further diagnostic testing like chest computed tomography (CT) scan  pulmonary angiogram  and D-dimer blood tests are needed to confirm. The patient has been administered oxygen therapy for immediate relief of symptoms and anticoagulants to prevent further clot formation.

Title: Presentation of Acute Pulmonary Embolism Case  I. Introduction Patient's name: Mr. Jameson Gray. He is a 60-year-old Caucasian male and a retired coal miner who is currently occupying two roles as a husband and a father of three grown children with six grandchildren. Mr. Gray lives at Barnstone  Nottinghamshire.  II. Presenting Complaints Mr. Gray presented to the hospital with sudden onset of shortness of breath for approximately 6-7 hours  accompanied by moderate to severe chest pain that he says began suddenly while resting. He also reported experiencing light-headedness  palpitations  and feelings of extreme anxiety.   III. Medical History 1. Hypertension: Mr. Gray has been suffering from hypertension for 10 years. His BP has been often monitored  averaging within 140/90 mmHg and he has been on antihypertensive medication (Amlodipine and Lisinopril).  2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus: The patient was diagnosed with DM 7 years ago  currently regulated with oral metformin and regular glucose monitoring.  3. Smoker: He has a 40-year history of smoking  which he quit about five years ago but had previously been consuming approximately a pack of cigarettes per day.  4. Past Lower Limb Injury: Mr. Gray sustained a lower limb fracture 5 years ago and had undergone surgery.  IV. Review of Systems Mr. Gray reported shortness of breath at rest  worsened by any form of activity  associated with chest discomfort. He denied any cough  fever  or weight change. There's evidence of peripheral edema and calf pain  raising the suspicion of deep vein thrombosis as a possible source of emboli.  In conclusion  based on his presenting signs and symptoms  and considering his past medical history and age  Mr. Gray has been identified as a high-risk patient  who displays symptoms suggestive of Acute Pulmonary Embolism. Detailed diagnostic tests including Doppler ultrasound  D-dimer tests  and Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) will be arranged to confirm the diagnosis. Prompt treatment will be initiated given his classification as a high-risk patient.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 62-Year-Old Female Patient   Good morning Ladies and Gentlemen   Today  We'll be discussing a case of a 62-year-old Caucasian female patient named Mrs. Emily who presented with acute pulmonary embolism.   Patient Information:  - Age: 62 years - Sex: Female  - Race: Caucasian  The patient is a retired schoolteacher who had been maintaining a healthy lifestyle with a balanced diet and routine walks. She had no known allergies. She was a non-smoker and minimized her alcohol intake to moderation.   Past Medical History:  Mrs. Emily's medical history revealed she had a laparoscopic hysterectomy 2 weeks ago. Prior to this  she had had no major illness apart from high blood pressure (hypertension) and hyperlipidemia. She had been on medications  Amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension and Simvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia.  Presenting Complaint: On that day of presentation  she complained of a sudden onset of shortness of breath accompanied by pleuritic chest pain. She also reported light-headedness  sweating  and a sense of palpitation.    Upon physical examination  she was found to be hypoxic with mild cyanosis and tachycardic. She also had a low-grade fever.   Preliminary Diagnosis: Based on her presenting symptoms  recent surgery  and the results of her physical examination  an acute pulmonary embolism was suspected.   Investigations: A D-dimer test was done which came out positive. An urgent computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the presence of bilateral pulmonary emboli.  Treatment & Management: The patient was immediately admitted to the Intensive Care Unit  where she was started on intravenous anticoagulants to prevent further embolic events and symptomatic management was done for her dyspnea and chest pain.  In conclusion: This case emphasized the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients with recent surgery presenting with sudden dyspnea and other related symptoms. It serves as a reminder to us that early diagnosis and management can lead to promising outcomes.   Thank you.

Title: Case Presentation on Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: Mr. James Thompson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male. He resides in Brooklyn  New York and is retired from his job as a civil engineer. He has been a non-smoker his entire life  drinks moderate alcohol  and has no known drug abuse history. He is a widower with two adult children. He denies any recent history of international travel and does not have a history of prolonged immobilization. His father died of a heart attack at age 75  and his mother died of old age.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia approximately 10 years ago  both of which have been relatively well-controlled with medication – Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He also has a history of gout  which has been asymptomatic with Allopurinol.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Thompson now presents with a sudden onset of dyspnea  sharp chest pain  cough with bloody sputum  and light-headedness that started approximately 72 hours ago. He has also experienced dramatic diaphoresis  and his daughter noticed his cyanotic lips and increased anxiety. According to his family  he has been maintaining his drugs and diet well and there has been no recent alteration.  Clinical Assessment: On a physical examination  his vital signs are: blood pressure 160/90  pulse rate 100/min  respiration 24/min  and temperature 37.1°C. Auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds in his left lung  with crackles heard throughout. His heart rate is tachycardic but regular with a soft S1  S2. A lower limb examination revealed slight paunchiness and redness of the left lower limb.   Given his symptoms and physical examination findings  there is a suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism. Next steps would involve further laboratory investigations such as D-dimer levels  Arterial blood gases  Complete Blood Count  and likely imaging such as CT pulmonary angiography or a V/Q scan.  Plan of Management: Upon arrival  the emergency team initiated oxygen therapy and IV access  and provided analgesia to manage his pain. Following confirmation of an acute pulmonary embolism with diagnostic testing  anticoagulant therapy like heparin infusion will be commenced. This will be later transitioned to oral anticoagulants such as Warfarin. His stay in the ICU will be required for monitoring his vitals and his response to treatment  after which pulmonary and cardiovascular rehabilitation could be considered. Prompt intervention at this stage will be aimed at clot resolution and preventing recurrence of thromboembolic disease  thereby minimizing risk of post-PE syndrome.

Patient Presentation:  Our patient today is a 62-year-old African American female named Mrs.A  who is presenting with an acute pulmonary embolism.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient was rushed to the hospital with sudden-onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain which worsened with deep breaths  occasional bouts of cough with streaks of blood  and lightheadedness.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. A's past medical history includes Hypertension  which is under control with regular medication (Lisinopril)  as well as Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  for which she takes Metformin. She underwent a total knee replacement five years ago and has been on long-term contraceptive use (oral contraceptive pills) for menopausal symptoms. Moreover  she has a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years prior to this presentation.  Family History:  Her family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis in her mother and maternal uncle.  Social History:  Mrs. A is a retired teacher. She is married and lives with her husband. She does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. She was an active smoker but ceased it 10 years back.  On physical examination:  Vital signs reveal a slightly accelerated heart rate (110 beats per minute)  elevated blood pressure (140/85 mmHg)  respiratory rate 22 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation 90% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs shows decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes of the right lung; the remainder of the lungs are clear. The rest of the physical examination  including the cardiac and abdominal exams  are within normal limits. The lower extremity examination does not reveal any signs of deep vein thrombosis.  In conclusion  Mrs. A is a 62-year-old African American woman who is presenting with symptoms that are highly suspicious of acute pulmonary embolism—a condition which her risk factors  such as history of hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  long-term contraceptive use  and a family history of thrombotic events place her at an increased risk for. We need to facilitate further investigations to confirm.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith. He was brought into the emergency department via ambulance on August 3. The patient appears active but complains he has been experiencing a gradual onset of shortness of breath along with a sharp chest pain over the past 24 hours. He describes the pain as “stabbing” primarily on the right side of his chest. According to his son  Mr. Smith collapsed at home but did not lose consciousness.  Notable medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease and hypertension for which Mr. Smith has been taking prescribed medication (aspirin  a beta-blocker  statin  and an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor) for the past 10 years. Mr. Smith is a retired truck driver and has a history of heavy smoking (35-pack years) and high alcohol intake  although he reported quitting alcohol three years ago. He has also suffered a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) post knee surgery in 2010 and was treated with warfarin for six months.   Family history records both parents suffered from cardiovascular disease. His father passed away at the age of 72 from a heart attack and his mother passed away from a stroke at the age of 79.   Current clinical findings indicate tachycardia (pulse rate 110 bpm)  tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths/minute  blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg  and an oxygen saturation level of 91%. Lung examination showed decreased breath sounds on the right side. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Given Mr. Smith's history and the presenting symptoms  acute pulmonary embolism has been taken into account as a primary diagnostic consideration.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism Case Presentation  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named John Smith  who resides in New York. He's a retired high school teacher and lives with his wife. He is a smoker with a 40 pack-year history and has a sedentary lifestyle.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith presents to the emergency department with acute onset breathlessness and sharp  pleuritic chest pain that subsided a bit after taking rest. He also reports coughing up blood  lightheadedness  and a feeling of apprehension. The symptoms have persisted over the course of the last two hours.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith is known to have hypertension and atherosclerotic coronary artery disease for which a stent was placed 5 years ago. He is compliant with his antihypertensive medication  namely Lisinopril and his antiplatelet drug  Clopidogrel. He also takes a cholesterol-lowering drug  Atorvastatin.   Mr. Smith underwent arthroscopic surgery on his right knee 6 weeks ago and was relatively immobile during his recovery period. He had his routine vaccinations and does not have any known allergies.
