Personal and Social History: Mr. Smith lives with his wife  is retired  and has a past history of heavy smoking. He consumes alcohol occasionally  a glass or two of wine per week. He does not engage in regular exercise  making his lifestyle predominantly sedentary.   Clinical Evaluation: On assessment  Mr. Smith appeared distressed and mildly cyanotic. He was tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Blood pressure was slightly raised at 150/95 mmHg. On auscultation  there was decreased breath sounds over the left lower lung field.  Preliminary Assessment & Plan: Given his recent surgery  immobilization  heavy smoking history  and presenting symptoms  Mr. Smith is suspected to have an acute pulmonary embolism.   Investigations including D-dimer  contrast CT angiography of the chest  ECG and echocardiography will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis  after which an appropriate management plan will be formulated.

Title: Acute Pulicmonary Embolism in a Middle-aged Male   Patient Information Name: Mr. Jones Age: 58 Sex: Male Race: African American Occupation: Mechanic  Presenting Problem:  Mr. Jones presents to the emergency room with sudden-onset difficulty in breathing  chest pain  cough  and light-headedness. He also mentions he’s been experiencing leg pain and swelling over the last week.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He does not have any known history of heart disease  DVT  or PE. His day-to-day activities have significantly reduced over the past year due to mild osteoarthritis. He is a moderate smoker  smoking half a pack a day for the past 35 years. He has a family history of coronary artery disease; his father died of a heart attack at the age of 62.  Diabetes mellitus: No Hypertension: Yes Dyslipidemia: Yes CKD: No Asthma/COPD: No Smoker: Yes  Surgical History:  Mr. Jones had a right knee replacement surgery 2 years ago due to severe osteoarthritis. He developed postoperative deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  but it was treated successfully with no reported recurrences.   Patient Medication:  Mr. Jones is currently taking antihypertensive medication (Losartan 50mg) and a statin (Atorvastatin 20mg) for dyslipidemia  as prescribed by his primary care physician.   Given the symptomatology and past history of DVT  the possibility of an acute pulmonary embolism should be strongly suspected for Mr. Jones and immediate diagnostic tests  including D-dimer testing and CT pulmonic angiography  should be performed. Treatment should begin with administration of oxygen and thrombolytic therapy followed by anticoagulant therapy once PE is confirmed.   This case emphasizes the importance of risk factor management and regular follow-ups in patients with a history of DVT  as well as quick response and active management upon signs of potential acute pulmonary embolism.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism Case Presentation  Patient Information:  Mr. Anthony Brown  a 67-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department. He is a retired mechanical engineer  a widower and lives with his 44-year-old daughter. A smoker with a 30-pack year history  Mr. Brown has past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and deep venous thrombosis (DVT) five years ago.  Chief Complaint:  His chief complaint is a sudden onset of breathlessness  chest pain  and spells of dizziness that started a few hours ago.   History of Present Illness: He was in his usual state of health until this evening when he suddenly developed shortness of breath accompanied by sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens upon deep inspiration. He also reports feeling dizzy with a near syncopal episode. There is no associated cough  fever  hemoptysis  or recent travel. No loss of consciousness or dysphagia noted.  Past Medical History: Mr. Brown has been suffering from hypertension for 10 years  for which he is treated with Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  controlled by Metformin and lifestyle modifications. His hyperlipidemia is managed by Atorvastatin. He suffered a DVT five years ago  for which he took Warfarin for six months and then stopped.  Medications:  Lisinopril  Metformin  and Atorvastatin.   Allergies:  None known drug allergies.  Family History:  His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and died at 76 due to stroke. His mother died at 67 due to complications of breast cancer. His older sister is alive and well with no significant illnesses.  Review of Systems:  Upon reviewing systems  he denied any related symptoms of fever  chills  weight loss  swelling of legs  rash  or palpitations.   Physical Examination: On examination  he was anxious  tachycardic with a heart rate of 106 beats/min  respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  temperature 36.9°C (98.4°F)  oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Chest auscultation revealed normal vesicular breath sounds with no wheeze or crackles  and cardiovascular examination was unremarkable with regular rate and rhythm.  Acute pulmonary embolism is suspected given the recent history of DVT  sudden onset dyspnea  and chest pain. Further diagnostic testing including D-dimer  ECG  chest X-ray  and possibly a CT pulmonary angiogram is planned to confirm the diagnosis.   Social History: He is a widower living with his daughter  known to consume alcohol socially and a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years. Has a history of working in a workshop with exposure to asbestos.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in 52-Year-Old Caucasian Woman  Introduction:  Today's case presentation is about Mrs. Jane Doe  a 52-year-old Caucasian woman  with Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE) also known as lung clot.   Demographics:  Mrs. Jane Doe is a married woman living in urban setting with her husband. She works as a paralegal in a law firm and has two grown-up daughters living separately. Her socioeconomic status is middle class. She has no known allergies. She is a non-smoker and reports social drinking only.  Past Medical History:  Mrs. Doe has a past medical history significant for Recurrent Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and obesity. She underwent appendectomy at the age of 25 and a Caesarean section during the birth of her first daughter. Mrs. Doe has been on oral contraceptives for years for endometriosis. She does not have any known history of cardiac disease  stroke  or malignancies. However  there is a family history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. Her medication history includes warfarin for DVT  and an oral contraceptive pill.   Presenting Issue:  Mrs. Doe initially presented to the emergency department with severe sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain worsened on deep inspiration and unexplained cough  with some blood-tinged sputum. The symptoms have been ongoing for the past 4 hours. She also reported mild fever and a sense of light-headedness.   Concluding Remark:  With her history of recurrent DVT  known risk factors such as obesity and the use of oral contraceptives  alongside her presenting symptoms  Mrs. Doe is a classic presentation of a patient with acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic tests and management strategies were promptly initiated given the serious and often fatal implications of Acute Pulmonary Embolism.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism: Case Study  Presentation:  I would like to present the case of a patient who came to us with Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE).   Demographics:  The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male. He is independent in activities of daily living  retired  has a history of smoking 1 pack per day for 40 years and lives with his wife in a suburban residential location. He has never been admitted to a hospital for similar symptoms before.   History:  We will discuss the patient's past medical history now. The patient has a significant past medical history of Hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago  managed with oral medications. However  the patient has been non-compliant with his medications for the past few months due to increased stress levels.   There is also a history of Type II Diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 7 years ago  managed with both dietary control and Metformin. Moreover  the patient recently had a right lower limb fracture that was managed conservatively. However  he remained bedridden for about 6 weeks post-accident. This immobile period likely contributed to the acute event of pulmonary embolism.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient reported sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain was 'stabbing' in nature  localized to the middle of the chest  and aggravated by deep breathing. The patient also described light-headedness  an increased heart rate  and a bit of blood in his cough.  Conclusion:  To summarize  we have a 63-year-old male with a good history of hypertension  diabetes  and prolonged immobility due to a recent injury  who presents with chest pain  breathing difficulty  elevated heart rate  and blood in expectoration indicative of an Acute Pulmonary Embolism. Immediate intervention was undertaken for diagnostic confirmation and treatment due to the life-threatening nature of the condition.

Patient Presentation: We have a 68-year-old Caucasian male patient  named John Doe  who presents with symptoms consistent with an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient reported a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness occurring over the last few hours. He has also noted an increased heart rate.  Demographic Information: Mr. Doe is a retired school teacher and currently lives alone. He does not smoke or consume alcohol. Physical activity is limited due to his pre-existing conditions. He has a known history of prolonged immobility due to recent total knee-arthroplasty surgery performed approximately two weeks ago. He doesn’t have any known drug allergies.  Past Medical History: His past medical history includes deep vein thrombosis (DVT) which occurred five years ago following a prolonged period of travel. He also has a history of well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. His family history is relevant with his father experiencing a PE in his early seventies. In terms of medication  Mr. Doe is currently on metformin for diabetes  amlodipine for hypertension  and warfarin for DVT prophylaxis  which he admits having discontinued one week prior to his knee surgery due to bleeding concerns.   Conclusion: Given the patient's recent surgery  his sudden onset of symptoms  his lack of compliance on warfarin  and his past medical history  it is likely that he's experiencing another PE. Urgent diagnostic tests and management considerations are needed.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mr. Timothy Anderson Age: 50 years old Race: Caucasian Sex: Male Occupation: Accountant  Presenting complaint:   Mr. Anderson presents in the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness. Pain is sharp  located in the right side of the chest and becomes worse upon deep breaths. He also mentioned he was coughing up blood.  Past medical history:   Mr. Anderson has a known history of deep vein thrombosis 2 years ago  managed with oral anticoagulation therapy  which he stopped 6 months ago. He is also a smoker with a 20-pack year history  and suffers from systemic hypertension controlled by ACE inhibitors. He does not have any known allergies.  Family history and psychosocial history:  Mr. Anderson’s father experienced a myocardial infarction at 60 years old  and his mother suffers from hypertension. He is divorced and lives alone. He reports high levels of stress at work.  Medication:  The patient is on Ramipril 2.5mg once daily for hypertension. He stopped taking his prescribed anticoagulation medicine rivaroxaban  6 months ago.  Review of systems:   The patient presents with respiratory symptoms including shortness of breath and hemoptysis. He also reported anxiety and feelings of impending doom. There are no reported gastroenterological  genitourinary  skin  or musculoskeletal symptoms.  Physical examination:   On observation  the patient was visibly distressed  diaphoretic  and tachypneic. His vital signs are: BP 135/85 mmHg  pulse rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 30 breaths/min  temperature 37.8 °C  SpO2 92% on room air.  Based on his symptoms  past medical history  and presentation  Mr. Anderson appears to be having an acute pulmonary embolism.  This is a medical emergency  Immediate management is needed including confirmatory diagnostic tests (CT chest angiogram  D-dimer assay)  supplement oxygen for hypoxia  systemic anticoagulation should be started  and possibly  thrombolysis or surgical evacuation.

Patient Presentation:  The patient presenting before us today is Ms. Jane Doe  a 58-year-old Caucasian woman  who works as an accountant. She has lived in Chicago  Illinois  for most of her adult life. Jane is currently living with her husband and has two adult children. She has been a non-smoker for her entire life.  In terms of her past medical history  she has been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and type II diabetes. She had been maintaining a relatively good health with her on-going medications controlling her conditions. However  two years ago  she underwent a total hysterectomy due to the presence of large uterine fibroids. Post-surgery  she experienced deep vein thrombosis  which was managed effectively with anticoagulants.  Presenting Condition:  Today  Ms. Doe arrived at the emergency department with sudden onset acute shortness of breath  chest pain  and a sense of impending doom  which started while she was at rest. The chest pain is sharp  radiates to the back  and is exacerbated with deep breathing. She mentioned she had been more sedentary than usual over the past week due to an increased workload and long hours at her desk.  She is noticeably tachypneic  tachycardic  appears anxious and the oxygen saturation on room air is around 93%. On auscultating the chest  no clear abnormalities are detected  the heart sounds are tachycardiac  no extra sounds or murmurs observed.  These symptoms and her history points towards a possible diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism. Further investigations with diagnostic imaging and a D-dimer test will be useful to confirm the diagnosis.  In the meantime  Jane needs to be stabilized  with a focus on improving her oxygenation. Given her past history  she may need to be started on anticoagulation therapy as soon as the diagnosis is confirmed  while we monitor her response to treatment and ensure that there are no complications. Her sedentary lifestyle  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and history of hysterectomy and DVT make her predisposed to this condition  emphasizing the importance of preventive care and lifestyle modification.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged  Obese Female Patient: A Case Presentation  Demographic Information:  Patient: Mrs. Jane Doe Age: 56 Sex: Female Race: Caucasian    Current Presentation: The patient presents with sudden shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness. She reports experiencing chest pain that worsens when she takes a deep breath or coughs. Further inquiries reveal anxiety  palpitations  and a bloody cough over the last few hours.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Doe's medical history is significant for obesity  hypertension and sedentary lifestyle. She had a cholecystectomy 10 years ago  and she underwent total knee joint replacement surgery on both knees two months back  post which she has been immobile for most of the time. Classified as obese (BMI > 30)  she has not been engaged in physical activity for the last several years. She has been on blood pressure medication for the past 5 years. No known allergies or significant family history of genetic diseases have been reported. Mrs. Doe has a 20 pack-year smoking history up until 10 years ago but quit tobacco use after her cholecystectomy.   Summary: Given the recent surgery and prolonged immobilization  the past medical history of obesity and hypertension  the current symptoms seem consistent with an acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic tests including D-dimer  computed tomography (CT) angiography of the chest  or a ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan will be necessary to confirm the diagnosis. This patient's case underscores the importance of considering underlying risk factors and indicating early mobilization to reduce complications like pulmonary embolism following orthopedic surgeries.

Title: Acute Pulicmonary Embolism Case Presentation  Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. James Smith Age: 60 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Truck Driver  Presenting History:  Mr. James Smith has presented to the emergency room with sudden onset dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain that started about 2 hours ago. He reports feeling lightheaded and says he almost fainted while at home. He also mentions experiencing a similar  but milder  episode last week which he attributed to stress and fatigue.  Past Medical History:  Mr. James Smith has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) about 5 years ago for which he was treated. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension  both of which are managed with medications. He is an ex-smoker who stopped smoking 10 years ago but had a 20 pack-year history up until then.   Family History:  There is positive family history for cardiovascular disease- father died of myocardial infarction at 65 and older brother has angina.   Social History:  Mr. Smith has been living alone since his divorce 3 years ago and consumes alcohol infrequently.   Recent History:  Mr. Smith recently recovered from a bout of bronchitis for which he received antibiotics. He has also completed long international flights in last month which potentially put him at risk for venous thromboembolism.   Condition:  On examination  Mr. Smith appears to be in acute distress. His heart rate is 110 bpm  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air.  Based on the history  the physical examination findings  and the risk factors  this presentation strongly supports the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Next Steps:  Immediate investigations including D-dimer  chest radiograph  and blood gases have been ordered. Given the acute nature of his symptoms  a CT pulmonary angiography will also be arranged as soon as possible.   If his condition worsens  immediate hospitalization and potentially thrombolytic therapy will be required. Anticoagulation treatment will be started based on the diagnosis. Patient education regarding lifestyle changes will also be discussed once condition stabilizes.

Subject: Case Presentation - Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Profile:  Mr. John Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired middle school teacher  presented to our emergency department. He is a non-smoker and moderate alcohol consumer. His body mass index (BMI) is 28.2  indicating overweight. He lives with his wife and has two adult children.   History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith has a two-day history of sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp right-sided chest pain getting worse with deep breaths and mild lightheadedness. He denies any cough  fever  leg pain or swelling. There is no known family member with similar symptoms.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which are well controlled with metformin and amlodipine  respectively. He had an event of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 3 years ago following a transcontinental flight which was treated. There is no known history of cancer  heart diseases  or surgeries.  Social History: Mr. Smith is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially. He lives with his wife and has no history of any drug abuse. He has a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in saturated fats. He stated a mild level of psychological stress due to his recent retirement.  On examination: Mr. Smith was anxious  tachycardic with a heart rate of 102 beats/min  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. Cardiac examination was unremarkable.  Based on the history and physical examination findings  Mr. Smith was suspected to have an Acute Pulmonary Embolism  and further investigations were ordered accordingly. Prompt management was initiated to stabilize his condition. His family members were informed about his medical situation and necessary precautions were discussed to avoid future episodes.

Title: Presentation of Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 65-year-old Female Patient   Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female. She is a retired elementary school teacher who resides in a suburban setting with her husband. She has a known history of being a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. She exercises moderately and leads an active lifestyle  regularly attending community activities and social clubs.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years and is currently controlling it through a combination of diet  exercise and the drug Lisinopril. In addition her past medical history includes Type 2 diabetes for the past 6 years managed with Metformin and diet regulation. No known allergies have been identified. She had her last pelvic examination and mammogram one year ago  with no abnormalities reported. She underwent a total knee replacement surgery two years ago and had contracted a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) post-operatively  to which she was placed on Rivaroxaban for a period of six months. There is a family history of heart disease.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath of one-day duration. Associated symptoms include chest pain  exacerbated on deep breathing  and a fainting episode earlier in the day. There is no history of fever  cough  or hemoptysis.   Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared distressed and was sweating. Vitals recorded at admission included a heart rate of 100 beats per minute  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia  but no murmurs  rubs or gallops. Pulmonary exam revealed decreased breath sounds on the lower right lung lobe without wheezes  rales  or rhonchi. Rest of the examination was within normal limits.  Given the patient’s clinical presentation in conjunction with her historical risk of DVT  there is high suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism. The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy and further investigations are underway.

Subject: Presentation of Patient with Acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE)  Introduction:  I present to you  a 65-year-old Caucasian male patient named Mr. Robert who has been brought to our emergency department presenting symptoms suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Demographics: Mr. Robert is a retired civil engineer  resides with his wife in a suburban neighborhood  and falls under the middle socioeconomic status. He has a history of moderate alcohol consumption and is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago. He lives an idle lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Medical History:  Mr. Robert has a chronic history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for which he is on anti-hypertensive medications and oral hypoglycemic agents  respectively. He also had a documented history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) approximately two years ago for which he underwent treatment. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases  his father having died of myocardial infarction and his mother of stroke.  Current Presentation: Mr. Robert arrived at the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath since last 2 hours accompanied by a sharp  stabbing chest pain that intensifies with deep breaths. He also reports feelings of lightheadedness and fainting. His vital signs on admission illustrate blood pressure: 150/90mmHg  pulse: 110 bpm  respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation: 89% on room air and temperature: 37.6°C.   On physical examination  he displayed signs of respiratory distress  with mild cyanosis  tachypnea  and tachycardia. Auscultation of the chest reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side. ECG reflects sinus tachycardia with possible S1Q3T3 pattern.   Investigations:  Our team has sent a D-Dimer test  arterial blood gases and basic metabolic panel. To confirm the suspected acute PE  we are planning for a CT Pulmonary angiogram.  Conclusion: Given his symptoms  vital sign abnormalities  past medical history of DVT  and current examination findings  he is highly suspected for acute pulmonary embolism. Considering this  we have initiated immediate treatment with anticoagulation therapy  supplemental oxygen and supportive measures. Further management will be decided based on the results of his laboratory tests and imaging studies.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 57-year-old female  Mrs. Jane Doe  presenting with symptoms indicative of an acute pulmonary embolism. Mrs. Doe is of Caucasian descent  currently resides in Boston  Massachusetts  and works as a school teacher. She is a non-smoker and reports she drinks alcohol only occasionally.   Mrs. Doe arrived in the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and palpitations since this morning. She describes the chest pain as sharp  located in the center of her chest  and worsening with deep breaths. She also reported experiencing light-headedness and a bout of coughing  but no hemoptysis. Her vitals on arrival demonstrated tachypnea  tachycardia  and mild hypoxia. She is afebrile.  In terms of past medical history  Mrs. Doe was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension five years ago  both of which she manages with medication. She underwent surgery for an inguinal hernia a month ago and has been relatively immobile during her recovery period. She has a family history of deep vein thrombosis  with her mother having experienced multiple incidents.   In terms of medication use  Mrs. Doe takes Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and low-dose Aspirin as a preventive measure. She has no known drug allergies.   In combination with her post-operative immobility  her medical history  family history of thrombotic condition  and her presentation of symptoms  this could possibly indicate an acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic tests  including D-dimer  CT angiography  and V/Q scan  are required to confirm the diagnosis. After confirmation  appropriate management will be initiated which might include anticoagulation and possible thrombolysis.   It is essential that Mrs. Doe's condition is managed promptly due to the serious and potentially fatal repercussions of a pulmonary embolism. Regular follow-ups will be necessary to monitor her response to treatment and to prevent potential recurrence.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Diabetic Patient  Introduction: We present a case of a 55-year-old African-American male who reported to the Emergency Department with symptoms of acute onset shortness of breath and chest discomfort. The patient is a known case of Diabetes Mellitus type II on Metformin therapy  diagnosed 10 years ago  but non-compliant to medication and diet control  and with poor glucose monitoring. He also has a history of long-term smoking  approximately a pack per day for 30 years  exacerbating his underlying risk of cardiovascular disease.  Clinical Presentation: The patient reported that he began feeling increasing discomfort in his chest  acute breathlessness with a sense of impending doom while changing his car tire. He was noticed to be in moderate to severe respiratory distress  clammy  and diaphoretic with increased respiratory rate. Additionally  the patient reported no hemoptysis  dizziness  or loss of consciousness.  Physical Examination and Investigation: Upon physical examination  the patient was found to have tachycardia and decreased breath sounds on the right side of the lung field with signs of right-sided heart failure. No signs of deep vein thrombosis were noticed in any extremities. Immediate electrocardiography revealed signs of right heart strain. A D-Dimer test was urgently performed which came back significantly positive.  Diagnosis and Management Plan: Considering the clinical symptoms  risk factors  and preliminary investigations  the patient was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism  possibly secondary to his poorly controlled diabetes and smoking habit leading to a pro-thrombotic state. The patient was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin  oxygen supplementation and intravenous fluids. Arrangement was done for a CT pulmonary angiogram to confirm the diagnosis and locate the site of the embolism. Concurrently  the hospital’s cardiology and endocrinology teams were consulted for the management of cogent conditions and optimizing his diabetes control.   Conclusion: This case illustrates the emergent presentation of a severe  potentially fatal condition  acute pulmonary embolism  stemming from the confluence of modifiable risk factors such as uncontrolled diabetes and smoking in a middle-aged man. The importance of prompt recognition  inducing rapid response and multi-disciplinary approach is highlighted in managing such acute cases.

Title: Case Presentation on Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Patient Demographics: Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department. He is a retired school teacher from New York who lives with his wife and has 3 adult children. He has a history of 40 pack-year smoking  drinks socially and denies any illicit drug use. He reports that he is fairly active  walking at least 30 minutes daily.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a significant past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  hypertension  type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and previous deep vein thrombosis (DVT) post hip replacement surgery 5 years ago. His medications consist of Metformin  Lisinopril  Symbicort  and Warfarin. He is allergic to Penicillin  which causes him a skin rash.  Presenting Problem:  Mr. Johnson presented with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and lightheadedness. Symptoms started while he was doing his regular walk earlier in the day and have progressively worsened. He denies any previous similar episodes  fevers  chills  cough  leg swelling  or recent prolonged travel. He also denies any family history of clotting disorders.  Conclusion:  Given the patient’s presenting symptoms  past medical history  and risk factors (age  previous DVT  COPD  prolonged period of immobilization post-surgery)  there is a high clinical suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism. Immediate tests including D-dimer  EKG  Troponin levels  and CT pulmonary angiography will be needed to confirm the diagnosis and initiate the appropriate management.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism Patient Presentation  Patient Information:   The patient under review is a 68-year-old African American man named William Johnson. Mr. Johnson is a retired air force officer who lives with his wife in Oregon  USA. His occupational exposure includes over 30 years in the aviation industry. He does not smoke  but has a significant alcohol consumption history  and a body mass index (BMI) of 29.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has been previously diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he has been managing with a combination of diet  exercise  and metformin therapy. Moreover  he has a well-controlled hypertension through medication (Lisinopril)  established around 8 years ago. He also has bilateral below-knee deep vein thrombosis (DVT) for which he completed anticoagulation treatment 4 years ago  alluding to a potential predisposition to thromboembolism. He has no known allergies.  Current Presentation:  Mr. Johnson presented to the Emergency Department with symptoms of sudden onset of shortness of breath  mild chest pain exacerbating on deep breathing  and light-headedness. These symptoms have not been improving over the past few hours. His vital signs on arrival were: blood pressure of 152/95 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute (tachypneic)  heart rate of 100 bpm (tachycardic) and an oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. On physical examination  he appeared distressed and was using accessory respiratory muscles.   Initial diagnostic investigations revealed an elevated D-dimer and an abnormal ECG showing features suggestive of pulmonary embolism. A confirmatory CT pulmonary angiogram demonstrated a large  centrally located  blood clot in the main pulmonary artery – confirming the suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism.   The patient is currently stable and has been commenced on emergency anticoagulant therapy  and further management is dictated by the hospital protocol.  This presentation wraps Mr. Johnson's case  a typical demographic likely to present with an acute pulmonary embolism  with significant past history of DVT and known risk factors like obesity  age  hypertension and diabetes. The presentation focuses on illustrating the importance of prompt diagnosis and immediate intervention to negate morbidity and mortality.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Postmenopausal Female Patient  Introduction:  Today  we discuss a 62-year-old Caucasian female patient who presented with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism.  Demographic and Personal History: Mrs. Smith is a retired school teacher and a lifelong nonsmoker who drinks socially. She resides with her husband in a suburban community. She was referred by her primary care physician after she presented with acute breathlessness and chest discomfort that had lasted for a couple of hours.  Presenting Signs and Symptoms: The patient described the chest pain as sharp and worse on deep inspiration. She also reported a sudden onset of shortness of breath. Additionally  she mentioned a sense of palpitations  light-headedness  but no syncope  cough  or hemoptysis.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Smith's past medical history is significant for hypertension that is well controlled with Lisinopril and she also takes daily aspirin for cardioprotection. She was diagnosed with Stage II breast cancer five years ago and completed treatment with surgery  chemotherapy  and radiation. She has been cancer-free for the last four years. She went through menopause at the age of 51 and has had no hormone replacement therapy.  Family History: She has a family history of malignancy (mother died from ovarian cancer and sister diagnosed with colon cancer) and cardiovascular disease (father died from myocardial infarction in his mid-sixties).  Social History:  She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially. She leads an active lifestyle  with regular exercise including daily walks and yoga classes.  Conclusion: Given her presenting symptoms  sudden onset  and risk factors like personal history of malignancy and family history of cardiovascular disease  the possibility of an acute pulmonary embolism was considered. An immediate evaluation with chest imaging and lab testing was planned to confirm the diagnosis and determine appropriate treatment strategies. Authorities were also notified for a possible hospital admission and further management. All the decisions were made considering the patient's overall health and personal preferences.

Patient Presentation:  I would like to present a case of a 62-year-old male  Caucasian  named Mr. James  who presented with symptoms indicative of acute pulmonary embolism. He is a retired truck driver  currently residing in Queens  New York  with his wife. He is a current smoker with a history of 20-pack years and consumes alcohol socially. Mr. James is a veteran  discharged honorably  and suffers from chronic post-traumatic stress disorder.  Mr. James has a significant past medical history. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 12 years ago  for which he takes oral hypoglycemic drugs. He also has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia being managed with amlodipine and atorvastatin  respectively. His surgical history includes a total knee replacement 3 years ago on his left side due to severe osteoarthritis. For this  he was on an anticoagulant regimen for a brief period post-operatively. He has no known drug allergies.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. James reported sudden onset of shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  and an episode of fainting that lasted minutes. He also complained of a mild cough with blood-streaked sputum and unexplained fatigue over the past week. He denied any recent prolonged periods of immobilization  recent surgeries  or a family history of blood clotting disorders.  In light of Mr. James' symptomatology coupled with his past medical history and lifestyle factors  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was considered. The patient was advised to get an immediate diagnostic evaluation including a D-dimer test  CT pulmonary angiography  and an ECG to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other potential causes for his symptoms. Risk assessment for determining the severity and possible interventions was also initiated.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 67-year-old African American male who presents with sudden onset difficulty in breathing and chest pain that is sharp and improves slightly with leaning forward. The pain started while he was resting at home and has continued unremitting for the past two hour.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of uncontrolled type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He is also obese with a BMI of 32. He has a history of smoking 1 pack per day for the last 30 years  though he quit 5 years ago. There is no known history of previous stroke  myocardial infarction  or clinics of deep vein thrombosis. His medication list includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He has no known allergies.  Social History:  The patient is married  lives with his spouse  and has three adult children. He is a retired school administrator; he remains largely inactive at home since his retirement. His alcohol use is mild and he denies the use of any illicit drugs.  Family History:  His family history is notable for a sister diagnosed with blood clots in her legs and lungs in her 60s. His father suffered from a stroke at the age of 74 and his mother was diagnosed with breast cancer at the age of 67.  Discussion:  This is an overview of a patient who has acute pulmonary embolism considering his symptoms  risk factors associated with his past medical history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension and his obesity. His family history is filled with significant thrombotic events. Further diagnostics like arterial blood gases  D-dimer  ECG  chest X-ray  CT pulmonary angiography  and ventilation-perfusion scan should be conducted to confirm this diagnosis. The patient should be managed swiftly to prevent any possible fatal outcomes. Early detection can lead to successful management and treatment  and hence the need for awareness on the signs of pulmonary embolism.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism Case Presentation   Demographics: Our patient  Mr. J.P is a 62-year-old Caucasian male of Hispanic origin. He is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban apartment. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  but has a 40-pack-year smoking history. He does not consume alcohol and denies any recreational drug use. He has a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity. His BMI is 27  indicating he is overweight.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. J.P presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of sharp  severe right-sided chest pain accompanied by shortness of breath. His shortness of breath has progressively worsened over the last 3 hours and is associated with minimal exertion. He denies any cough  fever  hemoptysis  leg pain  or swelling. He also has noted ensuing mild dizziness.  Past Medical History: Mr. J.P has a significant medical history of Type 2 diabetes  well controlled with diet and Metformin  and hypertension controlled with Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia two years ago and is currently on Atorvastatin. His last LDL level check six months ago was within normal limits.   He had a laparoscopic cholecystectomy 5 years ago for gallstones. He also claims to have a 'heart condition ' but detailed reports were not immediately available. He denies any history of Clotting disorders  stroke  or cancer.  Family History: Family history is positive for coronary artery disease with his father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 years  but negative for DVT/PE  clotting disorders  and cancer.  Medication History: For his diabetes  he takes Metformin 1000 mg twice daily  along with Lisinopril 10mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg daily. He is also on Aspirin 81mg once a day as prophylaxis. He takes over-the-counter fish oil for overall heart health.   Clinical Findings: On examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. His blood pressure is 136/82 mmHg  pulse 102 bpm  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air.  This combination of his clinical presentation  demographic features  past medical history  and current clinical symptoms strongly suggest the possibility of an acute pulmonary embolism. Immediate diagnostic steps  including D-dimer assay  chest computed tomography (CT) with contrast  and possible ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan will be pursued to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate treatment.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information:  Ms. Maria Turner  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the emergency department with symptoms highly suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism. She is a retired school teacher and has recently been involved in a cross-country road trip  where she was sedentary for long periods.   Past Medical History: Ms. Turner has a significant past medical history  including multiple key risk factors for thromboembolic events. She was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and has been managing it with diet  exercise  and medication. She also has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a hip replacement surgery five years ago  for which she received anticoagulation therapy with Warfarin. Additionally  a sedentary lifestyle coupled with a personal and family history of obesity puts her at a higher risk. She does not smoke or consume alcohol.  Presenting Complaint: Ms. Turner arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that worsened upon deep breathing  and mild hemoptysis. She also reported feeling light-headed and having episodes of rapid heart rate.   Summary: Ms. Turner  a 65-year-old woman with significant risk factors for pulmonary embolism including a history of DVT and recent prolonged sedentary behavior  presents with symptoms consistent with an acute pulmonary embolism. Her current cardiovascular risk factors  coupled with her presenting symptoms  require immediate diagnostic confirmation and treatment initiation.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 60-year-old Male Patient   Introduction:   Mr. John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presents today with a sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain  shortness of breath  and a surprising episode of faint and syncopal episode. Additionally  he reports of hemoptysis and tachycardia. The symptoms developed swiftly over a period of a few hours. He denies having a fever  cough  or any recent surgeries or hospitalizations.  Demographics:  Mr. Doe has been living in Boston  Massachusetts  for the last 40 years and runs a car maintenance garage. He is a former smoker  quitting approximately 20 years back. He drinks occasional socially.  Past Medical History:  Upon review of Mr. Doe's medical history  he has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past ten years  both controlled with medication. Mr. Doe underwent angioplasty for coronary artery disease five years back. Additionally  his father had a history of venous thromboembolism. Mr. Doe has been moderately active and denies a history of any long-term immobilization.   Current Medications:  1. Lisinopril (10 mg) oral daily for hypertension 2. Atorvastatin (20 mg) oral daily for hyperlipidemia   Allergies:   No known drug allergies.  Social History:   Married  two children  non-smoker  occasional alcohol use. Mr. Doe reports no illicit drug use  and he maintains a diet and exercise regimen to manage his health issues.  Conclusion:  Considering Mr. Doe's symptoms like sudden onset of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  fainting  and his presence of risk factors such as age  history of heart disease  and underlying hypercoagulable states  a probable diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism is suspected. Urgent diagnostic tests including D-dimer  arterial blood gas analysis  CT pulmonary angiogram  or V/Q scan  will be beneficial to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate management. Immediate attention to this patient is crucial as the condition can be fatal.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Robert Johnson  who presents to the emergency department with symptoms consistent with an acute pulmonary embolism. Of note  Mr. Johnson had recently returned home from a transatlantic business class flight of 8 hours.  Vital Signs: Upon arrival  his vitals showed a heart rate of 112 beats per minute  blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute  pulse oximetry reading of 90% on room air  and a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F).   Chief Complaint: Mr. Johnson described a sudden onset of shortness of breath accompanied by sharp  pleuritic chest pain that occurred earlier in the morning. He also reported experiencing a mild  dry cough but denied any hemoptysis.  Past Medical History: His medical history revealed that he is a well-controlled type 2 diabetic on Metformin  has hyperlipidemia  which is managed by a statin  and hypertension being controlled effectively by ACE-inhibitors. He also mentions a remote 30 pack years smoking history  but quit 15 years ago.   Family History: There is no family history suggestive of any hereditary thrombophilias but he reports of his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.   Social History: He lives with his wife  works as a financial consultant  and has no history of alcohol or illicit drug use. The patient reported significant sedentary lifestyle owing to his desk-bound job and long flights.  In summary  considering the patient’s recent long-duration flight  sedentary lifestyle and the abrupt onset of his symptoms including dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain  there is a high suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic tests are being perform to confirm this diagnosis and appropriate management will be initiated promptly.

Patient Presentation  Patient Profile:  Name: Ms. Jane Doe Gender: Female Age: 52 Occupation: Accountant Ethnicity: African American Residential Status: Urban Resident Marital Status: Divorced Health Insurance: Private  Presenting Problem:  Ms. Doe is a 52-year-old African American female accountant presenting with a sudden onset of severe chest pain  shortness of breath and light-headedness.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Doe has a history of obesity and hypertension  which she manages with diet and anti-hypertensive medications  respectively. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. She had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) two years ago  after undergoing a hip replacement surgery. Since then  she has been on a prophylactic anticoagulant therapy. However  she was recently been forced to discontinue the anticoagulant due to excessive menstrual bleeding. Ms. Doe also has a family history of pulmonary embolism  as her mother had a fatal PE at the age of 60.  Current Medications: - Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg for hypertension - Pravastatin 40 mg for hyperlipidemia  Physical Examination:  Upon a quick physical examination  Ms. Doe appears distressed and anxious due to the difficulty in breathing. Vital signs show tachypnea and tachycardia. Auscultation of her lungs reveals diminished breath sounds. Her oxygen saturation stands at 90% on room air. Her right lower limb is swollen and tender on palpation suggestive of deep vein thrombosis.  This clinical picture  combined with her past medical history and recent discontinuation of anticoagulant therapy  raises the suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism. We plan to confirm diagnosis through D-dimer testing and a CT pulmonary angiogram  and then decide the suitable line of management for Ms. Doe.

Patient Presentation: We have Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired truck driver. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes daily medication. He also has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  for which he underwent treatment five years ago. Currently  he is not on anticoagulation therapy.   Chief Complaint: The patient presents with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain  which he describes as a sharp pain that intensifies with deep breaths.   History of Present Illness: The patient began to feel unwell three days ago with progressive dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain. He denied any recent long-distance travel  surgery or immobilization. There were no reported lower limb pains or swellings. He has no known allergies.   He has been hypertensive for the past ten years  which is managed with medication; losartan 50 mg daily. He also has hypercholesterolemia which is managed with simvastatin 20 mg daily. He quit smoking ten years ago but has a past history of 40 pack years. He does not consume alcohol. He lives with his wife and leads a sedentary lifestyle post-retirement. He does not partake in any regular physical activity. Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease - his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58.  Physical Examination: On examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic with an elevated heart rate 120 beats/min  respiratory rate of 26 breaths/min  blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  and SpO2 of 92% on room air. Lung auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. Heart sounds were tachycardic but no murmurs. The abdomen was soft  non-tender with no organomegaly. There was no calf tenderness or swelling.   Impression: Based on these findings  there is a high clinical suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism. Considering his previous DVT history  combined with his current symptoms of pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea  this condition must be ruled out immediately. Further diagnostic testing  including D-dimer  arterial blood gases  troponin  computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiography should be performed  and treatment initiated as per guidelines. His sedentary lifestyle and history of DVT places him at significant risk for PE.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 52-year-old African-American female who presents with acute respiratory distress and chest pain. Her symptoms started abruptly two days ago while at rest and have progressively worsened. The pain is sharp  localized to the central part of her chest and it intensifies with deep breathing. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  fainting spells  and a recent episode of hemoptysis. She denies fever  cough or recent travel. She has not undergone any recent surgeries or trauma. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol.  Past Medical History:  She has a notable past medical history of obesity (BMI 32) and hypertension for which she has been taking Amlodipine 5mg daily for the past 10 years. She was diagnosed with Type II diabetes five years ago and has been on Metformin 500mg BID since then. Her paternal aunt had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the past but she denies any other significant family history of coagulopathies. Her last menstrual period was 20 years ago with surgical menopause due to hysterectomy for fibroids reports no use of oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy.  Weighing together the sudden onset of symptoms  her obesity  hypertension  diabetes  and a family history of DVT  this patient is at a high risk of pulmonary embolism. Further evaluation with a D-dimer test  CT pulmonary angiogram  and echocardiogram  if needed  are warranted to confirm the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism so that prompt intervention can be initiated.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 52-year-old African American male by the name Mr. Jones. Mr. Jones is a manager at a local firm and lives with his wife and two kids. He has presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of difficulty in breathing and a sharp  stabbing chest pain that becomes worse with deep inhalation.  Past medical history:   According to the records available  Mr. Jones has been a diagnosed case of hypertension for the last eight years and type II diabetes mellitus for six years. He is also a known patient with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) diagnosed three years ago and has been intermittently compliant with his prescribed anticoagulation treatment. Mr. Jones also has a 30-pack-year smoking history  but he quit smoking two years ago. He is relatively sedentary in terms of physical activity due to his desk job and is slightly overweight with a BMI of 28. There is also a history of familial cardiac diseases; his father passed away due to myocardial infarction at an early age.  Current Medications:  For his hypertension  Mr.Jones takes Lisinopril 10 mg daily and Amlodipine 5 mg daily. His diabetes is managed through twice-daily injections of 50/50 Humulin 25 units before breakfast and dinner and Metformin 1000 mg 2 times a day. To manage his DVT  he has been prescribed Warfarin dosed to maintain INR between 2-3 but he has been irregular with his clinic appointments and labs.  Allergic History:  Mr. Jones has an allergy to Penicillin  which causes him to have a rash.  Today's observation and provisional diagnosis:  Based on his symptoms of chest pain  sudden onset of shortness of breath alongside his personal history of DVT and intermittent anticoagulation  there is a strong suspicion that Mr. Jones is experiencing an Acute Pulmonary Embolism.  The patient has been stabilized and is currently undergoing further diagnostic procedures to confirm the diagnosis. Early indications from the EKG and D-dimer tests suggest probable pulmonary embolism. We intend to proceed with a CT pulmonary angiography for definitive diagnosis and thereafter will update the family members about his condition. Mr. Jones's condition  although serious  is managed in a timely manner.   His past issues with medical compliance indicate that thorough patient education may be needed to ensure adherence to future medical recommendations  particularly if long-term anticoagulation is deemed necessary.

Patient Presentation:  Patient's Name: John Doe Age: 55 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Computer Programmer Location: Miami  Florida  Present Issue:  Mr. Doe presented to our emergency department with sudden onset difficulty in breathing and chest pain that began earlier in the day. He describes the pain as sharp in nature  located at the center of the chest  and gets worse with deep breathing. There's been no trauma or injury. He also reports occasional dizziness but denies any recent leg swelling or pain  cough  fever  or palpitations. He has never experienced these symptoms before.  Past Medical History:  He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he is on amlodipine 5mg daily and atorvastatin 20mg daily respectively. He is a former smoker and quit about 5 years ago. He quitted alcohol about 2 years ago. He has no known drug allergies. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 60 and his mother suffered from diabetes mellitus. No history of clotting disorders or PE in his family.  Lifestyle:  Mr. Doe lives alone and works from home. His diet consists mainly of home-cooked meals and he engages in minimal physical activities. He maintains regular follow-ups with his primary physician for his chronic conditions.  In conclusion  considering Mr. Doe’s abrupt onset of symptoms  particularly the acute onset of breathlessness and chest pain worsening on deep inspiration  an immediate assessment for a possible pulmonary embolism seems to be appropriate.

Title: A Case of Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: Mrs. Elizabeth Turner is a 68-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  currently residing in San Rafael  California. She is non-smoker  social drinker  with fair exercise routine and balanced diet. She has a BMI of 27.  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Turner arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain  and a productive cough with blood-tinged sputum. These symptoms started approximately 3 hours prior. She also reported feelings of anxiety and mild dizziness.   Past Medical History: Mrs. Turner has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her left leg about two years ago during a flight back from Australia. She underwent treatment with anticoagulants and compression stocking therapy. Currently  she is on ongoing Metformin for the diabetes. There is no documented history of cancer  heart disease  or pulmonary diseases.   Family History: She has a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases  with both her parents succumbing to heart-related conditions. No known genetic disorders.  Social History: She lives alone since her husband passed away 6 years ago. She has two daughters who live in the same city  who she visits often and they also check on her regularly. She admits to having a glass of wine once or twice a week and has never smoked.  Review of Systems: She has been struggling with her diabetes but manages to control it with medication and diet. She has no known drug allergies. No clinical depression  substance abuse  or mental illnesses reported.  On review of her clinical symptoms  previous medical history of DVT  and family history of cardiovascular diseases  the preliminary diagnosis pointed towards acute Pulmonary Embolism. Due to her symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  and hemoptysis  PE was considered a potential life-threatening condition  and emergent management was instigated.

Patient Presentation:  I am presenting Ms. Paula Jefferson  a 65-year-old Caucasian female who was brought to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The symptoms began while she was watching television at home  with no physical exertion involved. Upon arrival  the patient appeared anxious  had a rapid heart rate of 110 beats per minute  a blood pressure of 135/80 mmHg  and saturations of 88% on room air.  Ms. Jefferson's past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which she takes lisinopril  and obesity with a body mass index of 32. She does not have diabetes  coronary artery disease  or any known lung disease. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. She worked as a flight attendant for 30 years  requiring her to be on her feet for long periods and to take frequent long-haul flights.   She underwent a total knee replacement surgery about two weeks ago and has been immobile since then. Her post-op recovery had been uneventful with no issues of wound infection. In terms of her family history  her father died of myocardial infarction at 72  and her mother died at 80 due to an unknown cause. She has no siblings.  The patient had no other symptoms such as fever  cough  hemoptysis  or leg swelling. Clinically and based on her recent immobility due to surgery  she is at high risk of developing venous thromboembolism. An immediate computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiogram was ordered and has confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Given that she is hemodynamically stable  without any contra-indications  she has been started on low molecular weight heparin for initial immediate anticoagulation  and oral anticoagulation has also been started.  In summary  Ms. Paula Jefferson is a 65-year-old woman with an acute pulmonary embolism  likely secondary to prolonged immobility post knee surgery.

Title: Presentation of Acute Pulmonary Embolism Patient  Patient Name: Mr. John Doe   Age: 58 years  Gender: Male  Address: 123 Main Street  Boston  Massachusetts   Occupation: Network Engineer   Marital Status: Married  Presenting Complaint:  John presented with sudden onset of dyspnea  chest pain  and coughing up blood  which started two hours before he arrived at the emergency department.  Past Medical History:  John has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right leg that occurred five years ago. He has been taking warfarin since then. He also has a 10-year history of type II diabetes mellitus and has been on metformin. There is also a previous history of hypertension  managed with lisinopril  for the past 15 years. He had a myocardial infarction approximately eight years ago  which was managed medically.   Physical Examination:  On examination  John appeared anxious and distressed. His temperature was 98.6°F  pulse was 110 beats/minute  blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  respiratory rate was 22 breaths/minute and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Upon auscultation  breath sounds were reduced in the right lower lobe and he had a rapid heart rate.   Laboratory Parameters:  His blood glucose level was elevated (200 mg/dL)  likely secondary to his underlying diabetes. His INR (international normalized ratio) was subtherapeutic at 1.8. A D-dimer test was positive.  Imaging and Diagnostics:  A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) revealed a clot in the right pulmonary artery  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.   Risk Factors:  John's risk factors for developing pulmonary embolism include his history of DVT  prolonged immobility due to his sedentary job  obesity (BMI of 30)  diabetes  and hypertension.  Treatment:  John was started on intravenous heparin for immediate anticoagulation.   Follow-up:  Given his history of DVT and now a PE  an outpatient appointment with a hematologist will be necessary for further evaluation of possible underlying thrombophilia. Long-term anticoagulation will be considered.  In conclusion  Mr. John Doe  a 58-year-old with a significant history of vascular conditions was diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism  likely resulting from his multiple risk factors. The patient recognises the need for lifestyle modifications to support his ongoing management.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. John Keto  is a 65-year-old African-American male who presents at the emergency department with dyspnea  chest pain  and slight hemoptysis. He reports sudden onset of symptoms which commenced approximately 6 hours prior to presentation. Mr. Keto indicates the pain is worse when taking a deep breath or coughing. Initial examination reveals tachypnea and tachycardia.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Keto has a significant past medical history which includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He was diagnosed with these conditions 10 years back and has been on antihypertensive (lisinopril) and statin (atorvastatin) medication since then. He has a BMI of 30 indicating obesity and  as a result  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago. He has been managing it with oral hypoglycemics. He quit smoking about 3 years back  had smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years. According to his records  he underwent a knee replacement surgery two weeks back and has been mostly bed-bound since. There is no known history of allergies.   Medical assessment:  Initial assessment and vital signs suggest an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). Given his recent surgical procedure and extended period of immobility  Mr. Keto is at high risk for a thromboembolic event. Chest computed tomography angiogram (CTA) and D-dimer test confirmation are pending. He will receive immediate anticoagulation therapy and will be monitored in the hospital's ICU for further management.

Patient Presentation  Name: Mrs. Jane Doe Age: 60 Sex: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher  Presenting Complaint: Mrs. Doe presents with sudden onset shortness of breath  intermittent chest pain  feeling lightheaded  cough producing blood-tinged sputum  and a rapid heart rate that started a few hours ago.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Doe is a known case of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and takes warfarin regularly. She had a bilateral knee replacement 3 months ago  after which she presented with DVT and was managed accordingly. She has hypertension and high cholesterol  which are well-controlled with medication. She has never smoked  consumes alcohol socially  and has no allergies documented. Family history includes father and brother with heart disease.  Review of Systems: Respiratory: Denies any chronic cough  wheezing  or asthma.  Cardiac: Has high cholesterol and high blood pressure regularly controlled by medication. Denies any previous heart attacks.  GI: Denies any occasional abdominal or GI discomfort.  Neurological: Denies any headache or syncope.   Physical Examination: Upon examination  Mrs. Doe appears distressed. She is tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm. Her blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg  her respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute  and her oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Auscultation of the lung fields reveals decreased breath sounds bilaterally. No audible heart murmurs. Her calves are non-tender without signs of DVT. Her skin is warm  dry  and good turgor.  Impression/Diagnosis: Given the patient’s presentation  history of DVT  and physical examination findings  acute pulmonary embolism is highly suspected.  Management Plan: The management plan will be to stabilize the patient's cardiovascular status with oxygen support  and to initiate anticoagulation therapy while further diagnostic tests (D-dimer assay  CT pulmonary angiography) are being conducted to confirm the diagnosis. Patient would be closely monitored in the ER and would be considered for ICU admission depending on the clinical status and lab results.

Title: Presentation of Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Female Patient  Good morning  our patient today is Mrs. L.S  a 54-year-old African American female  who resides in Minneapolis  MN. She is married with two children. She works as a financial consultant in a reputable firm.  Past Medical History: Mrs. L.S has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) from 3 years ago. She also has hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes mellitus  and is obese with a BMI of 32. She is currently under medications including Warfarin for DVT  Metformin for diabetes  and Lisinopril for hypertension. She smokes about a pack of cigarettes per day and admits to consuming alcohol occasionally.   Presenting Complaint: Over the past 3 days  Mrs. L.S has been experiencing sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that aggravates while taking deep breaths  and episodic fainting spells. She has also mentioned feeling light-headedness  lower limb swelling  and rapid heart rate.  Physical Examination: On examination  she seemed anxious  with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and a pulse rate of 100 beats per minute. Auscultation reveals decreased lung sounds on the right side  SpO2 is 92% on room air. Her BP is 130/85 mm Hg. Lower limb examination revealed mild swelling on the left side.  Impression: Based on her past medical history  symptoms and physical examination  an Acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE) is suspected.   Plan: Immediate diagnostic testing  including a D-dimer test  CT pulmonary angiography and a lower extremity venous ultrasound  are planned to confirm the suspected PE. Consult a pulmonologist for further management. Considering her recurrent thrombotic event  evaluation for hereditary thrombophilias is recommended. Patient education to quit smoking  eat healthier  and increase physical activities may help lower her risk for future PE.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics:  Sex: Female  Age: 61 years old  Race: African American Occupation: Retired schoolteacher Location in ED: Room 17   History of Present Illness: The patient presents with sudden onset  sharp and severe pleuritic chest pain which started 2 hours ago. She also endorses shortness of breath  with no associated fever  chills  nausea  or vomiting. The pain does not radiate and does not vary with position. She has not had a cough  recent surgery  or a long trip. There is no noted hemoptysis  night sweats or weight loss. She denies any recent leg pain or swelling. The patient denies any tobacco  alcohol  or recreational drug use.   Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension - Diagnosed 10 years ago and is currently well controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Diagnosed 5 years ago  currently being managed with metformin. 3. No known drug allergies.  Family History: 1. Mother had hypertension; died from myocardial infarction at 73. 2. Father had hypertension and diabetes; died from stroke at age 70.  3. Younger brother is living with hypertension.  Social History: The patient is retired and lives alone. She is very active in her community  she has no history of smoking  alcohol use or illicit drug use. She used oral contraceptive pills for 20 years and has been on hormone replacement therapy since menopause.  Physical Examination: The patient was found to have a mildly elevated respiratory rate (22 breaths per minute)  pulse oximetry of 93% on room air  and normal blood pressure and heart rate. Her physical examination is notable for clear lung fields  regular cardiac rhythm without murmur  and no calf swelling or tenderness.   Given her presentation  an acute pulmonary embolism is suspected  and further diagnostic workup and management will be necessary.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient also reported intermittent lightheadedness and palpitations.   His demographic information is as follows:  ● Age: 68 years old ● Sex: Male ● Race: Caucasian ● Origin: United States ● Occupation: Retired  former civil servant ● Marital status: Married ● Insurance: Medicare  Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) for which he was hospitalized two years ago. He is currently not on any form of anticoagulation treatment. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes and controlled hypertension. Mr. Doe had an appendectomy at age 22 and was a heavy smoker for 40 years before quitting 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and has no known drug allergies.   Family history reveals a sibling who suffered a stroke in their late 50s and both parents had hypertension and passed away from heart-related conditions.  Initial Physical Examination:  On arrival to the emergency department  initial vitals were blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg  pulse 115 bpm  respiratory rate 24/min  and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. He appeared anxious and distressed. On auscultation  his breath sounds were slightly diminished on the right side.   The patient was immediately placed on supplemental oxygen and further diagnostic tests were ordered to ascertain the situation  keeping in mind the urgent priority to rule out conditions like acute pulmonary embolism given his symptoms and past medical history.

Title: Case Presentation – Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Profile: The patient is Mr. John Smith  a white 65-year-old male residing on the upper east side of New York City. He is married  retired as a banker  and has two adult children. His past medical history includes controlled hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypercholesterolemia  and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 2 years ago.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset of severe chest pain that began around 2 hours prior to arrival. The pain was described as 'sharp-stabbing'  located on the right side of his chest  and worsened with deep breathing. Accompanying symptoms included shortness of breath  light-headedness  and a sense of 'impending doom'. He denied any recent travel  surgery  cough  fever  or trauma.  Physical Examination: On examination  he was tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.4 degrees Fahrenheit  and blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. He appeared to be in moderate distress. Cardiovascular exam revealed tachycardia but no murmurs. Pulmonary exam was notable for decreased breath sounds on the right lower lobe. Extremities showed no signs of deep venous thrombosis. The remainder of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Assessment: Given his symptoms  clinical picture and medical history  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE) was highly suspected. Investigations including chest radiograph  electrocardiograph  arterial blood gas analysis  and D-dimer assay were sent immediately. CT angiography was subsequently done  which confirmed the diagnosis  showing a clot in the right lower lobar artery.  Plan: He was immediately started on anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Due to the history of DVT  cardiologists and hematologists have been consulted to evaluate the need for long-term anticoagulation and to rule out any underlying hypercoagulable state. The patient was admitted to the Cardiac Care Unit for close monitoring and further management.  In summary  Mr. Smith's sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath  coupled with a history of DVT  led to a rapid diagnosis of acute PE. Prompt initiation of anticoagulation therapy was vital to reduce his risk of further clot formation and complications.

Title: Case Presentation- Acute Pulinary Embolism  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 64-year-old African American male  presents to the Emergency Department with complaints of sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath. He is a non-smoker and moderately obese with a BMI of 31. His previous medical history reveals well-managed hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He does not have any known allergies  and he lives with his wife. His family history reveals his father had a stroke at the age of 70.  Presenting Complaint: The patient reports experiencing sudden onset  sharp  localized pain in the right side of his chest that increases severity with deep breaths. Accompanied by this  he also mentions a feeling of breathlessness and lightheadedness since this morning. He denies having any cough  hemoptysis  or fever. He denies symptoms suggesting a urinary or gastrointestinal tract infection.   Past Medical History: He has well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes. History of medication includes Metformin and Losartan regularly. There's no previous history of similar episodes  hospitalizations or surgeries.  Examination: Upon physical examination  he appears breathless with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His pulse rate is 102 bpm  and his blood pressure measured 140/90 mmHg. Oxygen saturation levels were found to be low at 92% on room air. Auscultation revealed reduced breath sounds in the right lower lung field.  Impression: Considering the described sudden onset of localized chest pain  shortness of breath  tachycardia  with clinical signs of right-sided pleuritic chest pain  and hypoxia  these findings are suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Plan: Further confirmatory testing with D-dimer  CT pulmonary angiogram planned. Upon confirmation of diagnosis  start on an anticoagulant for management of pulmonary embolism. Also  manage possible risk factors such as obesity and recommend weight reduction program. Prolonged immobilization to be avoided and suggest a more active lifestyle. Follow-up appointments are recommended to ensure progress.

Patient Presentation:  Patient's Name: Mr. Andrew Thompson Age: 52-years old Sex: Male Marital Status: Married Ethnicity: Caucasian Address: New York Occupation: Manager  Chief Complaint: Mr. Thompson was brought to the emergency department complaining of sudden chest pain and shortness of breath started an hour ago.   Medical History:  Mr. Thompson has a past medical history of chronic hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and sedentary lifestyle. He had myocardial infarction 2 years ago for which he required coronary artery bypass graft surgery. He was given a prescription for aspirin  beta-blockers  and statins  which he reports he takes regularly.  Family History: There's a history of cardiovascular disease on both sides of the family - his father had a stroke at the age of 59 and his older sister was diagnosed with angina.   Social History:  Mr. Thompson has a history of smoking  but he has stopped 3 years ago. He admits to moderate alcohol consumption. He works in a high stress environment  spends long periods seated due to nature of his job.  Examination:  On examination  his blood pressure was 160/100 mmHg  pulse rate 120/min  respiratory rate 24/min  temperature 37.0°C  oxygen saturation 88% on room air. He exhibited signs of tachypnea and tachycardia. Heart sounds S1 and S2 were normal with no murmurs noted. Lungs had decreased breath sounds in the lower parts bilaterally. He displayed signs of peripheral edema.  Impression: Considering the worsening of shortness of breath  the chest pain and his past medical history  an Acute Pulmonary Embolism is suspected and further examinations and diagnostics are ordered to confirm the diagnosis and provide proper treatment.

Patient Presentation  I am here today to present Mr. John Simons  a 65-year-old Caucasian male who is exhibiting features of acute pulmonary embolism (PE). He was brought to the emergency department today morning with acute onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and a cough producing large amounts of blood-tinged sputum.   Regarding the patient's past medical history  he was diagnosed with hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus 15 years ago  which he has been managing with medication - Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes. This patient also reports a history of deep vein thrombosis three years ago for which he was treated with Warfarin for 6 months. Over the past few months  he has been leading a fairly sedentary lifestyle due to the COVID-19 lockdown. Mr. Simons is a former smoker  quitting 10 years ago  after a 30-year history of a pack per day habit.   On physical examination  he appears dyspneic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg  heart rate is fast and irregular at 110 beats per minute  and his oxygen saturation on room air is 88% (Normal: >95% on room air). His physical examination is remarkable for decreased breath sounds and crackles in the right lung.
