Given his sudden onset symptoms  his previous history of deep vein thrombosis  and his current physical findings  there is a high clinical suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism.   The initial diagnostic approach will include arterial blood gas test  chest X-ray  and ECG alongside the definitive diagnostic test - CT pulmonary Angiography. Following the diagnosis  the patient will require immediate anticoagulation therapy. His condition is treatable but serious  and rapid intervention is needed to protect against potentially fatal complications.

Patient Presentation:  Today we will be discussing Mr. John Roberts  a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents with an acute pulmonary embolism. He was brought to the emergency department today by his wife  who noticed him gasping for breath and appearing increasingly disoriented.  His main complaints are experiencing sudden shortness of breath  chest pain which worsens with deep breaths  and a feeling of lightheadedness. He reports a sudden onset of symptoms which has progressively worsened over the course of two hours.  Mr. Roberts is a former smoker having quit a decade ago after smoking one pack a day for about 30 years. He has a remarkable past medical history  including type II diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia which is being managed with Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin respectively. He had a myocardial infarction (MI) 5 years ago but seems to have good compliance with his medications and lifestyle changes since then.   He has a surgical history of right total hip arthroplasty due to severe osteoarthritis one month back. He reports good functional status prior to this event. There is no known family history of thrombotic or clotting disorders but his father died at a young age from a myocardial infarction.  He denies alcohol or recreational drug use but acknowledges sedentary lifestyle due to recent surgery and long-term desk job.  Given these symptoms  his recent surgery  and his existing risk factors  he has been diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism. He has been started on anticoagulant therapy in the emergency department  and the interventional radiology team have been alerted for possible thrombolytic therapy.

Slide 1: Introduction  Today  we will discuss the case of a patient with Acute Pulmonary Embolism. This condition involves a clot or obstruction in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lung  a serious condition that can cause heart damage or death.   Slide 2: Patient Presentation   Our patient is a 65-year-old  Caucasian male named John. He presented with sudden shortness of breath  chest pain  and a bloody cough. He also reported recent leg swelling and pain. A sudden onset of these symptoms often characterizes Acute Pulmonary Embolism.   Slide 3: Demographics and Lifestyle   John is a retired engineer  living in the suburbs and is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago. He is a social drinker and is physically inactive for most of the day  which can pose a risk for PE due to long periods of immobility.   Slide 4: Past Medical History   John has a history of chronic hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are under control with medication. However  John had undergone a total hip replacement surgery two months ago.  Slide 5: Risk Factors   Risk factors that may have contributed to the development of John's condition include:  - Advanced age - Surgery: His recent hip replacement puts him at heightened risk for clots  specifically deep vein thrombosis  which can travel to the lungs and cause PE. - Sedentary lifestyle - Chronic hypertension  - History of smoking  even though he quit years ago - Obesity  Slide 6: Conclusion   Given the patient's symptoms and medical history  we have established that the sudden onset of chest pain  shortness of breath and a bloody cough are likely caused by acute pulmonary embolism. Appropriate diagnostic tests and timely treatment are crucial in managing the condition and increasing survival rates.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with a sudden onset of sharp chest pain  shortness of breath  and cough. The patient mentioned that he has been relatively immobile for the past two weeks due to a recent knee replacement surgery. The pain started approximately 30 minutes prior to presentation and has been constant  with no alleviation or exacerbation factors. Associated symptoms include mild dizziness and faintness.   He does not have any known allergies. He has a past medical history of hypertension  for which he takes daily medication. He had undergone right knee replacement surgery two weeks ago. There are no reports of a similar event in the past.  The patient's family history is notable for his father  who died of a stroke at age 75; his mother  who is alive and has been diagnosed with hypertension.  He is a former smoker  having quit 5 years ago. There is no history of illicit drug use or excess alcohol consumption. The patient currently lives with his wife and has been adhering to the rehabilitation program given post-knee surgery.  In conclusion  based on the clinical presentation  the sudden onset of symptoms along with a history of recent surgery and immobility  the diagnostic suspicion is strongly oriented towards an acute pulmonary embolism. Further examination and investigation are needed to confirm this diagnosis and to assess the patient's overall clinical status.

Patient Presentation:   Demographics:  Mr. A is a 56-year-old Caucasian male who presents with an acute onset of shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he takes atenolol and atorvastatin respectively. The patient is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year history but quit smoking five years back. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He used to be physically active until his recent hip replacement surgery about a month ago  after which he has been fairly sedentary. Mr. A has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father dying at the age of 62 from a heart attack.  Present Complaint:   Mr. A reports that the shortness of breath started abruptly today while resting at home. He describes it as feeling like he can’t get enough air. Associated symptoms include a dull  vague chest pain  dry cough  light-headedness  and leg swelling. He denied any nausea  changes in consciousness  or diaphoresis. He has no known allergies and is currently not on any other medications apart from his regular ones.  Assessment:   Upon physical examination  Mr. A’s vital signs revealed tachycardia and tachypnea with low oxygen saturation levels on room air. His blood pressure was within normal limits and he was afebrile. His lower extremities showed pitting edema  particularly on the right side which was operated on.  Based on his recent history of surgery  prolonged period of inactivity  the presence of risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  age  and family history of cardiovascular disease  differential diagnosis will consider an acute pulmonary embolism. Diagnostic tests such as D-dimer  computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)  and Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities will be requested to confirm the diagnosis.   If the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is confirmed  treatment will include therapeutic anticoagulation such as low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)  direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs)  or warfarin depending on the severity and the risk of bleeding. The patient would also receive supplemental oxygen  and management of the leg swelling may involve compression stockings. Regular follow up would also be necessary to monitor the efficacy and side effects of the treatment.

Presentation of Patient with Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old African American female named Mrs. Sarah Jefferson who resides at 245 Springhill Drive  Los Angeles. She is retired and a widower with two adult children residing out of state. Her primary language is English  and she has a moderate level of education  having obtained a bachelor's degree. She is a non-smoker and occasionally drinks alcohol socially.  Medical History: Mrs. Jefferson has a significant past medical history including hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes  both of which have been controlled by medication for the past 15 years. She also has a three-year history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and receives regular inhaler therapy for this. Her mother died from a stroke and her father from a heart attack.  Current Presentation: On the morning of 20th June  2022  Mrs. Jefferson presented to the ER with acute onset of chest pain  shortness of breath and light-headedness. The pain was sudden  stabbing in nature  localized at the center of the chest and radiating to the left arm. It worsened with deep breaths  and was accompanied by a sense of impending doom. The patient reported a constant 7/10 pain which lasted for approximately a few hours prior to her arrival at the ER.  Additional Remarks: Records also indicate that Mrs. Jefferson had a recent trip that required prolonged sitting (a 12-hour flight to visit her son in Australia) and her mobility at home has been limited due to a sprained ankle  thereby increasing her risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  a common source of pulmonary embolism. Also  the patient's family history of cardiovascular diseases  her hypertension and diabetes  in combination with her current symptoms  strongly suggest a critical thromboembolic event such as acute pulmonary embolism. A CT angiography has been ordered to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Geoffrey Sanders  a 56-year-old African American male  presented to our emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain and cough with bloody sputum. He was traveling alone and there are no immediate family members available for collateral information.  He has a known history of hypertension  for which he is on amlodipine  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is well-controlled on metformin. He also suffered from a left calf deep vein thrombosis (DVT) two years ago and has a 15-year history of smoking. Patient was taken off anticoagulation after six months of his DVT diagnosis. He has no history of any surgeries. He is currently a real estate agent and denies any recent extended periods of travel or immobility.  On arrival  the patient is in obvious distress. He is tachycardic (Heart rate - 110 bpm) and tachypneic (Respiratory rate - 22 breaths per min)  with oxygen saturation of 90% on room air  temperature of 37°C  and blood pressure of 130/80 mm Hg. He has no allergies and there is no family history of blood clots or malignancy.  A diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is highly suspected given his symptoms and history. Further confirmatory imaging and lab tests  including D-Dimer  CT pulmonary angiography  chest x-ray  arterial blood gas  and ECG  have been ordered.   In terms of immediate management  the patient has been started on Oxygen therapy and parenteral anticoagulation pending the result of these investigations. Early mobilization will be planned as a long-term strategy  in addition to lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation  and eventual transition to oral anticoagulation  most likely a novel oral anticoagulant (NOAC)  unless contraindicated.  His hypertension and diabetes will also continue to be managed appropriately. He will need close monitoring for the development of any complications and to assess for any conditions that may have predisposed him to this event.  Follow-up with a hematologist may also be considered to rule out any underlying thrombophilia state.

Presentation Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism: A Clinical Case Study   Patient Overview:  We are discussing the case of Mr. Jenkins  a 56-year-old African-American male patient who presents with symptoms of Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE). He is currently employed as a truck driver  a lifestyle which involves long periods of immobility. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially.   Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Jenkins enters the clinic complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and palpitations that started approximately two hours ago. The pain is noted to be pleuritic in nature  worsening with deep breaths. He also reports a feeling of light-headedness but denies any loss of consciousness  cough  or hemoptysis.   Past Medical History: Upon review of his medical history  Mr. Jenkins was diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago and is currently under medication (amlodipine 5mg daily). However  his compliance to medication is inconsistent due to his job demands. He hasn't had any previous incidences of similar symptoms and his surgical history is unremarkable. His father had a history of deep vein thrombosis and there is a family history of Factor V Leiden  thus raising suspicion for a genetic predisposition to thromboembolic events.  Vitals at Presentation: On examination  he is anxious  pale  and diaphoretic. His vitals reveal tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  tachycardia with heart rate 110 bpm  blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  an oxygen saturation at 88% on room air  and temperature is normal at 37.1°C (98.8°F).  Summary: We are led to suspect Acute Pulmonary Embolism in Mr. Jenkins due to sudden onset dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain  tachycardia  tachypnea and family history of thromboembolic events. Today we'll discuss the diagnostic approach and management strategies as we aim to confirm the diagnosis and treat this potential APE effectively.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Post-Operative Patient  Patient Presentation: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  who presented to the emergency department with acute onset of shortness of breath and chest pain.  Demographics: He lives in a suburban environment with his wife  is a retired bank manager  and maintains a sedentary lifestyle. He neither smokes nor consumes alcohol. No known drug allergies reported by the patient.  Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension and type-II diabetes mellitus  both adequately controlled on medication: Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension and Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes. His family history is significant with a father dying of a stroke at 67 and mother suffering from rheumatoid arthritis. No history of pulmonary disease in the first degree family history.  Present Complaint: Over the last 24 hours  the patient has experienced sudden onset chest pain that has worsened with deep breaths  along with a persistent shortness of breath. The pains are severe  stabbing in nature and central in location. No exacerbating or relieving factors were identified by the patient. He also recalls feeling light-headed and having episodes of cold sweats. However  he denies any cough  hemoptysis  or recent sick contacts.  Recent Events: The patient had a total knee replacement surgery 10 days ago due to advancing osteoarthritis.   Physical Examination:  Upon examination  the patient was found to be anxious and noticeably dyspneic. Vital signs were as follows: BP – 135/85 mmHg  HR - 110/minute  RR - 22/minute  Temp – 98.6 F  SpO2 - 90% on room air. Auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds in the lower right lung field. His cardiovascular  abdominal  neurological examinations were unremarkable  and post-operative knee surgical wound was healing well.  Impression: Considering the patient's recent surgical history  his sedentary lifestyle  and the sudden onset of his symptoms  an acute pulmonary embolism is highly suspected.  Further Investigation: Computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) and D-Dimer tests are planned for the confirmation of the acute pulmonary embolism. Concurrently  venous Doppler ultrasonography for deep vein thrombosis detection will be performed given his recent surgery. The patient needs close monitoring and should anticoagulation be confirmed necessary  it should be started as soon as possible.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 60-year-old African-American male who presents to the emergency department of our health facility. He presents with a six-hour history of sudden-onset severe chest pain. The chest pain is centrally located  constant and depends on his breathing. He also states associated symptoms such as sudden onset of shortness of breath or dyspnea  cough  and mild hemoptysis. He also describes dizziness and episodes of fainting spells.   He denies fever  but reports subjective sense of chills and sweating. He also denies recent travel  surgeries or prolonged periods of immobility. He has no known drug allergies.  Demographic Information:  Mr. Johnson lives with his wife and one of their children in a nearby suburb. He is a retired civil engineer and his family history reveals his father experienced a similar episode in his late sixties. He is an ex-smoker with a history of high blood pressure and type II diabetes mellitus. He drinks alcohol only during festivities.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has been managing his hypertension and diabetes for the last 14 years. He was diagnosed with both conditions during his yearly check-up at the age of 46. Since then  he has been on a regimen of 1 tablet of amlodipine 5mg daily for BP and 1 tablet of metformin 500mg twice daily for his blood sugar. His last completely normal check-up was about three months ago.   Given his symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  and history of hypertension and diabetes  he was evaluated for a possible cardiac event. However  despite the signs and symptoms suggesting a myocardial infarction  an acute pulmonary embolism was considered due to sudden onset  its dependence on his respiration and the presence of hemoptysis. More precise assessments  which are recommended  should include D-dimer test  Computed Tomographic Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA)  or a ventilation-perfusion (VQ) scan to confirm the diagnosis.   In conclusion  Mr. Johnson represents a classic case of possible acute pulmonary embolism and further investigations are needed to confirm the diagnosis. Immediate measures will be taken to prevent further clotting and steps to dissolve the current clot are needed to limit damage to the lungs.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 62-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. Susan Bloom  who has presented to the emergency department with symptoms consistent with an acute pulmonary embolism. She has a BMI of 28  indicating that she's overweight  and she's a non-smoker.  Mrs. Bloom visited complaining of sudden onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and light-headedness for the few past hours. On assessment  her vitals were: blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate 110 bpm  respiration rate 25/min  oxygen saturation 92% on room air.   The patient has a significant past medical history. She is known to have systemic hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been under moderate control with her medications. She reports good compliance with her antihypertensive and lipid-lowering drugs.   Six weeks ago  Mrs. Bloom underwent a total hip arthroplasty due to osteoarthritis. She was anticoagulated at that time but the anticoagulation was stopped one week after the surgery. The typical risks associated with a recent surgical procedure  inactivity and her symptomology all suggest that an acute pulmonary embolism should be considered.  Her family history is also notable. Her father had coronary artery disease and her mother had a stroke. This adds up to her risk of having a thromboembolic disease. Her social history features living alone  being retired and having limited mobility due to the recent surgery.  Immediate diagnostic tests have been ordered  including D-dimer  CT Pulmonary Angiogram and ECG.   That is our current standing with Mrs. Bloom. We are initiating treatment immediately given the strong suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism. With her age  recent surgical history  limited mobility  and her symptomatic presentation  she's a high-risk patient and we are getting the results of the ordered labs and tests to confirm diagnosis and treatment plans.

Title: A Case Presentation on Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Profile: The patient is a 65-year-old male named Mr. Stuart reporting recent onset of shortness of breath and acute chest pain that is exacerbated with deep respirations  suggesting pleuritic chest pain. The patient also reports feeling light-headed but has not experienced any episodes of syncope. He has a history of long plane travel having recently returned from an international flight a week prior. His body mass index is 28 indicating overweight. He is a former smoker and reports moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History: Mr. Stuart has been previously diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension. He is on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and takes daily low-dose aspirin for cardiovascular prophylaxis. He does not have any prior history of surgery or prolonged immobilization. He also does not report any previous clot-related issues either personally or in his family history.   Current Presentation: On arrival  the patient appears anxious and diaphoretic with reported symptoms of severe acute chest pain and shortness of breath. On examination  he has an increased heart rate (tachycardia) around 105 beats per minute and slightly increased blood pressure (140/90 mmHg). Oxygen saturation is low at 92% on room air. There are no abnormal signs identified on lung auscultation and abdominal exam is normal.   Preliminary Diagnosis: Given the patient's report of recent long-distance travel  sudden onset of symptoms  and the nature of his presenting symptoms  our preliminary diagnosis is an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). This diagnosis will be confirmed with further investigations including a D-dimer test  followed by imaging tests like a CT Pulmonary angiography if needed. Meanwhile  the patient should be started on empirical treatment for PE considering the risk vs benefit favoring treatment.

Patient Presentation:  We have a 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J.M  who presents with sudden onset dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain  and light-headedness.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J.M has been under treatment for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the last 10 years. He is overweight  with a BMI of 28  and has a 40 pack-year smoking history. His mother had a history of a deep vein thrombosis. The patient does not report any history of surgery or trauma recently but does mention that he recently had a long-haul flight about a week ago.  Medications:  Mr. J.M's pharmaceutical regime includes Lisinopril 10mg Daily for his hypertension and Atorvastatin 20mg Daily for hyperlipidemia. He is also taking low dose Aspirin as per cardiovascular disease prevention guidelines. Mr. J.M is compliant with his medications and does not report any known allergies.  Clinical Exam:  On inspection  the patient is in acute distress  appearing anxious and slightly cyanotic. The patient's BP is 130/80 mmHg  Pulse 110 bpm with an irregular rhythm  and respiratory rate is 24 breaths/minute. His temperature is within normal limits. Oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. A pulmonary exam reveals tachypnea and decreased breath sounds in the right lower lobe. Heart sounds are tachycardic with no murmurs. His extremities are warm. There is mild ankle edema  and his calves are symmetrical with mild tenderness on the right side.  Plan:  The clinical presentation combined with this patient's risk factors creates a high suspicion for a possible Acute Pulmonary Embolism. The plan is to get a D-dimer  Troponin  ABG  Chest X-ray  and ECG as these initial investigations. The patient should be placed on supplemental oxygen immediately to decrease his hypoxia. The primary treatment plan for now includes anticoagulation therapy. Depending on the severity of his condition and initial test results  further imaging tests like CT Scan  V/Q Scan  or Pulmonary Angiography may be required.   This is a time-sensitive critical situation. Patient safety and comfort are prioritized  ensuring all necessary steps are promptly taken to confirm the diagnosis and start appropriate management.

Title: Acute Pulinary Embolism Case Presentation  Introduction: Our patient is a 63-year-old African American female  known as Patient X  who presents with symptoms suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Demographics: Patient X is known to be a non-smoker  living in an urban setting in Atlanta  Georgia. She is a retired school teacher  and she lives alone. She does not consume alcohol and has no known drug allergies. Her body mass index is within the normal range  suggesting she is not obese.  Past Medical History: Patient X has a significant past medical history of hypertension  controlled adequately with Lisinopril 10mg daily. She was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus about five years ago. Her glycemic control has been well-managed with metformin 500mg twice daily. For her hyperlipidemia  she is on simvastatin 10mg daily at night. She underwent total knee replacement surgery on her right knee about three months ago.  Presenting Complaint and History of Present Illness: Patient X presents with sudden onset shortness of breath which started two hours prior to presentation. The shortness of breath is associated with mild chest pain described as 'tightness' in the center of her chest. She also has a productive cough with white sputum but denies any hemoptysis. There is no history of recent trauma or infection. She reports low-grade fevers but no chills.  Physical Examination:  The patient appeared comfortable at rest but evidencing respiratory distress upon minimal exertion. Vital signs were Blood Pressure 140/90 mmHg  Pulse 105 bpm  Respiratory Rate 22 breaths per minute  Temperature 98.6°F and Oxygen Saturation 92% on room air. No cyanosis or jaundice was noted. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia with regular rhythm and no audible murmurs. Respiratory examination indicated diminished breath sounds over the right lower lung field.  Conclusion:  Given her recent history of major surgery (total knee replacement)  the acute onset of her symptoms  and the physical examination findings suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism  it was deemed necessary to initiate measures for immediate management while confirming the diagnosis with further investigations.

Subject: Mrs. Anita Thompson  a 72-year-old caucasian female  Residential Status : Lives alone in a two-story home  in the suburban part of the town. Moderate accessibility to medical facilities.  Presenting Vital Information: Unstable vital signs upon admission. Blood pressure: 148/90 mmHg  Heart rate: 115 beats per minute  Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation: 84% on room air.  Chief Complaint: Mrs. Thompson presented to the ER with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness that developed over a few hours.  Medical History: Mrs. Thompson has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she is on medication. She was also diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 5 years ago. Recently  she underwent a total hip replacement surgery on the right side 6 weeks ago. Regarding her lifestyle  she was a smoker with a 30 pack-year history but has been abstinent for the last 10 years. She drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use.  Family History: She has a family history of cardiovascular diseases with her father passing away from a myocardial infarction and her sister having a stroke.  Social History: She is a retired school teacher  a widow with 3 children who live interstate. She has a small circle of friends but remains socially active within her community.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  she appeared anxious  sweaty  and dyspneic at rest. Cardiac auscultation revealed tachycardia and an irregular rhythm consistent with her history of atrial fibrillation. Lung auscultation was notable for decreased breath sounds in the lower right lung field. She had mild pedal edema on the right side.  Diagnosis: Based on the patient's recent surgical history  symptoms  and physical examination  an initial diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is suspected. Emergent investigations including D-dimer assay  contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest or V/Q scan are in order to confirm the diagnosis.  Plan: Mrs. Thompson was started on high-flow oxygen via non-rebreather mask and will be closely monitored in intensive care. Anticoagulation therapy will be initiated once the diagnosis is confirmed. Further management decisions will be based on the patient's hemodynamic stability and result of diagnostic tests.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Male Patient with Hypertension and Obesity  Patient Profile: Mr. John Harris  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  is presenting with acute respiratory symptoms indicative of a possible pulmonary embolism. He was born and raised in Chicago  Illinois  has worked as a bank manager for over 30 years and has been leading a sedentary lifestyle for the past few years. He reports non-compliance to a balanced diet and physical activity  admitting to consume fast food more often.  Medical History: Mr. Harris has a registered history of systemic hypertension for the last 15 years  maintained on angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. He was diagnosed as obese (BMI 31.5) during a routine health examination 5 years ago but did not take significant measurements to control it barring a brief period of dietary regulations. He denies any history of smoking  alcohol consumption  diabetes  or hyperlipidemia. His family history is significant  with his father  who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and maternal uncle who had a stroke in his late 50s. There is no known history of hematological disorders in his family.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Harris came to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp chest pain  feeling faint and an episode of blood-tinged sputum  lasted for 2-3 hours. The symptoms reportedly started while he was at rest  watching television. The symptoms are not alleviated upon rest or change in position.   Physical Examination: On examination  he showed signs of distress  tachypnea (24 breaths/min)  and increased pulse rate (110 beats/min). His blood pressure measured 140/95 mmHg  a bit heightened  and oxygen saturation was 92%. Lung examination revealed decreased breath sounds in the lower left lung field. No noticeable leg swelling or signs of deep vein thrombosis were observed.  Preliminary Diagnosis: The patient's medical history  his risk factors including sedentary lifestyle  obesity  hypertension  and the current clinical symptoms like sudden onset of dyspnea  chest pain  tachycardia  hypertension  and hemoptysis primarily suggest the presence of an Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE).   Further Evaluations: Immediate investigations including D-dimer test  chest X-Ray  and Computed Tomographic Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) are recommended for confirmation. Upon confirmation  Mr. Harris would likely require anticoagulation therapy and lifestyle modifications to manage his condition and reduce the risk of future events.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Geriatric Patient  Presenting Patient:   Mr. Thompson  a 75-year-old African American male  presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain is pleuritic in nature and gets worse on deep inspiration.  Demographics:  Mr. Thompson is a retired teacher living in the urban area of Philadelphia. He is widowed and lives with his older son. He has a history of moderate alcohol use but quit smoking 10 years ago.   Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson has a significant medical history that includes hypertension (HTN)  type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)  and was hospitalized for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago. His diabetes and HTN are well-controlled with metformin and losartan respectively. He also takes tamsulosin for his BPH condition. He does not report any allergies.  Clinical Picture: Upon examination  the patient appears to be in moderate respiratory distress. His body mass index (BMI) is 28  indicating overweight. Vital signs reported are: Blood Pressure 150/90 mmHg  Pulse rate 110 per minute  Respiratory rate 28 per minute  Oxygen saturation 90% on room air  and Temperature 98.6F. Electrocardiogram (EKG) shows signs of right ventricular strain and labs reveal slightly elevated troponin levels. D-dimer levels came back as well-above normal which raises suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism.  These clinical features paired with his history of DVT increase the probability of an acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  which can pose as immediate threat to his life. The patient was immediately put on non-invasive ventilation and started on therapeutic doses of Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH). The team has ordered a Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) to confirm the diagnosis.   In light of this  Mr. Thompson's treatment plan will be further adjusted based on image findings and his response to initial pharmacological intervention. His son has been notified of his condition and the potential next steps and the team awaits the CTPA results to confirm diagnosis and devise the specific management plan.

Subject: Presentation of a patient with acute pulmonary embolism  Patient Information: The patient is a 57-year-old Caucasian male named Jack Thompson. He is height 5’10”  weighs 220 pounds  and is a construction worker by profession. He lives with his wife and has no children. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history and reports a sedentary lifestyle. There is no family history of genetic disorders.   Past Medical History: The patient has previously been diagnosed with high blood pressure (hypertension) and type 2 Diabetes. These conditions have been managed with prescribed medications (Lisinopril 10mg/day and Metformin 500mg twice a day  respectively) and a recommended diet. He had a right knee replacement two months ago. His medical records also show a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) diagnosed eight years ago which was treated with anticoagulation therapy.   Presenting Complaint: The patient was brought into the ER with sudden onset difficulty in breathing  chest pain that got worse with deep breathing and a sensation of 'racing heart'. He also reported feeling light-headed.  On physical examination  the patient was in acute distress with an increased heart rate (tachycardia) and increased rate of respiration (tachypnea). His blood pressure was slightly elevated (140/90 mmHg).   Based on his symptoms  medical history and physical examination  the patient was diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism.  In conclusion  considering the patient's past medical history and his recent surgery  the likeliness of pulmonary embolism increases. Regular follow-ups  medication adherence  lifestyle modifications and regular physical therapy post-surgery  could have been the possible deterrents for this condition. However  the immediate need is to stabilize the patient and treat the embolism aggressively. Regular counselling regarding the importance of follow-ups and medication adherence will be part of the patient's hospital course. It will be recommended for the patient to undergo a genetic counselling to rule out any genetic propensity towards clot formations.

Patient Presentation  Mr. James Alberts is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  who was brought into the Emergency Department with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain that worsens with deep breathing  and a low-grade fever for the past 24 hours. James lives with his wife in their suburban home in the heart of Miami. He has been a lifetime smoker  averaging about a pack per day and has a sedentary lifestyle – since retiring from his accounting job 5 years ago. He also reported recently traveling on a long-haul flight  which lasted for more than 8 hours.  Mr. James’s current medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he is on hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin  respectively. He was also diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago and manages it with metformin and a controlled diet. Additionally  he underwent a total knee replacement surgery a month ago and was on bed rest for several days after the procedure.   His family history is also significant. His mother died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 72  and his younger sister was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis. No known genetic disorders have been documented in the family. He has no known drug allergies but he is a self-reported heavy drinker.  Physical examination showed tachypnea  tachycardia  and slightly decreased oxygen saturation on room air. Blood pressure and body mass index are within normal range for his age and gender. Lungs were clear bilaterally on auscultation but with decreased breath sounds on the right lower lobe.  The patient's history of recent orthopedic surgery  along with his pronged immobilization  lifestyle choices  and presenting symptoms highly suggest an acute pulmonary embolism. Immediate intervention and further diagnostic testing have been recommended.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  has presented himself at our hospital's Emergency Department. He appears to be in visible distress  and anxious due to his current health condition.  Patient Complaints:  Mr. Doe reports sudden onset shortness of breath and intermittent chest pain for the past several hours. He ranks the pain's intensity at 7 of 10 and describes it as a sharp  sudden discomfort felt most intensely when he tries to breathe deeply or coughs.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a documented history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  for which he has been on oral anticoagulation therapy in the past. He also has been diagnosed with hypertension and Type II diabetes  both of which have been relatively well managed with medication. Mr. Doe's father had a history of pulmonary embolism and his mother had a history of stroke.   Social History:  Mr. Doe has a 30-pack year history of smoking and quit approximately 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. He lives with his wife and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his retirement.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  the patient is anxious  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg  and oxygen saturation of 92 percent on room air. Lung auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds at the left lower lobe. Cardiac examination is regular without murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Lower extremity examination shows no obvious signs of DVT such as swelling or redness.  Based on the medical history  current symptoms  and physical examination  the foremost clinical suspicion is of an acute pulmonary embolism that needs immediate action. Further tests like D-dimer  chest imaging (CT pulmonary angiogram)  and possibly echocardiogram for right ventricular strain would be imminent. Treatment will likely involve anticoagulation and possibly thrombolysis  depending on the severity of the embolism.

Patient Presentation:  We are discussing Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with acute onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and cough productive of blood-tinged sputum. He is a retired mechanical engineer and resides in Los Angeles  California  with his wife. He enjoys golfing during his spare time  but his physical activity has been significantly reduced these past few months due to his symptoms. Mr. Smith is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago after a pack-a-day habit for approximately 30 years. He denies alcohol or drug usage.  Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history including hypertension controlled with lisinopril and amlodipine  type 2 diabetes managed with metformin  hypercholesterolemia managed with simvastatin  a previous myocardial infarction five years ago with successful angioplasty and stent placement  and a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a hip replacement surgery two years ago. In addition to the aforementioned medications  he takes aspirin 81 mg daily and has been on chronic warfarin therapy since his DVT.   Recently  Mr. Smith had a prolonged plane trip (approximately 10 hours) two weeks ago  following which he noticed swelling in his right calf  which has now subsided. Yesterday  he started experiencing sudden  sharp chest pain and dyspnea which got worse on deep inspiration. The sputum became bloody this morning  prompting his visit to the emergency room.   Upon initial evaluation  his vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 bpm  an oxygen saturation of 89% on room air  and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. His physical examination is notable for tachypnea  right-sided lower lobe inspiratory crackles on chest auscultation and a swollen  tender right leg.  The presentation is consistent with acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  perhaps secondary to DVT. Further clarification will be obtained from a d-dimer test  lower extremity venous doppler ultrasonography  and CT-pulmonary angiogram as per protocol. Immediate management with anticoagulants has been initiated based on the clinical suspicion of PE.

Patient Presentation:  A 56-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain  shortness of breath and dry cough since last two hours. He also mentions feeling lightheaded with an episode of fainting beforehand. He rates his pain as 8/10  with the pain worsening on deep inspiration.  Past medical history (PMH):  The patient is a 20 pack-year smoker and has a history of hypertension which is inadequately controlled. He recently underwent a total knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago. No known drug allergies. There is a family history of blood clots; his mother had deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Past surgical history: Recent right total knee arthroplasty 2 weeks ago  appendectomy in 1994  no other surgeries.   Personal history: He is a current smoker with 20-pack years. Occasional alcohol user but denies any illicit drug use. He works desk job and has a sedentary lifestyle.   Review of systems: The patient also reports feeling fatigued in the last two days and mild swelling in his right lower limb  suggesting DVT. Denies fever  cough or gastrointestinal complaints.   Medications: Atenolol  aspirin  and a multivitamin each day.   Physical examination: Blood pressure: 140/90mmHg  Pulse: 108 bpm  Respiratory rate: 24 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation: 90% on room air. He appears anxious and in respiratory distress. There is a mild swelling and tenderness in the right lower limb. Lung examination reveals decreased breath sounds at the left lung base with no wheezing or crackles. No signs of deep vein thrombosis in the left lower extremity.   Given this patient's recent surgery  sudden onset of symptoms  and family history of blood clots  acute pulmonary embolism is strongly suspected and immediate diagnostic testing will be started.

A 65-year-old African-American female presents to the emergency department complaining of an acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath of several hours’ duration. She describes the pain as sharp  non-radiating  and worsening with deep inspiration. She also reports feeling light-headed  says her heart feels like it's 'racing ' but denies any cough  fever  or leg swelling. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and a left total knee arthroplasty performed 3 weeks prior  for which she was discharged home on aspirin. She has never smoked  does not consume alcohol  and has no known drug allergies. There is no family history of hypercoagulable disorders. She is a retired schoolteacher and lives with her husband. Her medications include lisinopril  hydrochlorothiazide  and low dose aspirin.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Jones is a 65-year-old African American male with a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) who presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and faintness for the past 3 hours. He also mentions that he has been coughing up a small amount of blood-streaked sputum. He denies any recent surgeries  injuries or long durations of travel. Upon further questioning  Mr. Jones admits to non-adherence with his anticoagulant medication regimen for the past 1 week due to financial constraints.  The patient's past medical history includes obesity  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. His regular medication regimen includes metformin  ramipril  atorvastatin  and warfarin. Mr. Jones is a non-smoker and occasional alcohol consumer. His family history is significant for DVT as his mother had a similar condition.   On physical examination  he has tachypnea with respiratory rate 26/min  elevated heart rate at 110 beats per minute  blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg  and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Upon auscultation  breath sounds are normal in both lungs with no wheezing or crackles noted. His lower extremities also show no signs of swelling  redness or palpable cords. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Due to his symptomology and prior medical history  acute pulmonary embolism is suspected and he will undergo diagnostic testing  including D-dimer  contrast-enhanced CT  and echocardiography. Given his conditions  he may also require cardiac biomarker evaluation to assess the severity and possible cardiac implications. His treatment plan will include re-initiation of anticoagulant therapy and possible thrombolytic therapy  as well as addressing his non-compliance with medication due to financial constraints.

Patient Presentation:  A 58-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department expressing complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens on deep inspiration. Furthering the examination  it is noted the patient is visibly anxious  diaphoretic  and experiencing tachycardia with a recorded pulse rate of 105 bpm. He reports episodes of hemoptysis and a feeling of faintness.  Demographic Details:  He is a smoker with a 20 pack-year history. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is within the overweight category  at 28.1 kg/m2. He is a building contractor by profession and follows a sedentary lifestyle outside his job. The patient reports long distance travel recently  with extended hours of immobility.  Relevant Past Medical History:  His past medical history reveals a prior deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 6 years back for which he was on anticoagulants but discontinued them as instructed. He also has a history of hypertension and rheumatoid arthritis for which he takes ibuprofen regularly. Neither diabetes nor any other significant family history of similar condition is present. No allergies are reported.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath for the past 10 hours. The patient also reported experiencing a sharp  stabbing chest pain that intensifies with deep breaths. The review of symptoms additionally included mild palpitations  light headedness  and a syncopal episode earlier in the day. No significant history of cough  sputum production  or hemoptysis was reported. She denied fever  nausea  vomiting  or pain elsewhere.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of deep vein thrombosis 3 years ago  for which she was treated and switched to aspirin. She has a past history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled with diet and medication. She had a remote history of smoking up to a half pack/day for 30 years but quit about 15 years ago. She is not currently on any hormonal therapies. Her mother passed away due to stroke in her early 70s. The patient has no known allergies. The patient flew back from a long-haul flight from Europe about 2 days ago.  She does not consume alcohol and has no history of drug use. She performs light physical activities like gardening and takes daily walks in the park. Her weight/BMI appeared to be within the healthy range.   Current Medication:  Aspirin 81mg daily  Lisinopril 20mg daily Atorvastatin 40 mg nightly

Patient is a 50-year-old Caucasian female presenting with an abrupt onset of dyspnea and mild pleuritic left-sided chest pain that started approximately 24 hours ago. She also reports a sense of apprehension and occasional coughing  but denies hemoptysis.  The patient has a significant history of obesity with BMI 35 kg/m2  hypertension  and her mother had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after a long airplane trip at a similar age. She stopped her oral contraceptives about a year ago when she was diagnosed with hypertension. She recently underwent a right knee arthroscopy due to a sports injury which limited her mobility for two weeks. She is currently not on any anticoagulant therapy.  She does not drink alcohol or use any illegal substances. She quit smoking 15 years back  previous smoking history of 1 pack per day for 10 years. She lives alone  has a sedentary job  and has recently completed a long-distance car travel to visit her family.  Physical examination shows the patient is anxious  and tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/minute. Her pulse is 110 bpm  blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation on room air is 92%. Lung examinations reveal decreased breath sounds at the lower left lung. There is no leg swelling  redness  or tenderness.  This presentation is suspicious for acute pulmonary embolism and she requires immediate diagnostic assessment. Due to her recent immobility  combined with her other risk factors  this is the working diagnosis to further evaluate.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain is described as sharp  stabbing  occurring over the last two hours and radiating to her back. She rates the pain at an 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. Her breathlessness has increased over the last week  but has abruptly worsened today. She also reports associated light-headedness and unilateral swelling and pain in her right calf.  The patient's medical history indicates she underwent a total hip replacement 4 weeks ago. Her medication includes hormone replacement therapy (Estrogen) which she has been using for her menopausal symptoms over the last 5 years. She smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years but quit 5 years ago. She does not have any known allergies. There is no family history of blood clotting disorders. Her vital signs on presentation include an elevated heart rate to 115 beats per minute  blood pressure of 125/80 mmHg  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. The patient lives alone at home and is quite independent in her daily activities.

Patient Presentation:  A 60-year-old Caucasian female presents to the Emergency Department complaining of acute sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain worsening with deep inhalation  and a sense of anxiety. The symptoms began approximately 4 hours ago  and the patient notes that she has never experienced anything like this before. The patient also reports increased fatigue over the last few days.  Demographics and Past Medical History:  The patient lives in the local area with her retired husband  is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year history  quit 5 years ago  and regularly consumes alcohol in moderation. She does not use illicit drugs. She had a prior unprovoked deep venous thrombosis (DVT) 10 years ago and was on warfarin for six months following that event. She has been off anticoagulation since then. Her only other past medical history is of hypertension which is well controlled with lisinopril. She has a history of sedentary lifestyle and has recently lost her job due to the ongoing pandemic  which has caused her stress. She denies recent surgery  immobilization  or travel. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease but no known inherited coagulation abnormalities. Her complete blood count  coagulation studies  and renal function from her routine health checkup last month were within normal limits. The patient also tested negative for COVID-19 one week back.

Patient Presentation: A 62-year-old Afro-Caribbean man presents to the emergency department with a one-day history of sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp  unilateral chest pain which worsens with deep breaths. The patient also notes that he has been feeling light-headed and has had episodes of coughing  with some streaks of blood in the sputum. The patient denies fever  recent travel history  or sick contacts. He has no allergies. His pulse is 100 bpm and oxygen saturation is 90% in room air.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and stage 2 chronic kidney disease. He also has a previous history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 3 years ago following a hip replacement surgery for which he was on warfarin for a period of 6 months. He stopped smoking 2 years ago but has a 30 pack-per-year history of smoking. He is currently on Lisinopril  Amlodipine  and Atorvastatin.   Family History: Patient's father had a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. His mother is alive and well in her 80s.  Social History: The patient is a retired civil engineer  married with two kids. He lives at home with his wife and occasionally consumes alcohol in a social setting. He quit smoking two years ago  after a long history of tobacco use over three decades.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the Emergency Department. He describes an acute onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and a noticeable feeling of a rapid and irregular heartbeat. He reports that these symptoms started suddenly a few hours prior to presentation  while he was watching television at home. He also mentions a slightly increased overall feeling of tiredness and fatigue over the past week  which he initially believed was due to his stressful work schedule.  Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a hip replacement surgery 5 years ago  for which he was treated with anticoagulants for 6 months. He has a 30 pack-year history of smoking that he quit 10 years ago. The patient also has high blood pressure controlled with medication  and he was diagnosed as overweight with a BMI of 30.  Family History:   familial history of blood clots  with his father suffering a pulmonary embolism at age 70  and a paternal aunt diagnosed with DVT. His mother has a history of cardiac diseases and his sister is diabetic.  Social History:  The patient lives with his wife and denies any alcohol or drug abuse. He used to be a professional truck driver which involved hours of prolonged sitting but retired 3 years ago.  This medical  family  and social history along with the acute onset of symptoms might suggest a possible Acute Pulmonary Embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for obesity  recent hip replacement surgery two weeks ago  and chronic atrial fibrillation for which he is not therapeutically anticoagulated  presents to the emergency room with acute onset shortness of breath which started at rest. The dyspnea was associated with a 'stabbing' chest pain that intensified upon deep inhalation. He also mentioned feeling lightheaded and experiencing a brief episode of syncope this morning. He denies any recent travel or family history of clotting disorders but admits noncompliance with post-op exercises prescribed after his hip surgery.   His vital signs include a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure of 125/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 24 bpm  temperature of 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. On physical examination  the patient seems anxious and diaphoretic  with slightly cyanotic lips. He also has swollen and tender right calf with redness. His heart sounds reveal tachycardia and a loud pulmonic component of second heart sound. Lung auscultation demonstrates decreased breath sounds at the base of the right lung. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Thompson is a 65-year-old African-American female with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  stage II breast cancer for which she underwent surgery and completed chemotherapy 8 months ago. She presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of sharp  right-sided chest pain  and shortness of breath that started about 6 hours ago. She also reports associated symptoms of light-headedness  palpitations  and a faint episode at home. She denies cough  fever  or leg swelling. She has been maintaining her health with good compliance to medication but noticed increasing fatigue over the past week. Her family history is significant for a cousin with pulmonary embolism. She lives alone and has been relatively inactive recently. She quit smoking 10 years ago and rarely drinks alcohol. She was not on any prophylactic anti-coagulation post-chemotherapy.   On examination  vital signs reveal tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 beats/min  blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  oxygen saturation 92% on room air. She appears in mild distress  diaphoretic with central cyanosis. Pulmonary examination reveals tachypnea and decreased breath sounds on the right lower lung field. Heart sounds are regular with a prominent pulmonic component of the second heart sound. No peripheral edema is noted  but there is a slight erythema on her right calf  which is warmer than the left.  Due to her acute symptoms and risk factors including her history of cancer  sedentary lifestyle  and obesity  the physician suspects an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 64-year-old African American female who presents to the emergency room complaining of intense  sudden onset discomfort in the left side of her chest which started approximately 3 hours ago at home. She describes the chest pain as sharp  radiating to her left shoulder and neck.  Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  slight dizziness  and a cough that has brought up small amounts of blood. She denies any fever  nausea  vomiting  or diastolic sweat. She also denies any recent long travel or immobility.  She has a past medical history significant for hypertension and heart disease. She quit smoking ten years ago  after having smoked a pack a day for 30 years. She admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in fats and sodium.  Family history includes her mother with a stroke at 70  a father with a heart attack at 68  and a younger brother with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at 50.  Current medications include Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension and Aspirin 81mg daily for heart disease prevention. She has no known drug allergies.  On physical examination  her blood pressure is slightly elevated at 142/88 mmHg  pulse is elevated at 102 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 26 breaths per minute  temperature is 98.8 degrees Fahrenheit  and O2 saturation is 90% on room air. On auscultation  lungs reveal decreased breath sounds in the left lung base. She appears dyspneic  anxious  and diaphoretic.  Given the patient’s history  symptoms  and physical examination findings  acute pulmonary embolism is suspected. Further diagnostic evaluation is warranted.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain that began a few hours ago. The pain is sharp  rated 8/10 severity  increases with deep breaths and is located in the mid-sternal region. He also reports a dry cough and feeling faint.  Regarding his past medical history  he has a diagnosis of hypertension  controlled with lisinopril  and a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) episode 3 years ago. He mentions that he has been sedentary for the past few days after a knee surgery. He is a former smoker  quit about 10 years back. He denies any other chronic conditions and denies ever having similar symptoms in the past. He has no known drug allergies.   His family history is significant for stroke in his mother and myocardial infarction in his father. He is retired  lives with his wife  and is quite active in his daily activities. He has been adhering to his medication and other lifestyle modifications. He consumes alcohol socially.   Given his history of DVT  recent knee surgery and recent change in activity level  an acute pulmonary embolism is suspected. Further diagnostic testing is suggested.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian female patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset chest pain radiating towards the back and dyspnea. She describes the chest pain as a sharp and constant  scoring it a 7/10 in intensity. Her dyspnea has been progressing over the past 2 hours. She also reports a non-productive cough  light-headedness  and palpitations. Denies fever  nausea  vomiting  or recent illnesses. She also noticed slight swelling of her right leg but denies any recent trauma or injury.  She is a former smoker and quit smoking 10 years ago. She consumes alcohol socially. She doesn’t use recreational drugs. She lives alone and is independent in all her daily living activities.   Relevant medical history: She has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation for which she is on warfarin. However  she admits to not taking her medication regularly over the past month. There's also a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She underwent a total knee replacement of the right knee six months back.  Family history suggests her father had a myocardial infarction in his sixties and her mother had a stroke in her seventies. She has two grown-up children who are healthy.   She is currently taking warfarin  amlodipine  and atorvastatin. She is allergic to sulfa drugs.  Upon examination  she appears uncomfortable and anxious. Her vital signs are notable for tachycardia (heart rate 110 bpm)  tachypnea (respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute)  and decreased oxygen saturation (92% on room air). She exhibits clear breath sounds bilaterally but with decreased breath sounds in the lower right lung field. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable  besides mild swelling and slight tenderness in her right calf.  Given the patients' symptoms  history of atrial fibrillation  non-compliance with her anticoagulation medication and recent orthopedic surgery  the emergency department has a high degree of suspicion for pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Jones is a 65-year-old Caucasian woman who presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep breaths. She reports the symptoms began 3 hours prior to presentation. She denies cough  fever  or known COVID-19 exposure. She also reports a left calf pain over the past 2 days which she initially attributed to muscle strain.   Ms. Jones recently underwent a major abdominal surgery 3 weeks ago after being diagnosed with colon cancer  and has been on bed rest at home since then. Her surgical course was unremarkable and she was released after 5 days in hospital. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs. She takes a daily aspirin and bisacodyl  prescribed by her primary care physician.   She does not report a family history of blood clotting disorders.   On physical examination  she appears anxious and in respiratory distress. Her vitals show tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  mild tachycardia with a heart rate of 103 beats per minute  normal blood pressure  and pulse oximetry shows 92% saturation on room air. Auscultation reveals normal breath sounds bilaterally with no signs of congestive heart failure. Her left calf appears mildly swollen and tender on palpation.  These findings along with the patient's recent history of major surgery  prolonged immobility  and sudden onset of unexplained shortness of breath and chest pain raise a high index of suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. A is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset shortness of breath which has been progressively worsening over the last 4 hours. She reports a sharp  constant chest pain that radiates to the back and gets worse on deep breaths. She also notes experiencing episodes of lightheadedness. She denies any cough  fever  or other respiratory symptoms.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Ms. A is a known smoker with a 40-pack year history. She has a significant medical history including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a previous deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 6 months ago whilst undergoing total knee arthroplasty.  She admitted to poor compliance with her DVT prophylaxis medication due to gastrointestinal upset. She has no known drug allergies. She lives alone and is relatively sedentary. She denies any recent travels or prolonged periods of immobility. Family history includes a brother who had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 60.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Buchanan is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain which is sharp and radiates to the back. He describes the pain as 'worse on inspiration.' The symptoms started earlier this morning  becoming progressively worse  prompting him to come to the hospital. He also mentioned a mild cough with blood-streaked sputum.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are controlled on medication. He had a right hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years and consumes alcohol occasionally. His mother died of a stroke  and his father had a coronary artery disease.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  pulse rate 110/min  respiratory rate 28/min  and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. There is slight distension of the jugular vein. Auscultation of the lungs reveals decreased breath sounds in the right lower lobe. His right leg is slightly swollen compared to the left.   Given his recent surgery and symptoms  he is suspected of having acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic workup is planned  including blood tests (D-dimer)  chest CT scan and leg Doppler ultrasound. His current medications include atorvastatin and lisinopril. Measures to maintain his oxygen levels  such as supplemental oxygen  are started immediately.

Patient Presentation:  A 55-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  and mild hemoptysis. She describes the dyspnea and chest pain as progressively worsening over the last three to four hours. She rates her pain as 6-7 out of 10 and says it becomes sharper with deeper breaths.   The patient also reports recent right leg swelling and a mild feeling of discomfort for about a week. She has a known medical history of obesity (BMI 33 kg/m2) and hypertension  for which she takes ramipril 5 mg daily. She also sustained a right leg fracture two weeks prior for which she underwent surgery and has been bedridden during recovery.  The patient recalls her father having a deep vein thrombosis in his 50s. She has no history of smoking  alcohol  or illegal drug use. She has a sedentary lifestyle with minimal involvement in physical activities. The patient reports her shortness of breath is exacerbated by mild exertion and relieved by rest. She denies any fever  chest tightness  or wheezing.  On examination  the patient looks anxious and pale. Her heart rate is 110 beats per minute  blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  respiration rate 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 94% on room air  and temperature 37.5 degrees Celsius.  Overall  looking at the provided history  our main differential would be an acute pulmonary embolism  likely secondary to deep vein thrombosis due to recent surgery and immobilization.

A 65-year-old Caucasian woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that started about 3 hours ago. The pain is pleuritic in nature and rates an 8/10 on the severity scale. She also describes a sense of impending doom.  She has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) for which she had been on Warfarin until a year ago when she decided to stop medication on her own. She has a past surgical history of left hip replacement 2 years back. She is a nonsmoker and denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. Her mother succumbed to a stroke at old age  but nothing else remarkable was reported in the patient's family history.   On examination  her vital signs are recorded as: Blood Pressure - 150/90 mm Hg  Pulse - 110 bpm  Respirations - 22 per min  Oxygen Saturation - 92% on room air  and Temperature - 98.2 F. She appears anxious and diaphoretic. Cardiovascular and respiratory examinations reveal tachycardia and decreased breath sounds on the right lower side of the chest  with increased respiratory rate. Lower limb examination indicates slight swelling  redness  and tenderness of the left calf.   These presentations  together with her risk factors - being sedentary  past history of DVT  discontinuation of anticoagulant therapy  surgery history  and age - all contribute to a strong suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain and shortness of breath that started approximately 2 hours ago. The pain is described as sharp  located in the middle of the chest and radiating to the neck region. On a severity scale of 0 to 10  the patient rates his pain as an 8. He also reports feeling lightheaded and a sense of impending doom. He further mentions experiencing a low-grade fever with night sweats and unexplained weight loss in the last month.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he takes amlodipine 5mg daily  type 2 diabetes managed with metformin 500mg twice daily  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his right lower leg 2 years ago  for which he was treated with warfarin but discontinued 6 months ago on his own. He does not smoke  drinks alcohol occasionally  and denies any illicit drug use. He admits to noncompliance with his medications and has a sedentary lifestyle. His father died of stroke at age 73  and his mother had a heart attack at age 66.  Physically  his vital signs are critical with a blood pressure of 90/60mm Hg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. On physical exam  he is anxious and he appears sweaty and in distress with marked respiratory effort. Auscultation reveals tachycardia and decreased breath sounds on the left side of the chest. Lower extremity examination shows slight swelling of the right calf with mild tenderness. No signs of trauma or injury are observed.  These symptoms suggest acute pulmonary embolism  likely stemming from history of DVT and discontinuation of anticoagulation therapy. Immediate intervention and evaluation include ruling out other causes of chest pain and dyspnea  anticoagulation therapy  and further risk stratification.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain which is getting worse with deep breathing  and light-headedness. The shortness of breath started a few hours ago and has progressively worsened. The patient also reports feeling faint and breaking out in cold sweats. He denies any cough  fever  or recent travel.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) post right total knee replacement surgery 4 years ago  which was treated with warfarin for 6 months  followed by aspirin prophylaxis. He also has hypertension controlled with lisinopril and hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin.  The patient is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history  but quit smoking 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially  and denies any illicit drug use. He lives with his wife  is retired  and usually is physically active.  Review of systems is otherwise negative with no recent illnesses or exposures. Family history reveals his father had a myocardial infarction in his late sixties  and his mother had a cerebrovascular accident. His only sibling  a brother  had DVT following a long-haul flight.  Current Medications:  1. Lisinopril 20mg once daily for hypertension 2. Atorvastatin 40 mg at bedtime for hyperlipidemia 3. Aspirin 81 mg once daily for DVT prophylaxis.

Patient Presentation:  A 55-year-old African American male presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that started two hours ago. The pain is located in the right side of the chest and radiates to the lower portion of the neck and right shoulder. The pain seems to intensify with deep breaths but does not worsen with movement or position change. The patient also reports lightheadedness  a rapid heart rate  and cough that started last night with blood streak sputum.  The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and deep vein thrombosis (treated 6 months ago). He had a right hip replacement surgery 10 days ago. He was on anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin) after the DVT diagnosis but had temporarily stopped the medication as per his orthopedic surgeon's instructions pre-operatively for hip surgery.  He is a current smoker with a 30 pack/year smoking history  and his father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 63. He denies any use of illicit drugs or alcohol. He works as a bank manager and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  He takes Atorvastatin 20 mg daily  Lisinopril 10 mg daily.   The patient is clearly anxious about his symptoms and worried about their implications. He denies fever  night sweats  or recent travel. His vital signs on arrival were temperature of 98.6 F  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air.   Given his symptoms  the patient was urgently evaluated for acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with sudden onset dyspnea  sharp  stabbing chest pain that is worsened with inspiration  a dry cough  and feelings of apprehension.  Demographic Details:  The patient is retired  living at home with his wife. He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago. His consumption of alcohol is reported as being minimal. He does not have any known allergies.  Relevant Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hypertension  treated with Lisinopril 10 mg daily  and hyperlipidemia  managed with a statin. He also reports a previous episode of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) in the leg following a long-haul flight approximately 3 years ago  which was managed with oral anticoagulants. He also underwent a right hip replacement surgery 2 weeks ago. His family history includes father passing away from a stroke at 75 and a mother passing from a myocardial infarction at age 68.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Hispanic female was brought to the emergency department with a 2-day history of sudden onset  sharp chest pain. The pain is primarily in the right side  intensifies with deep respirations  and is moderately relieved by rest. The patient also reports experiencing shortness of breath  moderate cough with frothy sputum  and lightheadedness since the onset of the chest pain. She denies fever  trauma  recent surgeries  or long periods of immobilization.  She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are well-controlled with medications. She is also a current smoker and reports a 30-pack-year history. She admits to occasional alcohol consumption and denies illicit drug use.  She is a retired school teacher living with her husband  who is her primary caregiver. She has three siblings; one of them had a deep vein thrombosis event a decade ago.  Her vitals on admission include a HR of 110 bpm  RR of 24/min  blood pressure of 142/90 mmHg  spo2 of 88% at room air  and temperature of 98.6°F. On physical examination  she appeared in mild distress due to dyspnea and was mildly diaphoretic. Her chest examination revealed tachypnea and decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung field. Heart sounds were tachycardic  without any murmurs or added sounds. Her peripheral pulses were palpable  and no sign of deep vein thrombosis detected.  Hence  with the history of sudden onset  sharp localized chest pain  dyspnea  frothy sputum  and decreased breath sounds  an acute pulmonary embolism is strongly suspected  and immediate diagnostic workup is indicated.

Patient Information: A 67-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reports chest pain that is sharp  positional  and worsens with deep breathing. She has been feeling increasingly short of breath over the past few hours. She describes a recent long flight (8 days ago) where she had minimal mobility. She denies cough  fever  hemoptysis  leg pain or swelling.   Relevant Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she is being treated with Hydrochlorothiazide and Atorvastatin. She is a nonsmoker with no known drug allergies. She had a total hip replacement surgery 3 years ago. Her family history revealed her father had DVT.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appears distressed. Vital signs are as follows: BP 160/90 mmHg  HR (tachycardia) 110 bpm  RR (tachypnea) 24 breaths/min  Temp 98.6 F  O2 sat 90% on room air. Cardiac exam is unremarkable. Lung sounds demonstrated tachypnea with decreased breath sounds on right lower lung. No leg swelling  erythema or tenderness on lower extremity exam.  Assessment: Given the patient's presentation  travel history and family history of DVT  there is a high index of suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism.   Plan: Immediate ECG and arterial blood gases analyses were ordered. Chest computed tomography angiogram (CTA)  D-dimer test  and lower extremity Doppler ultrasound were also ordered for further investigation. Discussion with patient regarding the need for potential hospital admission for further treatment and monitoring.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Jones is a 63-year-old African-American male who presents to the emergency department with severe sharp  stabbing chest pain that began suddenly about 15 hours ago. The pain is worsened by deep inspiration and does not radiate. Along with this  he has felt progressively short of breath over that last 24 hours  with increased difficulty climbing stairs in his home.
