He has also experienced a dry cough and an episode of fainting this morning shortly after waking up.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Jones is obese with a BMI of 37. He has a known medical history of chronic atrial fibrillation for which he is taking warfarin  but his adherence to medication and routine INR checks is inconsistent. He also has a history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) following a total hip replacement surgery 8 years ago. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history but quit 6 years ago. His mother also had a history of DVTs and passed away from a stroke at the age of 68. He does not have a history of any recent long-distance travel or immobility.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  and light-headedness. The shortness of breath was progressive over the last 6 hours  intensifying with deep breaths and positional changes. He denies any cough  fever  recent trauma  or weight loss.   He notes that he recently returned from a long-distance flight (over 12 hours) a two days ago. His medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis) 3 years ago for which he was on anticoagulation therapy (Warfarin) for 6 months.   Patient is currently on Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  but not on any anticoagulation medication. The patient has a 40-pack year smoking history with the last cigarette smoked 2 years ago. He denies any family history of blood clotting disorders.   On physical examination  his heart rate was 110 beats per minute  blood pressure 150/85 mmHg  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Chest examination showed tachycardia with regular rhythm and clear breath sounds bilaterally. Lower limb examination did not show any swelling or tenderness.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain which is worsened by deep breathing  and a sense of impending doom. The chest pain is localized in the central part of the chest. She also reports mild cough and low-grade fever. Upon questioning  she mentions that the symptoms appeared suddenly a few hours ago.  Vital signs on arrival show increased heart rate (110 bpm) and normal blood pressure. Oxygen saturation is moderately decreased at 92% on room air. On physical examination  the patient appears in mild distress due to difficulty breathing. Auscultation reveals clear lungs bilaterally. Rest of the physical examination is within normal limits.  Patient's past medical history is significant for recently-treated left leg deep vein thrombosis  diagnosed three weeks ago. The patient has also been suffering from irregular heart rhythms (atrial fibrillation) for the past two years  for which she is on oral anticoagulation therapy. Patient retired from her job as a long-haul truck driver six months ago. She is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago after smoking one pack a day for 25 years (25-pack year history).   The patient’s medication list includes Warfarin  a blood thinner for her atrial fibrillation. Family history is positive for her mother who had recurrent venous thromboembolism and passed away due to pulmonary embolism at age 70.   Given her current symptoms  recent treatment history of DVT  atrial fibrillation  and positive family history  there is significant suspicion for a pulmonary embolism  and subsequent diagnostic investigations are warranted immediately.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Robbins is a 67-year-old African-American female who presents in the emergency department complaining of shortness of breath  chest pain  rapid heart rate  and feeling lightheaded which began four hours ago while gardening. She explains that the shortness of breath has been intensifying and is exacerbated when she tries to lie down or move around. She describes having a sharp  persistent chest pain located in the center of her chest. The pain does not radiate and is slightly relieved when sitting up and leaning forward. Ms. Robbins additionally expresses occasional episodes of dizziness and has started coughing mildly over the last hour.   Her past medical history reveals a recent right total knee replacement surgery two weeks ago  which required her to be less physically active than usual. She was advised to wear compression stockings post-surgery  which she has not been consistent with. Ms. Robbins also has a 15-year history of hypertension for which she takes Lisinopril and has been smoking a pack a day for the last 30 years. She has no known allergies. She currently is on no other medications except for her blood pressure. She has no family history of blood clotting disorders. She has not recently traveled by air or long journeys sitting in a car or train.  She lives alone and is independent with all activities of daily living. She doesn't consume any alcohol and follows a balanced diet. These symptoms have not occurred before  and she is visibly distressed. Her vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  temperature of 37.8 degrees Celsius  and oxygen saturation of 89% on room air.   This patient's presentation  particularly the acute onset of symptoms  history of recent surgery with decreased mobility  hypertension  and a long history of smoking  raises a high suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:   A 67-year-old Caucasian female presents to emergency department with rapid onset shortness of breath  chest pain and increased breathlessness on exertion. She reports that the chest pain is sharp in nature  increases upon deep breathing and does not alleviate with rest. She also mentions occasional dizziness.   Vital signs upon admission are: BP 145/90 mmHg  pulse 106 bpm  respiratory rate 24 breaths per min  oxygen saturation at room air is 86%  and temperature is 98.7°F.  Patient has a significant past medical history of chronic atrial fibrillation for which she takes warfarin  diagnosed 7 years ago. She has also a 10-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. There is no history of cancer. This patient has two risk factors for pulmonary embolism: atrial fibrillation and hypercoagulability due to warfarin non-compliance. She has not had any recent surgeries or prolonged periods of immobilization. Family history is positive for deep vein thrombosis in her mother.  On examination  she appears anxious  in respiratory distress and is leaning forward. On auscultation there were decreased breath sounds on the right side  prolonged expiration and wheezing. The rest of the physical examination is essentially normal.  Her BMI is within a normal range and she does not drink alcohol or smoke. She lives with her retired husband and is relatively mobile and active.    This patient may be suffering from an acute pulmonary embolism due to her presenting symptoms and risk factors. Further investigations such as D-dimer level  chest imaging  and perhaps a ventilation-perfusion (VQ) scan or CT pulmonary angiography are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and direct appropriate treatment.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain which started two hours ago. The pain is localized on the left side of his chest  rated 8 out of 10 in severity  increases on deep inspiration and does not radiate. The patient also reports shortness of breath  mild cough but denies any hemoptysis.   He states that he has been inactive and mostly bed-bound for the past 10 days due to a recent left total knee arthroplasty. He’s got a 20-pack year smoking history but quit five years ago. He denies any other drug or alcohol usage. His medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with Lisinopril and hyperlipidemia controlled with Simvastatin. He underwent screening colonoscopy five years ago which was normal and has no known history of cancer. He reports no known drug allergies. His father had a history of deep venous thrombosis.  On physical exam  he appears to be in moderate respiratory distress with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and a heart rate of 105 beats per minute. His blood pressure is 146/88 mm Hg  and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. Aside from tachypnea and tachycardia  the remainder of his physical exam  including cardiovascular and pulmonary exam  is unremarkable. No leg swelling or tenderness noted.   Given his history  clinical presentation  and risk factors  the patient is suspected to have an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian female named Jane  working as a chief executive officer  a sedentary profession with significant work stress. She is an ex-smoker but has a history of deep vein thrombosis and is overweight (BMI 28.1). Jane does help in the house occasionally and walks the dog thrice a week.  Chief Complaint: Jane presents to the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath. She also reports a sharp  stabbing chest pain that get worse with deep breathing. She also says she has been feeling light-headed and faint.  History of Present Illness: Onset of symptoms was 3 hours ago while she was at work. The shortness of breath has been progressively worsening and is accompanied by a mild cough but with no sputum production. She denies any recent leg swelling or prolonged immobilization. She also denies any recent travel history.  Past Medical History: Jane has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a knee surgery 8 years ago. She also had a hysterectomy for uterine fibroids 5 years ago. She is hypertensive and is on treatment with beta-blockers.  Family History: She has a family history of DVT and Pulmonary Embolism - her father had a DVT and her brother had a PE.  Social History: Jane is married and lives with her husband in a suburban area. She does not smoke currently but is an ex-smoker and has been smoke-free for a year. She consumes alcohol occasionally. Her work involves long hours of sitting and she does not get much time for physical activity.  Given her history and presentation  she might be experiencing an acute pulmonary embolism and immediate diagnostic testing is required.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Anderson.  Presentation: Mr. Anderson arrived at the emergency department with sudden-onset dyspnea  chest pain  and faintness. He mentioned that he experienced pleuritic chest pain - sharp and worsening on deep breaths. He also noted a rapid heart-beat.  Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson had a left knee replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. He reports a history of hypertension  for which he takes medication. He stopped smoking 10 years ago after a 30-year smoking history.  Family History: His father had a deep vein thrombosis post-surgery and his older sister has a history of recurrent deep vein thrombosis.  Physical Examination: On presentation  Mr. Anderson appeared slightly cyanotic with an elevated respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute and a heart rate of 102 beats per minute. His blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/85 mmHg. Upon auscultation  there was reduced breath sounds in the lower right lung field. His oxygen saturation on room air was 94%.  Clinical Impressions: Given his sudden onset of symptoms  recent surgery  and family history  there is a high clinical suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism. Plans for immediate diagnostic evaluation with computed tomography angiography (CTA) have been arranged  and he has been started on supplemental oxygen and anticoagulation as bridging therapy as we wait for the results.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Rose  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the ER complaining of a sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  pleuritic chest pain that began this morning. She also reports feelings of light-headedness  occasional cough with pink frothy sputum  and rapid palpitations.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and was on Warfarin since an episode a year ago but admits to irregular medication compliance. She also has hypertension for 15 years  controlled with medication and has been a smoker for the past 40 years  averaging a pack per day. Ms. Rose had an uneventful total knee replacement surgery for osteoarthritis 3 months ago. She shared that she led a sedentary lifestyle due to her mobility issues before and after her surgery. There is no history suggestive of malignancy  tuberculosis  asthma or any other respiratory disease. The patient denies recent travel. She also denied fever  chills  night sweats  or unintentional weight loss. She lives alone and denies use of alcohol or illicit drugs.

Patient Information: A 63-year-old African American female  Mrs. T.B.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe chest pain and shortness of breath that started about an hour ago. The chest pain is pleuritic in nature  with deep breathing exacerbating the pain. She also describes feeling lightheaded and reports an episode of fainting.  Demographics: Mrs. T.B is a former office worker  now retired. She is currently living with her husband in their own home.  Medical History: Mrs. T.B is a nonsmoker. She has a medical history of hypertension managed by amlodipine and an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago following knee surgery. She was treated with an anticoagulant  which was discontinued after 6 months post-DVT.  In addition  she underwent a total right knee replacement surgery for severe osteoarthritis 2 weeks ago. The patient admits her mobility has been limited since her surgery and that she has not been performing her prescribed leg exercises.  Family History: She reports a family history of heart disease with her father dying of a heart attack at the age of 70.  Social History: Lives with her husband who is her primary caregiver. She denies any consumption of alcohol or recreational drugs. She has no known drug allergies.  Vital Signs: Temp: 36.9 C Pulse rate: 120 beats per minute Respiration rate: 26 breaths per minute Blood pressure: 150/90 mm Hg O2 saturation: 92% on room air  Physical Examination: On general physical examination  patient appears distressed. The lungs have decreased breath sounds at the right base and are overall clear to auscultation. Chest wall tenderness is present. There's mild lower leg swelling  more pronounced on the right.  Given her recent surgery  limited mobility  history of DVT  and presenting symptoms  the possibility of an acute pulmonary embolism is being considered and requires urgent investigation and management.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) who presents to the emergency department. The patient complains of sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and anxiety that started approximately two hours ago. He describes the chest pain as ""like a heavy weight "" radiating to the left arm. He also mentions he has been more sedentary than usual for the past week due to a broken ankle. He denies any recent travel  surgery  or trauma. His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidaemia. He is a former smoker and drinks alcohol socially. He takes atorvastatin for cholesterol management and lisinopril for his hypertension. He had a previous DVT after a knee surgery five years ago. He is allergic to penicillin  which causes him to develop a rash. Family history includes a brother with recurrent DVT and his mother  who had a stroke at age 68. He denies use of illicit drugs. He is anxious and diaphoretic  with vital signs revealing tachycardia and hypoxia on room air. Pulmonary examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side  without wheezing or crackles. The rest of the physical exam  including cardiac and abdominal exam  is unremarkable. The ill-fitting cast for the patient's broken ankle is noted  and upon removal  there is evidence of a swollen  erythematous  tender calf  suggestive of possible DVT.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room with complaints of sudden-onset chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient describes the chest pain as ""stabbing""  which worsens upon deep inspiration. The pain started about twelve hours back and has been constant since then.   He also mentions experiencing a sudden  unexplained bout of cough and seeing a light tinge of blood from his mouth when he brushed his teeth in the morning. He rates his current dyspnea severity as 7/10.   The patient denies any over the counter medication usage or recent injury. He's a former smoker with a history of 20 packs a year and has quit smoking ten years back. He has a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and atrial fibrillation for which he takes Losartan  Atorvastatin  and Warfarin respectively.  He has a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with his father having been diagnosed with DVT in his late 50s. The patient works as a truck driver  where he tends to sit for long periods of time. He recently completed a cross-country trip. He reports no allergies. He uses alcohol occasionally and denies illicit drug use.  On examination  he's in moderate distress  conscious  and oriented. His vital signs include blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 98 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation of 90% on room air  and body temperature of 37.1 C. Heart sounds are irregular with tachycardia. No murmur is detected. The lung sounds are diminished in the left lower field.   Given his history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  atrial fibrillation  and his family history and occupational risk  the patient's symptoms appear to be consistent with an acute episode of pulmonary embolism and warrants immediate work up and management.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  pleuritic chest pain radiating to the right shoulder. He rates the pain as 7 out of 10. The patient also reports episodes of light-headedness and increased heart rate. He denies any cough  fever  or recent trauma.   Past Medical History:  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and Stage II Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) diagnosed five years ago. The patient has a 40-year smoking history of one pack a day but quit two years ago. He further notes he had right total knee arthroplasty six weeks ago. Family history reveals a sister who passed away due to a pulmonary embolism. He is currently on amlodipine 10mg daily for hypertension and tiotropium bromide inhaler daily for COPD. The patient admits to noncompliance with prophylactic anticoagulation regimen following his knee surgery.   Review of symptoms:   Cardiac: positive for palpitations Resp: positive for shortness of breath  chest pain  no hemoptysis GI: denies nausea  vomiting  or abdominal pain CNS: denies headaches  seizure  neurological deficits Musculoskeletal: denies injury.  Patient appears in moderate distress  pale and diaphoretic. He demonstrates no obvious signs of lower limb edema or calf tenderness.   This presentation is concerning for an acute pulmonary embolism possibly due to recent surgery and non-compliance with prescribed anticoagulant regimen.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Smith is a 58-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and a recent total knee arthroplasty done six weeks ago  presents to the emergency department. She has been non-compliant with her prescribed anticoagulation therapy since the surgical procedure.  She complains of sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain that began a few hours ago and is worsening in severity. She describes the pain as 8/10  with the pain exacerbated during deep inspirations. Additionally  she has been experiencing progressive shortness of breath for the past three days  associated with a dry cough  and intermittent lightheadedness. She also mentions sporadic spells of profuse sweating. She denies any history of heart diseases  allergies  recent trauma  or infection.  On examination  she appears anxious and mildly distressed. She is tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm and tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg and oxygen saturation on room air is 93%. She has a low-grade fever of 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Her cardiovascular exam reveals a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound.  The rest of her physical examination is unremarkable  with clear auscultatory chest findings  adequate bilateral air entry  no peripheral edema  and no signs of deep vein thrombosis in the lower extremities. A high index of suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism is considered given her clinical presentation and recent surgery.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes  and recent total right hip arthroplasty 3 weeks ago  presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of right-sided pleuritic chest pain  shortness of breath  and mild hemoptysis. He describes the chest pain as sharp and worsening with deep breathing. Dyspnea is noted at rest and exacerbated on exertion. There's an absence of cough  fever  or any overt signs of infection.  He reports he has been largely sedentary since his hip surgery  but his post-operative recovery has been normal  experiencing usual pain and discomfort. He is on medications for his hypertension  hyperlipidemia and type II diabetes  which include metformin  atorvastatin and lisinopril. The patient also mentioned he had quit smoking 5 years ago. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use.  On examination  he is in apparent distress  with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  pulse rate 110/min  blood pressure 145/85 mmHg  and pulse oximetry showing an O2 saturation of 90% on room air. His right lower limb appears slightly swollen compared to the left. His heart sounds appear normal but distant  with no evident murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Breath sounds are decreased at right base with mild wheezing. Abdomen is soft  non-tender with no hepatosplenomegaly. There is no cyanosis  clubbing  or lymphadenopathy.  Given the medical history and clinical signs and symptoms  Mr. Doe is identified as a high-risk patient for an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). His recent orthopedic surgery and prolonged immobilization  along with his symptomatology of pleuritic chest pain  dyspnea  and tachycardia  rise suspicion for acute PE. Immediate diagnostic assessment  typically with a CT pulmonary angiography  is warranted.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old male  John Smith  retired truck driver  married  non-smoker  moderate alcohol drinker  living in urban area.    Chief Complaint: Sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep breaths.  Present Illness: Patient has been experiencing shortness of breath with minimal exertion for the past 6 hours. He woke up with a sharp  stabbing chest pain at the mid-chest area. He insists the symptoms have been steadily worsening and also reports associated lightheadedness  rapid heartbeat  wheezing  and coughing up blood.  Past Medical History: Notably significant for deep vein thrombosis 3 years prior to this episode  for which the patient was enrolled in regular anticoagulant therapy. Patient also has known hypertension for 10 years and takes Losartan.  Family History: His father had a stroke at age 75. His mother had coronary artery disease and died from an acute myocardial infarction at age 80.  Physical Examination: Patient seems anxious  slightly sweaty and pale. Respiratory rate: 26 breaths per minute  Pulse rate: 110 beats per minute  Blood Pressure: 152/90 mmHg  Oxygen saturation (SpO2): 90%. On auscultation  breath sounds are faint with rales in the lower lung zones.  Notable Laboratory Findings: D-dimer levels elevated  moderate-high probability on Wells Score for Pulmonary Embolism. EKG demonstrates sinus tachycardia  S1Q3T3 pattern.  Clinical Impressions: The clinical presentation and history  risk factors (previous DVT)  findings on physical examination and ancillary studies are consistent with a diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism. This condition is potentially life-threatening and requires urgent anticoagulant therapy  among other potential interventions depending upon the clinical course of the patient.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath for the past few hours. The chest pain is sharp  pleuritic in nature  and radiates to his back. He has also been feeling light-headed and experienced one episode of syncope earlier today. He has no known allergies.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of chronic hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medication. He is also a former smoker with a 30-pack year history. He had a total knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago with no complications. He has been mostly immobile since the surgery due to discomfort. His last hospitalization was about 10 years ago for an appendectomy.  Family History:  The patient's father had a myocardial infarction when he was in his 50s and later passed away from a stroke in his 70s. His mother has a history of arthritis and has been generally healthy otherwise.  Review of Systems:  On examination  the patient appears to be in considerable distress  diaphoretic and with shallow breathing. His blood pressure is 138/85 mmHg  pulse rate is 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 28 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. He denies any other symptoms such as cough  diarrhoea  or fever. He admits to feeling more fatigued over the last week but attributes this to lack of mobility   Social History:  The patient lives alone but his daughter checks in on him frequently. He is a retired accountant and denies any alcohol or substance use. He quit smoking 15 years ago.

Patient Information: Mrs. Stewart  a 62-year-old postmenopausal African American female  office assistant  non-smoker  with a BMI of 30.  Chief Complaint: Chest pain rated 6 out of 10 that started approximately five hours ago  shortness of breath  a sudden onset of cough  and feelings of lightheadedness.   History of Present Illness: She describes the pain as sharp  located centrally  and it worsens upon deep inhalation. The patient also mentioned that she's been feeling unusually tired lately.  Past Medical History: Known hypertensive on medication for the past 20 years. History of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) on anticoagulants for six months approximately five years ago. Admitted to hospital for right knee arthroplasty about two weeks ago.  Family History: Father died of stroke in his sixties.  Drug History: Taking Losartan 50mg daily for hypertension and a multivitamin for general wellbeing. Has no known drug allergies.  Social History: She is married with two grown-up daughters. She lives with her husband and an pet dog in a suburban home. She denies smoking  alcohol  or recreational drug use. Works as an office assistant and does not get time for exercise.  Review of Systems: Denies fever  chills  nausea  or vomiting.  On physical examination  she appears distressed with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  oxygen saturations of 92% on room air  and a slightly elevated heart rate at 104 beats per minute. No leg swelling  redness  or pain is found. However  her right knee surgical scar is clean and healing well. Chest exam reveals tachycardia but is otherwise normal without wheezes  rales  or rhonchi. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Impression: Given the patient's recent surgery  history of DVT  and the current symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  and cough  an acute pulmonary embolism is suspected.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African-American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of progressive shortness of breath and right-sided chest pain  which intensifies on deep breathing. The patient also reports a faint episode and feeling light-headed with mildly swollen and tender right lower leg.   Demographics:  Patient lives alone in a suburban community. He retired 5 years ago as a long-distance truck driver. He does not smoke  but does have a history of occasional alcohol consumption. He has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and a recent orthopedic surgery on his right hip 2 weeks ago. The patient's father died of a heart attack at the age of 70 and his mother was hypertensive and diabetic. He takes ramipril 5 mg once a day for hypertension and a daily aspirin. He was also given a short course of analgesics post-surgery. He reports poor compliance with prescribed medications and an active lifestyle prior to the surgery. He has no history of respiratory or other systemic diseases. His post-operative recovery was uneventful until his current symptoms.

Patient Information: 70 year-old male  retired engineer  non-smoker  residing in a suburban neighborhood with his wife.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe shortness of breath  feeling light-headed and chest pain that started 4 hours ago. Pain has been increasing in severity and it's located more on the right side. It got worse with deep breathing. No associated fever  cough or sputum production. He also reported mild lower limb swelling on right side that began few days ago.  Vital Signs: BP: 140/90mmHg  PR: 104/min  RR: 22/min  Temp: 37.0°C  SPO2: 93% on room air.  Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right leg one year ago for which he was prescribed warfarin but the compliance to the anticoagulation therapy was poor. He also has controlled hypertension  type-2 diabetes mellitus  and was operated for benign prostatic hyperplasia 2 years back.  Family History: No family history of venous thromboembolism but patient's father had a myocardial infarction at age 75.  Social History: He is a retired engineer and his lifestyle is mainly sedentary. He doesn't smoke  but occasionally drinks alcohol.  Physical Examination: On inspection  mild swelling was noted in the right lower limb; on auscultation  tachycardia and reduced breath sounds on the right lower lung fields were noted.  Given his history and current symptoms  the patient appears to be suffering from a possible acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic tests such as D-dimer  chest CT scan  and possibly  a ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) scan will be required for definite diagnosis.

Patient Presentation: A 66-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with acute onset of pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath that started within the past 8 hours. The patient describes the chest pain as stabbing  non-radiating and worse with deep breaths  scoring it 8 out of 10 in terms of severity. The shortness of breath is present even at rest. He also indicates light-headedness and intermittent palpitations. The patient has no history of cough  fever  hemoptysis  lower limb pain or swelling.  Past Medical History: The patient's medical history includes hypertension controlled with lisinopril  hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin  and a past DVT episode 5 years ago from which he recovered fully. He quit smoking 10 years ago  but previously had a 20 pack-year history. His father had a massive pulmonary embolism and died prematurely at the age of 55.   Other Medications: Daily aspirin   Allergies: The patient has no known drug allergies.  Reviewed Systems: The review of systems is negative for weight loss  night sweats  recent travel  prolonged immobilization  recent surgeries or hospitalization.   Physical Examination: Patient appears uncomfortable due to pain. Vital signs are stable  except for tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 per minute. Lung auscultation reveals normal breath sounds without crackles or wheezing. The cardiovascular exam revealed a regular rhythm without murmurs. There is no lower limb swelling  erythema  or tenderness to palpation. His skin is warm and well perfused. No cyanosis or clubbing is observed.  Psychosocial History: He is retired and lives with his wife. He maintains an active lifestyle and walks his dog daily. Consumes alcohol occasionally and denied illicit drug usage. His wife reports that he appeared somewhat more anxious than usual over the past few days.   Given the patient's sudden onset of symptoms  his history of DVT and familial history of PE  acute pulmonary embolism is high on the differential diagnosis and he should be worked-up promptly to confirm the diagnosis and initiate therapy.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith presents to the emergency department with sudden shortness of breath and chest pain that started two hours ago. The pain worsens upon inspiration and doesn't radiate anywhere. He also reports a dry cough and mild lightheadedness. Mr. Smith denies any recent trauma  fever or coughing up blood.  Mr. Smith is a retired truck driver and lives with his wife. He has never smoked or consumed alcohol. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he is on medications  including hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He underwent a total knee replacement surgery three weeks ago and has a familial thrombophilia history.  On examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic with a heart rate of 105 beats/minute  blood pressure of 145/85 mm Hg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute  and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air.  Given the recent orthopedic surgery  lack of mobility  and family history of thrombophilia  a clinical suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism is raised. The patient is immediately sent for confirmatory tests including a chest CT angiogram  D-dimer levels  and ECG.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a history of recent total knee replacement surgery (~2 weeks ago)  smoking  and obesity  presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that increases in intensity on deep inspiration  which started about an hour ago. He mentions that the pain lessens when he leans forward and holds his breath. He also reports light-headedness  coughing  and an episode of hemoptysis. He denies any fever  chill  localized leg pain  or swelling. He became more dyspneic while talking and turned pale. On enquiry  he revealed that he did not completely adhere to the post-operative DVT prophylaxis regimen prescribed after his knee surgery.  On examination  his BP is 100/60 mmHg  HR is 110/min  RR is 30/min  SpO2 is below 90% on room air  and temperature is 98.6F. Pulmonary examination reveals tachypnea and decreased breath sounds on the right side. Heart sounds are tachycardic  with a pronounced second heart sound. No leg swelling was observed.  His past medical history in detail revealed: uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  past smoker (quit 5 years ago but used to smoke 1 pack/day for 30 years)  known case of Type 2 Diabetes and was on insulin. No known history of allergies. His family history was significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his mother late in her life.   Overall  his symptoms  viital signs  past medical and surgical history raise high suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic tests including D-dimer  CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) and ECG will be necessary to confirm his diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with chief complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain that gets worse upon deep breathing  and feeling lightheaded for the past few hours. He also reports coughing up blood-tinged sputum. Upon observation  he appears anxious and diaphoretic. He denies any recent surgeries or hospitalizations  but he reports having been on a long-haul flight about a week ago. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he is taking atenolol and simvastatin respectively. He is allergic to penicillin  which causes rash.   He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history  but quit at the age of 60. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any illicit drug use. His mother had a deep vein thrombosis and his father had coronary artery disease. He lives alone and is retired. He also reports being less active than he used to be  mostly staying at home and reading books or watching television.  His vital signs on arrival are: BP- 130/85 mmHg  Heart rate- 102 beats/min  Temperature- 98.7F  Respiratory rate- 22 breaths/min and SpO2- 92% on room air.  Clinical examination reveals tachypnea and tachycardia. Cardiac auscultation reveals a loud S2 sound at the left sternal border and lung auscultation has some decreased breath sounds at the right base. On palpation  there is mild swelling and tenderness in the right calf.

Patient Presentation:  A 63-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department today with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath that started approximately 6 hours ago. The patient describes the chest pain as sharp  radiating to the left shoulder  increasing on deep inspiration  and not relieved by rest. Accompanying symptoms include light-headedness  hot flashes  and palpitations.  The patient has a relevant past medical history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril 5mg/daily  hyperlipidemia treated with Atorvastatin 10mg/daily  and a recent right total knee replacement surgery performed 3 weeks ago. Her history also suggests she is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago but with a 30 pack-year history prior to quitting. Has occasional alcohol use  denying any substance use. Family history includes her father who had suffered from deep vein thrombosis.   Patient denies any similar episode in the past. The patient is an office worker  engaged in a sedentary lifestyle  overweight with BMI of 30. No particular allergies are known. She lives alone and is independent in all activities of daily living.   Thus  the patient's clinical presentation and her postoperative status  along with certain risk factors like obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of thrombosis raise a strong suspicion for a potential acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  A 64-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath  right-sided chest pain  and dizziness that started 3 hours ago while watching television. The patient mentioned that his chest pain feels ""sharp"" and worsens with deep breaths. He also mentioned a cough with slight hemoptysis. Moreover  he noted that he recently flew back from a business trip which was a long-haul flight.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hypertension  which is controlled by antihypertensive medication. He also has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a knee replacement surgery 8 years ago. He is a former smoker of 20 pack years but quit 5 years ago. He does not consume alcohol. There are no known allergies. The patient is obese with a BMI of 32. He follows up regularly with his primary care physician and his last regular check-up was six months ago. The patient’s father had a pulmonary embolism in his late 60s.  Current Medications:  Atenolol 50mg once daily for hypertension. No other known medications.   Family History:   Father had a history of pulmonary embolism and hypertension. Mother is alive and healthy with no known chronic diseases. No siblings. One son who is healthy.   Review of Systems:  Denies fever  weight loss  or night sweats. Positive for cough and hemoptysis. Denies heart palpitations. Notes mild lower leg swelling primarily on the right.   Social History:  Lives with his wife  they have one son who lives out of state. He is retired now but used to work as a businessman  involving frequent travel. Denies any recreational drug use.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Marshall  a 65-year-old  Caucasian female  arrived at the Emergency Department with complaints of sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that began roughly one hour prior to arrival. The pain is noted as 8/10 severity and is worsened by deep inhalation or coughing. She also reports a moderate to high-level of anxiety due to the sudden onset of symptoms.   She denies any recent injury  falls  choking events  or changes in diet  as well as any history of similar symptoms. Patient admits to recent long car travel of about 10 hours duration a week ago. She has no known drug allergies.  Regarding her past medical history  Mrs. Marshall is known to have chronic hypertension and type two diabetes mellitus  for which she is on medication. She does not have a history of heart disease or lung disease. She's a former smoker  having quit five years ago  and admits to moderate alcohol use.  Her family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis in her mother and older sister  both were under long periods of inactivity during their events.   On arrival  her vitals were stable but her oxygen saturation was a bit lower than normal at 91%. During physical examination  she was positive for tachypnea and showed some signs of respiratory distress  but the rest of her breathing and chest sounds were overall normal with no wheezing  rhonchi  or rales.  A high-risk status can be considered due to her advanced age  prolonged immobility due to recent travel  and significant family history. The presence of sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain strongly suspects an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Lisa Brown is a 67-year-old Caucasian female presenting to the emergency department with a sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp chest pain that worsens when she takes a deep breath. The pain started suddenly about an hour ago while she was resting. She also complains of mild dizziness and feeling her heart ""beating fast and hard.""  Her past medical history is significant for obesity  sedentary lifestyle and recent left lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT) diagnosed one month ago  for which she had been prescribed oral anticoagulants. Her medication adherence history is however inconsistent. She has no known allergies. She denies smoking  alcohol or illicit drug use. Her family history reveals that her father had a heart attack and her mother passed away from stroke.  There is no history of travel  immobility or surgery within the past few months. Apart from DVT  she has no history of clotting disorders or malignancies. She is not on any medication other than the anticoagulant for her DVT. Her immunization is up to date. She has no prior history of lung disease.  On physical examination  vital signs show a heart rate of 120 beats per minute  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Inspection shows a moderately obese anxious woman with distress evident in her facial expression. She is tachypneic with an evident use of accessory muscles of respiration. On auscultation  her heart sounds are tachycardic  no extra sounds or murmurs. Lungs revealed diminished breath sounds at the bases bilaterally. Extremities showed no edema. Her coordinates are grossly good.  The rest of her physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies including electrolytes  BNP  Troponin level  and a chest X-ray have been ordered to rule out other possible causes of her symptoms and a STAT CT pulmonary angiogram has been ordered to confirm suspected acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  A 53-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset sharp chest pain and difficulty breathing for the past 6 hours. Patient describes pain as 7/10 in intensity  localized in the middle chest area and aggravated by deep breathing. He also reports an episode of fainting today in the morning which lasted for a few minutes followed by profuse sweating. He further expresses feeling a bit lightheaded and mentions an episode of vomiting before arriving. He denies any cough  fever  sputum production  or recent infectious disease.  Patient History:  The patient has a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes mellitus type II  and hyperlipidemia. He admits to be a current smoker for 30 years  approximately a pack per day  and a social drinker with occasional alcohol consumption on weekends. Patient had a right total knee replacement surgery about 3 weeks ago with an uneventful postoperative period. His family history is remarkable for cardiovascular disease  noting his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 56. Review of systems is otherwise negative.  Medications:  Patient is currently on Lisinopril 20mg once daily for his hypertension  Metformin 1000mg twice daily for his diabetes  and Simvastatin 40mg once daily for hyperlipidemia. He was on enoxaparin post-operatively which was discontinued after 10 days.  Social History:  Patient is a machinist and lives alone. He has two children who live out-of-town. He has no known drug allergies.  Physical Exam:  On exam  patient is in distress due to pain and dyspnea. His vital signs include blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breath per minute  body temperature 98.6F  and oxygen saturation 91% on room air. Auscultation reveals clear lung fields with tachycardia. Examination of the lower extremities reveals no evident swelling  erythema or tenderness.  These findings are concerning for acute pulmonary embolism and further investigations are underway to confirm the diagnosis with a chest CT angiogram and baseline labs.

Patient Presentation:  A 63-year-old African-American female presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  which started approximately an hour before arriving at the hospital. She describes the breathing difficulty as severe and states that she has never experienced anything like this before. She also reports sharp  localized chest pain that is worsened by deep breathing and coughing. She denies fever  cough  or recent travel.   Over the past few days  she says she has noted an unusual puffiness and pain in her right lower leg which she initially dismissed as leg strain. She does not have a personal or family history of clotting disorders but does have a past medical history significant for obesity and hypertension.   She is a nonsmoker  and her only medication is Lisinopril for her hypertension. Her mother died of a heart attack at the age of 67. She is a retired teacher and lives with her husband. She mainly has a sedentary lifestyle with moderate alcohol intake.   On examination  she has a slightly elevated heart rate (tachycardia)  normal blood pressure  and decreased oxygen saturation levels (hypoxia). Her right calf is swollen  warm  and tender. The rest of her physical examination is normal  including a normal respiratory examination. Given the patient's symptoms and risk factors  you suspect an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe chest pain that started two hours ago. He describes the pain as sharp  mostly located in the left side of his chest  and was not alleviated by rest or nitroglycerin. He also reports feeling short of breath and experiencing palpitations. Of note  the patient recently underwent a total hip replacement about two weeks ago.  Past medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day but quit 5 years ago. He admits he has not been mobile since his surgery and spends most of his time sitting or laying down. The patient takes aspirin  metoprolol  and atorvastatin regularly. He denies any known drug allergies.  In family history  his father had a myocardial infarction in his 60s and his sister has a history of deep vein thrombosis. He does not have any genetic conditions or clotting disorders that he is aware of.   On examination  the patient appears uncomfortable and slightly anxious. He has a blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  and his oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. He is afebrile. His respiratory examination reveals tachypnea and decreased breath sounds at the left base. The remainder of his examination is unremarkable.        Given his recent surgery  immobility  history of smoking  and current presentation  the clinician suspects that he may have suffered an acute pulmonary embolism. The patient is immediately administered oxygen and anticoagulation therapy is initiated while further investigations are underway.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Thompson  a 47-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset dyspnea over the past 6 hours  associated with sharp  pleuritic chest pain that exacerbates with deep breaths. She also reports feelings of light-headedness and a reduced ability to tolerate physical exertion. Patient has been traditionally fit and healthy  working as a physical education teacher.  Patient also reports having travelled on a long flight (8 hours) from Europe around 2 days ago and had been immobile for the majority of the journey. Her past medical history reveals that she went into an early menopause at 40 years of age and she has been on hormone replacement therapy since then. She also has a history of varicose veins. For lifestyle factors  she denies any smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use.  About a year ago  her mother (68) was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis. Ms. Thompson maintains an active lifestyle but admits to gaining around 5kg due to recent dietary changes. No significant abnormalities of note involving cardiovascular or respiratory systems in her personal medical history.   On examination  she appears acutely unwell and anxious. Her vitals reveal tachycardia and tachypnea  with oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs shows normal vesicular breathing with no added sounds. The rest of the physical exam is unremarkable.  Given her presentation and risk factors  a working diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is being considered.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith who is an ex-smoker and quit five years back. He presents to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath for the last 3-4 hours. The dyspnea was sudden in onset and progressively got worse over the past few hours. Supplemental oxygen at 4 LPM via nasal cannula has helped to moderately improve symptoms. He also reports a sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens on deep inspiration and a dry cough. No hemoptysis.   He had right knee replacement surgery 3 weeks before. His mobility was reduced post-surgery. He denies any recent travel or history of clots. He has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes well controlled by diet and metformin  and mild COPD. He is on aspirin 75mg for chest pain and has no known drug allergies.   His BMI is 28.2  and he experiences high stress due to his sales-related job. Denies alcohol  but admits to occasional social smoking. He has a family history of heart disease  his father died from a heart attack at the age of 60.   On physical examination  he appeared restless and in respiratory distress with an oxygen saturation of 92% on 4LPM oxygen  BP was 145/90 mmHg  pulse was 110/min  Respiratory rate was 24 per min. His Chest was clear to auscultation  heart sounds were fast but regular  and the rest of the physical exam was unremarkable.

A 67-year-old African American female presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and mild chest pain that started 3 hours ago. The patient describes the pain as a sharp  “stabbing” type  localized to the middle of the chest and rated 6/10 on a pain scale. The pain increases with deep breathing.  The patient has a history of obesity with a BMI of 32  hypertension treated with Lisinopril and Metoprolol  type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) one year ago treated with anticoagulant therapy. She had a hysterectomy operation fifteen years ago and has been sedentary lately. She is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. The patient also reports a recent long haul flight from overseas around 10 days back. She denies any cough  fever  or sweating.   The patient's family history is significant for cardiac disease and stroke. Her mother died of a heart attack at the age of 73 and her father had a stroke.  She lives alone  and she has no known drug allergies. She has been taking oral contraceptives for the past 5 years.  Given her history of DVT  recent immobility  long flight  and contraceptive use  a high suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism is warranted. Further investigations like D-dimer test  CT pulmonary angiography and possibly a venous ultrasound of her lower extremities to exclude a concurrent DVT should be conducted to confirm the diagnosis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of congestive heart failure  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp  pleuritic chest pain. He reports that he experienced sudden lightheadedness and an episode of syncope earlier in the day  prompting his visit to the emergency department. He often feels fatigued  but today it was worse than usual. He denies cough  fever  or leg swelling. He has a smoking history of 40 pack-years and takes metformin  lisinopril  and metoprolol. He had a total knee replacement two weeks ago and has been mostly sedentary during his recovery. His father died of a pulmonary embolism at around the same age.

A 65-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of breathlessness  chest pain  and palpitations for the past 2 hours. The pain is pleuritic type  localized on the right side and associated with a cough. She also reports low-grade fever since yesterday. She had taken a recent air travel of 12 hrs duration a week back for her granddaughter's wedding. The patient reveals a medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and has been recently diagnosed with a deep vein thrombosis in her right leg for which she was taking anticoagulants. She is a former smoker and has quit 5 years ago. She lives alone and manages the everyday activities independently. Her mother had a past history of stroke.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J. Anderson  a 63-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain for the past 2 hours. Pain has been continuous and rates it as an 8 on a scale of 10. The pain is worse on deep inspiration and is associated with breathlessness. He also mentions feeling faint with intermittent episodes of dizziness  but denies any previous episode of loss of consciousness. No associated symptoms such as cough  hemoptysis  fever or leg pain were reported.   He smokes tobacco (approximately 1 pack/day for the past 45 years) and drinks alcohol socially. He has a sedentary lifestyle and works a desk job. He regularly takes medications for his hypertension (Amlodipine) and hyperlipidemia (Atorvastatin).   Past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and obesity. No prior history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  pulmonary embolism (PE)  cardiac disease  or coagulation disorders. He underwent a right total hip replacement after a fall three weeks ago and since then has been less mobile than usual. No known drug allergies.   On examination  his blood pressure is 155/95 mm of Hg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute and temperature is 98.6 F. He is alert but appears mildly distress with slight cyanosis. Pulmonary examination reveals tachypnea and reduced breath sounds in the left lower lung field. Cardiac examination reveals tachycardia. His extremities are cool to touch with no peripheral edema or signs of DVT.   As PE is suspected  further diagnostic workup is warranted  including EKG  D-Dimer  chest CT angiography.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Doe is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department experienced a sudden onset of dyspnea on exertion  pleuritic chest pain  and mild hemoptysis earlier today. He has noted a rapid heart rate  light-headedness  and associated weakness.   Mr. Doe mentions that he has recently flown back from a two-week holiday in Europe and was considerably immobile during the long flight. He denies any past episodes of similar symptoms.   Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for hypertension (managed with an ACE inhibitor) and hyperlipidemia (managed with a statin). He underwent a hip replacement surgery 1 year back. There are no known drug allergies. He is a former smoker (quit 10 years ago) and consumes alcohol socially.   He is retired but was previously employed as a truck driver  often driving long hours without many opportunities to stand or stretch his legs.  The patient's father died due to a stroke in his late 70s and his mother had chronic venous insufficiency in her lower extremities but is still alive in her 90s. He has one older brother with a history of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation  A 67-year-old Caucasian male presents with sudden onsets of dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain  and a mild dry cough that started approximately three hours ago. The patient describes the chest pain as sharp  worse on deep inspiration  and radiating to the left shoulder. He also reports feelings of light-headedness and slight palpitations  but denies syncope. He has no known allergies.  Relevant past medical history includes a total knee arthroplasty performed 3 weeks prior; he also has chronic hypertension controlled with losartan 50 mg daily. He has no history of DVT or PE  no known malignancies  and no recent long-distance travel. He smokes a half pack of cigarettes per day and has been doing so for 45 years. His family history is unremarkable. The patient lives alone and is retired.  On examination  his vital signs are as follows: BP 145/95 mmHg  Pulse 105 bpm  Respiratory rate 22 bpm  Oxygen saturation 90% on room air  and Temperature 36.7 degrees Celsius.  Physical examination reveals tachypnea  mild diaphoresis and he appears anxious. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with regular rhythm. Respiratory examination reveals decreased breath sounds in the right lower lobe with slight crackles. Extremities show no signs of deep vein thrombosis.   Based on his recent surgery  clinical presentation  and examination findings  there is a high suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism. Further investigation with a CT pulmonary angiogram is warranted.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that is worse with deep breaths. He also mentions that he has felt light-headed and has had a dry cough intermittently ever since he woke up this morning. Speaking seems to accelerate his breathlessness. His wife  who accompanies him to the hospital  reports that he appeared increasingly pale and she has also noticed him to be slightly confused.  Mr. Smith has a 30-year history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day  although he quit five years ago. He has a known medical history of high blood pressure  high cholesterol  type II diabetes  and obesity. He recently underwent a total right hip replacement three weeks ago. His current medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He reports no known drug allergies.   The patient has a family history of vascular disorders. His father had suffered a stroke at age 63 and one of his brothers was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his late 50s. Mr. Smith denies any recent travel or periods of prolonged immobilization apart from the post-operative period following his hip replacement. He works as an accountant and describes his activities as predominantly sedentary. He is in a monogamous relationship  does not consume alcohol  and denies any illicit drug use.

Patient Presentation:   The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian female  presenting to the Emergency Department with a chief complaint of sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  pleuritic chest pain that started this morning. She rates her pain as a 7 on a scale of 1 to 10 and reports it worsens with deep breathing. She describes that her shortness of breath has progressively worsened throughout the day  leaving her unable to perform her normal daily activities. The patient has also reported a mild cough with clear sputum but denies any hemoptysis. She mentions she is currently feeling lightheaded and has experienced intermittent episodes of palpitations.   Past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which she has been prescribed hydrochlorothiazide. She also reports having undergone a total right hip replacement surgery four weeks ago due to osteoarthritis. Post-surgery  she has been less active than usual as she is in the process of recovery.   She denies any history of heart disease  diabetes  or known lung disease. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. She has no known allergies. Her family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis in her mother.   On physical examination  the patient appears anxious and in evident distress due to her breathing. Her blood pressure is 143/89 mm Hg  pulse rate 100 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  temperature 98.5 degrees Fahrenheit  and Sp02 of 92% on room air.  These circumstances - including her recent hip surgery  familial history  inactivity  and ongoing symptoms suggest the possibility of an acute pulmonary embolism. Any further investigations necessary should be expedited due to disease severity and patient condition.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. Baxter is a 66-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of hypertension and recent right hip replacement surgery 4 weeks ago. She presents to the ER today complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath which started about 3 hours ago at home. She also mentions experiencing chest pain rated as an 8 on the pain scale  along with mild hemoptysis.  The pain is sharp in quality  exacerbated with deep breaths  and is located on the right side of her chest. She denies any heartburn  nausea  or vomiting but does reveal an unintended weight loss over the last month. Additionally  she mentions fatigue and mild leg swelling. She denies alcohol use and is a former smoker who quit 20 years ago. She does not jog or workout and is usually sedentary.  On examination  the patient appears to be in distress  with tachypnea  tachycardia  and decreased breath sounds on the right lower side of her chest. Blood pressure is 135/89 mm Hg. Mrs. Baxter’s O2 sats are at 91% on room air. The remaining physical examination findings are unremarkable.  Her significant family history includes hereditary thrombophilia; her sister was diagnosed with Factor V Leiden mutation about a decade ago.  Given her recent surgery  immobility  and the hereditary risk of thromboembolism  there is a high clinical suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American male  retired army officer  married with three children  non-smoker  and moderate alcohol consumer.  Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that’s worsening with deep breaths.  History of Present Illness: The patient describes the onset of his symptoms as sudden  occurring approximately 5 hours ago. The pain is primarily on the right side of his chest. He also complains of mild lightheadedness but denies any recent fainting episodes  nausea  or vomiting. The shortness of breath has made it difficult for him to complete normal activities within his home. Cough or hemoptysis is absent. No recent illnesses or infections to note.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his right lower leg two years ago  following orthopedic surgery on his knee. He was treated with anticoagulants for six months post-surgery. He also has controlled hypertension and type II diabetes. There is no known history of heart disease or pulmonary problems.  Family History: Both parents passed away in their late 70s. His father had a history of stroke and his mother had breast cancer. He has a younger brother who is healthy.  Physical Exam: The patient is alert and oriented  but appears mildly distressed due to pain. His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg  pulse is rapid at 110 beats per minute  and his respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute with decreased oxygen saturation at 94%. Pulmonary auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side.  Impression: The patient's presenting symptoms  past medical history and physical examination findings are suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism  but further diagnostic tests will need to be carried out to confirm.

A 60-year-old obese female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain radiating to her back  which has been worsening over the past 24 hours. The patient states she started to feel unwell a few days ago  describing these feelings as a general malaise but did not seek immediate medical attention. She also mentions having had a cough with a slight wheeze  but no hemoptysis. She also reports mild dizziness but no fainting episodes.  The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with amlodipine  and she had a total knee replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. Her family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis in her mother. The patient denies smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug use. She recognizes not moving much after her surgery and complying poorly with her early mobilization and physical therapy recommendations. Initial vital signs show an elevated heart rate of 110 bpm and oxygen saturation at 92% on room air.

A 62-year-old male with a past medical history of Type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and DVT (deep venous thrombosis) three years ago  presents to the ER complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain that began two hours ago. The patient reports that the chest pain seems to worsen upon deep breaths and feels like a 'heavy weight.' Associated symptoms include light-headedness and palpitations  but denies any fever  cough  or hemoptysis. He admits to recent prolonged travel (6 hour flight) a week ago. There has been no recent surgery or hospitalization.  On physical examination  the patient seems in mild distress with elevated heart rate at 110  respiratory rate of 24  blood pressure of 135/85  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. His breath sounds were clear but decreased in the right lower zone. There is mild pitting edema on the right lower extremity.  The patient has a history of poor medication compliance and has been off his prescribed anticoagulant for the past year. Family history includes a brother who had a pulmonary embolism in his late 50s. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  and does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He lives with his wife and is retired.

Patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. S  presenting to the emergency department with sudden shortness of breath  chest pain  and a feeling of lightheadedness. She reports that the pain started abruptly a few hours ago when she was sitting  reading a book at home. The pain becomes worse when she takes a deep breath. For the last few weeks  she experienced leg swelling (left greater than right)  which she attributed to her long commute. She rated her chest pain an 8/10 in severity  and described it as a sharp  stabbing discomfort on her left side.   Mrs. S has a past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both controlled with medications. She has a BMI of 32  which classifies her as clinically obese. She has never been a smoker and does not use recreational drugs but consumes alcohol moderately. She recently recovered from a left total hip replacement surgery which required her to be immobilized for weeks post-surgery. She reported having missed some doses of her post-surgery anti-coagulant medicine.   Family history revealed her father died from a stroke and mother died from severe heart disease. Patient is currently on Lisinopril for hypertension  Simvastatin for high cholesterol  and was prescribed Enoxaparin injections following her hip surgery.   Given her symptoms and history  she is suspected of having an acute pulmonary embolism.

Chief Complaint: ""I have severe chest pain that started suddenly and I'm having difficulty breathing.""  Patient Information: James Harrison  59-year-old Caucasian male  married  employed as an office clerk  non-smoker  moderate alcohol use  BMI: 29 Kg/m2.  History of Present Illness: James reports the sudden onset of chest pain approximately two hours ago. The pain is pleuritic  located in the middle of the chest  with no radiation. He rates the pain as 9/10 in severity  and it is not relieved or worsened by position or exertion. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath  palpitations  light-headedness  and diaphoresis that worsened over the time.  Past Medical History: James has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and lifestyle managed type 2 diabetes. He also had an uneventful total knee arthroplasty on his right side about three weeks ago.  Medications: He takes daily Metformin for his diabetes  Lipitor for his cholesterol  and Lisinopril for hypertension.  Family History: Both of his parents died from heart diseases. His mother died from a heart attack at the age of 63 and father from stroke at the age of 67.  Social History: James is a non-smoker. He occasionally consumes alcohol and does not use any illicit drugs. He reports a sedentary lifestyle and follows a diet high in carbohydrates.  Review of Systems: Positive for chest pain  shortness of breath and profuse sweating. Negative for fever  cough  hemoptysis  leg pain or swelling  recent traumas or surgeries.  Physical Examination: James appears anxious and is in obvious distress due to the chest pain. His pulse rate is 110 bpm  respirations 22 rpm  blood pressure 155/95 mmHg  temperature 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. On lung auscultation  breath sounds are diminished in basal areas. Cardiac exam reveals tachycardia with regular rhythm. No jugular venous distention. Lower extremities are without edema or tenderness. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   This clinical presentation along with recent surgery  obesity and sedentary lifestyle raises suspicion for an acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic evaluation including D-dimer  CT pulmonary angiography  EKG  and echocardiography should be pursued.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset sharp  stabbing chest pain which started two hours ago. The pain is located at the right lateral side of the chest and radiates to the back. He rates his pain as 8/10 on the severity scale. He also reports an associated shortness of breath  palpitations  and mild lightheadedness. There is no history of fever  cough  or night sweats.  Past medical history is significant for hypertension and Stage I chronic kidney disease. The patient is a 20-pack year smoker and quit smoking 10 years ago. He also mentions having had a left hip replacement surgery about a month ago. He denies any prior history of blood clot or pulmonary embolism  although a paternal relative reportedly experienced a pulmonary embolism in his sixties.   On physical examination  he looks anxious and mildly distressed. His heart rate is 102 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute  blood pressure is 130/88 mmHg  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Lung auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds on the right lower lobe of the lung. Cardiovascular examination shows tachycardia but no murmur  rub  or gallop. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. He has a BMI of 27 indicating he is overweight.   The patient is currently prescribed hydrochlorothiazide for hypertension  and daily aspirin for primary prevention of cardiovascular diseases. He denies any known drug allergies.   Based on the above findings  there is a suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism  likely secondary to post-surgical thromboembolism. Further investigations are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

Patient Profile: Ms. Pauline Greene is a 65-year-old Caucasian female who lives alone in a city apartment. She has a sedentary lifestyle and is an ex-smoker with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Presenting Issue: Ms. Greene presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm  along with shortness of breath that began 4 hours prior. She reports the pain is sharp in nature  7/10 in intensity  and it increases with deep breaths. She also mentioned feeling lightheaded and having a sense of impending doom.  Vital Sign Examination: On presentation  she appears anxious and diaphoretic. She is tachycardic with a heart rate of 108 beats per minute  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and her Oxygen saturation is reading at 90% when breathing room air. Her blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg.  According to Ms. Greene's account  she has no allergies  and her current medications include Metformin for diabetes and Losartan for hypertension. Further exploration of her history reveals that she had an extended airline flight about 5 days ago and she admits being relatively immobile throughout the 10-hour flight. She denies substance abuse or consumption of alcohol. On examination  there are no overt signs of DVT like redness or swelling in limbs  but the rest of the examination is unremarkable.  In light of her medical history  clinical presentation  and recent long-haul flight  a preliminary diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is made and immediate management is initiated.

Patient Presentation:  A 62 year-old Caucasian woman  Mrs. Jones  presents to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset of sharp chest pain  shortness of breath  and rapid heart rate for the past few hours. She also mentions having hemoptysis (coughing up blood). On interrogation  Mrs. Jones reports a recent long-distance flight  about 2 weeks ago  with almost no mobility.  Her past medical records indicate that she has an extensive history of ovarian cancer  stage III  diagnosed 10 years ago; undergoing chemotherapy for the same. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia and type II diabetes  both controlled with medications. She is a non-smoker and doesn't consume alcohol.  On physical examination  she seems anxious  diaphoretic (sweaty)  and tachypneic with a Respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute. Her heart rate (tachycardic) is clocked at 120 beats per minute. On auscultation  she has regular heart sounds but also had a loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound.  Lab findings reveal an elevated D-dimer level of 800 ng/mL (normal range: 0-500 ng/mL)  while the arterial blood gases (ABG) show hypoxia with a PO2 of 73 mmHg on room air.  The present signs  symptoms  and evidence  raise the strong suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain that is exacerbated when she takes deep breaths  and palpitations  which started around 2 hours ago. She also mentions a swelling in her left lower leg which has been present for the past 3 days.   Demographic Information:  She is a retired school teacher  widow  and lives with her daughter. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol only occasionally at social gatherings. Her body mass index is currently 34  which indicates obesity.  Past Medical History:  She has a known medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 4 years ago  for which she had been on warfarin therapy but has not been well adhered to it for last few months. She also has long-standing hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Her orthopedic doctor had recently recommended bed rest for osteoarthritis of her left knee  which has limited her mobility for the past two weeks.   Her mother also had a history of DVT and her brother died of pulmonary embolism. The patient does not have any known allergies. She denies any previous surgeries.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain that is worsened by deep breathing and a feeling of lightheadedness. The symptoms have been progressively worsening for 3-4 hours. He rates his chest pain as 6 out of 10 and says it feels like a ""sharp stabbing"". The patient also reports a mild dry cough without any expectoration.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  and type II diabetes mellitus that is currently managed by Metformin. He is a former smoker who quit smoking 20 years ago  but has a 30 pack-year smoking history. The patient reports recent hospitalization 3 months ago due to a total hip replacement.   Social History: He is retired and lives with his wife. Has 3 grown children and denies any illicit drug usage. No family history of sudden death or pulmonary embolism.  Review of Systems: He has no fever  no night sweats  no recent weight loss  no comfortable position  no relief using nitroglycerin  no radiation of the pain. He denies any nausea  vomiting or diarrhea.  Physical Exam: Patient is in acute distress on the exam table. Vitals: heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure 118/82 mmHg  respiratory rate 22/min  oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Lung exam shows clear auscultation bilaterally. Cardiovascular exam displays tachycardia with no murmur. No calf tenderness  swelling or discoloration.   The above presentations make acute pulmonary embolism a very likely diagnosis. Immediate diagnostic tests are needed for this patient.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with complaints of acute onset  severe chest pain and shortness of breath that began around 2 hours ago. She describes the pain as a sharp  constant pain that worsens upon deep breathing and is located in the central part of her chest. She also mentions the presence of lightheadedness and has a history of excessive sweating.   Her past medical history is significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the leg one year back for which she had been advised prophylactic anticoagulation but she has been non-compliant due to fear of bleeding complications.
