She has a secondary medical history of hypertension controlled with medication  and she is a former smoker having quit 20 years ago.  Her family history reveals that her mother had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 55. She does not consume alcohol and denies use of illicit drugs. She works as a corporate team leader and lives with her retired husband. Her only medications include amlodipine for hypertension.   On examination  the patient appears anxious and diaphoretic. Her initial vital signs reveal tachycardia (110 bpm)  tachypnea (22 breaths/min)  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Her physical examination is remarkable for decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung field. There is no leg swelling noted.   The emergency department physician suspects an acute pulmonary embolism given her history  presentation  and physical exam findings. They order an immediate d-dimer test  and CT Pulmonary Angiogram to confirm their suspicion while starting her on oxygen support and anticoagulation in the interim.

Demographic Details: Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male retiree. He is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year history  quitting 10 years ago.   Chief Complaint: The patient arrived at the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath  chest pain mostly on deep inspiration  and light-headedness. The symptoms started a couple of hours ago while he was gardening at home.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he is currently taking amlodipine and atorvastatin  respectively. He underwent a total knee replacement surgery 6 weeks ago  after which he was largely immobile but was not on prophylactic anticoagulation treatment. He also shares a family history of deep vein thrombosis. He does not have any known drug allergies.  Clinical Examination: On physical examination  the patient seems anxious and in distress but oriented to time  place and person. Respiratory examination reveals tachypnea and mild wheezing  but no crackles or signs of consolidation. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia with regular rhythm  no murmurs or extra heart sounds. His oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient has mild swelling and tenderness in his right calf.  Given the patient's past medical history  recent surgery and immobility  acute onset symptoms and clinical findings  acute pulmonary embolism is highly suspected. He will need immediate diagnostic workup including D-dimer  chest CT angiogram and Doppler ultrasound of the leg to confirm the diagnosis and to decide on the best course of action for the treatment.

Patient Presentation:   Mrs. Smith is a 72-year-old African American retired schoolteacher who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain. She has a medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and had a total right hip replacement 5 months ago. She also suffers from high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes  both of which are managed with medications.   Over the past 48 hours  Mrs. Smith reports experiencing an increasing difficulty in breathing  especially when lying down  along with a dull  heavy ache in the right side of her chest. She also complains of feeling light-headed and fatigued. She denies any recent trauma  cough  or fever  but has noticed some intermittent swelling in her right calf  which she attributed to post-operative recovery.   She is a non-smoker but has a family history of thrombotic events in her mother and elder sister. On arrival  her vital signs are blood pressure 145/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 24/min  temperature 37.1 C  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. On physical examination  breath sounds are reduced on the right side. Her right calf is swollen and warm to touch.   The patient is otherwise alert and oriented  though clearly anxious regarding her breathing issues. Medication reconciliation shows she takes metformin for her diabetes  lisinopril for hypertension  and has not been compliant with her prescribed anticoagulant therapy post-hip surgery. Given these clinical findings  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is suspected.

Patient Information: 50-year-old  Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp chest pain  History of Present Illness: The patient reports developing sudden-onset difficulty breathing and a sharp  stabbing chest pain earlier this morning. The pain gets worse when he takes deep breaths. The patient also complains of feeling lightheaded and weak. No associated cough  fever  or sputum production.  Past Medical History: The patient is a smoker with a 30-pack year history. He is also overweight with a history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension. He recently had a total hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. No known drug allergies.  Vital Signs: Blood Pressure 140/90 mm Hg  Pulse 110 bpm  Respiratory Rate 24 breaths per minute  O2 saturation 92% on room air  Temperature 98.2 F.  Physical Examination: The patient appears anxious and in distress with signs of respiratory difficulty. Chest examination reveals tachypnea and decreased breath sounds on the right lower lung field. The remaining examination is within normal limits.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old African-American female retired teacher.  Chief Complaint: Sudden-onset difficulty breathing and chest discomfort.  History of Present Illness: Patient began to experience intense  sharp chest pain on her left side about 2 hours ago while sitting and watching TV at home. She reports the pain worsens when she takes deep breaths. She also has been experiencing sudden shortness of breath and a mild dry cough. She denies any fever  nausea  or vomiting. She is not experiencing palpitations nor lightheadedness. She rates her pain as 7 out of 10.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  well-controlled with medication. She suffered from deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago after a right hip replacement surgery where she was not ambulant for some time. She also has recurrent varicose veins  for which she’s been using compression stockings. She has not been on any anticoagulation since her DVT after her orthopedic surgeon discontinued after one year. Additionally  she had an episode of atrial fibrillation 2 years ago which was managed with cardioversion and she has been in sinus rhythm as per her most recent ECG 4 months ago. She does not have any known allergies.  Family History: Patient mother died from a stroke at the age of 85  father died from lung cancer. Her younger brother has a diagnosis of coronary artery disease.  Social History: The patient is a retired teacher  she lives alone  and she does not smoke or use illicit drugs and her alcohol consumption is limited to social occasions.  Review of Systems: General malaise  but otherwise negative.  Assessment: Taken together  her symptoms and past medical history are highly suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism. The patient needs immediate diagnostic testing including d-dimer  coagulation studies  arterial blood gases and if stable enough should proceed to computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) to confirm diagnosis.   Plan: Pending diagnostic results  she may be immediately started on anticoagulants such as heparin or direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC). A consultation with a pulmonologist and possibly hematology might be considered.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Hispanic male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of dyspnea  chest pain  and coughing up small amounts of blood for the last 2 hours. The pain is described as sharp  localized to the right side of his chest and gets worse during deep breathing. He also reports feeling light headed and experiencing palpitations. He denies any history of trauma or recent immobilization.   Past Medical History:  Relevant past medical history includes hypertension which is well-controlled on lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide  and type 2 diabetes for which he takes metformin. This patient has a 45 pack-year smoking history. He has never been told he has any lung or heart disease. He has not had any prior surgeries. There is no history of allergies. The patient also confirms a familial history of blood clots  with his mother suffering from multiple deep vein thromboses.   Social History:  He lives alone and is retired. He has been a heavy smoker for 45 years  does not drink alcohol  and denies any illicit drug use. His baseline activity is limited due to osteoarthritis of the knee. As for diet  he admits to consuming a usual American diet with high salt and fat content. He was recently on a 6-hour flight about a week ago.

Patient Presentation:   A 68-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that started approximately four hours prior to presentation. The patient describes the chest pain as sharp and pleuritic in nature  radiating to the left shoulder and intensifying with deep breaths. The patient admits to feeling lightheaded and having a fainting spell this morning  but denies any episodes of vomiting or changes in bowel habits. No cough  fever  chills  or night sweats. The patient also claims to have been experiencing swelling and tenderness in his right lower leg for the past week which he initially associated with his longstanding osteoarthritis.   Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are managed with Metoprolol and Metformin  respectively. He was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis in his right leg 2 years ago  for which he was prescribed Warfarin but has inconsistently taken it for the past six months. He had been a smoker for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. The patient does not have any known drug allergies.  Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father dying from a heart attack at an early age (55 years old) and his mother suffering from a stroke at the age of 62. His elder sister was diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism at the age of 65.   Social History:   The patient is a retired construction worker  lives with his wife and is mostly sedentary since retirement. He occasionally consumes alcohol but does not use any illicit drugs. He admits to noncompliance with his prescribed medication because of financial difficulties. Patient lives on the fourth floor in a building without an elevator and has been isolating himself due to recent COVID-19 lockdowns.

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department exhibiting acute shortness of breath  chest pain and coughing. She describes the chest pain as a sharp  constant pain which intensifies with deep inspiration. She also mentions she has been feeling light-headed and experienced a syncopal episode earlier in the day.  Demographic Details:   The patient is a retired school teacher  living with her husband  a former smoker who quit about 10 years ago. She denies any use of illicit drugs or alcohol. She takes hormone replacement therapy for post-menopausal symptoms. The patient has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 32 and leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History:  On delving deeper into her past medical history  it is revealed that the patient has a history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She also has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago when she experienced pain and swelling in her right leg after a long haul flight. Her only medications are lisinopril  atorvastatin  and the aforementioned hormone replacement therapy. She doesn't have any known drug allergies. She has never undergone a major surgery apart from an uncomplicated Cesarean section 35 years ago.    Family History:   Her father died of a heart attack at the age of 75 and her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 68. Her older brother is living and has a history of coronary artery disease. There is no family history of blood clotting disorders reported.

Patient Presentation: A 63-year-old Caucasian female named Jane Doe arrives at the ER complaining of sudden-onset chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitation which started 2 hours ago. The pain is described as sharp  located in the right side of her chest  and it worsens with deep breathing. She denies any cough  fever  or phlegm production. She has a profound history of smoking  approximately 30 pack-years. She currently smokes about half of a pack per day. She notes associated symptoms of lightheadedness but denies fainting  nausea  or sweating.   Past Medical History: She has a known history of hypertension  for which she is taking amlodipine 10 mg daily  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is on inhaled bronchodilators. She has no known drug allergies. She underwent a total right knee replacement surgery two weeks ago and has been relatively immobile since then. She has no history of lung disease  heart disease  or cancer. Family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis  with her mother having suffered from it. She lives alone and works as a clerk; her diet and sleep have been normal.

Patient Presentation:   Ms. Woods is a 62-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history significant for obesity (BMI: 35)  hypothyroidism  and recent total knee arthroplasty performed two weeks ago. She presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of a sudden onset of shortness of breath  which began earlier in the day and has been steadily worsening. She admits to chest pain  described as intense and sharp  which increases with deep inhalation.   She denies any history of similar symptoms but reports increasing fatigue and light-headedness over the past 48 hours. She has no known personal or familial history of coagulation disorders or pulmonary embolism. Ms. Woods reports smoking half a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. She lives alone but her daughter checks on her daily. She has been largely bed-ridden since her knee surgery.   No history of fever  cough  hemoptysis  or gross leg swelling. She does acknowledge a bit of warmth and slight swelling around the area of the knee surgery but does not attribute her current distress to these symptoms. On examination  she appears mildly distressed and is tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 26  heart rate of 110 BPM  blood pressure of 140/90  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Her physical exam is remarkable for decreased breath sounds over the right lung base  mild leg edema  and slight warmth and redness over the recent surgical site. She rates her pain as a 7 out of 10 while at rest and an 8/10 on deep inspiration.

Patient Presentation:  A 68-year-old African-American female presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that is sharp in nature and worsens upon deep inspiration. She also reports feeling lightheaded with occasional palpitations  but denies any cough  fever  or sputum production. The symptoms began approximately 3 hours ago while she was at home watching television. The patient is visibly anxious and appears diaphoretic and tachypnic. Her vitals on presentation are: BP 140/90 mmHg  HR 110 bpm  RR 28 breaths/min  Temperature 98.4°F (36.9°C)  and SpO2 of 86% on room air.   Past Medical History: This patient has a known history of hypertension  poorly controlled type-2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. She recently had a total hip replacement surgery on the left side 3 weeks ago. Post-operation  the patient was largely immobile. She is also a former smoker with a 25 pack-year history and quit smoking approximately 10 years ago.   Social History:  The patient lives alone but receives assistance from a home health aide twice a week. She denies any current tobacco  alcohol  or illicit drug use. She has a family history of deep vein thrombosis in her mother and maternal aunt.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of moderate-to-severe chest pain that started about 2 hours ago  with increased pain during deep inspiration. The patient also reports experiencing shortness of breath  palpitations  light-headedness  and moderate anxiety.  He has a past medical history significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago  hypertension for which he takes lisinopril  and is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history. He just completed a long-haul flight from Australia to the United States 24 hours earlier. He has no known allergies.  His vitals on arrival are: blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  heart rate 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  temperature 98.5°F  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air.  On physical examination  he appears distressed and diaphoretic. Lung auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds on the right lower lung field  with no obvious wheezing  crackles  or rhonchi. Heart Auscultation demonstrates tachycardia and no murmur. His lower extremities show no signs of edema  erythema  or tenderness. His skin is warm with good perfusion  and there are no signs of cyanosis. An initial ECG shows sinus tachycardia.   Given his symptoms and medical history  there is a high suspicion for an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. James Henderson  a 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type II diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and a 30 pack-year smoking history  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain. The chest pain is described as sharp and pleuritic in nature  worsening upon taking a deep breath. Mr. Henderson also reported light-headedness but denied any syncope  hemoptysis  or calf pain/swelling.  Over the past week  he has been more sedentary than usual due to a slight sprain in his right ankle. He denies any recent surgery  long-distance travel or family history of venous thrombo-embolism. On examination  he was found to be tachycardic and tachypneic with oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. No leg swelling or tenderness was observed. Rest of his examination was unremarkable.  In terms of medication  he has been compliant with his metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies. He lives alone and diagnosed with depression since his wife passed away last year. He mostly stays inside the house due to lack of social interactions. He drinks alcohol on social occasions and has a 30 pack-year smoking history. He didn't travel anywhere recently or hasn't been bedridden for a prolonged period.

Patient Presentation:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of dyspnea  sharp chest pain that is worse with deep breaths  and a dry cough that occurred while he was gardening this morning. He relates feeling lightheaded and reports a near-syncopal episode. He denies any recent surgery  trauma or immobilization.   Vitals: BP 125/80 mmHg  Heart rate 105 bpm  Respiratory rate 22 breaths/min  oxygen saturation 92% on room air  Temperature 98.7°F.   Demographics: Non-smoker  lives alone  moderate alcohol consumption  non drug user  doesn't have any allergies  BMI of 29 indicating obesity.   Past medical history includes uncontrolled hypertension for which he was prescribed Amlodipine 10mg daily but is non-compliant due to financial reasons. He also has hyperlipidemia managed with Atorvastatin and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago. He was taken off of anticoagulation 3 years ago by his primary. He has never had a screening for thrombophilia and does not have any family history of clotting disorders.   This presentation could potentially indicate acute pulmonary embolism  especially given his obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and previous history of DVT.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with an acute onset of shortness of breath  chest pain which worsens with deep breathing  and light-headedness that started about six hours ago. The patient also reports a productive cough with bloody sputum. There is no fever  vomiting  or abdominal pain.   The patient has a known past medical history of chronic atrial fibrillation for which she is on warfarin anti-coagulation therapy  deep vein thrombosis treated five years ago  obesity with a BMI of 34  and hypertension controlled with medication. She further reports she had knee replacement surgery 2 months ago. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. Family history reveals a father who died due to stroke and a mother with a history of recurrent blood clots.  On examination  she appears anxious and in respiratory distress with a respiratory rate of 28  heart rate 105  blood pressure 150/90  and oxygen saturation of 90% while breathing ambient air. Auscultation of the lungs reveals decreased breath sounds and crackles in the right lower lung field. Cardiac examination reveals an irregularly irregular heartbeat but no murmurs. Pulses are equal in all extremities  moderate pitting edema is noted in both lower limbs. Laboratory results indicate elevated troponin and D-dimer levels. A cursory ultrasound scan shows deep vein thrombosis in the left lower extremity.  The clinical presentation and labs highly suggest an acute pulmonary embolism  most likely due to a thrombus from her DVT. An immediate initiation of treatment is required.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. D  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  is an active smoker with a 40 pack-year smoking history. He has a past medical history significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hypertension. He recently had total knee replacement surgery four weeks ago. He presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath that started a few hours ago and has progressively gotten worse.   The patient reported the shortness of breath was not associated with any chest pain but he did notice an increased palpitation. He feels light-headed with movement. He also noticed a sudden coph and scant hemoptysis. He also reports that he has been mostly bed-ridden since his knee surgery and had been noticing some swelling in his operated leg for the last two days.  Mr. D's mother suffered a deep vein thrombosis in her late sixties. He had no allergies and his home medications include Spiriva and Lisinopril. Vital signs on presentation are as follows: BP 144/82 mmHg  HR 110 bpm  Temp 37C (98.6F)  RR 22 breaths per minute  and O2 saturation of 87% on room air. On examination  normal heart sounds were heard with tachycardia. His right knee was swollen; otherwise  the physical examination was unremarkable. While the patient appears anxious  there is no noted cyanosis or diaphoresis.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old African American male presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath and a sharp chest pain that worsens when he takes a deep breath. The patient states that he noticed sudden onset of symptoms which have progressively worsened over the past two hours.  Past Medical History:  The patient reports that he has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) for which he was on blood thinners  but had stopped taking them six months ago due to a minor surgery. He also shares that he has hypertension controlled by medication. He had hip replacement surgery three weeks ago and has been recovering at home with limited mobility. He does not have any known allergies. His family history includes a father and a brother who had heart diseases. He has a history of 30 pack-years of smoking but quit five years ago.  Current Medication:  The patient has been on Lisinopril for his hypertension. He was previously taking Warfarin for his DVT  but had stopped six months prior toPresentation.

Patient Presentation:  A 62-year-old African American female presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset  sharp and constant chest pain that started 3 hours ago. The pain is localized on the right side and increases with deep breathing. She reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  light headedness  and palpitations. There is no reported history of fever  cough  hemoptysis or lower limb swelling. She denies chest trauma  recent surgery or long periods of immobility.   Past medical history (PMH): She's a known hypertensive on treatment for the past 5 years. She has a history of active smoking for 30 years but quit 6 years ago. There is no known case of Diabetes Mellitus  Hypothyroidism  asthma or any other lung disease. Family history is pertinent for a sister with deep vein thrombosis.  On physical examination  the patient appears anxious and is in respiratory distress with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Vital signs are as follows: BP 142/88 mmHg  Pulse 104 bpm  Temperature 98.6°F  and Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. Chest auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds on the right lower zone but no abnormalities were detected on heart sounds. No peripheral edema is seen on limb examination. Rest of the systemic examination is unremarkable.

Patient Presentation  A 65-year-old African American male ambulance driver presents to the emergency department with acute onset of chest pain and sudden shortness of breath. The chest pain is sharp  localized to the right side of his chest  and gets worse upon deep inspiration. The patient ranked the pain as 8 out of 10. He also reports a dry cough but denies any fever or recent travel.   The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He has been non-compliant with his medications (Lisinopril and Metformin) due to his irregular work schedule. He notes a family history of deep vein thrombosis in his father. He also admits to a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical exercise outside his job.   Upon examination  the patient appears anxious and demonstrates tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation on room air is noted to be 88%. His heart rate is 99 beats per minute  and blood pressure is 154/95 mmHg. Chest examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side. The rest of physical exam  including cardiovascular and lower extremity examination  is unremarkable.   Suspecting a possible pulmonary embolism  the attending physician orders a d-dimer test  chest CT angiography  and an ECG. The working diagnosis is acute pulmonary embolism  likely secondary to possible underlying venous thromboembolism due to his extensive smoking history  family predisposition  hypertension  and sedentary lifestyle.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp  stabbing chest pain that gets worse with deep breathing  and blood-tinged sputum. The patient also reports feeling lightheaded and anxious.   Past medical history includes unilateral total knee replacement performed 2 weeks ago. Additionally  she has a medical history of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus which are well-controlled on Metformin and Lisinopril. She has also been a smoker for forty years. The patient lives alone and is retired  with a previous occupation as a school teacher.  The patient does not have any known allergies. Apart from her knee surgery  she has no other previous surgical history. Family history reveals that her mother had deep vein thrombosis. She denies any travel history in the past six months. The patient is compliant with her medications and follows a healthy diet. She does not consume alcohol but has a 20-pack year smoking history.   On physical examination  she is anxious with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths/minute  heart rate of 110 beats/minute  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  saturation of 90% on room air. Her chest examination reveals tachypnea and crackles at right lung base.  This scenario raises suspicion for an acute pulmonary embolism probably secondary to postoperative deep vein thrombosis. Immediate diagnostic studies and interventions are needed.

Patient Presentation:  Ms. Anita Gonzalez is a 65-year-old Latina retired school teacher who presents to the emergency department  complaining of sudden onset  sharp  right-sided chest pain  and shortness of breath since last night. She rates the pain as an 8 on a scale of 10  and mentions it worsens with deep breathing and coughing. She has been feeling lightheaded and experienced a bout of vomiting. She denies any recent trauma  fevers  cough  or hemoptysis.   She has been largely sedentary for the past month following a right total knee arthroplasty. She also has a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both well controlled with medications. She has a 45-pack year smoking history  but quit about five years back. She has not traveled recently but has been taking contraceptive pills for the past four years  following an onset of severe menstrual symptoms associated with menopause.   On examination  she is tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute  and her oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Chest examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the right lower lobe  but no audible wheeze or crackles.   Considering her symptoms  clinical findings  and risk factors (recent surgery  oral contraceptive usage  prolonged immobility)  an acute pulmonary embolism is suspected.

Chief Complaint: ""I suddenly started having trouble catching my breath""  Patient: 52-year-old  Caucasian male  Presenting Problem: Patient presents in the ER with sudden onset severe difficulty breathing  chest pain  and intermittent lightheadedness. The chest pain is sharp  worsens with deep breaths  and radiates to the back. Patient also reports limited mobility for the past week following a knee replacement surgery which led to minimal physical activity.  Vitals: BP 130/85 mmHg  HR 110 bpm  RR 28 bpm  Temp 98.8°F  SpO2 88% on room air  Past Medical History: 1. Type 2 diabetes mellitus 2. Hypertension 3. History of deep vein thrombosis following a long flight 3 years ago 4. Recent total knee replacement surgery a week ago.  Social History: Non-smoker with minimal alcohol intake  employed as an office worker.  Family History: Father had a stroke at age 67  mother has hypertension. No known family history of hypercoagulable states.   Physical examination: Slightly distressed due to dyspnea  mildly diaphoretic. Lung exam reveals tachypnea with no audible wheezes or crackles. Cardiovascular exam reveals tachycardia  no jugular venous distension  and normal heart sounds with no added sounds. No calf tenderness  swelling  or discoloration. Rest of the examination is unremarkable.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-aged Female Patient  Slide 1: Introduction Today  we will walk through a case involving an acute pulmonary embolism. Our patient is a middle-aged woman who presented with several concerning symptoms.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our patient is Mrs. Johnson  a 52-year-old Caucasian woman. She is a homemaker  nonsmoker  and rarely consumes alcohol. Mrs. Johnson has a body mass index (BMI) of 28  reflecting a mildly obese status. She resides in an urban location with her husband and has three adult children.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mrs. Johnson was diagnosed with high blood pressure eight years ago but has managed it effectively with medication. She was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes two years ago  which she's been monitoring and controlling with oral antidiabetic drugs. She also has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after her last childbirth 20 years ago. Furthermore  she has a sedentary lifestyle and a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms  Mrs. Johnson visited the emergency room complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  a sharp  localized chest pain that worsens with deep breaths  and mild bouts of unexplained coughing - occasionally with blood. Moreover  she reported experiencing episodes of fainting and mild swelling in her left leg.  Slide 5: Suspected Diagnosis and Reasons  Given her past medical history of DVT  current complaints  and predisposing factors (such as her sedentary lifestyle and history of hypertension and diabetes)  the symptoms strongly suggest an acute pulmonary embolism.  Slide 6: Tests and Diagnoses The diagnosis of pulmonary embolism is often confirmed with imaging tests. These may include Computerized tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) or a ventilation-perfusion (VQ) scan. D-dimer blood tests and ultrasound of the legs can further assist in diagnosing.  Slide 7: Conclusion  In conclusion  acute pulmonary embolism is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition. This case exemplifies how pre-existing health problems  lifestyle factors  and genetic predispositions can increase the risk. Early recognition and management of symptoms can significantly improve patient outcomes.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism: A Detailed Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction -  Subject: A case study of a patient diagnosed with Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE) -  Aim: To understand the unique medical history  presentation  diagnosis  and treatment options for APE  Slide 2: Patient Demographics -  Age: 50 years -  Gender: Male -  Race: Asian -  Occupation: Computer programmer  Slide 3: Past Medical History -  General: Non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumption -  Medical: Diagnosed with Type II Diabetes and Hypertension  managed with medication -  Family history: Father had Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT); mother died of Pulmonary Embolism (PE) -  Recent history: Returned from a long-haul flight (12 hours) two weeks ago  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms -  Presented to ER with sudden onset of chest pain  shortness of breath and light-headedness  -  Describes pain as central  sharp and intensified by breathing -  No symptoms of fever  cough  or hemoptysis  Slide 5: Clinical Examination -  Vital signs: Pulse 100 bpm  BP: 130/85 mmHg  Respiration: 24/min  Temperature: 98.4 F -  Chest examination: Diminished breath sounds right lower zone -  Cardiovascular  abdominal  neurological examination: Within normal limits  Slide 6: Preliminary Diagnosis -  Considering the patient's symptom profile and past medical history  a preliminary diagnosis of APE is made  -  Prioritized investigations: D-dimer test  CT Pulmonary Angiogram  Slide 7: Investigations and Final Diagnosis -  D-dimer test: Elevated -  CT Pulmonary Angiogram: Showed a clot in the right lower pulmonary artery confirming APE  Slide 8: Treatment and Management -  Initiated on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin -  Oral anticoagulation will be started before hospital discharge -  Patient education on lifestyle changes  importance of medication adherence and regular follow-ups   Slide 9: Prognosis and Follow-up - With early diagnosis and appropriate management  the prognosis is generally good -  Regular follow-ups to monitor the patient's response to treatment and to manage any potential side effects of medication  Slide 10: Conclusion  - This case highlights that a high degree of clinical suspicion and prompt action are paramount in managing patients with APE   - Encourage the timely recognition and treatment of PE and DVT to prevent fatal outcomes.

Slide 1: Introduction  Today  we will discuss a case involving an acute pulmonary embolism  a potentially life-threatening condition that requires immediate medical intervention.  Slide 2: Demographics  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith. He recently retired from his job as a bank accountant and lives with his wife in upstate New York. He has two children and two grandchildren  Slide 3: Presenting Condition  Mr. Smith presented to the emergency room with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain. The pain seesawed in intensity and noticeably worsened upon deep breaths. Nauses and dizziness were also reported.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  Mr. Smith is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago. He is slightly overweight with a BMI of 26.2 kg/m². He has a known history of deep vein thrombosis  high blood pressure  and hypercholesterolemia. He ceased recreational activities due to increased fatigue and shortness of breath over the past 6 months. There's been no history of surgery or long time immobilization.  Slide 5: Recent Clinical History   Ten days ago  Mr. Smith returned from a cross-country driving vacation. The journey required extended periods of sitting and minimal exercise.  Slide 6: Hospital Admission  Upon admission  the hospital staff performed a CT angiography  which confirmed the presence of a pulmonary embolism in his right lung. He was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy.  Slide 7: Conclusion  Mr. Smith's case underscores the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with shortness of breath and chest pain  especially those with risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  previous DVT  and history of long multistage driving. It also highlights the critical role of swift diagnostic procedures and timely commencement of therapy to prevent potential fatalities.   This concludes our case presentation on an acute pulmonary embolism. We will continue to monitor Mr. Smith's condition and adjust his treatment as necessary.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism - A Case Review  Slide 1: Patient Demographics • Patient Identifier: J.D. • Age: 65 years old • Gender: Male • Ethnicity: Caucasian • Occupation: Retired schoolteacher  Slide 2: Past Medical History • Non-smoker & occasional drinker • Hypertension - Diagnosed at the age of 53  and it has been controlled with medication • Type 2 Diabetes - Diagnosed at the age of 59  managed with diet and oral hypoglycemic agents • No family history of coagulation disorders • Completed a long drive (8 hours) 2 days before the onset of symptoms  Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms • Shortness of breath • Tachypnea • Mild pleuritic chest pain • Slight hemoptysis  Slide 4: Physical Examination Findings • Blood Pressure: 145/90 mmHg • Heart Rate: 110 bpm  • No obvious signs of DVT such as leg swelling or redness • The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Workup • ECG: Sinus tachycardia • CT pulmonary angiography: Showed a thrombus in the right main pulmonary artery - confirmed the diagnosis of Pulmonary Embolism • D-dimer: Elevated • Blood glucose and lipid profile within normal levels  Slide 6: Management & Prognosis • Immediate management started with anticoagulants for clot dissolution  • Oxygen therapy to address the patient's shortness of breath • Patient was educated about following up regularly and adhering to medication regimen • The prognosis is generally good with timely treatment; however  the patient will need regular monitoring due to his co-existing conditions.   Slide 7: Key Points to Take Home • Consider PE in any patient presenting with sudden unexplained dyspnea  chest pain  or unexplained hypoxia  especially with notable risk factors (like extended periods of immobilization) • Early detection and management of PE is crucial to prevent potentially fatal complications • Comorbid conditions influence management strategies and affect the patient's overall prognosis.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: ""Case Study: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 50-year-old Female Patient""  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - Age: 50 years  - Sex: Female - Occupation: Office worker  - Lifestyle: Sedentary  non-smoker  occasional alcohol - Family Background: No known familial history of cardiac or respiratory conditions.   Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms - Shortness of breath - Chest pain that intensifies with deep breaths or cough - Fainting or feeling lightheaded - Rapid pulse - Cough  sometimes with blood  Slide 4: Past Medical and Surgical History - Suffered from uncontrolled hypertension for the past 5 years. - Underwent total knee replacement surgery 6 weeks ago. - History of recurrent Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) despite therapeutic anticoagulation. - Diagnosed with obesity  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 35.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Evaluation - Computed tomographic pulmonary angiography (CTPA) confirmed the presence of a clot in the pulmonary artery. - D-dimer test came back positive  indicating possible blood clot. - Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of right heart strain. - Ultrasound revealed recurrent DVT in the left lower extremity.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan - Patient was immediately put on parenteral anticoagulation therapy (low-molecular-weight heparin) followed by oral anticoagulation (rivaroxaban). - In view of persisting hypoxia and large clot burden  she was evaluated for thrombolytic therapy.   Slide 7: Patient Education and Follow-up - Explained to patient about the condition and importance of medication adherence to prevent future pulmonary embolism. - Advised patient on lifestyle modification; regular exercise  low sodium diet and weight management strategies. - Six-month follow-up appointment scheduled to assess the condition and treatment effectiveness.   Slide 8: Conclusion - Despite the patient's relatively complex medical history  prompt diagnosis and appropriate management of an Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE) can lead to a successful patient outcome. - Educating the patient about the disease and importance of follow-up care to prevent recurrent APE.   Note: This is a hypothetical patient for educational purposes. Actual care plans should be made based on individual patient needs.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism: A Clinical Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction Here we discuss the case of a patient who presented with acute pulmonary embolism. Our aim is to review the etiology  movement  and management of pulmonary embolism.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our patient is a 58-year-old African American male  with a desk job and a smoking history of 30 pack-years.  Slide 3: Past Medical History The patient has a history of hypertension and obesity. BMI is 31. He was diagnosed with left lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 4 years ago  successfully treated with anticoagulation therapy. Patient's compliance with hypertension and anti-smoking medication is inconsistent.  Slide 4: Current Presentation The patient presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. Upon physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic. His vital parameters indicated tachycardia and tachypnea. He had bloody sputum  but no wheezing or leg swelling was observed.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Evaluation A CT pulmonary angiography confirmed the presence of a clot in the left pulmonary artery. Lab results showed elevated D-dimer level and mild troponin elevation. Electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia and S1Q3T3 pattern indicative of acute pulmonary embolism. Ultrasound of the legs revealed a fresh clot in the left popliteal vein suggestive of DVT recurrence.  Slide 6: Management and Treatment The patient was started on a heparin drip and later transitioned to oral anticoagulant therapy. Oxygen support was provided to correct hypoxia. He was educated about the importance of medication adherence  lifestyle modifications which include smoking cessation  weight management  and periodic follow-ups.  Slide 7: Follow-Up and Prognosis Follow-up recommendations include regular outpatient visits for monitoring blood coagulation parameters  echocardiogram assessments  leg ultrasounds  and ongoing support for smoking cessation. The patient's prognosis is guarded  given the history of past non-compliance  but with consistent treatment and lifestyle changes  significant improvements can be expected.   Slide 8: Conclusion This case reinforces the importance of considering Pulmonary Embolism in patients with a history of DVT presenting with chest symptoms. We were reminded of the significant impacts of lifestyle factors  particularly smoking and weight management  on disease presentation and progression.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Case Presentation on Acute Pulmonary Embolism ""Today we will be discussing a case of a patient who presented with symptoms leading us to suspect and confirm the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.""  Slide 2: Patient Demographics ""Patient X is a 65-year-old Caucasian female. She's a retired teacher  lives with her husband  and is quite active in her community. She doesn't smoke or drink and her BMI falls into the ideal range. She has two adult children and four grandchildren.""  Slide 3: Past Medical History ""Her past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which she takes a calcium channel blocker and a statin  respectively. She underwent a hysterectomy at the age of 48 due to fibroids. Her mother suffered from deep vein thrombosis. No history of surgeries  trauma  or prolonged immobilization.""  Slide 4: Current Presentation  ""Patient X presented to the emergency room with sudden onset dyspnea  light-headedness  palpitations  and sharp  central chest pain that exacerbated on deep inspiration. She denied a cough  hemoptysis  leg swelling  or recent travel.""  Slide 5: Examination ""Upon exam  she was found to be in mild distress  with a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg  respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 90% on room air. Chest examination showed tachypnea but was otherwise clear. No signs of deep vein thrombosis in extremities.""  Slide 6: Investigations  ""An electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia. Blood tests revealed elevated D-dimer levels. A CT pulmonary angiography was ordered which confirmed the presence of a pulmonary embolism. A duplex ultrasound of her lower extremities was negative for deep vein thrombosis.""  Slide 7: Diagnosis and Treatment  ""The clinical presentation  examination findings  and investigations confirm a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. Considering the absence of severe hemodynamic instability or major contraindications  she was initiated on anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin and then bridged to oral anticoagulation.""  Slide 8: Conclusion  ""Our patient is currently stable and doing well on the current treatment plan. Her case highlights the importance of early recognition and initiation of treatment of acute pulmonary embolism to prevent morbidity and mortality.""   Slide 9: Q&A  ""Any questions or comments?""

Slide 1: Title ""Case Presentation: Acute Pulmonary Embolism""  Slide 2: Patient Demographics ""Patient: Mr. X  a 58-year-old Caucasian male.""  Slide 3: Past Medical History ""Past Medical History reveals Mr. X is a former smoker (quit 10 years ago)  suffering from Stage 2 hypertension for the past 7 years  and has had uncontrolled type 2 diabetes for the last 6 years. He had an orthopedic surgery (hip replacement) approximately 4 weeks ago.""  Slide 4: Presenting Complaint ""Mr. X presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain  particularly on deep inspiration  that appeared a few hours ago. The pain was described as sharp and worsening with deep breaths.""  Slide 5: Physical Examination ""Upon examination  Mr. X appeared restless and anxious  his vitals were: Blood Pressure: 150/95 mmHg  Heart Rate: 108 bpm  Respiratory Rate: 24 breaths/min  SpO2: 90% on room air. On auscultation  his breath sounds appeared diminished with faint rales in the left lower region.""  Slide 6: Diagnostic Approach ""A D-dimer test  a chest X-ray  and an Electrocardiogram (ECG) were ordered immediately with a working differential of Acute Pulmonary embolism. The CT Pulmonary angiography was ordered based on the clinical presentation and elevated D-dimer levels.""   Slide 7: Diagnosis and Treatment ""The CT Pulmonary Angiogram revealed a filling defect in the left pulmonary artery confirming a diagnosis of Pulmonary Embolism. Mr. X was started right away on oxygen therapy  anticoagulants  and analgesics for chest pain relief.""  Slide 8: Prognosis & Counseling ""Mr. X responded well to the management with gradual relief of symptoms. He was recommended lifestyle modifications  regular follow-ups  and educated about recognizing possible symptoms of recurrence.""  Slide 9: Discussion & Questions ""This case emphasizes the high index of suspicion needed in patients with risk factors  to enable timely diagnosis and management of Acute Pulmonary Embolism."" ""Thank you for your attention  time for any questions or discussions.""  End of Presentation

Title: Case Presentation on Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Slide 1: Introduction • A clinical case of a 50-year-old female presenting with Acute Pulmonary Embolism.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  • Age: 50 years • Gender: Female • Occupation: Office worker • Lifestyle: Sedentary  non-smoker and non-alcoholic  Slide 3: Past Medical History • The patient had a large left ovarian cyst removed five years ago.  • She had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following the surgery. • She is obese with a BMI of 32.  • She has chronic hypertension controlled with medication.  Slide 4: Current Clinical Presentation • Patient presented to the ER with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and fainting.  • On arrival  blood pressure was 110/70 mmHg  heart rate was 120 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 25 breaths per minute.   Slide 5: Preliminary Diagnosis and Further Investigation • Given the patient's history and current symptoms  an acute pulmonary embolism was suspected. • An emergency CT scan of the chest was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a large clot in her left pulmonary artery.  Slide 6: Treatment Plan • The management plan includes immediate anticoagulation therapy with heparin. • Long-term oral anticoagulant - warfarin is considered taking her previous DVT episode into account. • Patient education on lifestyle changes  weight management and regular follow-ups are emphasized.  Slide 7: Conclusion • The patient's past medical history of DVT and current sedentary lifestyle greatly contributed to this acute episode of pulmonary embolism. • This case underscores the importance of early detection and effective management of risk factors for pulmonary embolism.

Title: Case Presentation of Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Slide 1: Introduction - Topic of discussion: Understanding Acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE) through a real-life case study. Title: A Clinical Case Review: Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Slide 1: Introduction - Title of Case: Acute Pulmonary Embolism – A diagnosis and management case study - Brief Outline: This presentation involves a case study about a patient who presented with Acute Pulmonary Embolism. We will discuss the clinical  diagnostic  and therapeutic approaches  evaluating the patient's past medical history and present symptoms.  Slide 2: The Case  -Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Johnson. -Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson was previously diagnosed with hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. -Health Habits: He has a 30-pack year smoking history and reports having a sedentary lifestyle. -Family History: Positive for heart disease with his father dying of a heart attack at the age of 68.  Slide 3: Symptoms and Physical Findings: -Mr. Johnson presented to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and moderate to severe chest pain. -He also reported episodes of light-headedness. -Upon examination: He was found to be tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 25/min  BP of 155/95 mm Hg  pulse of 110 bpm  T of 98.4°F  and O2 Sat: 91% on room air.  Slide 4: Diagnostic Approach:  -Initial Investigation: ECG was ordered which showed sinus tachycardia but no characteristic signs of a PE. -D-Dimer test: Elevated levels  suggesting a state of increased coagulation. -CT Angiography: Confirmed the diagnosis  it showed filling defects in the form of clots in the bilateral pulmonary arteries  indicating a pulmonary embolism. -Supported by echocardiography: Demonstrated right ventricular dilatation and strain.  Slide 5: Treatment and Follow Up:  -Anticoagulation Therapy: Patient was started on heparin infusion for immediate anticoagulation  followed by long-term oral anticoagulant warfarin. -Oxygen was supplied to correct hypoxia. -Patient Education: Mr. Johnson was counseled on lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation and increased physical activity. -Follow up: Regular monitoring was advocated to assess the resolution of the clot and to manage his chronic conditions.  Slide 6: Conclusion  -Our patient  Mr. Johnson  despite having a significant risk factor profile including hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  a sedentary lifestyle  and smoking history  was successfully diagnosed and managed for an acute episode of Pulmonary Embolism. -Well-coordinated and comprehensive care involving diagnostics  patient education  lifestyle modification  and drug therapy played a key role in his favorable prognosis.

Title: A Case Study on Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Slide 1: Introduction   The case I am presenting today involves a patient diagnosed with Acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE). PE is a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs  often initiated by blood clots  often originated in the leg  that travel up to the lungs.  Slide 2: Patient Information  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female. She is non-smoker and non-alcoholic leading a sedentary lifestyle. She works as an Executive  has long working hours and minimal physical activity.   Slide 3: Past Medical History  She has a history of Hypertension (HTN) and Type II Diabetes Mellitus (DM). She was on medication for both conditions. She has no known drug allergy and no surgical history. There's family history for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  Slide 4: Present Complaints  She was admitted to the emergency department showing symptoms of sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breaths  lightheadedness  and rapid pulse.  Slide 5: Diagnosis  Considering the symptoms  her medical history  and after respective diagnostic tests which included D-dimer test  CT pulmonary angiography  and Ultrasound of the lower limbs  she was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.  Slide 6: Medical Management   She was immediately started on anticoagulant medication to prevent further clot formation as well as thrombolytics to dissolve the current clot. Supportive oxygen therapy was given.  Slide 7: Conclusion  This case emphasizes the importance of considering PE in differentially diagnosing older patients with sudden unexplained dyspnea or chest discomfort  especially those with risk factors such as sedentary lifestyle  HTN  DM  and a family history of DVT. Prompt diagnosis and effective management result in appreciable clinical outcomes.   Slide 8: Lesson   To prevent the recurrence of PE  lifestyle changes like regular exercise  frequent movement during prolonged sitting or lying conditions should be advised. Those with HTN and DM should keep their conditions under control with regular follow-up and medication.   -EOM-

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction A discussion about a 67-year-old Caucasian male patient  who has been admitted to the emergency department with acute dyspnea and chest pain. This case study aims at evaluating the clinical history  diagnosis  management and relevant follow-ups of the patient suffering from acute pulmonary embolism.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics and Past Medical History Mr. J is a retired mechanical engineer with no history of smoking or drug abuse. His past medical history includes being overweight with a BMI of 28 and hypertension for which he has been on medication for the last 10 years. He recently had total knee replacement surgery three weeks ago.   Slide 3: Presenting Complaints Mr. J complains of sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that gets worse on deep breaths  and mild dizziness. He also mentioned that the symptoms have been progressively worsening over the course of the day.   Slide 4: Physical Examination On examination  Mr. J was anxious  his pulse rate was 110 beats/minute  blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg  respiratory rate was 24 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation was at 88% on room air. His lower extremity showed mild swelling.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Procedures An immediate chest CT angiography was ordered which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism showing clots in the right pulmonary artery. Blood tests showed abnormal coagulation times  elevated D-dimer levels  and mildly impaired renal function.  Slide 6: Treatment  Immediate anticoagulation therapy was initiated with low molecular weight heparin. Patient was hospitalized and took part in a pulmonary rehabilitation program.   Slide 7: Follow-up and Prognosis Mr. J was switched to oral anticoagulation therapy before being discharged. Educated on signs and symptoms of PE  importance of medication compliance and routine follow-up.   Slide 8: Conclusion This case study emphasizes the significance of timely recognition and treatment of acute pulmonary embolism  particularly high-risk patients. The role of ongoing patient education and vigilance in monitoring symptoms to minimize potential recurrence cannot be understated.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Case Presentation: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - Age: 66 years old - Gender: Female - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired school teacher - Lifestyle: Sedentary with minimal exercise  Slide 3: Past Medical History  - Hypertension (well controlled with medication) - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (Insulin-dependent) - Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD  managed with inhalants) - History of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) approximately 5 years ago  Slide 4: Presenting Complaint  - The patient presented with sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens on deep breathing  and a noticeable fast heart rate.  Slide 5: Physical Examination and Investigations  - Vital signs: BP-150/90 mmHg  Pulse-105/min  Respiratory rate-24/min  Temperature-98.5°F - Chest examination: Clear with normal vesicular breath sounds - Cardiac examination: Tachycardic but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops - Examination of lower limbs: No signs of DVT - Investigations: CT chest showing filling defects in both the pulmonary arteries (consistent with embolus)  D-Dimer levels elevated and Troponin levels slightly raised. ECG showing sinus tachycardia.  Slide 6: Diagnosis and Discussion  - Given the patient's symptoms  medical history  physical examination  and investigation results  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is made.  - The management will be focused on relieving symptoms and preventing these clots from getting larger. The patient's history of DVT suggests a propensity for blood clot formation  and her sedentary lifestyle and chronic conditions like type 2 diabetes and hypertension pose as risk factors.  Slide 7: Management and Outcome  - The patient was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy with Heparin  followed by oral Warfarin. - Further management focused on control of her diabetes and hypertension  increasing her physical activity  dietary modifications  and smoking cessation counseling  as she was a smoker. - The patient was closely monitored  and her symptoms improved significantly over the following days.  Slide 8: Conclusion  Through regular monitoring and medication  the patient's Pulmonary Embolism was successfully managed resulting in reduced symptoms and improved overall health status.

Slide 1: Introduction - Title: A Case Presentation on Acute Pulmonary Embolism - Presenter: Medical Educator - Purpose: To analyze and discuss a particular case to enhance our understanding and clinical decision process surrounding Acute Pulmonary Embolism.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  - The patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male.  - Occupation: Retired engineer.  - Social History: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol drinker  married with 2 adult children.  Slide 3: Chief Complaint  - The patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath which started roughly 3 hours prior to arrival.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  - The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation  for which he is on rhythm-control medications.  - He has some controlled hypertension and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years prior treated with anticoagulation.  - No known drug allergies.  Slide 5: Current Medications  - The patient reports taking the following medications regularly: - Rivaroxaban for Atrial Fibrillation. - Lisinopril for hypertension.  Slide 6: Clinical Findings - On examination  the patient appears distressed due to dyspnea. - Vital Signs: BP - 155/95 mmHg  HR - 110 beats/min  RR - 24 breaths/min  Temp - 98.7°F  O2 saturation - 90% on room air. - Auscultation reveals tachycardia and decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung field.  Slide 7: Initial Assessment  - Given the patient's presenting symptoms  history of DVT  atrial fibrillation  and physical examination  there should be a high index of suspicion for Acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE).  Slide 8: Diagnostic Approach - The initial investigations should include: D-Dimer  electrocardiogram  echocardiogram  CT Pulmonary Angiography and lower extremity ultrasonography to verify the suspicion.  Slide 9: Case Discussion and Management Plan - A comprehensive discussion on the management options  which primarily include therapeutic anticoagulation. This should take into consideration the patient's past medical history and current presentation.    Slide 10: Conclusion  - Highlight the importance of quick identification and treatment of patients presenting with Acute Pulmonary Embolism. This case also emphasizes the significance of considering a patient’s past medical history in diagnosis and treatment planning.   Slide 11: References - Listing of the references used for this case presentation.   Slide 12: Questions and Answers  - Attendees  colleagues  or students may raise questions or clarifications on the presented case. It's an interactive session to ensure all the aspects of the case are well understood.

Slide 1: Title ""Case Study: Acute Pulmonary Embolism""  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Age: 52-year-old - Sex: Female - Occupation: Administrative Assistant - Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle  occasionally smokes  Slide 3: Reason for Driving Concern - Presented with sudden onset dyspnea  chest pain  and light-headedness  - Detailed symptoms: Pain characterized as sharp  worsening with deep breaths  Slide 4: Past Medical History - General Overview: The patient has been generally healthy with routine medical check-ups. - Chronic Conditions: Mild hypertension  managed with lifestyle changes - Surgery/Injury History: Left total knee arthroplasty performed five weeks ago - Allergies: None reported - Family History: Father had a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  one brother with a history of cardiovascular disease  Slide 5: Suspected Diagnosis - Based on the symptoms of dyspnea  chest pain and clinical history of recent surgery  the suspected diagnosis is Acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE).  Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests - D-dimer test: Elevated levels suggesting the presence of a clot - Computerized Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA): Confirmed the diagnosis showing emboli in the pulmonary arteries.  Slide 7: Treatment and Management - Immediate therapeutic anticoagulation initiated with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) - After stabilizing the patient  plans to shift her on to oral anticoagulants for long-term management - Patient education regarding the prevention of DVT and PE  awareness of the symptoms suggestive of recurrence - Long-term follow-up care plan including periodic INR checks  monitoring of side effects  and lifestyle modifications.    Slide 8: Prognosis and Follow-up - Prognosis is generally good with early intervention and treatment. The patient will need to undergo regular follow-ups and maintain anticoagulant therapy. - Lifestyle modifications advised including cessation of smoking  adopting a physically active lifestyle  weight management and a healthy diet.  Slide 9: Lessons to Learn - Importance of detailed history taking for early detection of potential PE risks - Vigilance towards venous thromboembolism in post-surgical patients - Necessity of patient education in thrombotic event prevention and recurrence recognition.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism: A Clinical Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction - Acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE) is a common and potentially fatal cardiovascular disorder that should be promptly diagnosed and appropriately treated. - We'll discuss the case of a patient who was recently diagnosed with Acute Pulmonary Embolism.  Slide 2: Demographics - Patient: Mr. Sean Lawson - Age: 55 years - Gender: Male  - Occupation: Corporate employee - Non-smoker  Moderate alcohol consumer.  Slide 3: Symptoms and Initial Consultation  - The patient presented with abrupt onset of severe chest pain and dyspnea. - Patient complained of a sharp  stabbing type of pain  more severe during inhalation.   Slide 4: Past Medical History - Mr. Lawson has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). - Diagnosed and successfully treated for DVT 8 years ago. - Obesity and leading a sedentary lifestyle. - No history of heart diseases but has mild hypertension under control with medication.   Slide 5: Diagnostic tests & Results - D-Dimer test was carried out  levels were high  suggesting a clot. - CT pulmonary angiogram was performed indicating the presence of a blood clot. - ECG & Echocardiography showed signs of strain on the right ventricle  Slide 6: Diagnosis - Based on the symptoms  medical history and diagnostic tests  the patient was diagnosed with Acute Pulmonary embolism.  Slide 7: Treatment and Management - The patient was treated with anticoagulants and thrombolytic therapy to dissolve the clot. - Long-term anticoagulant therapy is recommended due to the history of DVT. - Suggested lifestyle changes: regular cardiovascular exercises  healthy diet to manage weight  and regular monitoring of blood pressure.  Slide 8: Prognosis & Follow-up - With appropriate treatment  the prognosis is generally good. - The risk of recurrence can be further reduced with lifestyle modifications. - Regular follow-ups will be scheduled for monitoring vitals and response to the treatment.  Slide 9: Conclusion  - This case highlights the importance of early diagnosis and treatment of Acute PE  as well as considering it as a possibility in patients with a history of DVT who present with chest pain and dyspnea. - Maintaining a healthy lifestyle can help prevent the recurrence of such life-threatening conditions.

Slide 1: Title: Case Study: Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Slide 2: Title: Patient Demographics Content: The patient in question is Mia  a 68-year-old African American woman who lives alone. She is a retired school teacher and her main form of exercise is gardening. She quit smoking 10 years ago but had a 30-year history of smoking. Recently  Mia returned from a trip where she had been sitting for extended periods of time.   Slide 3: Title: Patient's Past Medical History  Content: Mia suffers from chronic hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are managed by oral medications. She was obese until a gastric bypass procedure 5 years ago and now maintains a normal weight. She had an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago  following a knee replacement surgery. She was on anticoagulant therapy for six months post the DVT.  Slide 4: Title: Presenting Symptoms  Content: On the night of admission  Mia experienced a sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  coughing  and rapid heart rate. She reported severe sharp  stabbing chest pain that exacerbated by deep breaths. She looked anxious and was diaphoretic.  Slide 5: Title: Preliminary Diagnosis Content: Due to Mia’s symptoms and medical history  a preliminary diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was given. This was further confirmed by a CT pulmonary angiogram  which showed blockage in the main pulmonary arteries.  Slide 6: Title: Course of Treatment  Content: Anticoagulation therapy was begun immediately to prevent further clot formation and physiological support was provided to maintain blood pressure and oxygen saturation. Given her history of DVT and current presentation  it was decided to keep her on long-term oral anticoagulation.  Slide 7: Title: Patient Education & Preventive Measures Content: Mia was educated about her condition and instructed to avoid long periods of immobility  and to maintain good control of her diabetes and hypertension. Regular follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor her condition.  Slide 8: Title: Conclusion Content: Regular follow-ups are important for patients with DVT and PE history. Medical adherence  lifestyle modifications  patient awareness  and prompt action in managing symptoms can prevent complications and improve patient outcomes.
