A 57 year-old hypertensive and diabetic male  with a history of deep vein thrombosis  currently experiencing sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism.
63-year-old male  ex-smoker with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus  now presents with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea  diagnosed as acute pulmonary embolism.
A 68-year-old African-American male  hypertensive and ex-smoker  presents with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism  no prior incidents.
A 68-year-old male patient with a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis and sedentary lifestyle presents with acute dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.
A 58-year-old female patient  with a past medical history of hypertension and obesity  was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism following sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of long-term smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and recent orthopedic surgery presenting with acute shortness of breath  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.

A 58-year-old  overweight  Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  smoking and recent right hip replacement surgery  presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain; suspecting acute pulmonary embolism.

""A 45-year-old male smoker with a history of deep vein thrombosis  currently on anticoagulant therapy  presented with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.""

A 58-year-old female with a past medical history of smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and recurrent deep vein thrombosis now presenting with sudden dyspnea and chest pain suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism.

A 67-year-old male smoker with a medical history of hypertension and recent hip replacement surgery  presents with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath  was diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism.

A 52-year-old female  former smoker and recently underwent a total hip replacement surgery  presents with sudden onset dyspnea and chest pain  and was subsequently diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism.

A 55-year-old African-American female  a former smoker with a prior history of hypertension and obesity  currently presents with shortness of breath  chest pain  and an irregular heartbeat  indicative of an acute pulmonary embolism.

""64-year-old female smoker with a past medical history of DVT  hypertension  and obesity presents with a sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath  now diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.""

A 55-year-old male smoker with a history of hypertension and a sedentary lifestyle  presents with an acute episode of shortness of breath and chest pain  subsequently diagnosed with pulmonary embolism.

""A 58-year-old  obese  African-American female  with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes and chronic venous insufficiency  presented with sudden shortness of breath and chest pain  resulted in the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.""
A 56-year-old male smoker with a history of hypertension and DVT presenting with sudden onset chest pain and breathlessness  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.

""A 67-year-old female patient with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and recent total hip replacement surgery  presenting with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism.""
A 54-year-old male smoker with a history of hypertension and sedentary lifestyle presents with acute onset shortness of breath and chest pain  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.
54-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking  presents with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and deep vein thrombosis presented with sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp chest pain  subsequently diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.

A 52-year-old female email marketer with past medical history of obesity  deep vein thrombosis and sedentary lifestyle presents with sudden onset chest pain  tachycardia  and dyspnea  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.

A 58-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  obesity  and recent knee surgery now presents with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath  highly suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism.

""72-year-old African-American male  ex-smoker with history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  presents with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.""
""A 63-year-old male smoker with a history of deep vein thrombosis and hypertension  presents with acute onset shortness of breath  suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism.""

A 66-year-old African American male with a known history of atrial fibrillation (on anticoagulants)  obesity  and recent total right hip replacement surgery two weeks ago presents with a sudden onset of acute shortness of breath  chest pain that worsens on deep inhalation (pleuritic chest pain) and mild hemoptysis that started two hours prior to presentation. He also reported an insidious onset of right leg pain and swelling for a week. On presentation  he has a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation of 89% on room air  blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  and a heart rate of 110 beats per minute. Physical examination shows signs of right leg deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  whereas chest auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds on the left side without any added sounds. Further diagnostic testing and treatment for suspected acute pulmonary embolism are being planned.

A 60-year-old African American female patient with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and recent right hip replacement surgery (4 weeks ago) presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  a cough with blood-tinged sputum  and feeling faint. She denies any history of heart disease or malignancy. Her vitals show tachycardia with a heart rate of 120 bpm and hypoxia with O2 saturation of 88% on room air. Her physical evaluation reveals leg swelling but her lung auscultation is normal and the cardiovascular examination is unremarkable. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows sinus tachycardia and S1Q3T3 sign. Lab results are pending. She has never smoked or used illicit drugs and does not consume alcohol. She runs a small business and denies any recent long travel history. The presentation is suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism  likely secondary to deep vein thrombosis post-hip surgery.

Patient is a 65-year-old African-American male with a known history of hypertension  chronic atrial fibrillation  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  who presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain that is sharp and increases upon inspiration  and dizziness. His vital signs are stable  but oxygen saturation is low at 89% on room air. His current medications include metformin  lisinopril and warfarin. The patient also mentions recent long-haul air travel 10 days prior. Auscultation exhibits diminished breath sounds in the left lower chest. His lower extremities are symmetric with no visible signs of deep vein thrombosis. The patient has no known allergies. There's no family history of blood clotting disorders; he does not smoke or consume alcohol. His father died of stroke at the age of 72 and his mother died of heart attack at the age of 70.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history of deep vein thrombosis in the past  sedentary lifestyle  and recent travel for extended hours. She is presenting to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of severe chest pain  difficulty breathing  and fainting. She also reports experiencing a fast heart rate and excessive perspiration. On physical examination  patient appears anxious  diaphoretic and hypotensive. On auscultation  tachypnea and tachycardia are noted. Her O2 saturation is 90% on room air. Her symptoms suggest an acute pulmonary embolism  which could be related to her sedentary lifestyle  previous history of DVT  and recent long-distance travel. Urgent evaluation to confirm the diagnosis and intervene appropriately is indicated.

A 63-year-old Caucasian male patient with a medical history significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  recent orthopedic surgery (total right hip replacement 2 weeks ago)  and 20-pack year smoking history  presents to the emergency room with sudden onset of dyspnea  chest pain  and hemoptysis. On physical examination  he exhibits tachypnea  tachycardia  decreased breath sounds  and pleural friction rub. Blood tests show elevated D-dimer levels. This picture is highly suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  A 58-year-old Caucasian female  non-smoker  with a well-controlled past medical history of hypertension  presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath and severe  pleuritic chest pain that started 4 hours ago. The patient recently had total knee arthroplasty 10 days ago followed by an 8-hour flight. There are no symptoms of fever or cough. She is tachypneic with a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure of 135/80 mmHg  and an oxygen saturation level of 89% percent at rest. Her lower extremities show no signs of swelling. Lab tests show an elevated D-dimer level. Findings from the ECG show sinus tachycardia but no signs of right heart strain. Chest X-ray doesn't reveal any significant abnormalities or signs of other diseases.

Patient is a 65-year-old  obese male with a past medical history significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and a recent orthopedic surgery (hip replacement) four weeks ago. He presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset shortness of breath  chest pain that worsens with deep breathing  and a sense of impending doom. On examination  he is tachypneic. The vitals revealed tachycardia with a heart rate of 110/min and an oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. He denies any fever  cough  or sputum production. He also states he was not compliant with his prescribed anticoagulant medication post-surgery due to nausea side effects.

Patient is a 68-year-old African-American male with a past medical history of atrial fibrillation (on warfarin)  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease  and hypertension. He presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain that began three hours prior to presentation. The pain is worse when taking deep breaths and has been associated with shortness of breath  tachycardia  and an unproductive cough. The patient denies any other symptoms such as fever  chills  nausea  vomiting  palpation  dizziness or diaphoresis. He also reports recent traveling on a long flight. His current vitals are: Temp 98.6F  BP 130/85mmHg  RR 24 breaths/min  HR 110bpm  O2 Sat 92% on room air. Physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the right lung base with mild wheezing. No leg edema or tenderness is noticed. Given the clinical history and physical findings  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is suspected.

Patient Profile: A 67-year-old African-American male  Medical History: Known case of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  obesity  hypertension  ex-smoker  remote history of prostate cancer currently in remission.  Presenting Symptoms: Sudden onset of shortness of breath coupled with chest pain. Patient reports feeling faint  with intermittent episodes of dizziness. Additional symptoms include tachycardia  sweating  and low-grade fever. The pain is described as sharp  located centrally and notes an increase in pain while taking deep breaths.  Primary Problem: The patient's recent history of DVT in the context of sudden onset dyspnea  chest pain  and hypotension suggest a possible acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic testing is required to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

Patient Profile: A 67-year-old African American female  non-smoker  with a known medical history of obesity (BMI 32)  hypertension  and recent surgery (hip replacement) six weeks ago.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with sudden onset of dyspnea  chest pain that appears to worsen upon deep inspiration  light-headedness and palpitations. She also mentions a sense of impending doom.  Relevant Medical History: The patient's history reveals chronic hypertension  which has been managed with angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors; recent surgical history (hip replacement surgery)  which may contribute to thrombus formation; obesity  a risk factor for deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and subsequent pulmonary embolism (PE). The patient does not have any history of pulmonary or cardiac diseases.  Relevant Symptoms: The patient's clinical features include dyspnea  which suggests pulmonary compromise; chest pain  possibly due to pulmonary infarction or pleurisy; lightheadedness  which might indicate a decrease in cerebral perfusion due to reduced cardiac output; palpitations  possibly resulting from acute right heart strain or tachyarrhythmias  and a general sense of impending doom  a nonspecific symptom but commonly noted in acute life-threatening conditions like PE. No signs of swelling or tenderness in the lower limbs were noted on physical examination.

Patient Description: A 54-year-old Caucasian male sales manager with a recent history of prolonged immobilization due to a right ankle fracture. He has a past medical history significant for obesity and hyperlipidemia. No known drug allergies.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a sudden onset of acute shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain.  History of Present Illness: The patient states that he was in his usual state of health until 24 hours prior when he started experiencing sudden onset of severe shortness of breath which got worse with deep inspiration. He also has pleuritic chest pain and is coughing up a small amount of blood-tinged sputum. He denies fever  chills  or recent travel.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of obesity and hyperlipidemia. Our patient is a nonsmoker  does not use any illicit drugs  and drinks alcohol socially.  Review of Systems: General- fatigue and weakness. Respiratory- Difficulty breathing  cough  and bloody sputum. Cardiovascular- No history of heart disease  but the patient reports noticing a rapid heartbeat.  Physical Exam: On examination  patient appears anxious and dyspneic. Vitals show tachypnea  tachycardia and blood oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. Chest examination reveals decreased breath sounds on the right lower lobe. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable.   This clinical scenario raises the suspicion for an acute pulmonary embolism. Although further diagnostic testing will be necessary  the patient's recent immobilization due to a fracture  obesity  along with the acute onset of symptoms and the findings on physical examination  prompt immediate initiation of anticoagulation treatment while awaiting diagnostic confirmation.

A 52-year-old African American male  known smoker with a recent history of orthopedic surgery 3 weeks ago  presents with sudden onset shortness of breath  localized chest pain  and light-headedness. The patient has no previous history of cardiovascular disease  no family history of early-onset deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism  and is not on any regular medications except for an oral NSAID for post-operative pain control. His symptoms have progressively worsened over the last 4 hours. On clinical examination  he appears hypoxic and is breathing rapidly at 28 breaths per minute  heart rate is slightly elevated at 98 beats per minute. Auscultation of the chest reveals normal breath sounds bilaterally with no added sounds. His blood pressure and temperature are within normal limits. The noted symptoms indicate a possible acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient is a 65-year-old African-American female with a medical history significant for obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and recent total knee replacement surgery presenting with acute onset dyspnea  chest pain and unexplained tachycardia. Symptom onset was sudden and has been progressively worsening over the past 12 hours. Pain is described as sharp  located centrally on the chest with radiation to left shoulder. Patient rates pain as 8 out of 10  unrelieved with over-the-counter medication. Dyspnea is exacerbated by exertion and associated with mild diaphoresis and light-headedness. There is no concurrent cough  fever  leg swelling  or recent travel reported. Patient is a life-long non-smoker with no family history of clotting disorders  or personal history of malignancy or recent prolonged immobilization. UserDetails are indicative of acute pulmonary embolism.

Chief Complaint:  A 60-year-old African-American female with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and recent right total knee replacement 2 weeks ago presents to the emergency department with sudden onset dyspnea  chest pain  and light-headedness.  History of Present Illness: She reports that the shortness of breath started abruptly while at rest earlier today  associated with sharp chest pain on the right side  which gets worse with deep breathing. She admits to leg swelling which she attributed to her recent knee surgery. She also mentions feeling light-headed at times but denies any loss of consciousness  palpitations  cough  fever  or other symptoms.  Past Medical History:  Significant for obesity (BMI 35)  hypertension managed with Lisinopril  and total knee replacement surgery performed 2 weeks ago. No history of smoking or genetic conditions.   Vitals on Presentation: BP: 110/72 mmHg  Pulse: 110 bpm  Temp: 98.6 F  Resp: 22/min  O2 Sat: 92% on room air.   Physical Exam: The patient appears acutely distressed. Pulmonary auscultation reveals tachypnea with clear lung sounds bilaterally. She has tenderness and swelling over the right calf. Rest of the physical examination is within normal limits.  Assessment: Acute onset dyspnea and chest pain in the setting of recent knee surgery and physical exam findings suggesting deep vein thrombosis (DVT) increase the likelihood of an acute pulmonary embolism. Urgent diagnostic testing is required to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate treatment.

A 53-year-old female  with a significant medical history of familial thrombophilia  obesity  and a recent orthopedic surgery 2 weeks ago  presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of symptoms including sharp  pleuritic chest pain  shortness of breath  cough with faint streaks of blood  and a feeling of apprehension. She is hypotensive and tachycardic with a decreased oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. On physical examination  the patient appears sweaty and anxious. Her heart sounds are tachycardic  with a pronounced second heart sound (S2). She reports no history of smoking or other respiratory illness. The primary concern  given the patient's medical history and sudden presentation of symptoms  is acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female who presents to the emergency department with symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism  chief among them severe shortness of breath  tachypnea and tachycardia. Patient also reports coughing with traces of blood and crushing chest pain. Relevant medical history includes recent right hip replacement surgery two weeks ago  recurrent unexplained leg swelling and pain suggestive of deep venous thrombosis (DVT)  Hypertension (HTN)  smoking history  family history of clotting disorders and recent long-haul flight. Patient has no known drug allergies  but her medications include Lisinopril for her HTN and low-dose aspirin. Physical examination indicates decreased breath sounds and mild swelling of the right leg.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  prostate cancer treated with hormone therapy  and smoking who presents with the sudden onset of dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain  and a persistent cough with blood-tinged sputum over the past 24 hours. He also notes feeling increasingly fatigued and has a recorded oxygen saturation of 89%. His vitals revealed tachypnea and tachycardia. Given the presence of pleuritic chest pain  dyspnea  and history of DVT  acute pulmonary embolism (PE) is the leading diagnosis in this patient. Further diagnostic workup is needed urgently  including D-dimer  CT pulmonary angiography  and potential admission for close monitoring given the high risk of deterioration.

Patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian female with a history of estrogen hormone replacement therapy and deep vein thrombosis  who presents with sudden onset of sharp  right-sided chest pain  breathlessness and light-headedness over the past few hours. On examination  she is anxious  tachycardic with a heart rate of 115 bpm  blood pressure 95/60 mmHg and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. The patient has no other known allergies or previous surgeries. Her father and brother both suffered from thromboembolic disease. She smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and barely performs any regular exercise. She denies alcohol or illicit drug use. CBC  BMP  troponin are within normal limits  but D-dimer is elevated. A CT angiogram is urgently needed to confirm a diagnosis of suspected acute pulmonary embolism  in light of her symptoms and high-risk profile.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for deep venous thrombosis (DVT) following orthopedic surgery 2 years ago  currently presenting with sudden onset shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  and palpitations for the past few hours. The patient reports feeling a sharp  stabbing pain in his chest that gets worse when he takes a deep breath. He also appears to be in mild distress and hypoxia  with an oxygen saturation of 90% on ambient air. There are no signs of peripheral edema or calf tenderness. Pulse rate is elevated at 110 beats per minutes. The EKG shows sinus tachycardia. He has a Well's score of 4.5 points  making pulmonary embolism likely.

Patient is a 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a recent hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. He is a former smoker but quit 10 years ago. He presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  and hemoptysis that started this morning. Upon physical examination  patient appears in respiratory distress; vitals reveal tachypnea  hypoxia  and tachycardia. Routine blood work shows an elevated D-dimer level. He has no known drug allergies and is currently on lisinopril for hypertension and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. There is no history of previous pneumonic or thromboembolic events. Given his recent orthopedic surgery and the sudden onset of symptoms  the potential of an acute pulmonary embolism is highly suspected.

A 65-year-old African-American female with a past medical history significant for obesity (BMI 34)  hypertension  and recent total hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago  presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of severe chest pain  shortness of breath and unexplained sweating which started hour her ago. On examination  she appeared pale  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 28  had an O2 saturation of 90% on room air and demonstrated a raised blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg. The rest of the physical examination including cardiovascular and pulmonary system was unremarkable. Her EKG revealed a sinus tachycardia with a S1Q3T3 pattern  suggesting acute right ventricular strain. Her D-dimer test came back elevated. The rapid onset of symptoms  coupled with her risk factors and positive preliminary investigation results  raise a high suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism.

A 54-year-old African American male with a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  hypertension  and obesity  presents with acute onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and light-headedness. He reports that the chest pain is sharp  located in the middle of his chest  and is exacerbated when he takes deep breaths. He also reports an episode of hemoptysis this morning. The patient has a documented history of noncompliance with his DVT medication. Physical examination reveals increased respiratory rate  decreased breath sounds on the right side  and slight lower extremity edema  more evident on the right side. His blood pressure is slightly lowered  and his oxygen saturation is 88% on room air.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old  African-American male  smoker with a 25 pack year history   Medical History: Known hypertensive with history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) a year ago  for which he is on anticoagulation. No history of pulmonary diseases. No pertinent surgical history.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents to the hospital with sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath since the past 6 hours that has progressively worsened.  Other Relevant Symptoms: The chest pain is sharp  pleuritic type  worse on deep inspiration. He also reports light headedness and a fainting spell at home. He denies any leg swelling  cough  fever  or hemoptysis.  Physical Examination: On examination; patient is in obvious respiratory distress. Vital signs show a respiratory rate of 30/min  SpO2 of 88% on room air  heart rate of 110/min  and blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. Auscultation of chest notes reduced breath sounds and tachycardia. No lower limb edema or tenderness noted. Neurological examination is within normal limits.   Possible Diagnosis: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Plan: The initial assessment and presenting complaints raise suspicion for an acute pulmonary embolism given his past history of DVT and current symptoms. Plan to perform an immediate EKG and Chest X-ray  D-dimer test  lower limb venous doppler and CT pulmonary angiography. Arrange for immediate respiratory support with oxygen  consider anticoagulation  and cardiology consultation for further management.

Patient Profile: A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of type-2 diabetes  hypertension  and recent total knee arthroplasty one week ago.   Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents to the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain that started a couple of hours back. The pain is sharp  localized in the mid-chest  worsens with deep breaths. Along with breathlessness  he also reports feeling lightheaded  episodes of coughing and overall feeling very unwell.  Medical History: Patient has a history of smoking with 2 packs per day for more than 40 years. He has been managing his diabetes and hypertension with medication.  Examination Findings: Patient appears distressed  breathing rapidly and sweating profusely. Vital signs reveal tachycardia (heart rate 110) and tachypnea (respiratory rate 30)  blood pressure is slightly elevated (145/90)  oxygen saturation on room air is 90%. Auscultation of chest reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side.  Medical Problem Representation: This patient's presentation and medical history suggest a probable acute pulmonary embolism possibly precipitated by recent knee surgery and his long history of smoking. His diabetes and hypertension also contribute to his overall high-risk cardiovascular status.

A 72-year-old Caucasian female with a known history of hypertension and smoking presents with an acute onset of shortness of breath  chest pain and feeling light-headed. She reports the symptoms starting about an hour prior to coming to the emergency room and denies any similar episodes in the past. Her chest pain is sharp  pleuritic in nature  localized primarily to the right side and doesn't radiate. Her breathing has become progressively difficult and her lightheadedness has persisted. She also mentions recent prolonged travel and has been largely inactive due to COVID-related quarantine. Vital signs notable for tachycardia and hypoxia. She has no known drug allergies. She has been compliant with her blood pressure medications  but due to her age and sedentary lifestyle  she is at a high risk for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and hence  pulmonary embolism (PE). On physical examination  she appears anxious  in respiratory distress but her lung fields are clear to auscultation  and there is no leg swelling. Her ECG shows sinus tachycardia but is otherwise unremarkable. Chest X-Ray was ordered and doesn't show any acute abnormalities. Overall  her presentation is suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history of recent total hip replacement surgery  hypertension  and prior DVT presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest discomfort  and mild hemoptysis. The patient also reports recent long-distance traveling  excessive leg swelling  and decreased mobility. He reports a family history of VTE. On examination  he was tachycardic and demonstrated increased work of breathing. His oxygen saturation was 92% on room air with marginal relief upon oxygen supplementation. His blood pressure was stable. The lower limb examination showed unilateral edema. Rest of the systems examination was within normal limits.

Patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia who presents with sudden sharp  stabbing chest pain now for 4 hours. The pain is characteristically exacerbated by deep breathing and accompanied by shortness of breath  palpitations and a sense of impending doom. He also reports a recent travel on a prolonged flight (8 hours) 2 weeks ago. The patient denies fever  cough  or hemoptysis. There is heightened concern for acute pulmonary embolism given his history of DVT  recent prolonged immobility and the presenting symptoms.

Problem Representation:  Ms. A  a 67-year-old female with a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) currently on anticoagulation therapy  and a 20-year history of smoking (quit 10 years ago)  arrives in the emergency department. She complains of a sudden onset of shortness of breath which started around 4 hours ago  associated with chest pain that is sharp and gets worse with deep breaths. She mentions feeling light-headed and rates her fatigue level as 7 out of 10. On physical examination  she is found to have tachycardia and decreased breath sounds in the right lower lung field. Rest of the examination is within normal limits. She has no history of surgery or immobilization in recent times. The patient has mild renal insufficiency and her INR is within therapeutic range. Her family history includes hypertension in her father and a brother with premature coronary artery disease. She lives with her husband and has no known drug allergies.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the Emergency Department with acute onset shortness of breath and chest pain. He mentions that these symptoms started suddenly about 3-4 hours ago. The chest pain is pleuritic and he rates it as 7/10 in severity. He also reported feeling lightheaded and dizzy. He denied any fever  cough  expectoration  palpitations  or leg swelling. He's a former smoker with a 30-pack year history. He has a past medical history of high blood pressure  type 2 diabetes  and had a right hip replacement surgery two weeks ago. Family history is significant for deep venous thrombosis in his brother. Upon examination  the patient appeared anxious and cyanotic  blood pressure was 135/85 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation was 88% on ambient air  and increased stony dullness was observed in lower hemithorax. ECG showed sinus tachycardia. Chest X-ray was largely unremarkable. These findings suggest the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism  likely secondary to postoperative immobility given his recent surgery. Further investigations including D-dimer testing  a computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) or a ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan would be beneficial in confirming the diagnosis.

Problem Representation:  A 62-year old  African-American male with a notable past medical history for obesity  hypertension and recent total hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago  presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain radiating to his left arm that started 2 hours prior to admission. He describes the pain as severe  sharp and following no particular pattern. The patient also reports episodes of dizziness and feeling faint. He denies any fever  cough  hemoptysis or leg pain/swelling. On physical examination  patient shows signs of respiratory distress with increased work of breathing  tachypnea  and tachycardia. His blood oxygen saturation is low (90% on room air). The initial blood tests show an elevated d-dimer level. The patient's symptoms  recent surgery  and elevating D-dimer level raise the suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of smoking  obesity  and recent major orthopedic surgery presents with acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient reports that the symptoms started suddenly while at rest and have been progressively worsening over the past 2 hours. Vital sign abnormalities include tachycardia (heart rate 110bpm) and tachypnea (respiration rate 22bpm). Examination reveals decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field and cyanosis in the lower extremities. Further  the patient is anxious and diaphoretic. The patient's history of recent surgery  immobility  combined with his cardiovascular risk factors  raises concern for an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Information: A 58-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: The patient is a smoker  with a history of deep vein thrombosis 9 years ago  for which he was on anticoagulation therapy for 6 months. He also suffers from hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes daily medication. No history of cancer  surgery  or recent prolonged immobilization.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden-onset sharp  stabbing chest pain that heightened with deep breathing over the past 2 hours. He also reports shortness of breath and a feeling of rapid heart rate.   Clinical findings: On physical examination  tachycardia and tachypnea were observed. Heart rate: 120 bpm  blood pressure: 132/85 mmHg  respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation: 92% on room air. No leg swelling  cyanosis  or visible veins noted. His lung sounds were clear and no cardiac murmurs or gallops were appreciated.  Taken together  patient's history  symptoms  and clinical features indicate suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation: Mrs. Williams is a 60-year-old African-American female  non-smoker  with a past medical history of hypertension and deep vein thrombosis who is presented to the emergency room with sudden onset of severe shortness of breath and chest pain reports starting 2 hours ago while she was at rest. She also mentioned that the chest pain worsens with deep breathing. She does not recall any recent trauma  surgery  immobilization  or travel but has had a family history; her mother had pulmonary embolism secondary to malignancies. She was on antihypertensive medications and anticoagulation therapy for DVT  but adherence to the latter remained an issue.  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared anxious  sweaty and was tachypneic (RR = 22)  hypoxic with oxygen saturation of 88% on room air  hypotensive with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHG and had a pulse rate of 110  otherwise normal cardiovascular examination. Lung auscultations revealed no wheezing  rales  or rhonchi. Domains of the well's criteria such as recent immobilization or surgery  previous history of DVT  signs and symptoms of DVT (leg swelling and pain)  heart rate above 100 and alternative diagnosis less likely than PE make pulmonary embolism likely. The rest of her examination was essentially within normal limits. Her EKG shows tachycardia  minor ST depressions  and the chest X-ray was insignificant. An immediate CT pulmonary angiography  labs including D-dimer and treatment with anticoagulant is planned in this setting of suspected acute pulmonary embolism.

A 64-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of obesity (BMI 34)  recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  and recent right total knee arthroplasty 2 weeks ago presents to the emergency department. The patient reports sudden onset shortness of breath  lightheadedness and sharp  pleuritic chest pain that started a few hours ago. She mentions the pain gets worse while deep breathing. The patient also notes episodes of palpitations. She denies any cough  hemoptysis  or fever. She is a nonsmoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. There's no known drug allergy. She has been noncompliant with her post-operative anticoagulation therapy. Vital signs on admission are T 98.6°F  P 110 bpm  BP 125/75 mmHg  RR 24/min  and O2 sat 92% on room air. Physical examination is remarkable for tachypnea  tachycardia and decreased breath sounds over the right lung field. There's no lower limb edema or tenderness observed.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old female patient with a past medical history of Type 2 Diabetes  Hypertension  and recent total knee arthroplasty one month ago now presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain radiating to the left side of the jaw  and a palpable sense of anxiety. She reports the pain as sharp  exacerbated by deep breathing and partially relieved by leaning forward. She has no prior history of similar symptoms. She reported feeling lightheaded without loss of consciousness. She denies any cough  sputum production  fever  or leg swelling. Her mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis. The patient is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. Physical examination reveals tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. On auscultation  the chest is bilaterally clear  and cardiovascular examination shows tachycardia without murmurs  rubs or gallops. Lower extremity examination shows no signs of deep venous thrombosis  such as edema  erythema  or tenderness on palpation. The patient appeared diaphoretic with cool  pale skin and has a look of fear. Her recent immobility with surgery  personal history of thrombosis at a relatively young age  and the sudden onset of her symptoms suggest a potential diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient is a 53-year-old Caucasian male with past medical history of Type 2 Diabetes and controlled hypertension  who presents with acute onset of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and dizziness. The patient reports sudden onset of chest pain on the left side radiating to the back  associated with particular breathlessness starting approximately two hours ago while sitting at his desk. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 5 years ago; has a sedentary lifestyle and just recently completed a 4-hour plane journey. He denies any trauma  recent injury  substance use or known allergy. He appears pale  diaphoretic  tachycardic and has decreased breath sounds in the lower left lung on physical examination. No episodes of haemoptysis  syncope  fevers  or changes in appetite/weight were reported.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of acute onset shortness of breath and chest pain. She describes her chest pain as centrally located  sharp  and worsening with deep breaths. Her past medical history is notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  prior deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years prior for which she completed treatment  and a recent orthopedic knee surgery done three weeks prior for which she was largely immobile post-operatively. Her family history is significant for her father who had Pulmonary Embolism (PE). She denies any history of smoking  alcohol  or illicit drug abuse. On physical examination  she was found to be in distress  tachypneic  hypoxemic with an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air  and her heart rate was elevated at 110 beats per minute. Her respiratory rate was 28 breaths per minute and her blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg. Chest auscultation was notable for clear lungs bilaterally. Lower extremity examination revealed no edema  erythema  or calf tenderness. An ECG showed sinus tachycardia but was otherwise normal. The patient's D-dimer was significantly elevated. Her leukocyte count  liver function tests  and renal function tests are within normal limits. Based upon her clinical presentation  her recent period of immobility  a personal medical history of DVT and family history of PE  and an elevated D-dimer  a clinical suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism was made.

Patient Demographics: A 63-year-old Caucasian male smoker.  Relevant Medical History: Patient has a history of sedentary lifestyle  recent major orthopedic surgery three weeks ago (total hip replacement)  and protracted immobility. He also has a medical history of obesity  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) suggestive of hereditary thrombophilia.  Relevant Symptoms on Presentation: The patient presented to the emergency department with acute onset dyspnea  chest pain that worsens with deep breaths  and mild hemoptysis. Accompanying symptoms include palpitations  dizziness  profuse sweating  and a sense of impending doom. On examination  he appears anxious and is tachypneic  tachycardic  and mildly hypotensive. His oxygen saturation on room air is subnormal with peripheral cyanosis. There are no obvious signs of deep vein thrombosis such as swollen  painful leg or visible surface veins. No abnormal breath sounds are auscultated in the chest. Electrocardiogram (ECG) shows tachycardia with non-specific ST and T wave changes  and a D-dimer test was ordered  which proved to be significantly elevated. A pulmonary CT angiography was conducted to rule out acute pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Johnson  a 64-year-old male patient presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain radiating to the back that gets worse upon deep breaths. He reports feelings of light-headedness and faintness as well. Patient is a 60-year-old African American female with a significant medical history of obesity  hypertension  and recent right hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. A 65-year-old male  with a past medical history significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and hypertension  presents with sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp  pleuritic chest pain  tachycardia  and a recent history of prolonged immobilization following a hip fracture repair surgery. Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old female with a past medical history of hypertension and recurrent deep vein thrombosis on chronic anticoagulation therapy presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. The pain is sharp and started abruptly while resting at home  worsening during deep inspiration. She reports a pre-syncopal episode but denies complete loss of consciousness. She also reports sudden-onset unilateral leg swelling. She denies recent travel  surgery  hospitalization  or family history of clotting disorders. On physical examination  her heart rate is 110 bpm  blood pressure 100/60 mmHg  oxygen saturation 88% on room air  and respiratory rate 24/min. On auscultation  lungs are clear. On cardiovascular examination  no murmurs or gallops noted. The right lower extremity is swollen  erythematous  with a positive Homan's sign. There is no evidence of trauma or infection in the right leg. Prior to this incident  the patient has been in her usual state of health  and denial of fevers  cough or weight loss.   This problem representation suggests potential acute pulmonary embolism  given the patient's relevant medical history of recurrent deep vein thrombosis  and her acute symptoms of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  unexplained syncope  and unilateral leg swelling. The above information focuses the clinician's impression and future diagnostic steps to confirm or rule out this potentially life-threatening condition.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  and recent total knee replacement surgery  presents with sudden onset of dyspnea  chest pain  tachycardia  and oxygen desaturation to 92% on room air. A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and recent hip replacement surgery 3 weeks ago presents with sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp chest pain which gets worsened with deep breaths. Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American female.  Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain. Working Diagnosis: The sudden onset of shortness breath  non-specific chest pain  clinical history  physical findings  and preliminary test results suggest a high probability of acute pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  Mr. James  a 54-year-old male corporate executive  with a known history of hypertension  presents to the ER with sudden onset of chest pain which he describes as “sharp” and gets worse on deep inspiration. He also reports having experienced unexplained shortness of breath and episodes of light-headedness over the past 3 days. He acknowledges a flight from Europe to the United States three weeks ago. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. Denies having any fever  cough  or night sweats. He is currently taking hydrochlorothiazide and aspirin. He reports no known drug allergies. Family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis in his mother. Upon initial evaluation  he looks distressed and is breathing rapidly. His oxygen saturation on room air is 90%  in absence of any lung or heart disease. His blood pressure and heart rate are normal but he is in the emergency room due to acute onset of symptoms and significant medical history of hypertension.  This clinical picture is challenging due to his chest pain  dyspnea  recent long-haul flight  smoking history  and family history all presenting risk factors for a potential Acute Pulmonary Embolism.

A 62-year-old African-American female with a medical history significant for hypertension  obesity  and recently diagnosed stage II left-sided breast cancer for which she is receiving chemotherapy  presented with acute onset chest pain and shortness of breath. Patient Information: 62-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Acute onset of pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath. A 65-year-old Caucasian female with a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago and long-term oral contraception use presents to the emergency department. An arterial blood gas reveals hypoxia and a D-dimer test is ordered. The Hoehn and Yahr scale is being used to measure the progression of the patient's symptoms.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago. A 55-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and current smoking presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath at rest  sharp chest pain on inspiration (pleuritic chest pain)  hemoptysis  and lightheadedness. A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and recent hip joint replacement surgery  presents with sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain  and blood-streaked sputum. Patient Information: A 68-year-old  African American male  Medical History: The patient has known history of congestive heart failure and a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) that was treated approximately six months ago. Vital signs showed tachycardia and tachypnoea  with a decreased oxygen saturation level of 89% on room air. Patient was also anxious and sweaty. Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old retired male obesed smoker  with a past medical history of prolonged immobilization following recent right hip replacement surgery and hypertension presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp chest pain  and fast heartbeat. Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for atrial fibrillation not currently on anticoagulation  presenting to the emergency department with the chief complaint of acute onset dyspnea. He mentions that up until 24 hours ago  he was perfectly fine  following which he started experiencing sudden shortness of breath  chest pain  and intermittently felt lightheaded. He denies trauma  fever  cough  or recent travel. The patient admits to feeling a rapid heart rate  also known as tachycardia. On physical examination  the patient has increased respiratory rate and note of diminished lung sounds on the right side. Laboratory results are pending  and an EKG shows a new right bundle branch block. Lower limb Doppler ultrasound shows deep vein thrombosis in the right calf. This presentation is concerning for acute pulmonary embolism  potentially secondary to a paradoxical embolism given the history of untreated atrial fibrillation.

Demographic Information: A 62-year-old Caucasian male. Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old African American woman presents to the ER with sudden onset of unexplained shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that is worse when breathing in deeply or coughing  and light-headedness. Patient Presentation:  A 56-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department with sudden onset dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain of approximately 3 hours duration. The patient also reports episodes of light-headedness and palpitations. There is no history of fever  cough  hemoptysis or trauma. The patient has a significant medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and morbid obesity with BMI of 45. She reports recent prolonged immobility following total knee replacement surgery 2 weeks prior. The patient has a significant family history of deep vein thrombosis with her father previously diagnosed. She does not smoke and only drinks socially. There is no known history of cardiac disease. There is no recent history of travel.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  the patient is tachycardic with a pulse rate of 110/min and tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min. Oxygen saturation on room air is reduced at 94%. Blood pressure is within normal limits. The patient appears anxious and diaphoretic. No cyanosis or jaundice is noted. Auscultation of the chest reveals decreased breath sounds at the base of the right lung. No murmurs or adventitious heart sounds are heard. Abdomen is soft  non-tender  and non-distended with normal bowel sounds. No pitting edema or signs of deep vein thrombosis observed on bilateral lower limbs.   The presentation and history are suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism possibly secondary to postoperative immobility in a setting of obesity and diabetes.

A 52-year-old African-American female with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  Type 2 Diabetes  and deep vein thrombosis presents with sudden shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breaths  and light-headedness. She reports increasing lower leg swelling and redness in the past two weeks  which she attributed to her recent prolonged travel. She also mentions that she forgot to take her prescribed anticoagulation therapy due to the travel. Her blood pressure on arrival is 130/82 mmHg  with a pulse of 116 beats per minute and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Physical examination reveals unilateral lower limb swelling with calf tenderness. Her EKG shows tachycardia and deep vein ultrasound confirms the presence of a clot. Lab workup reveals an elevated D-dimer level. Her symptoms  history of DVT  and current findings are suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism episode.

Patient is a 60-year-old  overweight  Caucasian female with a history of smoking  hypertension  and recent hip replacement surgery  presenting with sudden-onset sharp chest pain  shortness of breath at rest  light-headedness  and an increased heart rate. Patient is a 65-year-old male smoker with a significant past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) requiring warfarin therapy. Labs reveal elevated D-dimer level.

Patient is a 65-year-old Asian male  with a relevant past medical history of deep venous thrombosis  hypertension  and a sedentary lifestyle. He had surgery 2 weeks prior. Patient Profile: 57-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Complaint: Patient presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness.  Relevant Medical History: Hypertension  recently had a total knee replacement surgery six weeks ago.  On Examination: Temperature is 37.7 degrees Celsius  pulse is 110 beats per minute  blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg  respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. The patient appears anxious and in distress. Chest examination reveals tachycardia with normal S1 and S2. Breath sounds are clear bilaterally with no rales or wheezes. D-dimer test came back positive. No signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Plan: Based on the presenting symptoms  medical history  examination findings  and positive D-dimer test  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is highly suspected. Arrange for a computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) for confirmation.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient with a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis and an inactive lifestyle presents with sudden-onset difficulty in breathing  sharp  stabbing chest pain worsened by deep breathing  and unexplained apprehension. A 56-year-old Caucasian female  nonsmoker  with a medical history of obesity and recent total hip replacement surgery  presents with sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain  and lightheadedness  which started 2 hours prior. A 57-year-old  Caucasian  obese female  non-smoker  with a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and varicose veins  who recently had a right total knee joint replacement surgery  woke up with an abrupt onset of chest pain with a sudden shortness of breath. Patient Representation:  Demographics: John Doe  a 50-year-old Caucasian male   Current Situation: He presented at the hospital's emergency department with complaints of sudden chest pain  mild shortness of breath  and faintness.   Past Medical History: 1. Smoker: John smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years but quit 5 years ago.  2. Hypertension: Diagnosed 10 years ago and maintained on Amlodipine. 3. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 8 years ago  managed with lifestyle modification. 4. Obesity: John has a BMI (Body Mass Index) of 32 and has struggled with weight loss. 5. Surgery: He had a knee replacement surgery two months ago where he was immobilized for a couple of weeks and does not recall any clot prevention measures.   Family History: - No family history of genetic blood clotting disorders.  - His mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65. - His father died of a stroke at the age of 70.  Other Relevant History: - No known drug allergies. - He is retired and lives with his wife.  - He occasionally consumes alcohol.  - He consumes a high-cholesterol diet frequently. - No previous episodes of chest pain or shortness of breath.  - Has not traveled recently.   This case representation raises the possibility of a pulmonary embolism given John's presenting symptoms (onset of sudden chest pain and shortness of breath) and several risk factors including previous surgery with a period of immobilization  long history of smoking leading to chronic lung changes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and obesity. While his family history of cardiovascular events doesn't directly increase his risk of PE but rev up overall risk for venous thrombosis.   The health care team should further examine  order diagnostic tests (D-dimer  CT pulmonary angiography)  and initiate appropriate treatment based on clinical findings and diagnostic results.  The team also needs to be cognizant of any complications that may arise due to this suspected condition or its treatment given his past medical history.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   - A 55-year-old Caucasian male  - Occupation: Desk job with long sedentary hours   Presenting Symptom:  - Sudden onset severe chest pain and difficulty breathing  Key Findings:  - Physical Examination: Rapid heart rate  low blood pressure  cyanosis. - Laboratory Tests: D-dimer test is positive  elevated troponin level. - Diagnostic Imaging: CT pulmonary angiogram confirms the presence of an embolus in the pulmonary artery.  Past Medical History:  - Had orthopedic surgery (knee replacement) 6 weeks ago. - 20 years history of smoking. - Family history of venous thromboembolism (VTE).  - Has been dealing with high blood pressure for the last 10 years.    Social and Lifestyle Factors:  - Sedentary lifestyle  exercise routine halted due to recent surgery. - Smokes about half a pack of cigarettes on a daily basis. - Occasionally consumes alcohol but is not a heavy drinker.  - Lives alone but has a strong social support network. - Limited mobility post-surgery resulting in prolonged bed rest.  This problem representation describes a typical patient with risks and factors leading to pulmonary embolism. These include perioperative state  personal and family history of VTE  smoking  hypertension  and a sedentary lifestyle. These factors should be considered when designing a relevant treatment and management plan.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 52 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Office worker Smoking Status: Non-smoker  Presenting Complaint:   John Doe presents to the Emergency Department complaining of a sudden onset of severe sharp chest pain and shortness of breath  begun approximately 2 hours ago. Relevant risk factors may include his previous DVT  sedentary lifestyle and obesity. His past history of hypertension and family history of cardiovascular events could potentially complicate his current scenario.

Patient Profile:   Name: John Doe Age: 65 years old  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Marital Status: Married  Residential: New York City  USA. Social History:  He is retired  lives with his wife and two adult children who visit frequently. He has a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for approximately 40 years  although he quit smoking 10 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally. He has a sedentary lifestyle and his diet is reported to be high in saturated fats and sugar.  Medications:  John is prescribed a daily dose of Asprin  a statin for his high cholesterol  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Warfarin due to his history of DVT.  Impression:  Considering John's presenting complaints  previous medical history of DVT  his highly sedentary lifestyle  and the cardiovascular risk factors like smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  a significant suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism is raised. He requires immediate hospital admission  diagnostic verification  risk stratification and appropriate management for potential Pulmonary Embolism.   Note: This is a fictional patient profile representation and should not replace or inform actual medical advice or decisions. Please consult with a healthcare professional for any medical concerns.

Patient Profile:  Patient: Ms. Brown  Demographic Characteristics: - Age: 70 years - Sex: Female - Ethnicity: African-American - Occupation: Retired  - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  occasional alcohol - Family History: Father passed away due to Myocardial Infarction at aged 55.  Relevant Past Medical History: - Hypertension: Diagnosed six years ago  maintained on Lisinopril. - Diabetes mellitus: Diagnosed five years ago  controlled with Metformin and regular exercise. - Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed three years ago  under statin therapy. - Atrial Fibrillation: Diagnosed three months ago  on warfarin anticoagulation. - Asthma: Controlled with occasional use of inhaled corticosteroids. - Mild renal impairment: Creatinine levels have been slightly above normal range in the last year  currently followed by a nephrologist.  Recent/Current Health Issue: Presented to the hospital with sudden onset of right-sided chest pain and difficulty in breathing that began a few hours ago. The patient also reported feeling faint and had a syncopal episode at home. She denied any cough  fever  or recent travels. She has been compliant with her medications.  Further investigations showed signs of respiratory distress with increased respiratory rate and decreased oxygen saturation on pulse oximetry. Her electrocardiogram showed right ventricular strain pattern and her D-dimer levels were highly elevated  raising suspicion for an acute pulmonary embolism. Immediate CT angiography was ordered for confirmation  which confirmed the presence of large embolus in the right pulmonary artery.  Given her medical history  current signs  and symptoms  and investigation results  a diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism is made. The patient is admitted to the hospital for further management  which includes oxygen supplementation  anticoagulant therapy adjustment  and considering thrombolytic therapy if her condition deteriorates.   Upon stabilization  she will need long-term anticoagulation and further evaluation for the cause of this embolus  given her history of atrial fibrillation  hypertension  and other risk factors. She may also benefit from pulmonary rehabilitation and lifestyle modifications to decrease the recurrence risk.

Problem Representation:  Patient Characteristics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired from a sedentary desk job and has a history of long-distance traveling. He is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago but continues to experience occasional shortness of breath. He has a BMI of 28.5  positioning him in the overweight category.  Clinical Presentation: The patient presents with sudden-onset dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain  and mild hemoptysis. These symptoms started 2 days ago. He describes the dyspnea as gradually worsening over the past 24 hours. He also reports having a persistent cough with mild mucus production for the past week. Vital signs reveal a heart rate of 110 beats/minute  blood pressure of 145/85 mmHg  a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation level at 90% on room air.  Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  deep vein thrombosis with inferior vena cava (IVC) filter placement 5 years ago  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He is compliant with his daily medications including an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor  a statin  and a bronchodilator.  Family History: The patient has a family history of cardiopulmonary diseases  including a father who died of pulmonary embolism  and a mother with coronary artery disease.  This patient's history and symptoms raise a high index of suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic evaluation like D-dimer  CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA)  or V/Q scan may be beneficial in this case to confirm the diagnosis. The patient's history of DTV  recent travel  and COPD further increase his risk for a PE event.

Problem Statement:  Patient Description: The patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who presents with symptoms indicative of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Demographic Profile: The patient is a retired teacher  married  non-smoker  and occasional drinker. He resides with his wife in the suburbs. Prior to retiring  he led a mostly sedentary lifestyle amid the demands of his profession. Now has a more active lifestyle but with minimal exercise. He is overweight with a BMI of 28.5 kg/m^2.  Relevant Past Medical History: Notably  the patient has a known past medical history of hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after a prolonged period of immobility due to a fracture to his right femur about 3 years ago. He has been on regular medication since then for his hypertension and diabetes. The patient has no known allergies.  Presenting Complaints:  Recently  the patient has been suffering from shortness of breath  chest pain worsened by deep breathing  cough  and episodes of feeling lightheaded. Upon consultation  the patient revealed that he recently undertook a long-haul flight approximately 1 week ago.  Investigations: Further investigations are required to confirm the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. These may include: 1. D-dimer blood test 2. CT pulmonary angiogram  3. Doppler ultrasound for the presence of DVT 4. Electrocardiogram   This clinical scenario emphasizes the need for considering acute pulmonary embolism in the differential diagnosis  particularly given the recent history of prolonged travel  previous history of DVT  sedentary lifestyle  and presence of other risk factors such as hypertension and diabetes.

Demographic Characterization: Patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian female  married  former smoker  BMI of 32  moderately active lifestyle  works at a desk job requiring prolonged sitting times  lives in a suburban environment.   Past Medical History: -Hypertension for the past 10 years and taking medications: Lisinopril  -History of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) around three years ago; the patient underwent treatment and then prophylaxis. -Underwent an orthopedic surgery (Knee Replacement) in the near past and had been immobile for a significant period. -Use of oral contraceptive medications for the past 20 years -Physical examination reports revealed mild obesity  -Family history of venous thromboembolism and hypercoagulable disorders. -No known allergies  Presentation of Symptoms: Patient was brought to the ER with sudden-onset difficulty in breathing and chest pain. The pain is sharp  and worsens with deep breathing. Patient is visibly anxious and short of breath. There is a non-productive cough and the patient also reports feeling light-headed.   These symptoms paired with the patient's past history and risk factors could suggest a potential acute pulmonary embolism. A detailed medical examination and necessary diagnostic tests are required for confirmation.

Patient Profile:   Geniva Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian woman with a calculated BMI of 28(overweight)  who presented to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath  chest pain  and palpitations. The symptoms started suddenly 2 hours back while she was gardening. She is an active smoker (30 pack years) and consumes alcohol occasionally. She denies illicit drug use. She works as a school administrator and lives with her husband. She has three kids and seven grandkids. She visited her family last for a holiday gathering two weeks ago. She was largely sedentary before the pandemic but has been more active in the last year.  Medical History:  Mrs. Smith has a past medical history (PMH) of venous thromboembolism (VTE) with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the lower extremities 5 years ago and one episode of non-massive pulmonary embolism (PE) which was resolved with anticoagulation therapy. She also has uncontrolled hypertension and type II diabetes; uncontrolled according to her most recent HbA1c and blood pressure readings. She was diagnosed with osteoporosis two years ago. Her surgical history includes hysterectomy and appendectomy.   Family history reveals father passed away with heart disease at the age of 70 and mother passed away with stroke at 72 years old. One sibling has been diagnosed with lung cancer and another has type 2 diabetes.   She is currently off of the anticoagulation due to recent GI bleed of about 3 weeks ago and she is on aspirin 81mg daily for CAD prophylaxis  metformin  and Lisinopril for diabetes and hypertension respectively. She denies allergies to any medication.   On examination  she is afebrile but tachycardic and tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 28 per minute and oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. Her blood pressure is also on the higher side of 150/90 mmHg.  She appears anxious  and distressed. On physical examination  there is decreased air entry on the left side of the chest. There are no leg swelling or tenderness to palpation. Positive bilateral basal crepitations.  This is a typical case presentation for a patient who has developed an acute pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents in the emergency department.  Primary Complaint:   The patient complains of sudden onset of sharp  left-sided chest pain that worsens with deep breaths. He also reports shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and feeling panicked. Additional symptoms include a rapid heartbeat and a noticeable episode of unprovoked leg swelling one week ago.  Demographics:  • Occupation: Retired engineer • Lifestyle: Sedentary with minimal physical activities • Alcohol: Occasional drinker • Smoking: Pack-day smoker for 40 years  quit 10 years ago • Marital Status: Married • Number of Children: 2  Medication History:  • On aspirin 81mg once daily for cardiovascular protection  Relevant Past Medical History:  • History of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) one year ago. • Chronic hypertension managed with beta-blockers. • Previous smoker - quit 10 years ago. • Family history of blood clot disorders.  Clinical Examination:  • Vital signs: Blood pressure = 155/95 mm-Hg  Pulse = 110 bpm  Respiratory rate = 24 breaths per minute  Temp = 37.3°C (99.1°F)  Oxygen saturation = 92% on room air. • General: The patient appears anxious and dyspneic. • Chest exam: Decreased breath sounds on left side  and tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. • Cardiovascualar exam: Tachycardic  regular rhythm  but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. • Leg exam: Noticeable swelling in the right calf; warmth  erythema  pain on dorsiflexion noted (positive Homan's sign). • Rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Given the history of unresolved right calf DVT  sudden chest pain  tachypnea  tachycardia  hypoxemia  and an anxious appearance  the most likely diagnosis is an acute pulmonary embolism. The patient should be stabilized and further diagnostic tests should be conducted immediately to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes of his symptoms.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: Gender: Male  Age: 65 years old  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired   Insurance: Medicare  Residence: Urban dwelling   Presenting Issue:  The patient presents with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain (particularly when taking a deep breath)  rapid pulse and feeling of lightheadedness.   Past Medical History:  Patient has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and underwent a knee replacement surgery three weeks ago. Patient also has a recorded history of smoking  high blood pressure and diabetes. Patient has a familial history of clotting disorders.  Physical Examination:  Patient is conscious and cooperative but anxious due to difficulty in breathing. Skin is warm and clammy with a noticeable bluish color around the lips and fingers. Breathing sounds are fast and shallow.  Laboratory Tests and Imaging: The physician would consider a D-dimer test  CT angiogram or a V/Q scan based on patient condition and risk factors.  Working Diagnosis: Given the sudden onset of symptoms  past medical history of DVT and recent orthopedic surgery  the working diagnosis is acute pulmonary embolism.   Plan of Care: Immediate treatment to restore the blood flow through the lungs  supplementary oxygen and medications to prevent future clots. Further confirmatory tests will be needed including imaging studies to locate blood clots. If confirmed  anticoagulant therapy would be considered. In severe cases  thrombolysis or surgical intervention may be necessary.   Risk Factors:  The major risk factors include obesity  recent surgery  bed rest or immobility  history of DVT  smoking and pre-disposition to clotting disorders.   Prognosis:  If treated promptly  patients can recover fully. However  delays in diagnosis or treatment can result in life-threatening complications.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male non-smoker  a retired construction worker  comes to the Emergency Department.  Presenting Complaint:  Patient reports shortness of breath that started suddenly this morning  along with mild chest discomfort. He denies any cough or fever but admits to feeling slightly lightheaded.  Past Medical History:  1. Recent surgery: Patient had a total hip replacement surgery three weeks ago  for which he was mostly bedridden during his recovery period. 2. Chronic medical conditions: Has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  which are decently controlled with medications. 3. Previous illnesses and hospitalizations: No previous history of myocardial infarction  asthma  COPD  or any lung disease. 4. Drug History: Regularly takes Ramipril and Atorvastatin. No known drug allergies. Does not smoke  drink alcohol  or use illicit drugs.  Family History:  There is a strong family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE).  Personal and Social History:  Lives alone with his dog. He is fairly independent  but since the surgery  he has had difficulty with mobility. He is still waiting for rehabilitation therapy.  Clinical Picture:  On examination  he appears mildly distressed and is breathing rapidly. Vital signs: Blood pressure - 140/90 mmHg  Heart Rate - 110 beats/min  Respiratory Rate - 22 breaths/min  Temperature - 98.1°F  Oxygen Saturation - 93% on room air. His lungs are clear to auscultation  heart rhythm regular  no lower limb swelling or calf tenderness noted. His electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia and a S1Q3T3 pattern  suggestive of acute cor pulmonale.  This clinical presentation is highly suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism  possibly precipitated by prolonged immobility post hip replacement surgery. Further investigations including blood tests (D-dimer  troponin) and an immediate CT pulmonary angiogram are being planned to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Profile:  Demographics: Name: John Doe Age: 60 years old Sex: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Corporate Executive Marital status: Married Place of Residence: New York City  USA   Presenting Complaint: John Doe was admitted to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe chest pain  shortness of breath and dizziness.   Past Medical History: The patient has a medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago  for which he underwent treatment with anticoagulants. He has hypertension and hyperlipidemia which has been managed over the years through medication and lifestyle modifications. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 10 years ago and has been on oral hypoglycemic agents since then. John is an ex-smoker  who quit smoking 3 years ago after a 30-year history of smoking.  Family History: His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 65. His mother has been living with osteoarthritis and is 87 years old. He has a sister with type 2 diabetes and a brother with no known health issues.  Social History: John frequently travels long distances for work  primarily by airplane. He lives an active lifestyle  exercises regularly  and follows a relatively balanced diet.   Clinical Examination Findings: Upon physical examination  he appears restless and in distress due to the pain. His blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg  heart rate is 104 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation is 93% on room air. On auscultation  his heart sounds are normal but his respiratory sounds show rales at the lung bases.   Investigations: A CT Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) and D-Dimer test have been ordered for further investigation. The electrocardiogram (ECG) shows signs of right ventricular strain.  Problem Representation: A 60-year-old male patient with a history of DVT  hypertension  high cholesterol  and diabetes  presenting with acute chest pain  breathlessness  and signs of hemodynamic instability. This presentation  along with his past medical history and frequent long-distance travel  highly suspect for an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Profile:  Name: [John Doe] Age: [57] Sex: Male Race: Ethnicity: [Caucasian] Occupation: [Retired Engineer] Living Situation: [Lives with his wife  Older son and daughter-in-law] Smoker: [Non-Smoker] Alcohol Usage: [Occasional] Nationality: American  Representation:   Mr. John Doe  57 years old retired engineer came to the ER complaining about sudden shortness of breath and sharp chest pain that worsens when he breathes deeply or coughs. Patient Profile:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  walks in unaccompanied  complaining of sudden  sharp chest pain and shortness of breath. He also reports that he has had a cough  with occasional bloody mucus  for the last two days. He looks visibly anxious and is perspiring excessively. His body mass index (BMI) is recorded as 28. He also mentions that he has experienced occasional bouts of dizziness and lightheadedness recently.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a known issue with high blood pressure for which he has been on medication (hydrochlorothiazide) for the past five years. He also had an episode of deep vein thrombosis 10 years ago  after undergoing a knee replacement surgery for which he was treated initially with heparin followed by warfarin. He has an established history of smoking about a pack of cigarettes daily for the past three decades  although he has been cutting back in recent years. He also reveals that his father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 70.  Social History:  He is a retired engineer and remains physically inactive most of the time  although he does engage in light gardening activities over the weekend. He lives alone in a two-story house and manages his chores independently. He admits to drinking socially and does not use any illicit substances.  Current Medications:  1. Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily for hypertension. 2. Aspirin 81mg daily  given his previous history of vein thrombosis.  Allergies:  Mr. Johnson reports no known drug allergies.  Based on the presenting symptoms and history  particularly in the context of previous DVT  long-term smoking  physical inactivity  and family history of PE  the specific problem of acute pulmonary embolism needs to be further evaluated.
