Patient Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who works as a long-haul truck driver.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant past medical history of hypertension for 15 years that is moderately controlled by oral antihypertensive medication. Additionally  he has a known hyperlipidemia for 10 years and is on statins for the same. He is also a known smoker for more than 30 years with a pack per day usage.  Illness Course: The patient entered the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breathing  and a sense of feeling faint.  Risk factor identification: Sedentary lifestyle due to long hours of sitting during his long-haul truck driving trips  chronic smoking habit  uncontrolled hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.  Possible triggers: A recent prolonged cross country truck-driving trip without breaks could have potentially triggered venous pooling and clot formation.  Overall  the patient’s medical history  lifestyle factors  and the sudden onset of his symptoms make an acute pulmonary embolism a likely diagnosis. Since pulmonary embolism can be life-threatening  urgent evaluation and treatment are indicated.

Demographic Characterization:   A 67-year-old Caucasian retired female who is a widow living along with her 45-year-old daughter and three grandchildren in the suburban area. She is a former educator with a high school education and has a moderate to low socioeconomic status with no personal health insurance coverage. She is slightly overweight with a sedentary lifestyle and a history of heavy smoking (30 pack-years) and moderate alcohol consumption. She possesses a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. Currently  she is experiencing moderate to severe shortness of breath and chest pain.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol for which she was recommended lifestyle modifications and prescribed statins and antihypertensives. She was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation eight months ago and was put on blood thinning medication. The patient had also undergone a total knee replacement surgery two months ago. She has type-2 diabetes well-controlled under medication and dietary management. There is a known history of occasional asthma  anemia  and osteoporosis for which she takes inhalers  iron supplements  and calcium tablets respectively.  Her surgical history includes the above-mentioned knee replacement  an appendectomy at age 25  and cesarean deliveries for two of her children.  On social aspects  she is a heavy smoker (30 pack-years) and consumes alcohol in moderation. She is independent in her activities of daily living. She is not allergic to any medication known so far. There are no prior records of drug abuse.  Adherence to medications is inconsistent due to her forgetfulness and sometimes  affordability issues. She does not regularly follow-up with her primary care physician or the specialists due to financial constraints and lack of support.  She presents here with acute onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and palpitations  suggestive of a possible pulmonary embolism. Her risk factors include older age  prolonged periods of immobility due to the recent knee surgery  hypertension  deep vein thrombosis due to atrial fibrillation  and smoking.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 63 Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Colorado  USA  Presenting Problem:   Mr. Doe has been experiencing sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath  and cough with bloody sputum for the past couple of hours. On further probing  he revealed that he had been inactive for prolonged periods due to a recent knee surgery.   Past Medical History:  1. History of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 2. Right knee arthroplasty six weeks ago. 3. Hypertension managed with daily Amlodipine 4. Former smoker - quit smoking 10 years ago. 5. Cardiac MRI four years ago showed no abnormalities  Social History:  1. Moderate alcohol consumption: 2 drinks per day on average 2. Retired from work as an accountant; currently lives alone 3. Has primary caregiver for aid since the knee surgery  Family History:  1. Father passed away from Myocardial Infarction at the age of 75  2. Mother deceased from Stroke; she had Atrial Fibrillation 3. Brother is alive and well; no known conditions  Investigations to be done:  Based on his symptoms and past medical history  Mr. Doe is a high-risk patient for pulmonary embolism. Hence  D-Dimer test  Computed Tomographic Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA)  and possibly an Ultrasound Doppler study should be ordered to confirm the diagnosis.  Plan:  1. Stabilize the patient: If the patient's vitals are unstable  he may need unfractionated heparin or low molecular weight heparin and oxygen therapy. 2. Confirm Diagnosis: Carry out all relevant investigations to confirm pulmonary embolism. 3. Treatment: Depending on the size and location of the embolism  treatment might vary from anticoagulation medication to thrombolytic therapy or surgical removal. 4. Counseling: The patient should be advised to avoid prolonged immobility and to stop alcohol consumption. 5. Follow up: The patient should be periodically monitored for his recovery and changes in his symptoms.

Problem Representation:  A 58-year-old African American male with a past medical history of hypertension  deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  and smoking presents with sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath  and hemoptysis for 12 hours. There are also accompanying symptoms such as light-headedness  fainting  and palpitations. The patient takes antihypertensive medications and has a BMI of 29.2 indicating overweight. Family history reveals his father had a pulmonary embolism at age 60. The patient states that he had been on a long flight (8 hours) about a week ago returning from a business trip. Physical examination shows that he is tachypneic and tachycardic with an O2 saturation of 92% on room air. Lab results show elevated D-dimer and troponins levels. The ECG shows sinus tachycardia but no evidence of right ventricular strain or acute ischemia.   This is a high-risk profile patient presenting with classic symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism such as sudden chest pain  shortness of breath  and hemoptysis. Relevant risk factors for this patient include his past history of DVT  smoking  prolonged immobilization (long flight)  hypertension  family history of PE  and being overweight. His symptoms  physical examination findings  and initial lab results (elevated D-dimer and troponins) are consistent with a possible diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 62-year-old African American male arrived at the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: He reports sudden onset of sharp  severe chest pain along with shortness of breath.  Present Illness: The pain started suddenly while the patient was resting at home  and has been persistent for the last 5 hours. It worsens with deep breathing and does not radiate. The dyspnea also started concurrently with the chest pain.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension (controlled with medication)  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) treated with anticoagulants 3 years ago. His paternal grandfather and mother had a history of pulmonary embolism. He recently had a knee replacement surgery 4 weeks ago and had been largely immobile during the recovery period.   Social History: The patient is a retired construction worker. He is a non-smoker and reports moderate alcohol use.  Clinical Examination: The patient is tachypneic  with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute and has O2 saturation of 92% on room air.   Problem List: Based on history and presentation  the primary concern is a possible acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  likely secondary to his recent surgery  immobility  past history of DVT  and familial predisposition to clotting disorders.   Diagnostic Plan: An urgent CT pulmonary angiogram to confirm the suspected diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism would be the next appropriate step. Concurrently  D-dimer levels  coagulation profile  complete blood count  and basic metabolic panel should also be ordered.   Therapeutic Plan: Simultaneously  the patient should be treated empirically for PE with anticoagulation therapy  pending diagnostic confirmation. Monitor the patient's vitals closely and provide supplemental oxygen to maintain O2 saturation above 94% if needed. If the PE is confirmed and is massive or the patient hemodynamically unstable  thrombolytic therapy or surgical thrombectomy would be considered.   This problem representation aims to underscore the importance of considering patient history and risk factors for conditions like PE and tailoring investigation and management plans accordingly.

Patient Profile: Mr. A is a 65-year-old African American male who works as a full-time accountant and is a resident of New York  USA.  Presenting Problem: Mr. A presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath that started while he was eating dinner. He also reported experiencing sharp chest pain  which worsened with deep breaths  and a persistent dry cough for the past few hours. He mentioned feeling lightheaded and faint.  Detailed History: Mr. A recalls having been more sedentary than usual for the last two weeks due to a major project at work that required prolonged periods of sitting. Also  there has been a recent history of long-haul flight travel two weeks ago. No significant weight loss  fever  night sweats or hemoptysis. There’s no family history of clotting disorders.   Past Medical History: His past medical history includes high blood pressure  for which he has been prescribed Lisinopril. He has been on this medication for five years and reports stable blood pressure readings at his regular checkups. He also reports a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) after a knee replacement surgery five years ago  for which he received anticoagulation therapy.   Review of Systems: Patient reports no recent illnesses or injuries  no changes in bowel or bladder function  no rashes  no changes in weight  appetite  or sleep patterns. Patient reports regular eye exams  denies blurry vision or eye pain. Patient denies problems with memory  speech  or balance.   Social History: Mr. A is a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. His diet is balanced and he tries to maintain a regular exercise routine.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared to be in mild respiratory distress. Vital signs at presentation were blood pressure 152/92 mmHg  heart rate 118 beats per minute  respiratory rate 24 per minute  oxygen saturation 92% on room air. Cardiac examination was normal. Lung auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds in the lower right lobe.   Given the patient's demographic  past medical  presenting symptoms  and clinical findings  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is strongly suspected and needs appropriate diagnostic testing for confirmation. The patient’s antecedents of long plane travels  sedentarism  and a previous DVT episode reinforce the suspicion of this diagnosis.

Patient Problem Presentation:  Patient Demographics:  A 58-year-old Caucasian female presents to the emergency department.  Chief Complaint:  Shortness of breath  sharp chest pain exacerbated by deep breathing  and episodes of feeling faint.  Medical History:  She reports a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her left leg two and a half years ago  which was treated with anticoagulation therapy. Additionally  she has a decade-long history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus  for which she takes Lisinopril  Simvastatin  and Metformin  respectively. She also reports a significant family history  with both her parents having passed away from heart-related issues in their sixties.  Lifestyle:  She is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and lives a fairly sedentary lifestyle due to office work. She reports a recent international flight about one week ago  which lasted for five hours.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  she appears diaphoretic and mildly distressful due to pain. Her heart rate is elevated at 110 beats per minute  and her blood pressure is slightly low at 110/70 mmHg. Oxygen saturation levels are low at 92% on room air  which return to normal (98%) on supplemental oxygen. Lung sounds reveal decreased breath sounds at the right lower lobe. The rest of the physical examination is within normal limits.  Impression: The patient's symptoms  medical history  and physical examination point to a possible pulmonary embolism  given her history of DVT  long sedentary periods  and recent prolonged flight. She may need immediate diagnostic tests like D-dimer  Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA)  or Ventilation/Perfusion (V/Q) scan to confirm the diagnosis and start on appropriate treatment promptly. As she has multiple risk factors for Cardiovascular Disease (CVD)  cardiac causes should also be ruled out.

Problem Representation:   Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian female.  Presenting Complaint: The patient reports sudden onset chest pain which worsens on deep breathing and shortness of breath for the past several hours.  Clinical History/Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and was on anticoagulation therapy which she self-discontinued one month ago. Significant history includes obesity  a sedentary lifestyle  long-distance travel two weeks ago  and a family history of pulmonary embolism (PE). She also has Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia which have been managed with medication. There is no known history of any malignancy  and she is a non-smoker  non-drinker.  Examination Findings:  On examination  the patient appears in mild distress due to pain. Vital signs reveal tachycardia and slightly elevated blood pressure. She is afebrile. Oxygen saturation on room air reveals hypoxemia. Pulmonary examination reveals tachypnea and decreased breath sounds on the right lower side of the chest.  Investigations:  Electrocardiography (ECG) and blood tests including D-dimer  Troponin level  complete blood count  coagulation profile  Arterial blood gas analysis  chest X-ray  and computed tomographic pulmonary angiography (CTPA or CT pulmonary angiogram) are ordered in a suspect of Acute pulmonary embolism.   Risk Factors:  The patient's risk factors include her age (over 60)  known history of DVT  discontinuation of anticoagulation therapy  recent long-distance travel  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  and family history of PE.  Possible Complications: Potential complications needing to be monitored for include recurrent DVT/PE  hemodynamic instability  right ventricular dysfunction or pulmonary hypertension  bleeding (due to anticoagulation therapy) and post-PE syndrome.  Management Plan:  The patient needs immediate hospital admission  with prompt initiation of anticoagulation therapy following confirmation of diagnosis  and further managing based on any complications. Secondary prevention strategies will also be needed  including patient education regarding medication adherence  lifestyle modifications  and regular follow-up.

Problem Representation:  Patient Information:  - Demographics: 65-year-old Caucasian male  - Occupation: Retired construction worker  - Lifestyle: Occasionally smokes cigars  drinks wine socially  minimal physical activity - Family History: Father died of lung cancer  mother had a stroke  Past Medical History:   - Hypertension  - Diabetes type II  - Previous Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) 3 years ago - treated with anticoagulation therapy. - Recent right knee arthroplasty – 2 weeks ago   Presenting Problem:  The patient presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breaths  and a sense of unease/anxiety. Noted to also be mildly confused and sweating profusely.   Upon physical examination:  - Tachycardia  - Low-grade fever - Low oxygen saturation level (88% on room air)  Clinical findings:  Blood tests show raised D-Dimer levels  ECG shows signs of Right heart strain.  Summary:  The 65-year-old male with a history of DVT  recent knee surgery  diabetes  and hypertension presents with acute shortness of breath  chest pain  anxiety  and common signs of pulmonary embolism. The suspicions are substantiated by the given medical history and recent immobilization due to surgery – both lead to increased risk for Pulmonary Embolism. Early recognition and management are vital for this life-threatening condition.

Patient Profile:  Gender: Female  Age: 62 years  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired office worker   Presenting Complaint:  The patient presents with sudden onset chest pain  difficulty in breathing  cough and restlessness that started a few hours earlier.  Past Medical History:  1. The patient has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left lower limb about two years ago  which was managed with anticoagulants. 2. She has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past ten years  under control with medication.  3. She underwent total knee replacement surgery on both knees one year ago  after which she was relatively immobile for a period due to post-operative pain.  4. She is a former smoker  having quit about 10 years ago. She smoked a pack a day for approximately 25 years. 5. The patient has a family history of pulmonary embolisms  with her mother having suffered from the same condition.  Social History:   The patient resides at her home with her husband. She is limited in her physical activities due to fear of repeat DVT. She does not consume alcohol or any illicit drugs.  Allergies:   No known drug allergies.  Understanding of Problem:  Based on the current presentation  past medical history  and demographic information  it is suspected that this patient is suffering from Acute Pulmonary Embolism  which is an obstruction of a pulmonary artery or one of its branches  frequently due to a thrombus that originated in the systemic venous system or in the right heart chambers. Considering her history of DVT  knee surgery  prolonged immobilization period  hypertension  smoking history  and family history of PE  she shows several risk factors associated with Pulmonary Embolism.

Problem Representation: Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of obesity  hypertension  and stage III chronic kidney disease. He is a longtime smoker with a 30-pack year smoking history. He also had an orthopedic surgery for a total knee replacement 1 month ago.   Yesterday  he abruptly began experiencing chest discomfort  rapid heart rate  shortness of breath  and faintness. He also mentioned that he has been coughing up blood. There is no history of fever  loss of consciousness  or neurological deficits. There is no previous history of similar presentation.   Mr. Smith's symptoms  along with his demographic and clinical background as well as recent surgery  strongly suggest a high risk for acute pulmonary embolism. His significant risk factors include age  smoking  obesity  immobilisation post-surgery  and chronic kidney disease. His symptoms such as sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath  coughing up blood  and tachycardia are classic signs of a pulmonary embolism.   His diagnostic evaluation should include a D-dimer test and imaging studies like Pulmonary angiogram  Chest CT angiography or V/Q scan. Immediate anticoagulation therapy should be considered while awaiting diagnostic results depending on the initial clinical assessment of his PE risk.   This approach will help confirm the diagnosis and guide subsequent management strategies respectively. The process will not only take into account his current clinical syndrome but also his past medical history  comorbid conditions as well as the risk involved in his potential treatment.  Patient education regarding the importance of postoperative mobility and risk factor management is also crucial in his condition. His previous smoking history and chronic diseases need special attention while planning for his long-term management.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a body mass index of 27 indicating that he is overweight. He has a history of 40 years of tobacco cigarette smoking  with an average of one pack per day. He recently retired from his job of 25 years as a truck driver where he spent long hours sitting.  Presenting Symptoms:  He presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep breaths. He also mentions that he has been feeling dizzy and lightheaded. Moreover  he notices occasional coughing up small amounts of blood. The symptoms appeared several hours ago  and he did not have any trauma  injury or excessive exertion preceding it.  Medical History:  His past medical history includes hypertension for 20 years  high cholesterol for 15 years  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left leg 6 months ago. He has been compliant with his prescribed medications  including an antihypertensive (lisinopril) and a statin (simvastatin).  He completed his course of anticoagulation therapy for DVT 2 months ago.  Family History:  He reports his father suffered a stroke at 67 years old and his mother suffered a myocardial infarction (heart attack) at 72.  Social History:  The patient admits to continuous tobacco use and reports consuming alcohol socially. He lives alone and has been fairly sedentary since his retirement.  Thought Process:  The patient's long history of smoking  prior incidence of DVT  recent immobilization due to substantial sitting from his previous job  and the recent discontinuation of anticoagulation therapy all increase his risk for a pulmonary embolism.  The sudden onset of symptoms and the nature of his chest pain also raise a high index of suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism. Confirmatory testing should be performed  including a D-dimer assay and CT pulmonary angiography.  Areas of Concern:  High risk of mortality if not treated promptly  risk of recurrent DVT and potential for post-thrombotic syndrome  chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension  and pulmonary infarction. The patient's substantial smoking history also puts him at risk for other cardiovascular and lung diseases.

Patient Problem Representation:  Chief Complaint: A 65-year-old  overweight  Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a one-day history of sudden onset  severe shortness of breath  and chest pain that gets worse with deep breaths.  Demographics: He is a retired teacher  lives with his wife  and is a former smoker (quit 10 years ago  with a history of 30 pack-years). He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. He is relatively sedentary and spends much of his time sitting or laying down.   Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension  for which he is on Metformin and Lisinopril  respectively. He was also diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) in his left leg five years ago  for which he was treated with warfarin. However  he stopped taking the medication two years ago on his own accord.  Family History: There is a family history of coronary artery disease (his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60).  Review of Systems: He denies any fever  cough  hemoptysis  palpitations or syncope. However  he mentions that his left leg has been slightly swollen and painful for about a week.  Social History: The patient and his wife recently returned from a long car trip (12+ hours).  Sexual History: He is married and monogamous.  Occupational Histories: Retired teacher  currently doesn't partake in any strenuous activities.   Allergies: No known drug allergies.  Medications: Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension.  Immunization History: Up-to-date on all recommended vaccines.   This presentation is consistent with a possible Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE). His risk factors include a history of DVT  prolonged immobility during a long car ride  obesity  and advanced age. His abrupt onset of symptoms suggests an acute event  while his chest pain  shortness of breath and previous unilateral leg swelling/pain may suggest embolic event. His past medical history of stopping warfarin  a prescribed anticoagulant  also puts him at an increased risk for thromboembolic events. His family history of coronary artery disease may also accelerate the disease process if it has not been adequately managed.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Anderson Age: 65 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired (Former banker)  Presenting Issue: Mr. Anderson presents with acute pulmonary embolism. He reports a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain that worsens with deep breathing  and feeling lightheaded. He also mentions recent coughing bouts  sometimes accompanied by a small quantity of bloody sputum.  Medical History: Mr. Anderson has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and takes warfarin to manage his condition. He had surgery for a hernia three weeks ago.   Risk Factor History: Mr. Anderson is a former smoker who quit approximately fifteen years ago. His BMI is 28  indicating that he is overweight. He has a sedentary lifestyle  due to his former work and his age. There is a family history of venous thromboembolism  thus suggesting a probable genetic predisposition.  Social History: The patient is widowed and lives alone. His two grown children are within a 1 hour's drive. He consumes alcohol moderately and has never used recreational drugs.  Medication Overview: Mr. Anderson takes warfarin regularly. Other medications include metformin for his type II diabetes  lisinopril for his hypertension  and a multivitamin tablet as suggested by his primary care physician. He is not currently taking any over-the-counter medicines or herbal supplements as per the last consultation.  Allergies History: Mr. Anderson reports a known allergy to penicillin. He experiences rash and itching upon exposure.  Concluding Notes: Mr. Anderson's medical  genetic  and lifestyle history  taken together  suggests that he is at high risk of developing conditions like pulmonary embolism. Prompt attention to his current presentation can be crucial in avoiding complications.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 50-year-old Caucasian female presents with sudden shortness of breath  chest pain  and a feeling of rapid heart rate that started two hours ago.  Demographic Information: She is an office worker  married with two children. She does not smoke  has a moderate alcohol intake  and pays attention to gaining a balanced diet. She has a body mass index of 25  is physically active  and has no known drug allergies.   Relevant Past Medical History: The patient has a history predictive of venous thromboembolism risk such as recent major surgery (hip replacement six weeks ago)  prolonged immobilization  and a personal history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Her father died of pulmonary embolism in his late 50s. There's no record of malignancy  autoimmune disease  or cardiovascular disease. She does not have a history of respiratory diseases like asthma or COPD. She was on prophylactic anticoagulation after her surgery but quit it after four weeks.   Relevant Medication History: The patient was on short-term prophylactic anticoagulation (rivaroxaban) following her hip replacement. She does not have a history of chronic medication use.   Past Surgical History:  The patient has undergone a cesarean section 20 years ago and recently a hip replacement surgery.  Social History: The patient lives with her husband and two children. She reports high levels of stress due to her demanding job and has a sedentary lifestyle. She has no history of illicit drug use.   Family History: Her father had an infrequent blood clotting disorder which led to his passing due to a pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:   A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and recent hip replacement surgery (trauma)  is presenting to the emergency department with acute onset of dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain and mild hemoptysis. The patient reports that the symptoms started suddenly last night  making it increasingly difficult for him to catch his breath. Additionally  there is a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE). He is currently on medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and has been on a prescribed course of prophylactic low molecular weight heparin (anticoagulant) post his hip replacement surgery.   Overall  this phenotype represents a senior patient with considerable cardiovascular morbidities and a recent surgical history  presenting with classic symptoms of a potential pulmonary embolism. Given his past medical history and the nature of symptoms  it is critical to rule in or out the diagnosis of PE.   Key Attributes:  - Age: 68 years old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Past Medical History: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  Total Hip Replacement Surgery  - Family history: Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and Pulmonary Embolism (PE) - Current Medications: Anti-hypertensives  Statins for hyperlipidemia  Prophylactic low molecular weight heparin - Chief Complaint: Acute onset of dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain  and mild hemoptysis.     This patient belongs to a high-risk group due to recent surgery (increased risk of blood clots)  COPD (increased susceptibility to respiratory complications)  hypertension (increased cardiovascular strain)  and relevant family history  all of which can lead to the occurrence of PE. His current symptoms of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and hemoptysis are also consistent with acute PE. Hence  he immediately warrants diagnostic testing and potential therapeutic procedures for addressing pulmonary embolism.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Smith  Age: 62 years  Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired military officer Residence: Urban domicile Marital Status: Married Smoking habit: None Alcohol use: Moderate Recreational drug use: None  Past Medical History: John has been diagnosed with bilateral knee osteoarthritis for which he underwent bilateral knee replacement surgery 3 weeks ago. John was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease 5 years ago. He has no known allergies.  Family's Past Medical History: Father died at age 65 of myocardial infarction. His mother is still alive  age 88  has type II diabetes. His brother  aged 59  has a history of deep vein thrombosis.  Current Complaint:  John came to the hospital complaining of acute onset shortness of breath that started two hours prior to his arrival. He also mentions having sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep breaths  and lightheadedness. There is no cough present  no fever  and no history of recent travelling.  Representative Problem: Given John’s recent orthopedic surgery and his family history of deep vein thrombosis  the fact he presents with sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain and lightheadedness is highly suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism. The severity of pulmonary embolism can range widely; urgent action is required in order to confirm the diagnosis and manage the patient appropriately.

Her mother had a history of recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) episodes. 4. Patient has a sedentary lifestyle due to immobility issues since her knee replacement surgery.  5. The combination of the symptoms with her past medical history  including a drastic lifestyle change since the surgery  family history of DVT  being on hormone replacement therapy  obesity  diabetes and hypertension all together suggest the likelihood of an acute pulmonary embolism.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 56-year-old hypertensive and diabetic Caucasian female who is a current smoker of about 30 years.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with sudden onset  sharp  intense pain in her right side chest along with breathlessness. She reports that she recently flew back from a vacation in Europe and immediately noticed the discomfort. She also reports an episode of fainting and sudden onset of cough since morning. The cough occasionally has specks of blood in phlegm.  Medical History: She has a history of type 2 diabetes which is well controlled on Metformin. Her hypertension is managed by Lisinopril. She also has a past medical history of DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis) post knee replacement surgery 5 years ago for which she was anticoagulated for 6 months. There is no family history of coagulopathies.  Surgical History: For the knee replacement surgery 5 years ago aside from a few minor complications  she had an overall successful recovery.  Social History: She lives alone  still works a desk job  and used to be inactive due to her knee problems till her surgery. Post her knee replacement surgery she had joined a local gym and was quite physically active.  Review of Systems: She denies any recent injury  fever  malaise  or unintentional weight loss.   Physical Examination: Vital signs on admission include a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  a temperature of 98.6°F  and an oxygen saturation of 93% on room air.  Risk Factors: Risk factors include advanced age  obesity (BMI 32)  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  diabetes mellitus  long haul air travel  smoking  prior history of DVT  and major surgery for knee replacement.   Impression: The symptoms  history  and presentation are highly suggestive of a possible acute pulmonary embolism  which needs immediate evaluation and treatment. The presence of multiple risk factors makes this a more likely diagnosis. Further investigation such as a D-dimer test and imaging like CT Pulmonary Angiogram must be performed rapidly.

Problem Representation:  Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Female Patient with Past History of Chronic Medical Conditions  Patient Demographic Information:  - Age: 56 - Gender: Female - Race and/or ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Office worker - Lifestyle: Sedentary  occasional smoker  moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History:  - Diagnosed with obesity (BMI 30.5) - Hypertension managed with oral antihypertensive medication - History of hyperlipidemia - Chronic Venous Insufficiency. - Previous diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) 2 years ago  successfully treated. - No known allergies  Clinical Presentation:  The patient comes in to the emergency department complaining of recent onset of chest pain that is sharp and increases with deep breathing. She also mentions sudden shortness of breath  coughing up blood and unexplained lightheaded/dizziness. On physical examination  tachycardia and tachypnea are observed.  The combination of the patient’s sudden clinical presentation  history of DVT and other risk factors such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  and hypertension all raise an immediate concern for acute pulmonary embolism.  The next step in management would be to obtain a validated risk-stratification tool  such as the Wells score  to further identify the need for diagnostic workup. Imaging studies like CT pulmonary angiography  D-dimer testing and potentially an Echocardiogram or Pulmonary angiogram would be effective in confirming the diagnosis of a pulmonary embolism.  Treatment strategy will then be formulated based on risk stratification results  which in most cases may involve anticoagulation therapy along with monitoring and potentially more aggressive interventions for high-risk patients.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 66-year-old Caucasian female with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 29  presenting to the emergency department.  Presenting Complaint: The patient reports a sudden onset of severe shortness of breath and chest discomfort that started while watching television at home. The symptoms are not relieved in any particular position and have been getting progressively worse over the last few hours.  Relevant Past Medical History: The patient has a significant history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both of which are well controlled on Amlodipine and Rosuvastatin  respectively. She is also a former smoker and quit approximately 10 years ago.   Recent History: The patient recently broke her ankle 3 weeks ago and was immobilized in a cast. She stayed mostly sedentary during this time.  Family History: There is a family history of deep vein thrombosis in a sister  who is on long-term anticoagulation.   Personal History: She does not consume alcohol and lives alone. She retired from her job as a teacher 6 years ago and remains largely inactive.  Clinical Examination: On examination  she is tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths/min  oxygen saturation of 90% on room air  pulse of 110 beats/min  and a blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg. Her physical examination reveals decreased breath sounds in the right lower lung field  and her D-dimer test is significantly elevated.  Possible Conclusion based on the above findings: Given the patient's clinical picture  including her presenting symptoms  history of recent immobilization due to a broken ankle  and elevated D-dimer levels  a possible diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism is considered.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and coughing up blood. The patient's presentation is accompanied by an increased heart rate and lower extremity edema. His oxygen saturation on room air is 92%. He has a history of smoking and sedentary lifestyle; he has never been screened for hypercoagulable states. He also has a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a hip replacement surgery 5 years ago  for which he completed a six-month course of anticoagulation. He does not have a history of heart disease or lung disease.  Additional pertinent information includes a family history of pulmonary embolism and DVT  suggesting a potential genetic predisposition towards hypercoagulable states. The patient has a BMI of 27. He has not been on any regular medication since completing anticoagulation therapy  but he takes an occasional over-the-counter NSAID for arthritis pain.  Social history reveals he is a retired office worker  lives with his wife  and they have no pets. His diet is high in red meat and processed foods. He does not engage in regular exercise  usually driving to nearby locations rather than walking. He has a 40-pack year history of smoking but quit 3 years ago.  This patient's clinical presentation of sudden dyspnea  tachycardia  hypoxia  and hemoptysis  along with a past history of DVT and known risk factors for pulmonary embolism (PE)  including a sedentary lifestyle  history of smoking  and potential genetic predisposition toward hypercoagulable states suggest a high probability of acute PE.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 60-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking and sedentary lifestyle recently developed unexplained dyspnea on exertion  chest discomfort  and coughing up blood-tinged sputum. The patient has a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and hypertension  for which he is on anticoagulants and antihypertensive drugs. He denies any recent long-distance travel  surgery  or trauma. The patient's lifestyle involves prolonged hours of sitting due to a desk job  and he has a 20 pack-year smoking history. His family history includes a father who died from a stroke and an elder brother with a heart attack. The patient is not on any routine exercise program and his diet is classically Western  high in fats and processed foods.  Problem List:  1. Recent symptoms: acute onset dyspnea  chest pain  and hemoptysis. 2. Risk Factors: Age over 60  male  sedentary lifestyle  history of DVT  hypertension  anticoagulant regimen  smoking history  obese  family history of cardiovascular diseases. 3. Associated conditions: Hypertension  previous DVT. 4. Lifestyle factors: Chronic tobacco use  sedentary occupation  poor dietary habits.   Hypotheses:  This patient's presentation suggests an acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  mostly secondary to a DVT considering his past medical history and lifestyle. Given his age  history of DVT  hypertension  smoking  sedentary lifestyle  coupled with acute symptoms consistent with a PE  this diagnosis is highly plausible.   Other considerations may include pneumonia  acute coronary syndrome  and aortic dissection; however  considering the past medical history and symptomatology  these seem less likely.

His age  history of hypertension  and hyperlipidemia add to his risk profile for cardiovascular events  including PE. This patient requires immediate attention and further diagnostic investigations to confirm the suspected diagnosis.   Referral & Management: Patient should be immediately referred to Cardiology for further evaluation and management. It is essential to stabilize the patient  offer supplemental oxygen  and initiate anticoagulant therapy while arranging for diagnostic imaging like a CT pulmonary angiogram  based on current symptoms and probable diagnosis.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 56-year-old Hypertensive and Diabetic Patient  Case Report:  Patient Information:   The patient is a 56-year-old male of African American descent  currently working as a school teacher. He does not drink alcohol  smoke  or use recreational drugs. The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which are currently being managed with pharmacotherapy - lisinopril 20 mg daily for hypertension and metformin 500 mg BID for diabetes.  History of Present Illness:  The patient was admitted to the emergency department presenting with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain (typically pleuritic  worse with deep breathing)  and mild hemoptysis. These symptoms had been persisting for the last 24 hours. Upon questioning  the patient denied leg pain or swelling.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 158/92 mmHg  pulse rate was 110 bpm  respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation was 88% on ambient air  and body temperature was 37.1°C. Cardiac auscultation revealed tachycardia  but no murmur. Lung auscultation was unremarkable. There were no signs of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) on examination of lower extremities.  Investigations:  An ECG showed sinus tachycardia but was otherwise unremarkable. Lab investigations were notable for raised D-dimer levels at 0.75 μg/ml (reference range: up to 0.5 μg/ml) and slightly elevated troponin-I at 0.06 ng/ml (reference range: up to 0.03 ng/ml). Complete blood count and renal function were within normal ranges  while fasting blood glucose was slightly elevated at 149 mg/dl (normal range: 70-99 mg/dl).  Given the clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism (PE)  a CT angiography was performed which confirmed the presence of a large central clot in the right pulmonary artery.  Management and Outcome:  Hemodynamically stable but with severity criteria  the patient was admitted to the hospital's intensive care unit and started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) and bridged to long-term oral anticoagulation therapy with rivaroxaban. Patient's symptoms started to resolve within the first week of treatment  and a repeat CT angiography after a month showed resolution of the pulmonary embolus. The patient was advised to continue with his rivaroxaban and was scheduled for follow-up appointments with both the pulmonologist and the cardiologist.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for PE in patients with risk factors such as age  hypertension  and diabetes presenting with non-specific chest symptoms.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information:  Mr. J  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain. Other details about the patient: he is an ex-smoker  having stopped smoking 5 years ago after an accumulated four years of consuming one pack of cigarettes per day. He is a retired office worker and lives with his wife. His BMI is 28.0 kg/m2  does not consume alcohol and has no known allergies. In terms of the patient's family history  both his parents had coronary artery disease; his mother died at the age of 81 and his father at 78.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  which is being controlled by Lisinopril. Also  Mr. J has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and was under anticoagulation therapy with Warfarin until two years ago. He discontinued anticoagulation since he did not experience any further episodes of DVT. There is no history of diabetes  stroke  or pulmonary disease.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. J complained of sudden onset chest pain that began approximately 12 hours before admission. He described the pain as characteristic of tightness around the chest that gradually intensified. Associated with this  he reported dyspnea and palpitations but denies symptoms of fever  cough  syncope  or hemoptysis.   Clinical Findings:  On clinical assessment  his heart rate was 115 beats/minute  blood pressure was 130/88 mmHg  respiratory rate was 22 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation as measured by pulse oximetry was 91% on room air. Physical examination revealed that his chest was clear on auscultation and the rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) was conducted  demonstrating sinus tachycardia  and S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute right heart strain secondary to pulmonary embolism. Urgent computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was suggestive of a large embolus obstructing the right pulmonary artery  in coordination with clinical findings and ECG results. D-Dimer test was significantly elevated at 3 500 ng/mL (reference range <500 ng/mL).  Therapeutic Interventions: Initial management included administration of oxygen via nasal prongs. To manage the acute pulmonary embolism  he was started on anticoagulation treatment with low molecular weight heparin  enoxaparin  according to weight-based dosing. After appropriate risk assessment  systemic thrombolysis was considered but excluded due to a moderate risk of bleeding.   Follow-up and Outcomes:  Mr. J's symptoms gradually improved over the next 48 hours. He was discharged home on long-term oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban.  Patient Perspective:  Mr. J expressed concern about the recurrence of blood clot-related issues but was reassured about the efficacy of the prescribed therapy.  Informed Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this anonymous case report.   Acknowledgments: The team appreciated the cooperation and consent of Mr. J for developing this case report.

Patient Information: A 55-year-old Caucasian male  known smoker with a history of high blood pressure  presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain particularly upon breathing in  and mild dizziness. The patient is a taxi driver by profession and reports being sedentary most of the day. He has no reported allergies.  Clinical Findings: On initial assessment  the patient appeared anxious and in respiratory distress with noticeable tachypnea. Vitals revealed blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  heart rate of 105 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation at 92% on room air. Physical examination was notable for decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes bilaterally  and mild pitting edema in the ankles. There were no signs of trauma or injury.  Diagnostic Assessment: Preliminary investigations included chest X-rays that showed no obvious signs of pneumonia  pleural effusion  or pneumothorax. Electrocardiogram (EKG) indicated a possible right ventricular strain pattern with a prolonged QT segment. Lab findings showed a mildly elevated troponin I level of 0.5 ng/dL and D-dimer was notably elevated at 1 500 ug/L. Arterial blood gases (ABGs) revealed a P(a)O2 of 72 mmHg and carbon dioxide at 35 mmHg with a slight metabolic acidosis.  Given the clinical picture and these findings  an acute pulmonary embolism (PE) was suspected. Computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was performed and confirmed multiple filling defects in the segmental and subsegmental arteries of both lung lobes consistent with acute PE.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on unfractionated Heparin infusion. Oxygen therapy was given to maintain saturation above 95%. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring and stabilization  and cardiology was consulted for further management and assessment. Once stable  the patient transitioned onto oral anticoagulant (Rivaroxaban).   Follow up and Outcome: The patient showed considerable improvement over the next few days. On day 5  he was transferred out of ICU to the medicine ward. After a total of 7 days  the patient was discharged on a long-term oral anticoagulant plan. He was also given a follow-up appointment in two weeks to evaluate the effectiveness of therapy.  Teaching Points and Patient's perspective: This case highlights the importance of suspicion and immediate diagnosis of PE in individuals presenting with sudden-onset dyspnea  chest pain  and history of prolonged sedentarism. The patient's understanding of his condition was essential for appropriate management. He was informed about the importance of regular follow-ups after initiation of therapy. Advice was also provided for lifestyle modifications like avoiding smoking  increasing physical activity  monitoring blood pressure  and adhering to his anticoagulation regime.   Conclusion: Prompt recognition and appropriate management of acute PE significantly improves prognosis and reduces adverse outcomes. Long-term anticoagulation significantly reduces the risk of recurrent PE. Additionally  educating patients about their condition helps in adherence to therapy and lifestyle modifications.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 58-year-old Female with a History of Deep Vein Thrombosis and Recent Surgery: A Case Report  **Case Presentation**  The patient  a 58-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency department with the sudden onset of shortness of breath and a feeling of heaviness in the chest. She had a past medical history significant for Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) diagnosed 2 years earlier. Additionally  she recently underwent a total knee arthroplasty due to osteoarthritis three weeks prior to presentation. She is a nonsmoker and has no known history of pulmonary diseases or heart disease.  Past relevant medications include warfarin for DVT  which she stopped a week before her surgery following her doctor's advice. After the surgical procedure  she was on low-dose aspirin as VTE prophylaxis but did not receive any heparin therapy post-surgery. Her family history was remarkable  with her father having died from myocardial infarction and a half-sister diagnosed with DVT.  **Clinical Findings**  Physical examination revealed a slightly distressed patient with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute  a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  oxygen saturation at 92% on room air. Auscultation of the chest demonstrated reduced breath sounds over the right lower lobe  but no wheeze or crepitations were noted.  **Timeline**  On the initial presentation  an ECG was done which showed sinus tachycardia. A D-dimer test was positive  blood gases showed slight hypoxemia with marginally reduced PaO2 and mild respiratory alkalosis. Troponin levels were slightly elevated.  **Diagnostic Assessment**  Given her concerning symptoms  coupled with her recent surgery and history of DVT  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was performed to rule out Pulmonary Embolism (PE). The CTPA scan confirmed an acute PE with a large embolus in the right lower lobar artery. No signs of right heart strain were reported.  **Therapeutic Intervention**  The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit and started on unfractionated heparin. Given her symptoms and risk factors  a decision was made to start a therapeutic dose of anticoagulants. An inferior vena cava (IVC) filter was also considered due to a past history of DVT and recent immobility secondary to surgery.   **Follow-up and Outcomes**  With therapeutic management  the patient's symptoms gradually improved over the following week. At a one month follow-up appointment  she reported no residual breathlessness or chest discomfort. A follow-up CTPA scan was planned to evaluate the resolution of the embolus.  **Patient Perspective**  The patient expressed gratitude for the prompt diagnosis and treatment. She acknowledged the role of her past medical history in the development of the PE and reinforced her commitment to adhere to post-discharge instructions  especially lifelong anticoagulation medication.  **Conclusion**  This case emphasizes the importance of considering PE in patients presenting with sudden unexplained breathlessness  particularly those with risk factors such as history of venous thromboembolism and recent surgery. Timely diagnosis and treatment are crucial to ensure good patient outcomes.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Female with Prior Deep Vein Thrombosis   Introduction: This case report describes a 53-year-old Caucasian female  presenting with a significant symptomatology suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism (APE)  with a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Case Presentation: The patient  who works as an office clerk  is a non-smoker  and her BMI is within normal range (21.7). She had an episode of deep vein thrombosis two years ago  which was managed with an anticoagulant (warfarin) for six months. She has stopped the regular use of anticoagulant ever since the completion of the recommended course and hasn't had any recurrent DVT symptoms. She has no known history of diabetes  hypertension  or heart disease. She stated that her mother had a history of stroke at the age of 60 years.  She arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden-onset dyspnea  sharp chest pain  and light-headedness  which had started about five hours before her arrival. She also reported anxiety and had a mild cough but no fever. On examination  her blood pressure was mildly elevated at 140/90 mmHg alongside an increased heart rate at 105 bpm. Her respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was low at 90%.  Investigations: Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of right heart strain  suggestive of pulmonary embolism. Blood test revealed increased d-dimer levels. An immediate computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a clot in the right pulmonary artery  confirming the diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE). A lower limb venous Doppler ultrasound was performed  showing no signs of DVT.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for her acute pulmonary embolism and admitted to the cardiology ward. Once stabilized  her treatment was switched to oral anticoagulant therapy (warfarin). She was educated about the chronic nature of her condition and the necessity of lifelong anticoagulation. On her two weeks and then three months follow up appointments  she reported a significant improvement in her symptoms and her repeat CTPA showed resolution of the pulmonary embolus.  Conclusion: It is important to consider PE in patients with past medical history of DVT  even in the absence of current DVT symptoms. While DVT recurrence is rare  monitoring for symptoms of PE is crucial. This case highlights the significance of long-term anticoagulant therapy in high-risk patients to prevent PE recurrence.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 65-year-old Female Patient with Known Atrial Fibrillation and Obesity  Patient Information The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female with a body mass index of 31 kg/m^2  height of 165 cm  and weight of 85 kg.   Present Medical History She has been diagnosed with atrial fibrillation  obesity  and hypertension. These diagnoses were made 7 years ago. The patient also has a history of frequent long haul flights over the last year due to work commitments. She has been on 10mg Warfarin once daily for her atrial fibrillation and 5mg Amlodipine for her hypertension. Her Body Mass Index suggests that she suffers from Class 1 obesity.  Case Presentation She presented to the emergency department complaining of suddenly experiencing severe shortness of breath  sharp stabbing chest pain  and feelings of dizziness. She also reported a recent increase in the swollenness of her left lower leg  which she presumed was due to a leg strain.   Physical examination revealed that the patient was in distress  had an elevated heart rate (110 bpm)  and increased respiration rate (22 breaths per minute). Oxygen saturation was at 90% on room air. On auscultation  heart sounds were rhythmically irregular; the lungs were clear. Her left calf was swollen  tender  and warm to touch  suggesting a deep vein thrombosis.  Clinical Findings An immediate ECG revealed signs consistent with an acute right heart strain. The D-dimer test was requested and came back significantly elevated. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiogram was performed and confirmed the presence of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Due to the patient’s history of atrial fibrillation  obesity  and frequent travels that included long  uninterrupted flights  she was deemed to be at high-risk for venous thromboembolism (VTE).   Treatment The patient was started on intravenous heparin and admitted to the intensive care unit for further management. Given her acute presentation  she was also discussed for possible thrombolysis or interventional radiology pulmonary embolectomy.  Outcome and Follow-up The patient responded well to the anticoagulation therapy. At the follow-up visit 3 months later  she reported no more shortness of breath. However  she was counselled about her high risk of recurrent VTE events and the importance of adequate anticoagulation therapy  weight control  and the necessity to take walks on long flights.  In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of early recognition and initiation of treatment for pulmonary embolism  especially in patients with high-risk factors such as atrial fibrillation  obesity  and frequent long flights.   Learning Points 1. Early recognition and treatment can improve the prognosis of acute pulmonary embolism vastly. 2. Patients with high-risk factors for deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolism should be counselled on strategies to decrease their risk and educated on/kept aware of symptoms of these potential complications.

Title: An Unusual Case of Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Introduction: An interesting case of a 60-year-old African-American male patient who presented with acute pulmonary embolism is being reported. Better knowledge and understanding of the patient’s past medical history can result in an improved diagnosis.  Case Presentation:  Mr. X  a 60-year-old African-American male known to have a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  visited our emergency department with severe difficulty in breathing along with chest pain. The patient is a non-smoker and doesn’t have a family history of thromboembolic disease. He had a significant past medical history of venous DVT in the left lower leg due to a motor vehicle accident around 4 years ago. The patient had been taking warfarin regularly for his condition.  Examination and Investigations:  On examination  he had a heart rate of 92 beats per minute  blood pressure was 140/90mmHg  respiratory rate was 20 cycles per minute  and oxygen saturation was 88% on room air. During physical examination  jugular venous distention was identified. He had clear but a bit brisk lung fields  suggestive of some underlying lung pathology. An EKG confirmed tachycardia but no other significant changes.   Because of his breathlessness  persistent chest pain  and previous DVT history  we suspected a pulmonary embolism (PE). An urgent Computer Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) was ordered which revealed a large thrombus in the left main pulmonary artery confirming the diagnosis of acute PE.   Management:  The patient’s oxygen saturation was further depleting which called for immediate action. He was started on high-flow oxygen via a mask. Anticoagulation therapy was also started immediately with intravenous administration of unfractionated heparin. The patient’s warfarin dosage was adjusted considering his coagulation parameters.  Outcome and Follow-up:  His condition started to improve considerably after 48 hours. Repeat CTPA was carried out after 5 days of treatment to determine the position and size of the thrombus. Thrombus size had significantly decreased and symptoms also were reduced significantly. The patient was discharged with advice to continue warfarin and regular monitoring of his coagulation parameters. A follow-up appointment was scheduled for 8 weeks later.   Conclusions:  This case highlights the importance of recognizing acute PE in patients with a history of DVT who come in with symptoms of chest pain and breathing difficulty. Early diagnosis with relevant investigations is the cornerstone in managing such critical cases to prevent fatal outcomes.  Socio-demographic data is crucial for identifying population groups with a high risk of PE. Equipped with this knowledge  healthcare professionals can prioritize preventative measures in high-risk groups to improve patient outcomes.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with an established medical history of chronic atrial fibrillation (AF)  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension. The Patient also has a known history of smoking. He's currently on Warfarin for AF  Metformin for T2DM  and Lisinopril for hypertension. The patient was not known to have any drug allergies and lives with his wife who is primary caregiver.  Case Presentation: The patient presented to the emergency department with progressive shortness of breath  chest pain  and sudden onset left-sided pleuritic pain. The Patient was also experiencing episodes of lightheadedness with increased fatigue over the past week. There was no history of hemoptysis  fever  or travel.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient appeared in respiratory distress with respiration rate of 26 breaths per minute  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  body temperature of 37.5°C  an oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. Chest auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds on the left.   Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: An arterial blood gas (ABG) test result showed hypoxemia with a PaO2 of 65 mmHg. Complete blood count  serum electrolytes  and kidney function were within normal limits. Troponin levels were slightly elevated. Electrocardiogram revealed tachycardia with frequent atrial ectopics but no ST-T changes.   Considering the clinical presentation and examination findings  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was performed and confirmed the presence of multiple segmental pulmonary emboli in the left lung.   Therapeutic Focus and Assessment: The diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was thus made  and the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit. Parenteral anticoagulation with therapeutic Enoxaparin was initiated immediately. The dose of enoxaparin was adjusted to renal function  and he was monitored for signs and symptoms of bleeding. His existing medication of Warfarin was discontinued temporarily due to the risk of bleeding.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient responded favourably to the treatment. Over a period of several days  he showed improvement in respiratory and hemodynamic parameters. On discharge  anticoagulation was switched from Enoxaparin to Apixaban after discussing the risks and benefits of long-term oral anticoagulation. The patient was given detailed counselling on lifestyle modifications and the importance of strict adherence to the medication.   A follow-up appointment was planned in the outpatient clinic after four weeks to assess his clinical condition and adjust medication as needed.  Key Learning Points: 1. Acute Pulmonary Embolism should be highly suspected in patients with worsening respiratory status and risk factors like atrial fibrillation. 2. Prompt diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation can improve outcomes significantly. 3. Transition from parenteral to oral anticoagulation  as possible  involves careful consideration of the patient's individual risk-benefit profile.   Readers can find this case interesting since it illustrates classic approach to suspected acute pulmonary embolism  particularly in a patient with multiple comorbidities. The management highlights the lasting need for thorough follow-up care and lifestyle counseling.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-aged Male with a Significant Smoking History  Case Report:  Patient Identification: 55-year-old male  Presenting Complaint: Acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath  Medical History: Patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension and 35 pack years of smoking. He stated that he quit smoking 3 years ago  but relapsed within the past year. The patient has a sedentary lifestyle and works as a long-haul truck driver.  Family History: His mother died of myocardial infarction at age 58  and his father has a history of ischemic stroke.  Medication History: The patient has been on antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril) for the past 10 years. No other medications  including over the counter drugs and supplements  were reported.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared breathless with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min  tachycardic with a heart rate of 120 beats/min  blood pressure of 150/95 mm Hg  oxygen saturation of 90% on room air  and temperature of 98.6’F. He was alert and oriented to time  place  and person. Chest examination revealed decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest  with mild wheezing on auscultation. There was peripheral edema in the lower extremities  particularly on the right side.  Diagnostic Tests: 12-lead ECG showed sinus tachycardia. Laboratory analysis revealed elevated D-dimer levels. Chest X-Ray normal  with no evidence of aortic dissection or pneumonia. Venous dopplers of lower extremities demonstrated deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right posterior tibial vein.  Diagnosis: Based on the clinical findings  laboratory investigations  and patient's risk factors  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with intravenous heparin  and further managed with oral rivaroxaban. The patient’s chest pain and breathlessness improved over the next 48 hours. After complete investigation and stabilization  the patient was discharged with a plan for strict follow-up to monitor anticoagulation therapy.  Discussion: This case underscores the importance of detailed medical history  diagnostic suspicion  and prompt treatment in acute pulmonary embolism  especially among high-risk individuals such as smokers with sedentary professions.  Recommendations: Regular follow-ups with appropriate anticoagulation monitoring  strong recommendation for smoking cessation  lifestyle modifications including regular exercise  and consideration for long-term DVT prophylaxis due to ongoing risk factors.   Key Learning Points: 1. Smoking increases the risk of DVT and consequently pulmonary embolism. 2. Uncontrolled hypertension is a modifiable risk factor for pulmonary embolism. 3. Prompt diagnosis and initiation of anticoagulation therapy can significantly improve the prognosis in pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Patient Information:  The patient  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a habitual smoker for the past 45 years  has recently retired from a sedentary office job. The patient lives in Newcastle  England  with his wife. He reports limited physical activity and a diet high in red meats and processed food.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain- sharp and stabbing in nature  pain radiating to the left shoulder. Accompanied with these symptoms were light-headedness and a general sense of anxiety.  Past Medical and Surgical History:  The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  for which he takes Ramipril 5mg daily  and hyperlipidemia  managed with Atorvastatin 20mg daily. He also takes Aspirin 75mg daily for prophylaxis against ischemic heart disease. There was no history of any significant surgical intervention or any prior incidence of venous thromboembolism (VTE).   Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  the patient was found to be in mild distress  with rapid pulse rate (110 bpm)  slightly increased blood pressure (140/90 mmHg) and an increased respiratory rate (22 breaths/min). Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed S1Q3T3 pattern (indicative of right heart strain). Blood tests revealed increased levels of D-dimer  a common biomarker for clot degradation.  Diagnosis:  Due to the presence of risk factors (age  smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  hypertension  hyperlipidemia)  the presenting symptoms  exam findings  and relevant tests results  an acute pulmonary embolism was suspected.  Imaging:  A CT pulmonary angiogram was performed  which confirmed the presence of a large clot in the right pulmonary artery  affirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment:  The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy with intravenous heparin in the emergency department and subsequently switched to oral apixaban before hospital discharge. The patient's previous anticoagulation with Aspirin for ischemic heart disease prophylaxis was discontinued.  Outcome and Follow-Up:  The patient reported a gradual improvement of symptoms over the next few days and was discharged after 6 days in the hospital. He was advised to quit smoking  maintain a balanced diet  and start a regular program of physical activity. His progress and anticoagulation status will be evaluated during follow-up appointments in the thrombosis clinic.  Conclusion:  This case report emphasizes the significance of recognizing the risk factors and symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism. Immediate diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial to prevent fatal outcomes. It also highlights the importance of preventative measures  like smoking cessation and regular physical activity  in reducing the risk of such conditions.

Patient Profile: John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presently living in Wyoming  U.S. He is a retired engineer and an ex-smoker. He has a body mass index of 28 and leads a sedentary lifestyle. His alcohol intake is moderate  and he denies any illicit drug use.   Presenting Complaint: John presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. He reported that the chest pain was worse upon breathing  and he was experiencing light-headedness.  Medical History:  Patient has a medical history of Type II Diabetes  Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia for which he is on medication - Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin  respectively. A year ago  he underwent a total knee replacement surgery on his right knee. He had a history of smoking for about 35 years but quit 10 years ago.  Family History: Patient's father had myocardial infarction at age 60 and mother had stroke at age 75. His only sibling  a brother  is living and has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).  Present Illness:  John began experiencing slight calf pain two days before the chest discomfort and dyspnea appeared. He did not seek medical attention  attributing it to his recent intensified physical therapy sessions for his knee.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  John appeared anxious  with a respiratory rate of 23 breaths/min  heart rate of 110 beats/min  blood pressure of 135/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. His chest was clear on auscultation. Cardiac auscultation showed tachycardia with regular rhythm  and no murmurs. His right calf was swollen  red  and tender.  Diagnostic Assessment: 1) Electrocardiogram (EKG): Showed sinus tachycardia and S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of pulmonary embolism. 2) D-dimer: Elevated - 900 ng/ml (Normal: <500 ng/ml) 3) Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA): Identified a large clot in the left pulmonary artery.  Therapeutic Intervention: John was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism (PE) and started on anticoagulation therapy. He was admitted to the hospital for further monitoring and management.  Patient’s Progress: John responded well to the treatment. His chest pain and dyspnea improved considerably. Follow-up venous Doppler ultrasonography of the right leg confirmed deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The anticoagulation therapy was continued. He received education about DVT and PE and the importance of adhering to his medications.  Conclusion:  John’s sedentary lifestyle  coupled with his recent surgery  likely contributed to his DVT  which subsequently led to his PE. This case emphasizes the importance of considering PE in patients presenting with abrupt onset chest pain and dyspnea  especially when associated with risk factors such as recent surgery and personal or family history of venous thromboembolism. Timely diagnosis and management are crucial to prevent fatal consequences.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 50-year-old Caucasian Female Patient  Patient Information:  The patient is a 50-year-old Caucasian female  a non-smoker  with a body mass index (BMI) of 29. She works in a high-stress corporate role and lives a sedentary lifestyle. She has no known allergies and currently lives with her husband and two kids in suburban Chicago.    Medical History:  The patient has a medical history notable for hypertension and high cholesterol  both managed with medication for the past five years. She also underwent menopause 18 months ago. No history of respiratory diseases like asthma or COPD has been noted. She does not have a history of surgeries  malignancies  or genetic disorders.   Presenting Symptom:  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe chest pain which started an hour prior to arrival. She described it as a sudden  sharp  stabbing pain  localized in the central chest area  exacerbated by deep breathing  and not relieved by rest.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  her heart rate was 120 beats per minute  blood pressure was 160/100mmHg  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Cardiovascular examination found tachycardia but no audible murmur. Lung auscultation revealed reduced breath sounds at the right lung base with no added sounds. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment: An ECG was done immediately which showed sinus tachycardia and S1Q3T3 pattern  suggestive of right heart strain. Bloodwork revealed elevated D-dimer levels. A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was performed which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. The thrombus was observed in the right lower lobe pulmonary artery.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was initiated on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and admitted to the medical ward for further management. Close monitoring of vital signs was maintained.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  The patient reported an improvement in her symptoms within 48 hours of therapy. She was switched to oral anticoagulation therapy with rivaroxaban and released with a referral for follow-up appointments both with her primary care physician and a pulmonologist.   Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed gratitude for the hospital's swift response and expressed an intention to adjust her lifestyle to prevent a recurrence.   Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion for pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with acute chest pain  especially those with a sedentary lifestyle and other risk factors  such as hypertension and high cholesterol. Prompt diagnosis and initiation of therapy can lead to a positive outcome.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 68-year-old African-American male  retired electrical engineer  who lives on his own. He is a nonsmoker and nonalcoholic. He has no known drug allergies.   Presenting Complaint:  The patient reported to the emergency room with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain which he described as sharp and stabbing. The symptoms started suddenly an hour ago while he was reading a book at his home. No unconsciousness or blurring of vision was noted. The patient denied having a fever  cough  or palpitations.   Past Medical History:  The patient underwent total right hip replacement seven days ago. Other than this  the patient has a history of hypertension  managed with antihypertensive medication – Metoprolol 50mg daily. No previous hospitalizations for acute or chronic illnesses. No family history of cardiovascular illnesses  thrombosis  or pulmonary embolism.   Physical Examination:  His vitals at presentation included a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute (tachycardia)  a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation recorded at 88% on room air. He looked anxious. The physical examination revealed clear lung sound in all fields with no rales  ronchi or wheeze. Heart sounds were tachycardic  but no murmur was appreciated. Other systemic examination was grossly normal. The right leg was slightly swollen compared to the left  but there was no redness or tenderness.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Owing to high suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism due to recent hip replacement surgery and the clinical picture  an urgent CT pulmonary angiography was advised. D-dimer levels were markedly raised (4.2 mg/l). Electrocardiogram revealed sinus tachycardia without ST-T changes. Troponin I levels were normal.   CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism involving the left segmental branches.   Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation with IV heparin and bridged to oral rivaroxaban thereafter. High-flow oxygen was administered to maintain saturation.   The patient's symptoms dramatically improved over the next few hours. He was extensively counseled regarding the necessity and duration of the anticoagulant therapy  and was discharged on long-term anticoagulation with rivaroxaban.  Conclusion:  This case demonstrated a classical presentation of an acute pulmonary embolism following a recent surgical procedure.
