The timeliness of diagnosis and intervention were crucial to the successful outcome. This underscores the importance of rapid evaluation and management of pulmonary embolism.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 57-Year Old Female Patient  Introduction:  This case report presents a 57-year old Caucasian female patient with acute pulmonary embolism (PE). The aim of this report is to describe her clinical presentation  diagnostic procedures  treatment  and progress. It provides insights into the identification  risk factors  and management of patients with PE.  Patient Information:  The patient is a 57-year old Caucasian female  non-smoker  with a regular intake of alcohol. She is a retired teacher  residing in the urban area. She has no history of overseas travel or immobility in the past six months. Her past medical history is significant for hypertension diagnosed at the age of 45  mild obesity with BMI of 32  and varicose veins diagnosed two years ago. She has not undergone any surgical procedures.   Clinical Finding:  The patient presented to the Emergency Department (ED) complaining about sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp chest pain for the past two hours. These symptoms were associated with a feeling of palpitations and light-headedness. There was no cough  fever  or hemoptysis.  On examination  she was tachypneic and tachycardic with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute and pulse of 110 beats per minute. Oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. Her blood pressure was 148/90 mmHg  and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable except for swollen and tender left calf.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given her clinical presentation  an immediate ECG was performed which revealed sinus tachycardia but no signs of right heart strain or ischemic changes. Blood investigation results: D-dimer level was elevated (1000 ng/mL). Her troponin I level was slightly elevated (0.05 ng/mL).  Based on the clinical risk stratification (Wells Criteria)  the patient was considered high probability for PE. Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) confirmed large thrombi in the left and right pulmonary artery.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Patient was immediately treated with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Upon confirmation of PE  anticoagulation treatment was switched to oral direct-acting oral anticoagulant (DOAC) - apixaban for long term management.   Follow-up and Outcome:  The patient responded well to treatment; her shortness of breath and chest pain gradually improved over the next few days. She was discharged after 5 days of hospital stay with a prescription of apixaban and was advised for regular follow-up at the anticoagulation clinic.   Discussion:  This case exemplifies the typical presentation of acute PE in a patient with previously known risk factors such as obesity  varicose veins  and hypertension. High clinical suspicion  rapid risk stratification  and appropriate diagnostic evaluations are key steps for early diagnosis and management.   Conclusion:  PE remains a significant cause of mortality  particularly when diagnosis is delayed. This case emphasizes the importance of immediate recognition of symptoms  knowledge of risk factors  and prompt administration of anticoagulant therapy in managing patients with PE. It highlights the urgency of educating clinicians regarding rapid diagnostic approaches to improve outcomes in patients with PE.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Post-Menopausal Female: A Case Report  1. Patient Information:   The patient was a 60-year-old Caucasian female who presented to the emergency department of the hospital with acute breathlessness  chest pain  and dizziness. She has been a resident of Rochester  New York  and lives with her husband. Retired from a bank job  the patient had a sedentary lifestyle with rare physical exercises.  2. Clinical Findings:   Upon admission  her vital signs were: blood pressure  150/90 mm Hg; pulse rate  110 beats per minute; the respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute; and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia with a regular rhythm. The respiratory system examination identified decreased breath sounds in the right lower lobe of the lungs.  3. Timeline:  The patient developed symptoms 3 days prior to seeking medical assistance. Initial onset was mild but progressively worsened. She experienced a sudden worsening of symptoms on the day of presentation  leading her to seek immediate medical attention.  4. Past Medical History:   The patient had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago  was treated with anticoagulation therapy  and had no recurrence since then. She also had a diagnosed hypertension managed with a daily dose of Lisinopril for the last seven years. The patient also reported she is a former smoker  quitting 10 years prior  and had menopause at age 51.  5. Diagnostic Assessment:  Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia with S1Q3T3 pattern  raising suspicion of Pulmonary Embolism. Computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) confirmed the diagnosis with an evidence of a large saddle embolus in the main pulmonary artery. The lower limb Doppler ultrasound demonstrated thrombus in the right posterior tibial vein  indicating DVT.  6. Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH). After her condition was stabilized  she was given oral anticoagulants. In addition  other supportive treatments were provided  including oxygen therapy and intravenous fluid supplementation.  7. Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient’s clinical condition improved over five days with adequate therapy. Prior to discharge  the patient and her family were counseled about the need for regular monitoring and the importance of consistent anticoagulation therapy. Follow-up appointments in the thrombosis clinic and a visit to her primary care provider were arranged for continued  comprehensive care.  8. Patient Perspective:   The patient expressed relief over her improved health status and agreed to adhere to the medication regiment and lifestyle modifications as advised.   In conclusion  this case study emphasizes the importance of early recognition and management of acute pulmonary embolism  especially in patients with a history of DVT and other risk factors.

Case Report:  Title: A Case Report of Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 62-year-old Female Patient with a History of Obesity  Smoking  and Hypertension  Introduction:   Pulmonary embolism is a serious  distressing condition typically arising from a deep vein thrombosis. This is a detailed report on a 62-year-old female patient presenting with acute pulmonary embolism.  Patient Information:  The patient  Mrs A  is a 62-year-old Caucasian female with a known history of obesity  hypertension  and a 40-year smoking habit. She is a retired factory worker  weight recorded at 105 kg  and height 155 cm  resident from a suburban area. There is no known family history of thromboembolic disorders. She is living with her husband and has two grown-up children.   Clinical Findings:  Mrs A presented to the emergency department with sudden  sharp  severe chest pain radiating to her upper right arm  dyspnea  and a sense of impending doom. She had no cough  hemoptysis  or fever. Upon examination  she was found to be tachycardic (HR 115 bpm)  tachypneic (RR 27 breaths per minute)  and hypotensive (BP 85/55 mmHg). Oxygen saturation on room air was found to be 88%. Auscultation revealed decreased breath sound on the right lower zone.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An ECG showed sinus tachycardia and S1Q3T3 (a nonspecific finding in pulmonary embolism). Lab tests showed elevated D-dimer levels. A CT Pulmonary Angiography identified large emboli in both pulmonary arteries with a greater burden on the right side  confirming the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Anticoagulation therapy with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) was promptly initiated while considering thrombolytic therapy.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Aside from the initial hypotension which was managed with crystalloids  the patient remained hemodynamically stable throughout her hospital stay and subsequently did not require thrombolysis. Over the following five days of her hospital stay  her symptoms resolved  and she was discharged on long-term oral anticoagulant therapy with Direct Oral Anticoagulant (DOAC).  Patient Perspective:  The patient was alarmed by the sudden onset of her symptoms but was grateful for the fast response of the healthcare team. She was appreciative of the information provided regarding her condition and management.   Conclusion:   This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and prompt management of acute pulmonary embolism  which led to a favorable prognosis in a patient at high risk due to her obesity  smoking history  and hypertension.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 57-year-old Male with Hypertensions: A Case Report  Synopsis:  This report describes the clinical scenario of a 57-year-old Caucasian male who was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism. The patient has a medical history of hypertension and was a former habitual smoker with a smoking history of 20 years.  Patient Description:  Mr. X  a 57-year-old Caucasian male  from Austin  Texas  presented to the Emergency department with a one-day history of severe breathlessness  sharp chest pain  and coughing up blood. He additionally experienced episodes of lightheadedness and rapid heart rates. His medical history revealed that he had been managing well-controlled hypertension for the past ten years. He had no history of surgeries or allergies  but he smoked cigarettes for about 20 years before quitting five years ago. He reported no illicit drug use or alcoholism.  Clinical Features and Investigation:  On examination  his blood pressure was 150/95 mmHg  and his heart rate was 110 beats per minute. His oxygen saturation was low  and he was dyspneic at rest with a respiratory rate of 24 per minute. Clinical examination revealed clinical signs of deep-vein thrombosis  including leg edema and tenderness over the left calf.   The electrocardiogram (EKG) showed tachycardia with a right bundle branch block  and arterial blood gases revealed hypoxemia with a slight respiratory alkalosis. A high resolution computed tomography (HRCT) scan of the chest was performed  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism  showing substantial radiolucencies in the right pulmonary artery  suggestive of a pulmonary embolism. In addition  a Doppler ultrasound of the lower limbs revealed deep vein thrombosis in the left leg's superficial femoral vein.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was then managed with immediate anticoagulation therapy consisting of heparin  followed by oral warfarin. Over the course of hospitalization  his dyspnea and chest pain gradually improved  and his vital signs gradually returned to near-normal levels. After a hospital stay of 5 days  the patient was discharged on long-term oral anticoagulation therapy.   The patient was also advised to attend regular follow-ups with the cardiology and respiratory team  avoid prolonged immobility  and continue with his antihypertensive medication. His hypertension has been managed with an ACE inhibitor and diuretic  and his BP level remained controlled during his admission.   This case emphasizes the life-threatening risks of pulmonary embolism in hypertensive patients  particularly in those with a history of smoking. It also underscores the importance of early recognition and effective management of high-risk patients.  Conclusion:  This case throws light on the risk factors and the association of pulmonary embolism with hypertension  emphasizing the importance of regular follow-up and commitment to antihypertensive treatment.  Keywords: Pulmonary embolism  Hypertension  Smoking  Case Report.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 62-year-old Caucasian male   Patient Information: A 62-year-old Caucasian male patient  known to be hypertensive and diabetic under medication  was admitted to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and dizziness. The patient was a heavy smoker with a history of 40+ pack-years and was obese (BMI of 31 kg/m²).  Clinical Findings:  The patient demonstrated tachycardia  tachypnea  and low blood oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 80% upon presentation. He also complained of right-sided chest pain  progressive dyspnea  dizziness  and palpitations that started a couple of hours prior to admission.  Diagnostic Assessment: An Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed sinus tachycardia with right-axis deviation and ST-T segment changes suggestive of right ventricular strain. The D-Dimer level was elevated at 1500 ng/mL  a troponin T test indicated an above-normal level of 0.2 ng/L  and arterial blood gas showed hypoxia and mild respiratory alkalosis. Chest radiography demonstrated a normal cardiothoracic ratio with increased bronchovascular markings. A computerized tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) confirmed the presence of a large clot in the right pulmonary artery extending to its branches.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately given supplementary oxygen through a mask and initiated on intravenous unfractionated heparin coupled with oral anticoagulants. As the symptoms were severe and the patient was hemodynamically unstable  the decision was made to proceed with catheter-directed thrombolysis to dissolve the clot.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Post-procedure  the patient demonstrated significant improvement with a resolution of symptoms. Follow-up CTPA scan showed substantial clot lysis and improved blood flow. The patient was discharged with lifelong oral anticoagulants and advised for strict control over his blood pressure  sugar levels  weight  and to stop smoking.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed his relief over the successful treatment but was worried about the underlying diseases that led to such a serious condition. The importance of lifestyle changes and medication adherence was emphasized.  Informed Consent:  Patient's informed consent was obtained for the treatments pursued and for the publication of this case report.  This case report underlines the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment of acute pulmonary embolism in patients with underlying risk factors. It also emphasizes the need for robust preventive strategies  including lifestyle modifications and optimal control of underlying conditions  in patients at risk of Pulmonary Embolism.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 62-Year-Old Female  Demographics: Patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian female  non-smoker  known to be a moderate drinker  weighing around 68 kg and with a height of 152 cm. She lives with her husband in a suburban area and is retired. She used to work as a teacher for over 30 years. She has a son and two grandchildren and she is always actively involved in their upbringing. She does not have any pets.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  varicose veins  and hypothyroidism. She reports adherence to prescribed medications which include an ACE inhibitor for hypertension  a statin for hypercholesterolemia  and levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. She also reports taking over-the-counter pain relievers on occasion for arthritic pain. There is no history suggestive of diabetes mellitus  tuberculosis  or malignancies. She underwent a hysterectomy 20 years ago due to fibroids.   Family history reveals that her father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at the age of 60  while her mother passed away at the age of 70 due to a stroke. Her only sibling  a brother  is currently witnessing cardiovascular issues. She is not aware of any genetic or inherited disorders in the family.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain which started at rest  she describes the pain as a ""sharp"" and ""stabbing"" feeling on the left side of her chest which worsens on deep inhalation. She is also experiencing generalized weakness  fatigue  and light-headedness. She denies abdominal pain  palpitations  fever  and cough.   On physical examination  her blood pressure was 148/92 mmHg  pulse rate was 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 22 breaths per minute  and SpO2 was 92% while breathing room air. Auscultation of the chest revealed decreased breath sounds in the left lower lobe. She also has pitting edema in her left leg.  Preliminary Diagnosis and Course of Treatment: Considering her symptoms  past medical history  and physical examination  the patient presented a picture of acute pulmonary embolism. She was admitted for further diagnostic tests which confirmed the initial diagnosis. She was treated with anticoagulant therapy  specifically the administration of intravenous heparin followed by oral warfarin. She responded well to the therapy and was discharged after a week. She was advised to avoid prolonged periods of immobility and was prescribed compression stockings to help decrease the risk of future thromboembolic events.   This case illustrates the importance of considering pulmonary embolism in the differential diagnosis of patients presenting with unexplained dyspnea  especially among individuals with risk factors for deep vein thrombosis such as long periods of immobility  understanding of varicose veins and other venous disorders  and a family history of cardio-vascular problems.

Report Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Female with A Hypercoagulable State  Patient Information:  1. Demographics: Female patient  aged 55 years  Caucasian  married  non-smoker  no alcohol consumption with a BMI of 28 kg/m2. Works as a software engineer and has a sedentary lifestyle.  2. Past Medical History: The patient has a history of oral contraceptive use  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a pelvic surgery eight years ago  and Factor V Leiden mutation which leads to a hypercoagulable state.  Primary Presenting Complaint: Sudden-onset dyspnea with chest discomfort  History of Present Illness: The patient was in her usual state of health until two days prior to complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath associated with chest discomfort that worsened upon deep inspiration.  Examination: On examination  vital signs were notable for tachycardia (Heart rate - 110 bpm) and a respiratory rate of 24/minute. The rest of her physical examination  including lung auscultation  was unremarkable.   Investigations:   1. The D-dimer level was raised at 900 ng/ml (Ref range: 0 - 500 ng/ml). 2. A computerized tomography (CT) pulmonary angiography showed filling defects consistent with acute bilateral pulmonary embolism. 3. Lower extremity venous Doppler ultrasound revealed a deep vein thrombosis in the left lower extremity.  Treatment:  The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) followed by oral anticoagulation with warfarin. After initial stabilization  she was admitted for further monitoring and treatment.  Outcome:   The patient demonstrated significant clinical improvement over the next few days and was subsequently discharged on warfarin  with strict instructions on maintaining compliance to her medication. An appointment for follow-up and monitoring of her INR was arranged.  Learning Points:  This case emphasizes the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting with sudden unexplained dyspnea. It also underscores the significant role of inherited thrombophilias like Factor V Leiden mutation in the risk stratification of thromboembolic diseases  especially in patients with a known history of venous thromboembolism. Early recognition and proper management may prevent potential life-threatening complications associated with acute pulmonary embolism.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Post-Menopausal Female: A Case Report.  Patient Information:   Mrs. X  a 65-year-old Caucasian female presented to the Emergency Department (ED) having experienced acute onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and light-headedness. She is a resident of New York  NY and is retired. She is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings:   The patient reported chest pain that was increasing in intensity  especially on inspiration  and shortness of breath  which started approximately two hours before presentation. The pain was described as sudden  sharp  and constant. Additionally  she complained of feeling light-headed and dizzy intermittently.  Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  both managed with oral medications. She underwent menopause ten years ago  but did not opt for Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT). She also underwent right hip replacement surgery three weeks ago. She has been relatively healthy otherwise. Her family history revealed a premature coronary artery disease in her father.   Physical Examination:   On physical examination  the patient was anxious and diaphoretic  with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths/minute  blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 BPM and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. The chest examination revealed no wheezing  but decreased breath sounds in the right lower zone. Her heart sounds were regular without any audible murmur. Lower extremities were negative for edema  erythema  or tenderness.  Differential Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical presentation  the differential diagnoses included acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  acute myocardial infarction  and pneumothorax.  Investigations and Treatment:  An emergent contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest revealed a large filling defect consistent with acute pulmonary embolism. Lab tests showed slightly elevated D-dimer levels and Troponin levels were within normal limits.   The patient was immediately initiated on intravenous (IV) heparin and supplemental oxygen therapy. Following a consultation with a Pulmonologist  she was started on oral anticoagulant rivaroxaban.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient was admitted to the ICU for close observation and monitoring. Over the next few days  her chest pain and dyspnea gradually improved  and she was successfully weaned off from the oxygen support. She was instructed on the importance of regular follow-up visits and medication compliance before discharge. Shortly after discharge  she was referred for a consultation with a Hematologist to rule out a possible underlying coagulopathy.  Learning Points:  This case underscores the importance of considering acute PE in post-menopausal females presenting with chest pain and shortness of breath  especially with a recent history of surgery  even in the absence of obvious signs of deep vein thrombosis. Early recognition and prompt treatment is crucial to ensure a favorable outcome.

Title: A Case Report of Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 58-Year-Old Female with Previous History of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Presentation and Demographics:  A 58-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department with the chief complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and a mild anxiety. The patient was overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 31  non-smoker  and her alcohol intake was within recommended limits. She lives in rural Colorado and works as a school teacher.  Past Medical History:  The patient's medical history was significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus (well-controlled)  and hypothyroidism. She also had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) approximately six years ago  managed with anticoagulation therapy. After undergoing a routine hysterectomy  the patient was detected with DVT but did not exhibit any signs of pulmonary embolism (PE) at that time. She adhered to a six-month course of Warfarin post DVT detection but was not kept on long-term anticoagulation.  Clinical Findings:  Upon arrival  her vitals were as follows: blood pressure 155/95 mmHg  heart rate 120 bpm  respiratory rate 28 breaths per minute  temperature 98.4°F (36.9°C)  and hypoxia with oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. The physical examination was noteworthy for tachypnea  tachycardia  mildly distended neck veins  decreased breath sounds on the right lower lung zone  and a right calf that was slightly swollen and tender to the touch.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An urgent electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia and S1Q3T3 pattern  suggesting PE. Subsequently  D-dimer levels were significantly elevated. A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the presence of an acute PE  with an embolus lodged in the right lower lobe pulmonary artery. Duplex venous ultrasound of the right lower extremity revealed a new DVT in the right calf's superficial femoral vein.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on therapeutic doses of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Oxygen was administered through a nasal cannula to correct hypoxia. Her symptoms improved with treatment  and anticoagulation therapy was bridged to Warfarin for long-term use.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient showed significant symptomatic improvement over the next 48 hours. She was discharged on Warfarin and instructed to follow-up with a pulmonologist and a hematologist for further evaluation of thrombophilia and management of anticoagulation.  Patient Perspective:  The patient reported that she was unaware of her heightened risk for PE due to her history of DVT. She expressed gratitude for the quality of care she received and indicated a commitment to adhering to her long-term anticoagulation regimen.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for this case report.  Conclusions and Significance:  The presence of DVT history in a patient presenting symptoms like dyspnea and chest discomfort should raise the possibility of PE. This case underscores the importance of considering PE in the differential diagnosis  especially in patients with a previous history of DVT. Early diagnosis  prompt anticoagulation treatment  and multidisciplinary approach in managing such patients can prevent potential complications and improve outcomes.

Patient Information   We report a case of Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African American male  resident of Chicago  United States.  Clinical findings  Mr. Johnson complained of abrupt onset of dyspnea with pleuritic chest pain  cough  and he was orthopneic. His resting oxygen saturation measured by pulse oximeter was 92%. Upon physical examination  he was found to be tachycardic and tachypneic with increased use of accessory muscles of respiration.   Medical  Family  and Psychosocial History   Mr. Johnson's past medical history includes well-controlled hypertension  type II diabetes  and mild Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). He has a 45-pack-year history of smoking but had quit 10 years back. No significant family history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism was found. Mr. Johnson is a retired engineer  lives with his wife and has a healthy  active lifestyle despite his medical conditions.  Clinical Differential Diagnosis   Considering his dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain  and hypoxia  the spectrum of differentials included acute coronary syndrome  pneumothorax  pneumonia  and pulmonary embolism.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment   Diagnostically  lab results showed an elevation of D-Dimer. A computed tomography (CT) angiography scan of the chest revealed a filling defect in the left main  left lower  and right middle lobe pulmonary artery branches  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia with a S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of Cor pulmonale. Additionally  lower extremity Doppler ultrasound was negative for deep vein thrombosis.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment   Treatment was promptly started on anticoagulation with intravenous Unfractionated Heparin as the first line. Additionally  supplemental oxygen was provided. Soon after he was evaluated by Hematology for starting long-term anticoagulation  he was switched to oral anticoagulation with Apixaban.   Follow-up and Outcomes   He was enrolled in a pulmonary rehabilitation program and given training for coping strategies to manage his dyspnea. He responded well to the treatment  with noted improvement in his symptoms over the following days. His oxygen saturation also improved to 96% on room air. He was then discharged with instructions for follow-up with a Hematologist and a Pulmonologist.  Patient Perspective  Mr. Johnson was grateful for the prompt diagnosis and management of his condition. He was keen to follow a strict medical regimen and adapt his lifestyle to prevent any future events.  Informed Consent   Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publishing this case report.    The case highlights the importance of considering pulmonary embolism as an integral part of the differential diagnosis in patients presenting with dyspnea  especially in the presence of risk factors like long-term smoking  hypertension  and COPD.

Patient Information:  A 58-year-old African American female with a weight of 85 kg and height of 1.67 m  an employee in a corporate firm  was brought to the emergency department (ED) citing sudden onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and fainting.  Clinical Findings:  The patient reported she was mid-conversation when she experienced an abrupt onset of right-sided chest pain and became rapidly short of breath. She fainted shortly afterwards. The pain was described as sharp  chest-constricting  8/10 in intensity  radiating to the right shoulder with associated nausea and diaphoresis.  Past Medical History:  The patient previously had two uncomplicated pregnancies and deliveries. She has been treated for high cholesterol and hypertension for a decade  both of which are well-controlled through medication. She also has a history of smoking (20 pack years) and occasional alcohol intake. There is no history of thromboembolic diseases  surgeries  trauma  or recent extensive travels.  Physical Exam:  On examination  the patient was noted to be alert but distressed with pain. She was tachypneic at 24 breaths/min  tachycardic with a heart rate of 101 beats per minute  blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. Pupils were equal and responsive. Lung fields had diminished breath sounds in the right lower field. Cardiovascular examination revealed a regular rhythm. There was no lower limb swelling or tenderness noted.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Lab results showed elevated D-dimer levels at 0.60 mg/L (reference value < 0.5 mg/L)  troponin I was slightly elevated at 0.05 (reference value < 0.03 ng/mL)  and the arterial blood gas showed hypoxemia with PaO2 at 72 mmHg. Electrocardiogram (EKG) demonstrated sinus tachycardia without S1Q3T3 pattern. A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was immediately carried out  which showed a thrombus in the right pulmonary artery  confirming a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on low-molecular-weight heparin (Enoxaparin 1 mg/kg) subcutaneously as briding therapy and oral anticoagulants (Xarelto 15 mg twice/day) were initiated. Symptomatic treatment for acute chest pain was also administered. Oxygen support was provided to correct the hypoxemia.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient's hospital course was uneventful with progressive improvement of symptoms over five days. Upon discharge  she was advised to continue oral anticoagulants and follow-up with the outpatient department for regular INR checks. Moreover  the patient was instructed about the importance of compliance with medications and regular follow-ups  and counseled about necessary lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation.  Lessons Learnt:  This case underlines the importance of considering pulmonary embolism in the differential diagnosis when a patient presents with sudden chest pain  shortness of breath  and syncope  especially in those with risk factors such as prolonged periods of immobility  hypertension  smoking  and high cholesterol. Failure to diagnose and treat in a timely manner can lead to serious complications.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 63-year-old Male with Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Demographics Information: Mr. A is a 63-year-old Caucasian male  married  retired  originally from Dartmouth  Nova Scotia  residing in Montreal  Quebec. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is calculated to be 28.9  indicating overweight. His diet is high in refined carbohydrates and fats. He reports a sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: Mr. A was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years prior and has been taking Amlodipine 10mg daily to manage his blood pressure. Additionally  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago and is currently on Metformin 500mg twice a day. He is regularly followed up by his primary physician for these chronic illnesses. Besides these  his past medical history is unremarkable with no history of either heart disease or stroke.  Present Illness: Mr. A presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness that developed suddenly while he was at home resting. The chest pain was described as a sharp  stabbing pain  worsened with deep breathing. He had febrile episodes for the previous two days prior to the onset of these symptoms  but no cough or sputum production.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  Mr. A appeared distressed  sweat-beaded  and cyanotic. His blood pressure was 150/90  heart rate was 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 26 breaths per min  and oxygen saturation measured by pulse oximeter was 90%. On chest auscultation  there were decreased breath sounds on the right.  Investigations and Diagnosis: The findings from an electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of right heart strain. A D-dimer test was positive. A subsequent computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the presence of a large embolus in the right pulmonary artery - hence confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Management: Mr. A was immediately admitted to the Intensive Care Unit and administered oxygen therapy. Anticoagulation therapy was initiated with intravenous heparin  and after 24 hours  the therapeutic response was attained  he was bridged to oral anticoagulant (Warfarin). His oxygen saturation and respiratory symptoms improved gradually over several days.  Comment: This case highlights the importance of timely diagnosis and management in acute conditions like pulmonary embolism  especially in patients with risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and a sedentary lifestyle.   Future Steps: A detailed account of his management  right from anticoagulation therapy to lifestyle modification  will be pertinent. Prompt follow-up investigations and appointments are scheduled with both his primary care physician and a pulmonologist to ensure the stabilization of his condition and prevent potential complications.  This case aims to create awareness about the often-overlooked severity of acute pulmonary embolism and the importance of prompt and aggressive management to ensure positive clinical outcomes.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 65-year-old Male with Chronic Atrial Fibrillation: A Case Report  Introduction:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department with sudden-onset dyspnea  chest pain  and fainting. Previous medical history included chronic atrial fibrillation  for which he had been on anticoagulation therapy (warfarin) for the past five years. He also had a past medical history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus.  Case Presentation:  Mr. Doe reported experiencing a sudden sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsened with deep breathing. He also reported episodes of hemoptysis and palpitations. His vitals on presentation were: Blood pressure 105/70 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 88% on room air  and temperature 98.6°F. On physical examination  he appeared anxious with cold and clammy skin.  Investigations:  Blood tests revealed elevated D-dimer levels. His chest x-ray was generally unremarkable  while an electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of right heart strain and atrial fibrillation. Computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiogram showed a large clot in the left pulmonary artery suggestive of a pulmonary embolism.   His INR was noted to be intherapeutic (1.9) upon examination. He also reported poor medication adherence due to the complexity of his medication regimen and frequent INR monitoring.   Management:  The patient was immediately started on full-dose unfractionated heparin and his oxygen was titrated to keep the oxygen saturation above 94%. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) due to the size of the embolism and potential risk for hemodynamic instability. After stabilization and further consultation with cardiology  the decision was made to switch Mr. Doe's anticoagulant therapy to direct oral anticoagulants (DOAC) to improve medication adherence.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Mr. Doe’s hospital course was complicated by transient acute kidney injury  likely due to hemodynamic changes associated with the acute pulmonary embolism. However  this resolved with intravenous fluids and he was clinically stable by day four. He was transitioned from heparin to apixaban before discharge  with a follow-up appointment arranged with his primary care physician and cardiology.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates the potential for severe pulmonary embolism even in patients on anticoagulant therapy  particularly when issues with medication adherence arise. Early recognition and rapid initiation of treatment for acute pulmonary embolism saved the life of this patient. It also emphasizes the importance of educating patients about the significance of medication adherence  potential complications of non-adherence  and the life-threatening risks associated with co-existing atrial fibrillation.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 65-year-old Male with a History of Deep Vein Thrombosis: A Case Report  Introduction:  Pulmonary embolism (PE) is a lethal condition originating from deep vein thrombosis (DVT). This condition typically presents with symptoms such as shortness of breath  chest pain  and sudden onset cough. This case report highlights the case of a 65-year-old male diagnosed with PE with a previous history of DVT.  Case Presentation: A 65-year-old African-American male presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain. The patient reported experiencing an abrupt onset of these symptoms while watching television at home. Upon examination  the patient appeared anxious  pale  and diaphoretic with vital signs showing a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22/min  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air.   The patient's medical history revealed a recent hospitalization four weeks prior due to DVT in the right lower limb. The patient had been discharged with a course of oral anticoagulants  which he admitted to not taking regularly. He had a 10-year history of hypertension and a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He quit smoking 10 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. Family history was positive for venous thromboembolism (VTE).   Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram (EKG) showed signs of right ventricular strain  which increased the suspicion of a PE. Blood work revealed elevated D-dimer levels and the patient’s arterial blood gas (ABG) showed decreased partial pressure of oxygen. A computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was performed  confirming a large thrombus in the right main pulmonary artery.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately treated with oxygen therapy and intravenous heparin. With a confirmed diagnosis of PE  thrombolytic therapy was given. The importance of adherence to anticoagulant therapy was reiterated to the patient.  Outcome and Follow-up: The patient’s symptoms improved dramatically over the subsequent 48 hours  and repeat CTPA after four days showed significant decrease in the size of the pulmonary emboli. The patient was discharged with NOAC therapy ought to be continued for at least three months  and regular outpatient follow-up appointments were arranged.  Conclusion: This case highlights the fatal risk of non-adherence to anticoagulant therapy in patients with a history of DVT. Further  it underlines the importance of immediate recognition and treatment of PE to prevent serious consequences.    Keywords: pulmonary embolism; deep vein thrombosis; non-adherence; anticoagulation; thrombolysis.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in Postmenopausal Woman with Obesity and Recent Total Knee Replacement Surgery  Case Report:  Patient Information: A 63-year-old African American woman presented to the emergency department (ED) with acute onset of breathlessness and chest pain. She has lived through the menopause and is classified as obese with a BMI of 32 kg/m2. Her past medical history includes hypertension controlled with amlodipine  osteoarthritis  and type II diabetes managed with metformin.  Recent Medical History: Four weeks prior to her ED presentation  she had an uncomplicated total knee replacement on her right knee due to severe osteoarthritis. She was kept on a prophylactic regimen of low-molecular-weight heparin for two weeks post-operatively.  Clinical Findings: On examination  she was visibly distressed  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute  and had an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air  which improved to 94% on 3 liters/minute supplemental nasal oxygen. Her blood pressure was stable at 136/82 mmHg; however  her pulse rate was elevated at 102 beats per minute. Upon chest auscultation  breath sounds were found to be normal. Lower limb examination showed no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Diagnosis: Laboratory investigations revealed elevated D-dimer levels at 1.2 mg/L (normal range <0.5 mg/L). The electrocardiogram demonstrated sinus tachycardia; however  other specific signs  such as S1Q3T3 pattern or T wave inversion  were absent. Given her symptoms and elevation of D-dimer  a CT pulmonary angiography was performed  which confirmed the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism with a clot located in the distal right pulmonary artery.  Treatment: She was administered intravenous unfractionated heparin in the ED and subsequently started on oral rivaroxaban.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Her symptoms improved gradually  with complete resolution of chest pain and breathlessness within a week. On a follow-up visit after two weeks  she was doing well without any recurrent symptoms. The rivaroxaban therapy was planned to be continued for at least six months  and lifestyle modification counseling was provided for weight loss  which might prevent future thrombotic episodes.  Discussion: Postoperative patients  especially those undergoing total joint arthroplasty  are at an increased risk for developing venous thromboembolism  encompassing deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. In this case  the patient's obesity and recent surgery significantly contributed to her risk. This case underscores the importance of risk stratification  appropriate prophylaxis  and early detection of pulmonary embolism in the postoperative period.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department in May 2021  with chief complaints of worsening chest discomfort and shortness of breath that started about a day ago. He had no noted fever  cough  or symptoms suggestive of infection. The patient lives in rural Georgia with his wife  in a smoking-free environment  though he had a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years which he quit ten years ago. He was a truck driver by profession  now retired. The patient consumes alcohol occasionally and denied illicit drug use.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history is significant for ischemic heart disease with a coronary artery bypass graft surgery performed 5 years ago  controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus (on metformin)  hypertension (on lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide)  and hyperlipidemia (on atorvastatin). The patient disclosed that he had been non-compliant with his medications over the past two weeks due to financial issues.  Family history sufficient for coronary artery disease in his father and brother. No reported history of venous thromboembolism in the family.  Clinical Findings: At presentation  the patient was visibly in distress with labored breathing. Vital signs showed a blood pressure of 142/88mmHg  heart rate of 110bpm  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Physical examination revealed crackles at the right lung base on auscultation. No swelling or signs of deep vein thrombosis were noted on both legs.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given the patient’s condition and medical history  Acute Pulmonary Embolism was suspected. Electrocardiography (EKG) showed sinus tachycardia with no acute ischemic changes. Initial labs demonstrated elevated d-dimer. A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the diagnosis revealing a large filling defect consistent with a clot in the right main pulmonary artery.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient received intravenous heparin on arrival and upon diagnoses confirmation  therapeutic anticoagulation was started with dalteparin. Patient's hemodynamics improved and managed to maintain a good oxygen saturation level (above 95%) on 2L/min nasal cannula.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: The patient spent 5 days in the hospital and was discharged home on oral apixaban. He was also educated about the importance of adherence to his regular medications. The patient was advised to have routine follow-ups and engage in regular physical activities. He was also counseled on the importance of adequate hydration  particularly on long trips.  Patient's Perspective: The patient was relieved after his condition improved and was thankful for the care and support he received from the healthcare team. He understands the seriousness of his condition and is committed to making lifestyle modifications and medication compliance.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Postmenopausal Female with a Prior History of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction: This is a case report of a 67-year-old Caucasian female who presented with acute pulmonary embolism (PE). She had a medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and a known family history of thromboembolic disorders.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: A 67-year-old Caucasian female presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and fainting episodes. She reported having a similar episode five years ago  diagnosed as deep vein thrombosis.  Clinical Findings: At presentation  the patient was tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute  and saturation was 90% on room air. On physical examination  she was found to be anxious  with cyanosis of lips and nail beds. Her blood pressure was 155/90 mmHg  and heart rate was 114 beats per minute. The chest examination revealed decreased breath sounds on the right lower side  and the cardiovascular examination was normal.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Her blood investigations showed a slightly elevated white blood cell count  D-dimer level was elevated at 4.5mg/L. An electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia. Doppler ultrasound of both lower limbs showed evidence of DVT in the left leg. Computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) demonstrated a large thrombus in the right main pulmonary artery extending into the lower lobar arteries on both sides  confirming the diagnosis of PE.  Therapeutic and Follow-up: Therapeutic intervention commenced immediately with low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) subcutaneously until an INR of 2.0 was achieved with oral warfarin  in line with standard therapy for acute PE. The patient showed gradual improvement in her symptoms within 72 hours of starting therapy  and her vitals were stable. She has been advised for a thorough follow-up.  Discussion:  Acute PE is a life-threatening condition when not diagnosed and treated promptly. This case was an example of how a patient's risk profile and history of DVT led to an early suspicion  prompt diagnosis  and successful management of acute PE.  Patient Perspective: ""I was scared by the sudden chest pain and faintness but relieved when I was told what was happening. I am glad to be alive after this frightful experience. I know it's important to keep up with my medication and check-ups to prevent this from happening again. Having survived this  I am committed to regular follow-up and medication compliance.""  This case underscores the importance of considering a diagnosis of PE in patients presenting with unexplained dyspnea  especially in those with a previous history of DVT.   Informed Consent: The patient provided consent to share her clinical details for the purpose of this case report.   Conclusion:  Risk stratification  early diagnosis  and prompt anticoagulation therapy were critical for the successful management of PE in this case. This report emphasizes the importance of recognizing PE in patients with risk factors and history of venous thromboembolism.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-aged Female Patient with a History of Sedentary Lifestyle and Obesity: A Case Report   Introduction: Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE) is a severe and potentially life-threatening condition caused by a blockage in one of the pulmonary arteries in the lungs. This case report concerns a female patient who developed APE  and her clinical journey.  Patient Information: The patient is a 52-year-old African American woman dwelling in an urban area. She is unmarried with no children and works from home as a freelance writer. She has a history of sedentary lifestyle  obesity characterized with Body Mass Index (BMI) of 35 kg/m2  and heavy smoking (20 cigarettes per day) for over 25 years. She has no known allergies. The patient's mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis and stroke. She lives alone  does not partake in regular physical activities  and has a moderate to high consumption of fatty  cholesterol-rich foods.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency department with acute onset of palpitations  chest pain that was intensifying during deep breathing  and shortness of breath. She reported dizziness and mild frequent cough over the past 1 week. Examination revealed an anxious patient with tachycardia (115 bpm)  tachypnea (22 breaths per minute)  blood pressure of 140/85 mm Hg  and oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 89% on room air.  Diagnostic Assessment: Initial ECG showed sinus tachycardia with S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute cor pulmonale. D-Dimer assay was found to be positive. A CT pulmonary angiography was done which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient received immediate anticoagulant therapy with intravenous unfractionated heparin which was then overlapped and transitioned to oral anticoagulant (Rivaroxaban). She was closely monitored in the critical care unit for possible complications.  Outcome: The patient showed improvement after initiation of treatment with a decrease in tachycardia  relief from chest pain and improved SpO2 levels. The patient was discharged on lifelong Rivaroxaban with advice to quit smoking  increase physical activities and follow dietary modifications. She was advised to follow up in the outpatient department and with her primary care physician for a regular check-up and dosage adjustment if required.  Conclusion: This case highlights the need for a high degree of clinical suspicion for diagnosing APE. Lifestyle modifications like quitting smoking  adopting an active lifestyle  and healthy dietary practices  are as important in preventing such life-threatening diseases as is the medical intervention. Additionally  the practitioner’s insight into family history also stands imperative in conditions such as these to possibly prevent adverse outcomes.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 57-year-old Female: A Case Report  Introduction  Pulmonary embolism (PE) is a common  often severe disease  with a clinical presentation that can be highly variable. Early diagnosis and prompt intervention can significantly decrease morbidity and mortality.  Patient Information:  Our patient is a 57-year-old Caucasian female  resident of San Francisco  diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism. Patient lives alone and is currently unemployed; her family history includes a brother with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). She is a former smoker  admitting a history of 20 pack-years. She did not report any past exposures to harmful substances or travel in recent past.   Medical History:  She has a medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  for which she was medicated with Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively. No known drug allergies were reported.  Clinical Findings:  The patient initially presented to the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain which worsened during deep inspiration and fatigue. Upon further examination  her vital signs were found to be unstable with tachycardia (110 bpm)  low blood oxyhemoglobin saturation (88%) on room air  and slightly raised blood pressure (145/95 mm Hg). She reported no prior overt symptoms.  Diagnostic Tests:  Her initial EKG showed signs of right ventricular strain characterized by a S1Q3T3 pattern. The D-dimer test was positive. Following this  a CT pulmonary angiogram was performed which confirmed the presence of large  bilateral proximal PE.   Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy with intravenous (IV) unfractionated heparin under the acute PE suspicion  which was then switched to oral apixaban after PE confirmation. Oxygen support was given to improve her oxygen saturation levels.   Patient Progress and Outcome:  Over the course of her hospital stay  the patient showed progressive improvement in symptoms with a drop in heart rate and normalization of oxygen saturation levels. Follow-up planned for outpatient continuation of apixaban  repeat imaging to assess PE resolution and thrombophilia workup considering her family history of DVT.  Conclusions:  This case underscores the importance of prompt evaluation and aggressive management of acute PE to offset the high morbidity and mortality associated with this condition. Clinical suspicion and early diagnostic intervention are vital when treating patients with potential PE. Regular follow-ups are necessary for these patients to monitor their status and prevent potential recurrences.   Learning Points:  - In patients presenting with sudden dyspnea  tachycardia and chest pain  PE should be a differential diagnosis. - Immediate diagnostic tests and prompt treatment initiation are crucial in managing acute PE. - Ongoing aftercare for such patients plays a critical role in preventing potential recurrences and other complications.

Patient Details: Name- [Confidential] Age/Sex - 54-year-old female Ethnicity - Caucasian  Presenting Complaints: A 54 year old Caucasian female with a BMI of 29 presented to the emergency department with acute onset of the following symptoms: shortness of breath  chest pain that exacerbated when breathing deeply  light-headedness  and tachycardia.  Past Medical History: The patient had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) six years back secondary to extensive travel history. She was successfully treated with anticoagulants for six months and since has been off medications. She also had a documented case of varicose veins  controlled hypertension  and osteoarthritis. The patient currently maintains a sedentary lifestyle and often gives a history of extended airplane travel due to her work commitments.  In terms of family history  patient’s mother had hypertension and died of myocardial infarction at the age of 69  and the father died of cerebral stroke at the age of 72. She has two elder brothers; one suffers from diabetes  and the other from congestive heart failure.  Presenting Condition: The patient's vitals upon presentation were: blood pressure of 128/84 mmHg  heart rate of 105 beats per minute  respiration rate of 20 per minute  temperature of 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. The physical examination did not reveal any significant abnormalities.  Investigations: Blood tests revealed an elevated D-dimer level  which is often indicative of a blood clot. Chest radiography was inconclusive. However  based on clinical signs and symptoms  patient's medical history  and post initial investigation reports  immediate computed tomography (CT) pulmonary angiography was performed that confirmed the presence of acute pulmonary embolism.   Treatment and Follow-Up: The patient was promptly initiated on low molecular weight heparin as a bridge to warfarin for prolonged anticoagulation. After 5 days of overlap  when her INR reached the therapeutic range of 2-3  intravenous heparin was discontinued.  The patient was discharged with instructions to maintain the same treatment dose and return for follow-up in two weeks or earlier  depending on any worsening symptoms or side effects from the medication. She was strongly advised to avoid long periods of immobility  stay well-hydrated  and start a gradual walking program  eventually leading to moderate aerobic activity. She was also advised to wear compression stockings for her varicose veins when travelling.  Current Situation: The patient is responding well to the anticoagulant therapy. The shortness of breath has improved significantly and no new complaints have been registered. The patient is planned for a reassessment in two months with a fresh set of tests  revised INR values  and symptoms check.  This case underscores the necessity of a high degree of clinical suspicion for pulmonary embolism in any patient with sudden unexplained dyspnea  chest pain  or hemoptysis. Early diagnosis is crucial for prompt initiation of anticoagulant therapy  which can significantly reduce the mortality rates associated with this condition.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Morbidly Obese Female with Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus Type 2  Patient Information:  A 65-year-old Caucasian woman came to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that worsens during deep breath  coughing up blood  and rapid heart rate.  Demographic Details:  Patient is from a suburban area  known pack-a-day smoker for the past 40 years  leads a sedentary lifestyle  and has Body Mass Index (BMI) of 42 indicating morbid obesity. The patient's sociodemographic status includes a retired school teacher living with her daughter and grandchildren.  Medical History:  The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 for the past ten years. The patient's hypertension has been relatively controlled with medication (losartan). Her recent HbA1c level is 7.5  indicating her diabetes is not well managed despite medication (metformin). She does not report any known allergies.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  the patient presents tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation level of 90% on room air. Heart rate was recorded as 110 beats per minute  blood pressure measured at 140/85 mmHg. She also exhibited signs of right ventricular strain. Pulmonary auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds in the right lower lung field.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute cor pulmonale. D-dimer test was markedly elevated. A CT Pulmonary Angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of a large acute pulmonary embolism in the right main pulmonary artery extending into the right lower lobar artery.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin (enoxaparin) and oral anticoagulant (apixaban) was added to the regimen.   Follow-Up and Outcomes: Patient's oxygen saturation levels improved over the subsequent days and the chest pain and respiratory distress diminished. The patient was educated regarding the importance of medication adherence  control over her obesity  diabetes  better hypertension management  cessation of smoking  and the need for a healthier lifestyle.  Patient Perspective:  Patient expressed concern over her life-threatening condition. She expressed motivation to modify her lifestyle habits dramatically  including quitting smoking  adopting a healthier diet regimen  and including regular exercise in her routine.  Takeaway message:  This case underscores the importance of recognizing the critical signs and risk factors associated with acute pulmonary embolism in patients  especially in those with multiple comorbid conditions like obesity  hypertension  and diabetes  and a history of long-term smoking. Early recognition and appropriate treatment can drastically improve the prognosis in such cases.   Contributors:  Dr. Y  emergency medicine; Dr. X  radiology; Dr. Z  cardiology.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Demographic Information: Patient Identifier: M.S. Age: 54 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: Asian-American Occupation: Office worker (sedentary job) Living Situation: Lives alone  Presenting Issue: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) experiencing sudden shortness of breath  chest pain  and a feeling of anxiety  most notably for 24 hours prior to admission. The pain was sharp  located in the mid-sternal region  and described as ""stabbing"" in nature. It intensified with deep inspiration. The patient also described experiencing episodes of dizziness and occasional bouts of mild coughing.  Medical History: The patient has a known medical history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both controlled with regular medication (Metformin and Losartan respectively). The patient had experienced no allergies or drug interactions before the current episode. He is a former smoker with a history of 25-pack years  having quit ten years ago. There is no known family history of clotting disorders.  On Presentation: On observation  the patient appears anxious  with noticeable pallor. He was slightly tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/minute and exhibited a pulse oximetry reading of 93% on room air. On auscultation  the lungs showed diminished breath sounds. His blood pressure was elevated (143/92 mm Hg) but his heart rate was within normal limits. However  a 12-lead EKG suggested nonspecific ST changes but no clear signs of right heart strain.  Diagnosis and Management: Given the patient’s presentation and medical history  an immediate D-Dimer test was ordered  which came back significantly elevated. A subsequent CT scan with pulmonary angiography revealed a large clot burden in the bifurcation of the main pulmonary artery  indicating an acute pulmonary embolism.  The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for close monitoring and initiated on anticoagulation therapy with intravenous heparin. After initial stabilization  the patient was switched to oral anticoagulants. The patient was also given supplemental oxygen to maintain his saturation above 95%  and his chest pain was managed with analgesics.  The patient was advised regarding lifestyle modification considering his sedentary occupation. He was also advised to continue the anticoagulants  strictly maintain control of his hypertension and diabetes  and prevent dehydration to reduce the risk of clot formation.  Outcome:  The patient’s breathlessness and chest pain progressively relieved after initiating treatment. His condition remained stable during his hospital stay  and he was deemed stable enough for discharge on the fifth day post-admission. He has been scheduled for regular follow-ups with his primary care physician for close monitoring.  Discussion: This case reiterates the mystery that is pulmonary embolism  often presenting with nonspecific symptoms that may be misinterpreted or overlooked entirely. Prompt attention to the symptoms and immediate tests like D-Dimer test in the ED can aid in the timely diagnosis and management of this potentially life-threatening condition. Regular follow-up and optimal management of comorbid conditions are essential to prevent recurrence.

Title: Acute Pulinary Embolism in a 68-Year-Old Male Patient with a History of Prostate Cancer and Hypertension   Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain. He reported progressive worsening of these symptoms throughout the day.  Medical History: The patient has a known medical history of prostate cancer  which was diagnosed eight years ago and managed with radiation therapy and androgen deprivation therapy. He also has hypertension controlled with a regimen of angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. He had no history of surgeries or allergies. He neither smokes nor drinks alcohol. He was an office worker before retirement.   Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient exhibited tachycardia  noted at a rate of 110 beats per minute  and tachypnea  with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. He was afebrile but his oxygen saturation was low at 88% on room air. The patient also expressed pain in the chest that grew worse upon deep breathing. His blood pressure was marginally high at 150/90 mm Hg.  Diagnostic Assessment: With suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism based on clinical symptoms  computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was immediately conducted. The results confirmed a large embolus located in the right main pulmonary artery extending into the lower lobar branches.   Laboratory findings included elevated D-dimer levels and Troponin-I levels suggestive of a possible myocardial injury  which is not uncommon in cases of severe pulmonary embolism. Complete blood count  renal function  liver function test  and coagulation profile were essentially within normal limits.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on systemic thrombolysis using tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) due to the extensive nature of the clot. Additionally  he was kept on oxygen supplementation via nasal cannula and anticoagulation therapy with heparin was initiated.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient reported an alleviation in his symptoms within 24 hours. Repeat imaging performed one week later showed substantial resolution of the embolus. The patient was subsequently transitioned to oral anticoagulation therapy with warfarin and he was referred to a pulmonary rehabilitation program.   Patient Perspective: Though frightened by the sudden onset of his symptoms  the patient was relieved with the rapid diagnosis and treatment. He expressed gratitude for the team's quick response and thorough care.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Conclusion: This case highlights the significance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in a patient presenting with chest pain and breathlessness  especially in those with risk factors like malignancy and hypertension. Immediate imaging and initiation of thrombolytic therapy can bring about swift resolution and prevent complications.

Patient Information:  Mr. T  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired teacher  presented to the emergency department of our hospital with complaints of sudden onset of dyspnea  chest pain  and light-headedness. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 25.3 kg/m2.  History:  Mr. T reported that his chest pain was sharp  constant  and exacerbated by deep breathing. He also complained of a sudden onset of shortness of breath  palpitations  and light-headedness. He denied any symptoms of fever  cough  sputum production  hemoptysis  or night sweats. His past medical history was notable for hypertension  intermittent atrial fibrillation (AF)  and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following orthopedic surgery 3 years ago. He is currently taking antihypertensive medication and anticoagulation.   Clinical Findings:  On initial examination  he was anxious  diaphoretic  wheezing  and in noticeable distress. He had a blood pressure of 95/60 mmHg  tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. On cardiovascular examination  there was a prominent P2 component of the second heart sound. The rest of the physical examination was within normal limits.  Diagnostic Focus  Assessment  and Treatment:  An ECG showed sinus tachycardia and S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute cor pulmonale. His blood tests revealed elevated D-dimer levels. A contrast-enhanced CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  indicating a clot located in the right main pulmonary artery extending into the lower lobe branches.   He was immediately begun on high flow oxygen and therapeutic anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) followed by oral anticoagulation therapy. In light of his AF and previous DVT  the decision was made for long-term anticoagulation.  Mr. T was admitted to the hospital for close observation and stabilization. He tolerated the treatment well without any complication. He was educated about his condition  the importance of medication adherence  and regular follow-ups.   Conclusion:  Mr. T was discharged after 5 days when his symptoms were significantly improved  and he remained stable. He was scheduled for a follow-up visit with a pulmonologist for further assessment and management. His case emphasizes the critical importance of maintaining a high suspicion for PE  particularly in patients with a history of thromboembolic events such as DVT and AF  despite being on anticoagulation therapy.   This case report highlights the need for an early diagnosis and promptly initiated anticoagulation treatment in patients presenting with an acute PE  as they may otherwise face a potentially fatal outcome. The situation calls for further studies about the management of patients with recurrent PE despite being on anticoagulant therapy.

Title: A Case Report of Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 65-year-old Male  Abstract: This case report describes the presentation  diagnosis  and management of a 65-year-old male with acute pulmonary embolism. Despite underlying comorbidities  including a history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and obesity  the patient was able to make a full recovery following a timely diagnosis and treatment.  Patient Information: The patient was a 65-year-old Caucasian male who had been previously diagnosed with hypertension  type II diabetes  and obesity. He was on medication for hypertension (lisinopril) and diabetes (metformin). The patient was a retired truck driver  had a history of smoking but quit 5 years ago  and had a sedentary lifestyle.  Medical History: His past medical history included a myocardial infarction at the age of 55  several episodes of unexplained syncope  and lower leg edema. These comorbidities placed the patient at an elevated risk for the formation of clots  leading to pulmonary embolism.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset dyspnea  palpitations  and pleuritic chest pain that started two hours before presentation. He also reported feeling light-headedness but had no loss of consciousness.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient was anxious  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute  tachycardiac (heart rate 110 bpm)  and hypotensive (blood pressure 90/60 mmHg). S1 and S2 were regular without any added sounds. Chest examination revealed reduced breath sounds in the right lower zone.  Diagnostic Assessment: A set of routine laboratory tests was performed. Arterial blood gases showed hypoxemia with a PaO2 of 64 mmHg. The D-dimer test was significantly elevated at 2000 ng/mL (normal 0-500 ng/mL). Electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia and S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism. The diagnosis was confirmed with a CT pulmonary angiogram  which showed multiple thrombi in the right lower lobe vessel.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on oxygen therapy immediately to correct hypoxemia and was throttled on heparin with a target aPTT of 60-80 seconds. After hemodynamic improvement  oral anticoagulants were started  and heparin was overlapped for 5 days then discontinued.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient's symptoms improved over two weeks  with reduction in breathlessness and hypoxia. Follow-up at 3 weeks showed the patient had returned to his normal daily activities without any symptoms. The patient was continued on anticoagulants  and regular monitoring was advised given his preexisting comorbidities.  Conclusion: This case offers insight into early recognition  diagnostic strategy  and the management of acute pulmonary embolism even in patients with underlying comorbidities. It highlights the importance of awareness of this fatal condition and the requirement for immediate interventions to improve patient outcomes.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-aged Male  Patient Profile: Mr. John Smith  a 56-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with sudden-onset chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient  who resides in Boise  Idaho  is a lifelong non-smoker and moderate consumer of alcohol. His weight and height measurements are within the normal range for his age and gender.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia  and he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention five years ago due to coronary artery disease. He has been on a regimen of aspirin  a beta-blocker  and a statin since that time. He has no known drug allergies. His family history is remarkable for cardiovascular disease. He had his last complete physical checkup three months ago  and the patient was recommended to increase his physical activity and adjust his diet to manage his cholesterol levels.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reported sudden severe chest pain and difficulty breathing that began while he was at rest. He described the chest pain as a sharp and constant pain located in the middle of his chest. The pain increased with deep breaths. He also experienced a sudden onset of dyspnea  light-headedness  and palpitations.  Examination Findings: On arrival  his blood pressure was 158/96 mmHg  heart rate was 115 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 90% while breathing room air. The patient was anxious but alert and oriented.  Diagnostic Evaluation: Electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia with right bundle branch block and the laboratory studies showed an elevated troponin level. The patient's D-dimer levels were also found to be significantly elevated. A computed tomographic pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was performed which confirmed the presence of a large clot obstructing the pulmonary artery.  Treatment and Progress: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism. Anticoagulation was initiated immediately with intravenous heparin and oral warfarin as per guidelines. The patient was monitored closely for signs of hemodynamic instability. Over the next few days  his symptoms improved greatly and he was transitioned to a continuing oral anticoagulation regimen.   As the patient had a significant clot burden and risk factors for further clots  it was decided to keep him on lifelong anticoagulation. The patient was counseled about the importance of regular follow-ups to monitor his INR and potential signs of recurrent pulmonary embolism.  Conclusions: This case highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion in older patients with sudden-onset dyspnea and chest pain. Prompt evaluation and initiation of anticoagulation therapy in cases of proven pulmonary embolism can reduce morbidity and mortality.  Physicians should be aware of aging patients' potential risk factors for pulmonary embolism  including history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension  and sedentary lifestyle  to ensure the condition is promptly recognized and treated.  Keywords: Pulmonary Embolism  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  Chest pain  Dyspnea  Case report.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 65-year-old Male  I. Patient Information  Mr. X is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired  and a former smoker. He resides with his wife and enjoys a semi-active lifestyle. He has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He is a non-alcoholic and follows a balanced diet. He does not have any known history of cardiac problems or blood clot disorders.  II. Chief Complaint  Mr. X presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe breathlessness  mild chest pain  and light-headedness that started a few hours before arrival.  III. History of Present Illness  Mr. X was in his usual state of health until earlier in the evening when he abruptly felt severely short of breath while watching television at home. The breathlessness was associated with a mild central chest discomfort and a sense of light-headedness. There was no cough  fever  or recent travel history.   IV. Physical Examination  Upon examination  Mr. X was obviously dyspneic with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure was 125/85 mmHg  and oxygen saturation was 90% on room air. Chest examination revealed decreased breath sounds on the right side.   V. Diagnostic Assessment  A D-Dimer assay was promptly done and came back significantly elevated. Electrocardiogram (ECG) exhibited tachycardia with S1Q3T3 pattern suggesting acute right heart strain.   Subsequently  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was performed which revealed a large thrombus obstruction in the right pulmonary artery extending into its lower lobar branches  confirming a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE).   VI. Therapeutic Intervention  Initial resuscitation with oxygen  fluids  and anticoagulation was started immediately with intravenous unfractionated heparin. The patient was admitted to the ICU for careful monitoring. Given the significant clot burden and initial hemodynamic instability  the decision was made to perform catheter-directed thrombolysis.  VII. Follow Up and Outcome  Mr. X's condition improved markedly over the subsequent 72 hours. His breathlessness  chest pain  and hypoxia resolved.
