He was switched from unfractionated heparin to oral anticoagulant  Rivaroxaban. A repeat echocardiogram after a week showed near normalization of the right ventricle size and function. He was discharged with close outpatient follow-up planned.  In conclusion  this case illustrates the acute presentation and management of pulmonary embolism. This is of clinical significance as acute PE is a potentially lethal condition and demands immediate medical attention and intervention. It also emphasizes the high level of clinical suspicion one should maintain while encountering older adults with new-onset breathlessness and chest discomfort.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information:  Mr. A is a 65-year-old African-American male  retired engineer  living with his wife in a suburban neighborhood.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath that began approximately 3 hours prior to arrival. He described the pain as sharp  constant  and worsening when taking deep breaths.  Medical History:  Past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  all of which are controlled well with medication. He quit smoking 10 years ago after a 30-year history of consistent smoking. He denied any history of cardiac disease  asthma  COPD  or other pulmonary conditions. He had no known allergies and took Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin as his regular medications.  Examination:  On examination  he was found to be anxious  diaphoretic and in apparent distress. His vital signs on admission were; blood pressure 165/95 mmHg  pulse rate 98 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 93% on room air. His chest examination revealed decreased breath sounds on the right lower side.  Investigations:  ECG showed sinus tachycardia  no S1Q3T3 pattern was evident. Lab investigations revealed an elevated D-Dimer. The patient was then subjected to a Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA)  which confirmed a clot in the right pulmonary artery - consistent with a diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Management:  The patient was swiftly initiated on therapeutic enoxaparin and supplementary oxygen. He was subsequently started on oral anticoagulation with Rivaroxaban. The patient remained in the hospital for 5 days before he was discharged home in a stable condition with instructions for follow-up care.   Outcome:  Patient showed improvements in symptoms after beginning treatment and his blood oxygen levels steadily increased. His follow up with a pulmonologist and an internist was arranged before discharge.  Learning Points:  This case highlights the importance of early detection and prompt treatment of acute PE  which can be life-threatening. This patient had numerous risk factors including age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and a previous history of smoking. His presentation with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath further highlighted the need for urgent investigation and definitive management.

Patient Information  Initials: J.K.  Gender: Female Age: 64  Race: Asian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Chief Complaint  Shortness of breath  fainting episodes  chest pain.  Present Illness  The patient arrived at the emergency department experiencing severe shortness of breath  dizziness  two fainting episodes  and chest pain during deep inspiration for the past 3 days.   Past Medical History  The patient has a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) two years ago  which was treated with anticoagulation. She reported that she stopped her anticoagulant medication 4 months ago due to recurring episodes of bleeding gums and nosebleeds. She has a history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. The patient had a cholecystectomy 14 years ago. She is non-smoker and drank alcohol occasionally.  Clinical Findings  On physical examination  the patient was conscious but appeared anxious and diaphoretic. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg  pulse rate at 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate at 26 breaths per minute and an oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. The lung auscultation demonstrated tachypnea but no other abnormalities. Lower extremity examination revealed no evidence of deep venous thrombosis. Cardiovascular examination showed tachycardia  normal heart sounds and no murmur.  Diagnostic Assessment  An electrocardiogram displayed sinus tachycardia with a right bundle branch block. A D-Dimer test was positive. A computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the presence of large emboli in the right main pulmonary artery and left lower lobe arteries. The patient's laboratory results showed slight thrombocytopenia and mildly elevated levels of Troponin I  which could suggest right ventricle strain.  Therapeutic intervention  As the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was confirmed  the patient started on therapeutic anticoagulation immediately with intravenous (IV) unfractionated Heparin. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring due to her hemodynamic instability.  Follow-up and outcome  The patient's fainting episodes and dizziness resolved  and her symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath improved significantly after 72 hours of treatment. A repeated CTA showed considerable resolution of pulmonary emboli. The patient was switched to oral anticoagulation (Warfarin) on discharge  with careful bleed risk assessment and close monitoring of INR levels.   Patient education was reinforced about the importance of compliance with her anticoagulant therapy and regular follow-up. She was advised to come in immediately if any signs of bleeding  recurrence of her symptoms  or new health issues arise.  Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients with a history of deep vein thrombosis who present with chest pain and shortness of breath. Patient education about medication compliance is crucial especially in the management of these cases to prevent potentially fatal recurrences.

Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the hospital presenting symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism (PE). He is a resident of Florida  USA and a retired engineer. He lives with his wife and has no children.   Patient Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for the past ten years (stage 2  moderate severity as per the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease classification). He also has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) diagnosed one year ago. He had been adhering to the recommended anticoagulant therapy until his current admission.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient was brought to the emergency department with complaints of a sudden onset of shortness of breath experienced for a period of two hours. He also reported accompanying chest discomfort  mild hemoptysis (coughing up of blood)  and palpitations.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient was anxious and in respiratory distress with oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. His heart rate was 110 beats per minute and blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg. On auscultation of the chest  decreased breath sounds and crackles were observed in the right lower lung field.  Investigations:  An immediate ECG showed sinus tachycardia. A computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was performed which confirmed a large embolus in the right pulmonary artery. His D-dimer levels were especially high  which often indicates the presence of a clot. Due to his recent DVT and current symptoms  a Doppler ultrasound exam of his lower limb veins is also performed which revealed a thrombus in his left femoral-popliteal vein. This suggests the source of the PE.   Management and Outcome:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous heparin as a bridge to warfarin. Anticoagulant therapy was continued as the main treatment for his condition. The patient's shortness of breath improved significantly over the next few hours  and he was clinically stable within 48 hours. After five days of hospitalization  the patient was discharged and instructed to continue his long-term oral anticoagulant therapy at home.  Follow-up Care:  Mr. Smith was advised to follow-up every two weeks to monitor his INR (International Normalized Ratio). Moreover  he and his wife were counseled about the importance of adherence to medication and to lookout for signs of abnormal bleeding or recurrences of PE or DVT.  Discussion:  This case emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and management of PE  particularly in patients with a history of DVT. Clinicians should ensure their patients with history of DVT understand the importance of long-term anticoagulant therapy and need to manage associated complications promptly. Follow-up care  to monitor medication compliance and any possible recurrence or complications  is also crucial in these patients.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information  Mr. D is a 73-year-old Caucasian male  retired  married with three children  and resides in New York City. His past medical history is significant for well-controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes but has no known allergies.  Presenting Complaint  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain of approximately 3-hour duration. The symptoms started at rest and were associated with fainting episodes. The intensity of the chest pain was described as 8/10 and substernal  not radiating  not related to physical activity  emotional stress  meal times  or during sleep or rest.   Examination Findings  On examination  the patient was anxious  profusely sweating  and appeared dyspneic. Vital signs were a pulse of 120 beats per minute  blood pressure of 140 over 90 mm Hg  and a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute. The peripheries were cold and clammy. The rest of the physical examination  including the cardiovascular system examination  was unremarkable.   Investigations and Imaging   Routine blood tests along with the D-dimer test were ordered. An immediate EKG was normal with no signs of ischemia. Lab results showed elevated D-dimer levels  a confirmation for the presence of a clot in the blood  though the routine blood parameters were within normal limits. A CT pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was performed due to the high suspicion of a pulmonary embolism  which revealed a clot in the right pulmonary artery.   Diagnosis  Based on clinical presentation  examination  elevated D-dimer levels  and findings on CTPA  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made.   Treatment  The patient was immediately anticoagulated with a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Subsequently  he was started on oral anticoagulants.   Outcome   The patient's clinical condition improved significantly within a few days of starting the treatment. He was eventually discharged and provided with information on the importance of taking his medication regularly  safety precautions in daily life  signs and symtoms of bleeding to look for  and when to seek immediate medical help.  Follow-up  A review appointment was made on discharge  for one month later  with instructions to return to emergency immediately if experiencing any concerning symptoms.   The patient was also advised to seek a consultation for possible causes of his pulmonary embolism  including an assessment for possible cancer and for pro-thrombotic conditions considering his age and the absence of any other risk factors for thrombosis.  This case underlines the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with unexplained shortness of breath and chest pain. Early diagnosis and immediate treatment are vital in reducing the morbidity and mortality associated with this condition.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Previously Healthy 48-Year-Old Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 48-year-old Caucasian male  height 178 cms  weight 95 kg  a resident of New York  working as a software engineer. He is a non-smoker  who drinks alcohol occasionally with no known drug use or allergies. He has no significant family history of any chronic diseases or genetic disorders. His past medical history is unremarkable other than periodic episodes of digestive discomfort associated with periods of work stress.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with symptoms of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and mild dizziness that had started two hours prior. He also identified an episode of fainting at work which prompted him to seek immediate medical attention.  Clinical Findings: Upon arrival  he was anxious and dyspneic with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute. Temperatures were 98.6°F. His pulse 102 beats /min and blood pressure 130/80mmHg. Auscultation revealed distant breath sounds and tachycardia  no added sounds were noted.  Diagnostic Assessment: An urgent Electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrated signs of right ventricular strain with sinus tachycardia. D-dimer levels were elevated. A computer imaging chest scan showed a filling defect in the right lower lobar pulmonary artery consistent with acute pulmonary embolism. Complete blood count  liver  and renal function tests were within normal limits.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was treated with therapeutic doses of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and supplemental oxygen immediately. After stabilization  he was considered fit for thrombolysis  and tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA) was administered. The improvement in symptoms was immediate and substantial.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient was monitored in the hospital for the next five days  on anticoagulants and an optimization regime for clot prevention. Follow-up CT scan showed resolution of pulmonary embolism. Due to the absence of any significant past medical history and risk factors  the cause of his pulmonary embolism remained idiopathic.  Patient Perspective: The patient recognized the swift diagnosis and treatment regimen. He appreciated the detailed information provided by the medical team regarding his condition  treatment and recovery plan. He consented to adapt lifestyle changes  to maintain optimal health  and minimize future risks.  Lessons Learned : Acute pulmonary embolism can present in patients without significant risk factors. Efficacious treatment and recognizing early signs and symptoms can result in substantial symptom relief and recovery. Public health awareness about the condition and its medical emergencies can save many lives.

Case Report - Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Patient Information: - Demographics: 57-year-old Caucasian male - Occupation: Booking agent (sedentary work) - Non-smoker  moderate alcohol intake  no known drug usage - BMI: 29 (Overweight) - Family History: Father died from a myocardial infarction in his early 60s; mother has a history of stroke and lives in assisted living due to physical disability.    Presenting Complaint:  - The patient presented to our emergency department reporting abrupt onset of severe  sharp pain in the chest radiating to the back and exacerbated by deep breathing. He mentioned he has been experiencing shortness of breath and an unexplained sense of palpitation for two days.    Medical History:  - Hypertension  diagnosed seven years ago and under control with Losartan. - Two episodes of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  last episode two years ago - No known allergies - No regular exercise regimen.   Clinical Evaluation: - Vital signs: Blood pressure: 145/85 mm Hg  Heart rate: 105 beats/min  Respiratory rate: 24 breaths/min  O2 saturation:90% on room air. - Physical examination: The patient was anxious. The chest examination revealed tachypnea and shallow breathing  with no audible wheezes  crackles  or rhonchi. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia but no additional heart sounds or murmurs.   Diagnostic Testing:  - D-dimer test was positive.  - A CT pulmonary angiogram showed a large clot burden in both pulmonary arteries  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.   - Electrocardiogram revealed sinus rhythm with a rate of 105 beats/min and signs of right ventricular strain (S1Q3T3 pattern). - Basic laboratory test  including full blood count and renal function test  were within normal limits.  Treatment: - The patient was immediately started on intravenous heparin. - Thrombolysis was not performed due to previous history of DVT and current stable hemodynamic state. - The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring and treatment.  Outcome and Follow-up: - The patient's condition improved symptomatically over the next few days under uninterrupted anticoagulation. - The patient was discharged on long-term anticoagulant therapy (Rivaroxaban) to prevent recurrence.   The case adds to the substantial body of evidence detailing the increased risk of pulmonary embolism in patients with a history of DVT  particularly those with additional risk factors such non-regular exercising  sedentary occupation  and hypertension. It also highlights the importance of vigilance in patients presenting with symptoms suggestive of pulmonary embolism  given the potential for life-threatening complications.

Patient Description:  Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  with a BMI of 27.1  a lifetime non-smoker  former military serviceman  currently retired  presented at the emergency department with acute breathlessness and chest pain.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient complained of a sudden sharp  stabbing chest pain that started a few hours prior and was intensified by deep breathing. He also reported mild coughing and shortness of breath  but had no signs of fever  hemoptysis  or syncope. Although the patient appeared anxious  his vitals at presentation showed slight tachycardia (heart rate at 110 beats per minute)  normal temperature  and normal blood pressure (143/87 mmHg).  Past Medical History:  The patient had a medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left calf ten years ago  which was managed successfully with anticoagulants. He also has a 3-year history of high blood pressure and is currently on antihypertensive medication  which is well-controlled. The patient underwent left knee arthroscopy 8 days ago. His mother died from a sudden stroke at the age of 72  possibly pointing to a genetic predisposition in the family.  Clinical Findings:  Electrocardiography (ECG) revealed tachycardia with no significant ST changes  and chest radiography showed no distinctive pulmonary abnormalities or pneumonic consolidation. A blood test showed a highly elevated D-dimer level.  Diagnosis:  Based on the patient's symptoms  medical history  and clinical findings  he was suspected of acute pulmonary embolism (PE). A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was immediately performed and confirmed the presence of acute bilateral pulmonary embolisms.  Management:  Given the patient’s medical history of DVT and recent orthopedic surgery  he was considered a high-risk PE patient and was therefore admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring and treatment. Intravenous heparin was initiated as a bridging therapy  and the patient was then switched to oral rivaroxaban for long-term anticoagulation.  Outcome:  The patient's symptoms significantly improved after heparin infusion  and he remained hemodynamically stable throughout his ICU stay. After 4 days  he was transferred to a general ward and discharged home on the 7th day after initiation of anticoagulation therapy with outpatient follow-up appointments.  This case reflects the critical aspect of early diagnosis and treatment of acute pulmonary embolism  taking into consideration the patient's past history  presentation  and risk factors and utilizing appropriate diagnostic imaging. It also emphasizes the importance of recognizing the potential risk of PE in post-operative patients  even after minor surgeries.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Postmenopausal Female with History of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Introduction:  This case report describes a 62-year-old African American postmenopausal female who presented with shortness of breath  followed by an acute episode of syncope  leading to the discovery of a large pulmonary embolism (PE).   Case Description:  A 62-year-old postmenopausal African American female presented to the emergency department with a 24-hour history of progressively worsening shortness of breath and an episode of syncope while at home.   The patient had several known risk factors for venous thromboembolism (VTE)  including a sedentary lifestyle  obesity (BMI of 32.5)  previous history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago  and an ongoing hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for hot flashes symptoms. She had denied any recent fractures  surgical interventions  or long-duration travel activities in the recent past.  On current admission  the physical parameters showed a blood pressure of 102/68 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. The physical exam revealed decreased breath sounds bilaterally with mild tachypnea. Cardiac exam showed tachycardia with a regular rhythm but no murmur  gallops or rubs. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia and nonspecific ST-segment and T-wave abnormalities. Laboratory investigations revealed a high serum d-dimer value (1200 ng/mL) suggestive of thrombosis. Arterial blood gases (ABGs) showed evidence of respiratory alkalosis with hypoxemia.  Due to high clinical suspicion  a spiral CT scan was performed  which revealed a large thrombus occupying the right main pulmonary artery extending into its lower branches  confirming the diagnosis of PE.   Management & Follow-Up:  The patient was immediately anticoagulated with unfractionated heparin and admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring. Given her DVT history  hormone replacement therapy has been discontinued. The PE was deemed sufficiently massive to warrant a thrombolytic therapy  which was done successfully with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA). The patient was subsequently transitioned to oral anticoagulation with Warfarin.  Her hospital course was also complicated by a hemodynamically significant right ventricular strain and with the initiation of treatment the hypoxia and tachycardia improved progressively. She was discharged on the seventh day  with follow-up appointments set with pulmonology and hematology for management of pulmonary embolism and evaluation for possible thrombophilia given her recurrent VTE events. Counseling on the risks of HRT  the promotion of physical activity and a healthier diet for weight control were also provided before discharge.   Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of high clinical suspicion and rapid initiation of treatment for PE  particularly in high-risk patients such as postmenopausal women on HRT with a previous history of DVT. It also highlights the necessity for thorough patient education about the risks of prescribed therapies and lifestyle modifications.  Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.

Patient Details File Number: EF13490 Name: John Doe Gender: Male Age: 67 years Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired Military Officer Residence: New York  NY Marital Status: Married  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented with sudden onset breathlessness and chest pain.  Medical History: Mr. Doe is a Type 2 diabetic and hypertensive patient under medication for the past ten years. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) in 2016 with no residual neurological deficits. His surgeries include an appendectomy at age 25 and cataract surgery in 2018. His lipid profile was historically borderline but has been under control with statins. He is a non-smoker and leads a moderately active lifestyle.   Review Of Systems: On examination  the patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic. He was tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute while at rest. Oxygen saturation on room air was 93%. The cardiovascular examination showed tachycardia at a rate of 110 beats/minute with regular rhythm and no murmur. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: The patient’s EKG showed sinus tachycardia. An emergent CTA of the chest confirmed an acute pulmonary embolism involving the right main pulmonary artery extending into the right lower lobar branches.  Treatment: The patient was admitted to the ICU and anticoagulation was started immediately with therapeutic low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH). After stabilizing the patient  bridging was done to warfarin. He was educated about the role of regular INR checks and was discharged five days later once it was within the therapeutic range.  Follow-Up: A close follow-up was planned for warfarin dose adjustments based on INR values and close monitoring of the signs of pulmonary hypertension. The patient was advised for admission to the hospital in case of any symptoms such as breathlessness  fainting  or chest pain  indicating the recurrence of a pulmonary embolism.   Conclusion: This case underlines the necessity of quick recognition of symptoms and immediate diagnostic procedures for pulmonary embolism to prevent significant morbidity and mortality. Furthermore  the patient's comorbid conditions like diabetes and hypertension mandate regular follow-up and careful management to mitigate future health risks.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Mr. X  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself to the emergency department on 3rd June 2021 with a two-day history of severe shortness of breath  chest pain  and profuse sweating. His body mass index is 32 kg/m2  indicating obesity. The patient is a current smoker with a 40-pack year history. He is a resident of Texas  where he works as an accountant. He reported no travel history and didn't have any recent surgeries or immobilization.   Past Medical History: Mr. X has a significant medical history of chronic hypertension for the past 10 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed seven years ago. His hypertension is managed with daily Metoprolol and his diabetes is managed through daily oral Metformin and diet modification. He has no known drug allergies  no family history of coagulation disordered  deep venous thrombosis (DVT)  or pulmonary embolism.   Presenting Complaints: The patient reported severe  sharp and central chest pain  which he described as ""stabbing"" and radiating to the back. He disclosed experiencing shortness of breath  which was aggravated upon minimal physical exertion. It was also noted that the patient had profuse sweating.   Clinical Findings: On evaluation  Mr. X was tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/minute  had a heart rate of 110 beats/minute  a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg and oxygen saturation of 88% (on room air). Temperature was 98.6°F. On auscultation  his breath sounds were decreased bilaterally. Mr. X's ECG showed sinus tachycardia with S1Q3T3 pattern. All these signs were suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism (APE) and were highly concerning given the patient's symptomatology.   Diagnostic Assessment: An immediate computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was conducted which confirmed the presence of a large filling defect in the right main pulmonary artery  consistent with an acute pulmonary embolism.  His D-dimer came back elevated (>5000 mcgFEU/L).   Therapeutic Intervention: Mr. X was initially managed with high-flow supplemental oxygen via mask. The patient was promptly initiated on intravenous unfractionated heparin as per the weight-based dosing protocol.   Follow Up & Outcomes: Over the following 48 hours  Mr. X showed progressive improvement in both symptoms and his oxygen saturation. He was then started on oral Apixaban for long-term anticoagulation therapy to prevent recurrence of an embolic event. On discharge  the patient was given appropriate education about the importance of smoking cessation  regular exercise  dietary modification  medication adherence and advised for periodic follow up visits.   Conclusion: Despite having two major risk factors - obesity and smoking  the prompt diagnosis and timely management have undoubtedly prevented a probable catastrophic outcome for Mr. X from acute pulmonary embolism. This case underlines the importance of early detection and treatment of high-risk individuals.   Authors: [Author's name] [Department] [Institution]

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 55-Year-Old Male with a History of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Information: The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male  residing in an urban area  who is a non-smoker and has a body mass index of 25. He works as an office manager and has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his right leg approximately 5 years ago. There is no other significant family medical history.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath and palpitations for the past few hours. The chest pain was pleuritic in nature  intensifying on deep breathing. The onset of the symptoms was abrupt while he was at his work.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic  his vital signs were: Blood pressure 135/85 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed tachycardia  normalized S1 and S2  and no murmurs or abnormal sounds. Pulmonary auscultation disclosed decreased breath sounds on the right side. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Tests and Results: A D-Dimer test was ordered  yielding a result far above the normal range. An ECG showed sinus tachycardia with an S1Q3T3 pattern  associated with acute pulmonary embolism. A chest X-ray showed slight right pleural effusion but was not conclusive. A CT pulmonary angiography was performed which showed multiple filling defects in the right pulmonary artery  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. Further investigations for a potential DVT (a Doppler ultrasound of the lower limbs) were requested.  Management: Management was begun promptly by starting the patient on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin. Oxygen therapy was initiated to correct hypoxemia. Over the next few days  oral anticoagulation with warfarin was started  aiming for an INR of 2.0-3.0.  Follow-up: The patient showed significant improvement and was discharged on the fifth day with prescriptions and clear instructions about his medications and lifestyle modifications. He was scheduled for a follow-up in a week.  Conclusion: This case is a common presentation of Acute Pulmonary Embolism. The patient's awareness of his previous DVT might have prompted his arrival to the ER  which led to an early diagnosis and treatment  potentially preventing serious complications.  Keywords: Pulmonary Embolism  DVT  Chest Pain  Shortness of breath  Tachycardia.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 42-Year-Old Female: A Case Report  Patient Information: The patient is a 42-year-old African American female  works as a real estate manager  married with two children  non-smoker  and no known illicit drug use. She resides in the suburbs of New York City.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness which persisted for two days before she sought medical help.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago post-childbirth  adequately treated with anticoagulants. Her only other significant medical history includes obesity (BMI 38) and Hypertension  for which she's receiving treatment (amlodipine). There is no known history of diabetes  cardiovascular disease  or lung disease. The patient reports no known drug allergies.  Physical Examination: On examination  she was anxious  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  blood pressure of 135/86 mmHg  heart rate fluctuant between 103-116 beats per minute  fingertip O_2 Sat 88%  and a BMI of 38. There was no cyanosis  clubbing  or peripheral edema.  Investigations: An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia. Pulmonary Computerized Tomography Angiography (CTPA) showed multiple emboli in the bilateral pulmonary arteries. D-Dimer levels were found to be elevated (4000 ng/mL). A lower limb venous Doppler revealed thrombi in the left popliteal vein  suggesting the emboli's origin.  Treatment: The patient was admitted to Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for monitoring. Intravenous unfractionated Heparin was immediately started for anticoagulation  followed by oral rivaroxaban after stabilization. Simultaneously  lower limb compression stockings were used to prevent further clot propagation.  Outcome and Follow-Up: Her symptoms gradually improved over a week  with improvement in oxygen saturation to 96%. She was discharged with instructions to continue rivaroxaban and to maintain regular follow-ups with the Hematology and Pulmonology clinics.  Discussion: This case demonstrates the critical importance of timely diagnosis and intervention in acute PE. A high index of suspicion is needed  especially in patients with risk factors like obesity  sedentary lifestyle  past history of DVT  and hypertension. The need for long-term secondary prophylaxis in such patients should be emphasized  considering the overall high recurrence rates of venous thromboembolism.  Conclusion: This illustrates the significance of early identification  diagnosis  and apt management in patients with a high risk for acute PE. It also emphasizes the need for prophylactic measures and continuous monitoring in patients with known risk factors. Additionally  it highlights the importance of patient education about lifestyle modifications and early symptom recognition to reduce morbidity and mortality associated with PE.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 62-year-old Obese Female with Previous History of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Case Report:  Patient Information: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian female with a body mass index of 33 (indicating obesity)  a known smoker for 40 years  and a sedentary lifestyle. The patient has a medical history significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago and hypertension  which is well-controlled with medication (lisinopril 10mg daily). She has no known allergies. Her surgical history includes a partial knee replacement surgery and gallbladder removal. She lives alone  with no support network in place.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented herself to the emergency department complaining of acute onset shortness of breath  chest pain exacerbated upon deep breathing  and an episode of dizziness. She denies any cough or fever.  Clinical Findings: Initial vitals showed blood pressure of 150/90mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiration rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Physical examination revealed reduced breath sounds at the right lung base. Heart sounds were normal  without any added sounds. Lower limb examination revealed no signs of DVT.  Diagnostic Assessment: An electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia and a S1Q3T3 pattern. Chest X-ray didn't reveal any lung infarction or pleural effusion. D-dimer level was significantly elevated. Due to a high clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism  the patient underwent a Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA)  confirming the diagnosis. CTPA revealed a large  acute pulmonary embolus occluding the right lower lobe pulmonary artery.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on intravenous heparin and further switched to oral anticoagulation with Apixaban. She was kept under inpatient monitoring for five days for potential complications.   Follow-up and Outcomes: Upon discharge  the patient was educated about the importance of continuing oral anticoagulation therapy  quitting smoking  and engaging in a more active lifestyle. She was also referred to a dietician for advice on achieving a healthier weight. Regular follow-up appointments were scheduled to monitor her anticoagulation status and overall health.  Patient Perspective: The patient voiced concern regarding the maintenance of her lifestyle after the episode and was responsive to smoking cessation counseling and dietary consultations for her obesity.  Informed Consent: The patient provided written informed consent for her case to be published.  Conclusion: This case serves as a reminder that a high degree of clinical suspicion is critical in patients with risk factors like obesity  advanced age  smoking history  and prior DVT  to facilitate early diagnosis and treatment of life-threatening conditions such as acute pulmonary embolism. Attempts should also be made to modify some of these risk factors to reduce the disease burden in such patients.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information The patient  a 65 year-old Caucasian male (initials: J.S.)  known to be hypertensive and with a history of long-term tobacco use  presented to the Emergency Department in the early hours of the morning. He lives with his wife in a suburban environment and was previously working as an accountant before retiring five years ago. There are no known allergies or developed drug reactions.  Clinical Findings The presenting complaints were sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and hemoptysis. The pain was pleuritic in nature and had started about 2 hours before presentation. The patient described the pain as ""stabbing"" in the left side of his chest. He had no fever or recent history of infection. There was no significant travel history  and he denied any history of deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism. Family history was non-contributory.  Diagnostic Assessment  His vital signs on presentation were blood pressure 145/90 mmHg  the pulse was 110 beats per minute  oxygen saturation 90% on room air  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  and temperature 37°C. Physical examination was generally unremarkable except for tachypnea and decreased breath sounds over the lower third of the left lung.  Laboratory tests including a full count  electrolytes  renal  liver function  coagulation screen  and troponin were all within normal limits except for a slightly elevated D-dimer at 0.65mg/L (normal range: <0.5mg/L). Chest radiograph did not show any acute abnormality.   Considering his clinical presentation and risk factors  the decision was made to perform a CT pulmonary angiogram to rule out pulmonary embolism. The CT scan demonstrated a large thrombus in the left lower lobe pulmonary artery consistent with acute pulmonary embolism.  Therapeutic Intervention The patient was admitted to the hospital and anticoagulation was initiated with a low molecular weight heparin  enoxaparin. On the second hospital day  apixaban was added for long-term anticoagulation. During his hospital stay  his symptoms improved and he was hemodynamically stable.  Outcome and Follow-up  After 5 days  the patient was discharged home on apixaban with counseling regarding the importance of medication compliance. He was also scheduled for follow-up in the outpatient clinic after 2 weeks and with advice to visit the emergency department if any worsening symptoms.   In conclusion  this case of acute pulmonary embolism highlights the importance of considering this diagnosis in patients presenting with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath  even without typical risk factors or suggestive findings on plain chest radiography. As is often the case  the simple test of D-dimer and a high index of suspicion led to the use of CT pulmonary angiography  the standard for the definitive diagnosis of PE.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  This case report details the diagnosis and management of acute pulmonary embolism in a 52-year-old African American male.  Case Presentation:  A 52-year-old African American male presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of sudden-onset chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations. The patient described the chest pain as dull  exertional  and radiating to the left arm. He also reported mild lightheadedness but no syncope  cough  or hemoptysis.  The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus but no known lung or heart diseases. He is a smoker with a 20-pack-year history and has a sedentary lifestyle. He takes metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin but reports inconsistent medication compliance. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease. The patient had no known drug allergies.   On examination  the patient was found to be anxious  with a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure of 145/92 mm Hg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. The chest was clear to auscultation bilaterally. His cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. The rest of the physical exam was unremarkable.  Investigations:  Due to the patient's symptoms and risk factors  acute pulmonary embolism was suspected. Blood tests revealed elevated levels of D-Dimer. An electrocardiogram (EKG) showed sinus tachycardia and a S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute right heart strain but no evidence of ischemia. A CT pulmonary angiogram was performed and confirmed the presence of a large embolus in the right pulmonary artery  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was immediately administered intravenous heparin and later transitioned to oral anticoagulation with warfarin. His shortness of breath and chest pain improved significantly over the next few days. He was discharged home on oral anticoagulants  instructed to quit smoking  increase physical activity  and adhered strictly to his prescribed medications. Appropriate follow-up was arranged.  Discussion:  This case highlights the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath  particularly in those with risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and a sedentary lifestyle. Timely investigation helped in diagnosing the condition earlier  ultimately leading to improved patient outcome. The case also underscores the role of adopting a healthy lifestyle and consistent medication compliance to prevent such life-threatening conditions.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Patient with Unremarkable Health History  Introduction:  An 82-year-old Caucasian female with a seemingly unremarkable medical history arrived at the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset chest pain and difficulty breathing. The patient also reported increased fatigue over the past week. No known history of smoking  regular alcohol consumption  or illicit drug use. The patient denied any recent surgeries or immobilization and was not on any regular medications prior to presentation. Family history was significant for deep vein thrombosis in a brother; however  detailed family history was inconclusive due to lack of information.  Clinical Findings:  Upon admission  vital signs revealed tachypnea with a rate of 24 breaths per min  blood pressure of 138/82  heart rate consistent with tachycardia at 110 beats per min  and oxygen saturation at 93% on room air. Physical examination elicited pleuritic chest pain on the right side. Breath sounds were reduced in the lower right lung field  but there were no overt signs of lower limb edema or cyanosis.   Investigations:  A D-dimer test confirmed a value of 5000 ng/mL (reference range <500 ng/mL). Her electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of S1Q3T3  suggestive of acute cor pulmonale. Her echocardiogram presented signs of right ventricular pressure and volume overload with pulmonic acceleration time reduced at 80 ms. Computated tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) revealed a large filling defect within the main pulmonary artery and its right and left branches  confirming a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Treatment and Outcomes:  The patient was immediately managed with supplemental oxygen and continuous monitoring in the intensive care unit (ICU). Anticoagulative therapy was initiated using unfractionated heparin. Despite aggressive management  the patient’s condition quickly deteriorated and thrombolytic therapy with alteplase was administered due to severe right ventricular strain and worsening clinical condition. Following thrombolysis  significant clinical improvement was noted with stabilized vital signs within 24 hours.  Discussion:  Acute pulmonary embolism is a severe  potentially fatal condition that presents with nonspecific symptoms  often making it challenging to diagnose promptly. Despite no immediate risk factors or prior medical history  this case highlights the need for high clinical suspicion  especially in elderly patients presenting with acute onset dyspnea  chest pain  and signs of hemodynamic instability. Prompt diagnosis and aggressive management can potentially improve outcomes and reduce mortality from this potentially fatal condition. As PE may be the first manifestation of thrombotic tendency  it's imperative that elderly patients with unexplained PE are screened for inherited prothrombotic conditions.  Conclusion:  Acute pulmonary embolism remains a diagnostic challenge due to heterogeneous clinical presentation. High clinical suspicion remains the key to timely diagnosis and management. This case underscores the significance of recognizing PE  even in patients without overt risk factors  given the high morbidity and mortality associated with the condition.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 45-Year-Old Female with Known History of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Case Report:  Patient Information:  The patient  Mrs. L  is a 45-year-old Caucasian female. She is non-smoker  experiences moderate alcohol intake  and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to her work nature.  Chief Complaint: She was presented to the hospital with acute onset shortness of breath accompanied with mild chest discomfort  lightheadedness  fainting spells  and palpitations. These symptoms began roughly 24 hours prior to her admission.   Medical History: Mrs. L has a significant medical history with an episode of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) three years ago. She was managed conservatively with oral anticoagulants with regular follow-up. She also reported chronic hypertension  which is controlled with medications prescribed by her primary care physician.   Examinations and Tests: On examination  her blood pressure was noted as 145/90  heart rate 105/min  respiratory rate 24/min  and oxygen saturation at 92% on room air. Lung auscultation revealed decreased breath sound in the right lower zone. Venous Doppler ultrasound of both lower extremities suggested no current DVT. The D-Dimer level was markedly elevated (1200 ng/mL). A Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) was performed revealing multiple filling defects in the right main pulmonary arteries. This confirmed a diagnosis of Pulmonary Embolism (PE).   Diagnosis: Based on clinical presentation  high D-dimer levels  and confirmation on CTPA  the patient was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.  Management and Outcome: The patient was immediately initiated on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and oral anticoagulant therapy. She was given supplemental oxygen to maintain saturation above 96%. As her vitals stabilized and her clinical condition improved  she was monitored in the hospital for the next seven days during which she remained stable. She was discharged with long term oral anticoagulant therapy and set for follow-up with a Pulmonologist and Hematologist. Counseling about lifestyle modification  regular exercise and DVT prophylaxis was also provided in the context of her sedentary work.  Discussion: This case highlights the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion of acute PE in patients with a known history of DVT even if currently non-apparent  especially when presenting with respiratory symptoms. Regular follow-up and continued anticoagulant therapy are critical for preventing such dangerous thrombotic events in these susceptible individuals.   Contributor: Dr. A  Department of Internal Medicine  [Hospital Name]

Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself at our emergency department. He is retired  lives alone and has no known allergies. He has a significant medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and hypertension. He is a former smoker but quit around 10 years ago. He does not consume alcohol and denies any illicit drug use. His medication includes daily low-dose aspirin and beta-blockers for hypertension.  Chief Complaint:  The patient presented with a 4-hour history of sudden onset severe chest pain and shortness of breath. He also reported experiencing palpitations  light-headedness  and a feeling of anxiousness.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  the patient appeared diaphoretic and in acute distress. His vital signs were as follows: blood pressure  150/90 mmHg; heart rate  110 bpm; respiratory rate  24 breaths per minute; temperature  37.5°C; and oxygen saturation  91% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed tachycardia with no audible murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary examination revealed decreased breath sounds in the right lung base. No edema or tenderness observed in lower extremities.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Given the patient’s symptoms and past medical history  a suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism (PE) was raised. A D-dimer test came back significantly elevated. Further diagnostic evaluation with a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the chest confirmed the presence of a large embolus in the right pulmonary artery.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on heparin drip for systemic anticoagulation and admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU). Concurrently  the thrombolytic agent  tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  was administered.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  After 48 hours  repeat CT scanning showed a remarkable decrease in the size of the clot  and his symptoms had significantly improved. Mr. Smith was then switched from heparin to warfarin for long-term anticoagulation. An inferior vena cava (IVC) filter was placed to prevent new pulmonary emboli given his history of DVT.  He was discharged after a week with instructions to continue his warfarin therapy and a referral to an outpatient pulmonologist for further management and follow-up.  Mr. Smith's case underscores the importance of prompt diagnosis and treatment in patients with a high clinical suspicion of PE  especially in those with a history of DVT. In cases of massive PE  as seen in Mr. Smith  thrombolytic therapy may prove to be highly beneficial and life-saving.

Patient Information:  A forty-eight year old female patient  non-smoker  of African descent presented to the emergency department with sudden chest pain and difficulty in breathing. She had a body mass index (BMI) of 29 kg/m2. She denied any history of drug or alcohol abuse. The patient  a sewing machine operator  mentioned that she had been experiencing pain and swelling in her left calf for approximately ten days.   Past Medical History:  The patient had a background of hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide (25 mg once daily) and type II diabetes mellitus managed with oral metformin (500 mg twice daily). Additionally  she had a history of a deep vein thrombosis in her right leg a year ago. Family history was remarkable for a sister who had been diagnosed with pulmonary embolism after a cesarean section.  Presenting Complaints:  Upon presentation  the patient complained of sudden onset  sharp  intense  7/10 chest pain  worse during inhalation  associated with shortness of breath and episodes of coughing. She also mentioned experiencing light-headedness and slight nausea  but denied any recent flu symptoms  fever  hemoptysis  sputum production  or weight loss.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient’s vital signs were: blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  pulse 105 beats per minute  temperature 37.2°C  respiratory rate 30 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 90% on room air. Her left calf was swollen and tender. Chest and cardiovascular examinations were unremarkable  except for tachycardia.  Diagnosis:  The patient was immediately evaluated for her chest pain and respiratory symptoms. ECG showed signs of right heart strain. D-Dimer was significantly elevated. CT pulmonary angiogram was promptly ordered and confirmed the presence of a large embolus within the right and left pulmonary arteries  suggestive of acute bilateral pulmonary embolism. Duplex sonogram demonstrated left calf deep vein thrombosis.  Treatment:  Therapy was initiated with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin for deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism  along with supplemental oxygen. Within 24 hours  the patient's symptoms started to alleviate  and her oxygen saturation improved. Arrangements were made for long term oral anticoagulant therapy following discharge.   Takeaway:  This case underlines the high level of suspicion needed for early detection of pulmonary embolism. Prompt identification and initiation of treatment can significantly improve patient outcomes. It also emphasizes the importance of considering thrombophilic conditions in patients with a personal and family history of venous thromboembolism.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE)  Patient Information  Mr. A.B.  a 67-year-old Hispanic male from Houston Texas  sought treatment at the emergency department (ED) of a local hospital. He is a retired school principal living with his wife. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 31.2 and a documented history of smoking for 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and high cholesterol levels. The patient denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.  Presenting Problem  Mr. A.B. presented to the ED with a chief complaint of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and fainting episodes that had begun suddenly about two hours before presenting to the ED. He complained the crumbling chest pain was central in nature and radiated to his back and left shoulder. He was also complaining of mild leg swelling  particularly on the right side.  Clinical Findings  On examination  the patient was anxious and diaphoretic  with an initial blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  body temperature of 36.8 °C  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Pulse was regular  and jugular vein pulsations were visible. Lower limb examination revealed mild pitting edema  particularly on the right side. Lung auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes bilaterally.  Diagnostic Assessment   An electrocardiogram (EKG) revealed sinus tachycardia with a S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism. A D-dimer test was ordered  which returned as significantly elevated  raising the suspicion of a thrombotic event. A Computerized Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) was performed which affirmed the diagnosis revealing large emboli in the main pulmonary arteries bilaterally. A Venous Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity also demonstrated deep vein thrombosis.   Therapeutic Intervention  Mr. A.B. was started on unfractionated heparin infusion and supplemental oxygen. Once stabilized  he was transitioned to oral anticoagulants for long-term management. He was also recommended for a lower limb compression device to alleviate right-sided swelling and prevent further clot development.  Follow-up and Outcomes  In view of the presence of risk factors  including his sedentary lifestyle  obesity  advanced age  and underlying chronic diseases  a multidisciplinary approach was discussed for Mr. A.B's management  involving dietary modification  rigorous physical exercise  and smoking cessation counseling.   Patient Consent  Informed consent was obtained from Mr. A.B. prior to conducting investigative procedures  starting medications and plans.   Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of considering the diagnosis of APE in patients presenting with sudden-onset dyspnea and chest pain. Furthermore  it also highlights the need for comprehensive management plans targeting modifiable risk factors in patients diagnosed with APE.  The case report was compiled by Dr. XY  his primary care doctor.  Patient data privacy is ensured.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Postmenopausal Female: A Case Report  Introduction:  This case report describes the clinical course of a 62-year-old postmenopausal female presenting with acute pulmonary embolism with no significant previous medical history.   Patient Information:  The patient is a 62-year-old female who is a nonsmoker and nondrinker  with a sedentary lifestyle. There were no known allergies. She was not on any regular medications  nor did she have any history of long-term immobility  recent surgeries  or underlying malignancies. Prior medical record demonstrated no history of personal or familial thromboembolic diseases  diabetes  hypertension  or any cardiovascular diseases. The patient was post-menopausal and didn't take hormone replacement therapy. No significant family history was documented.   Clinical Findings:   The patient presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of breathlessness and pain in her right lower chest for a duration of 5 hours. She had no associated cough  fever  hemoptysis  or weight loss. There was no history of leg pain or swelling.   Diagnostic Assessment:   Vitals on presentation revealed a pulse rate of 106/min  blood pressure of 100/70 mmHg  respiratory rate of 26/min  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air.   Initial laboratory testing showed elevated D-dimer levels. An electrocardiogram (ECG) was performed which didn’t reveal any specific changes but showed sinus tachycardia. There were no specific findings on chest radiography. A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was conducted given the high clinical suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism. The CTPA confirmed bilateral pulmonary emboli predominantly in the lower lobes.  Therapeutic Intervention:   The patient was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) as per the hospital policy for confirmed pulmonary embolism. Due to her stable condition  thrombolytic therapy was not warranted. The patient was referred for prophylactic placement of an inferior vena cava filter due to her reduced mobility.  Follow-up and outcomes:   The patient was hospitalized for a week and showed significant improvement in symptoms. The anticoagulation therapy was continued  and oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban was initiated before discharge  with a plan to continue treatment for at least six months. She was advised to maintain an active lifestyle and was discharged in a stable condition.   Patient Perspective:  The patient reported a willingness to improve her lifestyle to prevent episodes in the future. She mentioned her relief upon understanding the importance of an early diagnosis and prompt treatment.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the critical aspect of considering a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in a patient presenting with unexplained dyspnea  despite the lack of risk factors. Early diagnosis and proper thromboprophylaxis can result in a significant decrease in morbidity and mortality in such patients. It underscores the need for a high index of suspicion for acute PE  as delay in diagnosis and treatment can have fatal outcomes.

Title: A Case of Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Female with Prior History of Deep Vein Thrombosis   Patient Information: The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian female  who works as an office clerk  currently living in urban New York. She has a previous medical history significant for hypertension  obesity  and Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) treated five years ago.  Case Presentation: The patient presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  which was sharp and worsened with deep breathing. She reported a one-week history of mild leg swelling and pain in her left lower leg. No prior recent travel history  immobility  trauma  or surgery was reported. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  and reports a daily alcohol intake of approximately 1-2 drinks. Her family history is significant  with her mother also having a history of DVT.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  the patient was anxious and in visible respiratory distress. Vital signs indicated tachycardia  with a heart rate of 110 bpm  respiration rate of 24 bpm  and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. Her blood pressure was within a normal range. Lower extremity examination showed mild pitting edema and tenderness in the left calf.   Diagnostic Focus and Assessment: Given her symptoms and past medical history  we had a high clinical suspicion of Pulmonary Embolism (PE). An urgent D-dimer test was ordered which turned out to be considerably high. A computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was ordered and showed a large clot burden in the right pulmonary artery  confirming a diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started immediately on therapeutic anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH)  with a plan to transition to oral anticoagulation once the patient's condition stabilized. Supportive care included the administration of oxygen by nasal cannula.   Follow-up and Outcomes: Within days  the patient reported less pain and demonstrated improvement in oxygen saturation levels. Prior to discharge  she was transitioned to oral anticoagulant  Rivaroxaban. The hospital's anticoagulation clinic planned for patient follow-up in one week and the importance of medication adherence and potential adverse effects were discussed with the patient.  Patient Perspective: The patient was anxious initially due to her sudden onset of symptoms but was cooperative throughout her stay. She showed a positive attitude towards lifestyle changes necessary to manage her condition.   Informed consent: Patient's written informed consent was obtained post stabilizing her condition.   It's deemed significant to report this case given the patient's medical history and the circumstances leading to her PE development highlighting the need for prolonged prophylaxis in individuals with a prior DVT incident.

Patient Details:  Mr. Lopez  a 74-year-old Hispanic man with a residential address at New Mexico  visited the emergency room with emergent symptoms.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient presented with acute shortness of breath  rapid heart rate  and intermittent chest pain worsening over a period of two days. He also reported feeling light-headedness and experiencing a brief episode of dizziness.  Medical History and Lifestyle:  Mr. Lopez is a retired manual laborer  with past medical history significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. In the past  he has also been treated for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a long-haul flight three years ago. He is an ex-smoker and quit 15 years ago. He admits to a low-level alcohol intake and denies any recreational drug use. There is a family history of cardiac disease  with his father dying at the age of 61 due to myocardial infarction.  Current Medications: He is currently taking Metformin for his diabetes and Amlodipine for his blood pressure. At the time of admission  he was not receiving any anticoagulants.  Clinical Assessment: Upon physical examination  he appeared slightly diaphoretic but not in respiratory distress. Mr. Lopez's blood pressure was 160/90mmHg  pulse 105 per minute  and SpO2 of 90% on room air. Initial blood tests showed slightly raised D-dimer levels. A rapid COVID-19 antigen test was performed and reported negative. An ECG at this time showed sinus tachycardia without any ST changes.  Diagnosis and Treatment: Given his symptoms and clinical presentation  the patient was suspected to have an acute pulmonary embolism. This suspected diagnosis was later confirmed with a CT pulmonary angiogram  which showed a large clot burden within the main pulmonary arteries bilaterally.  Mr. Lopez was managed in the High Dependency Unit (HDU) and started on therapeutic intravenous heparin. His oxygen saturation was monitored continuously  and he was provided with supplemental oxygen therapy as required.  Prognosis and Follow-Up: The patient responded well to the treatment. His chest pain and breathlessness eased within a few days of starting anticoagulation therapy  and he was subsequently switched to oral anticoagulants. After a week  he was discharged with an appointment to attend the thrombosis clinic for follow-up and management of anticoagulation.  Mr. Lopez was also advised to minimize his risk of PE recurrence by maintaining a healthy weight  regularly exercising  taking his medication as prescribed  and staying hydrated. He was informed about the signs and symptoms of PE for increased vigilance.  Ethics: The patient provided written informed consent for his case details to be written and published. Personal identifying details were excluded for privacy.  Conclusion: This case highlights the need for a high index of suspicion for a pulmonary embolism in a patient with a history of DVT who presents with acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. Early recognition and prompt medical intervention can significantly improve outcomes and reduce mortality risk in these critical patients.

Patient Information  A 55-year-old African American male  non-smoker  non-alcoholic  and without any known drug allergies presented to the emergency room with severe shortness of breath  chest pain  and sudden onset of fainting spells. The patient's medical history reveals hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and deep vein thrombosis. The patient is currently on medication  including Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes  Losartan 100mg daily for hypertension  and Warfarin 5mg daily for deep vein thrombosis.  Clinical Findings  On examination  he appeared anxious  sweaty  and in respiratory distress with a notably rapid  shallow breathing pattern. His vital signs revealed tachycardia with heart rate up to 120 beats per min  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation level of 89% on room air. There was leg swelling  which was more pronounced on the left side. Auscultation of the lungs revealed reduced breath sounds in the right lower zone. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment  A complete blood count demonstrated a slightly increased white cell count of 13 000/mm^3  while other hematological parameters were within normal limits. The D-Dimer was markedly elevated at 4000 ng/mL(normal: less than 500 ng/mL).  Electrocardiography (ECG) showed a sinus tachycardia. Imaging studies were then conducted  including a chest X-ray  which revealed no significant findings. Computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) scan showed filling defects in the right lower lobar artery which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was promptly administered oxygen therapy and placed on continuous monitoring. The pre-existing Warfarin therapy was suspended  and he was initiated on intravenous heparin; aimed at achieving a target activated partial thromboplastin time 1.5–2 times the normal range. In addition  the patient received parenteral morphine for pain management.  Follow-up and Outcome  Reassessment after 48 hours showed significant improvement in his symptoms  with a reduction in tachycardia and improved oxygen saturation levels. Once his condition was systemic  he was discharged on long-term oral anticoagulation therapy (Rivaroxaban) for six months. Upon his follow-up a month later  there was a remarkable improvement  and no complications were reported. He will continue on the Rivaroxaban for another five months and is planned for regular 3-month follow-ups and imaging studies to monitor his status.   Conclusion  This case illustrates the importance of considering acute PE in patients presenting with shortness of breath and chest pain. Timely intervention and appropriate treatment can significantly improve patient outcomes. Despite being on anticoagulation therapy for deep vein thrombosis  the patient still developed PE  which emphasizes the need for regular follow-up and patient education about the importance of medication adherence and recognizing symptoms of potential complications.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Previously Healthy 53-year-old Female: A Case Report  Patient Information:  The patient is a 53-year-old Caucasian female. She was previously healthy  with no known chronic illnesses or regular medication use. She doesn’t have a history of any surgeries. She mentioned that she does not smoke  drink  or use illicit drugs. She works from home as a copy-editor and has a minimal level of physical activity. She reported she was taking oral contraceptive pills for menstrual regulation. Her family medical history reveals that her father had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) but was not currently under any treatment.  Chief Complaint:  She presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of difficulty in breathing and sharp chest pain which was intensified while taking a deep breath. She also mentioned that she’s been feeling ‘light-headed’ for the past few hours.  Clinical Findings:  Her physical examination revealed that she was tachycardic  with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and tachypneic  with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Her blood pressure was 130/85 mmHg  and her oxygen saturation was at 94% on room air. Cardiac auscultation revealed a regular rhythm  and pulmonary auscultation showed decreased breath sounds on the right lower side.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The initial electrocardiogram (ECG) showed a sinus tachycardia and a S1Q3T3 pattern  suggestive of pulmonary embolism. D-dimer levels were significantly raised (4500 ng/mL). A Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the presence of a large clot in the right main pulmonary artery. Her lower extremity Doppler ultrasound showed no signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the acuteness of her situation  systemic thrombolysis with alteplase was immediately administered following hospital protocol. After she was stabilized  anticoagulation with very low molecular weight heparin was started as a bridge to warfarin therapy.  Outcome and Follow-up:  The patient had significant relief from her symptoms after thrombolysis. Following 5 days of inpatient care  she was discharged on long-term warfarin therapy. A review after one month showed the patient was symptom-free and had adjusted well to the anticoagulation therapy.  Given the patient's positive family history of DVT and the usage of oral contraceptives  it may have predisposed her to a thromboembolic event. This case accentuates the need for considering individuals’ risk factors for pulmonary embolism and ensuring appropriate risk management strategies are in place.  Learning Points:  1. Acute pulmonary embolism should always be considered in patients presenting with sudden onset of unexplained shortness of breath  chest pain  and palpitations. 2. A high index of suspicion should be maintained in patients with risk factors like familial history of thrombotic events  sedentary lifestyle  and hormone use. 3. Immediate therapeutic intervention can significantly impact the patient's quality of life and decrease mortality. 4. Educating patients about the need for lifestyle modifications and the risks associated with oral contraceptives utilization  especially in the context of positive family history  is critical.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 45-year-old Male: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 45-year-old Caucasian male  a commercial truck driver by profession  presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. The patient was a heavy smoker (2 packs/day for over 20 years)  overweight (Body Mass Index of 31 kg/m2)  and has a family history of venous thromboembolism (VTE).  Clinical Findings: The patient described a sharp  central chest pain radiating to his left arm  with sudden onset of shortness of breath. He denied any preceding cough  fever  hemoptysis  or recent travel. His vital signs at the time of presentation were blood pressure 155/95 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 28 per minute  oxygen saturation of 91% on room air  and temperature of 37.2 degrees Celsius. The rest of his physical examination was unremarkable; his lungs were clear to auscultation  heart sounds were normal without added sounds  and there was no lower limb edema or tenderness.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given the patient's presenting symptoms and medical history  an acute pulmonary embolism (PE) was suspected. The patient underwent an electrocardiogram (EKG) that showed sinus tachycardia with no ST-segment or T wave changes. A D-dimer assay was ordered  which returned elevated at 5000 ng/ml (normal range 0-500 ng/ml).   The patient was subsequently referred for a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA)  confirming the presence of a large obstructive thrombus in the right pulmonary artery. Laboratory investigations revealed elevated cardiac troponin (0.3 ng/ml; normal range 0-0.1 ng/ml)  and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) (900 pg/mL; normal range 0-100 pg/mL) thus pointing towards right ventricular strain.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on therapeutic unfractionated heparin. Owing to the presence of right ventricular dysfunction and the high risk of deterioration  the patient was referred for emergency thrombolysis with alteplase.   Follow up and Outcomes: The patient’s clinical condition improved over the next few hours with a decrease in dyspnea and chest pain. A repeat CTPA after 24 hours showed significant resolution of the thrombus. The patient was switched to oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban and was discharged after a week with instructions for lifestyle modifications including weight loss  smoking cessation  and regular exercise.  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in the differential diagnosis of acute chest pain  particularly in the presence of risk factors. Early diagnosis and aggressive management are essential to prevent potentially fatal outcomes in this condition.

Title: A Case Report on Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 67-Year-Old Male Patient  Introduction: A 67-year-old Caucasian male patient was brought into the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness that started approximately two hours before presenting to the hospital.   Patient Information:  The patient  Mr. Forsythe  is a retired school teacher with a past medical history significant for atrial fibrillation  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. He has no known drug allergies. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol socially. He has a family history of heart disease; his father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 65.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient appeared distressed with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg. His oxygen saturation on room air was 90%. He had evidence of right ventricular heave but no jugular venous distention. The rest of the cardiovascular and respiratory examination was unremarkable. He had slight edema in the lower extremities.   Diagnostic Assessment:  An urgent EKG was indicative of right ventricular strain  a sign often associated with acute pulmonary embolism. Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels. The patient's atrial fibrillation and recent long-haul flight led us to consider the high probability of a thromboembolic event. A CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the diagnosis  and showed a large clot in the right pulmonary artery with signs of right heart strain.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Immediately after the diagnosis  the patient was started on therapeutic anticoagulation with intravenous heparin and scheduled for catheter-directed thrombolysis. His initial response to the treatment was positive with a significant improvement in symptoms and normalisation of vitals.  Follow Up and Outcomes:  Mr. Forsythe  over the course of the following week  made a good recovery with gradual resolution of symptoms and improvement of vital parameters. He was bridged from heparin to a direct oral anticoagulant and was given instructions for strict compliance due to his risk of recurrent thromboembolic events. Lifestyle modification advice was also provided. His follow-up appointment was scheduled in the anticoagulation clinic in two weeks and cardiology clinic in one month.  Patient's Perspective: Mr. Forsythe expressed his gratitude for the quick diagnosis and effective treatment. He admitted his initial fear and anxiety  but appreciated the comprehensive explanation of his condition and the plan for his ongoing care.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients with sudden onset unexplained dyspnea  chest pain  and hypoxia particularly those with risk factors for venous thromboembolism such as atrial fibrillation and recent prolonged immobilization. Early diagnosis and treatment significantly influence  and can potentially be lifesaving in these patients.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Female Patient with an Unknown History of Thrombophilia  Patient Information: Ms. A is a 54-year-old Caucasian woman residing in Ohio with no known history of serious medical conditions. She is a non-smoker and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to her occupation as a software developer. Her family history is significant for cardiovascular disease. Her father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at the age of 65.  Presenting Complaints: Ms. A presented in the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath which started around 2 hours prior to her arrival.  Past Medical History:  The patient’s known personal medical history is unremarkable  with her only complaint being occasional lower extremity edema  specifically in her right leg. She was not on any regular medications or hormonal therapies. She denied a history of miscarriages  deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  or pulmonary embolism (PE).  Clinical Findings: At the ED  her blood pressure was normal (130/70mmHg) but her heart rate was elevated (110 bpm). She had a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  SpO2 was 90% on room air and her temperature was 98.6°F. Physical examination revealed tachycardia and decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest. Her right calf appeared swollen and tender on palpation.
