Diagnostic Assessment: Suspecting PE  a D-dimer test was ordered  which returned positive. A computerized tomographic pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was performed  confirming the diagnosis by showing a large clot in the lower lobe of the right lung. A Doppler ultrasound of the right leg was performed  revealing deep vein thrombosis confirming the source of the embolism.   Additionally  given her symptoms  family history  and lack of known risk factors  the decision was also made to test her for thrombophilia. Thrombophilia panel revealed heterozygous factor V Leiden mutation  which was previously unknown.  Treatment: The patient was promptly started on anticoagulant therapy with intravenous heparin. Once the patient was stabilized  she was switched over to oral anticoagulants (Warfarin) for continued therapy. Leg elevation was recommended to reduce the edema  and intermittent pneumatic compression devices were used to prevent worsening of DVT.  Outcome and Follow-up: Ms. A responded well to the treatment  and experienced a significant relief of her symptoms in the following days. She will be scheduled for routine follow-ups for monitoring her anticoagulation status and evaluation of her DVT.  Learning Points: This case reinforces the importance of considering thrombophilic conditions in patients presenting with PE  despite having no known or discernible risk factors. Early identification and treatment of inherited thrombophilias can significantly improve patient outcomes by preventing recurrent thromboembolic events.

Patient Information:   A 75-year-old Caucasian female was presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with complaints of a sudden shortness of breath. The patient  a retired school teacher  resides in upstate New York with her husband of 50 years. She is a non-smoker and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Medical History:   Her past medical history is significant with hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both under control with regular medication (metformin and amlodipine). The patient was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years back and is on statins since then. She underwent a total right knee arthroplasty two weeks prior. She denies any history of pulmonary disease  heart disease  or malignancies. There is no familial history of clotting disorders.  Findings:  When presented  patient was found to be tachycardic with a heart rate of 115 beats min  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min  and blood pressure was 145/85 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation was a bit low at 91% on room air. Physical examination also revealed a moderately obese woman in mild distress due to dyspnea but without palpable leg edema or homan’s sign.  Investigations:  A 12-lead ECG showed sinus tachycardia with no ST changes. Chest X-ray was unremarkable. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest with an intravenous contrast demonstrated a large central filling defect in the right pulmonary artery  further extending to the segmental and subsegmental branches suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism (PE).   Laboratory investigations reported elevated Troponin-I levels (0.6 ng/mL) and D-Dimer levels were significantly high with a value of 3500 ng/ml. A baseline blood investigation showed elevated fasting blood glucose and lipid panel was also deranged. Hemoglobin  white blood cell count  platelets  kidney and liver function tests were within normal limits. The patient’s calculated Well’s Score was a high risk of 9 points.  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was administered subcutaneous injections of Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) for immediate anticoagulation therapy  and started on Oxygen therapy to manage dyspnea. Thrombolysis was considered considering her age  but was decided against due to the risk factors involving a recent surgical procedure. The patient's condition stabilized after 24 hours of treatment.  She was later referred to a pulmonologist and a cardiologist for further outpatient follow-up and long-term anticoagulation therapy. PE was likely caused by deep vein thrombosis post-operative due to the recent knee replacement surgery along with her sedentary lifestyle.  Ethics:  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the treatment provided and for the use of her medical data for the purpose of documentation whilst maintaining her anonymity.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of considering PE in the differential diagnosis in a postoperative patient presenting with sudden dyspnea. Prompt diagnosis with stratification of risk and immediate initiation of anticoagulation therapy can significantly improve patient outcomes.

Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. X  an otherwise healthy 65-year-old retired mathematician  originally from Seattle  USA  presented to the Emergency Department. He is a non-smoker and has no known drug allergies. He does not consume alcohol and denies any substance abuse.  Chief Complaints: Mr. X reported experiencing sudden onset shortness of breath and pleuritic chest pain for the last three hours. The pain was sharp in nature  aggravated on inspiration  and not radiated anywhere.  Medical History: Mr. X has a history of hypertension  controlled by medication (Atenolol 50mg daily for the past 5 years)  and was recently diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) a month ago. He was on oral anticoagulants for the same. He denied past medical history of heart disease or diabetes. His family history is unremarkable.  Examination and Investigations: On physical examination  he had a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  heart rate was 122 beats per minute  blood pressure at 138/86 mmHg  O2 saturation 90% at room air  and he was afebrile. Chest auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds in the right lower part of the lung. Rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.   His laboratory findings on admission included a slightly increased troponin I (0.6 ng/mL [normal limit: <0.4 ng/mL])  His D-dimer was elevated at 800 ng/mL (normal limit: <500 ng/mL). EKG showed sinus tachycardia with a S1Q3T3 pattern.   A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest was performed  which showed a filling defect in the right pulmonary artery  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Treatment and outcome: Mr. X was immediately started on intravenous heparin. His breathlessness slightly improved over 24 hours. The cardiology consultation was obtained and the patient was switched to Rivaroxaban after 48 hours. He was discharged after 5 days with advice to follow up in the outpatient department in two weeks.  This case report emphasizes the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with unexplained dyspnea  especially who have recent or ongoing venous thromboembolism (VTE).  Contributors: Dr. YZ  Department of Pulmonology.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 65-year-old Male Patient with Hypertension and Type 2-Diabetes: A Case Report   Introduction:  We report a case of a 65-year-old male diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism (APE). The patient has a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The purpose of this case report is to highlight the intersection of various complex comorbidities with acute pulmonary embolism.  Case Description:  The 65-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with chief complaints of sudden chest pain  breathlessness  and fainting spells. He had a known medical history of poorly controlled hypertension along with type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was a non-smoker  non-alcoholic  and had a sedentary lifestyle.  On examination  his blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate was 110 per/min  respiratory rate was 24 breaths/min and oxygen saturation was 88% on room air. Lower limb examination did not show any signs of deep venous thrombosis.  Laboratory investigations revealed a high D-dimer level of 2500 ng/mL (normal: 0-500 ng/mL). Both the complete blood count and blood chemistries were within normal limits except for an elevated fasting blood glucose level of 180 mg/dL and HbA1c of 9.2%. An ECG showed signs of right heart strain  suggestive of pulmonary embolism.  A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the diagnosis by revealing a large thrombus in the right and left pulmonary arteries. Bedside transthoracic echocardiography showed signs of right ventricular dysfunction.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was immediately managed using anticoagulation therapy  with intravenous heparin. After a period of initial stabilization  his symptoms improved  and he was transitioned to oral apixaban. His diabetes and hypertension were also simultaneously managed with metformin and amlodipine  respectively.  During follow up after four weeks  the patient had significant symptomatic relief and his conditions  including hypertension and diabetes  were under better control. A repeat CTPA showed significant reduction in the size of the thrombus.  Discussion:  This case underscores the higher likelihood of encountering acute pulmonary embolism in patients with associated comorbidities like hypertension and diabetes  which could be potential risk factors. It also highlights the importance of immediate recognition and prompt anticoagulation management  alongside concomitant management of existing comorbidities.  Conclusion:  This case report illustrates the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism as a differential  particularly in older patients presenting with sudden chest pain and breathlessness and who have a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus. Early diagnosis and timely initiation of anticoagulation treatment are key to positive patient outcomes.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 52-year-old Caucasian Female with Obesity and Sedentary Lifestyle  Introduction: This case involves a 52-year-old Caucasian female who presented with sudden onset shortness of breath  chest discomfort  and exertional fatigue suggestive of an Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE).  Case Presentation:   The patient  Mrs. J  was a housewife with a BMI of 30.2 characterized as 'Obese' with a history of a sedentary lifestyle  but no known history of thrombotic disease. She had a longstanding history of hypertension well-controlled with Olmesartan 20mg once daily. She does not consume alcohol  smoke cigarettes  or use recreational drugs. She had no known family history of thrombotic diseases. Her mother had a history of hypertension and father had type II diabetes  but there was no record of cardiac disease or pulmonary issues.  Two weeks prior to her hospital admission  she returned from a 12-hour long-haul flight with her husband. She was slightly immobile during the flight because she had a window seat and hesitated to disturb her husband while he was sleeping. Within a week  she began to experience shortness of breath and chest discomfort upon exertion.    On the day of admission  she presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of severe shortness of breath accompanied by sharp chest pain that increased with deep breathing. At presentation  she was tachycardic with a pulse rate of 110bpm  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 26 cycles/min  and had oxygen saturations of 90% on room air.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  A clinical assessment suggested possible pulmonary embolism. A contrast-enhanced chest computed tomography (CT) revealed a large thrombus occluding the right pulmonary artery confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. Her D-dimer levels were significantly raised to 680 ng/mL (normal <500 ng/mL). An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed S1Q3T3 suggestive of cor pulmonale secondary to acute pulmonary thromboembolism. Ultrasonography of the lower limbs was performed to find the site of deep venous thrombosis  which revealed a clot in the right calf veins.  Therapeutic Intervention:  As soon as the diagnosis was confirmed  the patient was commenced on low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) followed by oral anticoagulation with rivaroxaban  and her oxygen saturation improved to 96% on 2L nasal cannula.   Follow-up and Outcomes:  During the hospital stay  Mrs. J continued to show improvement in her symptoms over the course of a week  and her oxygen requirement weaned off. She was discharged on rivaroxaban for six months with clear instructions about follow-ups and signs of complications/thrombosis.  Discussion:  This case emphasizes the severity and potential deadliness of acute pulmonary embolism  especially in people with risk factors such as prolonged immobility  obesity  and long haul flights. Early recognition and timely intervention is pivotal in the management of such cases.   Patient Perspective:   Mrs. J acknowledges her sedentary lifestyle as a contributing factor to her condition and is grateful for the timely intervention. She is committed to positive lifestyle modifications  including exercise and weight management.  Key Learning Points:  This case study highlights that a high index of suspicion for acute pulmonary emboli should be maintained in people presenting with sudden onset dyspnea  chest discomfort  particularly if they have recently taken long-haul flights or have other predisposing factors like obesity.

Patient Information: Mr. J is a 56-year-old Caucasian male with a body mass index (BMI) of 27.5. He is a non-smoker and consumes moderate quantities of alcohol. He is employed as an air traffic controller  a job that demands long hours of sitting.   Chief Complaint: The patient presented with sudden breathlessness  chest pain  and light-headedness.  History of Present Illness: Mr. J was in his usual state of health until 7 days ago when he started to experience progressive difficulty in breathing  accompanied by mild chest discomfort that exaggerated into severe chest pain which was described as ‘sharp’ and ‘stabbing.' The chest pain was also triggered on the deep inhalation. Further probing revealed that he has been feeling lightheaded intermittently.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  controlled on medication. There is no history of diabetes mellitus  coronary artery disease  or stroke. He also reported a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 10 years ago after a long-haul flight journey. He completed anticoagulation without recurrence  and there has been no family history suggestive of any clotting disorder. There has been no recent history of prolonged immobilization  surgery  or malignancy.  Investigations/Results: His initial pulse rate was 100 beats/minute and blood pressure was 130/85 mm of Hg. His oxygen saturation on room air was 94%. Laboratory results revealed a high D-dimer level. Chest X-ray was non-significant but ECG showed tachycardia. The diagnosis was confirmed with computed tomographic pulmonary angiography (CTPA)  which revealed a clot in the right pulmonary artery.   Assessment: With thorough case history  clinical findings  and investigation results  Mr. J was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Discussion: The patient's presentation is highly suggestive of a massive PE. Given Mr. J's history of DVT and his profession requiring long periods of sitting  it indicates prolonged periods of immobility  which is a major risk factor for DVT and consequent PE. The management involves immediate anticoagulation therapy  and since he is hemodynamically stable  he was started on low-molecular-weight Heparin and oral anticoagulant rivaroxaban. The patient was advised to follow-up in one week for reevaluation.   The case not only provides an insight into the clinical presentation of acute PE but also reinforces the significance of prolonged immobility as a risk factor of PE. More studies are warranted to elucidate optimal protocols for PE patients with prior history of VTE and strategies to reduce immobility-associated risks.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 68-year-old Female with History of Prolonged Immobility  Introduction:  This case report describes a 68-year old Caucasian female with acute symptomatic pulmonary embolism (PE)  with underlying risk factors including prolonged immobilization and obesity.  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female who lives in a semi-rural area  living alone with minimal assistance. She has no history of tobacco or alcohol use. She has a known history of Type II Diabetes  controlled with oral medication  and hypertension treated with Lisinopril therapy. She has no history of surgeries or hospitalizations previously.   The patient has a BMI of 30  indicating obesity  and spends most of her time immobile due to severe arthritis  which potentially puts her at risk of thromboembolic events. She takes over-the-counter NSAIDs for her arthritis pain.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented with acute onset of dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain  and a cough producing pink frothy sputum. On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and dyspneic  vital signs showed tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air  indicating respiratory compromise.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  The ECG showed sinus tachycardia and the chest X-ray was essentially normal. A D-Dimer test was done due to the high clinical suspicion for PE  which came back significantly elevated. A subsequent computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) confirmed a large clot in her right pulmonary artery  indicating acute PE.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was started on therapeutic dose subcutaneous enoxaparin with plans to bridge anticoagulation to oral warfare. Her Oxygen saturation improved with supplemental oxygen and her symptoms gradually improved over the next few days in the hospital.  Follow-Up:  In follow-up  the patient was transitioned to apixaban for long term anticoagulation after reviewing the risks and benefits. She was referred to the outpatient pulmonary clinic and physiotherapy for mobilization and rehabilitation.  Clinical Lessons/Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of risk stratification and appropriate treatment in elderly patients who have prolonged immobility and other risk factors for venous thromboembolism. Close collaboration between health care professionals in inpatient and outpatient settings is of utmost importance to prevent morbidity and mortality.  Acknowledgements: We would like to thank the patient for agreeing to participate and for providing written consent for this case report. We also would like to thank the interdisciplinary team involved in her care.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian female  Mrs. A  currently residing in New York City. She is a retired bank officer living with her husband and has been a smoker for over 40 years. She has a family history of hypertension and heart disease  with her mother passing away due to heart-related issues at the age of 82.  Presenting Problem:  Mrs. A presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of sudden onset chest pain and mild shortness of breath that started two hours ago while watching television. The chest pain was stabbing in nature and localized in the middle of the chest  and seems to increase with deep breathing.   Past Medical History:  Mrs. A has a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type-2 diabetes mellitus  all of which have been managed with amlodipine  atorvastatin  and metformin  respectively. She was also diagnosed with peripheral vascular disease 3 years ago  which has been treated conservatively. She had no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings:  Vital signs at ED presentation were as follows: temperature 37.2°C  blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 90% on room air. On physical examination  she appeared visibly anxious. Cardiac examination revealed tachycardia with no murmur. Auscultation of the lungs revealed decreased breath sounds on the right lower lung field.  Diagnostic Assessment:  With the suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was ordered which confirmed the presence of a large clot in the right pulmonary artery. Lab tests showed a slightly elevated D-dimer level and troponin level. Her EKG showed a sinus tachycardia and right axis deviation which further supported the diagnosis of PE.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Mrs. A was immediately started on oxygen therapy and administered intravenous unfractionated heparin. Given her high risk of PE  she was admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring.  Follow-up & Outcomes:  Her hospital course was uneventful with gradual improvement in her symptoms over the following week. She was transitioned to oral anticoagulation therapy with warfarin before discharge from the hospital. She was advised to quit smoking and was designed a personalized diet and exercise routine. Outpatient regimen included controlling her high blood pressure and blood glucose levels  and management of her hyperlipidemia. A referral was made for follow-up care with a pulmonologist in two weeks.  Patient Perspective:  Mrs. A expressed her willingness to manage her lifestyle habits and expressed gratitude for the care provided.   Informed Consent:  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for publishing her medical history.  Key Learning Points:  This case highlights the importance of considering acute PE in the differential diagnosis when patients with known PVD present with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath. Furthermore  this case underscores the importance of patient history taking and radiological investigations for diagnosis.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 65-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher.  Chief Complaint:  Sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea which has persisted for approximately six hours.  History of Present Illness: The patient was at home when she suddenly experienced a sharp  stabbing chest pain that has progressively gotten worse. The chest pain is non-radiating  increases with deep breathing  and is accompanied by an increasing shortness of breath  light-headedness  and diaphoresis. She has no history of fever  cough  hemoptysis  or recent travel.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. She underwent a right total knee arthroplasty two weeks ago. She reports no known drug allergies. She has never smoked and only drinks alcohol occasionally.  Family History: Mother and father succumbed to myocardial infarction and stroke respectively  in their 80s. The patient has one sibling  a sister  with no history of cardiovascular disease.  Physical Exam: On examination  the patient appeared anxious and in respiratory distress. Vital signs showed a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  temperature of 36.8°C  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Her BMI was calculated to be 29 kg/m2. Auscultation of the lungs revealed decreased breath sounds without wheezes or crackles.  Investigations: A D-dimer test was markedly elevated and chest radiography did not show any significant abnormalities. Electrocardiogram showed a sinus tachycardia and the classic S1Q3T3 pattern indicative of acute right heart strain. Further confirmation via CT pulmonary angiography showed a large thrombus lodged in the right main pulmonary artery - a definitive diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment and Follow-up: The patient was immediately started on anticoagulation with intravenous heparin. After stabilization  she was switched to oral Factor Xa inhibitor for a duration of 6 months. The patient was also educated about the signs of bleeding  a potential side effect of her medication. She was discharged five days later and scheduled for regular outpatient follow-ups with Cardiology and Hematology for anticoagulation monitoring and investigation for possible hypercoagulability disorders.  Informed Consent: Informed written consent was taken from the patient for publication of this case report. Her identity has been kept confidential.  This case demonstrates the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in the differential diagnosis for a patient presenting with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea  especially in those with recent major surgery as a provoking event.

Patient Information/Overview:  The patient  a 63-year-old Caucasian male was rushed to the emergency department with complaints of sudden shortness of breath  chest pain  and an alarming drop in blood pressure. The patient is a heavy smoker  with a history of 20-pack years and is moderately obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 30. His past medical history revealed that he has type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and elevated cholesterol levels. There is no known familial history of pulmonary or cardiovascular diseases.   Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  the patient presented pale skin  difficulty in breathing  and decreased breath sounds on the right side. He also demonstrated tachycardia  with a heart rate of 110 bpm. Oxygen saturation level measured was 89% on room air. His blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg.   Diagnosis:  Laboratory investigations were immediately ordered due to suspicion of Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE). D-dimer test results came back elevated. Chest computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis showing a large filling defect in the right pulmonary artery  indicative of an acute pulmonary embolism. Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed S1Q3T3 pattern which is a classical sign of a large pulmonary embolism. Troponin and Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) levels were also raised which points towards right heart strain.   Treatment:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous (IV) heparin and given supplemental oxygen to manage his acute symptoms. He was later started on oral anticoagulation in the form of warfarin. Furthermore  physical therapy was prescribed to address his obesity and sedentary lifestyle to prevent future PE. Counseling for smoking cessation was also provided.  Outcome:  The patient responded well to the treatment  his oxygen saturation improved to 95%  and the tachycardia subsided. The patient was educated about the importance of regular follow-up  compliance to medication  good dietary habits  and regular light physical activity.  Follow-up:  Regular follow-ups were scheduled for the patient to monitor his response to treatment and any side effects from anticoagulation. His anticoagulation status was regularly checked with prothrombin time (PT) and INR.  In conclusion  this case outlines the necessity of immediate diagnosis and timely intervention in the presentation of acute pulmonary embolism  particularly in at-risk patients with lifestyle-related co-morbidities such as obesity  smoking  and diabetes. It also underscores the importance of managing underlying risk factors to prevent future incidents.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information:   A 68-year old caucasian male was admitted to the emergency department with acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient holds a sedentary lifestyle in a quiet suburban community. He is a retired factory worker  a nonsmoker  and has a reported history of moderate alcohol consumption.  His medical history consists of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and Type II diabetes mellitus  all of which are managed with oral medications. He has no reported history of pulmonary diseases or cancer and no family history of thromboembolic disease. He underwent a hip replacement surgery about three weeks prior to admission  after which he had been largely immobile.   Clinical Findings:  The patient presented at rest  dyspneic and tachypneic  with a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg and heart rate of 108 beats/min. An EKG showed sinus tachycardia and blood tests showed a significantly elevated D-Dimer level (1500 ng/mL - normal range <500 ng/mL). His oxygen saturation was 90% on room air.  Diagnostic Assessment:  A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was ordered considering the clinical picture and elevated D-Dimer levels. It showed a large central filling defect in the right pulmonary artery indicating a large clot.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on therapeutic anticoagulation with intravenous heparin. Further  after stabilizing the patient  systemic thrombolytic therapy was given due to the significant clot burden and the patient's hemodynamic instability.  The patient was also given oxygen therapy to maintain an oxygen saturation of over 95%.   Follow-up and Outcome:  The patient began to show considerable improvement within the following 48 hours. His dyspnea decreased and oxygen saturation levels improved to 95-97%.  After 5 days  he was transitioned to oral anticoagulants with a plan to continue for at least 3 months. He will be re-evaluated at the time to assess the necessity for further anticoagulation therapy.  Patient was discharged with a home care plan that included strict medication adherence  gradual increase in mobilization  and diet control. The importance of regular follow up was emphasized.  Learning Points:  This case highlights the need for a high degree of suspicion for pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with unexplained dyspnea  especially in the setting of relative immobility such as post-surgical states  even in the absence of traditionally known risk factors like smoking or a personal/familial history of venous thromboembolism.    It also highlights the importance of early diagnosis and aggressive treatment of pulmonary embolism to prevent unnecessary morbidity and mortality.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 59-year-old Male with Type II Diabetes and Hypertension  Patient Information: A 59-year-old Caucasian male  an office worker with a sedentary lifestyle  presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of sudden onset chest pain  dyspnea  and syncope.  Clinical Presentation and Timeline: The patient reported progressive chest pain for the past two hours  along with an episode of syncope. His past medical history was significant for Type II diabetes and hypertension.   Relevant Past Medical History: The patient was diagnosed with Type II diabetes about 10 years prior and subsequently with hypertension 7 years ago. His conditions were managed with metformin for diabetes and losartan for hypertension. Apart from occasional alcohol intake  he denied any use of tobacco or other recreational substances.  Physical Examination and Diagnostic Assessment: On arrival  he was tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute and had an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. His blood pressure was 138/85 mmHg  and he was tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute. His body mass index was 32 kg/m2  denoting obesity.  An ECG showed signs of acute right heart strain (S1Q3T3 pattern). Laboratory findings showed elevated D-dimer levels and mildly elevated troponins. ABG analysis found hypoxemia and a mild respiratory alkalosis.  Based on these findings  the patient was sent for computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)  which showed a large thrombus in the right pulmonary artery extending into the lobar branches. This confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.   Diagnostic Intervention and Treatment: The patient was immediately started on therapeutic low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and admitted to the intensive care unit for further monitoring. Consultation with a cardiologist and hematologist was made.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was scheduled for pulmonary thromboembolectomy by the cardiology team after initial stabilization. Post operatively  the patient was kept on LMWH for three months. Gradual mobilization was initiated. Patient education was provided about the importance of a healthy lifestyle and regular exercises.  Follow-up and Outcomes: On follow-up after three months  the patient reported significant improvement in chest pain and dyspnea. His oxygen saturation had improved to 96% on room air  and repeat CTPA demonstrated resolution of previous clot burden.  Learning Points & Discussion: This case highlights the potentially fatal complication of a sedentary lifestyle and obesity in patients with chronic diseases like diabetes and hypertension. It reinforces the importance of regular monitoring  lifestyle modifications  and patient education in this vulnerable population. Moreover  early diagnosis and suitable interventional management can significantly improve prognostic outcomes in acute pulmonary embolism.

Case Report  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old African-American male presented to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that exacerbates with deep inhalation. He also reported mild dizziness and profuse  cold sweats.   Past Medical History:  The patient's past medical history is positive for type II diabetes mellitus  which was diagnosed approximately seven years ago  and for hypertension  currently under control with daily medication  specifically 50 mg of Losartan. There is no history of any cardiovascular events  although he is an active smoker for the past 30 years with a 20-pack-year smoking history. His family history is remarkable for premature heart disease with his mother and younger brother both experiencing myocardial infarction in their 50s. Patient denies any recent lengthy immobilization  long distance travel  or any familial history of blood clotting disorders.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  he appeared dyspneic but was alert and oriented. His body mass index was calculated to be 29. His vital signs were: temperature 37.1°C  pulse 98 bpm  respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute  blood pressure 142/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation 93% while breathing room air. Lung examination revealed slightly decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes bilaterally. The remainder of his physical exam was normal  with no signs of deep venous thrombosis in the extremities.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given the patient's presentation and risk factors  a clinical suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism was made. An immediate D-dimer test was ordered  which returned significantly elevated. Additionally  EKG showed sinus tachycardia but no signs of right heart strain. A CT pulmonary angiography was ordered which confirmed the diagnosis by demonstrating emboli within bilateral segmental pulmonary arteries.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was immediately started on intravenous heparin  and his oxygenation was supported with supplemental oxygen. Eventually  he was transitioned to oral anticoagulation with Rivaroxaban for convenient long-term management.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient's symptoms of shortness of breath gradually improved over the course of hospitalization. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for 2 weeks after discharge to monitor the patient’s symptoms  re-evaluate his anticoagulation plan  and discuss smoking cessation strategies.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients with sudden onset breathlessness  chest pain and with several risk factors  including smoking  hypertension  and family history. Early diagnosis  adequate anticoagulation  and appropriate follow-up care can lead to better patient outcomes.

Patient Information and Demographic: A Caucasian female  aged 57 years  presented to the emergency department. She is a nonsmoker and nonalcoholic. She lives with her family and is a high-school teacher by profession. She has no past history of drug addiction or substance abuse.   Presenting Complaint: The patient had been complaining of experiencing sudden-onset shortness of breath and sharp chest pain for 24 hours. The pain was not radiating and exacerbated by deep breathing.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left lower limb 2 years back. The condition had been managed with anticoagulants which she discontinued a year back. The only other health concern was controlled hypertension. She had no history of cancer  heart diseases  or surgeries in the past. There were no known allergies. Her family history consisted of an uncle with a pulmonary embolism.   Physical Examination: On examination  she had a body temperature of 37.8 degree Celsius  heart rate was 110 bpm  respiratory rate was 26 breaths per minute  blood pressure was found to be 130/80 mm Hg  and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. She was awake and oriented but agitated due to chest pain.  Investigations: Routine blood investigation was done  a complete blood count and coagulation profile were within normal limits. D-Dimer test showed an elevated level of 600 ng/ml. ECG showed sinus tachycardia but no signs of right heart strain. Chest X-ray did not show any active lung disease. The suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism was high and thus  computerized tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a large clot burden in the right main pulmonary artery and its branches.   Management: Considering her history of DVT and high risk due to the large clot burden  she was initially managed with anticoagulation therapy (low molecular weight heparin). The option of thrombolysis or a pulmonary embolectomy was reserved in case of hemodynamic instability. Her clinical condition improved after anticoagulation initiation.  Discussion: The patient's previous history of DVT and discontinuation of anticoagulants coupled with the presentation of acute chest pain and shortness of breath led to a high suspicion diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. The CTPA scan confirmed the diagnosis. Due to her previous history and the large clot burden  the decision was taken to commence anticoagulation therapy immediately. The critical decision at this point was regarding aggressive measures like thrombolysis or surgical embolectomy. As the patient was hemodynamically stable and responded well to anticoagulation therapy  these invasive measures were reserved for possible future use.   The patient was discharged after five days with no signs of chest pain or difficulty in respiration. She was advised to continue the oral anticoagulant medication and regular follow up.

CASE REPORT – ACUTE PULMONARY EMBOLISM  Patient Information: A 67-year-old Caucasian female presented herself at the emergency department.  Chief Complaint: The patient complained of sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain  revealing symptoms that began earlier the same day.  History of Present Illness: The patient stated she has been in her usual state of health until four hours prior to admission when she suddenly developed severe difficulty breathing accompanied with chest pain. The pain started in the center of her chest and radiated to her back. No associated symptoms like sweating  vomiting  or fainting were reported.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in left lower limb two years ago  for which she was treated with Warfarin for six months to a satisfactory response. Moreover  she has hypertension  and type II diabetes  both being managed appropriately with regular medications. She mentioned she has been irregular with her medications for DVT.  Social History: The patient is a former smoker and mentioned quitting ten years ago. She has a history of mild alcohol consumption with no history of illicit drug use or occupational exposures. The patient lives with her husband and is independent for all her daily tasks.  Examination: Upon inspection  the patient appeared distressed due to shortness of breath and had a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. Other vitals included pulse -110 per minute  blood pressure - 145/95 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 91% on room air. The cardiovascular system examination showed tachycardia with regular rhythm. The chest was bilaterally symmetrical  vesicular breath sounds with no added sounds were noted. No swelling or tenderness in the lower limbs was noticed.  Initial Laboratory Investigations: Standard blood tests were ordered  with her D-dimer levels being significantly elevated. The Chest X-ray was normal and the ECG showed a sinus tachycardia with right bundle branch block.  Diagnosis and Management: Considering her elevated D-dimer levels  history of DVT and her clinical condition  a computed tomography angiography (CTA) was ordered to confirm the clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism. The CTA revealed multiple filling defects in both lungs consistent with PE.  She was immediately put on oxygen support via nasal cannula and started on therapeutic anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin.   Disposition: Given the acute nature of her illness and as her symptoms were severe  the patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for close monitoring and adjustment of treatment.  Conclusion: This case reaffirms the importance of a thorough medical history in manage acute conditions  especially in patients who have got a history of DVT  given the known risk for PE. The fact that the patient was irregular with her anticoagulants might have contributed to the recurrence of thrombotic event. It is essential to continually educate patients about the risks of medication non-compliance.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Woman with Prior History of Deep Vein Thrombosis: A Case Report  Introduction:  This case report discusses a 45-year-old Caucasian woman with an acute episode of pulmonary embolism (PE) with previously diagnosed deep vein thrombosis (DVT).  Case Report:  The patient  a 45-year-old woman with a known history of recurrent DVT  was brought to our emergency department reporting sudden shortness of breath. Associated symptoms included chest pain that worsened with deep breathing  mild dizziness  and cough with bloody sputum.  Her medical history was significant for recurrent DVT and she was on anticoagulant therapy (Rivaroxaban). She is a non-smoker  zero alcohol consumption and no history of illicit drug usage. She had a desk job with minimal physical activity and was a known case of Obesity (BMI-32). There was no family history of coagulation disorders but her mother had a history of stroke.  On clinical examination  the patient was dyspneic with respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  heart rate 105 beats per minute  blood pressure was 125/85 mmHg  and oxygen saturation was 90 percent on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Her D-dimer levels were significantly elevated  which prompted an immediate CT scan of her chest. Imaging indicated a Large embolus lodged in the right pulmonary artery (RPA) confirming the diagnosis of acute PE.   Full blood count  comprehensive metabolic panel  coagulation profile (apart from D-dimer)  and arterial blood gases were within normal limits. Echocardiography exhibited right ventricular strain suggesting the severity of the embolism.  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was promptly started on therapeutic heparin and admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). An inferior vena cava filter was placed due to her complication of experiencing a PE despite being on anticoagulation.  Her hospital stay lasted for 10 days during which her symptoms gradually improved. The patient was discharged with advice on high mobility  weight loss  and long-term anticoagulation therapy. She was also scheduled for regular outpatient follow-ups including extensive laboratory monitoring.  Discussion:  This case highlights the importance of high clinical suspicion for PE in patients with past medical history of DVT and emphasizes the need for aggressive management in these high-risk patients. It also underscores the importance of lifestyle changes as part of the management plan for patients with a history of thromboembolic phenomenon.

Patient Information:   A 63-year-old Hispanic male arrived at the emergency department via ambulance. The patient reports a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and slight confusion; symptoms were present since he woke up in the morning. He lives with his wife and adult son  who alerted the emergency services. He is an ex-smoker  having ceased 15 years ago  and consumes alcohol in moderation. He is a retired electrician.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he has been on medication (Losartan and atorvastatin) for the past seven years. In addition  the patient had surgery to repair a hernia three weeks ago from which he was reported to be recovering well. He has no history of cardiac diseases  blood clots  disorders  or malignancy. He has obesity with a BMI of 31.9 kg/m²  and he doesn't regularly engage in physical activities. He has no known drug allergies.  Case Presentation:  Upon receiving the patient at the emergency department  the vital signs indicated tachycardia (Pulse 110 bpm)  a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  oxygen saturation was 88% on room air  and his temperature was 37.2°C. His ECG showed sinus tachycardia with no signs of acute myocardial infarction. The physical examination didn't reveal any significant findings except for the signs of respiratory distress (use of accessory muscles  diaphoresis) and distal leg swelling.  Diagnosis & Assessment:   The patient's symptoms  history  and presentation were suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism  which was confirmed by a CT pulmonary angiogram  which demonstrated multiple clots in both pulmonary arteries. Laboratory investigations highlighted elevated D-dimer levels. The patient was sent for lower extremity venous doppler ultrasound that showed bilateral lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Treatment & Outcome:  He was immediately started on intravenous anticoagulation (heparin) and administered supplemental oxygen. Given the patient's hemodynamic stability  he was not considered a candidate for thrombolytic therapy. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring and further management. His condition improved over the following days  with relief in symptoms  and he was shifted to oral anticoagulants (Rivaroxaban) for a prolonged period to prevent recurrences. After stabilization  he was discharged with advice to maintain a healthy lifestyle and continue his prescribed medications.  Follow-up:  Appointments were scheduled for follow-up visits with the patient’s primary care physician and a pulmonology specialist to monitor his condition and manage his anticoagulant therapy. An early mobilization plan was discussed to reduce the risk of further blood clot formation  as the patient had been relatively sedentary after his hernia surgery. His medications need to be consistently evaluated for dose adjustments to prevent any side effects or interactions.    This case underlines the importance of prompt recognition and management of acute pulmonary embolism  a potentially fatal condition  particularly in patients with recent surgery and prolonged immobility. It also reinforces the need for implementation of DVT prophylaxis in post-operative patients.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Patient Information ---------------------- Age: 67 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Location: Birkenhead  England Occupational History: Retired Vehicle Mechanic  Presenting Complaint: ----------------------------- Shortness of breath  chest pain radiating to the back  and intermittent lightheadedness for the past two days  Past Medical History ----------------------------- Type II Diabetes Mellitus (On Metformin 1000mg twice daily) Hypertension (Treated with Losartan 50mg daily) Previous deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 8 years ago following a knee surgery  managed with warfarin. No known drug allergies.   Current Examination: -------------------------- Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths/min Heart Rate: 102 beats/min Blood Pressure: 145/90 mmHg SpO2: 89% on room air  Physical examination reveals a slightly distressed patient with notably perspiration. Auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds on the lower right lung field.  Investigations: ------------------- Electrocardiogram showed S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute right heart strain.  D-dimer level was elevated beyond the normal range. Urgent CTA confirmed the presence of multiple emboli in the right pulmonary artery.  Lower extremity ultrasound was negative for DVT.   Treatment: ------------- Patient was immediately administered high-flow oxygen therapy (4-6 L/min) via non-rebreather mask. A bolus dose of unfractionated heparin was given followed by infusion to maintain therapeutic levels while in hospital.   Outcome: ---------- The patient's symptoms improved over the next 48 hours. He was transitioned to oral anticoagulation with Rivaroxaban  with a planned course of treatment for six months under the care of his general practitioner. He was advised to get compression stockings and to avoid long periods of immobility to reduce the risk of further episodes of DVT. He was also referred for a follow-up with a thrombophilia clinic for a potential genetic predisposition screening due to his recurrent thromboembolic events.  Conclusion: ----------------- High clinical suspicion and quick diagnostic measures were vital in the successful management of this patient. This case also signifies the need for extended anticoagulation in recurrent thromboembolic incidents.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Post-Menopausal Woman: A case study  Introduction: Pulmonary embolism (PE) is a prevalent  yet highly misdiagnosed clinical condition  resulting from obstructions in the pulmonary vasculature. This study presents a case of acute PE in a 52-year-old postmenopausal woman.  Patient Information: The patient in the present case  referred to as Mr. J  is a Caucasian female  aged 52  from Milwaukee  Wisconsin. She is the mother of two children and practices as a kindergarten teacher. She has a BMI of 27 indicating overweight  non-smoker  doesn't consume alcohol  leads a moderately active lifestyle  and has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings: Ms. J presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden-onset dyspnea  chest pain  and palpitations. Initial vitals showed tachycardia (heart rate  118 bpm)  increased respiratory rate (22 breaths per minute)  blood pressure was 136/78 mmHg  and oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 92% on room air.  Past Medical History: Ms. J has a past history of gallbladder removal surgery (cholecystectomy) 3 weeks prior to the current hospital visit. She has been postmenopausal for 2 years  with associated obesity and a family history of venous thromboembolism (mother and older brother). She also has a history of hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril) and has never been diagnosed with any form of heart disease or diabetes.  Clinical progression: Conventional diagnostic protocols  including D-dimer test  were conducted and returned positive. Computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) showed small-to-medium-sized thrombi in the right and left pulmonary arteries. An electrocardiogram showed signs of right heart strain (S1Q3T3).  Treatment: Ms. J was stabilized with oxygen therapy and promptly started on intravenous heparin for anticoagulation.   Outcome & Follow-Up: She responded well to the treatment over the following days. Her chest pain and dyspnea improved  her SpO2 returned to 98% and tachycardia had eased off to 84 bpm by day 3 of admission. She remained in the hospital for observation for 5 days  was transitioned from IV Heparin to oral Rivaroxaban. She was discharged  with follow-up appointments scheduled for further assessment and to monitor response to the ongoing anticoagulation therapy.  Discussion: In patients with recent surgical interventions  PE remains a major complication  particularly in postmenopausal women. Early identification  diagnosis  and administration of anticoagulant therapy significantly reduce morbidity and mortality risk.  Patient Consent:  Informed consent was obtained from the patient to allow this report's publication.   Conclusion: This report emphasizes the need for a high index of suspicion for PE in patients presenting with immediate post-operative dyspnea and chest pain  especially considering previous potential risk factors such as recent surgery  family history of VTE  post-menopausal state  and obesity.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Hypertensive Male: A Case Report  Patient Information: The patient is a 52-year-old Caucasian male  residing in New York City  working as a financial advisor. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father suffered from a myocardial infarction  while his mother has been diagnosed with hypertension.  Past medical history: The patient has a medical history significant for chronic hypertension  which has remained under control with Lisinopril 10mg once daily. He also has obesity with a BMI of 30.3 and has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus that he manages with Metformin 500mg twice daily.  Presenting Complaints: The patient arrived at the emergency department accompanied by his wife  presenting with sudden onset dyspnea  sharp pleuritic chest pain  and lightheadedness.  Examination & Investigations: Upon examination  he was tachypneic and hypotensive (BP- 90/50 mm Hg)  with an increased heart rate (HR- 110 bpm). Oxygen saturation on room air was 89%. The laboratory report revealed an elevated serum troponin level and D-dimer. An urgent computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) demonstrated a large clot obstructing the right and left main pulmonary arteries  consistent with acute bilateral pulmonary embolism. Lower limb Doppler ultrasound also revealed deep venous thrombosis in the right lower limb  indicating the probable source of the emboli.  Clinical Course: The patient was immediately given a bolus of intravenous unfractionated heparin followed by a continuous infusion. An inferior vena cava filter was placed for prevention of further embolic events. During his hospitalization  his dyspnea gradually improved and his vital signs stabilized.  Discussion: This case demonstrates acute pulmonary embolism in a patient with multiple risk factors namely  chronic hypertension  obesity  and type 2 diabetes  creating a hypercoagulable state. His family history of cardiovascular disease further underscored his risk profile. Early recognition and immediate anticoagulation were critical to improving his prognosis.  Conclusion: The high index of suspicion for pulmonary embolism and timely initiation of anticoagulation was key to the favorable clinical outcome in this case. This case also highlights the need for early recognition of the thrombotic risk profile in patients with similar comorbidities and lifestyle factors. Health education regarding symptom recognition and regular health check-ups could also contribute to early detection and better long-term outcomes in such patients.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 55-Year-Old Female: A Case Report  Introduction:   We report a case of acute pulmonary embolism in a 55-year-old Caucasian female patient  who presented with sudden chest pain  shortness of breath and fainting.  Case Presentation:  The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian female  non-smoker  with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and had undergone a total right knee replacement six weeks prior to the presentation. She had been otherwise healthy until six hours before admission when she experienced sudden-onset chest pain. The pain was described as dull  continuous  and located in the substernal area. This was also associated with shortness of breath  light-headedness  and one episode of syncope.   The patient denied any recent trauma  long-duration travel  family or personal history of blood clot disorders. She was on regular medications for her hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and had been prescribed a prophylactic daily dose of low-molecular-weight heparin following her knee replacement operation.  Upon examination  blood pressure was 105/70 mmHg  heart rate was 120 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 90% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Respiratory exam disclosed decreased breath sounds on the lower lung fields bilaterally. Lower limbs were symmetric with no edema or warmth.  An electrocardiogram demonstrated sinus tachycardia with right bundle branch block and S1Q3T3 pattern. Chest X-ray was unremarkable. D-dimer level was significantly elevated. Due to the high clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism  a computed tomographic angiogram of the chest was performed  revealing bilateral pulmonary emboli.   The patient was treated with thrombolytics and she was started on therapeutic anticoagulation therapy  with significant improvement in her oxygenation and symptoms over the next several hours. The hospital's multidisciplinary team was involved in her care  suggesting the cause of pulmonary embolism could be postoperative immobility along with her non-modifiable risk (age) and modifiable risk factors (hypertension and hyperlipidemia). Strategies were put in place for optimal medical management  physiotherapy  and future prevention.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the complex and serious nature of acute pulmonary embolism  especially in postoperative patients with other risk factors. It emphasizes the importance of swift diagnosis and treatment  as well as the critical role of preventive strategies in at-risk patients.

Patient Information  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset of severe dyspnea  chest pain  and episodes of fainting. He resides in a community in Northern California  retired  and lives with his wife. He denies smoking but concedes to drinking alcohol socially. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle since retirement.  Medical History  The patient has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are being controlled with medication. He denies any history of diabetes mellitus  pulmonary disease  or cardiovascular diseases. The patient also reports he underwent a total hip replacement surgery 6 weeks prior to this current episode  following which he was bedbound for an extended period of time. There is no known history of deep venous thrombosis  bleeding disorder  atrial fibrillation  or malignancy. He is currently administered Lisinopril for hypertension and Simvastatin for high cholesterol levels.  Investigations and Diagnosis  The patient's vitals revealed a blood pressure of 138/85 mmHg  heart rate of 107 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. His ECG showed sinus tachycardia without any signs of myocardial ischemia. Chest radiography didn’t reveal any acute cardiopulmonary abnormality  and there were no abnormalities detected on physical examination.   Due to his symptoms and recent immobility following surgery  a suspicion of pulmonary embolism (PE) was raised. A D-dimer test was ordered and came out significantly high  suggesting possible blood clot formation. Subsequently  a computed tomography angiography (CTA) scan was performed and confirmed the presence of a large clot in the right pulmonary artery confirming the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment and Follow-up  Immediately  the patient was started on intravenous heparin  following which his symptoms started to improve. A follow-up echocardiogram revealed mild right ventricular dilation  but there were no signs of severe right heart strain. Further screening for thrombophilia and malignancy were done  of which all results came out normal.  The patient was transitioned to oral anticoagulant therapy with rivaroxaban before being discharged. He was instructed to regularly follow-up with his primary care physician  with strict instructions for medication compliance.  Outcome  The patient’s recovery was uncomplicated  and after 3-months follow-up  he was symptom-free with normalized D-dimer levels. He will continue on anticoagulation therapy for additional 3 months considering his risk factors and will continue for lifelong if any recurrent events.  Take-Home Message  This case highlights the importance of considering a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with sudden onset dyspnea  especially with risk factors like recent surgery or prolonged immobilization. Early diagnosis and immediate treatment significantly impact the prognosis in such cases.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a recent total hip arthroplasty surgery four weeks ago. The patient is a retired accountant  living with his wife in a suburban community. He has been a non-smoker for the past 10 years  drinks alcohol socially  and does not have a known history of any allergies.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient arrived at the emergency department after experiencing an unexpected episode of lightheadedness  increased heart rate (tachycardia)  and acute onset of breathlessness that started while he was reading the newspaper early in the morning. Associated symptoms were diaphoresis and chest heaviness.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic. He was tachycardic  with pulse 110 beats per minute  blood pressure was 130/82 mmHg  respiratory rate 24 per minute with signs of labored breathing. Oxygen saturation measured 90% in room air. Cardiac examination revealed a regular rhythm and no audible murmurs. Respiratory examination showed decreased breath sounds in the right lower lung without any apparent wheezing or rales. Abdominal and neurological examinations were unremarkable.  Lab Tests and Imaging:  Laboratory investigations revealed elevated D-dimer levels. Complete blood counts  electrolytes  liver and renal function tests were within normal ranges. ECG showed sinus tachycardia with no signs of myocardial infarction. A Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) was immediately performed due to a high clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism and revealed a large embolus lodged in the right pulmonary artery extending into its lower lobe branches.  Treatment and Progress:  Based on the CTPA findings  the patient was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism. Anticoagulation therapy was initiated immediately with intravenous administration of heparin followed by a transition to oral warfarin. He showed marked clinical improvement over the next few days with a decrease in breathlessness and tachycardia.   Conclusion:   This case showcases an excellent example of acute pulmonary embolism likely secondary to deep vein thrombosis (DVT) formed post-hip arthroplasty  a known high-risk surgery for thromboembolism. It emphasizes the need for appropriate prophylaxis and high clinical suspicion for such complications in the immediate postoperative period to guide early diagnosis and treatment.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Male with Past Medical History of Deep Vein Thrombosis  Patient Profile:  Mr. A  a 52-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath. He is a pack-a-day smoker and has a sedentary job. His past medical history is significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a lower leg fracture five years prior  which was treated with a course of anticoagulants.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient described the chest pain as sharp and pleuritic  worsening on deep inspiration. He also reported mild hemoptysis and an episode of syncope prior to presenting at the ED. There were no symptoms of fever  cough  or wheezing. He has been increasingly sedentary in recent weeks due to community quarantine restrictions and increased work-from-home duties.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  the patient was tachypneic and tachycardic with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and heart rate of 110 beats per minute. Oxygen saturation was below normal at 90% on room air. Auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds in the right lower lobe. There were signs of right lower limb swelling and tenderness on palpation  suggestive of a possible DVT recurrence.  Investigations:  A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) showed a S1Q3T3 pattern indicative of right heart strain. A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  with a large embolus visible in the right lower lobe pulmonary artery. A D-dimer test was also markedly elevated at 5000 ng/mL (normal range: <=500 ng/mL). A duplex ultrasonography of the patient's right leg revealed an occlusive thrombus in the distal femoral vein.  Treatment and Outcomes:  The patient was immediately started on therapeutic anticoagulation with low-molecular-weight heparin and admitted to the medical intensive care unit for close monitoring given the size of the PE and his unstable vitals. Over the next few days  with ongoing anticoagulation treatment  the patient's symptoms improved significantly. Follow-up CTPA after two weeks showed significant resolution of the pulmonary embolism.   Discussion:  This case underlines the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients with a history of DVT presenting with chest pain and shortness of breath  especially in those with increased sedentary behavior. Early recognition and prompt treatment are vital to prevent severe complications and mortality.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-aged Male with a History of Sedentary Lifestyle   Patient Information:  Mr. J is a 52-year-old Caucasian male from a suburban town. He is married  has two adult children  and currently works as a software engineer with minimal physical activity. He measures approximately 175cm in height and weighs around 98 kg. His BMI is calculated to be 31.9  placing him in the category of obesity. Mr. J is a former smoker  having quit eight years prior  and reports moderate alcohol consumption on the weekends. He does not have any known drug use.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J has a history of essential hypertension  for which he has been prescribed Amlodipine 5mg daily for the past five years. He is also a type 2 diabetic  managed with Metformin 1000mg twice a day for the past three years. There are no known allergies. Family history reveals a positive cardiovascular disease history in his mother and father both  with heart attacks occurring in their mid-50s.  Presenting Complaints:  In the emergency department  Mr. J presented with sudden onset breathlessness lasting a couple of hours. This was associated with a sharp chest pain that worsened with deep breaths but was not relieved by rest or changing positions. He denied any associated symptoms such as cough  hemoptysis  fever  or syncope.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  Mr. J was in apparent distress  appearing anxious and sweaty with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. His blood pressure was 148/94 mmHg  heart rate was 110 bpm and temperature was 98.6 Fahrenheit.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Suspecting a possible pulmonary embolism given his sudden onset symptoms and risk factors  a computed tomogram pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was ordered which revealed an intraluminar filling defect in the left pulmonary artery consistent with an acute pulmonary embolism.   Laboratory tests showed D-dimer levels elevated at 1200 ng/mL. Troponin T level was slightly raised at 0.05 ng/mL. Complete blood count  renal function test  liver function test were all within normal limits.  Management:  Mr. J was started on systemic anticoagulation therapy with intravenous heparin. Hypoxemia was managed with supplemental oxygen to maintain oxygen saturation above 94%. After stabilizing him with these measures  he was subsequently transferred to the intensive care unit for further assessment and treatment.  Follow Up:  During follow-up  treatment with oral anticoagulants was initiated. Mr. J was also encouraged to increase physical activity and was referred to a nutritionist for assistance with weight management.    The case exemplifies the importance of early recognition of acute pulmonary embolism in the emergency setting. Prompt diagnosis and treatment can potentially reduce mortality rates associated with this serious condition.   Ethical Considerations:  The patient's records were anonymized and privacy was respected at all stages.  Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and accompanying images. He understood that his name and initials will not be published and all identifiable characteristics would be omitted.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 55-Year-old obese Ex-Smoker Female with Hypertension and Hypercholesterolemia  Patient Information: Mrs. Jane Doe  a 55-year-old Caucasian woman  married  with an occupation as an administrative worker  from an urban setting  was admitted to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain and dyspnea. The patient has no known drug allergies.  Medical History: Mrs. Doe is an ex-smoker and quit smoking five years ago (a pack a day for about 30 years). She is known to have hypertension for the past ten years  controlled with a fixed-dose combination of Amlodipine and Lisinopril. The patient was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia five years ago and maintained on Statins. She is obese  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 31kg/m2. Her past medical history also includes early-age menopause at the age of 46. She is non-diabetic and does not have any known family history of heart disease. The patient doesn’t have a history of traveling  surgery  or immobilization in the past months. Her records show no past incidence of venous thromboembolism or bleeding disorders.  Case Presentation: On physical examination  Mrs. Doe was found anxious  dyspneic  respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute  with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and blood pressure 145/90 mmHg. Oxygen saturation was 93% on room air. No calf swelling or lower limb asymmetry was noted. Chest and cardiac exam were unremarkable  except for tachycardia. Electrocardiogram (EKG) showed a sinus tachycardia and a S1Q3T3 pattern  suggesting right heart strain. The D-dimers test came back positive.  Investigations: The patient was sent for an emergent CT pulmonary angiography  which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism  with the presence of clots in the main pulmonary artery and its branches.   Treatment: She was promptly initiated on treatment with low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) according to her body weight. Because of her high-risk profile for a recurrent clot  a decision was made to start oral anticoagulation. She was discharged on Rivaroxaban and was instructed about the importance of regular follow-up and anticoagulation therapy.   Outcome and follow-up: Her symptoms improved gradually  and she was regularly followed up in the outpatient department. The patient is under monitoring for possible side effects of the anticoagulation therapy  including bleeding  haematoma or bruising. Preventive measures were discussed and reinforced  including weight management  regular exercise and healthy dietary habits.   Learning points: This case underscores the importance of considering the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with acute-onset chest pain and dyspnea  particularly in patients with risk factors such as obesity  smoking  and hypertension. It also emphasizes the role of early diagnosis and management  leading to improved patient outcomes.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 66-year-old African American Female  Patient Profile: A 66-year-old African American female presented to the Emergency Department with acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. She lives alone and is typically independent with her daily activities. The patient does not smoke or drink alcohol. She has a history of obesity  type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and chronic kidney disease  stage III.   History of Present Illness: The patient described her chest pain as sharp  localized to the left side  exacerbated by deep breaths  and unrelated to physical activity. The pain had developed suddenly earlier that day  prompting her to seek immediate medical assistance. Accompanying the chest pain was dyspnea  she rated as 8 out of 10 severity. She denied any symptoms of dizziness  palpitations  or syncope. There were no reported symptoms of cough  sputum production  or hemoptysis. According to the patient  there was no recent history of travel  surgery  immobilization  or any known malignancies. However  she admitted non-adherence to her diabetic and hypertensive medications due to financial difficulties.  Clinical Findings: Hospital admission vitals revealed a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 112 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation of 89% on room air  and temperature of 98.7° F. Physical examination showed a BMI of 32  distress in breathing  and diminished breath sounds in the left lower lung field. No leg edemas or signs of deep vein thrombosis were found.   Investigations: Electrocardiography (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia but no S1Q3T3 pattern typical of pulmonary embolism. Lab tests revealed D-dimer levels above normal range  supporting a suspected diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. Her chest X-ray was insignificant  ruling out pneumonia or other lung disorders. Computed Tomographic Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) confirmed a massive embolus obstructing the left main pulmonary artery  thereby confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment and Outcome: The patient was promptly initiated on therapeutic anticoagulation therapy with intravenous heparin and subsequently transitioned to oral rivaroxaban. Her symptoms improved significantly over 72 hours  and she was discharged with a prescription for rivaroxaban. Lifestyle modification counseling was provided  and an economical solution for her existing chronic conditions' medication was worked out.   Follow-up: A follow-up appointment was scheduled in A week  and a referral was made to a Hematologist for a hypercoagulation workup. The patient was counseled about the importance of medication adherence and management of her weight  blood pressure  and blood sugar levels. She was educated about the signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism recurrence or any potential side effects of the new therapy.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of early identification and timely treatment of acute pulmonary embolism in an elderly  non-adherent patient with multiple comorbidities. It reminds healthcare providers of the substantial risks posed by untreated chronic conditions and illustrates the socioeconomic factors often influencing patient adherence to medication regimes.

Patient Profile: ---------------------- Initials: K.B. Sex: Female Age: 58 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired nurse Address: Eugene  Oregon  Presenting Complaint: ----------------------------- The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain characterized as sharp and stabbing  radiating to her back  and exacerbated by deep breaths. Associated symptoms included palpitations  excessively profuse sweating  and mild anxiety.  Past Medical History: ----------------------------- The patient has a previous history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a total knee replacement surgery 5 years ago. She also has a 10-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both well-controlled with medication. She quit smoking 20 years ago. No documented allergies.  Clinical Examination: ----------------------------- On examination  she was afebrile  with a respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute  heart rate 120 bpm irregular  BP 160/95mmHg  and Sat02: 93% on room air. Her physical examination was significant for an anxious individual with mild chest wall tenderness and clear breath sounds bilaterally.  Investigation Findings: --------------------------------- Her EKG showed sinus tachycardia with non-specific S-T and T wave abnormalities. No evidence of ST elevation or depression was seen suggesting a heart infarction. Her chest radiograph was unremarkable. Routine laboratory investigations including complete blood counts  renal  and liver panels were within normal limits. However  her D-dimer levels were elevated.  In view of her past medical history  symptoms and elevated D-dimers  a CT pulmonary angiogram was conducted which showed a large clot burden in the bilateral pulmonary arteries  confirming acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment: ---------------- The patient was given oxygen along with IV heparin  and warfarin dosing was started  aiming at a target INR of 2-3. Given the acute nature of her symptoms and her elevated clot burden  an emergency catheter-directed thrombolysis was performed.  Conclusion: ----------------- The patient responded well to the therapy  with her symptoms abating within 24 hours of the procedure. Anticoagulation therapy was continued with warfarin. She was advised on the importance of medication compliance and regular INR monitoring. The patient was discharged home in a stable condition and was scheduled for regular follow-ups.  This case underscores the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with sudden onset chest pain and dyspnea  particularly in those with risk factors such as a history of DVT.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith. The patient is a retired engineer  is married  has two children  and does not smoke or drink alcohol. The patient's family has a history of cardiovascular diseases. The patient weighs 185 lbs and is 5'10"" tall. He reported he has been suffering from obesity and recently started an exercise program.   Past Medical History  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension for which he is on medication. He has been managing Type 2 diabetes with the help of diet and medication for the past ten years. Besides  he also has moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and had an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago. Mr. Smith is currently on oral anticoagulants.  Presenting Complaints  Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with sudden onset severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and lightheadedness. He also reported hemoptysis (coughing up blood)  tachycardia (increased heart rate)  and anxiety.  Physical Examination   On examination  the patient was pale  sweating  and experiencing visible distress. His heart rate was 110 bpm  respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation (SaO2) was 92% on room air. Blood pressure was slightly elevated  at 140/90 mm Hg.
