Investigations  Based on the presenting symptoms  an urgent CT-pulmonary angiogram was performed  which confirmed that a significant clot was blocking the right pulmonary artery  leading to an acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment  Mr. Smith was immediately started on intravenous heparin and was admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring. After stabilization  he was transferred to the regular ward and switched to oral anticoagulation therapy. Pulmonologists and cardiologists were consulted for ongoing management of COPD and risk of further embolic events.  Outcome & Follow-Up  After few days  Mr. Smith's condition improved significantly and his symptoms subsided. He was discharged on long-term oral anticoagulation therapy  and a plan was developed for comprehensive outpatient follow-up including medication adjustments  lifestyle recommendations and routine check-ups.  This case highlights the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism as a differential diagnosis in older patients with sudden onset of chest pain  breathlessness  and history of DVT. Early recognition and immediate treatment in such cases are crucial.

Patient Information:  This case report is related to a 53-year-old Caucasian male  domiciled and employed as an engineer  who presented to the Emergency Department with symptoms suggestive of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient complained of sudden onset shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain that worsened with deep breathing  cough accompanied by bloody sputum  and lightheadedness. His symptoms had begun suddenly a few hours prior to his arrival in the emergency department.  Past Medical History:  The patient was a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  well-managed with Metformin for the past eight years. He also had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the right lower extremity two years back  from which he had recovered following treatment  but had been non-compliant with his anticoagulation therapy. He was a non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption and had no known allergies.  Family History:  The patient’s father had a history of recurrent venous thromboembolism and had passed away due to a myocardial infarction. His mother was hypertensive. His older sibling was healthy with no significant medical conditions.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  his vital signs indicated tachypnea (respiratory rate: 26/min)  tachycardia (heart rate: 110/min)  and a low-grade fever (37.5˚C). Oxygen saturation level was 90% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed tachycardia without any murmurs  gallops  or rubs. Respiratory examination showed decreased breath sounds on the left lower zone with crackles. He appeared anxious and sweaty.  Investigations:  Blood investigations showed raised D-dimer levels and mild leucocytosis. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of right heart strain (S1Q3T3 pattern). Chest X-ray was largely normal with no signs of pneumonia or pneumothorax. An urgent CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism  showing a large clot in the left lower lober artery.  Diagnosis:  The patient was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism based on his clinical picture  typical findings on ECG  raised D-dimer levels  and the confirmatory CT Pulmonary Angiogram.  Treatment:  He was immediately started on high-flow oxygen therapy to correct the hypoxemia. Therapeutic anticoagulation with intravenous Heparin was initiated. The case was discussed with the pulmonology team for possible thrombolytic therapy due to the patient's unstable hemodynamics  which was commenced accordingly.  Outcome:  The patient's respiratory and hemodynamic parameters started to stabilize in the next 48 hours with significant relief in his symptoms. He was transferred to the medical ward for further management and was discharged a week later with long term oral anticoagulation  lifestyle modification advice  and appointments for regular follow-ups.   Learning points:  This case is a reminder of the serious potential consequences of non-compliance to therapy  particularly in patients with past history of thrombotic events. It also underscores the importance of a high index of suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism in patients who present with new-onset dyspnea  chest pain  and history of DVT.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Middle-Aged Female: A Case Report  Introduction: This case describes a 45-year-old Caucasian female with Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE) who presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath and chest pain.  Patient Information: A previously healthy 45-year-old Caucasian female  an office worker  non-smoker  non-alcoholic and with a family history of deep vein thrombosis. She has no past medical history of chronic diseases such as hypertension  diabetes  or cardiorespiratory ailments. She has experienced a noticeable decrease in physical activeness in the recent past due to her office-oriented work routine.    Clinical Findings: The patient reported that she experienced sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp  stabbing chest pain which was exacerbated by deep breathing. She also reported episodes of faintness  unexplained sweating  and a mild  incessant cough with traces of blood. On physical examination  she was found to be tachypneic (respiratory rate 24/min) with decreased oxygen saturation levels (SpO2 89% on room air). Vital signs revealed an elevated heart rate (110 bpm)  blood pressure was within normal range (120/80 mmHg)  and she didn't have a fever (Temp 36.6°C).  Diagnostic Assessment: Lab investigations reported elevated D-dimer levels. An EKG showed nonspecific ST-segment changes. Chest X-ray didn't reveal any acute lung findings. A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was performed due to high clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism  which confirmed the presence of a large clot in the left pulmonary artery.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on parenteral anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for rapid anticoagulation to prevent further clot formation. Additionally  she was supplied with supplemental oxygen to maintain sufficient oxygen saturation level.  Follow-up & Progress: The patient's condition gradually improved over the next few days in hospital and was shifted to oral anticoagulant therapy (Warfarin) for long-term management. She was discharged with strict instructions for follow-up visits  timely medication  and lifestyle modifications including increasing physical activity and a balanced diet.   Patient Perspective: The patient was confused and frightened by the sudden onset of the disease but was relieved by the prompt diagnosis and therapeutic measures. She expressed her willingness to make necessary lifestyle changes to prevent any future health concerns.  Discussion: This case highlights the importance of considering Acute Pulmonary Embolism as a differential diagnosis in patients presenting to the emergency department with unexplained chest pain and shortness of breath. Following correct diagnosis  immediate initiation of the anticoagulant therapy can prove life-saving – as evidenced in this patient's gradual recovery.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in A 73-Year-Old Female Patient  Patient Information ------ The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian female  retired  with a body mass index (BMI) of 28.6.  Chief Complaint ------ The patient was brought to the emergency department complaining of sudden difficulty in breathing  chest pain and coughing up blood.  History of Present Illness ------ The patient woke up with a sudden onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and coughing up blood  which progressively worsened over the course of a few hours. The chest pain was intense and stabbing  intensified with deep breaths and did not radiate to any other area. The cough was dry but later had hemoptysis.  Previous Medical History ------ The patient has a documented history of diabetes mellitus type 2 for which she has been on Metformin  hypertension that has been managed with Lisinopril  and mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for which she uses an inhaler as needed. She has never smoked in her life. The patient had a fractured hip about two months prior to presentation that required surgical intervention followed by prolonged bed rest.  Physical Examination ------ At the time of presentation  the patient was acutely distressed with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute  blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  a pulse of 120 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air which improved to 92% with the use of 2 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. Chest auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds on the left side. She did not have any leg swelling  redness or warmth.  Diagnostic Assessment ------ Given her recent immobilization  respiratory symptoms  and physical examination results  a diagnosis of pulmonary embolism was suspected. A CT angiography was immediately ordered  which confirmed an acute pulmonary embolism in the left main pulmonary artery. The D-dimer levels were also elevated  suggesting high clot burden.   Therapeutic Intervention ------ The patient was admitted to the ICU and started on intravenous heparin for immediate anticoagulation. After stabilization  she was transferred to the medical ward and switched to oral anticoagulants. The dosage was carefully adjusted keeping in view her renal function and risk of bleeding.   Follow-Up and Outcomes ------ The patient tolerated the treatment well with a significant improvement in her symptoms. Her oxygen saturation level remained stable on room air  and no active bleeding was observed. She was discharged on the fifth day of hospitalization  with arrangements for at-home nursing care and follow-ups at the anticoagulation clinic. Patient’s family was educated about the signs of possible complications like bleeding and instructed to bring her for immediate medical attention if symptoms recur.  Patient Perspective ------ The patient expressed anxiety about her condition  but understood the importance of adherence to her medication to prevent future events.  Lessons from the case ------ This case illustrates the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in the differential diagnosis when a patient with recently immobilized condition presents with unexplained acute chest pain  breathlessness  and hemoptysis. It reminds health practitioners to keep in mind that a PE can occur in non-smoking patients with COPD and that age  recent surgery  and bed rest are all risk factors for PE.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 54-year-old Female with No Previous Cardiopulmonary Disease  Introduction: This case report describes a patient with acute pulmonary embolism with no prior history of cardiopulmonary disease or other predisposing factors.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 54-year-old African-American female  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset dyspnea  chest pain  and palpitations lasting for over three hours. She reported no past medical history of cardiopulmonary diseases  hypercoagulable state  nor any recent travels or surgeries. She is a non-smoker with no recreational drug use. She consumes alcohol socially and has a BMI of 24.7 (Normal BMI: 18.5-24.9 kg/m2). She has a family history of hypertension on the maternal and paternal side but no history of cardiovascular diseases or venous thromboembolism.  Clinical Findings: On presentation  she was tachycardic with a heart rate of 111 beats per minute  blood pressure of 137/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Physical examination revealed an anxious woman in moderate respiratory distress. Heart examination revealed tachycardia with regular rhythm  no murmurs  rubs or gallops. Lung exam showed decreased breath sounds in the lower lobes bilaterally  but it was otherwise clear. Her extremities were warm with trace edema bilaterally  no evidence of deep vein thrombosis was observed. Rest of the physical exam was unremarkable.   Investigations: Complete blood count  Kidney function tests  Liver function tests  and COVID-19 RT-PCR came back within normal limits. Her electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia with no ST or T wave changes. Chest X-ray was unremarkable. A high-resolution computed tomography (CT) of the chest with contrast showed filling defects in the bilateral pulmonary arteries consistent with pulmonary embolism. Her D-dimer level was elevated  and her Wells score was calculated to be 4.5 (moderate probability of pulmonary embolism).  Treatment: Patient was treated immediately with low-molecular-weight Heparin and given supplemental oxygen. No thrombolytics were required as patient was hemodynamically stable.  Outcome and Follow-up: The patient was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for close monitoring. Her dyspnea and tachycardia improved within 24 hours. She was transitioned to Warfarin for long term anticoagulation therapy  aiming for an INR of 2-3.  Conclusion: This case highlights the fact that acute pulmonary embolism can occur even in individuals with no prior cardiopulmonary disease. Prompt diagnosis and immediate treatment are crucial in managing such patients. It also underscores the importance of high clinical suspicion for pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with unexplained dyspnea. The patient's family was advised to undergo thrombophilia screening considering the unprovoked nature of the event.

Case Presentation: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Overview:  Mr. J. G  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  presented with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain. He works as an accountant and leads a largely sedentary lifestyle. He's a former smoker who quit five years ago after a 40-year pack-a-day smoking history.  Relevant Past History:  In Mr. G's medical history  he has controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a diagnosis of non-insulin dependent diabetes mellitus. He had an appendectomy at the age of 20 and a coronary angioplasty 3 years ago. His medications include Aspirin  Simvastatin  Lisinopril and Metformin.  Family History:  There's a significant family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack at the age of 62  and his mother had a stroke in her 70s but survived. His only sibling  a younger sister  has chronic atrial fibrillation.  Presentation:  This time  Mr. G reported an acute onset of sharp  right-sided chest pain which was exacerbated on deep inspiration. He also reported severe dyspnea  light-headedness  and palpitations. No signs of hemoptysis or lower limb edema were reported.  Assessment:  On examination  he was observed to be in distress  his vital signs demonstrated tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air.  The lab reports showed a slightly elevated D-dimer and troponin level. His ECG showed sinus tachycardia with no specific ST-T wave changes. CT Pulmonary Angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism  showing clot in the right pulmonary artery.   Plan:  With the diagnosis confirmed  Mr. G was immediately started on intravenous heparin and given supplemental oxygen. Given his comorbid conditions and history  pulmonary embolism's decision for long-term anticoagulation and potential inferior vena cava filter placement will be considered in further discussion with a multidisciplinary team.  This case highlights the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in the differential diagnosis of sudden-onset chest pain and dyspnea. Additionally  it emphasizes the role of individual patient factors such as Mr. G's sedentary lifestyle  smoking history  and significant family history of cardiovascular diseases in the development of this acute condition.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Robert Adams  a 69-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Shortness of breath and mild chest pain persisting for the past two days.  Past Medical History: Mr. Adams has a history of hypertension and was diagnosed with Type II diabetes five years ago. Both conditions are managed with medication (Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension). Also  he suffered a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) event about three years ago. He's a former smoker (30 pack-years) and quit 10 years ago. He occasionally imbibes alcohol.  Family History: His father passed away from a myocardial infarction at age 75; his mother had a history of obesity  diabetes  and hypertension and passed away at age 78. He has a younger sister who is alive and healthy.  Current Presentation: Mr. Adams came to the emergency department presenting shortness of breath  mild chest pain  and a cough. Upon examination  he was found to be tachypneic and slightly tachycardic with oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. The chest was clear on auscultation.  Investigations: His blood investigation showed an elevated D Dimer level and a chest CT scan showed multiple small peripheral pulmonary emboli in both lungs.  Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.  Management Plan: He was immediately started on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) followed by oral anticoagulation medication (Warfarin). Mr. Adams was counseled about the importance of medication adherence to prevent PE recurrence and potential complications.  Follow-up: He will be followed up in the clinic in a week to assess his symptoms and  if needed  adjust medications. Lifestyle modification guidance  including a healthy diet and exercise to manage his diabetes and blood pressure  was also recommended.  Overall  Mr. Adams' case represents the typical risk factors and presenting symptoms for a pulmonary embolism. His history of DVT  older age  diabetes  and hypertension are significant risk factors for PE. Moreover  his ex-smoking status may also contribute to his risk. As a preventive measure  consideration should be given to prophylactic anticoagulation therapy  particularly as Mr. Adams also has a family history of cardiovascular disease.

Patient Case Presentation  Summary:  The patient  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the hospital with a Chief Complaint of sudden onset of dyspnea  or shortness of breath  and sharp chest pain for a period of about 6 hours. The patient also reported a lightheaded feeling and rapid heartbeat.   Past Medical History:  The patient carries a diagnosis of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and chronic atrial fibrillation. His medications include Warfarin  a blood thinner  for atrial fibrillation  and Lisinopril for hypertension. The atrial fibrillation had been relatively well controlled until this event. Also  the patient has a history of smoking approximately 20 cigarettes per day for the past 40 years and remains a current smoker. There are no past records of any surgeries.   Family History:  The patient has a family history of cardiac disease in the father who had a Myocardial Infarction at the age of 65.  Social History:  The patient was an executive for an insurance company before retiring. He is married with two adult children. The patient drinks alcohol occasionally and is a smoker.  Examination & Investigation:  On physical examination  his blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg. His heart rate was tachycardic at 110 beats per minute. Oxygen saturation was low at 90% on room air. Despite some limited ability on auscultation due to obesity  the lung fields were clear.   Investigation results from a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the presence of a large embolus in the right pulmonary artery. His D-dimer blood test was significantly elevated. The EKG showed an irregular heart rhythm typical of atrial fibrillation with a rapid heart rate. There were no specific findings suggestive of myocardial infarction. The echocardiogram displayed elevated pulmonary artery pressure  suggesting strain due to the embolus.  Treatment & Discharge:  The patient was started on intravenous Heparin initially followed by Rivaroxaban  a type of blood thinner  once he was stabilized. The prescription was given for long-term anticoagulation with Rivaroxaban  and his Warfarin was discontinued. The patient was referred to the Pulmonary Rehabilitation Program and encouraged to closely follow his blood pressure and lipid management plan. He was also asked to enroll in a smoking cessation program.  Follow Up:  It was recommended that the patient have a follow-up appointment in the hospital's anticoagulation clinic for monitoring of his new medication. Continual appointments with Pulmonary and Cardiology were also recommended to monitor his long-term progress.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old African-American male who presented to the emergency department with acute onset of shortness of breath  which started approximately two hours before his arrival. The patient also described an associated chest pain  which was pleuritic in nature  and cough with mild hemoptysis.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Johnson has a pertinent history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) around 9 years ago  which was successfully managed with anticoagulation therapy. He is hypertensive and has been stable on his medication (Lisinopril). He also has Type 2 diabetes mellitus well controlled with Metformin.  Family History:  Mr. Johnson has an older brother and sister. Both have hypertension and his brother has a history of DVT as well. His parents are both deceased; his father had a history of coronary artery disease  and his mother had Type 2 diabetes and Alzheimer's disease.  Social History:   Retired military officer leading a generally sedentary lifestyle. He smokes a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years. He is a social drinker and denies any previous or current illicit drug use.  Emergency Department Assessment:  On arrival  the patient was tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min  and SpO2 of 92% on room air. His body mass index (BMI) count was 29 and was afebrile. Auscultation of lungs revealed normal breath sounds  and the cardiovascular examination was unremarkable.  The patient underwent a series of diagnostic tests. The results of the D-dimer test were elevated  prompting the need for a contrast CT  which confirmed the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism.   This patient with a history of DVT presenting with characteristic symptoms and high D-dimer levels was confirmed with CT to have a pulmonary embolism. He was admitted for therapeutic anticoagulation and further management. A detailed risk-factor analysis was initiated  and smoking cessation and lifestyle modification counseling were also planned.  Mr. Johnson's case represents the typical features of acute pulmonary embolism  reminding us of the importance of considering such a diagnosis in any patient with unexplained dyspnea  chest pain  or hemoptysis  especially in the presence of risk factors such as personal and family history of DVT or PE  and smoking.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J.K. is a 70-year-old Caucasian man with a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE). He presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J.K. has a significant past medical history that includes hypertension  diabetes  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has had two previous instances of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He quit smoking about a year ago following his more recent DVT episode.  Personal and Family History:  Mr. JK is recently widowed  lives alone  and has a daughter who lives nearby. He has a relatively sedentary lifestyle. His family history reveals that his brother died at an early age from a pulmonary embolism and his mother had recurrent DVT.   Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis:  On examination in the ED  Mr. J.K. was in acute distress  with a respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 92% on room air and blood pressure of 140/85mmHg. An electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed sinus tachycardia. Given the clinical manifestations and his past medical history  suspicion for acute PE was high.   He was immediately started on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH)  while maintaining a high level of suspicion due to his previous history of DVT. A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was done immediately  which confirmed the diagnosis of acute PE.  Management:  Mr. J.K. was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring. His anticoagulation was bridged to warfarin  while the LMWH was continued until the INR was therapeutic.   Given his history of previous DVT  his case was discussed in a multidisciplinary team meeting with consultants from Pulmonology  Cardiology  and Hematology for considering lifetime anticoagulation to prevent further thromboembolic events.   On day 2  his symptoms improved and on day 5  he was discharged home with a comprehensive plan of care that included warfarin for long-term anticoagulation  as well as a referral to a respiratory rehabilitation program to increase his overall fitness level.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering a diagnosis of PE in patients with sudden onset of breathlessness  particularly in those with risk factors such as prior history of DVT. Early recognition and immediate initiation of anticoagulation therapy can significantly improve patient outcomes. It also emphasizes the value of individualizing patient care and considering long-term anticoagulation in patients with recurrent DVT or PE.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  a 62-year-old African-American male  visited the emergency department with acute shortness of breath and chest pain.   Medical History: Before presentation  Mr. Johnson had a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a non-smoker but has a record of moderate alcohol intake. Mr. Johnson reported that he has been largely sedentary  especially after an ankle fracture six weeks ago. He had been well until a week ago when he started presenting symptoms like fatigue  increased heart rate  and insufficient breath.  Family History: Father deceased due to myocardial infarction at 70 years old. Mother  85  diagnosed with type 2 diabetes but otherwise healthy. No siblings. One son who is healthy.  Current Presentation: Upon admission  noted signs included increased respiratory rate (22 breaths/min)  heart rate of 110 beats/min  and blood pressure 150/90 mmHg. SpO2 was 92% on room air. His body mass index is 28.5 kg/m2  indicating that he is overweight. On clinical examination  the patient appeared distressed  but the chest was clear to auscultation  and the heart sounds were regular without murmurs.   Workup & Diagnosis: Given the clinical presentation  immediate blood tests and imaging were requested. A D-dimer test was ordered  showing high levels suggestive of a clot. In addition  an echocardiogram showed evidence of right ventricular strain. A CT Pulmonary Angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.   Management: The patient was immediately anticoagulated with low molecular weight heparin. Considering the patient’s age  comorbidities  and clot burden  he was admitted to the medical ICU for close monitoring. The case will be discussed with the multidisciplinary PERT (Pulmonary Embolism Response Team). Counseling was done regarding the importance of mobility  adequate hydration  and the avoidance of alcohol. Furthermore  the importance of compliance with the prescribed anticoagulant was stressed.   On the second day of admission  given his stability and improvement in symptoms  he was transferred to the medical floor and bridged to oral anticoagulation with Rivaroxaban  a factor Xa inhibitor. Full anticoagulation will be for 3 months  followed by re-evaluation for the potential risks and benefits of long-term anticoagulation.  Summary: A suspected case of acute pulmonary embolism was confirmed in a 62-year-old hypertensive  diabetic  overweight  sedentarily living male patient with recent immobilization due to fracture. The patient was stabilized and expected to recover with appropriate management. Education was enforced concerning risk factors and preventing recurrence. A follow-up visit is scheduled for further evaluation and management.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. X who was brought to the emergency department (ED) for sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain that started while he was gardening a few hours ago. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  with a 30 pack-year smoking history.  Past Medical History  The patient's past medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and peripheral vascular disease. He also had a myocardial infarction about five years ago that was managed percutaneously. The patient is currently on regular aspirin  metoprolol  and metformin  and his blood pressure and glucose are generally well managed.  Family History  The family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father having passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 68. His elder sister suffered a stroke in her early 70s.  Current Episode  On arrival at the ED  Mr. X's vitals were blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 24/minute  and SaO2 of 90% on room air. His initial EKG showed sinus tachycardia but no acute ischemic changes. Chest X-ray was normal as well. D-dimer  ordered due to high clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism (PE)  was markedly elevated.  Diagnostic Test   A CT pulmonary angiogram was promptly conducted  which confirmed the presence of a large embolus in the right pulmonary artery. Transthoracic echocardiography showed signs of right ventricular strain.     Plan  Mr. X was diagnosed with an acute PE  likely due to his peripheral vascular disease  history of myocardial infarction  and sedentary lifestyle. Anticoagulation therapy was initiated with low molecular weight heparin  and he was admitted for further management. Hemodynamic monitoring was initiated to manage the risk of possible right heart failure. The patient and his family were counseled on the importance of medication compliance  smoking cessation  and lifestyle modifications  including regular exercise and a healthy diet.  In conclusion  this case highlights the importance of early detection and prompt treatment of acute PE  particularly in older patients with multiple comorbidities.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. E is a 67-year-old Caucasian male presenting with acute shortness of breath. The symptom onset was sudden  around an hour before entering the hospital. He describes the sensation as though he cannot take in a deep breath  and it is accompanied by moderate to severe chest pain.  Past Medical History:  Mr. E was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago  which he manages with Lisinopril. Five years ago  he was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for which he takes Metformin. He quit smoking 10 years ago  smoked a pack per day for 25 years. Mr. E's BMI is 29  having a history of being overweight.  Complete Demographics:  Mr. E is a retired teacher  widowed for the past 4 years  and lives alone. He has two daughters living out of state  who check on him regularly over the phone. He is a graduate and has a medical insurance policy. He is not a smoker  consumes alcohol occasionally  and denies any illicit drug use. He states that he remains fairly active and walks about two miles daily.  Family History:  Mr. E's mother died at the age of 58 due to myocardial infarction  and his father died at 76 due to cancer. He has an older brother who suffers from coronary artery disease and a younger sister who is healthy. There is no known family history of blood clotting disorders.  Current Condition:  Physical examination reveals an anxious but cooperative patient. He is tachycardic and tachypneic  with a respiratory rate of 26 per minute. Oxygen saturation hovers around 92% on room air  improving to 95-96% on 2 liters via nasal cannula. Chest exam reveals decreased breath sounds on the right side from base to mid-thorax.  Diagnostic Results:  D-dimer test is positive. Computed Tomographic Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) reveals a large embolus in the right pulmonary artery with extension into the lobar branches. Lower limb doppler did not show any evidence of deep vein thrombosis.  Based on the clinical findings and diagnostic results  Mr. E has been diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism. Treatment includes anticoagulation therapy with enoxaparin and warfarin. Consultation with a pulmonologist has been considered for possible thrombolytic or surgical intervention  along with supportive therapy. An echocardiogram will also be required to monitor potential strain on the heart.   Health education on weight management  diet  medication adherence  and frequent mobilization is provided  considering Mr. E's risk factors. He has been advised to have regular follow-ups for monitoring and adjustment of medication doses.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 60-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. X. He is a retired engineer  living in a suburb with his wife. He used to smoke about a pack of cigarettes a day but quit 30 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally. His height and weight indicate that he is slightly overweight (BMI 27).  Past Medical History: Mr. X has a past medical history of hypertension which is managed by Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 5 years ago  which he controls by diet and Metformin. His most recent HbA1c was 6.9. He also has a history of high cholesterol  for which he takes Atorvastatin.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. X presented to the emergency room complaining of sudden onset sharp chest pain  breathlessness and light-headedness. He also mentions experiencing a dry cough for the past 2 weeks. Upon exploration  it came to light that Mr. X recently returned from a long-distance flight (12 hours).  Clinical Findings/Investigation results: Vital signs on examination reveal a blood pressure of 145/85mmHg  a heart rate of 98 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and SaO2 of 91% on room air. On auscultation  lungs had decreased breath sounds at the lower lobes bilaterally. A D-dimer test was done which came back positive. EKG showed tachycardia but no sign of ST-segment changes. Chest X-ray was normal.  A CT scan with contrast demonstrated a filling defect within the left lower lobar pulmonary artery  suggesting a pulmonary embolism.  Family History: There is a history of cardiovascular disease in his family; his father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 70. His older brother has angina. No known family history of blood clotting disorders.  Final Diagnosis: Based on the clinical presentation and CT imaging  a final diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made.  Treatment and Plan: The patient was started on treatment with low molecular weight Heparin  which was switched to Rivaroxaban (an oral anticoagulant) at discharge  which he will continue for 3 months. He also received supplemental oxygen to maintain his oxygen saturation over 95%. Mr. X is educated about the signs of potential complications to watch for  including sudden shortness of breath and chest pain.  Discharge and Follow-up: Mr. X was discharged after 3 days in stable condition. He will follow up with his primary care physician and a cardiologist in one week and then regularly thereafter to monitor anticoagulation and his recovery. He will also have an appointment with a dietitian to help manage his weight  diabetes  and cholesterol.   It is crucial to maintain a comprehensive overview and regular follow-ups of such patients  given his risks for recurrent embolism and other cardiovascular diseases.

Patient Information: The patient  Mr. John Smith  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking for over 30 years. He is retired and lives alone. He has a BMI of 27.5 and leads a sedentary lifestyle. Mr. Smith does not consume alcohol frequently and has no known drug allergies. He is an ex-automobile mechanic and was mainly exposed to various gases and dust at his workplace.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Smith was brought to the ER exhibiting symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath that had started suddenly a few hours prior. He reported the pain as a sharp  constant ache  rating it as a 7 on a scale of 10. Accompanying symptoms were coughing and episodes of light-headedness.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and early stages of COPD due to prolonged exposure to second-hand smoke and his own smoking habit. He was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) two years ago. His medication regimen includes lisinopril (for hypertension)  metformin (for diabetes)  and salmeterol/fluticasone propionate (for COPD).   Family History: His father passed away at the age of 75 due to ischemic heart disease. His mother is still alive at age 88 and has hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He has two sisters; one diagnosed with breast cancer and another with hypothyroidism.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient was clearly anxious  dyspneic with tachypnea (respiratory rate 28 breaths/min)  and also shown tachycardia (heart rate 112 beats/min). Auscultation of lungs showed decreased breath sounds on the right side. His blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg. Oxygen saturation was low at 88% on room air.   Diagnostic Assessment: Based on the clinical symptoms and history  acute pulmonary embolism was suspected. A D-dimer test showed a high level of D-dimer (1000 ng/mL). A CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the presence of a clot in the right pulmonary artery.   Treatment Plan: He was immediately given supplemental oxygen and started on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). A consultation with the pulmonology team was requested for more specialized care and future management.   Prognosis: Mr. Smith's condition is critical and will require hospitalization for careful monitoring. His smoking history and sedentary lifestyle are significant risk factors. However  with immediate  correct management  his prognosis can be improved.  It is imperative that Mr. Smith be counseled about lifestyle modification (smoking cessation  active lifestyle  DVT prophylaxis) as part of his treatment plan. It's also important his family is informed of his condition  and genetic risk investigations are considered given his family's medical history.   Educational Goals & Objectives: This case prompts the importance of considering past medical and occupational history in acute cases  the need for prompt diagnosis in PE cases  and the necessity of long-term management strategies for conditions like diabetes  hypertension  and COPD.   References: 1) Goldhaber SZ  et al. Acute pulmonary embolism: clinical outcomes in the International Cooperative Pulmonary Embolism Registry (ICOPER). Lancet. 1999;353(9162):1386-9. 2) Konstantinides SV  et al. 2014 ESC guidelines on the diagnosis and management of acute pulmonary embolism. Eur Heart J. 2014;35(43):3033-69.

Patient Information: Mr. Greene  a 67-year-old Caucasian male living in a suburban area.  Presenting Complaint: Sudden chest pain  rapid heart rate  and shortness of breath following a recent long-haul flight.  Past Medical History: Mr. Greene has a ten-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a two-pack per day smoker with a 40-year history. He underwent a right total hip replacement 6 months ago. No known allergies. No previous diagnosis of any cardiac or lung diseases.   Family History: His mother suffered from deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His father died at the age of 70 due to myocardial infarction.  Current Medications: He is regularly taking Lisinopril for his hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  but admits that he often forgets to take his medications.  Review of Systems: He reported a sudden onset of right-sided chest pain exacerbated by deep breathing and shortness of breath. He also reported calf pain  minor swelling  and slight discoloration on his right leg.  Physical Exam: Initial vitals showed the following: Temperature: 37.8°C  Blood pressure: 148/90 mmHg  Heart rate: 105 beats per minute  Respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation: 92% on room air. On examination  tenderness  minor swelling and slight discoloration were noted in his right lower leg. Lungs auscultation demonstrated decreased breath sounds on the right side.  Diagnostic Tests: D-dimer levels were elevated. A Doppler ultrasound of the right lower extremity showed a DVT in the right popliteal vein. A CTPA (CT pulmonary angiogram) confirmed the presence of an acute pulmonary embolism.   Treatment Plan: The patient was initiated on therapeutic anticoagulation with Heparin drip. Later  he was transitioned to Warfarin for long-term anticoagulation treatment. Counselling was done regarding the importance of medication adherence  lifestyle modification  and quitting smoking.  Plan for Follow-up: The patient has been advised regular follow-ups with a cardiologist for monitoring coagulation parameters to maintain therapeutic INR levels and also simultaneously with a pulmonologist for further management of the pulmonary embolism.   This case enlightens the significance of investigating the underlying deep vein thrombosis in a patient with acute pulmonary embolism which is clinically relevant and important for most such cases.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  referred to as Mr. X for his privacy  who was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism. He was brought into the ER with acute onset of shortness of breath and slight chest pain. Mr. X is an office worker based in Chicago and lives with his wife.   Medical History:  Mr. X has a history of hypertension for which he is on medication. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 3 years ago  and he is on antiplatelet therapy. He is controlled Type 2 diabetic for the last ten years on oral hypoglycemic agents. Mr. X is a former smoker  who quit tobacco 15 years ago  and he drinks alcohol occasionally. Mr. X is overweight (Body Mass Index of 29).   Family History:  His father had a stroke at the age of 72 and his mother died of breast cancer at 68. His eldest brother of 65 years has coronary artery disease. No known family history of pulmonary embolism  DVTs  or inherited coagulopathies.  Recent History:  Mr. X recently underwent total right knee arthroplasty. He underwent the operation due to osteoarthritis. The surgery appeared to be successful with no immediate complications  but Mr. X reported that he was largely immobile postoperatively.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. X complained of sudden onsets of shortness of breath and chest pain that developed over several hours. He also described a mild cough  but with no hemoptysis. He denied fever  recent trauma  or the use of illicit drugs.  Physical Examination:  On presentation  he was in mild distress. His vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 158/94 mm Hg  a pulse rate of 108/min  a respiratory rate of 22/min  an oxygen saturation of 92% while breathing ambient air  and a BMI recorded of 29 kg/m^2. The rest of the physical examination was normal; specifically  there was no lower extremity edema or calf tenderness.  Given the patient’s presenting symptoms and history  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made. Early detection and appropriate therapeutic intervention significantly improved Mr. X's prognosis. Mr. X was admitted into the hospital for further investigation and suitable treatment management.

Patient's Introduction:  Mr Amir  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness. The patient's main concern was his rapid heart rate and his difficulty in taking a full breath.   Patient's Background:  Mr Amir is a retired banker residing in New York with his wife. He is a former smoker who quit five years ago but has previously smoked 20 cigarettes a day for about 30 years. He is teetotaler with no history of drug abuse. He reportedly maintains a sedentary lifestyle  with very little physical exercise. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia controlled with medication (metoprolol and rosuvastatin respectively). His parents both had coronary artery disease. His father died of myocardial infarction at age 70 and his mother had a stroke at the age of 75.  Current Admission:  On examination  Mr Amir appeared breathless and diaphoretic. His heart rate was tachycardic at 120 beats per minute  blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  respiratory rate was elevated (25 breaths per minute)  oxygen saturation was 92% on room air and his body mass index was raised at 31. His chest examination revealed clear lung fields with no additional sounds.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Blood tests levels showed a significantly raised D-dimer level. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) displayed tachycardia with no specific ST segment changes or Q waves. Based on these initial investigations and suggestive symptoms a working diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE) was made. This diagnosis was affirmed by a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA)  which showed a large clot in the right main pulmonary artery.   Conclusion:  Mr Amir's case is a representation of a common  serious medical condition that can present in many different ways. This case highlights the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism as a potential diagnosis in patients presenting with sudden onset of dyspnea  especially in those with risk factors such as advanced age  sedentary lifestyle  and a history of smoking.   Mr Amir was started on anticoagulation therapy in line with current treatment guidelines for APE. His oxygen delivery was supported until he no longer showed signs of hypoxemia  ensuring a regular follow up and advice regarding lifestyle modifications which include an increased physical activity  dietary changes  and dedicated smoking cessation (in case of relapses). With these measures in place  he has a good prognosis.

Patient Information:  Mr. X is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of chest pain and difficulty breathing. He was at rest when the pain began and it is localized to the middle of his chest with no radiation. Accompanying symptoms include sweating  palpitations and a feeling of impending doom.  History of Present Illness:  Prior to presentation  the patient was in his usual state of health. The onset of symptoms began two hours before he arrived at the ER. He denies any similar episodes in the past. He has had a deep  cough productive with clear sputum for the past couple of weeks  which he attributed to a common cold. He also noted recent swelling in his right lower extremity which he had ignored.  Past Medical History:  Mr. X is known hypertensive for 10 years and has hyperlipidemia. He continues to smoke a pack of cigarettes per day despite his 40-year history of smoking. He has a sedentary lifestyle and his body mass index classifies him as obese. He travels frequently for work  often with long intercontinental flights.  Family History:  His father had a stroke at age 50 and his mother has type II diabetes mellitus. He has two siblings both of whom are hypertensive. His older brother  aged 62  has a history of deep vein thrombosis.  Physical Examination:  During assessment  he was oriented to time  place  and person but appeared anxious. His blood pressure was 150/90 mm Hg  his pulse was 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation was 92% on room air  and temperature was 37°C. His right lower leg was swollen and tender. His cardiovascular and respiratory examination revealed a tachycardia with clear lung fields.  Impression:  Considering his symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  the recent onset lower limb swelling  and his risk factors such as long distance air travel  sedentary lifestyle and smoking; Mr. X was suspected to have an acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Plan:  In the emergency room  he was given supplemental oxygen  placed on telemetry  and venous access was established. After securing his airway  initial blood tests including complete blood count  clotting profile  troponin  and D-dimer were ordered  and an ECG and chest X-ray were urgently performed. A CT pulmonary angiography was done which confirmed the diagnosis of acute PE. Mr. X was started on anticoagulation therapy and admitted to the ICU for close monitoring. His case was also discussed with the interventional radiology team for possible intervention  if needed. Smoking cessation counseling was recommended. A plan for an ultrasound of leg veins was made to confirm deep vein thrombosis.

Patient Presentation:  John Doe  a 57-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain  which was described as sharp and worsened on deep inspiration. He was accompanied by his wife who stated that the symptoms occurred suddenly while they were having dinner. There was no reported history of trauma prior to the onset of symptoms.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has been battling type 2 diabetes mellitus for about 15 years. Apart from this  he has a known diagnosis of hypertension and dyslipidemia. The patient rarely exercises and his diet is high in fats and sugars.  Family History:  Mr. Doe is a non-smoker and social drinker. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease; his father had a heart attack at the age of 60. His sister is also type 2 diabetes mellitus positive.  Clinical Examination:  On evaluation  Mr. Doe was found to be slightly tachypneic with an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. His blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/90 mm Hg. On auscultation  no obvious abnormalities were found in the lungs and heart.  Initial Diagnostic Impression:  Given the sudden onset of symptoms and his clinical condition  acute pulmonary embolism was suspected.  Investigations:  Immediate D-dimer test was undertaken  which came back positive. A computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was subsequently ordered  which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Discussion:  Mr. Doe’s sedentary lifestyle  poor diet  and family history of cardiovascular disease put him at an increased risk for developing clots  leading to conditions such as pulmonary embolism  especially with ongoing comorbidities like type 2 diabetes and hypertension. Immediate management steps were initiated with oxygen supplement and anticoagulation therapy in the form of low molecular weight Heparin  as well as counseling on dietary modifications and the importance of exercise.  In general  acute pulmonary embolism is a potentially life-threatening condition which requires prompt diagnosis and management. It’s often difficult to diagnose because of its nonspecific clinical presentation. The risk factors include prolonged immobilization  surgery  malignancy  pregnancy  and hormonal therapy. Hence  a high degree of clinical suspicion remains an important aspect for early detection of this condition. Mr. Doe was admitted to the intensive care unit for monitoring and further management. His case serves as an important reminder to consider PE in patients with sudden-onset dyspnea  especially when the clinical context fits.

Patient Introduction and Demographics:  The patient is a 45-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith  who works as an IT specialist and lives alone in an urban area. He is divorced with no children  a non-smoker with a sedentary lifestyle  has no drug allergies  and is known to consume alcohol socially. His family history includes a late father with coronary artery disease and a late mother with colorectal cancer.  Complaints and Symptoms:  Mr. Smith was rushed into the ER after presenting with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and coughing with some blood-tinged sputum. His chest pain was described as sharp and persistent. It worsened with deep breathing and he also had a slight fever. The symptoms started a few hours before the consultation.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith is obese with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30.2. He was diagnosed with Stage 1 hypertension 3 years ago and has been on antihypertensive medication. He had undergone surgery for an ingrown toenail 10 days prior to his current presentation. His medical history did not feature any significant respiratory or cardiovascular diseases.  Examinations:  Initial vital signs showed tachypnea  tachycardia  and decreased saturation of oxygen. CBC showed elevated white blood cells. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed a sinus tachycardia with S1Q3T3 pattern. The D-dimer test was positive.  Diagnosis:  Acute Pulmonary Embolism was diagnosed based on his clinical presentation and results of investigations. This condition was likely secondary to post-operative immobilization leading to deep vein thrombosis and subsequent embolization.  Treatment:  He was given oxygen therapy immediately to alleviate hypoxia. He was given anticoagulants to stop further clotting and thrombolytics to dissolve existing clots.   Progress:  Mr. Smith’s considerably improved however further investigations such as CT angiography of the chest and Doppler Ultrasonography of the lower limbs were advised for confirmation of diagnosis and to ascertain the source of the embolism. After his discharge  Mr. Smith was advised regular follow-ups and encouraged to embrace a more active lifestyle to combat his obesity and sedentary habits.   It is advisable to provide genetic counseling considering his family history. Lifestyle modifications and management of his hypertension were also emphasized to reduce his risk of cardiovascular events in the future.   This case presentation demonstrates how imperative it is for healthcare providers to encourage lifestyle modifications and monitor patients who have undergone recent surgery and are at risk for deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

Patient Information: Ms. Clarke  a 65-year-old Caucasian female with a known history of fibrinogenemia (an inherited blood clotting disorder) and hypertension  presented to the emergency department with acute onset shortness of breath  mild chest pain  and a cough productive of blood-tinged sputum.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports she was at home this morning when she suddenly began to feel shortness of breath and experienced mild chest pain which she rated as a 4/10. Ms. Clarke also mentioned noticing blood-tinged sputum when she coughed  subsequent to the chest pain. She denied any history of travel or prolonged periods of immobilization.  Past Medical History: Ms. Clarke has a known history of fibrinogenemia and hypertension managed with Lisinopril. She had undergone a total knee replacement 6 months ago. She is a non-smoker and lives a moderately active lifestyle.  Family History: Her family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with her mother dying from a stroke at the age of 70 and her brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his early 60s.  Physical Examination: On arrival  she was anxious  diaphoretic and tachypneic with an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air  blood pressure of 175/90 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. She had decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung fields and appeared mildly cyanotic.  Diagnostic Tests: An EKG showed sinus tachycardia. A CT angiogram of the chest demonstrated a large filling defect in the left pulmonary artery  characteristic of a pulmonary embolism. Her D-dimer levels were elevated at 800 ng/ml (normal value  0-500 ng/ml)  while cardiac enzymes were found within normal ranges.  Management and Progression: Ms. Clarke was promptly initiated on intravenous heparin  with a plan to bridge to Coumadin for long term anticoagulation. Given her history of hypertension  blood pressure has been carefully managed. Subsequent days showed improvement in her shortness of breath and resolution of chest pain. The patient tolerated the therapy well.  Plan: Ms. Clarke will continue her therapy and will be carefully monitored. She will be provided a complete patient education about the nature of her condition  importance of compliance to medication  lifestyle modifications  and signs of possible complications to look out for. Genetic counseling and testing were suggested for her children and regular follow-ups with Respiratory Medicine and Cardiology have been arranged.    This case demonstrates the significant role of inherited clotting disorders in the development of pulmonary embolism in patients even without established risk factors such as immobilization or recent surgery. It underscores the importance of prompt diagnosis  and effective management in these to prevent morbidity and mortality.

Patient Description:  A 65-year-old Caucasian female presents to the hospital with symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  and coughing. The patient has been experiencing these symptoms for the past two days. She has also noted hemoptysis (coughing up blood). The patient's vitals are stable  but she presents with tachycardia (heart rate: 110 bpm) and tachypnea (respiratory rate: 24 bpm).  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of atrial fibrillation and is on warfarin for the same. She was hospitalized last year for a bout of pneumonia. She also has a diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension that are managed with oral medications. She has never smoked but has moderate alcohol consumption.  Family History: Her mother died from breast cancer  and her father had a stroke. There is no reported history of pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis in the family.  Clinical Evaluation and Diagnosis: Upon physical examination  there were no notable abnormalities. However  due to the patient's reported symptoms and history of atrial fibrillation  an electrocardiogram was obtained  showing signs of right heart strain. Following this  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was performed  revealing a clot in the right pulmonary artery indicating acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE).   Treatment and Follow-up: The patient was promptly initiated on therapeutic heparin. Given her overall stable condition  a decision was made to continue on the therapeutic anticoagulation and monitor her closely. The patient's warfarin was held temporarily  and she was admitted to the hospital for close surveillance. The patient was educated on the signs and symptoms of PE exacerbation and was instructed to return to the hospital immediately if symptoms worsen. On follow-up appointments  the patient showed resolution of her symptoms and the anticoagulation therapy was reviewed and restarted with increased vigilance.   The case reflects the importance of clinical suspicion in a patient with risk factors experiencing symptoms suggestive of a pulmonary embolism. In this case  early diagnosis and management possibly prevented a significant deterioration in the patient's condition. This case also underlines the need for stringent control and monitoring of anticoagulant therapy in patients with atrial fibrillation.

Patient Initials: JD Age: 53 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Presenting Problem: JD presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset  sharp chest pain  and shortness of breath. He also reported experiencing light-headedness and a rapid pulse.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are well-managed with medication. He was a smoker but quit 15 years ago.  Present Medication: JD is currently taking Lisinopril for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Family History: Both of JD's parents died in their late seventies. His father had a history of ischemic heart disease. JD's mother had chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hyperlipidemia.  Psycho-Social History: JD is married with two children. He works as a car mechanic. JD quit smoking 15 years ago and drinks alcohol socially  approximately 1-2 times per month.  Objective Findings: Vital signs at presentation demonstrated a BP of 145/92  heart rate of 105 bpm  respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 88% on room air  temperature of 37.1 degrees Celsius. Physical examination revealed tachypnea and tachycardia. No swelling or redness noted on the extremities.   Assessment: A CT pulmonary angiography was performed  showing thrombi in both pulmonary arteries confirming the diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE). Laboratory tests showed elevated D-dimer levels.   Treatment Plan: Emergent anticoagulation was initiated with unfractionated heparin. Due to continued symptoms of shortness of breath and low oxygen saturation  the patient was admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and further management.   Follow-Up Plan: Thrombolytic therapy considered if patient's condition worsens. Risk factor modification including managing hypertension  maintaining a healthy diet and regular exercise encouraged. Further discussions regarding the long-term use of anticoagulant therapy to prevent recurrence will occur once the patient has stabilized.  Patient Education: Patient and family were educated about the condition  risk factors  symptom recognition  and the importance of medication adherence  healthy lifestyle  and regular follow-up appointments.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  referred to as Mr. A  presenting with symptoms of acute shortness of breath and chest pain. He is a retired banker  married with two adult children. His past medical history includes controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed by medication for the past ten years. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. He denies any illicit drug use. There is no notable family history of respiratory diseases  but his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.  Presentation of Symptoms:  Mr. A's symptoms started abruptly with chest discomfort radiating to his left upper arm. The pain progressively worsened  becoming sharp and stabbing in nature when he took deep breaths. Along with this  he also noticed sudden onset of breathlessness. There were no associated symptoms like fever  productive cough  or hemoptysis.  Findings:  Upon physical examination  Mr. A was anxious  sweating  and using accessory muscles for breathing. His vital signs were: respiratory rate 22 breaths/min  heart rate 120 beats/min  blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  oxygen saturation 91% on ambient air and temperature was normal. Cardiac examination revealed tachycardia but no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Similarly  pulmonary auscultation showed decreased breath sounds on the right lower chest  but no wheezes or crackles were noted. Abdomen and neurological examinations were unremarkable.  Investigations:  An urgent D-dimer test was ordered and it came back significantly elevated. Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed sinus tachycardia with no signs of myocardial ischemia. Due to the pattern of his presenting symptoms and the findings of his D-dimer test  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was promptly performed which confirmed bilateral pulmonary emboli.  Management and Outcome:  Given the acute pulmonary embolism diagnosis  the patient was treated with anticoagulant therapy. He was administered low molecular weight Heparin (LMWH) as bridging therapy in combination with a new oral anticoagulant. His symptoms began to improve with the treatment. Risk factors for venous thromboembolism were analyzed - recent immobilization or surgery  malignancy  or an inherited thrombophilic disorder - but none were found. After 5 days  he was discharged home with advice to continue oral anticoagulation and arrangements were made for regular follow-ups in the outpatient clinic.  Conclusion:  This case highlights that a high index of suspicion for pulmonary embolism should be maintained in patients presenting with shortness of breath and unexplained chest pain even in the absence of other risk factors. Prompt diagnosis and immediate initiation of anticoagulation treatment are critical in preventing potential fatality.

Patient Information  - Name: J. Smith - Age: 61 years old - Sex: Male - Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Problem:  J. Smith presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and mildly sharp chest pain that began earlier this morning. He reported that he has had no cough  no bloody or abnormal sputum  and swift deterioration in his capacity to perform moderate exercise.  Medical History:  J. Smith has a history of hypertension (Controlled with Lisinopril) and hypercholesterolemia (maintained with Atorvastatin). In addition  patient had a total knee replacement 6 months ago. The surgery was uneventful and he recovered well. He is a non-smoker and moderately drinks alcohol.  Family History:  His father deceased due to a myocardial infarction in his early 70s and mother had stroke  lived to 90. He has no siblings.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  J. Smith was anxious and tachycardic with a weak rapid pulse (115/minute)   elevated blood pressure of 140/90mmHg  and slightly tachypneic (22/minute)  but his temperature was within the normal range.  His oxygen saturation was hovering around 88% on room air. The respiratory examination revealed decreased breath sounds at the lower lobe of the right lung. Remainder of physical examination was pretty unremarkable.   Lab Testing:  His arterial blood gas analysis was slight hypoxemia and hypocarbia  which screamed an elevated A-a gradient. The D-Dimer test results were positive. Electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia with an occasional extra beat but no classic S1Q3T3 pattern for Pulmonary embolism.   Investigations and Results:  A CT pulmonary angiogram was arranged that confirmed the diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE)  showing filling defects within the pulmonary artery branches supplying the right lower lobe.  Discussion:  In Mr. Smith's case  the pulmonary embolism likely arose due to the deep vein thrombosis caused post orthopedic surgery. His knee surgery 6 months ago as well as his inactive and sedentary life style may have added in developing a Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) that subsequently traveled up to his lung circulation.  Plan/Therapeutic Intervention:  Prompt therapeutic anticoagulation was initiated with low molecular weight Heparin (LMWH). After 5 days  he was transitioned to oral anticoagulant (Apixaban) for long-term use. Ambulation and graduated compression stockings were suggested as preventive measures for DVT formation. Scheduled for follow-up chest imaging and on dual therapy (Anticoagulant + Statin). He was educated about the symptoms of bleeding (a side effect of anticoagulant therapy) and was advised to come to the hospital if these occur. Thorough lifestyle modifications and regular follow-ups were advised.   Prognosis:  The prognosis for Mr. Smith looks decent as the embolism was diagnosed and treated quickly. With lifestyle modifications and appropriate medication  he may have a very good chance of living a normal life. Regular monitoring of vitals and routine checkups will be needed. Mr. Smith shows an encouraging spirit towards a healthy lifestyle changes.

Patient Information:   Mr. James Hughes  a 67-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department.  Reason for Visit:   Mr. Hughes was experiencing sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  cough  and light-headedness. His symptoms started while at home and progressively worsened within a few hours.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Hughes is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago  but with a 40 pack-year smoking history. He has been managing hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past seven years with medication  with a recent HbA1c level of 6.8%. He also has a history of a deep vein thrombosis in his left leg a year ago  which was treated with anticoagulation therapy.   Family History:   His mother died at the age of 70 from a stroke  and his father died from a myocardial infarction at 65. His older brother  aged 70  has a history of coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination:   On initial examination  Mr. Hughes was observed to be in acute respiratory distress. He was tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths/minute and an oxygen saturation on room air of 89%. His blood pressure was 130/80mmHg  and his pulse rate was 110 bpm. On auscultation  there were decreased breath sounds on the right lower side of the chest.  Investigations:   A preliminary electrocardiogram showed a sinus tachycardia with an incomplete right bundle branch block. A subsequent chest CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment And Response:   Mr. Hughes was promptly started on supplemental oxygen and anticoagulation therapy. After 72 hours  patient's symptoms improved and his oxygen saturation levels returned to normal. A repeat imaging study showed resolution of the embolism.  Summary:   Mr. Hughes' past medical history and presenting symptoms fit the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. The early detection and prompt start of treatment massively contributed to his recovery. His history of DVT and smoking history should alert medical practitioners to the slightly increased risk for thromboembolic events. Hence  a strict follow-up for the management of risk factors is advised.   Outcome:   James is planned for discharge with long-term oral anticoagulation and follow-up appointments with Hematology to manage his risk factors. Education about modifiable risk factors  medication compliance  and when to seek medical help were reinforced with the patient.

Patient Case Presentation:  Name: Mr. John Ricci Age: 65 years  Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired civil engineer  Presenting Complaint: Acute chest pain  coughing  and shortness of breath.  Medical History: Mr. Ricci has a past medical history of hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily) and hyperlipidemia. He has been a smoker for 40 years  averaging around 1 pack per day. He also manifests signs of chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD). In his early 60s  he had a right hip replacement and has been relatively sedentary since. He is overweight with a BMI of 29. No allergies.   Family History: Comes from a small family. His parents succumbed to old age and reportedly had cardiovascular issues. He has one older brother who suffered a myocardial infarction in his early 60s. No known genetic disorders or malignancies in the family.  Physical Examination: On presentation  he was tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure within normal limits (135/85 mmHg)  respiratory rate was increased at 22 breaths per minute and his oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Chest examination revealed decreased breath sounds bilaterally and crackles in the right lower lobe. Lower limb examination revealed right calf tenderness.  Laboratory Findings and Diagnostics: Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer (750 ng/mL). Other measures remained relatively normal  including CBC  liver function tests  and renal panel. Chest X-ray was largely unremarkable with no signs of infarction or pneumothorax. EKG showed sinus tachycardia but no signs of right heart strain. Subsequently spiral computed tomography (CT) angiography confirmed the diagnosis of acute bilateral pulmonary emboli.  Clinical Progress: Mr. Ricci was immediately started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and admitted to the ICU for further monitoring of potential complications such as progressive respiratory failure or cardiovascular collapse. His condition has been stable so far with improving oxygen saturation on supplemental oxygen therapy.  Plan:  1. Continue anticoagulant therapy with LMWH.  2. Regular monitoring of vital signs  oxygen saturation  CBC  renal and liver function. 3. Engage oral anticoagulant plan with warfarin  in consultation with a hematologist. 4. Smoking cessation counselling. 5. Planned future follow-ups with pulmonologist and primary care physician to manage COPD  smoking cessation  and hypertensive status.  This case highlights the high index of suspicion required in middle-aged  sedentary smokers with a history of surgery presenting with chest pain and respiratory distress. Additional steps such as smoking cessation and weight reduction should be approached as a part of overall health improvement and prevention of further PE episodes or other related illnesses.

Patient Information:  Mr. Jones  a 61-year-old Caucasian male  an engineer by profession  was admitted to the hospital with acute shortness of breath  chest discomfort and dizziness. He has a history of heavy smoking (approx. 30 pack-years) and Hypertension  both being managed by medication (antihypertensives). He is also a type 2 diabetic but under control through lifestyle changes including diet and exercise.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient complained of sudden acute shortness of breath that started the day of admittance. He experienced increasing chest discomfort and occasional bouts of dizziness over the past 72 hours. There was no history of fever  cough  or hemoptysis.  Family History: Mr. Jones' father suffered from coronary artery disease and passed away from myocardial infarction at the age of 65. His mother died at age 72 due to Alzheimer's. He has a younger sister who is healthy.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he appeared anxious and short of breath. His temperature was 36.9 C  blood pressure 145/90 mm Hg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 28 breaths per minute  and O2 Sat is 90% on room air. Lung auscultation revealed normal breath sounds with no added sounds. Cardiovascular examination was unremarkable apart from tachycardia.  Lab Results: His initial arterial blood gases (ABGs) showed hypoxemia and mild respiratory alkalosis. His complete blood count  renal and liver parameter did not reveal abnormal findings. Prothrombin time (PT)  activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT)  and D-Dimer levels were checked. The D-Dimer was raised which increased the suspicion of a pulmonary embolism.   Imaging: A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the presence of multiple small emboli to both lungs  more on the right side than the left.  Final Diagnosis: The most likely cause for Mr. Jones' clinical condition was diagnosed as an Acute Pulmonary Embolism.  Treatment Plan:  He was promptly started on therapeutic-dose intravenous heparin infusion as a bridge to long-term oral Anticoagulant therapy. Risk factor modification such as smoking cessation  regular exercise  and proper diet was advised  to manage his hypertension and diabetes better and to prevent future complications. His condition improved gradually over the next few days  and plans for discharge with oral anticoagulants were made.   Considering the family history  the patient was also advised to attend cardiovascular and neurology clinics for regular check-ups for early detection of dementia and heart disease. He was also educated about the symptoms of deep vein thrombosis and advised to seek medical attention if he notices any such changes.

Patient Introduction:  Mr. R  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the Emergency Department (ED) with chief complaints of acute onset shortness of breath and chest pain. His height is 180 cm  weighs 95 kg  and with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 29.3.  History: His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes mellitus  and a 20-Pack-year smoking history  although quitted 6 years back. The patient is married and has two adult children. He owns a local bakery and reports that he's been under a lot of stress lately due to work pressure. His alcohol consumption is moderate  with occasional alcohol during social events and denies any illicit drug use.  On Assessment: Upon arrival  Mr. R's vitals were: blood pressure 148/92 mmHg  heart rate 106 bpm  respiratory rate 28 bpm  and oxygen saturation 88% on room air. Physical examination revealed increased work of breathing  with use of accessory muscles  and slightly decreased breath sounds in the left lower lobe. ECG showed sinus tachycardia. Other systems did not reveal any significant abnormality.  Lab & Radiological Investigations: Lab findings showed an elevated D-dimer level and Troponin I levels  while CBC  renal function  and liver function were within normal ranges. His chest X-ray was unremarkable. A contrast-enhanced Computed Tomography angiography (CTPA) of the Chest confirmed the presence of a clot in the distal left pulmonary artery branch.  Treatment: Mr. R was started on supplemental oxygen and immediately initiated on therapeutic Anticoagulation with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) as per acute pulmonary embolism (PE) protocol. His oxygen saturation improved to 96% with supplemental oxygen.  Family History: His father had a history of coronary artery disease and passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 72. His mother is 80 and has type II diabetes  and his younger brother was recently diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Summary: Presenting the case of a 58-year-old male with multiple risk factors including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes  former smoker  occupational stress and a strong family history of cardiovascular disease. His acute presentation with shortness of breath  chest pain  and subsequent diagnostic findings confirmed the diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism. Immediate appropriate intervention with oxygen therapy and anticoagulation improved his clinical status. Further management will include optimization of his risk factors and long-term anticoagulation considering his risk for thromboembolic events.  Note: [This is a simulated case for illustrative purpose]

Patient Identification: A 61-year-old  Caucasian woman named Mrs. Jacobs presented herself in the emergency department.  Present Illness: Mrs. Jacobs complained about sudden chest pain  shortness of breath  and profuse sweating which she categorized as severe. She also noticed an increase in her heart rate. These symptoms started approximately 3 hours prior to her ER visit.  Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history revealed that she had been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she had been taking medication as prescribed. She was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) two years ago. She had a well-controlled medical history with no surgeries or hospitalizations.  Family History: She has a positive family history of cardiovascular diseases as her father and one of her brothers had myocardial infarctions in their 50s. Her mother is alive with hypertension and diabetes.  Personal and Social History: Mrs. Jacobs is a retired school teacher who lives alone  is widowed  and has two children. She is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. She reports leading a relatively sedentary lifestyle and has recently undertaken a long car trip.
