Physical Examination: Upon examination  tachypnea  tachycardia  and reduced oxygen saturation level at 92% were noted. Her blood pressure was slightly elevated at 140/90 mmHg.  Investigation Results: D-dimer test showed a massively elevated level. CT pulmonary angiography confirmed the presence of a significant pulmonary embolism burden.   Diagnosis: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Plan: The patient was admitted to a monitored bed in the intensive care unit for further treatment. As she was at high risk because of the significant PE burden  she was started on therapeutic anticoagulation (heparin)  which will later be switched to novel oral anticoagulants (NOAC). Regular monitoring of her vital signs  oxygen saturation  and response to treatment was mandated. A follow-up appointment was scheduled post-discharge with a pulmonologist and a cardiologist.  In view of her history of DVT  a sedentary lifestyle  and recent long car trip  it is recommended for Mrs. Jacobs to make lifestyle modifications. These include incorporating regular physical activity in her daily routine and using compression stockings while traveling. The risk-benefit ratio of continuing anticoagulation therapy will also be re-evaluated after three months.

Patient Profile: Mr. Anthony  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  presented with sudden onset breathlessness and chest pain. He is a retired lawyer  lives with his wife  and is an active smoker for the past 30 years with a cumulative intake of 40 pack-years.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Anthony has a diagnosis of hypertension  controlled with medication over the past 10 years. He had undergone right knee replacement surgery two weeks ago. He does not carry any known allergy to food or medication.  Family History:  His father died in his 70s due to myocardial infarction. His mother passed away due to an unexplained sudden death in her 60s. He has one older sister who recently had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) treated.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Anthony described the onset of sharp  left-sided chest pain that began earlier in the day  which intensified on deep breathing. He also reported experiencing increasing dyspnea over the previous 2 days.  Investigations Performed:  EKG revealed sinus tachycardia but was otherwise unremarkable. Lab results showed elevated D-dimer levels  and his arterial blood gas analysis indicated moderate hypoxemia. A CT pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was conducted that showed signs of a pulmonary embolism in the left lower lobe branch of the pulmonary artery.  Diagnosis:  Based on the CTPA findings and clinical context  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made. Due to his recent orthopedic surgery and family history  Mr. Anthony is at a high risk for Thromboembolic events.  Management Plan:  He was subsequently started on low-molecular-weight heparin as an in-patient and was discussed for longer-term anticoagulation given his high-risk status. Stopping smoking was also severely advised.  Follow-Up: A referral was being made to the thrombosis clinic for continued management of his anticoagulation and risk factors. His case also highlighted the need for post-operative venous thromboembolism prophylaxis in orthopedic cases  which was discussed in a multidisciplinary meeting.   Mr. Anthony represents a typical case of acute pulmonary embolism precipitated by a recent surgical procedure  underscoring the importance of risk stratification and prophylaxis in perioperative management.    This case presentation can be expanded or modified based on any specific aspects you need to focus on  like discussion on the diagnostic approach  detailed management plan  long-term follow-up  or preventive strategies.

Patient Case Presentation - Acute Pulmonary Embolism -------------------------------------------------------------  I. Patient Details: --------------------- The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Richard Dawson. He is 170 cm tall  weighs 84 kg  and is a retired teacher.  II. Presenting Complaint: --------------------------- Mr. Dawson has been brought to the ER complaining of sudden  acute chest pain and shortness of breath that started a few hours ago. He also mentioned experiencing dizziness and an episode of fainting.  III. Past Medical History: ---------------------------- On further investigations of his past medical history  it has been found that Mr. Dawson was diagnosed with hypertension 12 years ago and has been on medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). He also underwent a hip replacement surgery around three weeks back due to a fall accident.  IV. Family History: ---------------------- His father died of a myocardial infarction  and his older brother was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the past.   V. Physical Examination: ---------------------------- He has a blood pressure reading of 165/95 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. His physical examination is marked by tachycardia  decreased breath sounds on the right side of the chest  and swelling in his right lower leg.  VI. Investigations & Diagnosis: ----------------------------------- Given that the triad of symptoms and signs - chest pain  shortness of breath  and clinical evidence of DVT  of Mr. Dawson pointed towards PE  hence a CT pulmonary angiogram was performed which confirmed a large clot in the right pulmonary artery. The D-Dimer test was also performed which further validated the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. EKG showed signs of right heart strain.  VII: Treatment: ----------------- Mr. Dawson was immediately started on unfractionated heparin for anticoagulation. After the clinical stabilization  he was then transitioned to oral anticoagulants  which he will need to continue for several months.  VIII: Patient Education & Follow up: -------------------------------------- The patient was educated about his condition  including factors that might have contributed to his PE condition such as recent surgery and family history of DVT. The importance of taking his medication as prescribed and the need for regular follow-ups were stressed. The patient was also advised to immediately report to the hospital if symptoms such as chest pain or breathlessness recurred in the future.   The follow up is planned in 4 weeks time for monitoring his condition and ensuring the right level of anticoagulation has been achieved.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. X is a 65-year-old caucasian male  presenting with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain which he describes as ""sharp""  rating it an 8 on a scale of 1-10. He mentions that the pain seems to exacerbate while taking deep breaths. His wife  who accompanied him  states that the patient also complained of light-headedness and has been excessively sweating for the past 1 hour.   Past Medical History (PMH):  Mr. X has a known case of hypertension for which he is on medication (Amlodipine). He is also a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history but quit smoking around 10 years back. He was detected to have type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago and is currently on metformin. There are no known drug allergies.   Family History:  His father died of a Myocardial Infarction at the age of 72 and his mother died of stroke at 80. He has a younger brother  aged 62  who was recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT). His eldest son  aged 35  is a known hypertensive.  Social History:  The patient is retired and lives with his wife and a 30-year-old son. He denies any alcohol or substance abuse. He is a veteran who served in the military for 20 years but has led a sedentary lifestyle post-retirement.  Examination:   On examination  the patient appears in respiratory distress. His vitals reveal a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and his oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Lung auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds at the right lung base. The lower extremities do not show any signs of DVT.   Investigations:  An ECG showed sinus tachycardia but no signs of myocardial infarction. D-dimer levels were found to be significantly elevated. A subsequent CT Pulmonary Angiogram confirmed the diagnosis with visualization of a clot in the right lower lobe pulmonary artery.  Summary:  In view of the clinical presentation  past medical history suggestive of multiple risk factors (history of hypertension  diabetes  smoking)  family history (brother with DVT)  raised D-Dimer levels  and positive radiological evidence of clot in the lung  a diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism was made. The patient was successfully managed with oxygen therapy and anticoagulation therapy in the hospital.

Presentation:  The patient  Mr. Johnson  is a 72-year-old African American male presenting with sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath at rest which started two days ago. His medical history reveals a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hypertension. He has been on a combination of antihypertensive drugs including ACE inhibitors and calcium channel blockers for his hypertension. He also has a 40-year pack history of cigarette smoking.   Regarding familial history  Mr. Johnson has two late brothers  one died from a myocardial infarction and the other from stoke  both at relatively young ages (60s). He lives with his wife and their two adult children  in a 2-story house and refers to be mostly sedentary  avoiding any strenuous activities as a result of feeling short-of-breath.   Recently  he was on a long international flight back to the states (about 12 hours of flight time) from visiting relatives. He noticed that he became increasingly short of breath for about two days  which didn't improve with rest. Today  upon arrival to the emergency department (ED)  he appears visibly distressed  diaphoretic  and tachypneic. His vitals in the ED are as follows  Blood pressure: 114/78 mmHg  Heart rate: 112 bpm  RR: 28 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation: 89%  Temperature: 98.7 degrees Fahrenheit.  He received oxygen and is currently on 2L per nasal cannula. He is still tachypneic and short of breath. His right lower leg is slightly swollen and darker in color compared to his left leg. Due to the suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism  a computed tomographic angiography (CTA) was performed revealing a large clot burden in the right main pulmonary artery. D-dimer levels were also elevated.  In light of his history  clinical picture  and diagnostic imaging  Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism. He was subsequently started on anticoagulation therapy. His family has been informed  and discussions about the importance of medication adherence  lifestyle modifications  and potential measures to prevent future deep vein thrombosis (DVTs) are ongoing.

Case Presentation  Patient Profile: Mr. X is a 60-year-old African-American male  who works as an accountant. He's married with two children  weighs approximately 90 kg  and stands at 6 feet tall.  Presenting Complaint: He presents to the emergency department of our hospital with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath followed by sharp  stabbing chest pains worsened by deep breathing. The patient also reports feeling lightheaded and is experiencing substantial sweating.  Past Medical History: The patient is known to have Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes  both of which he manages with medication (metformin for diabetes and amlodipine for high blood pressure). He also had an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a knee replacement surgery approximately two years ago  for which he took anticoagulants for six months.  Family History: Both his parents had hypertension and his father died of a myocardial infarction in his late 70s. His older sister also has type 2 diabetes. There is no known history of hereditary clotting disorders in his family.  Social History: The patient leads a sedentary lifestyle and works predominantly seated. He indicates occasional alcohol intake but denies any smoking habits or use of illicit drugs. His diet primarily consists of processed foods and he admits to struggling with weight management.  Investigations: Preliminary examination reveals tachycardia with a rate of 100 bpm and tachypnea with 22 breaths/min. His blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. A CT pulmonary angiogram is ordered and confirms the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism.   Laboratory Findings: A D-dimer test was also found to be positive. His complete blood count  kidney  and liver function tests are within normal limits. His HbA1C is 7.2  indicating suboptimal glucose control.   Summary: Mr. X's symptoms  prior history of DVT  and the recent CT scan's findings solidly confirm an acute pulmonary embolism. His history of hypertension  diabetes  and a sedentary lifestyle places him at a higher risk for thromboembolic events. Given his prior medication history  compliance  and current situation  an appropriate anticoagulation treatment plan is being considered. In addition  lifestyle modifications and better diabetes management will be crucial components in his recovery and long-term health strategy.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 58-year-old African American male  named John  with a history of obesity and chronic sedentary lifestyle. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. His past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are well-controlled with medication (Atenolol and Atorvastatin  respectively). He lives with his wife and has three adult children. He is a retired engineer.  Family History:  John's father passed away at a young age (in his late 50s) due to myocardial infarction. His mother is living and has Type II diabetes. One of his siblings was diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism at 50 years old. John has never had any genetic or blood clotting disorder testing.  Presenting Symptoms:  John presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath coupled with chest pain which started earlier in the morning while he was reading the newspaper. He complained that his symptoms worsened when lying down and he found relief when he sat upright. John also noted feeling anxious due to breathing difficulty. He denied any cough  leg swelling  or recent long travel.  Examination:  On examination  he was in obvious distress. His vitals revealed tachycardia (heart rate elevated at 110 beats/minute) and mild hypotension. Oxygen saturation was low (85%). He was afebrile. Exam also noted his body mass index (BMI) was at the level of obesity. Lungs auscultation showed poor air entry bilaterally. The rest of the exam was within normal limits  including a normal neurological exam.  Diagnosis:  His D-dimer levels were extremely high  raising high suspicion of a clot. A subsequent Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) revealed a large clot in the right pulmonary artery confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Management and prognosis:  John was immediately started on anticoagulation therapy with Low Molecular Weight Heparin and admission to the intensive care unit (ICU) was arranged. Arrangement was also made for a consultants from cardiology  hematology and pulmonology teams to further manage the patient's condition.  This case demonstrates the importance of considering Pulmonary Embolism (PE) in patients presenting with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain  especially in patients with risk factors like obesity  hypertension  and a family history of PE. This case also underscores the need for quick evaluation and immediate treatment in these types of patients to lower the mortality rate.

Case Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. J. Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department of our hospital over the weekend. His chief complaints were sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain. The symptoms began abruptly two hours prior to hospital admission. His daughter reported he looked pale  somewhat sweaty  and appeared quite anxious.   Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has had chronic hypertension for the last 15 years  for which he takes Lisinopril. He also has a history of unprovoked deep venous thrombosis (DVT) of his right lower leg  diagnosed three years ago for which he received anticoagulant therapy but had discontinued this one year ago. Mr. Doe has no history of coronary artery disease  diabetes  or respiratory illness.  Family History: His family history revealed that his father died from an acute myocardial infarction at 67 years old  and his mother passed away from breast cancer at the age of 76. His younger brother was diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism at the age of 51 but is alive and in good health after treatment.   Social History: Mr. Doe is a retired accountant who smokes about half a packet of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years. He consumes the occasional social drink of alcohol but denies illicit drug use. He has been generally active but recognizes that he has been less mobile during recent lockdown measures due to the pandemic.  Physical Examination: On assessment  he was conscious  but had marked respiratory distress. His blood pressure was 105/75 mmHg  his pulse was 112 bpm  the respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and he had an oxygen saturation of 92% while breathing room air.  Clinical Course: His blood tests showed raised D-dimer levels  a complete blood count and chemistry panel came out normal. The electrocardiogram revealed sinus tachycardia. Chest X-ray did not show any abnormalities. Owing to the clinical suspicion of pulmonary embolism  a CT pulmonary angiography was done  which confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral pulmonary embolism.  Key Issues/Plan: The plan includes the initiation of anticoagulant therapy and monitoring his oxygen saturation and hemodynamic stability closely. As he also has a history of DVT and a recurrence of venous thromboembolism  a consultation with a hematologist will be scheduled to discuss the possibility of a lifelong anticoagulant treatment. His smoking habits should be addressed and should be given smoking cessation advice  given the underlying cardiac risks due to hypertension.

Patient Case Presentation   Patient Information: Patient's initials: J.B.  Age: 59  Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian   Presenting Complaint: Patient J.B.  presented to the emergency department (ED) with abrupt onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: J.B. has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he is on regular medication. He had a knee replacement surgery a month ago. He's a non-smoker and rarely consumes alcohol. He does not have history of drug abuse.  Family History: His mother had a stroke at the age of 60 and his father died at a young age due to myocardial infarction. He has two healthy siblings and his only son is asthmatic.  Clinical Exam: On examination  J.B. was restless and in obvious distress. His blood pressure was found to be 160/90 mmHg  his heart rate was 110 bpm  his respiratory rate was 24 breaths/minute  and his oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Cardiac examination was unremarkable apart from tachycardia. His lung examination revealed decreased breath sounds on the right lower lung fields  but no crackles or wheezes were noted.  Investigations: Blood tests showed increased D-dimer levels. An Electrocardiogram (EKG) showed sinus tachycardia but no ST segment or T wave changes. A chest X-ray showed no signs of pneumonia  pneumothorax  or other obvious abnormalities. A subsequent computed tomography (CT) angiogram scan confirmed the presence of an acute pulmonary embolism in the right lower lobe pulmonary artery.  Diagnosis: Given the sudden onset of symptoms  the patient's recent surgery  the presence of risk factors in his medical history and the results of clinical investigations  a diagnosis of acute right lower lobe pulmonary embolism was made.  Treatment: J.B. was placed on supplemental oxygen to combat his hypoxemia and was initiated on intravenous heparin to prevent further clot formation. The decision was made to admit him to the Intensive Care Unit for close monitoring. Consultation requests were also sent to a pulmonologist and a hematologist for further management.  Discussion: This case emphasizes the importance of considering a pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with sudden onset of chest discomfort and dyspnea  especially in the presence of known risk factors like recent surgery  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. The case also highlights the importance of various investigations in confirming the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. It serves as a reminder that appropriate and immediate management can greatly improve the prognosis in such serious conditions.

Subject: Acute Pulley Emblation  Patient Information: Name: Mrs. Gonzalez Age: 56 Sex: Female Ethnicity: Hispanic Country: USA  Brief History & Lifestyle: Mrs. Gonzalez  a known smoker for 25 years  works a sedentary office job. She leads a relatively inactive lifestyle and battles obesity. Her diet is poor with frequent consumption of fast food and high salt and cholesterol products. She has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and has complaints of recent onset of difficulty in breathing.   Medical History: She has a medical history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM) and Hypertension for the past 7 years. Family history includes a father who passed away due to a Stroke and a mother with a history of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). She has been non-compliant with her medication more than once due to financial concerns. There are no allergies reported.  Presenting:  Came to the emergency complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp chest pain  palpitations  which started around 6 hours back  while she was at work. She was profusely sweating  and felt faintness before arrival. On arrival  her pulse was 101/min  BP -140/93mmHg  respirations were 24/min and SpO2 was 88% on room air.  Investigation Results: ABG showed Hypoxemia  a D-dimer test was done given her risk factors  which came back positive. Her chest X-ray was unremarkable  ECG showed sinus tachycardia. Given her symptoms  medical and family history a Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) test was ordered which confirmed the diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism.  Management: She was started on oxygen therapy immediately. Anticoagulation was initiated with Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) and she was admitted to the ICU where she will be closely monitored for her symptoms. Once stabilize further testing will be conducted to look for other possible sources of emboli. She will be recommended lifestyle changes and will be encouraged to follow diligently her prescribed medications to prevent further events.  Conclusion: The patient's medical history  lifestyle  and family history can all be correlated to her current diagnosis. Non-compliance to medication  history of T2DM and hypertension  sedentary lifestyle  and a family history of thrombotic diseases are all risk factors. Mrs. Gonzalez needs to undergo immediate lifestyle changes and remain compliant with her course of medications.

Patient Overview:  The patient is Mr. Michael Brown  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  currently residing in middle-class suburban Houston  Texas. He is employments retired and lives with his wife.   Past Medical History:  He has a history of arteriosclerosis  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and peptic ulcer disease. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history but quit 10 years ago. He also has a significant history of long  sedentary periods due to his previous employment as a truck driver.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Brown presented in the emergency department complaining of sudden-onset shortness of breath  chest tightness and light-headedness. His symptoms started suddenly while sitting and watching television at home. There were no precipitating factors such as trauma or rigorous exercise.  Family History:  His father died of a stroke at the age of 72 and his mother had diabetes and died at the age of 88 due to kidney failure. His older brother suffers from peripheral vascular disease and also has been recently diagnosed with atrial fibrillation.  Clinical Findings and Diagnosis:  On examination  Mr. Brown was visibly distressed  tachycardic  tachypneic and hypoxic. His oxygen saturation was 88% on room air. Blood pressure was 165/95mmHg. A physical examination revealed decreased breath sounds and crackles on the right lower lung. The well's criterion score was 6  suggestive of a high probability of pulmonary embolism.  Investigations:  An electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia and right bundle branch block. Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels. A bedside ultrasound showed signs of right ventricular strain  and a CT pulmonary angiography confirmed the diagnosis of a massive right-sided pulmonary embolism.  Management and Follow Up:  He was immediately started on Oxygen therapy  and Low molecular weight Heparin was administered for anticoagulation. The patient was admitted to the ICU for further management and monitoring. Interventional Radiology was consulted for possible thrombectomy given the size and severity of embolism. Hospitalization  strict bed rest  and follow-up anticoagulant checks have been scheduled.  Prevention:  Given the patient’s travel history and sedentary lifestyle  he will be counseled on the potential risk factors for recurring instances of a pulmonary embolism. Long periods of immobility will be discouraged  and he will be instructed to engage in mild  but regular activity. His family has also been made aware of the situation to ensure proper social support.  In conclusion  Mr. Brown's presentation  history  and clinical findings led to a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. Immediate intervention and follow-up care are essential components of his management plan. It is equally crucial to update his lifestyle habits for the prevention of any recurring events.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Smith Age: 55 years old Gender: Male Profession: Investment Banker  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. John Smith presented to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset  sharp  central chest pain and shortness of breath for the past 4 hours. The pain worsened on deep breathing and did not radiate to any other part of the body.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both of which have been well-controlled with medication. He also has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 2 years ago. He takes ramipril  metformin  and atorvastatin.  Family History:  His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  both his father and paternal uncle having suffered myocardial infarctions in their sixth decade.  Social History:  He is an occasional smoker and consumes alcohol socially. His job as an investment banker is largely sedentary with long working hours and frequent air travel.   Examination and Investigation:  On examination  he was found to be in respiratory distress with tachypnea  tachycardia  and decreased oxygen saturation (SpO2 90% on room air). His blood pressure was stable. Blood tests showed elevated D-dimer levels. An ECG showed sinus tachycardia but no signs of myocardial infarction. A Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE) showing a large embolus lodged in the right main pulmonary artery.  Diagnosis and Treatment:  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism likely secondary to his history of DVT and recent long-haul flight (risk factors for VTE - venous thromboembolism). He was started on therapeutic anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and later bridged to a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC). His case was discussed with the Hematology team and it was agreed to continue lifelong anticoagulation considering his risk factors and previous episodes. He was stabilized  educated about the importance of medication compliance  and was discharged with outpatient follow-ups.    Throughout his hospital stay  he was closely monitored for complications including deterioration in respiratory status or signs of bleeding  a possible side effect of anticoagulation therapy.  Outcome and Plan:  Mr. Smith recovered well with a notable improvement in his symptoms. He was advised to mitigate other modifiable risk factors  such as trying to quit smoking  reducing alcohol intake  maintaining a balanced diet  and incorporating regular physical activity into his routine. He will be reviewed routinely in the outpatient clinic  focusing on adherence to medication and lifestyle modification advice. He was also suggested to wear compression stockings during prolonged periods of immobility such as long flights to reduce the risk of DVT.

Subject: Acute Pulmonary Embolism – Patient Case Summary  Patient Information:  The patient is a 55-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. X  who resides in Johnson City  a non-smoker  and has a non-vegetarian diet.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. X presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain  which was aggravated by deep inspirations.  Past Medical History: The patient has a noted history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg two years ago. It was treated with a course of anticoagulants. Other medical records indicate current controlled hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus.  Family History: His family history is positive for cardiovascular diseases; his father had a myocardial infarction at age 65 and his mother passed due to stroke at age 72.  Diagnosis: Given the patient's presenting symptoms and past medical history  a D-dimer test was completed in the ED. The results were elevated at 0.7 mcg/mL (normal ranges are less than 0.5 mcg/mL). Consequently  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was done  confirming a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment: The patient was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy with intravenous Heparin  followed by warfarinization.   Current Status: The initial treatment response was positive; the patient's shortness of breath and chest pains diminished progressively. He was hospitalized for observation and management  and currently  his vital signs remain stable.   Plan: The patient will continue with his coagulation therapies during the hospitalization and is planned to be discharged on oral anticoagulants – Warfarin for a minimum of three months post-discharge. Additionally  he will be referred for a lifestyle and nutrition consultancy for obesity management  and diabetes and hypertension regular follow-ups are also planned.   Prevention: To prevent further instances of DVT or PE  the patient should maintain good control of his diabetes and hypertension  adhere to the prescribed anticoagulant regime  partake in regular moderate-intensity exercises  and remain hydrated. This case underscores the importance of early detection and management of DVT in a high-risk patient.   Conclusion: Keeping in view of the patient's medical history  the sudden onset of symptoms  D-dimer result and the positive CTPA test  we diagnosed this as a case of acute pulmonary embolism. A multidisciplinary approach involving the cardiologist  nutritionist  and physiotherapist along with the patient's primary care physician is required to manage the range of health issues including PE  obesity  hypertension  and diabetes.

Patient Case Presentation: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: The patient  Mr. John Doe  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male residing in New York City. He is retired  having previously worked as a schoolteacher  and currently lives alone  with occasional visits from his daughter.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  but has maintained both conditions relatively well through medication and lifestyle modifications. He also suffered from deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago. His BMI is in the overweight range. His surgical history includes an appendectomy at the age of 30 and a hernia repair at age 45.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe presented with sudden onset dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain  and mild hemoptysis which had started a few hours prior to his arrival at the hospital. Upon questioning  he also reported recent lack of appetite and a slight weight gain.  Family History: The patient’s father died at age 72 due to myocardial infarction. His mother  aged 87  is living and has hypertension and Parkinson's disease. His older brother died at 60 due to complications after a heart bypass surgery. No blood disorders are known in the family.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  Mr. Doe appeared anxious. Vital signs were notable for tachycardia with a heart rate of 124 bpm  BP of 136/85 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  with oxygen saturation at 90% on room air. His temperature was within normal limits at 37.0 C°.  Investigations: Blood investigations confirmed marginally elevated D-dimers. Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed sinus tachycardia with no signs of right heart strain. Chest radiographs were unremarkable. Ultrasound conducted on both lower extremities showed the presence of DVT. Finally  a CT pulmonary angiogram revealed a clot in the left pulmonary artery  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Management Plan: He was immediately started on parenteral anticoagulation therapy with low-molecular-weight heparin and then transitioned to oral anticoagulation with warfarin for long term anticoagulation. The plan includes outpatient follow-ups to monitor INR levels and adjustment of warfarin dosage accordingly. The patient was advised for lifestyle modification  weight loss  and compliance to medications.  Prognosis: Although Mr. Doe presents a risk due to his previous history of DVT and current PE  his response to the immediate anticoagulation therapy was positive. He was stabilized and discharged after 5 days. Close monitoring and medical compliance will be necessary for the patient to maintain his health status.  This case highlights the importance of swift action and diagnosis in acute cases of PE  taking into account an individual's physiological and pathological history as well as clinical manifestations.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a 55-year-old Male   Patient Profile:   The patient under discussion is a 55-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Smith. He weighs 92 kg and is 176 cm tall. He is a non-smoker  with no previous history of substance or alcohol abuse.   Medical History:   Mr. Smith has had a history of prolonged immobility due to his job of long-distance truck driving. Also  a past medical history of hypertension is present. He had been taking antihypertensive medication for the last seven years. He underwent a hernia repair surgery two years ago. There's no history of any known allergies.   Presenting Complaint:   Mr. Smith presented with sudden onset dyspnea  chest pain  and blood-streaked sputum. Complaints of light-headedness and fainting spell were also reported. On admission  he appeared cyanotic  with a visible diaphoresis.  Examination & Investigations:   On examination  he was tachycardic and tachypneic with oxygen saturation of 85% on room air. His blood pressure measured at 110/70mmHg. D-dimer levels were found to be significantly elevated. A CT pulmonary angiogram was ordered that confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral pulmonary embolism.  Interventions:   Mr. Smith was immediately started on supplemental oxygen and anticoagulation therapy with low molecular weight heparin. Hemodynamic stability was achieved. Subsequent plan for introduction of oral anticoagulation- Coumadin was made considering the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Family History:  His father had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and his mother was hypertensive. He had no siblings.  Social History:  Mr. Smith lives with his wife and two adult children. His job involves long hours of driving with minimal physical activity. He reports consumption of fast food due to lack of time and admits difficulty in managing regular exercise and a healthy diet.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of considering Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE) as a differential in patients presenting with dyspnea  chest pain under the background of risk factors such as prolonged immobility  especially in those with a positive family history of DVT. Patient's job involving long-distance driving was a significant non-modifiable risk factor. Regular patient education about maintaining a healthy lifestyle  despite job constraints  is warranted.   Follow-up:  Mr. Smith's case would also require regular follow-ups considering his occupation puts him at risk for recurrent events. Planning for patient education regarding signs of recurrent PE  need for regular medication compliance  and lifestyle modifications is crucial in his case.

Patient Presentation:  Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male named John. He is a retired banker and lives with his wife.  Chief Complaint: John presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain that started two hours ago. He also complained of shortness of breath and anxiety.  Past Medical History: John has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His hypertension is controlled by a daily regimen of Lisinopril and his diabetes is managed with metformin. He was also diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his right leg 6 months ago  for which he was prescribed a 6-month course of rivaroxaban  which he just completed last month.  Social History: John quit smoking 10 years ago after a 30-pack-year history. He drinks alcohol socially and has a diet that is high in sodium.  Family History: Both his parents had a history of cardiovascular diseases. His mother died because of a stroke at 72  and his father had coronary artery disease and died at the age of 79.  Physical Exam: John is anxious  has tachypnea (respiratory rate 30/min) with lung examination revealing decreased breath sounds at the right lower lobe. Heart rate is 110 bpm  blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg. Lower extremity examination shows no signs of DVT.  Investigations: An urgent CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of right-sided pulmonary embolism. In addition  an ECG revealed S1Q3T3 pattern. D-dimer levels were significantly raised.  Conclusion: Considering John's history of DVT  elevated D-dimer levels and CT angiogram findings  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made. His treatment was started immediately  including the administration of oxygen and anticoagulant therapy as well as closely monitoring of his hemodynamic status considering his age and cardiovascular risks.

Patient Presentation  Patient Details:  The patient is a 55-year-old African American male  who lives and works in New York as a bank manager. He smokes approximately half a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 30 years and consumes alcohol moderately. He is overweight with a BMI of 30 and is consistently engaged in a sedentary lifestyle.  Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and chronic type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with both these conditions 10 years ago. His medication includes Metformin 1000mg twice daily  Losartan 50mg once a day  and daily Aspirin 81mg. He is inconsistent with his medications and follow-ups due to his busy work life.   Family History: His father died at 60 from a myocardial infarction and his maternal aunt from a stroke at the age of 50. He has two elder brothers who are both living and have histories of deep vein thrombosis. No family history of malignancy is noted.  Presenting Complaints: The patient arrived at the emergency department presenting with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  and mild hemoptysis. He also reported a progressively worsening left leg pain and swelling over the past week  which he initially overlooked  attributing it to prolonged sitting at work.  Examination & Investigation: On examination  his heart rate was 110 beats per minute  blood pressure was 155/95mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  oxygen saturations 90% on room air. An ECG showed signs of right heart strain. A Doppler Ultrasound of his left leg revealed a thrombus in the deep veins of the calf  and a subsequent CT Chest angiography confirmed a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment: He was immediately commenced on low molecular weight heparins and plans for long-term anticoagulation were discussed. An IVC filter was also considered due to his significant risk of recurrent DVT and PE. He was counseled on the importance of regular follow-ups  medication adherence  and lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation  weight reduction  and adding exercise to his daily routine.  Future Consideration: Given his lifestyle  strong family history and co-morbidities  the patient is at significantly high risk for further cardiovascular events. It is advised that he needs stringent cardiovascular risk factor modification  close follow-up care  and patient education regarding the signs of DVT and pulmonary embolism.   This patient's case highlights that symptoms of DVT can often be ignored by the patient leading to more life-threatening conditions like pulmonary embolism. Active health education and promotion is an important strategy to prevent such cases.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Dwight Becker  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself to the emergency department with symptoms of acute shortness of breath  chest discomfort  and cough with blood-streaked sputum. He is a retired corporate officer  widowed  and takes care of his small farm partly for sustenance and partly as a physical activity hobby.   Past Medical History: Mr. Becker has a history of hypertension and was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes five years ago  which is currently managed with metformin. He also has moderately managed osteoarthritis. He is a former smoker  with a smoking history of 30 pack-years  having quit seven years ago. He also enjoys a moderate alcohol intake weekly. In the past ten years  he has maintained exercise and dietary discipline that has helped manage his blood pressure and blood sugar.  Family History: The patient's father had coronary artery disease and passed away in his 70s due to a myocardial infarction. His mother had osteoarthritis  but lived until the ripe age of 83. His older sister (68 years old) is alive and has a history of rheumatic heart disease.  Current Presentation: Mr. Becker rated his chest pain as 6/10 on the pain scale  describing it as a sudden sharp pain under the rib cage while breathing. He reported a two-day history of progressive dyspnea and calf pain  as well as tachycardia and a fainting episode. The patient's vitals at presentation were as follows: BP - 148/92 mmHg  HR - 115 bpm  RR - 22 breaths/min  T - 98.6°F  SpO2 - 92% on room air. His BMI calculates to be 29.9 (Height: 5 feet 8 inches  Weight: 195 pounds).  Diagnostic Evaluation and Outcome: Based on the symptoms and the elevated D-dimer level  a CT angiogram was ordered  which confirmed bi-lateral pulmonary emboli. Lower extremity Doppler studies verified a DVT in his right calf. He was admitted to the hospital and promptly started on anticoagulation (heparin drip). Over the next three days  his symptoms improved significantly. He was transitioned to oral warfarin for long-term therapy.  Further management includes risk factor modification and a thrombophilia workup to determine possible genetic or acquired predisposition. He has been advised regular follow-ups and to continue the exercise and diet for his comorbidities.  Therefore  the in-depth examination  appropriate lab studies  understanding patient history  swift diagnosis  and prompt management paved the way for a quick recovery from this precarious condition.   Over the next visits  the clinical focus would be on compliance with the medications for the comorbid conditions and the newly diagnosed PE  necessary lifestyle modifications  and to ensure early detection and intervention for possible exacerbations or complications.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old male  presented with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that intensified with breathing. He has no known allergies but has a past medical history significant for hypertension  diabetes  and smoking. Mr. Smith is a retired lawyer  a lifetime smoker with a 30 pack year history  a weekend alcoholic  and has a sedentary lifestyle. He lives with his wife and does not have any kids. He denies any illicit drug use. He takes Metformin and Lisinopril for his diabetes and hypertension  respectively and is compliant with his medications.  Family History:   His father had an ischemic stroke at the age of 70 and his mother has hypertension and osteoporosis. His brother was recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT).   Current Presentation:   The patient reported experiencing a sudden onset of dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain for the last 6 hours. There have been no previous episodes of this nature. He denies cough  fever  night sweats  weight loss  or hemoptysis. He also denies recent prolonged immobility  surgery  or trauma.   Physical Exam:   Physical examination demonstrated a moderately distressed man due to dyspnea. His vitals included blood pressure of 145/95 mm Hg  heart rate of 105 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 per minute  temperature of 98.7°F  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. His BMI was calculated to be 28. His cardiovascular exam was notable for tachycardia but no murmurs  rubs  or gallop. The lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally  but he had decreased breath sounds on the right side. Lower extremity examination did not reveal any signs of DVT.   Investigations and Diagnosis:  Given the acute onset of symptoms and family history of DVT  a hypercoagulability work-up was ordered  including D-dimer which came back elevated. CT Pulmonary Angiogram was performed that confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  with evidence of a large clot burden within the right pulmonary artery.   Management:  Mr. Smith was promptly started on Oxygen therapy and anticoagulant medication  low molecular weight heparin  was initiated. In view of his large clot burden and elevated troponin  a discussion regarding the appropriateness of thrombolytic therapy was held.  Conclusion:  This case of Mr. Smith is a clear example of how a sedentary lifestyle  along with other practices  such as smoking and alcohol  can contribute to life-threatening conditions like acute PE. Public health efforts should aim at educating people on recognizing signs of conditions like PE and seeking prompt help.  Note: Patient and family consent taken for case discussion.

Patient Details:   - Name: Mr. James Thompson - Age: 58 - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Taxi driver  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Thompson presented to the Emergency Department with a 2-day history of progressively worsening shortness of breath  chest pain (described as sharp  8/10 intensity)  and a low-grade fever. He also reported an episode of fainting while climbing the stairs at home.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson has a 20-year history of hypertension controlled by medication (Lisinopril 10 mg/daily). He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes 5 years ago and has been managing it diet and Metformin. He quit smoking 10 years ago and has a history of heavy alcohol intake. He has no known allergies.  Family History:  His father died at age 62 due to myocardial infarction and his mother  aged 78  is living with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). His younger brother  aged 55  has recently been diagnosed with Prostate Cancer.  Relevant Examination Results:  - Temperature: 37.8 degrees Celsius - Pulse: 110 bpm and irregular - Blood Pressure: 165/95 mm Hg - Respiratory Rate: 24 breaths per minute - Oxygen Saturation: 92% on room air.   Blood investigation showed elevated D-dimer levels. Chest X-ray didn't show any significant abnormality. Given his symptoms and risk factors  Mr. Thompson underwent a CT Pulmonary Angiogram  which confirmed the presence of multiple emboli in the lobar arteries of both lungs.  Management:  A diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made. He was immediately started on low molecular weight Heparin (LMWH) and later switched to oral anticoagulation Warfarin. Mr. Thompson was advised to quit alcohol and to maintain a healthy lifestyle including a balanced diet and regular exercise  which would also assist with his hypertension and diabetes management.  Mr. Thompson's case further strengthens our understanding of the importance of patient’s history  clinical presentation  and early diagnostic intervention in managing potentially life-threatening conditions such as acute pulmonary embolism. This multidisciplinary approach involving emergency physicians  radiologists  and cardiologists was key in providing the best possible care to Mr. Thompson in a timely manner. Future management will focus on controlling his risk factors while monitoring for any complications associated with his treatment.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. A.B. His occupation is a retired bank manager. He is a former smoker and consumes alcohol only occasionally. There is no ilegal drug use. He is married with two adult children.   Presenting Complaint: The patient was brought into the emergency department (ED) with breathlessness and chest pain lasting for a few hours.   History of Present Illness: At admission  the patient reported that the pain in his chest started suddenly when he was gardening  described as sharp and non-radiating  and was exacerbated by taking deep breaths. There was also an associated sudden onset of breathlessness but no cough or hemoptysis. He did not experience any palpitations  unconsciousness  leg swelling  or recent long flights in the past month.  Past Medical History: His past medical history includes controlled hypertension for the past 10 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for 7 years. He suffered a heart attack 8 years ago and had a stent placed. There’s no known history of deep vein thrombosis or clotting disorders.  Family History: His father passed away in his 60s from a heart attack and his mother is in her 90s and diagnosed with dementia. His sister suffers from hypothyroidism.  Treatment History and Medications: The patient is on Metformin  Lisinopril  Aspirin  and Lipitor. The patient claims to be compliant with his medication routine.  Physical exam: On examination  he displayed signs of respiratory distress  evident through increased respiratory rates (22 breaths per min) and oxygen saturation levels at 92% on room air. His blood pressure was 148/90 mmHg  Heart rate 102 bpm  and body temperature 98.6°F. Chest examination revealed tachycardia with a normal rhythm and no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  Investigations: An ECG demonstrated signs of right ventricular strain. A chest X-ray was normal. D-dimer test was significantly raised. In view of his symptoms  raised D-Dimer and pointers from ECG  a CT pulmonary angiography was promptly performed which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Plan: The diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was immediately addressed by starting the patient on anticoagulant therapy intravenously in the ED. Further risk stratification to identify the severity of PE is necessary to tailor the subsequent management plan. Given his age and cardiac history  a referral to a hematologist for further investigations into an underlying hypercoagulable state should also be considered.  This case requires the coordination of multiple health care professionals  involving emergency physicians  radiologists  cardiologists  and hematologists  to both manage the acute crisis and develop a long-term management plan for the patient.

Patient Information: Mr. A is a 56-year-old Caucasian male. He is a non-smoker and professionally  he is a truck driver.  Chief Complaint: Complaints of sudden-onset and progressively worsening shortness of breath. Accompanied by chest pain that intensifies with deep breathing.  Past Medical History: Includes hypertension and obesity for which he is regularly taking antihypertensives and has been advised a low-calorie diet and regular exercise. He admits to being non-compliant with lifestyle modifications.  Family History: Father passed away from myocardial infarction in his early 60s. Mother has type 2 diabetes and hypertension.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  he looked anxious and dyspneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/min  blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  and heart rate of 102 beats/min. Lung auscultation was unremarkable and there was no lower limb swelling.  Assessment: Given the patient's symptoms and risk factors such as age  hypertension  obesity  and sedentary lifestyle  there was a strong suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism.   Diagnostic Tests: Complete blood count  coagulation profile  D-dimers  chest X-ray and ECG were initially performed. D-dimers were elevated  ECG showed sinus tachycardia but was otherwise nonspecific  chest X-ray was unremarkable. A computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was then subsequently performed which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment: The patient was started on oxygen therapy and parenteral anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin  followed by transition to oral anticoagulation.  Follow-Up: He was advised to continue on oral anticoagulation  control hypertension  manage obesity through diet and lifestyle modifications  and consider prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis during long drives associated with his profession. A follow-up visit in the clinic was scheduled in two weeks to assess the patient's status.  This case highlights the significance of considering pulmonary embolism in patients presenting with unexplained dyspnea  especially if they have risk factors for venous thromboembolism. Prompt diagnosis and treatment can significantly improve patient's outcomes. A multidisciplinary approach  involving lifestyle modifications and patient education about disease and medication compliance  is crucial for secondary prevention.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Dexter Thompson  aged 61  African-American  is a retired construction worker presenting to the emergency department with complaints of sudden-onset breathlessness  palpitations  and a sharp chest pain on the left side that gets worse upon inhalation. He described his pain intensity as 8/10. He denies any alleviation factors but admits that pain intensification occurs with deep inhalation.  Past Medical history:  Mr. Thompson was diagnosed with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus 12 years ago  both conditions are well-controlled with consistent medication Amlodipine 10mg daily  Metformin 1000mg twice daily  and Novolin 70/30 Insulin 15 Units twice daily. He was also diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) 4 years ago but denies history of asthma attacks  allergy  or tuberculosis.  Family history:  He reports his father died at 70 from a myocardial infarction and his mother passed away at 85 with no significant health complications. His elder brother aged 64  has been diagnosed with coronary artery disease.   Social History:  Mr. Thompson is living with his wife and retired from working in construction 6 years ago. He is a former smoker with a smoking history of 30 pack-years but has been abstinent for the past 6 years following his COPD diagnosis. His alcohol consumption is occasional. Mr. Thompson has no known drug allergies.  Investigation:  Preliminary examination reveals a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  oxygen saturation of 93% on room air  and blood pressure of 140/90mmHg. Physical examination uncovers that he appears to be in distress with clear signs of respiratory struggle. Chest examination shows reduced breath sounds on the left side compared to the right. Electrocardiogram (ECG) demonstrates signs of right heart strain  most probably due to pulmonary embolism.   Working Diagnosis:  Considering Mr. Thompson’s sudden onset of symptoms  ECG findings and his history of COPD and hypertension  the most probable diagnosis is that of an acute pulmonary embolism. Next  a confirmatory diagnosis should be made by conducting a CT pulmonary angiogram and D-dimer tests.   Treatment Plan:  If the tests confirm the diagnosis  Mr. Thompson should be commenced on anticoagulant therapy immediately with a direct oral anticoagulant to manage his acute condition. As he is a high-risk patient  he may require admission to the ICU for close monitoring. Also  he should be strongly advised to attend follow-up appointments and monitor any worsening symptoms.   Prepared by: [Your Name] [Your Position]

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Watkins  a 59-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department with acute-onset dyspnea at rest and sharp  stabbing chest pain  which increased upon deep inspiration. The pain started suddenly 4 hours prior to his presentation. He also reported occasional bouts of dry cough  no hemoptysis. These symptoms were preceded by a 3-days history of left lower calf pain and tenderness.    Past Medical History:  Mr. Watkins has a known history of hypertension  for which he is on medication (Carvedilol 12.5mg BD and Amlodipine 5mg OD). He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (Metformin 500mg BD) and was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 8 years ago. Mr. Watkins is a current smoker  with a 20-pack per year history  and engages only in mild physical activities due to sedentary work nature.  Family History:  Both of his parents had hypertension  his father died of a stroke at the age of 74  and his mother is alive at 82 with managed hypertension and COPD. His older sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at 66.  Social History:  Mr. Watkins is a recently retired computer engineer  currently living with his wife. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug usage.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  Mr. Watkins appeared visibly anxious  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/minute  blood pressure 155/90mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  and oxygen saturation 92% on atmospheric air. Chest auscultation revealed reduced breath sounds with occasional inspiratory crackles at the right base. His cardiovascular examination was essentially normal. Lower limb examination noted swelling of the left leg with a positive Homan's sign.   Lab Investigations and Imaging:  His D-dimer level was 5 times the normal limit. An urgent computed tomographic pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) indicated the presence of a clot in the right lower lobe pulmonary artery  confirming acute pulmonary embolism (PE). The ultrasound of his left leg detected a thrombus in the popliteal vein indicating DVT.  Treatment:  Given his medical history and severity of PE  Mr. Watkins was indicated for immediate therapeutic anticoagulation. He was started on an intravenous line with unfractionated Heparin and hospital admission was recommended for further observation and management.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of considering acute PE in patients with sudden  unexplained dyspnea and chest pain  especially among those with risk factors like personal or family history of DVT or PE  hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and sedentary lifestyle. It also highlights the imperative need for immediate initiation of anticoagulation therapy in confirmed cases.

Patient Presentation:  Patient: Mr. Smith  65-year-old Caucasian male   Presenting Condition: Diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism (PE).   Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith suffered from hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and was a former smoker with 20-pack years. In 2010  he had a myocardial infarction  followed by a coronary angioplasty. A detached slipped disc was surgically treated in 2015. Last March  he was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes. Aside from his medications (ACE inhibitor for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes  Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia)  Mr. Smith is not on any other supplements.   Presenting Issue:   He was admitted to the hospital following an episode of acute breathlessness and sharp  one-sided chest pain. Upon physical examination  the patient presented signs of distress with a high respiratory rate. He also reported significant fatigue over the last two weeks  with slight swelling in his right calf.   Family History:    His mother died of stroke at age 70 and his father of a heart attack at age 73. He has a younger brother diagnosed with heart disease and an older sister with Type 2 diabetes.  Investigations and Diagnosis:   His EKG showed a sinus tachycardia  while venous Doppler ultrasound showed deep vein thrombosis in his right calf. A CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of a large acute PE in his right lung. His D-dimer levels were significantly elevated.  Treatment:   Given his hemodynamic instability  Mr. Smith was initiated on thrombolytic therapy with tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)  followed by systemic anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). After stabilization  he was transitioned to long-term oral anticoagulant therapy with Warfarin.  Education and Future Prevention Strategies:  Upon discharge  Mr. Smith was counseled on the need for medication adherence  importance of regular follow-ups  and lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation  regular exercise  and a healthy balanced diet to manage his comorbidities and lower the risk of recurrence.  Conclusion:   This case illustrates the complexities in managing acute PE in a patient with multiple comorbidities. Early recognition  prompt diagnosis and treatment  and comprehensive patient education are crucial in managing such cases.

Patient Overview:  Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented with chief complaints of sudden shortness of breath and sharp chest pain  particularly upon deep inhalation. The patient reports that the symptoms began abruptly a few hours prior to his hospital visit.   History:  Mr. Doe has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus and hypertension  both managed with metformin and lisinopril  respectively. He has no documented allergies. His station involved a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activity. Mr. Doe had a recent history of lower extremity deep venous thrombosis (DVT)  four weeks ago after a long overseas flight; it was treated with rivaroxaban. He does not smoke cigarettes or consume alcohol.   Family History:  The patient's family history is notable for myocardial infarction with his father passing away at 72 years of age. His mother had type II diabetes and died of stroke at the age of 78. The patient has one sibling who is alive and healthy.  Physical Examination:  The patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic. He was tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute and tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation was low at 92% on room air. Blood pressure was 138/86 mmHg.   Investigations:  Electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia with S1Q3T3 pattern. His D-dimer was significantly elevated. Complete blood count and metabolic panel were within normal limits except for an elevated serum glucose level. Chest x-ray showed no infiltrates or pneumothorax. Computed tomographic angiography (CTA) of the chest revealed acute embolus in the right and left pulmonary arteries  indicating the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE).   Management and Conclusion:  The severity of the PE was considered massive due to hemodynamic instability. Therefore  Mr. Doe was admitted to the intensive care unit and was initiated on thrombolytic therapy with alteplase  followed by systemic anticoagulation. His symptoms gradually improved  and he was later switched to warfarin.  In conclusion  Mr. Doe’s previous episode of deep venous thrombosis (DVT)  sedentary lifestyle  and his recent long flight probably predisposed him to this acute episode of pulmonary embolism. Assertive management and follow-up will be necessary to prevent future thromboembolic events. He should also be educated about the importance of mobility  especially during long-haul flights  and the need for adherence to prescribed anticoagulant therapy.

Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 50 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Accountant  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of pleuritic chest pain and shortness of breath.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a past medical history of hypertension for which he takes amlodipine 5mg daily. Mr. Doe is a previous smoker with a 20 pack year record. He stopped smoking five years ago. He has no known allergies.  Present Illness History: The patient mentioned that the symptoms began earlier in the day while he was walking upstairs at work. Besides chest pain and difficulty breathing  he also experienced a bout of dry coughing. There is no history of fever  hemoptysis  or recent trauma. No associated cardiac symptoms such as palpitations or syncope.  Family History: Mr. Doe's father died of a myocardial infarction at 60 years old. His mother passed away at 75 years old due to complications of Alzheimer's disease. His younger brother was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a long flight two years ago.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  Mr. Doe appeared anxious with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  heart rate of 96 beats per minute  blood pressure of 120/80 mmHg  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Chest auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds in the right lower field. The remainder of the physical exam was within normal limits.  Investigations and Treatment: A D-dimer test was immediately done and it came back elevated. Following the result  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) showed a clot in the pulmonary arteries confirming the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism. The patient was started on anticoagulation therapy with subcutaneous enoxaparin and oral apixaban was initiated  in addition to his existing antihypertensive medication.  Disposition: Mr. Doe was admitted to the hospital for further monitoring  to avoid complications such as pulmonary infarction  right ventricular dysfunction or chronic thromboembolic pulmonary disease.  Education and Counseling: The patient was educated about the potential causes of his condition including prolonged immobility  recent surgery  and a familial predisposition to thrombosis. He was also counseled on the importance of adhering to his anticoagulation therapy and regular follow-ups. Lifestyle modifications including maintaining a balanced diet  regular exercise  and monitoring blood pressure were also discussed.   Follow-up plan: Regular outpatient follow-ups were scheduled for tracking the effectiveness of his anticoagulant therapy  any potential complication of PE and adjusting medications as required. A referral to a respiratory specialist for comprehensive care was suggested.

Patient Presentation  Name: Mrs. Josephine Adams  Age: 64 years  Gender: Female  Demographics: African-American  retired high school teacher  widow  living alone in Houston  Texas.   Chief Complaint: Mrs. Adams came to the hospital complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and fainting spells that she has been experiencing over the past 24 hours.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Adams is hypertensive  normocholesterolemic and has type 2 diabetes  all controlled with medication. Her condition has been stable for the past 10 years. She quit smoking 7 years ago  after a 30-year history of smoking one packet of cigarettes per day. She also has a history of intermittent leg swelling. There have been no prior hospitalizations except for a cholecystectomy 15 years prior.   Family History: Mrs. Adams's father died at the age of 70 of myocardial infarction and her mother is alive and well at 85. She has a younger sister who was recently diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis.  Examination and Investigation: On examination  Mrs. Adams was found to be anxious  tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm  short of breath at rest with a respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute  had low oxygen saturation levels (SpO2 – 87% on room air) and blood pressure was mildly elevated at 150/90 mm Hg.  A D-Dimer assay was positive  which is a general marker of blood clot formation and the breakdown. CT pulmonary angiography confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Assessment: Considering the patient's history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  prior smoking  family history of deep vein thrombosis and her recent signs and symptoms  she carries high risk for blood clots.  Treatment plan: She has been admitted to the hospital for close monitoring  started on systemic thrombolytic therapy with streptokinase  supplemental oxygen therapy and anticoagulation with heparin  bridging to a long-term plan of oral anticoagulation with warfarin  continued diabetic and hypertensive management  counseling about lifestyle modifications including diet  exercise and the importance of medication compliance.  Prognosis: Given her age and general health status  Mrs. Adams' prognosis is optimistic if she follows the prescribed treatment regimen and lifestyle changes  though she does have an elevated risk of recurrence. Regular follow-up reviews are crucial in this case.   Acknowledgement and consent: Mrs. Adams was made aware of her diagnosis  treatment plan and understood the same. She gave her consent for the treatment plan as proposed.   This is a brief presentation of the case of Mrs. Adams  a patient diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism. Future updates on her recovery will be made in succeeding case presentations.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. T  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  was brought into the ER in acute distress.  Demographics: Mr. T is a married construction site engineer with two grown-up children. He lives in an urban setup and is a non-smoker. He has a normal BMI and does not consume alcohol.  Past Medical History: Mr. T has been previously diagnosed with hypertension  dyslipidemia  and has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 3 years ago. He has been taking medicine for hypertension and has been on anticoagulant therapy for DVT. He recently discontinued anticoagulants after what he thought was sufficient treatment.  Presenting Complaints: He arrived at the hospital presenting with sudden onset of severe shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness. His symptoms began acutely while at work  starting with a sharp  stabbing chest pain that was worse upon deep inspiration.   Family History: Mr. T's father had a history of coronary artery disease and died from myocardial infarction in his early sixties. His mother is alive and well. He has one older sister who was diagnosed with breast cancer in her fifties.  Physical Examination: Initial vitals showed that he was tachycardic with a heart rate of 114 bpm  tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 24 per minute  blood pressure was 155/95 mm Hg  temperature was 98.6°F and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. His physical examination revealed a slightly distressed patient with increased respiratory work; however  examination of the heart and lungs was unremarkable.   Investigations: Given his strong history of DVT and current signs consistent with a pulmonary embolism  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was immediately ordered  which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.   Management: Mr. T was stabilized with supplemental oxygen therapy. Therapeutic anticoagulation was initiated immediately with intravenous administration of low molecular weight heparin.   Summary: This is a case of a 55-year-old male with a history of DVT and cardiovascular risk factors presenting with an acute pulmonary embolism. Key points to note include his recent discontinuation of anticoagulants and the importance of ongoing management of high-risk patients. This case emphasizes the potentially severe consequences of DVT and the importance of appropriately managing and educating these patients about the risks of discontinuing medication.

Patient Profile: Mr. James E. Thomson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired corporate lawyer  presented with symptoms of acute chest pain and shortness of breath. Mr. Thomson lives in Los Angeles  California with his wife of 40 years. He describes himself as a light social drinker and a non-smoker. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 27  indicating that he is slightly overweight.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thomson has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago  which was treated with anticoagulant therapy. He also has hypertension controlled with medications and a history of a minor myocardial infarction 7 years ago. No known drug allergies are reported.  Demographics: Mr. Thomson is physically active  engaging in golf and regular walking. He follows a moderately healthy diet with occasional indulgence in high cholesterol foods. His alcohol intake is moderate  and his caffeine intake is high due to his habit of drinking 2-3 cups of coffee a day.  Family History: His family history is significant with his father dying of a massive heart attack at age 62  and his mother  currently 92 years of age  has persistent atrial fibrillation. His older brother  age 72  is in good health with no significant medical conditions.  Recent Events: Mr. Thomson recently returned from a trip from Australia  a flight lasting approximately 15 hours. His symptoms began during the flight but were mild and he dismissed them as fatigue.   Presentation: On presentation  Mr. Thomson described a sharp and stabbing retrosternal chest discomfort radiating to the back  accompanied by dyspnea. Increased work of breathing with decreased breath sounds over the right lung was observed. Pulse oximetry showed an oxygen saturation of 90% on room air.  Investigations & Diagnosis: A D-dimer test was ordered due to his history of DVT and was found to be elevated  necessitating further workup. His EKG showed tachycardia but no signs of an acute heart attack. Subsequent CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) confirmed the presence of an acute pulmonary embolism in the right lung.  Management: The patient was stabilized with supplemental oxygen and started on anticoagulant therapy with heparin and warfarin for long-term management of the condition.   Possible risk factors in this case include his advanced age  prolonged immobilization during the long-haul flight  being slightly overweight  personal history of DVT  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. It will be necessary to keep these in mind when managing this patient's condition and planning for future prevention of recurrent events.   Plans include ongoing anticoagulant therapy  risk factor modification such as assistance with weight loss  further investigation for possible malignancy as this can also contribute to a hypercoagulable state  and possible placement of an inferior vena cava filter to prevent future embolisms.  The patient and his family were educated about the disease  its complications  and the importance of adherence to medication  lifestyle modification  and regular follow-ups.

Patient Information: Mr. S  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired firefighter from Michigan  presented in the emergency department of our hospital.  Chief Complaint: Mr. S reported experiencing sudden-onset severe chest pain and shortness of breath after performing some heavy lifting tasks at home.  Past Medical and Surgical History:  The patient has a history of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and hypertension. Also  he had leg thrombosis two years ago  leading to a diagnosis of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT). He is currently on medication for the same. His surgical history is unremarkable.  Family History: His father passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 75  and his mother has diabetes and is currently living. There is no history of clotting disorders or malignancy in his family.  Social History:  He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol socially. He lives alone but has a good support system of friends and nearby relatives.  Physical Examination and Diagnostics: Upon admission  his vitals were as follows: BP- 153/92 mm Hg  HR- 105 bpm  Respiration rate- 24 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation- 92% on room air. His physical examination revealed decreased breath sounds  tachycardia  and a swollen lower right leg.  A CT angiography subsequently revealed a clot in the right pulmonary artery  indicating a pulmonary embolism.  Current Treatment and Medications:  Mr. S has been on warfarin and furosemide for his previous DVT. The medication has now been escalated to include Heparin  to rapidly thin his blood.  Impression: Given the sudden onset of symptoms  the patient’s medical history  physical examination  and imaging studies  Mr. S has been diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism  likely a complication of his previous DVT.  Discussion: The major risk factors for Mr. S are the history of DVT  his age  and his COPD. It is now crucial to keep him under close monitoring and adjust the anticoagulant treatment as necessary. It is also advisable to assess if there are any other possible risk factors for deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. A multi-disciplinary approach will be necessary for managing this patient's illness.  Plan: The immediate plan is to continue anticoagulant therapy while monitoring the patient closely in the ICU. Given the emerging evidence around the sequelae of acute pulmonary embolism  Mr. S is a candidate for early mobilization  physiotherapy  and rehabilitation. Further  he should be educated about the signs of worsening symptoms and when to seek medical help. His treatment will involve regular follow-up visits and monitoring of his medication regimen.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old African-American male  married  retired veteran  nonsmoker  and teetotaler resident of New York City.  Presenting Complaint: The patient stepped into the Emergency Department complaint about sudden chest pain and shortness of breath that started 4 hours prior to his visit. Associated symptoms included cough  dizziness  and a general feeling of unwellness.  Medical History: The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM)  which is well-controlled via oral hypoglycemics  hypertension treated with ACE inhibitors  and occasional episodes of deep vein thrombosis treated with anticoagulants. He also reports occasional bouts of anxiety  but he has not sought any psychiatric treatment for this. No known allergies.  Surgical History: Underwent a cholecystectomy twenty years ago due to gall bladder stone and an appendectomy at the age of 12.  Family History: His father died of a stroke at the age of 74  and his mother is alive at 90 years old dealing with Alzheimer's disease. His eldest sister died at 62 due to breast cancer.  Social History: The patient lives with his wife and has 2 adult children. He is a retired army officer with no travel history in recent times due to the covid-19 pandemic. Reports having a nutritious diet and walking for extensive periods are a daily routine for him.
