Examination Findings: On examination  the patient had a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure was 150/90 mm Hg  respiratory rate of 24 per minute  and oxygen saturation was 90% on room air. The chest examination revealed tachypnea and decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung field. No pitting edema or tenderness was noted in the legs. Rest of physical examination was normal.  Outcome (Diagnosis and Treatment Plan): The CT pulmonary angiography demonstrated multiple filling defects in the pulmonary arteries of both lungs suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism. ECG showed signs of right heart strain. The patient was admitted to the ICU and administered heparin infusion initially for immediate anticoagulation. For long-term anticoagulation  considering his past history of DVT  warfarin was selected.   The patient’s family was explained about the disease condition and the need for long-term anticoagulation  regular PT/INR monitoring  the possibility of bleeding risk  and diet modification due to warfarin therapy. The multidisciplinary team would manage associated hypertension and diabetes. His progress will be closely monitored.  This case underscores the importance of considering pulmonary embolism diagnosis in individuals presenting with unexplained shortness of breath  particularly in individuals with known coagulation abnormalities  or who are at increased risk of clotting such as with a history of DVT  hypertension  and diabetes  as seen in this patient's case.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  presented with sudden-onset dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain and small hemoptysis.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and alcoholism. The patient is a former smoker with a 20-year history  but he claims to have quit 10 years ago. He had a myocardial infarction 8 years ago followed with stent placement. His medications include aspirin  lisinopril  metoprolol  and pravastatin. He reports compliance with these medications.  Demographics:  Mr. Doe is a retired military officer  who is currently working part-time consulting for a security firm. He is married and lives with his wife in the suburbs. He has two adult children living out of state. He is a moderate alcohol consumer  but denies illicit drug use.  Family History:  Mr. Doe's father passed away from a heart attack at age 75 and his mother passed away from a stroke at age 70. His sister  aged 65  is living with type 2 diabetes and his brother  63  was recently diagnosed with lung cancer.  Clinical Story:  Mr. Doe felt well until two days ago when he suffered from sudden onset of chest pain and shortage of breath during his morning walk. The chest pain was described as sharp  worsened on deep inspiration and did not radiate. He also complained of cough with a small amount of blood tinged sputum. Mr. Doe initially neglected the signs assuming it as recurrence of his gastric reflux  but when he started experiencing mild dizziness and persistent dyspnea  he consulted the hospital. His vital signs at presentation were within the normal range except mild tachypnea and elevated blood pressure.  Diagnostic tests clicked towards acute pulmonary embolism. He received a D-dimer test which came back elevated. Follow up CT pulmonary angiogram was performed revealing multiple pulmonary emboli in both lung fields. Echocardiogram was also ordered showing a normal left ventricular function with no signs of right ventricular strain.  Key Points:  The patient's sudden onset of chest pain  complaints of breathlessness  hemoptysis led to a suspicion of pulmonary embolism. The patient is at an increased risk due his past medical history of myocardial infarction  hypertension and his family history. The diagnosis was further substantiated with elevated D-dimer test and confirmed by Pulmonary CT angiogram.  Initial Management:  Mr. Doe was initially given oxygen to maintain SpO2 above 94%. Simultaneously  he was started on a Heparin drip for immediate anticoagulation while being evaluated for potential thrombectomy based on the large clot burden. The patient will need to be transitioned to long-term anticoagulation pending resolution and stability of the acute embolic event. Further  the patient will also require follow-up outpatient care with cardiology and pulmonology specialists.

Patient Overview:   A 50-year-old African American male presents to the Emergency Department (ED) with severe shortness of breath that has gradually worsened over the past three days. He is a non-smoker with a history of obesity (BMI 31)  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  which are all managed with medication (ACE inhibitors and Metformin  respectively). The patient also reported intermittent chest pain and lightheadedness.   Medical History:  The patient has been hospitalized twice over the past 5 years for similar symptoms  with the most recent being 2 years back. Previous evaluations for ischemic heart disease had been negative. His father died of a stroke in his 70s  and his mother has type 2 diabetes and high blood pressure.   Clinical Assessment & Investigations:  The patient is anxious  diaphoretic  and his oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Physical examination reveals tachycardia (heart rate - 110 bpm)  tachypnea (respiration rate - 24 breaths per minute)  and blood pressure of 160/100 mm Hg. Upon auscultation  breath sounds are diminished in the lower lung fields.   A 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) shows S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of right heart strain and sinus tachycardia. There are no signs of previous myocardial infarction. His D-dimer level is significantly elevated. A CT pulmonary angiography was ordered  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism with a saddle embolus in the bifurcation of the major pulmonary arteries.  Management:   Started on a therapeutic dose of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Cardiothoracic surgery is consulted for possibly emergent thrombectomy due to hemodynamic instability. The patient is also started on supplemental oxygen to maintain O2 saturation above 92%.   Follow-up:  He is to be transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) for further management and close probation. A discussion on anticoagulation and the prevention of future thromboembolic events will be held once the patient is stable. The importance of optimal control of his other comorbid conditions (hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and obesity) will be reiterated during follow-up after his recovery from the acute event.   This case presents a classic example of acute pulmonary embolism  highlighting the importance of urgent investigation and treatment in such cases to prevent fatal outcomes.

Patient Profile: The patient  Mr. Jones  is a 63-year-old Caucasian male with a body mass index (BMI) of 29  indicating overweight. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year history  who quit ten years ago. Mr. Jones is married  has two grown children  and is a retired engineer. He lives in a suburban area with his wife and dog. He occasionally consumes alcohol  mostly on special occasions.   Past Medical history: Mr. Jones has a history of hypertension  diagnosed ten years ago  and has been managing it with medication (Lisinopril 10 mg daily). He was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus five years ago  which he has poorly controlled with Metformin and lifestyle changes. He had an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago after a prolonged trip.  Presenting Complaint: He presented to the emergency department with sudden onset intense chest pain  feeling of breathlessness  and palpitations that started a few hours ago while he was doing yard work.  Family History: There is a strong family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a myocardial infarction at 58  and his brother experienced a stroke at 60. His mother has a history of Type 2 diabetes  and his sister was diagnosed with breast cancer at age 55.  Clinical Findings: On examination  Mr. Jones had a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute (BPM) and an O2 saturation of 90% on room air. His blood pressure was 140/90 mm Hg  heart rate was 110 BPM  and he had a fever of 101 degrees Fahrenheit. The patient appeared anxious. His chest examination revealed reduced breath sounds on the right lower side. His ECG showed sinus tachycardia and the D-dimer test was positive.   Working Diagnosis & Management: A diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made  most likely due to his sedentary lifestyle  personal history of DVT  pro-thrombotic state due to uncontrolled diabetes  and family history. He was immediately started on oxygen and low molecular weight heparin. The patient was further referred for a CT pulmonary angiogram  which confirmed the presence of a large embolus in the right lower pulmonary artery.  The patient was then hospitalized and anticoagulation therapy was initiated for long-term management. It was also recommended that Mr. Jones take steps to better control his diabetes and lose weight. Educational material on how to recognize the signs of PE was provided to the patient and his family.   Follow-up: A follow-up appointment was scheduled in a week to monitor his response to the medication  and a referral to a dietician was made to address his weight and diabetes management. His family members were also advised to get screened for thrombotic risks due to their family history.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. Thompson  is a 62-year-old African-American male who presented to the emergency department experiencing shortness of breath  chest pain  and slight coughing. His vital signs were measured revealing blood pressure 145/85mmHg  heart rate 95 bpm  respirations 22/min  O2 saturation 92% under room air  and temperature 98.6°F.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson is seen in clinic regularly for controlled hypertension. He's also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and has been managed on Metformin. His other medical history includes high cholesterol and obesity. He does not smoke but admits to drinking alcohol rarely. He follows a regular diet and a moderate-level activity lifestyle.  Present Illness:  The symptoms started suddenly three hours ago when Mr. Thompson experienced an unwarranted pain in the chest. The pain has since then intensified and is now coupled with shortness of breath and light-headedness. He does not exhibit any signs of upper respiratory tract infection  no hemoptysis.  Family History:  His mother passed away in her 70s from heart disease  and his father died in his early 80s due to lung cancer. He has one brother who has so far been healthy and free from any chronic diseases.  Investigation and Diagnosis:  Initial examination revealed decreased breath sounds in the lower half of the right lung  indicative of potential pulmonary embolism. An urgent D-dimer was ordered which returned high  suggesting increased clotting activity. A CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the presence of a clot in the right lower-lobe branch of the pulmonary artery consistent with an acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment:  Mr. Thompson was immediately started on thrombolytic therapy (Apixaban). Owing to his medical history of hypertension  diabetes  and high cholesterol  he was also recommended lifestyle modifications and stricter control of his concurrent conditions.  Follow-up:  He is currently stable and recovering in critical care. His chest pain has reduced significantly and breathlessness is also improving. He will receive follow-up care from a pulmonary specialist to monitor his condition and reaction to medication prescribed. A dietician and physiotherapist have also been consulted for lifestyle management advice. Sensitivity to shortness of breath  chest pain  or fainting in the future was briefed to Mr. Thompson to ensure immediate medical attention if required. He will be discharged once his vitals are stable  and is advised for regular follow-up checks with his primary care provider.

Patient Presentation  Patient X is a 51-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the ER complaining of sudden shortness of breath and a sharp chest pain that got worse when he took a deep breath. The patient also reported occasional dizzy spells and palpitations over the past couple of days. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  for which he takes amlodipine. He recently underwent a total hip arthroplasty due to osteoarthritis three weeks ago  and has been immobilized and off work since then.   He smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day for the past 30 years  and his alcohol consumption is occasional and moderate. Family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases; his father had a myocardial infarction at 58  and his older brother was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis at the age of 50. He has a sedentary lifestyle and works as an accountant. He does not engage in any regular exercise.   In the ER  his vitals showed a BP of 140/90 mm Hg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  temperature was 37 C  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. His physical examination revealed tachypnea  tachycardia  and decreased breath sounds on the lower right side of the lung.  Blood tests revealed raised D-dimer levels. An ECG showed signs of sinus tachycardia. A CT pulmonary angiography confirmed the presence of a clot in the right pulmonary artery  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Patient X was immediately initiated on anticoagulation therapy and admitted to the hospital for further management and monitoring. His smoking habit  recent surgery  immobilization  family history  and sedentary lifestyle significantly contributed to his risk of developing pulmonary embolism  underlining the importance of personalizing treatment and preventive strategies based on individual risk profiles.   Next step for the patient would be an assessment of his response to anticoagulation therapy  management of his hypertension and recommendation of lifestyle modifications like smoking cessation  increased physical activity  and regular follow-ups. Long-term management may also include the need for thrombolytic therapy.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 64-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department on March 25  2023  complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and sharp  continuous pain in his chest area which intensified with deep breathing.  Demographics:  Mr. Doe works as a truck driver  which requires long hours of travel and stationary periods. He resides in Richmond  Virginia. He is a non-smoker but admits to a frequent alcohol intake. He lives with his wife  and they have two adult children.  Past Medical History:  He was diagnosed with hypertension two years ago  for which he was prescribed Lisinopril. His compliance to medication as per report has been intermittent. He also has a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus since he was 45  for which he is on Metformin. He reports no recent surgeries  hospitalizations  or allergies.  Family History:  His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 71 and his mother at 72 due to a stroke. His elder sister is alive with no significant medical history. His younger brother died in a car accident.  Recent History:  Mr. Doe recently came back from a cross-country truck trip of 8 days. He noticed swelling and tenderness increasingly escalating in his right lower extremity three days ago. However  he attributed it to his prolonged periods of immobility during his driving hours without any suspicion of deep vein thrombosis.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  his BMI was 30  indicating obesity. His blood pressure was elevated at 160/95 mmHg and he was tachycardic with a pulse rate of 110 beats/min. On auscultation  he had decreased breath sounds on the right lower side of the chest. The right calf was significantly swollen as compared to the left.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  An EKG showed sinus tachycardia. Lab results revealed elevated Troponin levels and a subsequent D-dimer test came back as positive. Considering the clinical symptoms  a CT Pulmonary angiogram was done which revealed a filling defect in the right lower lobar artery  confirming the diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism (APE).  Course of Action:  He was started on intravenous Heparin immediately and was closely monitored. His oxygen levels  blood pressure  and heart rate were regularly monitored in the intensive care unit. He is planned for a lower limb Doppler to determine the presence of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT).  Patient education is essential to emphasize the importance of medication compliance  risk of long hours of immobility  lifestyle modifications including weight reduction  regulation of blood pressure  glycemic control  and cessation of alcohol. The family will be educated about the genetic predisposition to cardiovascular diseases.

Subject: Case Presentation - Acute Pulley Embolism in a 65-year-old Male Patient  Patient Initials: TG Date of Birth: 03/13/1956 Age: 65 Gender: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Issue:  TG presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with complaints of sudden-onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness since yesterday. Upon examination  he appeared cyanotic with increased respiratory rate.  Past Medical History: TG has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is an active smoker with a 25-pack-year smoking history. The patient had undergone a right hip replacement 2 years ago and a recent knee surgery 3 weeks ago.   Family History:  His father died at the age of 72 due to a myocardial infarction and his mother had a history of hypertension and died at the age of 78 due to stroke. His brother  aged 70  is living with diabetes and hypertension.  Investigation: The patient's D-dimer levels were significantly elevated. An urgent CTPA (CT pulmonary angiography) showed a filling defect in the right lower lobe pulmonary artery  leading to the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE). EKG showed sinus tachycardia.  Given his recent surgery  TG was considered to be in the high-risk category because of his immobilization. Upon risk stratification with the PESI score  he was categorized into the class IV risk group  indicating a high mortality risk.   Plan: The patient was immediately started on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin. Consideration for thrombolysis/thrombectomy was discussed with his family due to him falling into the high-risk category. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for close monitoring.   The patient and family have been counselled about the possible causes and consequences of pulmonary embolism. A smoking cessation program has been advised to the patient.   Follow-up appointments with a pulmonologist and cardiologist for further management and primary physician for smoking cessation counselling have been scheduled.  Conclusion: Monitoring the patient's clinical responses along with follow-up imaging studies are essential steps in managing this patient optimally. Leveraging support for smoking cessation and strict control of risk factors will be crucial to diminish the risk of further complications.

Patient Information:  Patient Mr. John Doe is a 57-year-old Caucasian male  married  an active smoker with a 30 pack-year history. He is a secondary school teacher by profession.  Presenting Symptoms: John presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  especially upon coughing and breathing deeply  and fainting spell.  Medical History: Upon examination  significant history in John includes Grade 2 Hypertension for the past ten years  moderate obesity (BMI 31.5)  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus managed on medication for the past five years. Steroid medication for rheumatoid arthritis was added to the regimen 3 months prior.  Surgical History: He also has a surgical history of a bilateral knee replacement procedure three weeks prior.  Family History: John's father died of myocardial infarction at age 60  and his mother is living with COPD. His only sibling  a brother  is asymptomatic but has recently been diagnosed with thrombophilia.  Diagnosis: Based on John's symptoms  namely the shortness of breath  chest pain  and fainting  he was suspected to have an acute pulmonary embolism (PE). A computed tomographic pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was conducted  which confirmed the diagnosis by revealing a large clot in the right pulmonary artery.  Treatment Plan: John has been acutely managed with intravenous Heparin for anticoagulation. Considering the high risk for future clotting given John's history of pre-existing conditions  prolonged anticoagulation moving to Warfarin as an oral medication and addressing weight loss and smoking cessation were advised.  Clinical Course & Outcomes: The patient showed progressive improvements over the next few days  following which he was safely discharged with a follow-up appointment in the outpatient clinic in one week.  Discussion: In this case  Mr. Doe presented with classic symptoms of pulmonary embolism  which likely arose due to his recent surgical procedure  immobility  smoking habits  and chronic medical conditions which increase his risk for clotting. His family’s medical history also reveals a genetic disposition to clotting disorders. Identification of these risks and directed interventions to control modifiable factors signify a crucial aspect in managing such patients.   This case serves as a reminder of the importance of vigilant surveillance for potential PE  especially among patients who have undergone recent surgery or who are immobilized and are smokers or are overweight  and the role of anticoagulant therapy in the management of PE. It emphasizes the importance of lifestyle factors in the development and progression of such significant health problems.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Profile: A 66-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Henry Johnson. He is a retired high school teacher  is a non-smoker  and maintains a moderately active lifestyle. He lives with his wife in a suburban area.  Chief Complaint: Presented to the Emergency Department experiencing sudden onset of dyspnea  chest pain  and light-headedness.  Past Medical History: He has been managing controlled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past ten years with prescribed medications (Lisinopril and Metformin respectively). His sleep apnea is managed using continual positive airway pressure (CPAP) therapy. He had an appendectomy at age 20 and a history of DVT (deep vein thrombosis) five years ago. Vaccines are all up-to-date.   Family History: His father passed away at the age of 70 due to a myocardial infarction and mother passed away at the age of 78 due to COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease).  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  the patient showed tachypnea (Respiratory rate: 22/min) and tachycardia (Heart rate: 110 bpm). Oxygen saturation was lower than normal (SpO2: 88% on room air). His blood pressure was a bit elevated (Blood Pressure: 150/90 mmHg). During a chest examination  no crackles or wheezing was observed.  Investigations: Blood gas analysis showed hypoxemia and mild respiratory alkalosis. D-dimer levels were raised. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed a sinus tachycardia and a right bundle branch block. A CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed an acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment: The patient was immediately put on therapeutic anticoagulation with parenteral heparin and bridged to oral anticoagulation with Warfarin.   Current Status: The patient's dyspnea and chest pain have resolved  and he has been counseled about his condition. He has been recommended to regular follow-ups and is planned to be on long-term anticoagulation therapy considering his history of DVT and now Pulmonary Embolism.   Education on lifestyle modification  importance of medication adherence  and close outpatient follow-up to monitor his INR with his primary care physician have been scheduled. His family has been informed and educated about signs of complications or recurrence like sudden onset of breathlessness or chest pain.   This case underscores the importance of considering acute pulmonary embolism in older patients presenting with unexplained dyspnea  tachycardia  chest discomfort  especially in those with a history of a thromboembolic event.

Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith  a 61-year-old Caucasian male  was referred to the emergency department with an acute onset of shortness of breath and palpitations. He also complained of moderate chest discomfort. He's a retired soldier  lives with his wife and two grown-up children  and smokes a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He has no known allergies.  Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis five years ago  controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  and mild hypertension. He had been taking Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension. However  he admitted non-compliance with his medications recently due to the stress of losing his job.  Family History:  His family history reveals that his mother died of stroke at 76 and his father died of myocardial infarction at 78. His older brother is currently being managed for chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder while his younger sister is in early-stage breast cancer treatment. No family history of genetic diseases.  Presenting Complaints:  Upon examination  he presented with tachycardia  tachypnea  mild cyanosis  and decreased breath sounds on the right side. A D-dimer test was ordered which came back positive. A CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed an acute pulmonary embolism in the right lower lung lobe.  Management:  Heparin drip was promptly started  in accordance with standard treatment guidelines. Warfarin therapy will be initiated after 2 days  intending for an INR of 2-3. Recommendations for regular follow-up appointments and a Pulmonologist referral has been set up.   Plan for Patient Education:  Education regarding the importance of medication compliance  smoking cessation  diet and exercise has been discussed with the patient. The family was educated about the symptoms of pulmonary embolism and were guided to seek medical help immediately if symptoms recur.   The patient will need continued monitoring and assessment. The key goal is to improve Mr. Smith's quality of life  decrease his risk of recurrent pulmonary embolism  and manage his risk factors effectively.  Follow Up:  Mr. Smith requires regular follow-up to monitor his INR levels  check medication side effects  and assess his symptoms. He would benefit from continued support for smoking cessation  as well as counselling to help manage his life stressors. Future management of his diabetes and hypertension is also an important aspect of his overall care. He is scheduled to return to the clinic in two weeks.

Patient Information:  Mr. Smith  a 58-year-old African-American male  has been diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker (20 pack-years) and lives a sedentary lifestyle. He was recently hospitalized for total knee replacement surgery. He had a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a previous surgery approximately 5 years ago. Furthermore  Mr. Smith’s medication history includes a combination of antihypertensive drugs  statins for hyperlipidemia  and prophylactic low-dose aspirin.  Family History:   Mr. Smith’s father suffered from coronary artery disease and his mother had a stroke. There is no known hereditary thrombophilia.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Smith presented at the emergency room with shortness of breath  resting tachycardia  chest pain  and fatigue.  Investigations:  Emergency room physicians arranged an urgent CT pulmonary angiography upon suspicion of pulmonary embolism  which showed multiple emboli within the bilateral pulmonary arteries. A Venous Doppler ultrasound of both lower extremities demonstrated evidence of DVT in the left lower extremity  above the prior surgical site.   Bloodwork:  The coagulation profile demonstrated a high D-dimer level  and lipid profile showed elevated cholesterol and LDL ('bad cholesterol'). Increased B-type natriuretic peptide levels were indicative of elevated cardiac stress. Troponin levels were within normal range.  Treatment:  Physicians have initiated anticoagulation therapy with intravenous heparin. Following stabilization of vital signs  he is planned for a shift to oral anticoagulants (NOACs or VKAs). Specialists have recommended lifelong anticoagulation therapy given his past and recent history of VTE post-surgery  and discussed the risk-benefit ratio with the patient.   Discussion:  The patient's postoperative status  history of DVT  obesity  and sedentary lifestyle serve as significant risk factors for the development of his acute pulmonary embolism. It is crucial to control other modifiable risk factors such as hyperlipidemia and high blood pressure to reduce the overall cardiovascular risk. The case serves as a reminder of the importance of maintaining prophylactic measures in postoperative patients with a history of thrombotic events.

Patient Presentation:  Name: John Doe Age: 56 years old Sex: Male Ethnicity: White  Non-Hispanic Occupation: Certified Public Accountant Residence: Urban living  three-story townhouse  Medical History:   The patient was diagnosed with primary hypertension eight years ago  which is well controlled on amlodipine (10 mg once daily). He also has a history of type 2 diabetes managed by metformin and lifestyle modification. He suffered from a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago following a long-haul plane flight  for which he received treatment with oral anticoagulant therapy for six months. His last regular health check-up  about six months ago  revealed no significant abnormalities. He follows up regularly with his primary care physician for management of hypertension and type 2 diabetes but does not have a pulmonologist or hematologist.  Social History:  He was a former smoker  quit 20 years ago  and has no regular alcohol consumption. The patient lives alone and follows a sedentary lifestyle with a high-fat diet.   Family History:   His father suffered a myocardial infarction at 60 years of age and his mother had a stroke at 68. His elder brother was diagnosed with thromboembolic disease in his early 50s. No family history of any bleeding disorder or any known genetic disorders.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient was brought in by a neighbor  complaining of acute chest pain and shortness of breath that started suddenly while climbing stairs to his residence. He mentioned feeling dizzy and light-headed with associated palpitations.  Diagnosis:  Based on his presenting symptoms  history of DVT  and family history of thromboembolic disease  John Doe was diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism.   Investigations:   His D-dimer test was markedly elevated. An Electrocardiogram (EKG) showed signs of right heart strain  and a computerized tomography angiogram (CTA scan) confirmed the presence of clots in his pulmonary arteries. His renal parameters were within normal limits and the glucose control was acceptable.  Treatment:  Oxygen therapy was immediately started  and he was subsequently admitted in ICU for close monitoring. Anticoagulation was initiated with low molecular weight Heparin  later bridged to new oral anticoagulants.   Prognosis and management:  The patient was stabilized after three days in ICU. Long-term anticoagulation therapy with an oral anticoagulant was planned  looking at his risk of thromboembolic events. It was emphasized to the patient to focus on lifestyle modification  better diabetic control  and compliance with his medication. Further family and potentially genetic testing were discussed as a possible part of future management due to his family history of thromboembolic diseases.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John  a 60-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain  and light-headedness. He reports no trauma  fever  cough  or hemoptysis  and is a lifetime non-smoker.  Past Medical History:  Mr. John has a past medical history of hypertension controlled by Lisinopril  type-2 diabetes managed with Metformin  intermittent claudication due to peripheral artery disease  and a deep venous thrombosis (DVT) episode two years ago. He also mentions a sedentary lifestyle due to his executive job and long daily driving periods.  Family History:  His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his mother passing away from myocardial infarction at a younger age (65 years old) and a brother who suffered from a stroke at 58.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  vital signs are remarkable for tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  heart rate of 110 bpm  blood pressure of 142/88 mmHg  temp 98.6F  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Auscultation of the lungs demonstrates decreased breath sounds on the right side  and No leg swelling or tenderness observed.   Laboratory Testing:  Lab test was ordered  including a D-dimer which came back highly elevated. An arterial blood gas shows hypoxemia and respiratory alkalosis. Electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia and no signs of right heart strain.  Imaging:  A CT pulmonary angiography is carried out and demonstrates a large embolus in the right main pulmonary artery. This validated the diagnosis of an Acute Pulmonary Embolism.  Management:   Mr. John is subsequently started on intravenous heparin and admitted to the ICU for further management. He was further evaluated for a longer-term anticoagulation plan by the hospital’s Hematology team.  In this case  the patient’s age  sedentary lifestyle  long travel history  and previous DVT put him at high risk of developing a PE. His current clinical presentation and confirmatory imaging led to the final diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. X  is a 62-year-old Caucasian male residing in Boston. He presented to the emergency department with new onset of acute chest pain and shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a history of hypertension controlled with medication (Losartan 50mg daily) and type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with Metformin. He also has a 20 pack-year history of smoking. There is no known history of surgeries or prior hospitalizations. In general  he has an irregular schedule of moderate physical activity  walking mostly.   Family History:  The patient's mother died of a heart attack at age 67  and his father passed away at 72 from lung cancer. His older sister is living with type 2 diabetes and hypertension. There is no known history of any clotting disorders in the family.  Social History:  Mr. X is a retired school principal. He is a regular smoker  consuming approximately a pack of cigarettes per day and has done so for more than 40 years. He denies any use of illicit drugs or alcohol abuse.  Present Illness History:  Mr. X reported progressive chest discomfort that had begun two days ago  accompanied by mild weakness  diaphoresis  palpitations  and breathlessness. There is no associated cough  fever  or hemoptysis. He also noted a recent episode of left lower limb swelling and discomfort  which he attributed to an ankle sprain 2 weeks ago.  Physical Exam:  Upon examination  Mr. X was in visible distress  pale  sweating  and experiencing tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Vital signs: Blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  SpO2 92% on room air. Auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds in the left lung base and a tachycardic but regular heart rhythm. His left lower limb was mildly swollen and warm to the touch.  Investigations:  Given the combination of chest pain  increased shortness of breath  and history of recent leg swelling  acute pulmonary embolism was suspected. A D-dimer test was ordered  which came back significantly elevated. CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the diagnosis with the presence of a large embolus located in his left lower lobe pulmonary artery. EKG showed sinus tachycardia and incomplete RBBB but no clear signs of right heart strain.  Management:  Mr. X was admitted to the ICU  started on oxygen therapy  and anticoagulation with intravenous heparin  bridged to warfarin later. The lower extremity duplex ultrasound showed evidence of a deep vein thrombosis in the left popliteal vein. Upon discharge  patient education was emphasized  particularly regarding medication compliance  smoking cessation  increased physical activity  and regular follow-up.  Prognosis:  The patient's prognosis largely depends on his ability to manage risk factors such as smoking and sedentary lifestyle  and adherence to anticoagulation therapy. Close medical follow-up will be required.

Patient Profile: Name: Robert Schmidt  Age: 65-year-old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired accountant  Presenting Complaint: Robert presented to the emergency department with an ongoing onset of sudden chest pain which exacerbated during deep breaths. Accompanying symptoms include light-headedness  dyspnea  and mild hemoptysis (blood-tinged sputum).  Medical History: History of hypertension controlled with lisinopril 20 mg daily for the past 15 years. Robert also has been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus since age 50  managed by metformin 500 mg two times per day and a controlled diet. Robert quit smoking 5 years ago but had a smoking history of 20 pack-years.  Family History: Robert’s father had passed away at the age of 70 because of ischemic heart disease. His mother is alive and well at age 85 but has a history of COPD presumably due to a long smoking history. He has two siblings  one of which had a stroke at the age of 60.  Social History: Robert lives with his wife in a suburban area. After retirement  he tends to have a sedentary lifestyle and does not regularly engage in physical activity. He denies alcohol or drug use. He stopped smoking five years ago.  Diagnosis: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Clinical Reasoning: Given Robert's presenting symptoms of chest pain  light-headedness  dyspnea  and mild hemoptysis along with risk factors such as older age  history of smoking  hypertension and sedentary lifestyle  a preliminary diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made.   Investigations: This was further confirmed with an elevated D-dimer level  arterial blood gases showing hypoxemia  and CT pulmonary angiogram showing presence of clot in the pulmonary arteries.  Treatment Plan: Robert was admitted to the ICU for close monitoring. He was initially started on intravenous heparin. After having the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism confirmed by a CT pulmonary angiogram  it was decided to transition to oral anticoagulants such as Rivaroxaban for long term management.   Follow-up/Plan: Robert was informed about his diagnosis and the importance of medication adherence. A follow-up appointment was booked for two weeks post-discharge to monitor the therapeutic effect of the anticoagulant and review the need for further imaging or possible referral for thrombolysis or surgery.  Patient Education: Educated on thrombus prevention including increased mobility  hydration  and wearing compression stockings during long periods of immobility. Counseled on tobacco abstinence and better management of his diabetes and hypertension through healthy diet and regular exercise. Informed to watch for signs of excessive bleeding.

Case Presentation: Patient Overview: Ms. Jane Brown  a 64-year-old woman  has been diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism. She lives in a suburban area in Austin  Texas  with her retired husband. She had been a high school teacher prior to her retirement. She is a non-smoker and drinks occasionally. Her height is 5’5'' and she weighs roughly 165 lbs. Her BMI falls within the 'Overweight' category  but she is otherwise physically active with frequent gardening and light exercises.  Past Medical History: Ms. Brown has a medical history of recurrent Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) diagnosed 8 years before the current presentation. She was on warfarin therapy for the past 6 years under close monitoring  which was discontinued a year ago due to the recurrent episodes of gum bleeding and bruising. She also has hypertension which is currently being managed by daily antihypertensive medication. She underwent a hysterectomy at the age of 45 due to uterine fibroids; the procedure was uneventful  followed by an uncomplicated recovery.  Family History: Her father passed away from acute myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and her maternal uncle had a stroke at the age of 59. Her two older siblings are reported to have hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Her mother is 88 years old and suffers from dementia. There is no known family history of malignant cancer or genetic disorders.  Presenting Symptoms: Ms. Brown was brought to the ER by her husband due to a sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain which was progressively worsening. She also reported a mild cough and lightheadedness. The chest pain was sharp  localized in the center of her chest  and was exacerbated on taking a deep breath.  Testing and Diagnosis: Initial examination recorded a blood pressure of 158/90 mmHg  pulse 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. Blood tests showed elevated D-Dimer and slight thrombocytopenia. Chest computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the acute pulmonary embolism. The diagnosis was further validated using the Wells score  as the clinical probability of PE was high in her case. The Wells score components included clinical signs and symptoms of DVT  PE being the most likely diagnosis  and a heart rate more than 100 bpm.  Hospital Course and Management: Ms. Brown was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). Anticoagulant therapy was re-started (low molecular weight heparin initially followed by warfarin)  consideration for thrombolytic therapy based on ongoing evaluation. Regular monitoring of her vitals  ECG  and coagulation profile was instituted.   Future Implications: Ms. Brown is advised to follow up with a pulmonologist and a hematologist to monitor her recovery  adjust her anticoagulant therapy as necessary  and evaluate her for chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension in the future. Lifestyle changes are recommended  including a low sodium diet for her hypertension and exercises tailored to her condition. Her case may merit evaluation for underlying malignancies  given unprovoked DVT subceding the pulmonary embolism.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe is a 55-year-old Caucasian male. He is married with two children and works as a software engineer with long-hitting hours mostly seated. He is a non-smoker and drinks moderately. He has a known family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a myocardial infarction at 60 years and his elder brother recently got diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease.  History of Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden onset  sharp  and stabbing right-sided chest discomfort  which became worse with deep inspiration. He was also experiencing shortness of breath and mild palpitations.  Past Medical History:  On evaluation of his records  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with hypertension about 4 years ago  for which he has been prescribed Amlodipine 5mg once daily. He also suffers from obesity  but there are no signs of diabetes at any point in his medical history  nor any allergies reported.   On Examination:  On admission  his blood pressure was 146/94 mmHg  a heart rate of 104 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 90% while on room air. On physical examination  his chest was clear on auscultation.  Investigations:  Blood reports revealed elevated D-dimer. An EKG showed sinus tachycardia and right bundle branch block. Chest radiograph was essentially unremarkable. CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the presence of an embolus in the right lower lobe pulmonary artery.  Impression/Diagnosis:   Based on the clinical history  investigation results  and radiologic findings  he was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.  Treatment and Plan:  Mr. Doe was admitted to the respiratory unit. Intravenous Heparin was immediately started  and Warfarin was introduced for long-term anticoagulation. The patient was also advised about the need for weight regulation  regular exercise  and hypertension control as part of his long-term management. He was counselled about the importance of medication compliance and regular follow-ups.   The case was discussed with the vascular surgery team  but as there was no hemodynamic instability  thrombolysis or embolectomy was not considered at this stage.       Follow-up:  The patient’s condition improved over the subsequent days. As his symptoms resolved and his vitals were stable  Mr. Doe was discharged but was advised to continue Warfarin. He is scheduled for a follow-up in the outpatient department with complete blood count and coagulation profile tests 2 weeks post-discharge.

Patient Information:   Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African-American male  presented to the emergency department with shortness of breath and severe chest pain that started while he was reading a newspaper at home.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and was a heavy smoker with a smoking history of 30 pack-years. He has been jaundiced on occasion but never undergone surgical procedures. His medications include a bronchodilator and inhaled corticosteroids. He also revealed that he has been a bit sedentary in recent weeks due to a foot injury that kept him largely immobile. There was no known history of malignancy or recent weight loss.  Family History:  Mr. Johnson’s father died of myocardial infarction when he was in his 60s. His mother  currently in her late 80s  suffers from hypertension and type 2 diabetes.   Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  Mr. Johnson appeared anxious and diaphoretic. His respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute  blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  and oxygen saturation was 94% while breathing room air. Auscultation revealed diminished breath sounds at the right lung base accompanied by some crackles.  Investigations:  Blood tests revealed elevated levels of D-dimer. Troponin level was normal which indicated no cardiac involvement. Bedside echocardiography showed signs of right heart strain. This clinical suspicion led the team to perform a CT pulmonary angiogram that showed multiple bilateral pulmonary emboli  confirming acute pulmonary embolism.   Treatment:  Mr. Johnson was admitted to the intensive care unit and was immediately begun on therapeutic low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) and supplemental oxygen.   Follow-up:   Arrangements were made for follow-up care in the out-patient clinic to monitor Mr. Johnson's INR and check his response to treatment. Also  he was referred to the smoking cessation clinic and physiotherapy to gradually increase his mobility and avoid recurrence of such episodes in the future.   This case highlights the importance of considering pulmonary embolism as a potentially lethal condition  especially in patients with risk factors such as prolonged immobilization  COPD and a significant smoking history.

Presenting Patient:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male was brought to the emergency department (ED) by his wife on account of sudden shortness of breath which started approximately 2 hours prior to his arrival. The patient reports having a racing heart and feeling dizzy. His wife also reports that he seemed a bit confused at times. He has no known allergies.  Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of Type 2 Diabetes  controlled with Metformin  and Hypertension managed by Lisinopril. He had laparoscopic inguinal hernia repair surgery approximately 4 weeks ago from which he recovered well according to the reports. He is a former smoker  having stopped 5 years ago after a 30 pack-year history. He admits to occasional alcohol intake and denies any use of recreational drugs.  Family History:  The patient’s father had a myocardial infarction at age 65 and his mother had rheumatoid arthritis. He has a younger brother living with Type 2 Diabetes and a sister who had breast cancer.  Physical Examination:  In the ED  he was noted to be anxious  tachycardic with a heart rate of 120/min  blood-pressure was 145/90 mmHg  respiratory rate was 28 /min  SpO2 was 89% on room air which improved to 94% with 2-litre oxygen via nasal cannula. His BMI was 28  indicating overweight status. Other systems  including cardiovascular  gastrointestinal and neurological showed no significant abnormalities.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Given the patient’s symptoms and recent surgery  a diagnosis of acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE) was suspected. D-dimer levels were significantly raised. CT pulmonary angiography was performed  which confirmed the diagnosis by showing a filling defect in the right lower lobar pulmonary artery. The patient's Wells score was 4.5 which placed him in the high-probability category.  Management and Outcomes:  The patient was given supplemental oxygen  started on intravenous (IV) heparin and admitted to the hospital for further evaluation and treatment. Hospital pharmacists recommended switching from IV Heparin to Apixaban for long term anticoagulation.  Plan:  The plan going forward is to maintain the patient on Apixaban for at least 3 months  as per the recommended guidelines. The patient will also need frequent follow-ups with the pulmonology and cardiology departments  and may require adjustment of his hypertensive drugs. The patient and his wife will need counselling on lifestyle modification  importance of medication adherence  and the signs and symptoms of PE recurrence.   Conclusion:  This is a case of a 65-year-old male who developed acute PE post hernia repair surgery. The likely cause is prolonged immobility post-surgery. The patient recovered with early diagnosis and prompt therapeutic intervention.

Patient Profile: Mr. Charles  a 68-year-old African-American male  retired lawyer  presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness. The symptoms began approximately four hours prior to his visit to the hospital.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  deep vein thrombosis (DVT) from five years ago  and chronic atrial fibrillation  for which he is taking warfarin. He is a former smoker  with a 30-pack-year history. He quit smoking ten years ago. Reportedly  he remains largely sedentary. The patient has an allergy to penicillin-based drugs.  Demographics: Mr. Charles lives at home with his wife and receives support from a home care nurse who visits weekly. He does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs  and has a diet high in fats and low in fruits and vegetables.  Family History: Both his parents had a history of cardiovascular disease  his father suffered from a heart attack at the age of 56 and his mother had an ischemic stroke at the age of 60. His elder brother  currently 70 years of age  has a history of DVT as well.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Charles is experiencing tachypnea (respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute)  tachycardia (heart rate: 102 bpm) and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Temperature and blood pressure were normal at 98.6 °F and 130/80 mmHg  respectively.   Investigations & Diagnosis: Based on his history of DVT and the presenting symptoms  a clinical suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism (PE) was raised. A D-dimer test was performed which came back positive. A computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was then conducted  which confirmed an acute PE.   Treatment: The patient was started on a heparin drip and his warfarin was held. He was admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring.  This case highlights the importance of considering acute PE in patients with previous history of DVT  atrial fibrillation  and sudden onset of symptoms like shortness of breath and chest pain.  The patient's sedentary lifestyle  diet  past smoking history  and family history all potentially contribute to his heightened risk for cardiovascular events such as DVT and PE. Going forward  these factors will need to be addressed in order to reduce the risk of further complications. Education on the importance of medication adherence in reducing his risk for thromboembolic events will be crucial in his management plan.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. J. He presented to the emergency department with sudden onset dyspnea  left-sided chest pain  and hemoptysis. He also complained of feeling faint and mildly nauseated. Upon physical examination  he was slightly cyanotic upon arriving at our facility. His vital signs upon admission were as follows: Blood pressure -150/90mmHg  heart rate - 100bpm  respiratory rate - 20 breaths per minute  and body weight - 80kg.   Past Medical History:  Mr. J has a known history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) about 6 years ago. For this reason  he has been on anticoagulant therapy using Warfarin since then. His latest INR was 2.0  taken 2 months ago  and was not regular in the follow-up visits. He also has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes  which is managed with Metformin tablets  and a 15-year history of hypertension controlled with Losartan. There is no history of any known allergies.  Family History:  Mr. J comes from a family with a history of cardiovascular diseases. His father passed away at the age of 75 due to myocardial infarction  and his elder brother  now 70  was diagnosed with angina pectoris 5 years ago.  Social History:  He is a retired engineer  married  with 2 adult children who are healthy. Mr. J is a former smoker. He quit 6 years ago  but he had a 30-pack-year smoking history. He drinks socially and doesn't use any illicit drugs.  Clinical Findings and Assessment:  Considering his past medical history of DVT and the present symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE) is suspected. An urgent CT angiogram confirms the presence of large emboli in the bilateral pulmonary arteries. D-dimer levels were significantly elevated  and an ECG demonstrated right ventricular strain  consistent with a diagnosis of acute PE.  Hospital Course and Management:  Mr. J was admitted to the ICU in stable condition but requiring close monitoring. He was started on systemic thrombolytic therapy with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rt-PA) in addition to the continuation of anticoagulation therapy. His oxygen saturation and respiratory functions improved gradually.  Conclusion:  This case re-emphasizes the vital connections between patient history  particularly a history of DVT  and the potential for acute pulmonary embolism. An ongoing adherence to management and follow-up with health professionals is significant  primarily when patient's lifestyle factors  such as former smoking and family history  increases the risk of PE. Proper anticoagulant management and patient education can reduce this risk and prevent a serious  potentially life-threatening event like PE. Doctors should ensure that patients  once diagnosed with conditions like DVT  receive adequate counseling regarding the importance of medication compliance and regular follow-up.

Patient Information  Name: Mrs. Jane Smith Age: 68 years Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher  Presenting Complaint  Jane was brought to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain  which she described as a sharp pain amplifying when she takes deep breaths. The pain started about three hours before presenting to the emergency department. Jane also reported a feeling of faintness along with mild dizziness.   Past Medical History  Jane was previously diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left leg 10 years ago which was treated accordingly. She's also been on medication for hypertension for the past 7 years and has a history of type 2 diabetes. She is a breast cancer survivor  having completed chemotherapy five years ago. She has a BMI of 28  indicating overweight.  Medication: Losartan for hypertension  Metformin for diabetes.  Family History  Both her parents suffered from cardiovascular diseases. Her father died of myocardial infarction and her mother has chronic heart failure. Jane's twin sister also has a history of hypertension and her elder brother has a history of stroke.   Social History  She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. She lives alone and is physically active  often participating in community yoga classes for seniors.   Examination and Investigation  On examination  Jane appeared anxious  her pulse was 110 beats per minute and BP was 160/90 mmHg. Her respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation was 91% on room air. On auscultation  heart sounds were regular with no murmurs and lung fields sounded clear.   D-dimer test was performed immediately and results came back positive  which led the emergency physician to suspect a pulmonary embolism (PE)  especially considering her symptoms and past history of DVT. A CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the presence of PE in the right lower pulmonary artery.  Diagnosis  Acute pulmonary embolism  Management Plan  Immediately following the confirmation of PE  Jane was started on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) for anticoagulation  with plans to initiate long-term anticoagulation therapy. She will be monitored closely in hospital for signs of hemodynamic instability and considered for thrombolytic therapy if her condition deteriorates. Education about recognizing symptoms of PE and the importance of medication adherence will be provided. Upon discharge  she will be scheduled for necessary follow-up appointments  and it is suggested that her hypertension management be reassessed in the light of her acute PE event.

Case Presentation   Patient Identification: Mr. E.J. is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who resides in a suburban neighborhood.  Chief Complaint: Patient arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  palpitation  and a sharp  stabbing chest pain which intensifies with deep breaths.  Past Medical History: Mr. E.J. has a known history of hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hypertension. All three conditions are well-managed with medication. He also had a total knee replacement surgery two years ago.  Family History:  Mother suffered stroke at 81 and father had coronary artery disease  resulting in his death at 75. His younger brother  69  has type 2 diabetes and his elder sister  75  has osteoporosis.  Social History:  He is a retired accountant  non-smoker  and drinks alcohol occasionally (around one drink per week). He’s been sedentary since retirement.  Physical Examination: On physical exam  Mr. E. J. looked anxious and was sweating profusely. His vital signs noted were: blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats/minute  respiratory rate of 24 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation of 89% on room air.  Investigations: Chest X-ray did not show any overt abnormalities while electrocardiogram showed sinus tachycardia. Labs showed an elevated D-dimer. Chest computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed the presence of saddle pulmonary emboli.  Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Management: He was started on therapeutic enoxaparin and later transitioned to oral anticoagulation therapy. His oxygen saturation improved with supplemental oxygen. His condition stabilized and with time symptoms gradually resolved.  Follow up: Mr. E.J will need close outpatient follow-up  compliance to lifestyle modifications (increased mobility  dietary changes)  and long-term anticoagulation therapy to prevent recurrence of PE.  Educational counseling regarding disease  its course  necessary lifestyle modifications  and adherence to therapy is necessary for Mr. E.J. A referral was made for outpatient cardiac rehabilitation to help improve his exercise capacity.   Conclusion: This case highlights the significance of early detection and prompt management of acute PE in a patient with multiple risk factors including advanced age  history of surgery and sedentary lifestyle. It also reinforces the importance of long-term management strategies and patient education in preventing PE recurrence.

Patient Profile: Mr. John Wilson  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  has presented to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness that have been intensifying over a period of the last few hours. Mr. Wilson works in a high-stress job as an attorney and lives in the city with his wife. He smokes one pack of cigarettes a day for the last 30 years and drinks alcohol socially. He leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his long working hours.  Past Medical History: Mr. Wilson has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia that was diagnosed five years ago. He is on antihypertensive medications and statins for the same. He has had a sedentary lifestyle with limited physical activities and a diet high in saturated fats. No history of surgeries  allergies  or previous episodes of similar symptoms is reported.  Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father had his first myocardial infarction at 60 and his younger brother had a stroke at the age of 50. His mother died of complications from diabetes.  Current Presentation: On physical examination  his BP was recorded at 162/98 mm of Hg  heart rate 112 beats per minute  respiratory rate 22 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 92% on room air. The patient appeared anxious  sweaty and at a rate of respiration that was greater than normal. On auscultation  breath sounds appeared to be decreased on the right lower side of the chest.  Didactic Correlation:  Acute pulmonary embolism was suspected based on the clinical symptoms and patient's risk factors  which include his advanced age  smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of cardiovascular diseases.   Further Assessment and Diagnosis: A D-dimer test was ordered to rule out pulmonary embolism and the results were positive(580 ng/mL; the reference range is 0 to 500 ng/mL). A CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was ordered and confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Management Plan: Mr. Wilson was admitted to the hospital  started on anticoagulant therapy  oxygen therapy was provided and a hydration status was maintained. He was advised to stop smoking and increase his physical activity along with a proper diet.  Prognosis and Patient Education: Regular follow-ups were recommended to ensure the efficacy of therapy and to monitor for any potential side effects of the medication. Education about the signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolism and when to seek immediate help was provided to both Mr. Wilson and his wife.  This case demonstrates the importance of taking patient demographics  past medical history  and family history into account when diagnosing acute conditions. The sedentary lifestyle  coupled with other risk factors such as smoking and family history of cardiovascular diseases  pointed towards the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Name: John K. Doe Age: 65 Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Chief Complaint: Episode of acute chest pain and sudden onset of breathlessness post a long-haul 9-hour flight.  Past medical history:   John is an ex-smoker who quit smoking five years ago after a 30-year habit. He has a history of hypertension  well controlled with Amlodipine. Reported occasional episodes of unspecified arrhythmias  not on any medication.  Family history:   Father passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 68. Mother is a 90-year-old with Type 2 diabetes. A younger sibling underwent stent placement for coronary artery disease at 57.  Clinical Examination:  On presentation  his blood pressure was 155/90 mmHg. Heart rate was 106 beats per minute. Oxygen saturation was 93%. Physical examination revealed apparent signs of distress  diaphoresis and tachypnea. Auscultation of lungs exhibited normal breath sounds without any wheeze.  Investigations:  Blood tests showed increased D-dimer level. An electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute right heart strain. A contrast-enhanced chest CT was performed given the high suspicion of pulmonary embolism  which confirmed extensive bilateral pulmonary embolism.  Management:  Following the stakeholder discussion  John was started on therapeutic unfractionated heparin  while maintaining activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) between 60 to 80 seconds. He was also given supplemental oxygen.  Outcome:  Over the next few days  shortness of breath improved significantly  and he became gradually less tachycardic and hypoxic. He was discharged home on oral anticoagulation (warfarin) and counseled on the importance of medication adherence  healthy lifestyle  and regular follow-up.  Given that this is his first episode of unprovoked PE  further work-up for hypercoagulability  including cancer screening  was planned on follow-up.  Conclusion:  Overall  John's presentation of acute onset breathlessness and chest pain post a long-haul flight  raised suspicion of a pulmonary embolism  later confirmed by elevated D-dimer levels and CT pulmonary angiogram.  It is vital to consider the medical and family history  lifestyle  and presenting symptoms when approaching differential diagnoses. Quick diagnostic work-up and prompt initiation of anticoagulation therapy are indispensable in managing such cases effectively to improve outcome and decrease morbidity and mortality.

Patient Presentation:  Subject: Mrs. Jane Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the ER complaining of sudden shortness of breath together with sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsened with deep breaths.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Doe is a known hypertensive and diabetic patient. She also has a history of chronic bronchitis. All conditions are properly managed with medications. Due to her decreased mobility  she has a high BMI (32.8 kg/m2)  she is labeled as obese. In the past  she was treated for a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) post a total knee replacement surgery two years ago. She has an allergy to penicillin.  Family History: She has a strong family history of cardiovascular diseases. Her father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 50  and her mother died of stroke at the age of 72. Mrs. Doe has one sibling  a younger sister diagnosed with hypertension.  Social History: She is a retired school teacher living with her husband. She is a non-smoker and has a moderate consumption of alcohol. She has no history of illicit drug use.   Current Episode: The patient commented that the symptoms started abruptly a few hours ago when she was watching television. The pain does not radiate and there is no associated nausea  vomiting  sweating  or syncope. The review of systems was otherwise negative.   Physical examination: The patient appeared anxious  diaphoretic with notable tachypnea. Her blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate was 110 beats per minute. Auscultation of her lungs revealed decreased breath sounds in the left lower lung.  Based on her symptoms  history  and physical examination  a provisional diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made. D-dimer test was ordered  which came back positive. A confirmatory CT pulmonary angiogram was performed  which indeed confirmed the presence of a clot in the left pulmonary artery.   Plan: Mrs. Doe is started on IV heparin and will continue on warfarin post-discharge for three months. Education about lifestyle changes including weight loss  routine exercise  and a low-sodium diet were discussed to manage her hypertension and diabetes.   Prognosis: Prognosis is cautiously optimistic assuming compliance with her treatment plan  though she will require close monitoring given her severe comorbidities and increased risk of recurrent PE due to her history of DVT.

Patient Case Presentation: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Demographics: Patient: Mr. Richard Davis Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Residence: San Francisco  California  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Davis presented at the Emergency Department with complaints of sudden-onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain exacerbated by deep breaths and coughing  and signs of circulatory shock including light-headedness  fainting  and rapid heart rate.  Past Medical History: Mr. Davis has been on medications for high blood pressure and high cholesterol for the past ten years. He also had a total knee replacement surgery two months ago  from which he is still recovering.  Family History: Heart disease and hypertension run in Mr. Davis' family; both his father and his older brother had heart disease and died of heart attacks  his mother had a stroke  and an aunt had a DVT a few years ago.  Clinical Findings & Diagnostics: ECG displayed right heart strain and an elevated troponin level. Chest CT angiogram demonstrated a large clot in the right pulmonary artery. D-dimer test was also elevated. Hemoglobin levels were marginally decreased  and CBC showed mild leukocytosis. The patient's oxygen saturation level was found to be 92%  lower than the acceptable range.  Diagnosis & Treatment: Based on the clinical history  symptoms  and diagnostic findings  Mr. Davis was diagnosed with Acute Pulmonary Embolism. Immediately after the diagnosis  he was started on unfractionated heparin with plans to bridging to warfarin. His vital signs were stabilized  and oxygen was administered.  Hospital Course: In the subsequent two days in the hospital  the patient's symptoms considerably improved with a stabilized heart rate and increased oxygen saturation level. He was educated on the use of warfarin  the importance of regular International Normalized Ratio (INR) check-ups  and the course of treatment.  Patient Disposition & Follow-Up: Mr. Davis was discharged after four days  on continued Warfarin therapy. He was instructed to return for follow-up in one week to ensure the effectiveness of the treatment and monitor for any side-effects or recurrence of symptoms.  Bearing in mind the patient's joint surgery and family history of thromboembolism  it was decided to recommend genetic testing for thrombophilias once his anticoagulation therapy is completed. The importance of regular ambulation and active living was stressed to Mr. Davis before discharge to prevent the likelihood of any future thrombotic events.

Patient Case Presentation  Patient Information: The patient is Mrs. G  a 67-year-old African-American female residing in Manhattan  New York. She is a retired high school teacher  married with three adult children  and attends her local church regularly. Mrs. G has never smoked or used other illicit substances  but her alcohol consumption is moderate  with social drinking events. She is obese with a body mass index of 32 kg/m^2 and a sedentary lifestyle.  Chief Complaint & Episode Description: Mrs. G came to the Emergency Department complaining of a sudden onset of shortness of breath for the past 8 hours which started while walking in her garden. She also reported experiencing sharp chest pain radiating to her back  light-headedness  and palpitations.  Past Medical History: Mrs. G has a history of varicose veins and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) that occurred 3 years ago and was managed by anticoagulation therapy. The patient also has type 2 diabetes and hypertensive cardiovascular disease  both of which are under control with medication and regular monitoring.   Family History: There is a strong family history of cardiovascular disease  with her father having died of an acute myocardial infarction at 60  and a maternal aunt who died from a stroke. Two of her three siblings have hypertension. Her mother is alive and has type 2 diabetes and osteoarthritis.  Social History: She lives with her husband and states that she has a good social support system among her family  friends  and church community. Mrs. G is retired and devotes most of her time to home-keeping  reading  and attending social events with her church congregation.   Clinical Findings: On physical examination  her BP was 160/90 mm Hg; heart rate was 110 beats/minute and irregular; respiratory rate was 22 breaths/minute; temperature was 98.6F; and oxygen saturation on room air was 86%. ECG revealed sinus tachycardia with a right bundle branch block  and chest X-ray showed no lung consolidation or pneumothorax.   Diagnostic Impressions & Management Plan: Based on the clinical findings  the history of DVT  and the presenting symptoms  the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made. A CT angiogram of the chest confirmed the diagnosis. The patient was admitted to the hospital for further management. She was started on anticoagulation therapy and oxygen supplementation as the initial management strategy. The importance of weight loss  regular exercise  and maintaining a balanced diet were also emphasized as important preventive measures. Mrs. G was also referred to a cardiologist and pulmonologist for further management and follow-up.   Outcome: The patient responded well to the treatment and showed significant improvements in her symptoms after 48 hours. Plans are underway for her continued management and long-term monitoring to prevent recurrence. Her family is involved in the management plan  and they have committed to helping Mrs. G make the appropriate lifestyle modifications.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian female named Mrs. Patricia Smith.  Chief Complaint: The patient arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain that started two hours ago.  History of Present Illness: Mrs. Smith stated that she had experienced symptoms of chest tightness  palpitations  and moderate to severe dyspnea since the morning. Notably  she also mentioned a non-productive cough. She denied any fever  chills  or contact with sick individuals.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Smith is a former smoker with a 25-pack year history  but she quit eight years ago. She has known hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which she is taking medication. Additionally  she had left-knee surgery 15-days prior to her symptoms  following which she was largely bedridden.  Family History: Her father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and her mother had a stroke at 78. She has two siblings  one of whom has been diagnosed with Deep Vein Thrombosis in the past.  Examination:  Vital Signs: BP: 144/90 mmHg  HR: 112 bpm  RR: 24/min  SpO2: 90% on room air  Physical examination was significant for tachypnea and tachycardia. Pulmonary examination revealed decreased breath sounds in the left lower lobe.  Lab Findings: D-dimer test was elevated. Other lab parameters including troponin and EKG were normal.  Investigations: With her presenting symptoms and raised D-dimer test  urgent CT pulmonary angiography was carried out which confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Diagnosis: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Treatment plan: Considering her hypoxia  tachycardia  past medical history  and moderate risk PE  she was started on systemic therapeutic anticoagulation (low molecular weight heparin) followed by oral anticoagulants.  Brief Discussion: This patient presented with acute PE  likely secondary to her recent orthopedic surgery and prolonged immobilization. This case highlights the importance of a thorough history and examination high index of suspicion for PE in patients with recent surgery and appropriate steps in management. The patient needs close monitoring  considering her elevated BP and family history which put her at an increased risk for cardiovascular events. Furthermore  she needs counseling regarding the importance of mobility post-surgery.

Patient Information:   Jane Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency room of our hospital. She is a retired teacher who lives with her husband and reports significant lifestyle modifications due to escalating health issues recently.  Chief Complaint:   She complained of sudden onset sharp chest pain and shortness of breath  rating the pain as 7/10.  Present Illness:  The chest pain started a few hours ago and progressively worsened  radiating to the back. Accompanied by shortness of breath that's getting worse even on slight exertion.  Past Medical History:  Ms. Smith has a history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  both of which are under control with medication. She has a 10-year history of smoking but quit 15 years ago. In addition  she sustained a left ankle fracture three weeks ago for which she was immobilized.   Family History:  Her mother had a stroke at the age of 70  and the patient's father died from a myocardial infarction at 75. No reported history of clotting disorders.  Physical Examination:  On examination  Ms. Smith appeared anxious and was experiencing tachycardia (118 bpm) and tachypnea (22 breaths per minute). Oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. BP was 145/90 mm Hg.   Mental status was okay  and other system examinations were within normal ranges  except for decreased breath sounds on the right lower side.  Investigation:  Laboratory tests displayed elevated D-Dimer. Chest x-ray was performed  which was inconclusive. However  a high-resolution computed tomography (CT) scan showed signs of acute pulmonary embolism.   Diagnosis:  Given her recent immobilization due to fracture  clinical presentation  and radiological findings  a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was made.  Treatment:  Ms. Smith has been started on therapeutic anticoagulation with parenteral Heparin  overlapped with Warfarin. She has responded well to the initial therapy.  Discussion:  This case highlights the importance of considering the possibility of pulmonary embolism in patients who present with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain  particularly if they've had recent immobilization or exhibiting risk factors. Prompt diagnosis and treatment are of extreme importance due to the potential for rapid deterioration and high mortality associated with untreated pulmonary embolism.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 68-year-old African American male with a medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain. The pain was described as sharp  worse upon inspiration. There were no other associated symptoms like fever  cough  or hemoptysis. He is a retired truck driver and lives with his wife. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol only on social occasions. He denies any illicit drug use. His current medications include warfarin for DVT and amlodipine for his hypertension.  He has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having died from a myocardial infarction in his 60s  and his mother diagnosed with congestive heart failure in her late 70s.
