On physical examination  he was observed to be in moderate respiratory distress  with increased respiratory rate. Oxygen saturation was 92% while breathing room air. Breath sounds were decreased on the right lower side. His heart rate was elevated with normal rhythm  and blood pressure was slightly elevated (150/90 mmHg). No leg swelling or signs of DVT were evident on physical examination.  Initial laboratory results showed an elevated D-dimer level. An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed normal sinus rhythm with no specific ST-T changes. Given his symptomatology and history of DVT  a computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was ordered  which confirmed the diagnosis of bilateral pulmonary embolism.  The patient was immediately started on heparin treatment  and his warfarin was held. He was placed on oxygen therapy to improve his oxygenation. The case was discussed with the hematologist for future placement of an inferior vena cava filter given his history of recurrent DVT and now pulmonary embolism.  Mr. J’s case highlights the need for vigilant monitoring and control of risk factors in patients with a history of DVT  especially in those with a familial history of cardiovascular disease. Optimization of anticoagulation therapy is crucial in such cases to prevent life-threatening complications such as pulmonary embolisms.

Patient Presentation   Patient Details: Ms. Elizabeth Jacobs  60-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath and intermittent chest pain for the last 48 hours.  Presenting Symptoms: Ms. Jacobs reports experiencing sudden shortness of breath even while at rest  along with chest pain that's non-radiating in nature. She characterizes the chest pain as 'stabbing' mainly during deep inhalation. She also noted episodes of coughing spells sometimes with streaks of blood.  Past Medical History: Ms. Jacobs has a known history of systemic hypertension controlled by medication (amlodipine 10mg once daily). She also has a history of surgery for an ovarian cyst removal (uncomplicated) 15 years ago. She does not have diabetes or heart disease and is a non-smoker. She stays relatively active for her age and is not obese (BMI:22).  Family History: Both her parents died at old age due to cardiac issues. Her mother had a history of stroke at the age of 75. She also has a younger brother diagnosed with deep venous thrombosis (DVT).   Investigations: On physical examination  she appeared anxious  sweating  and was in respiratory distress. Her vital signs demonstrated tachycardia (Heart Rate: 110 beats/minute) and hypoxia (Oxygen Saturation: 90%). The ECG showed sinus tachycardia without any ST-T changes.   Lab results revealed an elevated D-dimer. Her blood reports indicate marginally high Troponin level but normal renal function. A CT pulmonary angiogram confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. A Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities indicated no signs of DVT.  Management: Ms. Jacobs was started on oxygen therapy and anticoagulant therapy (Low-molecular-weight heparin). She was admitted to the ICU for close monitoring and further management.  Risk Factors: Given her family history of DVT and her own personal history of surgery  Ms. Jacobs is at increased risk of developing a blood clot. Her condition may have been triggered due to her sedentary lifestyle following her recent ankle sprain which limited her mobility for some weeks.  Brief Summary: This is the case of a 60-year-old female with a previous medical history significant for hypertension and surgery with recent decreased activity levels. She presented with symptoms of acute shortness of breath and chest pain. Investigations corroborated the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. She's currently on anticoagulant therapy under close monitoring in the ICU. Her condition draws attention to the importance of monitoring post-operative and immobilized patients for signs of thromboembolic events  even years after the surgery.

Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male patient  was admitted to the Emergency Room.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient complained of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of chronic hypertension and high cholesterol  treated with amlodipine and statins  respectively. He also suffers from a sedentary lifestyle due to his work as a desk job professional. Last year he had an invasive knee replacement surgery but had no complications post-surgery.  Family History:  His father died at a relatively young age due to myocardial infarction and the patient's younger sister has a history of deep vein thrombosis.   Social History:  Non-smoker and social drinker. No known drug history.   Investigations:  Lab Results revealed elevated D-dimer and blood test indicating high troponin levels. An immediate ECG was done which did not show any changes associated with acute infarction or ischemia.   A CT angiography identified a large embolus in the right pulmonary artery  confirming the diagnosis of an acute pulmonary embolism (PE).  Treatment:  The patient was immediately initiated on low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and oral anticoagulants. Oxygen support was provided due to his symptoms of shortness of breath.  Outcome:  Patient response to treatment is being monitored. He has been scheduled for a follow-up after discharge to assess treatment effectiveness and plan for long-term management.  Summary:  This case presents an instance of acute pulmonary embolism in a 65-year-old male with risk factors including hypertension  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of venous thromboembolic events  highlighting the importance of prompt diagnosis and appropriate management to prevent severe complications.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents with sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and fevers. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  type II diabetes  and obesity. He reports a sedentary lifestyle and a 30-pack-year smoking history. He has a family history of venous thromboembolism (VTE)  with his father having had a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) at the age of 58.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient reported a recent gradual onset of fatigue and dyspnea  but related that his symptoms dramatically worsened over the past 48 hours. He also reported a recent episode of coughing up blood-tinged sputum. The patient attributed his ongoing fatigue and early dyspnea to progression of age.  Investigations:  Electrocardiography reveals a sinus tachycardia. Imaging reports a chest computed tomography (CT) scan showing signs consistent with an acute pulmonary embolism. Blood tests indicate an elevated D-dimer level. His oxygen saturation is decreased to 88% in room air.   Diagnosis:  Based on the presenting symptoms  imaging investigation  and blood results  the patient was diagnosed with an acute pulmonary embolism. The presence of the risk factors  such as obesity  smoking  a sedentary lifestyle  and family history of VTE  increased the index of suspicion.  Management:  The patient was started on low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) and later transitioned to oral anticoagulation in the hospital setting. Patient counseling was initiated to explain the severity of the condition and the importance of medication compliance and lifestyle modifications.  Complications:  Due to late presentation  the patient developed right-sided heart strain/risk of pulmonary hypertension; repeated echocardiography would be needed to monitor this.  Prognosis:  The patient remains at an elevated risk of recurrent PE and DVT due to his multiple risk factors. Long-term management will depend on therapeutic response  medication tolerance  and patient compliance with lifestyle modifications.  Follow-Up:  The patient will be required to have regular follow up appointments with a pulmonologist and cardiologist to ensure his PE has resolved  manage potential complications and evaluate the need for extended anticoagulation therapy. He has also been referred to a smoking cessation program and a dietitian to help with weight loss and lifestyle modification.

Patient Information:   The patient is a 58-year-old African American male  a retired military officer  currently living alone. He was brought to the emergency department by his neighbor after he complained of sudden-onset shortness of breath and chest pain. He has been reportedly losing weight for the last couple of weeks. He denies any history of fever  trauma  cough  or hemoptysis.   Past Medical History:   The patient is known to have multiple comorbidities  which include chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and atrial fibrillation (AF) for which he has failed to maintain an optimal INR on Warfarin. He has a history of DVT on his left leg 3 years ago.   Family History:  According to patient  his father died at age 63 due to myocardial infarction and his mother died at 58 due to cerebral vascular attack. He has 2 siblings  one of them known to have hypertension and the other one with diabetes. He is non-alcoholic and a former smoker with no illicit drug use.  Clinical Findings:  The oxygen saturation measured by pulse oximetry was 88% on room air. The BP was elevated at 160/90mmHg  heart rate 110 beats/min  and respiratory rate 24/min. On examination  he was found sweaty and in considerable distress. Cardiovascular examination revealed an irregularly irregular rhythm. There was edema and erythema of the left lower extremity  but both limbs were warm.  Investigations:  Chest X-ray didn't reveal any significant lung pathology. The patient showed a marked increase in D-dimer level based on lab results. An ECG was indicative of an S1Q3T3 pattern  raising suspicion for a possible pulmonary embolism (PE). CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) was performed and confirmed the diagnosis of PE.  Management:  Given the patient's uncontrolled AF  history of DVT  and weight loss  he was admitted to the hospital under the cardiology service for the management of the PE and further investigation of weight loss  with consideration for malignancy. He was started on a full dose of low molecular weight heparin(LMWH) as a bridge to oral anticoagulation  provided that there is no contraindication. Given the possibility of malignancy  a hematology/oncology consultation was also requested for further management.   Prognosis:  He is currently stable but acutely ill  with guarded prognosis due to underlying comorbidities and the acute PE. It should be noted that early and fast detection is key in the successful management of patients with PE  which can be life-threatening if left untreated. We will need to ensure optimized management of his COAD and AF  with a focus on the INR range to avoid the risks of thrombotic and bleeding events in the future.   This case highlights the importance of considering PE in patients presenting with sudden shortness of breath  particularly in patients with risk factors such as AF and a previous history of DVT. Although most patients with PE present with dyspnea  chest pain  or syncope  some symptoms can be quite vague  and maintaining a high index of suspicion is essential to prompt diagnosis and treatment.

Patient Presentation  Patient Profile:  This case study involves a 52-year-old Caucasian male presenting with acute pulmonary embolism (PE). He is a non-smoker and controls his moderate alcohol consumption. The patient is married  self-employed  enjoys cycling  and has no history of drug use.   Past medical history:  The patient had an appendectomy at the age of 22. His medical history includes hypertension  which is well-managed with Amlodipine 5mg once a day. He has no known allergies.  Presenting Symptoms:  The patient reported acute onset of shortness of breath  chest pain that worsened on deep inspiration  and light-headedness. He denied any symptoms related to lower limb pain or swelling. His symptoms occurred suddenly while working at his desk.  Family History:   The patient's father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55  and his mother has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Otherwise  the family history is negative for thrombosis-related conditions.  Physical Examination:  On examination  his blood pressure was slightly elevated (150/95 mmHg). His heart rate was regular but slightly tachycardic at 110 bpm. He was afebrile with oxygen saturation of 92%. There was no lower limb swelling or tenderness  and cardiovascular and abdominal examination were unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Working in consideration of the symptoms and risk factors  PE was suspected. His D-dimer test was remarkably high. CT pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) confirmed the presence of multiple clots in both pulmonary arteries  therefore confirming the diagnosis of acute PE.  Management and Outcome:  He was started on anticoagulant therapy with Enoxaparin injections and afterward switched to long-term oral anticoagulant therapy with Warfarin for the prevention of recurrent PE. Statins were added for his hypertension. He was also advised for lifestyle changes.  Prognosis and Follow-up:  The patient responded well to the aforementioned treatment regimen. His symptoms resolved over a period of a few weeks. He was encouraged to make lifestyle modifications and was scheduled for regular follow-ups and blood tests to monitor his condition and anticoagulation status.  Ethical Considerations:  The patient provided informed consent for all the diagnostic procedures and management plans incorporated into his care. He was given detailed information about the diagnosis  possible complications  and treatment plan.  This case underlines the importance of considering PE as one of the differential diagnoses when dealing with sudden-onset shortness of breath and unexplained tachycardia  further emphasizing the value of careful history evaluation and examination in clinical practices.

Patient Presentation  Patient Profile:  G.M. is a 68-year-old African American male who currently resides in Austin  Texas. He is a retired mechanic who lives with his wife. He appears anxious and visibly distressed due to his difficulty in breathing.   Medical History:  Patient has a notable medical history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril and Aspirin for the past 10 years. No history of surgeries or other significant diseases. Also  he has a history of occasional alcohol use and smoking for 40 years.   Chief Complaint:  His initial complaint was a sudden onset of severe shortness of breath  chest pain  and lightheadedness that has persisted for a few hours.  Preliminary Diagnosis & Testing:  Based on the presenting symptoms and risk factors  a preliminary diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE) was suspected. In order to support the diagnosis  a D-dimer test was ordered revealing significantly elevated levels. Given the severity of symptoms  a computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) was subsequently performed  confirming the presence of a pulmonary embolism.   Family History:  Patient’s family history reveals a father who died from a stroke at 78 and a mother who died from congestive heart failure at 82. The patient has two siblings: an older brother with diabetes and a younger sister with no significant health issues.  Social History:  Patient is currently retired and lives with his wife. He enjoys reading  gardening  and spending time with his grandchildren. The patient has a 40 pack-year history from smoking (two packs per day for 20 years)  but quit smoking 5 years ago. He occasionally drinks alcohol but denies any illicit drug use.  Treatment Plan:  He was put on anticoagulants  with a low molecular weight heparin (enoxaparin) for immediate effect  along with warfarin therapy for long term management. The patient was also given supplemental oxygen and pain relief.  Patient education was done emphasizing on the need for regular follow-ups  medication compliance  diet  exercise  smoking cessation  and when to seek immediate medical attention. Patient and the wife verbalized understanding of the information.   Plan is to follow-up in the clinic next week.  This case underlines the importance of immediate recognition and treatment of pulmonary embolism to prevent significant morbidity and mortality. The patient's history of smoking and hypertension possibly contributed to his risk for developing a PE. Timely intervention and appropriate treatment have likely improved the patient's prognosis  but continued education and support regarding lifestyle modifications are essential.

Patient Profile: Mr. Peter Xavier  a 55-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the ER with complaints of sudden onset sharp chest pain radiating to the shoulder  accompanied by shortness of breath and light-headedness. The patient reports a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) seven years ago. He works as an accountant and admits to a sedentary lifestyle. He is a former smoker  having quit five years ago  drinks social alcohol  and denies any drug use. The family history reveals that his father had an ischemic stroke at the age of 67.  On examination  he was anxious  with a pulse rate of 115 bpm  blood pressure of 130/85 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute  and SpO2 of 92% on room air. Physical examination was otherwise normal  and no leg swelling noted.  He was immediately given oxygen support via nasal cannula  and labs were ordered. His D-dimer level was significantly elevated. An ECG didn't show any signs of ischemia. Chest X-Ray didn't show any significant abnormalities. However  a CT pulmonary angiography revealed a thrombus in the right pulmonary artery  confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  The patient seemed to be stable without any signs of compromise in the functioning of his heart  placing him under a category of submassive (intermediate-risk) pulmonary embolism.   We started the patient on anticoagulation therapy with parenteral heparin and oral apixaban. No thrombolytic agents were used considering his current risk classification and potential risk of bleeding.   Considering his sedentary lifestyle and history of DVT  he was recommended lifestyle modifications and physical activities like regular walking and leg exercises to promote blood flow.  The patient responded well to the treatment and showed improvement in symptoms within a matter of days. His oxygen saturation levels returned to normal and respiration rate slowed. He was discharged on lifelong oral anticoagulants and has been scheduled for regular follow-ups to monitor his progress and drug side effects if any.  A discussion on a genetic predisposition to thrombosis has been opened with the patient and family  advising genetic counseling and screening for hereditary thrombophilias for his children considering his familial history of stroke and personal history of DVT and pulmonary embolism.

Case Presentation  Patient Information:   Mr. Richardson  a 67-year-old African American male  was brought to the Emergency Department (ED) with acute shortness of breath  chest pain  and mild dizziness. He describes the pain as ""sharp"" in nature  located on the right side of his chest and worsening with deep breaths. His wife reported that he had been increasingly fatigued over the past week  with intermittent cough but no hemoptysis or fever.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Richardson has a 10-year history of poorly controlled type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He had been a heavy cigarette smoker for 25 years before quitting 15 years ago. He had a lower limb deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years back and was on warfarin therapy for six months.  Family History:   His mother died of myocardial infarction in her late 50s. His father had a stroke and was also diagnosed with diabetes and hypertension. He has one sibling  a brother  also diagnosed with hypertension.  Review of Systems (ROS):  Negative for nausea  vomiting  and abdominal pain  but he endorses recent leg swelling (right > left).  Physical Examination:  Upon arrival  he was afebrile with a heart rate of 110 bpm  BP of 170/95 mmHg  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 88% on room air. His BMI was noted to be 29. Examination revealed decreased breath sounds on the right side and swollen  tender right lower limb. Cardiac examination was notable for tachycardia but no murmurs. The rest of the physical examination was within normal limits.  Investigations:  A d-dimer was significantly raised. Chest X-ray was unremarkable  and a CT pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) showed bilateral multiple pulmonary emboli. An ultrasound of the lower limbs detected a DVT in the right leg.  Diagnosis:  Acute pulmonary embolism probably secondary to deep venous thrombosis.   Treatment:  Given his hypoxia  tachycardia  and extent of clot burden  Mr. Richardson was admitted to the Intensive Care Unit for close monitoring and was started on therapeutic intravenous heparin. Warfarin therapy was also recommenced.  Discussion:  This case is an example of acute pulmonary embolism  particularly concerning due to the patient's extensive clot size and the history of previous DVT. Management should include anticoagulation therapy with attention to improving his hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and diabetes control for overall cardiovascular risk reduction. His case serves as a reminder that we carefully evaluate each patient for risk factors of thrombotic episodes and consider early therapeutic interventions.

Patient Profile:  The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who goes by the name of Mr. Smith. He is a retired army officer  with a medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  diagnosed approximately seven years ago  for which he had discontinued the prescribed anticoagulant therapy against medical advice. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago and is being treated with oral hypoglycemic agents. He had quit smoking 10 years ago and carries a 20 pack-year history. He does not consume alcohol. He leads a sedentary life since his retirement two years ago. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father passing away at the age of 55 due to a heart attack and his elder sibling being diagnosed with heart disease at an early age of 50 years.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of breathlessness and sharp  stabbing chest pain radiating to his back  exacerbated on deep inspiration. The patient also reported experiencing light-headedness and a fainting episode earlier in the day.   Clinical Findings:  On initial evaluation  Mr. Smith had a blood pressure of 145/100  a heart rate of 110 bpm (tachycardia)  respiration rate of 26 breaths/minute (tachypnea)  oxygen saturation 90% on room air and was afebrile. On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and was in acute respiratory distress. He presented with signs of right heart strain. No leg swelling or tenderness was noted.  Investigations:  Laboratory findings showed elevated D-dimer levels indicative of thrombus formation. A chest computed tomography (CT) with contrast immediately performed confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism (PE) with blockage observed in both the main pulmonary arteries. An echocardiogram revealed right ventricular dysfunction consistent with PE. The blood glucose level was mildly elevated. His EKG showed tachycardia and S1Q3T3 pattern suggestive of acute PE.  Treatment Plan:  Our patient was immediately commenced on anticoagulant therapy via Low Molecular Weight Heparin administration to prevent further clotting and oral Warfarin for long-term anticoagulation. The lack of hemodynamic instability ruled out the need for thrombolytic therapy.   Outcome:  The patient responded well to the initial treatment  showing improvement in breathlessness and chest discomfort. Long term  Mr. Smith will require close monitoring of his INR (International Normalized Ratio)  continuous diabetic control  and lifestyle modifications to manage his PE condition. He has also been advised to maintain his anti-coagulation therapy to mitigate the risk of recurrence.

Patient Presentation/Introduction: Mr. J. Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male referred to the emergency department exhibiting symptoms of acute shortness of breath  chest pain  and a persistent cough. He is a businessman with a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Mr. Smith is a retired military officer and lives with his family of four in Tampa  Florida.  Medical History: Mr. Smith has been managing his pre-existing conditions of hypertension and type 2 diabetes well with regular insulin injections and diet regulation for the latter and hypertensive medication (Lisinopril) for the former. Moreover  he was diagnosed with DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis) in his left leg 3 years ago. Over the past year  he reported frequent episodes of chest pain but attributed it to acid reflux.  Family History: He has a family history of cardiac diseases; his father died from a myocardial infarction at age 70  and his older brother  who is 70 years old  underwent a bypass surgery two years ago.   Physical Examination: On physical examination  he appeared uncomfortable and cyanotic. He had an increased respiratory rate (24 breaths per minute) and tachycardia (112 beats per minute). Blood pressure was noted as 145/90mmHg  and oxygen saturation was 89% on room air  indicating low oxygen levels in the blood.   Investigations/Lab results: Lab results demonstrated elevated levels of D-dimer - 1 200 ng/mL (normal range <500 ng/mL). A subsequent CT scan confirmed the presence of blood clots in the pulmonary artery.  Provisional Diagnosis: Based on his symptoms and lab results  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with acute pulmonary embolism.  Management: He was immediately put on oxygen therapy via nasal cannula to relieve hypoxia and started on anticoagulant therapy with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). Considering his family history of cardiac diseases and his elevated BP  a beta-blocker was also introduced to manage his tachycardia.  Conclusion: Mr. Smith's case indicates the importance of vigilance in patients with a history of DVT and co-morbid conditions like hypertension and diabetes since they are at a higher risk for developing Pulmonary embolism. Earlier suspicious signs of chest pains should've been investigated thoroughly. It also highlights the requirement for regular check-ups and adherence to medication for such patients due to their increased susceptibility to severe conditions like PE.

Patient Profile: Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old male  Caucasian. He is a retired engineer  married  with two adult children. He lives in suburban Midwest and is mainly sedentary.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe was admitted to the emergency department presenting with acute onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and blood-streaked sputum for the last six hours.  Past Medical History: He has a 10-year history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus and hypertension and was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago. He is a former smoker  with a 20-pack-year smoking history  and quit smoking 15 years ago.   Family History: His father died of a heart attack at the age of 62  but a detailed family history report shows no known inherited thrombophilic conditions.  Current Medications: He is currently taking Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia.  Investigations: On examination  he had a heart rate of 105 bpm  a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. His blood pressure was measured as 140/90 mmHg. An ECG showed sinus tachycardia with a S1Q3T3 pattern. His D-Dimer level was elevated.   A CT pulmonary angiography was performed which confirmed the presence of a large clot in the right lower lobe pulmonary artery  clarifying the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  Management: Mr. Doe was immediately started on Oxygen therapy and low molecular weight heparin. Warfarin was also added to his treatment regimen for long-term anticoagulation. His previous medications were continued. His diet was optimized to control his glucose levels and efforts were made to improve control of his hypertension.  Given his history of hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia  he is at high risk for a recurrent event  therefore strict control of his cardiovascular risk factors will be key to reducing this risk.  Follow-ups: He has regular follow-ups scheduled with endocrinology to manage his diabetes  cardiology for anticoagulation management and risk factor reduction  and his primary care provider for holistic wellness support.  In conclusion  Mr. Doe's ongoing management will be multi-disciplinary and will focus on managing his acute condition  optimizing his chronic disease management  and reducing his overall cardiovascular risk.

Patient Presentation  Mr. J.D.  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain  which is exacerbated by deep breathing. The patient recalls having a feeling of sudden unwell and lightheadedness prior to this episode. He denied having cough  fever  or hemoptysis. He has a BMI of 29 kg/m2.  Past Medical History  Mr. J.D.'s medical history is significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM) and Hypertension (HTN)  both of which are well-controlled with Metformin and Lisinopril respectively. He suffered from a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago and was on warfarin for several months at that time. He previously smoked but has been smoke-free for the past decade. He drinks occasionally.  Family History  Family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  as his father had a fatal myocardial infarction at 72 years old. His mother had Type 2 DM and succumbed to complications of a stroke at the age of 80. His elder brother is living with HTN and hyperlipidemia.  Clinical Course and Management  On physical examination  he was tachycardic (HR: 120 bpm) and tachypneic (RR: 25 breaths per min) with a blood pressure of 128/80 mmHg. Oxygen saturation was 90% on room air  and he had decreased breath sounds in the lower lobe of the right lung.  Laboratory results showed elevated D-dimer  while ECG revealed sinus tachycardia but no evidence of right heart strain. Chest X-ray appeared unremarkable  and a subsequent CT pulmonary angiography confirmed the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism in the right lower lobe.  The patient was initially stabilized with oxygen and intravenous fluids. Given his previous history of DVT and the acute pulmonary embolism  he was started on Low Molecular Weight Heparin. Anticoagulation was bridged to warfarin with a plan to continue it for at least 6 to 12 months in consultation with a hematologist.   Patient education about the importance of compliance with medication  regular follow-ups  and lifestyle modifications including moderate exercise and a healthy diet was also emphasized.   Outcome and Follow-up  The patient's condition improved gradually  and he was discharged home. Mr. J.D. is scheduled for a follow-up in 2 weeks to assess his response to the treatment and any potential side effects of medication. A referral was made to the thrombotic disorder specialty clinic for long-term management.

Case Report: Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Doe Sex: Male Age: 60  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Truck driver  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes which was managed with lifestyle modifications and medication. He also has a history of smoking 1 pack per day for 25 years but quit 10 years ago. No prior surgery or hospitalization.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with chief complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain for the past 4 hours which worsens on deep inspiration  and mild light-headedness. He also mentioned a recent long haul journey in his truck lasting 20 hours with few breaks.  Key Examination Findings:  Upon arrival  Mr. Doe appeared acutely distressed  with an observed respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  pulse rate of 100 beats per minute  blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg  and oxygen saturation of 92%. Physical examination revealed signs of central cyanosis with mildly distended neck veins and chest examination found no lung consolidation or wheezing but decreased breath sounds over the right lower lung zone.  Key Investigation Findings:  Lab work showed elevated D-dimer levels. A subsequent Computed Tomography Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) was conducted which confirmed a diagnosis of acute right sided pulmonary Embolism.   Summary: This case describes an acute presentation of pulmonary embolism in a patient with multiple risk factors including prolonged immobility due to a long-distance drive  a history of DVT  hypertension  and a history of smoke exposure. Key symptoms included sudden onset sharp chest pain  shortness of breath and light-headedness.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian female  Present Complaints: The patient presented with sudden onset difficulty breathing  chest pain that intensified with deep breaths  and a feeling of light-headedness.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 5-year history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus. She reported that she had undergoing a total knee replacement surgery approximately three weeks ago. She is a former cigarette smoker  with a 20-pack-year history  but quit 10 years ago.  Social/lifestyle information: The patient lives alone  has a sedentary lifestyle and does not engage in any regular physical activities. She is on medication for her hypertension and diabetes which includes Lisinopril and Metformin.   Family History: Her father died at the age of 72 due to a myocardial infarction and her mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis  diagnosed at the age of 75.   Physical Examination upon arrival: The patient was in apparent distress  with fast breathing and high heart rate revealed in the physical examination. Her blood pressure was slightly elevated  and oxygen saturation level was lower than normal. She appeared pale and anxious.  Diagnosis for consideration: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  This case presentation should trigger considerations about risk factors  symptoms  physical examination findings  and management strategies for acute pulmonary embolism allowing a comprehensive and interactive discussion-based training scenario.

Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in an Elderly Male with Past History of DVT and Recent Orthopedic Surgery  Demographics:  Mr. Franklin is a 74-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker  married  retired industrial engineer.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Franklin has a history of hypertension  well-controlled with Amlodipine 5mg daily. He has a significant past medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 5 years ago  successfully managed with oral anticoagulant treatment. He also underwent a right knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Franklin presents to the Emergency Department with a one-day history of acute onset shortness of breath  noticeable chest discomfort especially on deep inspiration (pleuritic chest pain) and palpitations. His wife also noticed he looked pale and seemed fatigued today compared to the previous day.   Supporting Information: The patient has not been regularly mobile since his recent knee surgery due to pain  and has only been taking short distanced walks around his house. He was also switched from his regular anticoagulant medication to low-molecular-weight heparin (due to surgery) which he administers as a subcutaneous injection but admits to forgetting the medication two days in a row because his regular nurse was on holiday.  The case would go on to reveal a diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism  with the knee replacement surgery  personal history of DVT  periods of immobility and error in anticoagulant administration being the major risk factors. The symptoms of acute shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  and palpitations provide valuable clues connecting to the condition.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics Name: Patient X Age: 60 years old Gender: Female Race: African American Occupation: Retired school teacher  Past Medical History  Patient X has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  all well controlled with medication. She had a total knee arthroplasty 3 weeks ago. She is an ex-smoker and quit 10 years ago. She drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. There is a family history of deep vein thrombosis in her elder brother.  Chief Complaints Patient X presents to the emergency department with sudden onset dyspnea which started a few hours ago. She also complains of pleuritic chest pain  unilaterally leg swelling  and mild hemoptysis. Patient also mentioned increasingly fatigue over the past week but attributed it to her post-surgery recovery.  The case should focus on early detection signs and symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism. The students should be reminded of risk factors such as recent surgery  family history of DVT or any thromboembolic event  smoking history  and extensive periods of immobility. They should be guided to do appropriate diagnostic testing keeping in mind the probability based on clinical presentation. It should also focus on management options for such situations.

Case Vignette: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Johnson  Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Past medical history: 1. Hypertension for the past 15 years  controlled with medication (Ramipril) 2. Type II Diabetes managed with diet and Glyburide 3. Obesity with a BMI of 32 4. Sedentary lifestyle 5. Ex-smoker – quit smoking 10 years ago. Had a 20-pack year smoking history. 6. Appendix surgery 3 weeks ago 7. Recent air travel - returned from a transcontinental flight 5 days back  Chief Complaint: Mr. Johnson presented to the ER complaining of sudden onset severe chest pain for the past 2 hours. He describes the pain as sharp  stabbing type  located at the left side of the chest  aggravated by deep breaths and not radiating anywhere. He also reports sudden onset shortness of breath which is progressively worsening. He also feels light-headed but denies any syncope  fever  cough or hemoptysis.  Physical Examination Findings: Blood Pressure: 150/90 mm Hg Pulse: 100 beats per min Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths per min Oxygen Saturation: 92% on room air Temperature: 98.7 degrees Fahrenheit  He appears distressed due to pain. His chest auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds in the left lower zone without any added sounds. Heart sounds are normal without any murmurs. Rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.   Please teach the students to pick up on the risk factors for pulmonary embolism in the patient's history and to associate them with the presenting complaints. Also  highlight the significance of timely diagnosis and intervention in conditions like acute pulmonary embolism that can drastically affect the prognosis.

Patient Information: 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaints: Sudden onset severe chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath and feeling of apprehension.  Past Medical History:  History of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) three years ago  treated with anticoagulants; current smoker with a 40 pack-year history  and a family history of pulmonary embolism. Patient has been non-compliant with medication for hypertension for one year now.  Present Illness:  The patient complained of sudden onset severe central chest pain that radiates to the back and occurred at rest. The pain was not relieved by rest or nitroglycerine. Additionally  the patient reported recent episodes of palpitations  sudden shortness of breath even at rest  and a general feeling of apprehension. He has no history of cough  wheezing  or fever. He was also stressed about recent prolonged immobility due to a broken ankle (6 weeks) that required non-weight bearing immobilization and recumbence.  Physical Examination:  Patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic. He had tachycardia (heart-rate 110 beats per minute)  tachypnea (respiratory rate 25 breaths per minute)  and was hypoxic (oxygen saturation 92% on room air). His blood pressure was initially 115/70 mmHg  which dropped to 90/60 mmHg on repeated measurement. Auscultation revealed normal breath sounds. No leg swelling  tenderness  or signs of DVT were noted  but the patient complained of residual pain from his broken ankle.   This case should be used to train medical students on identifying and managing acute pulmonary embolism. Concerning elements include the patient's history of DVT  symptoms of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  the recent period of immobility  tachycardia  tachypnea  hypoxia  and the recent episode of hypotension.

Patient Case Report  Demographics: Mr. James Martin  a 67-year-old Caucasian retired bank manager  presents to the emergency department. He is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol occasionally. The patient is married  has two adult children  and lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood.  Past Medical History: Mr. Martin has a documented history of uncontrolled hypertension for the past seven years. He had an ischemic stroke two years ago but showed tremendous recovery with minor right-sided weakness. He also has Type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he is on oral antidiabetic medication. The patient had an open cholecystectomy 10 years ago. Details of the family medical history reveal that his father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 75.  Presenting Complaints: Just prior to his ED admission  Mr. Martin experienced sudden onset of shortness of breath after returning from a long car journey. He describes the dyspnea as gradually worsening over a 24-hour period  now associated with sharp  right-sided chest pain that gets worse when he takes deep breaths. He also reports a non-productive cough and feeling unusually fatigued. He denies fevers  hemoptysis  night sweats  or unexplained weight loss. The patient also recounts some recent swelling and discomfort in his right calf  which he dismissed as a minor issue.  This case would continue with physical examination  differential diagnosis  further investigations  management and follow-up plans  and discussion on complications and preventive measures for recurrent incidents.  The principal learning objective is to highlight the significant aspects of acute pulmonary embolism  correlation with Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  and the importance of early detection and proper management.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 65-year-old  non-smoking male  John  of Caucasian descent. He is retired and lives with his spouse. His BMI is 28  indicating that he may be in the overweight range.  Past Medical History: John has a past medical history significant for deep venous thrombosis (5 years ago)  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes  all of which have been reasonably managed with medication. He also had a mild stroke 10 years ago. He has been inactive recently due to a fractured ankle three months ago.  Key Complaints:  John presented at the emergency department (ED) complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath  which has been getting progressively worse over the past few hours. The dyspnea is associated with chest pain that is sharp in nature  exacerbated by deep breathing and mildly relieved by leaning forward. He rates the pain as 7 on a scale from 0 to 10.  On further questioning  John admits that he ignored mild leg pain and a slightly swollen and warm right calf which started a week ago. He recalls that similar signs and symptoms preceded his previous DVT event. He denies any recent travel  surgery or history of malignancy.  In the ED  his vital signs are: Blood pressure 160/90 mmHg  pulse 110 beats per minute  respiration rate 24 breaths per minute  SpO2 85% on room air. His respiratory status and leg signs along with his past history suggest possible acute pulmonary embolism (PE).   This case will guide students through the necessary steps in diagnosing and treating a patient with suspected pulmonary embolism. It also emphasizes the importance of considering patients' past medical history in informing diagnostic decisions and treatment plans.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Smith  Age: 62 Sex: Male  Occupation: Retired military officer Race: Caucasian   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes  high blood pressure  and had an orthopedic surgery (total knee replacement) 2 weeks ago. No known allergies  non-smoker  and drinks alcohol occasionally. There is no family history of blood clotting disorders. The patient is on Metformin for diabetes and Atenolol for blood pressure.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Smith presented himself to the ER with acute onset of chest pain  shortness of breath  and a cough producing blood-tinged sputum for the past few hours. He rates the pain as 8/10 on the pain scale  describing it as sharp  that worsens with deep breaths. He also reports a mild fever and feeling light-headed. He reports having been largely inactive post his knee surgery.  This case provides an opportunity to discuss the prevention  diagnosis  and management of acute pulmonary embolism in a medical setting. Important discussion points would include the risk factors (such as immobility related to recent surgery  age  high blood pressure  diabetes)  symptoms  diagnostic tests  and treatment options.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 58 years old Sex: Male Race: African-American  Occupational status: Forklift operator  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson is a known hypertensive patient on medications for the last 10 years. He also has a 25 year history of smoking  smoking approximately one pack of cigarettes per day. There were no incidents of surgery or hospitalization due to any serious health complications in the past. There is a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his grandparents on his mother’s side. He consumes alcohol occasionally and does not have known any drug allergies. He is not a regular exerciser  primarily due to the nature of his job which involves a lot of physical labor. His BMI is 27 and he gets routine health check-ups done. His blood works in the past have always shown normal parameters.  Key Complaints: On a visit to the ER  Mr. Johnson is experiencing complaints of a sudden onset of chest pain which he describes as a 'sharp' and 'stabbing' sensation. The pain appears to be increasing with deep inhalation and has been noted for the last two hours. He also reports bouts of coughing with blood-streaked sputum. He looks significantly anxious and states that he is experiencing a sensation of 'breathlessness' and 'tightness' in the chest. He has not experienced a similar episode before. He also indicates feelings of lightheadedness and slight confusion. He denies any recent history of travel  surgery  or prolonged bed rest.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Ms. Smith is a 72-year-old female with a BMI of 28. She is a nonsmoker and does not consume alcohol. She lives alone  is retired  and her activity level is very low due to her pre-existing medical conditions. She's of Caucasian descent.  Past Medical History:   Ms. Smith is a known case of Hypertension and Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus  maintained adequately on medications. She also has a surgical history of a total knee replacement of her right knee two months back.   Presenting Complaints:  Ms. Smith was brought to the emergency room by a neighbor who noticed that she seemed unusually distressed. Ms. Smith reported she felt a sudden onset of difficulty in breathing which has been worsening progressively. Along with this  she experienced a sharp  stabbing pain in her chest which accentuated while taking deep breaths and symptoms of dizziness. She also mentioned coughing up blood-tinged sputum.   This case study focuses on the immediate suspicion of Acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE) based on her history of recent orthopedic surgery (posing an increased risk of deep vein thrombosis) and her symptoms. It can spark discussions on crucial topics like deep vein thrombosis and its complications  the approach to acute chest pain  vital signs examination  the relevance of radiological investigations in PE  and acute management as well as prophylaxis of PE. This case serves as a practical scenario for medical students to get a better understanding of PE enabling them to correlate theoretical knowledge with clinical practice.

Patient Case:  Case Details:  Patient: Mr. John Thompson Age: 54 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Financial Analyst  Past Medical History: - Known hypertensive for 10 years (treated with Atenolol) - No history of Diabetes Mellitus  Thyroid Disorders  or any other chronic illness. - Underwent left total knee arthroplasty 2 weeks ago due to severe osteoarthritis. - History of smoking  approximately 20 cigarettes per day for 30 years.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson presented to the Emergency department with sudden onset of sharp  severe chest pain that started 4 hours prior; pain is localized in the center  and radiates to his left arm. Not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. Along with chest pain  he is also suffering from unexplained shortness of breath  noticeable anxiety  and increased feelings of unease. He also complained of feeling faint with episodes of profuse sweating.  Upon inquiry  there was no history of trauma  fever  cough  wheezing  nocturnal dyspnea  or orthopnea. Mr. Thompson denies having any GI symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or loss of sensation. His co-morbidities are under control and he has been compliant with his hypertensive medication and quitting smoking post his knee surgery. He also denies any history of travel to hyper endemic regions or exposure to infectious disease.  Given his recent surgical history  acute onset of symptoms  and characteristic presentation  Acute Pulmonary Embolism is strongly suspected.  As an instructor  proceed with the discussion of evaluation including history  physical examination  diagnostic criteria  risk factors  management  and complication.

Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Jorge Ruiz Age: 59 Sex: Male Race: Hispanic Occupation: Office administrator Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History:  1. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) 2. Type 2 diabetes mellitus well-controlled with oral medication 3. Former smoker  quit 10 years ago 4. History of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following hip replacement surgery 5 years ago; completed 6 months on warfarin therapy postoperatively  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Ruiz was brought to the emergency department by his wife. He reported experiencing sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain which worsened on deep breathing  over the last 2 hours. He denied any recent long-distance travel  periods of immobilization  or trauma. His wife reported he has been unusually restless and anxious. She also mentioned that over the past week  he had complained of mild pain and swelling in the calf region of his right leg  which he dismissed as a result of overexertion.  Brief Clinical Examination:  On assessment  Mr. Ruiz looked visibly distressed and was sweating. His vital signs were as follows: blood pressure was 145/90 mm Hg  heart rate was 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate was 24 breaths per minute  SpO2 was 88% on room air. His body mass index (BMI) was 30 (height: 5ft 7in  weight: 200lb). On physical examination  there was mild swelling of the right calf. No superficial veins were visible. Routine neurological examination was normal. His chest was clear on auscultation and heart sounds were normal with no extra sounds or murmurs.  Based on his clinical presentation  a consideration of acute pulmonary embolism was made. Further investigations were ordered accordingly.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Patient X (To ensure confidentiality) Age: 55  Gender: Male Occupation: Desk Job Worker  Past Medical History: Patient X has a history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes and unprovoked deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago. He has been sedentary due to his occupation as an accountant and adopts a sedentary lifestyle outside of work. The patient is a nonsmoker. He is also obese with a BMI of 32. His father had a history of pulmonary embolism.   Key Complaints: Patient X presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of breathlessness and chest pain that has been worsening over the last few hours. The pain was sharp  pleuritic  and located in the right side of his chest. The patient also reported a feeling of apprehension and had been sweating excessively. On further questioning  the patient admitted to having swollen and painful calves over the past week but did not seek medical attention as he attributed it to long hours of sitting at work.  Summary: This case outlines the presentation and past medical history of a male patient with risk factors ideal for a training case on acute pulmonary embolism. The key complaints include sudden shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  and unexplained sweating. An important element for students to understand here is how past medical history  risk factors such as prolonged immobility  family history of PE  and current symptoms contribute to the clinical suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism. This will direct further investigations and management.

Case Report:  Patient Information: A 62-year-old African American male  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  hypertension  and a 40-pack year smoking history. He underwent a total knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago. His medications include atorvastatin 10 mg daily  amlodipine 5 mg daily  and bronchodilator inhalers for his COPD.  Key Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with a complaint of a sudden onset of shortness of breath which started 2 hours ago while he was watching TV at home. He describes it as an intense struggle to breathe that is far more severe than his typical COPD symptoms. He also has a stabbing chest pain  especially on deep inhalation  and reports feeling light-headed. He denies any fever  cough or sputum production. He also mentions he stopped taking his prescribed anticoagulant medication (a factor Xa inhibitor) against medical advice after his surgery due to concerns about excessive bleeding.  Physical Examination: The patient appears in moderate respiratory distress. Vital signs are Blood Pressure: 155/95 mmHg  Heart Rate: 110 bpm  Respiratory Rate: 25 breaths per minute  SpO2: 88% on room air  and Temperature: 98.5 °F. Pulmonary examination reveals tachypnea and clear lung fields bilaterally. He is noted to have a moderate swelling of his right lower extremity.  Based on the patient's history of recent surgery  his abrupt onset of dyspnea and chest pain  cessation of anticoagulation therapy  signs of possible deep vein thrombosis  this patient's symptoms could potentially indicate an acute pulmonary embolism  however  further diagnostic workup is needed to confirm the diagnosis.   Through this case  medical students will learn the process of recognizing  diagnosing  and managing acute pulmonary embolism  particularly in a patient with multiple risk factors including recent surgery  non-compliance to prescribed prophylaxis and long-term COPD. Furthermore  they will learn communication strategies to handle patients who are non-compliant to prescribed therapy.

Case Report:  Patient Introduction:  A 62-year-old African-American male presents himself to the Emergency department.  Demographics:  Occupation: Retired Army veteran Residence: Suburban community  Marital Status: Married  Chief Complaints:  The patient reports sudden onset of shortness of breath and a sharp  stabbing type of chest pain that worsens when he takes a deep breath. He also describes a light-headedness and an unexplained anxiety.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medication. He quit smoking 15 years ago but has a 20-pack year history of smoking. He underwent a left total knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago and has been relatively immobile post-surgery. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases - both his father and brother have suffered heart attacks.   Medications: Metformin  Lisinopril  Aspirin Allergies: No known drug allergies   Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appears anxious and slightly diaphoretic. Vital signs show an elevated heart rate (tachycardia – 110 beats per minute)  normal blood pressure (130/80 mmHg)  increased respiratory rate (22 breaths per minute)  and oxygen saturation at 92% on room air (indicative of mild hypoxemia). Heart sounds are normal with no audible murmurs. Lung fields are clear to auscultation. Lower extremities show mild edema on the left side with slight calf tenderness.  This case report presents a high clinical suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  especially considering the patient's recent orthopedic surgery and family history of cardiovascular disease. The combination of shortness of breath  unexplained anxiety  chest discomfort  tachypnea  and tachycardia  coupled with recent immobilization and a surgical history  are highly suggestive of acute PE.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 60-year-old Caucasian male  employed as a software engineer.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) suffered around five years ago. He also has obesity (BMI: 32) and is a former smoker  quit 10 years ago. Mr. Doe leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his job nature. There are no allergies or known family history of clotting or cardiovascular disease. His medications include aspirin 81 mg daily and simvastatin 20 mg daily.  Key Complaints: Today  Mr. Doe has visited the emergency room presenting with a sudden onset of shortness of breath which has been worsening over the past few days. Accompanying symptoms are chest pain which he describes as a ""stabbing pain"" that intensifies with deep breathes. He also states that he has been feeling lightheaded and dizzy over the past day. His wife also notices that he seems to be confused at times. She also mentions a slight bluish discoloration of his lips and skin (cyanosis). He denies any recent injuries  travel  or prolonged immobilization.  This case study is formulated to educate the medical students about the symptoms  diagnosis  and treatment strategies of acute pulmonary embolism. It is important for the students to understand the complexity of the disease and the necessity for an immediate and precise response in medical treatment. This case prompts to recognize the connection between the patient's past medical history of DVT  his lifestyle  the presented symptoms and the likely diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.

Case Report - Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: Mr. Jones  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago after a 40-pack per year history. He is known to have hypertension for which he takes Amlodipine 10mg daily and controlled type II diabetes mellitus managed with Metformin. Patient had a total hip arthroplasty three weeks prior to presentation. He lives alone and is relatively sedentary but self-dependent.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Jones was brought to the ED by his daughter who reported her father was experiencing sudden shortness of breath which started two hours prior to arrival. Associated symptoms include mild chest pain  exacerbated by deep breaths  and episodes of feeling light-headed. He denies any cough  fever  or hemoptysis. No reports of lower limb swelling or pain.  Emergency Intervention: Immediate intervention includes administration of oxygen  ECG  chest radiography followed by a D-dimer test given the high suspicion of pulmonary embolism. Mr. Jones's oxygen saturation on room air is found to be 88 prior to administration of supplementary oxygen. His blood pressure and pulse rate are stable at 135/85 and 92/min  respectively.  This training case focuses on acute pulmonary embolism and aims at teaching students to recognize the signs and risk factors  importance of early diagnosis  selection and interpretation of appropriate diagnostic tests  and understanding of treatment modalities. This case stimulates clinical reasoning and decision-making skills in emergency and high-stakes situations.   Follow-up tasks could include discussion of underlying pathophysiology  potential complications  role of prophylaxis in cases of major surgeries and in high-risk patients  and differentiating between other causes of chest pain and dyspnea.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   - A 68-year-old Caucasian female - Retired accountant - Lives alone  widowed  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension controlled with Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors - Mild hypercholesterolemia managed with lifestyle modifications - No history of thromboembolic events - Recently traveled long-haul flight from Australia to Canada (~16 hours) - Former smoker (25 pack years  quit 10 years ago) - No history of illicit drug use - No known allergies  Key Complaints:  The patient presents to the emergency department complaining of:  - Sudden onset of shortness of breath started a couple of hours ago - Sharp  stabbing chest pain that gets worse with deep breaths - Dizziness and light-headedness - Recent mild swelling of the right lower leg  without redness or warmth - No associated cough  wheezing  or fever  Family History:  - Father died of myocardial infarction at age 72 - Mother deceased  cause unknown - No known family history of blood clotting disorders  Social History:  - Consumes alcohol moderately (occasional wine with dinner) - Lives alone but has assistance from a caregiver twice a week - Limited physical activities due to arthritis - Regularly attends a book club with friends.   This case presents a patient with typical clinical features of acute pulmonary embolism  a potentially life-threatening condition  and additional risk factors such as recent prolonged immobility (long-haul flight) and old age.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Mr. Bolton  a 56-year-old African-American male  employed as an HR executive with a sedentary lifestyle  presents to the emergency department (ED).  Past Medical History: Mr. Bolton has a history of hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide therapy  but he’s been non-compliant for the last couple of weeks. He had a below-knee cast applied for an un-displaced fracture of the left lower leg  sustained two weeks ago while playing golf. He has been overweight for the past 10 years with BMI of 29 kg/m2. There is no history of any genetic condition or thrombophilias. He is a non-smoker with moderate alcohol consumption and no history of drug abuse.  Key Complaints: Mr. Bolton arrived at the ED complaining about a sudden onset of shortness of breath lasting for one hour  which exacerbated on physical exertion and concurrent moderate to severe pleuritic chest pain  located centrally and worsening with inspiration. He also reported an ongoing cough but no hemoptysis. Furthermore  he expressed uneasiness and anxiety about these new symptoms.  On examination  he was anxious  with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Blood pressure was 140/90mmHg  pulse 98 beats per minute and temperature 98.6°F. No cyanosis or clubbing was noted. Chest examination revealed tachycardia but was clinically clear  and heart sounds were normal. Systemic examination was unremarkable except for tenderness over his left calf  which was also slightly swollen.  This symptomatology  especially in light of Mr. Bolton's recent immobility and history of hypertension  suggests a potential for acute pulmonary embolism. Investigations including ECG  arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis  D-dimer tests and confirmatory imaging should be ordered to allow diagnosis and timely treatment of this potentially life-threatening condition.

Patient Information:  Name: Mr. James Smith Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Banker Smoking Status: Ex-smoker (quit 10 years ago) Alcohol consumption: Social drinker  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a known history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) following a hip replacement surgery 5 years ago. He is managed on daily tablets of aspirin 81 mg by his primary healthcare provider. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia controlled with statins and mild hypertension managed with lifestyle modifications. He has no known allergies.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of difficulty breathing that started a couple of hours ago while he was at home reading a book. He further reported that his shortness of breath has been accompanied by a sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep breaths. He also experienced an episode of fainting  prompting the visit to the hospital. He denies any history of cough  fever  or recent travels.  Intended Learning Outcomes:  Medical students should understand the presentation  risk factors  diagnosis  and management of an acute pulmonary embolism. They should appreciate the importance of history taking and physical examination in making a confident clinical diagnosis. Further  they should understand the role of appropriate investigations in confirming the diagnosis and ruling out other differential diagnoses for acute shortness of breath. Finally  they should be aware of the principles of acute and long-term management  including anticoagulation therapy. In this patient's case  they should discuss the risk-benefit of long-term aspirin therapy for DVT prophylaxis.   Teaching points and tips:   - Risk factors for pulmonary embolism (Barring any genetic predisposition  relevant risk factors in the patient include a previous DVT  recent surgery  age  and sedentary lifestyle). - Clinical manifestations of pulmonary embolism (sudden onset of shortness of breath  sharp stabbing chest pain  lightheadedness  possibly syncope). - Appreciation of the broad differential diagnoses in a patient with similar presenting complaints  including myocardial infarction  pneumothorax  pneumonia  and acute pericarditis. - Understanding the importance and urgency of obtaining imaging (like a CT pulmonary angiogram) to confirm the diagnosis of PE. - Understanding the principles of management including immediate anticoagulation with heparin  followed by long-term anticoagulation. - Awareness of potential complications if left untreated. - Importance of patient education in PE risk factors and symptoms  for early presentation and treatment.

Case Report:  Patient Details: Mr. A is a 63-year-old male  nondiabetic  nonsmoker  who presents to the Emergency Department (ED). He is an accountant by profession with no specific occupational hazards. He is not on any chronic medication.  Past Medical History: Mr. A has a past medical history of hypertension  controlled with daily medication for the past 15 years. He had a right total knee arthroplasty three weeks ago. He has no history of pulmonary embolism (PE) or deep vein thrombosis (DVT). He does not have a family history of PE  DVT  or bleeding disorders. He does not take any illicit drugs. His last routine check-up  two months ago  was unremarkable.   Chief Complaints: He came to the ED complaining of progressive  acute onset  sharp chest pain since the last 4 hours. The pain is localized in the middle third of the chest without radiation  increasing on inspiration  rated 6 on a pain scale from 0 to 10. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath and mild dizziness. He denies symptoms like fever  chill  cough  leg pain  swelling  abdominal pain  nausea  vomiting  or other gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient did not encounter any known allergens  nor did he have any physical exertion or emotional upset prior to the onset of the symptoms.   Although this is a hypothetical case  it is a classic representation of an acute pulmonary embolism presentation. The patient's recent surgery  along with continuous inactive position  places him at a high risk for this disorder. The medical students should be educated on the significance of immediate clinical evaluation using necessary imaging studies and lab tests in such a scenario to rule out life-threatening situations. Instituting appropriate therapy as rapidly as possible is needed to prevent morbidity and mortality.

Patient Information: Name:  Mrs. Davis Age:  60  Sex: Female  Race:  African American Occupation: Retired high school teacher Location: New York  Medical History: Mrs. Davis has a history of chronic hypertension which is usually controlled through medication (Lisinopril 20 mg daily). She has been overweight for the past 20 years but has no diagnosable metabolic issues like diabetes or hyperlipidemia. There is no smoking history or significant alcohol use and no history of surgeries or hospitalizations. Her mother died of a stroke at the age of 55 and her father of myocardial infarction at 60.  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Davis presented to the emergency department with sudden onset  sharp  pleuritic chest pain that woke her from sleep. The pain increases with deep breathing and does not radiate. Over the past week  she noticed a progressively increasing shortness of breath  difficulty in climbing stairs  and mild swelling in her right leg. She denies any recent travel  hospitalizations  or immobilization. The only additional symptom she noted was episodes of sweating and a feeling of ""impending doom"".   Physician's Query: The case is arranged in a manner to raise the suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism. Key points for the physician to explore would be her sudden-onset chest pain  shortness of breath  and unexplained right leg swelling.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Ms. Esther Jackson  an African-American female  aged 53  hailing from Hartford  Connecticut  Single  has been engaged in a sedentary occupation as an editor at a prominent publishing house for the past 25 years.  Past Medical History:   Ms. Jackson has been a smoker for 35 years  consuming a half pack daily  and has associated chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She also has a past medical history of controlled hypertension and a body mass index (BMI) of 27  indicating overweight. She reported a hereditary history of deep vein thrombosis  as her father had it a few years ago. She had undergone a total hip arthroplasty on the right side 10 days back to address her osteoarthritis.   Key Complaints:  Ms. Jackson visited the emergency department presenting with acute chest pain  which she described as 'sharp' and 'stabbing'  localized to the right side and exacerbated on deep inspiration. She also mentioned a sudden onset of dyspnea that has worsened over the past few days  along with an unexplained sense of anxiety. She additionally complained about occasional bouts of lightheadedness and palpitations  which started a week ago. The patient also reported that she noticed the swelling on her right lower leg (post-operatively) that had not subsided and lately  the area above the swollen region had become warm and reddish. She denied any fever  cough  hemoptysis  or syncope.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Jones Sex: Male Age: 68 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jones has a significant history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his right lower leg 8 years ago  which was managed with anticoagulants. He also has a history of hypertension  managed well with medication  and obesity with a BMI of 32. He was an active smoker but quit 5 years ago. There is no significant family history of venous thromboembolism.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Jones presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath that had developed over a few hours. He described a sharp  localized chest pain on the left side that becomes worse with deep breaths. He also reported a mild cough  but with no hemoptysis and has had episodes of light-headedness and rapid heart rate. He denies any leg pain or recent travel.  The objective is to train students to discern the symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism:   1. Shortness of breath: This often occurs suddenly and always gets worse with exertion. 2. Chest pain: Patient may experience pleuritic chest pain or chest discomfort that becomes worse when you take a deep breath and may also get worse with exertion. 3. Cough: This might produce bloody or blood-streaked sputum. 4. Tachycardia or rapid heart rate.  Immediate actions should include arranging for a CT pulmonary angiogram to confirm the diagnosis and blood tests to assess the heart's function. Anticoagulant treatment should also be initiated.  Clinical follow-up should include adjustment of anticoagulant dosage  monitoring recurrence of symptoms  and patient education regarding the prevention of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) and hence pulmonary embolism. The students should also be trained to advise such patients about weight loss and the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Rodriguez is a 68-year-old male who is a retired mechanic. He is a lifetime non-smoker  ethnically Hispanic  and has an average build with a body mass index (BMI) of 26 kg/m². He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has no known drug allergies.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez has a complex medical history. He has been monitored for high blood pressure for the past 15 years  which is partially managed by diuretic medication (hydrochlorothiazide). He is also diabetic and effectively controls his blood sugar levels via regular insulin injections and a prescribed diet. Additionally  he has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his right leg five years ago  for which he was treated with anticoagulants.  Key Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of dyspnea and mild chest pain that worsened on deep inspiration. He also reported a cough with bloody sputum but no other symptoms such as fever  chills  pain in the legs  or swelling. He noted feeling light-headed and anxious.  Summary: This case presents an elderly  sedentary male with relevant medical history  specifically DVT  hypertension  and diabetes  who has arrived at ED with acute onset of dyspnea  chest pain  and hemoptysis. The aim is to train medical students to think about a possible diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism in this context. The subsequent training should focus on the appropriate diagnostic workup  management options  and preventive measures for this condition.   Students should consider what immediate diagnostic tests are needed  the risk stratification of pulmonary embolism  the importance of ruling out other causes of the symptoms  and the management pathway for confirmed acute pulmonary embolism. The case also allows students to discuss factors contributing to Mr. Rodriguez's thrombotic risk  including his prior history of DVT  hypertension  diabetes  sedentary lifestyle  and ethnicity.

Patient Information:  - Demographics: 65-year-old Caucasian male - Occupation: Retired Banker - Marital Status: Married - Smoking status: Non-smoker - Alcohol: Occasional drinker  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension - Previous deep vein thrombosis - Familial history of cardiovascular disease - No history of surgery or recent trauma - No allergies reported  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents with sudden chest pain that started a few hours ago. The pain is sharp  localized on the right side  and intensifies with deep breaths. He also reports a feeling of breathlessness. Compared to his usual state  he appears anxious and sweaty.  He also mentions episodes of lightheadedness  feeling like he might faint  and faster than normal heart rate. The patient also mentions observed swelling and discomfort in his right calf over the past week but attributed it to possible strain during evening walks.   He denies any cough  fever  or recent travels.  The case should lead the students to consider acute pulmonary embolism  originating from a deep vein thrombosis in the leg  as a differential. The case can be used to teach the students about the clinical presentations  risk factors and the diagnostic approach to patients with symptoms indicative of acute pulmonary embolism. By the end of the case  the students should have a clear understanding of how to identify  diagnose  and manage this potentially life-threatening condition.

Patient Demographics: Gender: Female Age: 62 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Teacher Location: New Jersey  U.S.A  Past Medical History: - Chronic atrial fibrillation - Hypertension - History of deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  - Episodic migraines  Key complaints:  1) Sudden onset shortness of breath 2) Mild chest pain  3) Feeling of faintness  4) Past few days of leg swelling and discomfort in the left leg  Brief Case Report:  Ms. S is a 62-year-old retired teacher who presented to the emergency department complaining of acute shortness of breath which began few hours prior to her visit. In addition to breathlessness  the patient reported experiencing a mild chest pain that primarily presented as more of a discomfort than a severe pain. It worsened on deep inspiration. She also described a sudden onset of feeling faint. These symptoms came as a sudden bout while she was gardening.  Upon further inquiry  the patient revealed that she had been experiencing the symptoms of left leg swelling and discomfort for the past few days  but dismissed it as a result of her gardening activities. She did not report any recent trauma  period of immobilization  or long-distance travel.  Her past medical history is significant for chronic atrial fibrillation for which she takes daily medications. She also has a history of hypertension. She had an episode of DVT around three years ago  for which she was treated. Ms. S has episodic migraines which are generally well managed with lifestyle modifications and medications when needed.   She has no known allergies. Her social history reveals that she is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. Her family history is pertinent for vascular diseases  with her father having suffered from a stroke at the age of 79.  A detailed clinical examination and relevant investigations will be carried out to confirm the diagnosis  keeping in mind the critical possibility of an acute pulmonary embolism given the combination of her chronic atrial fibrillation  history of DVT  and current presentation.

Case Study: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Ms. A  a 68-year old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  non-smoker  and moderate alcohol consumer. She lives alone in a single-story house and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: Ms. A has a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago  managed with anticoagulation therapy.
