She also has hypertension that’s well controlled with medication and a past history of total knee replacement due to osteoarthritis. Family history reveals her father died from a massive pulmonary embolism.  Key Complaints: Ms. A was brought to the hospital emergency department for sudden onset  severe dyspnea and chest pain that started two hours before her arrival. The pain was described as sharp  localized predominantly to the left side  and it worsened upon deep breaths. She also reported a feeling of lightheadedness and an episode of hemoptysis. She denied any recent long travels or immobilization  neither any symptoms of lower limb swelling. The vital signs showed tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  a heart rate of 110 beats/min  blood pressure of 110/85 mmHg  a temperature of 98.6°F  and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air.  Initial Assessment: Physical exam noted tachypnea and tachycardia with reduced breath sounds in left lower lung fields without any murmurs. No leg edema was detected; the rest of the examination was unremarkable. D-dimer was ordered due to history and symptoms  which returned significantly elevated. A chest CT angiography was done considering the risk factor  symptoms  and the elevated d-dimer result.  Diagnosis: The chest CT angiography displayed a large acute central pulmonary embolism in the left pulmonary artery confirming the diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  For the complete case-based learning experience  include a further detailed case analysis with a focus on pathophysiology  risk factors  differential diagnosis  management  and prognosis of acute pulmonary embolism. Encourage students to discuss what they expect to find on investigations such as chest X-rays  ECG  and VQ scan  and to discuss how they would manage the patient.

Patient Information:   Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  who is recently retired. He's a non-smoker and moderately overweight with a BMI of 28. He works as a part-time professor in a local college.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left leg 5 years ago  managed with oral anticoagulants. He has a history of hypertension  well controlled on a low dose of amlodipine. He had been relatively fit until the DVT incident  with no history of pulmonary diseases. He also underwent a hernia repair surgery 2 years ago. His mother died at 72 due to myocardial infarction and his father had a stroke in his late 60s.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Johnson visits the emergency clinic and presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath that started a few hours before coming to the ER. He also complains of a sharp  stabbing chest pain on the right side that exacerbates with deep breathing. He admits to feeling lightheaded and has been increasingly fatigued over the past week or so. He also says that he has noticed his left leg being slightly swollen and warmer than usual.  On examination  he appears anxious and diaphoretic. His heart rate is high at 110 beats per minute  and his respirations are quick and shallow at 24 breaths per minute. Blood pressure is stable at 140/85mmHg. Pulse oximetry shows his oxygen saturation at 91% despite being on room air.  Given this information  medical students should think of potential diagnoses  including acute pulmonary embolism  especially considering his relevant past medical history of DVT and his new  severe symptoms. Clinical reasoning and subsequent management for his condition can then be discussed.

Patient Information:  Name : J.K. Age : 55 Sex : Female Marital status : Married Address : Portland  Oregon Occupation : Administrative Assistant  Patient History:   J.K. is a 55-year-old Caucasian female with a known history of obesity  varicose veins  and hypercholesterolemia. She had a total hip replacement surgery approximately two weeks prior. She is a former smoker  having quit five years prior with a 15 pack-year history. She is currently on rivaroxaban for prevention of deep vein thrombosis post-surgery.  Presenting Complaints:  1) She has been experiencing sudden onset shortness of breath and chest pain since morning  which is aggravated upon taking deep breaths.  2) She also mentioned suffering from a dry cough and episodes of hemoptysis.  3) She remarked having a mild fever over the past two days  which she initially dismissed as post-operative inflammation.  4) She has been feeling lightheaded and has had episodes of fainting.  5) Her family has also noted that her skin is paler than usual.  Assessments:  Given her recent history of major surgery  current use of a blood thinner  history of obesity and varicose veins  the symptoms suggest that this patient could potentially have an acute pulmonary embolism. The shortness of breath  chest pain  cough with hemoptysis  and hypotension (suggested by fainting and pallor) all point towards this diagnosis.  Next Steps:  1) Immediate attention to stabilize her condition should be taken.  2) Additional testing (D-Dimer  CT Pulmonary Angiography  blood tests for troponins etc) and specialist consults would be initiated on a priority basis to confirm the diagnosis.  3) Depending on test results  initiate appropriate treatment which may include anticoagulant therapy  thrombolysis or embolectomy.

Patient Details:  Name: James Harrington Age: 57 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Office Clerk   Medical History:  James is a chronic smoker with a 30 pack-year history. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes five years ago and hypertension about six months ago. Two weeks ago  he underwent orthopedic surgery on his right hip due to a fall.   Presenting Complaint:  James arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and light-headedness. The pain seemed to intensify when he tried to breathe deeply or cough. He also mentioned that he's been experiencing unusual signs of fatigue over the past week along with occasional dizzy spells. He's concerned about a possible respiratory problem relating to his long-term smoking.   Vitals on Admission:  BP: 138/89 mmHg Heart rate: 110 bpm  Respiratory Rate: 24 per minute Oxygen saturation: 92% on room air.   Hospital Admission: Considering the recent orthopedic surgery and his symptoms  there is a suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic tests - D-dimer test  compression ultrasound of the leg  CT pulmonary angiogram- are planned to confirm the diagnosis. He has been admitted for close observation and management. Multiple teams (Cardiology  Pulmonology) have been alerted for further assessment and management.

Case Study: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information Name: Mr. Keith Age: 63 Sex: Male Ethnicity: African-American Occupation: Retired banker   Past Medical History:  1. Diagnosed with hypertension ten years ago; managed with Lisinopril. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for seven years; on Metformin and diet control. 3. Had right proximal femur fracture due to a fall six weeks ago  managed with hip replacement surgery.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Keith presented to the ER with acute onset  pleuritic central chest pain that started suddenly around two hours ago while sitting and watching television. The pain radiated to the back. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath  palpitations  a dry cough without expectoration and mild dizziness. He denies any trauma  recent travel  or family history of similar episodes.   On examination  he appears anxious and in acute distress due to pain. The initial assessment showed a tachycardia (heart rate: 110 bpm)  a rise in blood pressure (160/90 mm Hg)  and an increased respiratory rate (22 breaths/min). His Oxygen saturation on room air was 90%. Auscultation revealed decreased breath sounds and mild crackles at the base of the right lung.  The subsequent detailed investigations should include an ECG  chest X-ray  heart biomarkers  D-Dimer  ABG  CT pulmonary angiography  and venous doppler of lower limbs to confirm the diagnosis and extend of the disease.   The learning outcomes from this case can focus on risk factors  clinical presentation  diagnostic strategies  and management of Acute Pulmonary Embolism. In particular  the case emphasizes how immobilization following hip surgery can result in deep vein thrombosis (a risk factor for pulmonary embolism) and the importance of prophylaxis measures post-surgery. This case study also illustrates the importance of immediate assessment and management  appropriate investigations  and the significance of multidisciplinary intervention in managing such complex patients.

Patient Case: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics:  Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  weighing 84 kilograms at a height of 178 centimeters. He is a retired accountant and lives with his wife in a suburban community. He has a history of occasional alcohol consumption and quit smoking 10 years ago after a 30-year pack history.  Past Medical History: Patient has a history of hypertension  well-controlled with Amlodipine 5mg daily for the past seven years. The patient underwent right total knee arthroplasty two weeks ago and has completed a short course of prophylactic low molecular-weight Heparin post-operatively until discharge 10 days ago. He does not have any known drug allergies. He has no history of lung disease or blood clotting disorders. His family history includes a father who died from a stroke and a mother who died from breast cancer.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Johnson presented to the hospital with a two-day history of progressive shortness of breath and sharp chest pain that is worse on deep inspiration. He also complained of feeling lightheaded  experiencing bouts of palpitations  and a recent episode of fainting. He states that the symptoms began suddenly while he was watching television at home. He denied any fever  cough  or hemoptysis. He also noted decreased mobility and prolonged periods of sitting due to postoperative knee pain. Prior to the onset of these symptoms  Mr. Johnson’s recovery was progressing routinely. His vital signs demonstrated a heart rate of 112/min  blood pressure of 140/90  respiratory rate of 24/min  and an oxygen saturation of 92% on room air.

Patient Information: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 years  Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Past Medical History: John is a retired mechanic with a significant history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He is a former smoker having quit 15 years ago but has an estimated 30 pack-year smoking history. He underwent a hip replacement surgery 6 months ago.     Presenting Complaints: John presents to the ER with a sudden onset of shortness of breath which began while gardening earlier in the day. He describes the feeling as an inability to draw in a complete breath and it was associated with a feeling of discomfort in the central chest. He also reports a brief episode of dizziness and feeling as if he might lose consciousness. He also complains of a sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep inhalation. He reports no cough  fever  recent travel  leg pain or swelling.  The case centers around ruling out or confirming a diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism  bearing in mind the patient's age  prior surgery  as well as his symptoms of shortness of breath  potential syncope  and pleuritic chest pain. These symptom characterizations are what might be expected from someone presenting with an acute pulmonary embolism. Medical students should tackle this case by running the necessary diagnostic tests such as ECG  D-Dimer  CT Pulmonary Angiography  and considering factors from the Wells or Geneva score to determine the probability of Pulmonary Embolism. The management procedure discussed should consider whether the patient is hemodynamically stable or unstable.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism   Patient Information: Mrs. Johanna D  57-year-old Caucasian female  presented in the emergency department. She is a lifelong resident of Cleveland  Ohio  works as a bank officer  and lives with her husband. Mrs. D smokes half a pack a day for the past 35 years and drinks alcohol occasionally. She has a sedentary lifestyle and is overweight with a BMI of 29.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypothyroidism  for which she is taking levothyroxine sodium. She also has essential hypertension controlled with lisinopril and a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) three years ago  for which she had been on warfarin therapy for 6 months. She has no known allergies.  Family history is notable for her father who passed away from a heart attack at the age of 65 and her mother who had a stroke and died at 70. She has five siblings  one of whom has cardiovascular disease.  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. D presented with a 2-day history of sudden onset  progressively worsening sharp  stabbing right-sided chest pain which became more intense on deep inspiration. She also complained of dyspnea  especially during exertion  and faint dizziness.   The night before her visit  she noticed an increased heart rate and a bout of unproductive cough. She did not have any symptoms of a cold  fever  or flu. There was no history of trauma or injury.  Recent History:  Patient recently traveled for a business trip which involved a long-haul flight of around 8 hours two weeks ago. She mentioned having leg swelling and pain in the right calf  which she ignored assuming it to be due to the long sitting duration during her flight. These symptoms now stand resolved.  This case report has been prepared to provide a comprehensive overview of acute pulmonary embolism  its risk factors  symptomatology  diagnostic procedures  and therapeutic interventions.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information:  - Mrs. Jane Smith - 65 years old  - White Female  - Retired Teacher   Past Medical History: - Mrs. Smith has a 10-year history of hypertension  controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). - She was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes five years ago and manages her condition with diet and Metformin. - She had a total knee arthroplasty (TKA) six weeks ago and her postoperative period was uneventful. - She has a BMI of 33 indicating obesity and a history of smoking  although she quit ten years ago. - She has no known allergies.  Chief Complaints: - Severe sudden-onset dyspnea - Chest pain - Palpitations - Cough with blood-streaked sputum - Felt light-headed and experienced intermittent episodes of confusion in the past two days  The above case highlights key risk factors associated with acute pulmonary embolism such as obesity  recent surgery (TKA)  and history of smoking. Symptoms presented are also classic for acute PE and should lead medical students to further investigations to confirm the diagnosis and initiate appropriate management.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  previously worked in an office setup with a sedentary lifestyle.   Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a notable past medical history which includes systemic hypertension for the last 15 years  well-controlled with medication  type 2 diabetes mellitus and recently 7 months ago undergone a total knee arthroplasty on the right side. He used to smoke for about 40 years but quit 10 years ago. There is no known history of any cardiac disease  asthma  tuberculosis  or any genetic disease.  Current Medications: - Lisinopril for hypertension - Metformin for diabetes - Over-the-counter multivitamins  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe reports to the emergency department with the primary complaint of sudden onset of shortness of breath which has been progressively worsening over the last few hours. He also mentions a sharp  stabbing chest pain  more pronounced on deep breathing. He also reports a subjective feeling of lightheadedness and increased heart rate. There is no associated cough  fever  or hemoptysis. He denies any recent trauma or significant stress. Review of systems is unremarkable.  Mr. Doe states he has been isolating at home for the past few weeks due to the COVID-19 pandemic  and has been more sedentary than usual. He also mentions he had a car trip that lasted about 8 hours 2 days ago.  In the light of the above information  students must suspect the possibility of acute pulmonary embolism as a differential diagnosis in regards to Mr. Doe's symptoms and medical history. Students should consider ordering diagnostic tests such as D-Dimer  CT Pulmonary Angiography  or a VQ scan  as well as evaluate for potential treatment options.   This case aims to exemplify how certain factors like lifestyle  past surgery  long car journeys  and history of smoking can predispose patients to the risk of developing acute pulmonary embolisms.

Case Report:  Patient Information: The patient is a 63-year-old African American female named Ms. Johnson. She is a non-smoker and has a history of occasional alcohol use. She has no known drug allergies and is on aspirin prophylaxis for cardiovascular disease.   Past Medical History: Ms. Johnson has type II diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  all of which are well-controlled with oral antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications. She has a history of recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT)  diagnosed 2 years ago and managed with anticoagulation therapy. Her family history reveals a sister who died of an undiagnosed pulmonary embolism.  Presenting Complaints: Upon the office consultation  Ms. Johnson complained of recent abrupt onset of shortness of breath for the past 2 days  acute chest pain that worsens on deep inspiration  recent onset of cough  and occasional hemoptysis. She also mentioned a rapid onset of fatigue and lightheaded feeling over the aforementioned time period. In the week leading up to her acute symptoms  she had traveled via plane from New York to California.  This case scenario is designed to focus on the diagnosis and management of acute pulmonary embolism  a life-threatening emergency. The student should consider Ms. Johnson's comprehensive history of DVT  recent long plane travel  and the classic symptoms of pulmonary embolism in their evaluations. Patients like Ms. Johnson are at high risk  hence the need for prompt evaluation and management. The case presents an opportunity to explore diagnostic tools (e.g.  D-dimer tests  CT pulmonary angiogram  ventilation-perfusion scan) and treatment options such as anticoagulation therapy and thrombolytic therapy.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Gender: Female Age: 59 Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Bank accountant   Past Medical History: - Obesity (BMI of 31) - Type II diabetes mellitus (on metformin) - Systemic Hypertension (controlled with Amlodipine) - History of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) 12 years prior - Ex-smoker (quit 10 years ago) - Sedentary lifestyle due to her desk job  Key Complaints: Ms. Smith presented to the emergency department with: 1. Acute onset sharp  stabbing chest pain in the left side of her chest that worsens with deep breathing 2. Shortness of breath that started suddenly a few hours prior to presentation 3. Palpitations  4. Feeling of unsteadiness and light-headedness 5. Diaphoresis  On questioning  she mentioned a recent long airplane flight (12 hours) that she took for a business trip two days prior to her symptom onset and had been seated for a majority of this time.    Ms. Smith denied symptoms of leg pain or swelling  cough  hemoptysis  or fever. However  she reported that her recent sedentary behavior  lengthy flight and past medical history of DVT may have contributed towards her current condition.  This case report is indicative of an acute pulmonary embolism scenario. Further evaluation such as physical examination  oxygen saturation  EKG  D-dimer  etc. are needed to confirm this cardiovascular emergency and immediate treatment should be initiated. Additionally  discussions can be initiated with medical students about prevention  risk factors  symptoms  and management of acute pulmonary embolism.

Case Report Description:  Patient Demographics:  Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  truck driver by profession  residing in the rural outskirts of Texas. He lives alone  and his closest family  a daughter  lives about 100 miles away. He is an ex-smoker and drinks alcohol moderately.   Past Medical History:  He has a history of uncontrolled hypertension and was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago  for which he takes medications irregularly. The patient had a minor stroke two years back. He also has a documented history of deep vein thrombosis when he was 60 and was advised lifestyle modifications and exercise to increase mobility during his long drives.  Key Complaints:  He presented to the emergency department with acute onset of difficulty in breathing  chest pain  and coughing up blood. The patient reports the pain in his chest is sharp and increases with deep breathing. He also reports observing swelling and mild pain in his left calf for the last two days  but he neglected it presuming it as a muscle pull due to driving.  Upon admission  his vitals were recorded as follows:  Blood Pressure: 155/95 mmHg   Heart Rate: 120/min  Respiratory Rate: 22 breaths per minute  Oxygen Saturation: 90% on room air.  Fresh investigations and diagnostic procedures are to be carried out to confirm the suspicion of an acute pulmonary embolism. This case gives a classic presentation of a high-risk profile patient with previous embolism history presenting with primary signs and symptoms of a pulmonary embolism  with the presence of potential triggers for deep vein thrombosis. Detailed patient history is crucial in such cases for early diagnosis and treatment to prevent fatality.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. AB is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired from active worklife with an occupation history of driving long distances.  Past Medical History: He is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history. He has been diagnosed with hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for which he is under medication (beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and bronchodilators). He also has a history of a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) episode 5 years back  secondary to prolonged immobilization owing to a hip fracture. His BMI is 27  suggesting he is overweight.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. AB presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of breathlessness  which started about two hours prior to admission. He also reported experiencing sharp  stabbing chest pain worsening on inspiration. He mentioned feeling lightheaded and experiencing a bout of coughing up blood-streaked sputum earlier in the day.  The case is aimed at further exploration of the patient's condition- identifying key clinical features  leveraging diagnostic tests for condition confirmation (like d-dimer  CT pulmonary angiography  etc.)  offering appropriate treatment methods (oxygen therapy  anticoagulation therapy)  and discussing preventive measures and follow-up plan for patients with acute pulmonary embolism diagnosis.  The given case compels medical students to delve into acute pulmonary embolism's topic  considering risk factors like age  previous DVT history  COPD  and obesity which are all relevant to this patient. This case also provides students an opportunity to study the ideal management and complications of such a medical scenario.  Overall  this case encourages medical students to adopt a comprehensive approach in managing patients presenting with breathlessness and chest pain  to differentially diagnose pulmonary embolism from similar presenting conditions  and to understand the significance of medical history and risk factors in diagnosing conditions.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Mr. Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a height of 6’1” and a weight of 210 lbs  was brought in by his daughter. He is a retired construction worker and is currently living with his wife. He is a habitual smoker  with a history of 1 pack per day for the past 40 years. He abstains from alcohol and illicit drug use. His current lifestyle is sedentary  and he enjoys spending his retirement reading and woodworking.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both being managed by lifestyle modifications and regular medication. He was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) post-knee surgery 2 years ago. He was treated with anticoagulant therapy for 3 months following surgery. He has no history of cardiac disease or pulmonary disorders  no known drug allergies  and no family history of clotting disorders or coronary artery disease.  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith primarily presented with sudden onset of dyspnea  mild chest discomfort most noticeable on deep breathing  and few episodes of hemoptysis. He also complained of recent nonspecific symptoms including malaise  mild cough  and unilateral leg swelling. He denied any recent travel  prolonged immobility  or signs of infection. Upon further inquiry  he admitted to intermittently skipping his blood pressure medication. He has no fever  no recent surgeries or hospitalizations and reports no other complaints such as vertigo  palpitations  angina  or syncope.  The given case is intended not only towards developing students’ clinical expertise but also recognizing the importance of adherence to prescribed medication in chronic conditions.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired  previous occupation - Office Worker  Past Medical History: • Hypertensive for past 7 years  currently taking Losartan. • Type 2 Diabetic Mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago  managing with Metformin. • History of obesity with current BMI of 32. • Former Smoker: Smoked 1 pack/day for 25 years  quit smoking 10 years ago. • History of DVT in left lower extremity 3 years ago  resolved after treatment with rivaroxaban. • Has a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Chief Complaints: • Sudden onset of shortness of breath at rest  started 24 hours ago. • Also complains of a sharp  constant chest pain radiating to the back  started around the same time. • Intermittent dry cough. • Mild dizziness on exertion.  On careful questioning  it was noted that Mr. Doe recently travelled overseas  involving a long  non-stop flight for 9 hours  on the return journey which was a week ago. He denies any recent surgery  trauma  malignancy  or use of oral contraceptives. He does confirm the recent lack of mobility due to the overseas travel.   This clinical case is designed to educate medical students about Acute Pulmonary Embolism's key features  including understanding the risk factors (previous history of DVT  prolonged immobilization  smoking  obesity)  recognizing typical clinical manifestations (acute onset shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain)  and highlighting the condition's life-threatening nature. Proper understanding of these features will guide the students in prompt recognition and swift initiation of the correct diagnostic and therapeutic pathways.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Patient is a 62-year-old white male  non-smoker  and moderate alcoholic.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 10-year history of well-controlled hypertension. The patient has no known allergies. He also reported a hip replacement surgery 2 months ago and was put on bed rest during that period.  Chief Complaint: The patient admitted to the emergency department (ED) with sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain  mostly on the right side  which came on after a walk. This pain gets worse on deep inspiration. Patient also reported a history of increasing shortness of breath and leg swelling for the past week. The patient has a mild cough with occasional pink frothy sputum.  Vital signs on arrival:  - Heart rate: 118 beats/minute - Blood pressure: 100/60 mmHg - Respiratory rate: 22 breaths/minute and labored - Oxygen saturation: 89% on room air  Physical Examination: Physical examination revealed a well-built male who was in distress due to pain. He was found to have tachypnea and tachycardia. His lungs showed decreased breath sounds on the right lower side. There was also noticeable swelling and tenderness on examination of the right calf.  Preliminary Diagnosis: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Teaching Point: This is a classic case of acute pulmonary embolism. Risk factors include his recent orthopedic surgery  prolonged immobilization  and patient's age. Symptoms such as sudden onset chest pain  tachypnea  pink frothy sputum signal this condition  and physical examination findings confirm the need for immediate diagnostic studies (like D-dimer test  CT scan  etc.) and treatment. A situation like this requires rapid diagnosis and treatment to prevent fatal complications. It is also an opportunity to discuss the importance of preventive measures (like early mobilization  use of prophylactic anticoagulants) in patients at risk of developing thromboembolic diseases.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Gender: Female Age: 65 years old Race: Caucasian  Past Medical History: This patient is known to have type II diabetes mellitus  adequately managed with metformin. She also has a past history of venous thromboembolism (VTE) five years ago after undergoing knee replacement surgery. There is a history of hormone replacement therapy for menopausal symptoms  which she discontinued after her first VTE. Currently on aspirin for primary prophylaxis of cardiovascular diseases. No history of smoking or alcohol abuse.  Chief Complaints: The patient came to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden onset shortness of breath starting 4 hours before presentation. She also reported palpitations and mild substernal chest pain which she described as 'sharp and stabbing' in nature. She also mentioned that her breathing difficulty escalates upon exerting herself. She denies any cough  fever  or hemoptysis. Also reported a recent prolonged car travel (8 hours) for a family reunion a week ago.      The case points towards shortness of breath and chest pain  extensively significant in the case of acute pulmonary embolism. The history of venous thrombosis  current aspirin intake  and recent prolonged immobility further strengthens the possibility. It is important to follow up with immediate assessments like ECG  D-dimer test  and radiographic findings to confirm the diagnosis and decide on the management.

Patient Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information:  A 67-year-old female  African American.  Past Medical History:  The patient has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication. She is also a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago. The patient underwent a total knee replacement 6 days ago and was discharged two days later. She lives alone and is normally active  with no history of vascular disease.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that worsens upon deep inhalation. She also reports experiencing an abrupt onset of dizziness and has a faint episode at home. The patient mentions that she has had swelling in her operated leg since her surgery. However  she missed follow-up appointments due to her home being in a remote location.  Please have discussions with the students centering on the need for a high index of suspicion for pulmonary embolism in post-surgical patients presenting with dyspnea  chest pain  and unilateral leg edema. The case should strengthen knowledge of how to diagnose PE through the use of risk stratification tools  clinical findings  D-dimer  computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA)  and echocardiography as necessary. The management of acute PE emphases should be prompt anticoagulation with adjustment based on risk stratification and further intervention if required.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Gender: Female Age: 74 years Race: Hispanic Occupation: Retired teacher Living Situation: Lives with husband in a two-story house  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and has been maintained on warfarin therapy for anticoagulation. The patient is post-menopausal with no history of hormone replacement therapy. She is also diagnosed with hypertension controlled by medication  previously had a cholecystectomy for gallstones  and is non-diabetic. Her surgical history includes a total knee replacement 7 years ago. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago. There is no known family history of thromboembolic disease or coagulation disorders.  Key Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of acute dyspnea  with a reported onset of about 24 hours prior. She also complains of mild retrosternal chest pain  described as a heavy sensation  but reports no pain on deep inhalation. The pain started approximately the same time as the dyspnea. Additionally  she expressed feelings of being unusually fatigued accompanied by lightheadedness. She denied any cough  recent travel  periods of prolonged immobility  sinus symptoms  fever  sore throat  or leg swelling. She also reports minor unsteadiness on her feet for about the same duration. The patient confirms that she has been taking her medications regularly and denies any recent illnesses or changes in her medical condition.    It’s important to note the patient's risk factors  such as long-term anticoagulant use (with potential over/under-coagulation)  age  past surgery  chronic atrial fibrillation  and hypertension. It’s vital to consider her symptoms within the context of her medical history to guide on further examination and diagnostic tests pertinent to acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Information: Ms. Janet Johnson  65-year-old Caucasian female  retired teacher  Past Medical History: Hypertension  Obesity (BMI 32)  Non-smoker  Non-drinker; recent hip arthroplasty surgery four weeks ago   Presenting Complaint: Janet comes to the clinic with a 24-hour history of sudden onset shortness of breath which has been progressively worsening. She also mentions a sharp  stabbing chest pain that is worse on deep inspiration. There is no associated cough  fever  or hemoptysis.  Review of Systems: Negative for limb symptoms such as pain  swelling  redness or warmth. Positive for feelings of anxiety and mild lightheadedness. No recent travel  no family history of clotting disorders.  Physical Examination: Janet appears in moderate respiratory distress. Vital signs reveal tachypnea (RR: 23)  tachycardia (HR: 110 bpm)  BP: 140/85mmHg  and SpO2: 92% on room air. Chest examination demonstrated clear auscultation bilaterally  heart sounds were normal with no murmurs. Lower extremity examination does not show any signs of deep vein thrombosis (no swelling  erythema or calf tenderness).  Note that this training case is concise and facilitates understanding about important points in the diagnostic journey of acute pulmonary embolism  including potential predisposing factors (e.g.  recent surgery  obesity)  relevant presenting complaints (e.g.  sudden onset shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  signs of anxiety as clinical manifestation of hypoxia)  and critical physical examination findings (e.g.  tachycardia  tachypnea  low oxygen saturation).

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics:  Patient is a 52-year old Caucasian female  non-smoker  overweight with a BMI of 31. The patient works as a corporate lawyer and leads a sedentary lifestyle. No known allergies.  Past Medical History: The patient was previously healthy with no chronic conditions. Family history suggests a genetic predisposition to coagulopathy - her mother had deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and her father suffered from stroke. No previous surgeries. Only medication taken is oral contraceptive. Regular mammograms have all been normal.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents with sudden onset of difficulty in breathing or dyspnea  chest pain that worsens with deep breaths  dizziness  and mild hemoptysis. The symptoms began acutely a few hours prior to her visit to the Emergency Department. She reports feeling anxious due to her breathing difficulty. She also reports a minor recent leg injury from a fall  which resulted in an immobilized left leg due to soft tissue injury.  This case should stimulate discussion on risk factors for Pulmonary Embolism such as obesity  sedentary lifestyle  genetic predisposition  oral contraceptive use  injury leading to immobilization  symptoms such as unexplained dyspnea  chest pain  and hemoptysis. The case should also highlight the diagnostic pathways including D-dimer testing  V/Q imaging  and CTPA as well as treatment options for acute pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: - Name: Mr. Smith - Age: 64 years - Gender: Male - Race: African American - Occupation: Retired engineer - Residence: Urban area  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a recorded history of high blood pressure  which has been managed for the last 20 years with medication. He also suffered a heart attack eight years prior and has been on aspirin therapy since. He has a 45 pack-year history of smoking but quit ten years ago after his heart attack. Notably  Mr. Smith also underwent a total hip replacement surgery six weeks prior following a fall at home. He is currently taking antihypertensive medication and aspirin therapy as prescribed. He also completed three weeks of post-operative prophylactic anticoagulation therapy with enoxaparin.  Complaints and Symptoms: Mr. Smith arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of acute shortness of breath that has been progressively worsening over the last few hours. He also mentioned a feeling of heaviness and tightness in his chest along with a mild  persistent cough. On further probing  he recalled experiencing sudden sharp  stabbing pain on deep breathing. There was no record of fever  cough with expectoration  chest trauma or any allergies.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  Mr. Smith was found to be tachypneic (rapid breathing) and tachycardic (increased heart rate)  although his blood pressure was within normal limits. Upon auscultation  decreased breath sounds were found in the right lower lobe of the lung with associated increased heart sounds heard over the second left intercostal space (pulmonic area) of the chest wall.  Through this training case  medical students are supposed to recognize symptoms  risk factors and physical examination findings that point towards a possible diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism. They should understand the importance of immediate further evaluation  including use of diagnostic tests such as a D-dimer test  computed tomography pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) or ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) scan  with an aim to confirm the diagnosis and initiate prompt management.

Patient Information: Ms. L  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  retired attorney  Presenting Complaint: The patient visited the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain particularly upon deep breathing  light-headedness and cough producing bloody mucus.  Past Medical History: Mrs. L is a former smoker and has a medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and estrogen-based hormone replacement therapy (HRT). She recently underwent arthroplasty of her right knee following a fall at home 6 weeks ago. She lives by herself and has no known allergies. She is mobile with help of walker.  Medication: Maintenance includes a bronchodilator for her COPD and an estrogen-based hormone replacement therapy treatment.  Social History: Ms. L quit smoking 15 years ago after a 30-year pack-a-day habit. She consumes alcohol socially  about 1-2 units once a week. She has no history of recreational drug use.   Family History: Her mother died of breast cancer at the age of 74 and father had a stroke at the age of 68.  Review of Systems: Patient reported a minor swelling and pain in her right calf over the past week which she attributed to 'overdoing it' with her physical therapy exercises. She reiterates her distress over unexpected breathlessness scaling up to 8 on a pain scale of 10  which was preceded by a bout of coughing.    Preliminary Diagnosis: Based on the patient's history and current symptoms  acute pulmonary embolism should be first on the differential diagnosis list  considering the recent mobility-limiting surgery  her history of COPD  advanced age  HRT and previous smoking status.  This case will help students understand the importance of recognizing the signs and symptoms of an acute pulmonary embolism  particularly in patients with various risk factors  and how to execute appropriate management to reduce mortality and enhance the quality of life. The students will learn how to apply their theoretical knowledge of pathophysiology  pharmacology  and clinical medicine in a practical context.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: Name: Patient X Age: 63 years Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Marital Status: Married  3 children Living: Lives with husband Smoking History: Non-smoker Alcohol History: Social drinker  one glass of wine with dinner Family History: Grandfather suffered from Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT)  Past Medical History: Patient X has a history of hypertension  moderately controlled with Amlodipine 5mg once daily. She also has a history of hyperlipidemia  for which she takes Atorvastatin 20mg nightly. She had a total knee arthroplasty on right knee 6 weeks ago and completed her course of post-surgical prophylactic anticoagulation two weeks ago.  The patient does not have any history of heart disease  stroke  diabetes  DVT  or pulmonary embolism (PE). She has no known allergies. Her surgical history is significant for a caesarean section 30 years ago  a cholecystectomy 10 years ago  and most recently  a knee replacement surgery.  Key Complaints: Patient X presents to the emergency department via ambulance with a sharp stabbing 9/10 chest pain that radiates to her back since morning  as well as persistent shortness of breath that started suddenly while she was gardening. She denies cough  fevers  chills  dizziness  weight loss  or night sweats. However  she mentions feeling lightheaded and a recent episode of unexplained excessive sweating. She mentions that her mother is currently in hospital recovering from hip surgery and she wonders whether her recent stress could be causing her symptoms.   On arrival  patient appeared distressed  tachypneic  and diaphoretic. Initial vital signs revealed blood pressure of 145/95  heart rate of 110  respiratory rate of 26  temperature 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation was 90% on room air.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Mrs. Isabel Johnson  aged 72  Caucasian female. She is a retired school teacher  lives with her husband in the suburbs of Chicago. She is a non-smoker but has a history of occasional alcohol consumption. Mrs. Johnson is obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 32.   Past Medical History: • In 2006  Mrs. Johnson was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus for which she has been under oral medications • In 2009  she underwent a total knee replacement surgery on her right knee due to severe osteoarthritis. • She was also diagnosed with hypertension in 2015. • She has a family history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stroke. • Also  she has a history of multiple long distance air-travel as she frequently visits her children who live abroad.  Key complaints: Mrs. Johnson presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden onset of sharp  stabbing chest pain which started 2 hours back. She also complains of shortness of breath  palpitations  and light-headedness. She also mentions that she developed swelling in her right calf which started a week ago after a 10-hour flight  but she attributed it to her long journey and knee arthritis.   The symptoms suggest the possibility of an acute pulmonary embolism. Further investigation is required to confirm the diagnosis and plan a suitable treatment strategy  keeping her diabetes and hypertension in consideration.

Patient Details: Gender: Female Age: 63 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired School Teacher  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation for which she has been prescribed oral anticoagulation (Warfarin)  but her adherence is inconsistent. She also has a history of hypertension managed on Lisinopril. She is a former smoker with a pack-a-day habit for 30 years  but quit 3 years prior. There is no history of diabetes  cancer or previous thromboembolic disease.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents with sudden onset dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain  which occurred at rest. The symptoms started two hours ago and she reported that they are getting progressively worse. She adds that she has experienced dizziness and felt faint just prior to the onset of these symptoms. She also mentions experiencing recurrent episodes of light-headedness and palpitations over the last two weeks.  Based on her presenting complaints  the medical students must then work through a differential diagnosis with special focus on acute pulmonary embolism considering her medical history and current symptoms. Clinical reasoning questions could prompt students to interpret further investigations  including blood tests  EKG  arterial blood gases  D-dimer tests and imaging  apply knowledge of risk factors for PE  and weigh the need for immediate treatment versus further diagnostic tests. The case should also emphasize management strategies including anticoagulation and education about medication adherence.

Patient Information:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male has presented to the emergency department.  Chief Complaints:  The patient complains of sudden-onset shortness of breath  sharp chest pain worsened by deep breathing  dizziness  and palpitations that began earlier in the day.  History of Present Illness:  The patient reports that the symptoms have increased progressively throughout the day. He has never experienced symptoms like these before and says they started suddenly  shortly after getting out of bed this morning.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are managed with lifestyle modifications and medications (hydrochlorothiazide and simvastatin). He underwent a total knee replacement surgery three weeks ago and has been largely immobile post-surgery. He has no known allergies. He quit smoking ten years ago and consumes alcohol socially. The patient denies any illicit drug usage.  Family History:  His father succumbed to myocardial infarction at age 70  and his mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has two adult children in good health.  Social History:  The patient is a retired engineer  lives with his wife  and their home setting involves steps.   Review of Systems:  Constitutional: Negative for fever or weight loss. Cardiovascular: Positive for palpitations and chest pain. Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath. Gastrointestinal: Negative for nausea  vomiting  or abdominal pain. Musculoskeletal: Negative for recent trauma or injury. Neurological: Negative for headache or syncope  but positive for dizziness.  This case is suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  particularly due to his history of recent orthopedic surgery and prolonged immobilization that are significant risk factors for deep vein thrombosis  which might have led to a PE.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. John  a 65-year-old male of Caucasian descent  presented to the Emergency Department. He is a retired university professor  non-smoker  from an urban setting with a BMI of 28.  Past Medical History: Mr. John's background includes a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension  for which he is on metformin and lisinopril. He underwent knee replacement surgery two weeks prior to this presentation. He has no known drug allergies.  Chief Complaint: Mr. John reports an acute onset of severe  unrelenting shortness of breath starting 2 hours ago. He also complains of a sharp  stabbing chest pain that gets worse with deep breaths. He comments that he's never experienced such a rapid and alarming onset of breathlessness. There's no history of fever  cough  hemoptysis  syncope  or palpitations.  Physical Examination and Vital Signs: On examination  Mr. John appears anxious and restless  is profusely sweating  and is breathing rapidly. His vital signs show a heart rate of 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 26 breaths/min  blood pressure of 130/89 mmHg  oxygen saturation of 88% on room air  and a body temperature of 98.6 °F (37 °C).  This case could be an instance of acute pulmonary embolism  potentially resulting from a deep vein thrombosis following his recent knee surgery  a complication that his immobility might have precipitated. The medical student should use this case to review the risk factors  clinical presentation  diagnostic process  and management of acute pulmonary embolism.

Case: Patient's initial: Mr. A Sex: Male Age: 64 years  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired software engineer   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. A presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath which had been progressively getting worse over the last 4-5 hours. Additionally  he reported experiencing a sharp chest pain  which was aggravated with deep breathing. He also noted a faint-headedness and unexplained episodes of sweating.  Past Medical History: The patient is a known case of hypertensive heart disease and had been prescribed antihypertensives 3 years ago. Smoking history is significant  with a pack-a-day habit for more than 35 years  but reports he quit smoking 5 years ago. He also mentioned about having a sedentary lifestyle post-retirement. There was a surgical history of hip replacement 6 weeks ago followed by intermittent bed rest. His father died of stroke at 67 and his sister is being treated for deep vein thrombosis. He denies any known allergies.   Medication: Tablet Amlodipine 5 mg once daily for hypertension.  Family History:  Father had a history of stroke and sibling with deep vein thrombosis.  Social History:  Retired software engineer with significant smoking history  currently non-smoker. No reported alcohol or drug misuse. Sedentary lifestyle post-retirement.   This case is specially designed to give a sense of potentially life-threatening  acute medical condition namely acute pulmonary embolism. Key takeawa is to make students vigilant of risk factors and precipitants  such as recent surgery  prolonged bed rest  a family history of venous thromboembolism  older age  hypertension  smoking history  and physical inactivity.

Patient Information: Mr. Allen Smith  Male  67-years-old  Caucasian  Retired English Teacher.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith has approached the Emergency Department with complaints of sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain  and mild cough. The chest pain exacerbates during deep breaths. He had two episodes of fainting in the past week.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history for hypertension under control with medication  and smoking about 1 pack/day for the last 40 years. He underwent a hip replacement surgery 6 weeks ago. He has no known allergies  no known drug intolerances.   Family History: Both his parents had cardiovascular illnesses  with his father having a heart attack at the age of 57 and his mother  frequent bouts of angina.   Social History: Mr. Smith is a widower who lives alone after retirement. He was a regular smoker for many years and has limited physical activity since his hip replacement.  Current Medications: Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension.  Summary: This case presents Mr. Smith  a 67-year-old male with key complaints of acute onset dyspnea  chest pain that intensifies during deep breath  fainting spells  and a notable history of recent hospitalization for hip replacement. His medical history also includes controlled hypertension and long-term smoking history  placing him at a higher risk for cardiovascular diseases.   The combination of his symptoms  personal medical history  and family history should heighten the index of suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic procedures should proceed to confirm the diagnosis  assess the severity  and develop an appropriate management plan.

Subject: Acute Pulmonary Embolism Case Study  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 58 Gender: Male Occupation: Corporate Executive Race: Caucasian  Past Medical History: 1. Ex-smoker (approx. 25 pack-years; quit 5 years ago) 2. Hypertension (well-managed by medication) 3. Type 2 Diabetes (managed through a combination of diet  exercise  and medication) 4. Family history of cardiovascular diseases 5. Deep Vein Thrombosis (hospitalized 2 years ago)  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Doe enters the emergency department  reporting a sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that gets worse on deep inhalation. He describes the pain as 'stabbing'  localized to the left side of his chest. He also mentions experiencing lightheadedness and a 'feeling of doom'.   Accompanying Symptoms: He has had a dry cough without chest pain and recalls having a swollen  painful left calf about a week ago  which he dismissed as muscle strain due to exercise. His wife mentions that he seemed to be more fatigued than usual over the past couple of days but they attributed it to work stress.  Vitals on arrival: 1. BP: 155/90 mmHg 2. Heart rate: 110 bpm 3. Respiration rate: 22 breaths/min 4. Oxygen saturation: 92% on room air  Given his past medical history  current symptoms  distress and vitals  your suspicion is an acute pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male. He and his wife recently moved to Florida after he retired. His wife reports that he has been generally healthy and active  enjoying golf and regular walking. He has never smoked  drinks alcohol occasionally  and does not use any illicit substances. He is currently not taking any regular medication.  Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which has been well controlled without medication. His family history revealed that his father died of a heart attack at the age of 70  and his mother has great blood pressure at the age of 89. He underwent a routine colonoscopy five years ago  which was normal. He has been noted to have a slightly elevated cholesterol in the past but has been managed conservatively due to his active lifestyle.  Key Complaints: The patient presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with sudden onset dyspnea and mild pleuritic chest pain started in the morning  while he was taking a stroll around his neighborhood. Accompanying symptoms include light-headedness  rapid heart rate  and excessive sweating.   He noticed his symptoms got worse over a couple of hours  especially the shortness of breath  to the point where he felt he was unable to carry on with his regular walk. He denied any other symptoms  including fever  cough  sputum production  hemoptysis  wheezing  leg swelling  or recent long-distance travel.  He drove himself to the ED when his symptoms did not improve after resting at home. Upon presentation  he did not appear in acute distress but was anxious about his symptoms.   In conclusion  given the sudden onset of dyspnea  pleuritic chest pain and risk factor of hypertension  acute pulmonary embolism should be considered and immediate further evaluations should be arranged.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: Name: Mr. A Sex: Male Age: 62 years Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaint: The patient was presented to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  which had been persistent for the past few hours. He also reports having sharp  localized chest pain  worsened by deep breathing or coughing. He also remarked that he noticed his heart racing a couple of times that day.  Medical History: Mr. A is an ex-smoker and has been diagnosed with hypertension under control with medication (Ramipril) for nine years. About 4 years ago  Mr. A suffered a major stroke resulting in perennial weakness of the right side of his body. Since then  his mobility has been limited  often requiring a wheelchair for movement. The patient also has a familial history of coagulation disorders (mother with Factor V Leiden).  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. A appeared to be in distress due to difficulty breathing. His heart rate was 115 beats per minute  blood pressure: 140/90 mm Hg  respiratory rate: 22 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 89% on room air. The chest examination revealed tachycardia with no added sounds. The rest of the examination was unremarkable  with no leg swelling or tenderness noticed.  This clinical scenario  therefore  outlines the case of a patient showing symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism that the medical students must reason through  basing their hypotheses on the patient's complaints  past medical history  risk factors  and the initial findings of the physical examination. The case also provides students the opportunity to unveil the proper emergency treatment approach and management of acute pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Patient Identification: 72-year-old African American man  Past Medical History: - Hypertension (managed with Metoprolol 50mg daily for the last 10 years) - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for 10 years (on Metformin 1000mg twice daily) - Hyperlipidemia (on Atorvastatin 40mg daily) - Ex-smoker (quit 5 years ago  smoked pack per day for 30 years) - Had a right hip replacement surgery four weeks ago due to arthritis and currently undergoing physiotherapy sessions.   Presenting Complaints: Over the past two days  the patient experienced sudden onset of sharp  localized right-sided chest pain. The pain is severe  rated as 8 on a scale of 10  increasing with deep breathing and occasionally radiating to the right arm. Associated symptoms include episodes of palpitations  light-headedness  and persisting shortness of breath even while at rest. The mentioned symptoms were combined with cold  clammy skin  fatigue  and a minor bout of anxiety. He denies any cough  fever  hemoptysis  or recent infections.  Upon examination  he was found to be in respiratory distress with a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  with an oxygen saturation of 89% on room air. His pulse rate was 110 beats per minute  and blood pressure was 140/90 mmHg.   Please consider this case as an example of acute pulmonary embolism (PE). Key points to discuss would include early vigilance for symptoms of PE in patients who have major risk factors such as recent surgery  immobility  advanced age  hypertension  and history of smoking. Discussion on immediate management  stable versus unstable PE  and long-term thromboprophylaxis would also be safe venues to explore in this case.   This case could help to train medical students in making a quick assessment  recognizing high-risk patients  rational decision-making  and effective planning for immediate and long-distance medical care.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. James Brown  a 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Brown has a history of hypertension managed with Lisinopril. He recently underwent a total right hip replacement two months ago. He has moderate obesity (BMI 30) and a 15-year history of smoking  though he quit five years ago. He has no known allergies.  Key Complaints: Mr. Brown presented to the emergency department reporting an acute onset of shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and chest pain that began a few hours prior to presentation. The chest pain was described as sharp and stabbing  generally worsening with deep inspiration. He denied having a cough but mentioned he has felt a bit more fatigued than usual over the past week  which he attributed initially to his surgery recovery.  The challenge faced when treating Mr. Brown is recognizing that his symptoms of breathlessness  chest pain  and fatigue may be frequently encountered in various conditions  but his recent hip surgery and his past history of smoking are risk factors that increase his chances of having an acute pulmonary embolism (PE).+

Case Report  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female  retired school teacher  residing in an urban neighborhood. She is a current smoker with a 40-pack year smoking history and is also moderately overweight.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of varicose veins and had undergone knee joint replacement surgery four weeks ago. She has also been diagnosed with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both of which are being managed through medication. Her family history is significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with her mother having suffered from the condition. She has no known drug allergies.  Key Complaints: The patient presents with a sudden onset of shortness of breath that started a few hours ago. She describes it as feeling like she cannot get enough air and it is worse when she is trying to walk. She also reports a sharp  stabbing pain in the chest that is exacerbated by deep breathing. She has noticed rapid heart palpitations and is feeling lightheadedness. She has also been suffering from a dry cough.  She denies having any recent travel history or prolonged immobilization. She also denies having any fever  wheezing  hemoptysis  or leg swelling. Other than the knee joint replacement surgery  she hasn't undergone any recent surgery or hospitalization. She further reports that her surgical wound has healed completely and there are no signs of infection or complications. She is currently living alone and is fairly independent in her daily activities.  The major concern with this patient is her risk of pulmonary embolism due to her previous surgery  her smoking habit  and her family history of DVT. This case presents an opportunity to educate medical students about the risk factors  preventive measures  symptoms  diagnosis  and management of pulmonary embolism.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old male named Mr. Thompson. He is a retired professor and a current smoker with a pack history of 30 years. He is Caucasian and lives with his wife in a suburban area.  Past medical history: Mr. Thompson has type 2 diabetes and hypertension  both well-controlled with medication. He also has a documented history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) around four years ago  for which he underwent treatment with anticoagulants. His surgery history includes a total hip replacement two months ago.  Current Complaint: Mr. Thompson presents with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  which started an hour ago. He describes the shortness of breath as feeling ""unable to catch his breath"". He has also complained about moderate to severe chest pain that is sharp and increases with deep breathing. He has mild lightheadedness and fainting once this morning before coming to the hospital.  Presentation: On examination  Mr. Thompson appeared anxious and was breathing rapidly. His blood pressure was 145/90 mm of Hg  pulse 98 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Oxygen saturation was measured at 93% on room air.  Given the patient's past medical history of DVT and recent orthopedic surgery  as well as his current symptoms  there is a high clinical suspicion of acute pulmonary embolism.  This case invites students to consider issues such as:  - Principals of DVT and Pulmonary Embolism's pathophysiology  including risk factors and prevalence - Typical and atypical symptomatology of acute pulmonary embolism - Suitable diagnostic tests for Mr. Thompson's situation - Current treatment options  including the use of anticoagulants and interventions - The importance of patient education  including smoking cessation  exercise regime  and medication adherence.      The case will also provide an opportunity to practice clinical reasoning skill  develop differential diagnosis  and discuss the prevention strategies for patients at risk of developing pulmonary embolism.

Case Report:  Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics:  - Name: Pseudonym/Initial (e.g. Mr. P) - Age: 72 - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Engineer - Ethnicity: Caucasian - BMI: 30 (Obese)  Past Medical History:  - Non-insulin Dependent Diabetes Mellitus (Type 2) - Hypertension - Hyperlipidemia - Ex-Smoker  quit 10 years ago - Previous Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) 7 years ago - Knee replacement surgery 2 weeks ago  Present Complaints:  - Sudden onset of shortness of breath (dyspnea) worsening over last 2 hours - Chest pain exacerbated on deep inspiration (Pleuritic chest pain) - Mild hemoptysis  - Tachycardia - Recent onset of fatigue and lightheadedness - Mild swollen right leg but less than left (previous knee surgery)  Note: Mr. P's knee recovery had been progressing well and he had been ambulating well with a walking aid. His current symptoms started abruptly  without any changes to activity levels or other identifiable causes. He has no fever  cough or recent illnesses. His surgical incision site shows no signs of infection. His family history is pertinent for a brother who had a DVT after a long-haul flight  and a father who died of a massive pulmonary embolism (PE) at the age of 65.  Primary Impression: Acute Pulmonary Embolism.   Please note that the case report provided is a probable scenario and is designed to guide medical educators in creating a case discussion for students on Acute Pulmonary Embolism. Other relevant topics to cover in the case discussion may include pathophysiology  risk factors  diagnostic tests (D-dimer  CT Pulmonary Angiogram)  treatment options (anticoagulation)  and prevention methods.

Patient Presentation:  Name: Mrs. Mitchell Age: 66 years old  Gender: Female Race: African American Occupation: Retired Nurse  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension - Well controlled on Losartan 50 mg daily for 10 years 2. Type 2 Diabetes - Under control with Metformin 500 mg Twice a day for 15 years 3. Remote history of Deep Venous Thrombosis (DVT) - 5 years ago  completed treatment with Warfarin 4. No known allergies  Key Complaints:  - Sudden onset sharp chest pain  rated 7/10  aggravated when taking deep breaths - Shortness of breath started simultaneously with chest pain - Mild dizziness  She denies any recent travel  surgery  or prolonged immobility. She also denied any symptoms suggestive of lower extremity DVTs such as unilateral calf pain or swelling. There is no reported cough  hemoptysis  or fever. She has not been taking her anticoagulant medication regularly due to the fear of bleeding complications.  Objective: This case is designed to instruct students on recognizing  diagnosing  and starting initial treatment in a patient presenting with acute pulmonary embolism in an emergency room setting. It is further intended to promote discussion on medication adherence and managing chronic health conditions to prevent medical emergencies.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: Name: David W. Gender: Male Age: 58 Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Accountant  Past Medical History: • Smoking history (20 pack-years) • Obesity (BMI: 32) • Hypertension • High cholesterol • No history of surgeries or blood clots  Presenting Complaints: David came to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath which has been progressively worsening over the past couple of hours. He also reported a feeling of tightness in his chest and occasional sharp chest pain  especially upon inspiration. He experienced light-headedness but denied any syncope or presyncope. No recent long travels or periods of prolonged immobility.  Initial Evaluation: At initial contact  David appeared quite anxious and diaphoretic. Vital signs revealed pulse rate 108 bpm  blood pressure 142/88 mmHg  respiratory rate 22 breaths/min  oxygen saturation 90% on room air. Physical examination otherwise unremarkable.  While this is just the initial presenting case  the subsequent training case should ideally include initial investigations like blood tests (D-Dimer)  imaging (CT Pulmonary Angiography)  and EKG  progressing on to the differential diagnosis  management  and prevention of the condition  to provide a comprehensive understanding of acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Information:  • Name: Jane Doe • Age: 55 years • Sex: Female  • Race: Caucasian • Occupation: Office Administrator  Patient History:  • Past Medical History: Jane has been managing her type II diabetes for the past ten years through a mixture of diet  regular exercise  and medication (Metformin). Jane's body mass index is 29  placing her in the overweight category. She has a history of sedentarism due to her long hours of desk work. Jane had a total knee replacement surgery six weeks ago following a sports injury.    • Family History: Jane's father was diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and her mother died due to an acute myocardial infarction at age 63.  • Social History: Jane is a non-smoker and occasional alcohol drinker. She lives alone  is currently on sick leave from work and is relatively inactive due to her recent surgery.  Key Complaints:  Jane visited the hospital emergency room experiencing sudden shortness of breath  sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breaths and occasional coughing producing blood-tinged sputum. She also reported a rapid heart rate  light-headedness  and sweating. Surgery had limited her physical activity lately  and she noted some swelling and a slight pain in her right calf  which she wrote off initially as post-operative changes.    These symptoms started occurring suddenly a few hours prior to hospital visitation. Jane had originally attributed it to her recovery process and only decided to seek immediate medical help as it worsened.   Remembered Case Summary: A 55-year-old woman with controlled Type II diabetes and a history of recent knee surgery presented to the ER with a sudden onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  cough with blood-tinged sputum  rapid heart rate  and symptoms suggestive of deep vein thrombosis.

Patient's Case Report  Patient Demographics: Name: Patient X Sex: Male Age: 57 years Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Office job  Past Medical History: Patient X has been dealing with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) for the last 6 years  managed by inhalers. He's also a current smoker with a 35-pack-year history. He was recently immobilized for 2 weeks following a hip fracture and surgery. His other medical records show that he is hypertensive and obese (BMI: 31.8). He doesn't have any known allergy.  Presenting Complaints: Patient X presented to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset severe chest pain that started two hours ago. The pain was sharp  localized on the right side of the chest  and aggravated with deep respiration  cough  and movements. He also reported shortness of breath  and mild hemoptysis. On further questioning  the patient shared experiencing a vague discomfort in his right calf.   Patient has a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure of 145/95 mmHg  oxygen saturation of 88% on room air  and a temperature of 37.4 degrees Celsius.  This case should trigger a differential diagnosis that includes acute pulmonary embolism. The subsequent discussions and examinations should focus on this diagnosis and its management.

Case Report:  Patient's Information: Name: [Anonymous] Age: 68 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Medical Background: The patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes and Hypertension. His diabetes is controlled by oral hypoglycemic agents and hypertension is controlled by ACE inhibitors. He is also a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago. The patient also experienced a right hip fracture two weeks ago and has been relatively immobile. He has been on prophylactic low molecular weight heparin.  Chief Complaints: The patient reported to the emergency department  complaining of sudden onset of breathlessness for the past 4 hours  accompanied by sharp  right-sided chest pain which is exacerbated by deep inspiration. He additionally reported a cough with blood-tinged sputum and the feeling of palpitations in his chest. He denies fever  chills  or recent illness.  Objective Assessment: On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious and breathless. His vital signs were noted to be BP: 155/95 mmHg  Pulse: 105 beats per minute with occasional missed beats  Respirations: 22 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation: 92% on room air. On auscultation  breath sounds were reduced in the right lower lung field and his heart rate was tachycardic. No murmurs were noted.  This hypothetical patient shows signs and symptoms that could align with an acute pulmonary embolism. The preceding major surgery and immobility  along with his other risk factors of age  hypertension  and history of smoking might have contributed to this condition  should it be the final diagnosis. It's recommended to further perform diagnostic tests including a D-dimer test  CT Pulmonary Angiography  or a ventilation/perfusion scan to confirm the condition.

Patient Information: Demographics: 65-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for 15 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for approximately 5 years. He's a former smoker  and he quit smoking a decade ago. He is on an oral medication regimen consisting of Metformin (for diabetes)  Lisinopril (for hypertension)  and Atorvastatin (for hyperlipidemia).  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents with gradual onset shortness of breath that has progressively worsened over the last two days. He describes the feeling as gasping for air even at rest. He also reported intermittent episodes of sharp  localized chest pain intensified by deep breathing. He denied any associated symptoms like fever  cough  syncope  palpitations  leg pain  or recent travel.   Description: This case presents acute pulmonary embolism. The patient's presenting symptoms combined with risk factors like age  history of smoking and potential poor blood circulation from diabetes and hypertension are suggestive. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis with methods such as a D-dimer test  CT pulmonary angiography  and possibly a V/Q scan depending on the patient's renal function. The purpose of this case is to teach medical students about recognizing the symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism and understanding the appropriate next steps for confirming diagnosis and treatment. Treatment considerations include anticoagulation  possibly thrombolysis  and addressing underlying risk factors to prevent recurrence.   Teaching points: 1. Importance of review of systems and past medical histories in patients with shortness of breath. 2. Understanding the risk factors for pulmonary embolism. 3. How to evaluate pulmonary embolism with various investigations. 4. Available treatment options for acute pulmonary embolism.   This case emphasizes the importance of considering potentially lethal differential diagnoses in patients presenting with common symptoms like shortness of breath.

Case Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Mrs. Ruth Davies  a 62-year-old Caucasian female  residing in the city suburbs. She is a non-smoker and teetotaller  retired schoolteacher living with her supportive husband. Of late  she has mentioned that her physical activity level has significantly dropped due to lingering tiredness.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Davies has a medical history of rheumatoid arthritis diagnosed 8 years ago  for which she has been taking a low-dose methotrexate and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) as required. She is obese with a BMI of 32 and was diagnosed with type II Diabetes controlled by diet and Metformin. She also has controlled hypertension on low-dose hydrochlorothiazide. In addition  there is a history of recent surgery  a total knee replacement  carried out a week ago. Mrs. Davies has familial history of thromboembolic diseases  with her late mother suffering from deep-vein thrombosis (DVT).  Key Complaints: Mrs. Davies presented to ER complaining of sudden onset dyspnea  sharp chest pain that worsens with deep breaths  and a feeling of light-headedness. She also mentioned having a dry cough. On a closer inquiry  Mrs. Davies also reported an unexpected swelling in her right calf muscle along with localized tenderness and redness – features that commenced post her orthopedic surgery a week ago but were written off as post-surgical effects. She has correlating symptoms such as tachycardia (110/min) and tachypnea cantered around 23 breaths/min.   Given Mrs. Davies's recent medical history and presenting complaints  this case was approached with a high index of suspicion towards Pulmonary Embolism (PE). Further assessment with diagnostic tests was suggested.

Case Report - Acute Pulaneous Embolism  Patient Information:  Name: John Doe Age: 63 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired school teacher Race: Caucasian  Smoking Status: Ex-smoker (quit 10 years ago) Alcohol Consumption: Moderate Physical Activity: Sedentary  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension  controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20 mg daily) 2. Previous DVT (Deep Vein Thrombosis) event 5 years ago  managed with anticoagulant therapy 3. Type 2 diabetes (on Metformin 500mg twice daily) 4. 3-vessel CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting) performed eight years ago  Presenting Complaints:  John presented to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of:  1. Shortness of breath on exertion  2. Chest pain  which he describes as a 'heavy pressure' sensation  3. Some degree of light-headedness 4. Periodic coughing with blood-tinged sputum 5. Mild leg swelling and discomfort   Clinical Note:  Mr. Doe's previous history of DVT  along with his presenting symptoms  particularly the acute onset of shortness of breath  chest pain  and hemoptysis  raises a high suspicion of Acute Pulmonary Embolism (PE). His other comorbidities including hypertension  Type 2 diabetes  and coronary artery disease further increase his risk. Hence  immediate action towards diagnosis and management should be embarked upon with high suspicion for acute PE. This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing the signs and symptoms of PE  particularly in patients with a history of DVT or other hypercoagulable states. As future doctors  a high index of clinical suspicion and prompt management can often significantly improve the prognosis in such critical cases.
