Case Report:  Patient Information:   - Sex: Female - Age: 67 - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired teacher  Past Medical History:   - Patient has a history of breast cancer  post-operative for a mastectomy 6 years ago with subsequent chemotherapy and radiation treatment.  - Currently  on hormone therapy (Tamoxifen) as part of her cancer treatment plan. - History of hypertension managed by Lisinopril. - No history of DVT/PE. - No significant family history of clotting disorders. - Non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally and has a sedentary lifestyle.  Key complaints:   The patient arrived at the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath  chest pain that increases with deep inspiration and mild coughing. She rates the pain as 7 on a scale of 10. She also mentioned feeling faint and having a rapid heartbeat since the morning. She denies any recent travelling  surgery or prolonged immobilisation.  Post-edit: No documented medication  drug allergies.   As this is a training case  it's important to note that the history of breast cancer  hormone therapy and sedentary lifestyle are significant risk factors for Pulmonary Embolism. This patient does present with typical symptoms of PE such as shortness of breath  pleuritic chest pain  and palpitations. In absence of other explanations  suspect pulmonary embolism and proceed towards relevant investigation and treatment. It's also crucial to remember that PE might present with atypical symptoms and signs such as isolated syncope  seizures  fever  productive cough and so on.

Case Report: Acute Pulinary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Name: Ms. Maria Smith Age: 57 years Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: High school teacher Location: Urban  Past Medical History: Ms. Smith has been recently diagnosed with Type II diabetes and is currently on oral hypoglycemic agents. She is also hypertensive and has been taking medication for the past 10 years. She has been a smoker of 1 pack/day for 35 years. She underwent an uncomplicated total knee replacement surgery one week ago.  Presenting Symptoms: Ms. Smith presents with sudden onset of chest pain  which she describes as sharp and stabbing  worse on deep inspiration. She also reports shortness of breath and a mild cough. Over the past 24 hours  she has been increasingly anxious due to her symptoms. There is no history of fever  hemoptysis  or leg swelling.  Physical Examination: Vital Signs: BP - 150/90 mmHg  Pulse - 110/min  RR - 24/min  Temp - 98.6°F. On examination  she appears anxious and breathless. There is decreased breath sound in the right lower zone of the lungs. No palpable leg swelling or tenderness.  Impression: Given the patient's recent surgery  sudden onset of chest pain  and breathlessness  acute pulmonary embolism is highly suspicious and needs to be ruled out. This case provides an excellent opportunity to explore topics related to risk factors  diagnosis  and management of acute pulmonary embolism.

Patient Information: Mr. Smith  a 60-year-old Caucasian male. Occupation: Office worker  mostly sedentary work life.  Past Medical History: Five years ago  he had undergone right total knee arthroplasty due to severe osteoarthritis. He has hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus which are well-controlled by medication. He is a former smoker (quit 10 years ago). His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases. He maintains a BMI of 32  classified as obese.  Present Complaint: Mr. Smith presents to the emergency department (ED) with acute onset of chest pain and shortness of breath that started a few hours ago. He describes his chest pain as a sharp  stabbing type  which worsens upon deep inspiration. He also reported experiencing mild episodes of dizziness.   He was noted to have a recent period of immobilization due to a broken ankle  which had him on bed rest for a week. No signs of infection  cough  or hemoptysis.  On physical examination: He appears anxious and diaphoretic (sweating excessively). Vital signs show a respiratory rate of 24 breaths/minute  oxygen saturation 92% on room air  heart rate 110 beats/minute  blood pressure 145/85 mmHg. Lung auscultation reveals normal breath sounds bilaterally  cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia  mild ankle edema is observed.   Based on the above history and examination findings  acute pulmonary embolism should be highly suspected. Emphasize on the risk factors of the patient which are obesity  recent immobilization  history of surgery  and age. Further confirmatory tests such as D-dimer  computed tomography pulmonary angiography (CTPA) or a V/Q scan should be done to establish the diagnosis to facilitate prompt treatment.

Patient Demographics:  Patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired construction worker. He lives with his wife and dog in suburban Chicago. He is an occasional smoker with a pack per day for 25 years and drinks alcohol socially.   Past Medical History:  Patient has a known history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) after a right knee replacement surgery two years ago. He was put on an anticoagulant for 6 months  which he completed. He has also been diagnosed with hypertension and Type II diabetes  both of which are reasonably well controlled with lifestyle modifications and medication. This patient also has a family history of coagulation disorders - his mother had Protein C deficiency.   Presenting Complaints:  The patient presents at the emergency department with sudden-onset shortness of breath for two hours now. He describes it as a 'heavy feeling' in his chest. He also reports experiencing mild chest pain  which he describes as more of a 'discomfort' rather than distinct pain. He denies any symptoms of cough  fever  or hemoptysis. But he mentions becoming increasingly aware of a fast heart rate over the last two hours. He also mentions moderate to severe pain and swelling in his right calf  which he noticed a day back but dismissed as ""muscle pain.""

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: - Name: James Atkins - Age: 48-years-old - Sex: Male - Race: African American - Occupation: Truck driver  Past Medical History: Mr. Atkins is a smoker with a 20-pack per year history and has been previously diagnosed with hypertension which is managed with medication (Lisinopril 20 mg daily). He is overweight (BMI 28.3) and has a family history of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism on his maternal side. He has never had a personal history of venous thromboembolism. No known allergies. He rarely exercises and spends the majority of his time sitting  either while working or at home.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Atkins presented to the emergency department in the early hours with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath  which started about two hours prior. He also reports feeling lightheaded and faint. He denies fever  cough  or hemoptysis. He said his chest pain is sharp  located at the center of the chest  and worsens with deep breaths. He rated his pain as 7 out of 10. He did not experience any alleviating or aggravating factors.   Given Mr. Atkins' risk factors  symptoms suggestive of pleuritic chest pain  and the episodic nature of his symptoms  acute pulmonary embolism should be high on the differential diagnosis list. This training case will focus on recognizing the symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism  understanding the risk factors  and managing the case with appropriate treatment plans.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. A. Smith  a 68 year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency room.  Past Medical History: He has a known medical history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) one year prior  hypertension for the past 10 years  and atrial fibrillation diagnosed six months ago. He is on Warfarin for atrial fibrillation  Lisinopril for hypertension  and previously completed a course of anticoagulants post DVT diagnosis.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith is reporting sudden onset of shortness of breath that started earlier in the day. The patient describes it as feeling out of breath even with minimal exertion. Along with this  he also mentions a sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsens with deep breaths. He reports being lightheaded and an episode of fainting at home.  On querying further  he says he had recently completed a long car journey (around 12 hours) with minimal breaks for leg movements. He denies any cough  hemoptysis  fever  or leg swelling.  With this case  students should be made to consider an acute pulmonary embolism with differential diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome  aortic dissection  and pneumonia. Diagnostic procedures  treatment protocols  and prevention methods should be emphasized. Clinical reasoning and decision-making skills should be honed during the discussion of this case.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mrs. Smith  Age / Gender: 65-year-old woman  Ethnicity: Caucasian   Occupation: Retired teacher  Past Medical History:  - Hypertension  managed with ACE inhibitors. - Smoking history of two packs daily for 35 years.  - Recent laparoscopic total abdominal hysterectomy secondary to uterine fibroids  2 weeks ago.  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Smith presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset shortness of breath which has worsened over the last few hours. She also complains of pleuritic chest pain which increases in intensity upon coughing and deep inspiration. She denies experiencing any recent trauma.  She also mentions the observation of streaks of blood in her sputum once this morning. She reports a sudden-onset sharp  stabbing pain in her chest and palpitations. She expresses concern due to her lack of appetite  feeling weak and an unusual sense of looming anxiety.  No headaches  visual changes  slurring of speech  difficulty in understanding or expressing speech  or facial asymmetry have been reported indicating ruling out a cerebrovascular accident. No swelling  tenderness or redness over legs reported which might specify deep vein thrombosis.   Family History:  - Her mother died due to myocardial infarction at the age of 70.  - Her father survived a stroke in his 60s.   Physical Exam upon admission: - Vital signs: BP= 150/90 mmHg  HR= 110bpm  RR= 30 breaths per minute  SpO2= 88% on room air. - On general physical examination  she appears anxious. She is in acute distress  sitting upright in bed and breathing through pursed lips.  - Oxygen saturation is low despite having no history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.  - On auscultation  breath sounds are normal with no crepitations or wheezes.  - Heart sounds are normal with no murmurs  rubs or gallops. - No lower limb swelling or redness is noticed.   This case study should provoke further investigations including arterial blood gas analysis  chest radiograph  electrocardiogram  D-dimer  and possibility of imaging for suspected pulmonary embolism such as a CT Pulmonary Angiogram. Students should consider the likelihood of PE given her recent surgery  smoking history  and the sudden onset of symptoms. The teaching case can also educate students about the importance of prophylaxis in high-risk patients to prevent such acute incidents.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: Mr. Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department. He is a retired school teacher  non-smoker with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus (managed through oral hypoglycemic agents) and obesity (BMI 30.5 kg/m2). He has no family history of clotting disorders. His only medication is metformin.  Key Complaints: He complains of chest discomfort of sudden onset  shortness of breath  and feeling lightheaded. He also reports a productive cough with blood-tinged sputum for the past few hours. Further inquiry reveals that Mr. Smith took a 12-hour flight about 72 hours ago  following which he has been mostly bedridden due to jet lag and fatigue. He has not reported any chest pain  palpitations  syncope  or other cardiac symptoms.  Assessment: Vital signs on admission are BP: 125/80 mmHg  HR: 110 bpm  RR: 25/min  and Temp: 37.2°C. He is anxious with noticeable diaphoresis. Initial physical examination reveals tachypnea and decreased breath sounds on the left side of his chest  with mild-to-moderate cyanosis of the lips and fingertips. There are no evident signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) such as leg swelling or pain on palpation.   This preliminary information is suggestive of acute pulmonary embolism  commonly associated with prolonged immobility such as a recent long-haul flight. Further investigations  including D-dimer tests  CT pulmonary angiography  and arterial blood gas study  would aid in confirming the diagnosis and initiating the most appropriate treatment regimen.  Considerations for discussion and learning points among medical students include risk factors for pulmonary embolism  understanding of Virchow’s triad  diagnostic process  medical and surgical treatment options  and preventive measures for patients at risk.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Mendoza Age: 55 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Hispanic Occupation: Software Engineer  Past Medical History: - Type 2 diabetes mellitus (7 years  well controlled on metformin) - Essential hypertension (5 years  managed with lisinopril) - Former smoker (quit 10 years ago)  - No known drug allergies - No previous surgeries - Family history positive for deep vein thrombosis in a sibling  Key Complaints: Mr. Mendoza visited the emergency department with the following complaints: - Sudden onset shortness of breath that started a few hours ago - Sharp  stabbing chest pain with deep inspiration - Light-headedness - Mild hemoptysis (blood-tinged sputum) - Recent history of swelling and pain in the right lower leg - He mentioned a prolonged period of immobility due to a recent cross-country business road trip  As the case proceeds  medical students should consider acute pulmonary embolism as a part of their differential diagnosis given the patient's recent history of long-distance travel  leg symptoms and acute onset shortness of breath. The learning objectives should focus on understanding risk factors for pulmonary embolism  learning to recognize the key clinical features  and how to initiate its diagnostic workup and management.

Patient Information:  NAME: Mr. John Doe   AGE: 62 years old  SEX: Male  ETHNICITY: Caucasian  OCCUPATION: Retired accountant  CASE DESCRIPTION:  Mr. John Doe  a 62-year-old retired accountant  presents to the ER with the main complaint of a sudden onset chest pain that started about 2 hours prior. He describes the pain as sharp and occurring mainly on the left side of his chest  and it worsens with deep breathing. He denies pressure-like pain that spreads to the arms  neck  jaw  or back. Along with chest pain  Mr. Doe also reports a recent episode of shortness of breath and moderate dizziness.  Over the past four days  he also noted a mild  intermittent cough with rust-colored mucus. He noticed some leg swelling on his left leg  mainly in the calf area  which has been seemingly persistent over the past week. He reports no hemoptysis  fevers  chills  or recent traumas  and no symptoms of upper respiratory infections.  Mr. Doe is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago with a 40-pack-year history prior to cessation. His past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are well-controlled with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. Mr. Doe also had an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his left leg about five years ago after a long haul flight. His records indicate he had completed treatment with Warfarin at the time. He reports no known drug allergies.  He lives with his wife  their dog  and he enjoys gardening and short walks around the neighborhood for physical activity. His diet is balanced  but he admits to indulging in high-sodium and high-cholesterol foods occasionally. He reports moderate alcohol consumption  equivalent to 2-3 glasses of wine per week. He denies any illicit substance usage.  Mr. Doe's family history is significant for heart disease. His father had coronary artery disease and underwent a bypass surgery at the age of 68. His mother was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation in her late 70s. His older brother has been recently diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.   Given his symptoms and personal and family medical history  acute pulmonary embolism could be a strong part of the differential diagnosis. Further diagnostic procedures must be conducted to confirm or reject the hypothesis  and to rule out any similar conditions.

Patient Information:  • Initials: J.D. • Gender: Female • Age: 67 years old • Ethnicity: African American  Past Medical History:   • Hypertension • Type 2 diabetes • Former smoker (quit 15 years ago; smoked 1 pack a day for 25 years) • Recent right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a long-haul flight; treated with a course of anticoagulants  but did not complete her medication regimen  Presenting Complaints:   J.D. presented to the emergency department with sudden onset of sharp  right-sided chest pain that is worse on deep inhalation. She reported feeling unwell for the past few days with slight cough and shortness of breath that she attributed to her usual bouts of bronchitis. However  over the past several hours  she noticed that the shortness of breath had worsened and she felt faint. She also mentioned sudden onset of increased heart rate.  Key Points to cover during case discussion:  In this case scenario  the student should recognize the urgency of J.D.'s condition and consider acute pulmonary embolism in the differential diagnosis due to her recent history of DVT  symptoms of pleuritic chest pain  shortness of breath  and tachycardia.  The training case may also emphasize the importance of a therapeutic relationship with patients concerning medication compliance  as J.D.'s decision to discontinue her anticoagulation medication could be a contributing factor to her current predicament.  This case provides an opportunity for students to discuss the pathophysiology of PE  risk factors  how a DVT can lead to a PE  the importance of patient history  and appropriate diagnostic tests (like a D-dimer test  chest CT angiogram  ultrasound of the legs) and treatment options for acute pulmonary embolism.   It's important to also discuss the differential diagnoses for a patient presenting shortness of breath  chest pain and cough like pneumonia  pneumothorax  lung cancer  asthma  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Case Study: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Information: Name: Ms. Walters  Age: 62 years Sex: Female Ethnicity: African-American  Occupation: Retired School Teacher  Presenting Issue: Ms. Walters presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that started two hours ago. The pain is sharp  localized on the right side of the chest  and gets worse with deep breaths. She also complains of some unusual leg swelling for the past few days.   Past Medical History: Ms. Walter has a history of atrial fibrillation for which she takes Aspirin. She underwent orthopedic surgery on her left knee six weeks ago and post-surgery  was immobilized for a period of two weeks. She admits to not being very active since the surgery. Her medication list also includes Atorvastatin for dyslipidemia  Metformin for type II diabetes  and Ramipril for hypertension. She does not drink or smoke and has no known drug allergies.  Potential Diagnosis: Considering Ms. Walters' recent orthopedic surgery  immobilisation  current symptoms and medical history  these findings suggest a high probability of an acute pulmonary embolism. However  further diagnostic procedures must be carried out to confirm this diagnosis.  This case can be used to further discuss diagnosing methods such as D-dimer assays  CT pulmonary angiography  and ventilation/perfusion scanning. There should also be discussions about potential treatment options  including anticoagulants and thrombolytic therapy  and the patient's prognosis.  The case also provides an opportunity to discuss risk factors for pulmonary embolism  such as recent surgery  immobilisation  atrial fibrillation  and the use of estrogen-containing medication. It would be crucial to discuss the importance of early detection and treatment of this condition to prevent life-threatening complications such as a stroke or organ damage due to lack of blood flow.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   A 58-year-old African-American male presented to the emergency department.   Past Medical History:   The patient has known hypertension controlled with medication for the past 7 years. Besides that  the patient had a surgery for a bilateral total hip replacement two months ago. He has been relatively sedentary during his post-operative recovery period. He is a smoker with a 30 pack-year history. The patient's mother had a history of deep vein thrombosis.  Chief Complaints:   The patient describes a sudden onset of sharp  right-sided chest pain that started a few hours ago. He notes that the pain becomes worse with deep breaths. He also reports experiencing episodes of light-headedness and rapid heartbeat. Since yesterday  he has been feeling short of breath even while at rest. No symptoms of a cough  hemoptysis  fever  or sweating were noted. He has not traveled long-distance recently.  Assessment:   Vital signs on presentation demonstrate a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  pulse 110 beats/min  respirations 20/min  and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. On physical examination  he appears anxious but is not in acute respiratory distress. There is tachycardia but no murmurs  rubs or gallops on cardiac auscultation. Pulmonary examination reveals tachypnea  but lung auscultation shows clear and equal breath sounds bilaterally with no evidence of consolidation; no leg swelling or calf tenderness noted.  From these  there are multiple risk factors - recent hip surgery and associated reduction in mobility  smoking  and family history of thrombosis. Curtain index of suspicion leans towards an acute pulmonary embolism. Further diagnostic procedures should be performed to confirm.   Key Learning Points:   Acute pulmonary embolism can occur in individuals with risk factors such as prolonged immobilization  recent surgeries  smoking  and individuals with family histories of thromboembolic diseases. Symptoms may include sudden-onset chest pain  shortness of breath  tachypnea  and signs of deep vein thrombosis. Management of such patients includes ruling out other conditions like acute myocardial infarction and aortic dissection  confirming the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism through imaging studies  and initiating appropriate treatment strategies.

Patient Information: A 64-year-old African-American male named Mr. Brown.  Past Medical History: Mr. Brown has a past medical history significant for obesity  hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and a recent total hip arthroplasty performed 10 days ago.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Brown came in to the ER complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath that started approximately 2 hours ago. He describes the dyspnea as being progressive and now feels that he can't catch his breath  even at rest. Furthermore  he voices that he started feeling a sharp pain on the left side of his chest that is worsening when he takes deep breaths. He denies any cough  fever  or palpitations.  Other Relevant Information: Mr. Brown stopped his blood-thinning medicine three days ago due to some minor post-surgery bleeding. He has been less mobile since the operation  largely confined to bed. He denies cigarette smoking or any drug use but admits to moderate alcohol intake. He has a family history of deep vein thrombosis with his father.  Objective Data: On examination  he is anxious and mildly diaphoretic. He has tachycardia and tachypnea. His blood pressure is normal but his oxygen saturation is on the lower side of normal on room air.   Further evaluation and workup needs to be done as his patient profile suggests possible acute pulmonary embolism. A high index of suspicion for acute pulmonary embolism is important in this case due to the patient's recent surgery and immobility  coupled with his sudden onset of breathlessness and chest pain.   Training objectives:  1. Understand the risk factors  pathophysiology  presentations  and complications of acute pulmonary embolism. 2. Understand how to differentiate pulmonary embolism from other causes of chest pain and shortness of breath.  3. Obtain skills in performing an appropriate history  examination  and diagnostic workup for a patient with suspected pulmonary embolism. 4. Develop a management plan for a patient with pulmonary embolism  including immediate stabilization and long-term management.  5. Help students understand the importance of preventive measures such as pre and post-surgical prophylaxis.

Patient Information:   - Age: 56 years  - Gender: Female  - Occupation: Librarian  - Ethnicity: Caucasian   Past Medical History:   - Patient has been in overall good health.  - Personal history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) following a knee replacement surgery five years ago.  - Current medication includes daily aspirin.  - Ex-smoker  quit 15 years ago - Family history of heart disease and stroke.  Presenting Complaints:  - Patient arrived at the emergency department complaining of sudden onset shortness of breath which started approximately an hour ago. - Patient rated her pain as 8/10 on the pain scale. - No known triggering factor was identified.  - She also noted the sudden onset of chest pain  describing it as sharp and intensifying with deep breaths. - Review of symptoms also revealed mild dizziness and a sense of fatigue for the last two days. - No signs of fever or cough.   Physical Examination:  - Vital signs showed tachypnea (respiratory rate around 22 breaths/min) and tachycardia (heart rate around 110 bpm).  - Oxygen saturation was observed to be 92% on room air.  - No abnormalities were noted in the lung and cardiac auscultation.   This concise case sets the stage for a differential diagnosis that should include acute pulmonary embolism (PE)  based on the patient's risk factors (post-surgery history of DVT)  age  and symptoms  but also considering other potential diagnoses such as acute coronary syndrome  pneumothorax  pneumonia or even a panic attack. Appropriate lab tests  imaging  and management should follow this initial clinical approach. Students should utilize a decision-making model such as Well's criteria for PE  or the Pulmonary embolism rule-out criteria (PERC)  to guide their actions.

Patient Information:  - Demographics: 58-year-old African American male - Occupation: Works as a long-distance truck driver  - Past medical history: Hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  smoker (20 pack-years) - Medication: Lisinopril  Metformin  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presents to the emergency department complaining of progressive shortness of breath and chest pain that started suddenly a day ago while sitting in his truck. He describes his chest pain as a constant sharp stabbing pain  situated centrally and radiating to his jaws. The pain increases with deep breath and coughing. He also reports feeling lightheaded and mentions a near syncopal episode. He denied any recent surgeries  leg pain or swelling. He has no known allergies. He has no family history of blood clots. He reports being generally sedentary during his job  often sitting for long periods during his cross-country drives  and he admits to not keeping his diabetes and hypertension under good control.  On physical examination: - Vital Signs: BP 145/95 mmHg  HR 115 bpm  RR 22 breaths/min  Temperature 98.1°F  Oxygen saturation on room air 88%   - Appearance: Diaphoretic  seems anxious - Chest: Decreased breath sounds on the left side with mild crackles - Cardiovascular: Tachycardic  regular rhythm  no murmur - Extremities: No edema  no calf tenderness  pulses intact. - Other: Rest of physical exam normal   Given the patient’s presenting symptoms  risk factors  and clinical status  acute pulmonary embolism should be highly suspected. Further investigations such as D-dimer  chest imaging  and possibly CT pulmonary angiography should be done for confirmation of diagnosis. This case allows discussion and learning about risk factors  pathophysiology  clinical presentation  diagnosis  and management of acute pulmonary embolism. It also highlights the importance of preventive measures in high-risk individuals.

Patient Profile:  Name: Jane Smith Age: 64 Sex: Female  Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired school teacher Residential Status: Lives with husband in a suburban home  Past Medical History: - Long-term smoker for 40 years - Diagnosed with diabetes mellitus type II (on oral hypoglycemic agents) - History of total left hip replacement 5 weeks ago - No known allergies  Current Complaint: The patient was brought to the ER complaining of sudden to right side chest pain which began around 2 hours ago while she was reading a book. She describes the pain as sharp  constant and worsening with inspiration. She also reports progressive shortness of breath. She denies cough  fever  or recent travel. She hasn't had any emission of blood in sputum.  Her heart rate is rapid with mild swelling noted in the ankle region  and she is evidently anxious. On auscultation  heart sounds turn out to be tachycardic with no obvious murmurs. Oxygen saturation is 92% on room air.  Comments on the case: The mentioned case is designed to help students correlate clinical findings with acute pulmonary embolism. The case highlights some of the common risk factors associated with PE  including prolonged immobilization after hip replacement surgery  the presence of diabetes  and a history of long-term smoking. The symptom of sudden onset dyspnea and pleuritic chest pain also aligns with features typically seen in PE. The learning outcome for students here should be recognizing the signs and symptoms of acute PE and understanding the importance of immediate diagnostic evaluation.

Case Report: Acute Pulmonary Embolism  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian female named Mrs. Johnson  who is a former school teacher.  Past Medical History: Mrs. Johnson's medical history reveals she has hypertension  obesity with a BMI of 32  and type II diabetes mellitus that is well controlled with metformin. She had a knee replacement surgery 4 weeks ago and has been slightly immobile since then.  Key Complaints: Mrs. Johnson presented to the emergency department with sudden onset shortness of breath that started a few hours ago  accompanied by a mild-sharp pain in her chest that increases with deep breaths. She's also complained about feeling faint and has a persistent  dry cough. She denies any recent trauma  vomiting  palpitations  diaphoresis  or fever. She has not had any recent travel history but has been under deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis since her surgery.  Soon after this  I'll need a comprehensive approach summarizing the diagnostic tests and management that medical students should follow in this case.

Case Title: Acute Pulmonary Embolism in a Post-Operative Female Patient  Patient Information: - Age: 65 years old - Gender: Female - Occupation: Retired teacher - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Chief Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that started around two hours ago. She characterized the pain as sharp and stabbing  exacerbated by deep inhaling  and not associated with any particular body posture.   Past Medical History: The patient underwent total hip replacement surgery three weeks ago. She has a 15-year history of hypertension  controlled with losartan. She also has type 2 diabetes  managed with metformin  and hyperlipidemia  treated with atorvastatin. She is a non-smoker with a body mass index of 32. She lives alone but has a support network in the form of her two adult children who live nearby. She has no known drug allergies.  Pre-Existing Conditions: 1. Hypertension 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 3. Hyperlipidemia 4. Obesity  Past Surgical History:  1. Right total hip replacement 3 weeks ago  Medication History:  1. Losartan 50mg OD  2. Metformin 1000mg BID 3. Atorvastatin 20mg HS   Presumptive Diagnosis: Considering sudden onset of symptoms  history of recent surgery and pre-existing conditions favoring hypercoagulability  a presumptive diagnosis of Acute Pulmonary Embolism is made.  Additional Comments: The context provided here allows students to apply their understanding of risk factors  presentation  and management for suspected acute pulmonary embolism. The insights that can be gained from this case are significant  particularly in understanding how underlying medical conditions and recent surgical history contribute to the prevalence of a life-threatening condition such as pulmonary embolism.

Patient Profile:  Name: Jane Doe Age: 68 Gender: Female Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Teacher   Medical History: Ms. Doe has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and had right total knee arthroplasty surgery 10 days ago. She has no known drug allergies and takes Losartan and Atorvastatin daily.   Presenting Complaints:  Ms. Doe presents with sudden onset chest pain  shortness of breath  and palpitations that began earlier today. The chest pain is pleuritic  sharp in nature and increases when taking deep breaths. She has noticed a mild cough but denies hemoptysis  fever  or recent illness.  She reports an overall feeling of anxiety  light-headedness and restlessness. She also reports difficulty in getting around after her recent surgery due to leg pain and limited mobility.  Physical Analysis: On physical examination  Ms. Doe appears anxious. Vital signs demonstrate tachypnea (RR: 24/min) and tachycardia (HR: 110 bpm). Oxygen saturation was found to be 92% on room air. She has a regular rhythm without murmur on heart auscultation. Lungs have decreased breath sounds in the lower right quadrant without crackles or wheezes. Lower extremities show slight swelling of the right calf that is tender to touch  with no discoloration or warmth.  These symptoms are consistent with a suspected acute pulmonary embolism  possibly a post-operative complication. For confirmation and further investigation  a D-dimer test and imaging such as a CT pulmonary angiography should be considered.  Educational Objectives: 1. Recognize the signs and symptoms of acute pulmonary embolism. 2. Understand the importance of taking a thorough history  focusing on recent surgeries  immobilization  or other risk factors for venous thromboembolism. 3. Identify the key diagnostic tests needed to confirm a suspected diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism.  4. Understand the importance of starting immediate anticoagulation therapy when acute pulmonary embolism is suspected. 5. Identify the importance of measures to prevent pulmonary embolism post-surgery.  6. Understand the potential complications and mortality associated with acute pulmonary embolism if not diagnosed and treated promptly.

Case Presentation:   Patient Information: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 52 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Accountant  Chief Complaint: Mr. Doe presents with sudden onset of shortness of breath and sharp  stabbing chest pain that worsened with deep breathing.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has been hypertensive for the last 10 years managed with a regimen of Lisinopril. He is a former smoker (10 pack-years) but quit 5 years ago. He is moderately overweight (BMI 27) and lacks regular physical activity. Patient has no known allergies.  Family History: His father had coronary artery disease and died from a heart attack at the age of 60. His mother is alive and has type 2 diabetes.  Social History: Mr. Doe lives alone  denies illicit drug use  and admits to occasional alcohol consumption. He has a sedentary lifestyle with a desk job and admits to long stretches of sitting while at work.  Recent History: The patient recently returned from an international business trip that involved a long-haul flight (12 hours).  Review of System: Patient also reports light-headedness  faintness  rapid heart rate but denies fever  cough  or hemoptysis.  In the context of the patient's recent long-haul flight and his presentation of shortness of breath and chest pain  a high index of suspicion should be maintained for conditions such as pulmonary embolism. Students should be encouraged to immediately order diagnostic tests  including D-dimer  CT Pulmonary angiography  and ECG. Treatment should be started considering the severity of the patient's presentation immediately after diagnosis confirmation.

Case Report  Patient Information: Mrs. Smith is a 57-year-old obese Caucasian female.  Past Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. She is a former smoker who quit 20 years ago and has no known drug allergies. She underwent a total knee replacement surgery 3 weeks ago and has been relatively immobile post-op.  Presenting Complaints: Mrs. Smith was brought to the Emergency Department by her family after experiencing sudden onset of severe chest pain  shortness of breath  and cough. She also reported feeling dizzy and sweaty and had fainting spells.   The patient mentioned that she had been having occasional pain and swelling in her right calf over the past week  but she did not seek medical attention as it was minor and she thought it was due to her recent surgery.  Family History: The patient's father had died following a massive heart attack in his early sixties and her mother had a stroke in her late sixties.  Observations: Initial physical examination showed tachycardia and ECG revealed right ventricular strain suggesting pulmonary hypertension. She also had decreased breath sounds on the right side. The swelling observed in her right calf was tender and warm to touch. She was hypoxic with oxygen saturation of 86% on room air.   Clinical Decision: Given her clinical presentation and risk factors (recent surgery  immobility  obesity  and family history)  a working diagnosis of acute pulmonary embolism was considered.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired college professor  currently living alone  is a former smoker with a 20-year pack history.  Past Medical History: He has a medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  hypercholesterolemia  and was sporadically taking aspirin. He underwent a total knee replacement three weeks ago. There is no family history of cardiovascular diseases  coagulative disorders or cancers.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presents to the emergency department with severe sudden onset dyspnea that started three hours prior to his arrival. He also reports pleuritic chest pain intensified with deep breaths  but no cough  fever  hemoptysis  or recent trauma. He describes intermittent episodes of lightheadedness which was considered as post-surgical condition but without syncope.  On admission  he was found to be tachycardic with a heart rate of 110 bpm  borderline hypotensive with a blood pressure of 95/60 mmHg  and tachypneic at 25 breaths per minute. His oxygen saturation was 90% on room air which improved to 98% on 3L of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula.  On physical examination  no leg pain  swelling  or signs of deep vein thrombosis were noted. The heart sound was tachycardic but regular without murmur  and lung auscultation was clear. The patient was reportedly anxious with cold sweat  but without cyanosis.  This case can be used to teach medical students about the signs  symptoms  and management of acute pulmonary embolism  as well as the time-sensitive nature of treatment and importance of a thorough history and physical examination in leading to a correct diagnosis. This case also highlights the importance of understanding risk factors such as surgery and immobility.

Patient Information:   Mr. George Simmons is a 65-year-old African American male with a height of 6 feet and weighs 82 kg. He is a retired bank manager  a non-smoker  and occasionally indulges in alcohol during social events. He lives with his wife in an urban setting and does not have children.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Simmons has been managing hypertension and diabetes Mellitus type II for the past 10 years using medication. He had a total right knee replacement 4 weeks ago due to severe osteoarthritis. His immediate post-operative period had been uneventful and he was discharged to home with appropriate follow-up appointments. She does not have any known allergies.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Simmons came to the Emergency Department complaining of sudden  sharp  right-sided chest pain that started 5 hours ago  aggravated by deep breaths and coughing. He also reports an episode of hemoptysis. His wife mentions that he was feeling a bit short of breath for the past 48 hours but they thought it might be because of his increased focus on exercise as part of his post-operative knee rehabilitation.   He also reported feeling a bit dizzy at times but does not have syncope  seizures  or confusion. He denies any abdominal pain  urinary symptoms  limb numbness/weakness  rash  recent sick contacts  or recent travel.  Vital Signs upon arrival:   BP: 155/90 mmHg Pulse: 110/min Respiratory Rate: 22/min Temperature: 98.6 F Oxygen Saturation: 92% on room air  Suspected Diagnosis:   With these symptoms and history  suspicion is high for Acute Pulmonary Embolism. Further diagnostic tests are needed to confirm this diagnosis.

Case Report:  Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American male.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (DM2) and hypertension (HTN). He was operated for right hip replacement two weeks ago. He was a smoker but quit 4 years ago.  Chief Complaint: The patient comes in complaining of a sudden onset of shortness of breath and chest pain that worsens with deep breaths.   History of Present Illness: The pain started suddenly about 2 hours ago. It is described as stabbing  radiating to the jaw and left shoulder. It's a 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. He denies having any associated symptoms like nausea or sweating. He denies cough  fever  chills  weight loss  leg pain  or swelling.   These symptoms are concerning for acute pulmonary embolism especially after the recent orthopedic surgery and history of prolonged immobility.  Plan: The patients require immediate attention. Clinical examination  chest X-Ray  ECG  and other laboratory investigations should be conducted  including D-Dimer test. CTA Chest or V/Q scan should be considered for definitive diagnosis. Life-saving measures such as Oxygen supplementation  anticoagulant therapy  and cardiorespiratory support should be initiated promptly  if necessary. If confirmed  the case discussions could revolve around long-term thromboprophylaxis and lifestyle modifications for this patient based on patient factors and other comorbid conditions.
